         <tei:p>Afro tropical jumping plant lice<tei:lb/>of the family Triozidae<tei:lb/>(Homoptera: Psylloidea)</tei:p>

      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>The Bulletin of the British Museum (Natural History), instituted in 1949, is issued in four<tei:lb/>scientific series, Botany, Entomology, Geology (incorporating Mineralogy) and Zoology,<tei:lb/>and an Historical series.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Papers in the Bulletin are primarily the results of research carried out on the unique and<tei:lb/>ever-growing collections of the Museum, both by the scientific staff of the Museum and by<tei:lb/>specialists from elsewhere who make use of the Museum's resources. Many of the papers are<tei:lb/>works of reference that will remain indispensable for years to come.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Parts are published at irregular intervals as they become ready, each is complete in itself,<tei:lb/>available separately, and individually priced. Volumes contain about 300 pages and several<tei:lb/>volumes may appear within a calendar year. Subscriptions may be placed for one or more of<tei:lb/>the series on either an Annual or Per Volume basis. Prices vary according to the contents of<tei:lb/>the individual parts. Orders and enquiries should be sent to:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>t \S H ^^Publications Sales</tei:p>

         <tei:p>j</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Museum (Natural History),<tei:lb/>Cromwell Road,</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Afrotropical jumping plant lice of the famil<tei:lb/>Triozidae (Homoptera: Psylloidea)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BRITISH MU:</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Index 101</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Synopsis</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The family Triozidae is defined within the context of the superfamily Psylloidea. A list is given of the genera<tei:lb/>included in the family, on a world basis, with type-species and a summary of numbers of species, their<tei:lb/>distribution and host plant data. The family-group name Pauropsyllinae is placed within the Triozidae,<tei:lb/>necessitating the transfer of Paurocephala back to the Aphalaridae and Microceropsylla and Pelmato-<tei:lb/>brachia to the Calophyidae, and seven new combinations. The genus-group name Sympauropsylla is<tei:lb/>synonymised with Pauropsylla. A checklist of Afrotropical taxa is given, with host plant and distribution<tei:lb/>data, and a key is provided for the identification of the 69 recognisable species. Two of the eight previously<tei:lb/>described species are treated as doubtful because their types are lost or untraced and the species cannot be<tei:lb/>recognised from their original descriptions; Trioza eastopi Orian is synonymised with T. litseae Bordage;<tei:lb/>one new genus and 63 new species are described.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bull. Br. Mus. nat. Hist. (Ent.) 49 (1): 1-102 Issued 28 June 1984</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>2 DAVID HOLLIS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Introduction</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Throughout the world, species of the family Triozidae display a wide range of body form and<tei:lb/>host plant preferences. Currently 48 genera are recognised but many of these are poorly defined<tei:lb/>and have no clear diagnostic features. Members of the family may be recognised easily, in the<tei:lb/>adult stage, by the unique venation and structure of the forewing (pp. 8-10, and Figs 40, 43).<tei:lb/>Fifth instar larvae of most species are also characteristic as the head and body margins normally<tei:lb/>have a complete fringe of specialised wax-producing setae called sectasetae (Figs 280, 289, 315).<tei:lb/>Table 1 gives, for each genus of Triozidae, a summary of the type-species, numbers of species<tei:lb/>included, distribution and host plant preferences.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Table 1 Genera of Triozidae with type-species, numbers of species, distribution and host plant data. Numbers of<tei:lb/>species recorded in parenthesis under one zoogeographical region also occur in another region. For the purposes of this<tei:lb/>table species previously included under the generic names Megatrioza, Heterotrioza and Smirnovla are here included<tei:lb/>under Trioza. (Heterotrioza Dobreanu &amp; Manolache, 1962: 258; type-species Trioza obliqua Thomson. Megatrioza<tei:lb/>Crawford, 1915: 264; type-species M. armata Crawford. Smirnovia Klimaszewski, 1968: 13; type-species Trioza<tei:lb/>femoralis Foerster.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>GENUS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>NUMBERS<tei:lb/>OF SPECIES</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST PLANT<tei:lb/>FAMILIES</tei:p>
         <tei:p>6 -&gt;</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>AFROTROPICAL JUMPING PLANT LICE</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>4 DAVID HOLLIS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Like most Psylloidea, triozid species have very restricted trophic requirements, at least in<tei:lb/>their larval stages. They are associated with dicotyledonous plants, and the host range of<tei:lb/>triozids, as a whole, is greater than any other family of psyllids. It is worthy of note that the<tei:lb/>family does not colonise the Fabaceae (= Leguminosae), a plant family greatly exploited by the<tei:lb/>Arytaininae/Euphalerinae complex of the Psyllidae. Two Trioza species in New Zealand, T.<tei:lb/>color ata (Ferris &amp; Klyver) and T. dacrydii Tuthill, are known to develop on Dacrydium, a<tei:lb/>gymnosperm (Podocarpaceae); and one species in Hawaii, Megatrioza palmicola Crawford,<tei:lb/>develops on Pritchardia spp. (Palmae). One Palaearctic species, Trioza nigricornis Foerster, is<tei:lb/>apparently polyphagous and has been recorded from Brassica (Cruciferae), Daucus (Apiaceae),<tei:lb/>Solarium (Solanaceae) and Beta (Chenopodiaceae), but recent work (Hodkinson, 1981) sug-<tei:lb/>gests a species complex may be involved.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Several other triozid species are associated with plants of economic importance. Trioza alacris<tei:lb/>Flor causes leaf-rolling in bay laurel (Laurus nobilis, Lauraceae) and has been introduced to<tei:lb/>various parts of the world, along with its host plant. In the New World Paratrioza cockerelli<tei:lb/>(Sulc) causes 'psyllid yellows' on potato (Solanum tuberosum, Solanaceae); T. anceps Tuthill, T.<tei:lb/>magnoliae Ashmead and T. perseae Tuthill feed on avocado pear (Persea americana, Lauraceae)<tei:lb/>in Central and South America. In the Oriental Region Trioza vitiensis Kirkaldy causes gall<tei:lb/>formation on the leaves of Malay apple (Eugenia malaccensis, Myrtaceae), and T. cinnamomi<tei:lb/>(Boselli) larvae form pit-galls on the leaves of Cinnamomum spp. (Lauraceae). In North Africa<tei:lb/>and the eastern Mediterranean basin Pauropsylla willcocksi Dcbski causes pit-gall formation on<tei:lb/>the leaves of fig trees (Ficus sycomorus, Moraceae). T. litseae Bordage develops on Litsea<tei:lb/>glutinosa (Lauraceae) and feeds as an adult on Vanilla planifolia (Orchidaceae) on Reunion and<tei:lb/>Mauritius, and T. erytreae (Del Guercio) is a serious pest of citrus (Rutaceae) in eastern and<tei:lb/>southern Africa where it is the principal vector of 'citrus greening disease'.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Because of its pest status, T. erytreae has received considerable attention from biologists.<tei:lb/>Information on its life-cycle, bionomics, control, and further references may be found in Catling<tei:lb/>(19690; 19696; 1969c; 1970; 1971; 1972; 1973); Moran (1968a; 19686); Moran&amp; Blowers (1967);<tei:lb/>Moran &amp; Brown (1973); and Moran &amp; Buchan (1975). This species is of considerable taxonomic<tei:lb/>interest as it is part of a complex of species, all of which are difficult to define morphologically,<tei:lb/>but which have discrete host plant preferences (see pp. 36-42).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Five other triozid species are recorded from the Afrotropical Region and the present paper<tei:lb/>adds a further 63 hitherto undescribed species to this list. A species and host plant checklist is<tei:lb/>given below.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Checklist, host plants and distribution of Afrotropical Triozidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>SPECIES HOST PLANTS DISTRIBUTION</tei:p>
         <tei:p>family species</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ficus sp. Angola</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Tanzania<tei:lb/>Tanzania</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Senegal, Ivory Coast,<tei:lb/>Ghana, Nigeria, Zaire,<tei:lb/>Tanzania</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tanzania</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Central African Republic,<tei:lb/>Uganda</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Material, methods and terminology</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The bulk of the material studied is deposited in the British Museum (Natural History) (BMNH),<tei:lb/>with additional material from the Museum fur Naturkunde der Humboldt Universitat, Berlin<tei:lb/>(MNHU); Musee Royal de 1'Afrique Centrale, Tervuren (MRAC); and the [National Collec-<tei:lb/>tion of Insects] Plant Protection Research Institute, Pretoria (NCI). Holotypes and paratypes of<tei:lb/>the species treated below are deposited in BMNH, MNHU, NCI, Museum National d'Histoire<tei:lb/>Naturelle, Paris (MNHN); the National Museums of Kenya (NMK); South African Museum,<tei:lb/>Cape Town (SAM); and the National Museum of Natural History, Washington (USNM).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>8 DAVID HOLLIS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>All measurements are quoted in millimetres and were taken from slide-mounted material.<tei:lb/>Reference points, within which measurements were taken of the various structures, are given in<tei:lb/>Hollis (1976), with additional information in Fig. 43. The length of the antennal flagellum is a<tei:lb/>summation of the lengths of individual flagellomeres.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Unless otherwise stated all figures were drawn from slide-mounted material; scale lines<tei:lb/>represent 0-1 mm unless labelled otherwise. On the forewing figures the outer limits of patches<tei:lb/>of spinules are indicated by pecked lines, as is the claval suture. Each paramere figure shows the<tei:lb/>inner surface of the right paramere. The figures of the larvae show the dorsal surface outline, left<tei:lb/>side only; details are shown of the marginal setae, representing 0.1 mm, of the head, forewing<tei:lb/>bud and caudal plate. The detail of the anal pore area is shown from a ventral view, right side<tei:lb/>only.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Structural terminology follows that of Vondracek (1957) and Hollis (1976). Wing venation<tei:lb/>terminology is explained in Figs 40, 43. The mi cell value is an expression of shape calculated by<tei:lb/>dividing the length of M 1+2 by the distance between the apices of M 1+2 and A/ 3+4 . Similarly the<tei:lb/>cu\ cell value is the distance between the apices of Cw la and Cw lb divided by the length of Cw lb .<tei:lb/>The Rs-Cui a line is an imaginary line connecting the apices of Rs and Cw la .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acknowledgements</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I thank Dr L. A. Mound, BMNH, and Dr M. R. Wilson, Commonwealth Institute of<tei:lb/>Entomology, London, for offering constructive criticism of early drafts of the manuscript. The<tei:lb/>following colleagues provided valuable loans and gifts of material: A. L. Capener, formerly of<tei:lb/>NCI; Jose Passes de Carvalho, presently with Departamento de Entomologia, Esta?ao Agrono-<tei:lb/>mica Nacional, Portugal; J. Etienne, Institut Senegalais Recherches Agricoles, Ziguinchor; Dr<tei:lb/>U. Gollner-Scheiding, MNHU; A. van Harten, presently with Projecto Luta Integrada, Praia,<tei:lb/>Cape Verde Is; and Dr G. Schmitz, MRAC.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TRIOZIDAE Low</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Triozinae Low, 1879: 605, 609; Maskell, 1890: 164; Froggatt, 1901: 272; Crawford, 1914: 64; 1919: 184;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pflugfelder, 1941: 78;Tuthill, 1943: 545; 1944: 144; 1952: 97; Zimmermann, 1948: 14; Heslop-Harrison,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1958: 562; 1961: 529; Ramirez-Gomez, 1960: 15; Mathur, 1975: 299. Type-genus: Trioza Foerster.<tei:lb/>Triozina Low; Low, 1886: 163.<tei:lb/>Triozaria Low; Puton, 1886: 93.<tei:lb/>Triozidae Low; Edwards, 1896: 251; Vondracek, 1957: 297; Dobreanu &amp; Manolache, 1962: 253; Loginova,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1964: 473; Klimaszewski, 1973: 231; 1975: 201; Bekker-Migdisova, 1973: 113.<tei:lb/>Siphonaleyrodinae Takahashi, 1932: 48. Type-genus: Siphonaleyrodes Takahashi. [Synonymised by</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mound &amp; Halsey, 1978: 252.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIFFERENTIATING DIAGNOSIS. Forewing (Fig. 40) without a costal break; R^ unbranched and pterostigma<tei:lb/>absent; M+Cu stem absent or very short so that R+M+Cu stem branches into its component veins at<tei:lb/>approximately one point; R s not fused to M stem at any point.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. This suite of characters separates the Triozidae from all other psyllid groups and I<tei:lb/>regard it as autapomorphic for the family. Furthermore I^elieve the morphology of the triozid<tei:lb/>forewing has evolved to produce a wing movement which is fundamentally different to that of<tei:lb/>other psyllids: there being no nodal line, from the costal break through to the break on the hind<tei:lb/>margin at the apex of the claval suture, for the wing to flex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Many other groups of psyllids have some, but not all, of the triozid wing features. The costal<tei:lb/>break is lost in the Macrohomotomini, the Carsidarini and many members of the Arytainini; in<tei:lb/>Epipsylla the pterostigma is lost; and in many members of the Calophyidae M+Cu stem is<tei:lb/>reduced. In the Central and South American genus Synoza the triozid wing condition is achieved<tei:lb/>in an entirely different way. Rs is fused to M stem along its proximal two-thirds, the costal break<tei:lb/>is absent but C+Sc is only very weakly sclerotised in the break area. The venation of this genus<tei:lb/>can be derived easily from that of some South East Asian members of the Homotominae to<tei:lb/>which Synoza is most closely related.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>AFROTROPICAL JUMPING PLANT LICE 9</tei:p>
         <tei:p>As yet I have been unable to find synapomorphies linking the Triozidae with any one other<tei:lb/>group of psyllids to the exclusion of all others . Therefore I am regarding the rest of the Psylloidea<tei:lb/>as a paraphyletic group with respect to the Triozidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The systematic scope of the Triozidae, as considered here, is similar to that of most recent<tei:lb/>authors but with the addition of the genera Pauropsylla and Leptynoptera. This is a relatively<tei:lb/>radical change as all previous authors, apart from White (1980), regarded Pauropsylla as a<tei:lb/>member of the Pauropsyllinae (or Pauropsyllini) within either the Carsidaridae or the Aphalar-<tei:lb/>idae (seep. 27).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Some attempt has been made by previous authors to provide a subfamilial or tribal<tei:lb/>classification for the Triozidae. Vondracek (1963) placed Triozamia in the Bactericerinae but<tei:lb/>retained the subfamily within the Ciriacreminidae (sensu Heslop-Harrison, 1958; nee Hollis,<tei:lb/>1976). Klimaszewski (1964: fig. 7) divided the group into two subfamilies, the Bactericerinae<tei:lb/>and the Triozinae. Bekker-Migdisova (1973) retained these two subfamilies and divided the<tei:lb/>Bactericerinae into two tribes, the monotypic Triozamini (Triozamia) and the Bactericerini<tei:lb/>(Bactericera, Rhinopsylla, Levidea and one unnamed genus). She divided the Triozinae into the<tei:lb/>Hemischizocraniini (Hemischizocranium) , the Paracomecini (Paracomeca) and the Eutriozini<tei:lb/>(Eutrioza) . Presumably she regarded the remaining 40 or so genera as members of a fourth tribe ,<tei:lb/>the Triozini. Kwon (1983), in a review of the Korean psyllid fauna, erected the monobasic tribes<tei:lb/>Epitriozini (Epitrioza) and Trichochermini (Trichochermes) , apparently without reference to<tei:lb/>the remaining world fauna.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Most of the 47 previously described triozid genera are poorly defined and often based on<tei:lb/>inadequate or primitive characters. Species have been added to various genera without<tei:lb/>comparison with relevant type-species, thus stretching generic limits beyond usefulness and<tei:lb/>logic. The resulting network of genera is impossible to unravel without an overall examination of<tei:lb/>original material. No attempt is made here to 'fit' species into existing genera other than Trioza,<tei:lb/>only one new genus is erected and the bulk of the Afrotropical species are placed in Trioza on a<tei:lb/>temporary basis. Where species-groups are recognisable these are defined, and if relationships<tei:lb/>with the triozid fauna outside Africa are apparent then these are noted.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The characters used to differentiate taxa in this paper are discussed, together with their likely<tei:lb/>polarity. When other faunas are examined in the light of these, and probably other characters<tei:lb/>not considered here, we may be able to produce a reasonably natural and predictive higher<tei:lb/>classification for the Triozidae and offer useful biogeographical comment on the group.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Characters and their polarity</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The integument has a general covering of setae of varying density which can be of use in<tei:lb/>distinguishing between closely related species. Often the density of pilosity on the vertex and<tei:lb/>thoracic dorsum is different to that of the genal cones and legs. Illustrations of dense, sparse,<tei:lb/>long and short pilosity are given in Figs 35, 38, 39.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The head, in its primitive condition, is adpressed to the thorax and not declined from the<tei:lb/>longitudinal axis of the body (Figs 32, 33). The occipital margin is sharply defined, the median<tei:lb/>suture of the vertex is well developed and the median ocellus is visible from above. Frontal lobes<tei:lb/>on the vertex tend to be better developed in the primitive head condition. Genal cones are<tei:lb/>normally well developed in the group and cover the frons. Generally, in psyllids, it is thought<tei:lb/>that the absence of genal cones is~a primitive condition but their absence may be a reversal in<tei:lb/>Triozidae. The more derived head condition shows it declined towards 90 from the longitudinal<tei:lb/>axis of the body (Fig. 34), with a rounded occipital margin. The vertex becomes rounded<tei:lb/>downwards and lacks frontal lobes. In some species, especially in the genus Pauropsylla, the<tei:lb/>median suture of the vertex is lost.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The antenna (Figs 9-29) shows many useful characters. In the primitive condition it has a<tei:lb/>scape, pedicel and a flagellum which has eight flagellomeres, with a single rhinarium present<tei:lb/>subapically on each of flagellomeres 2, 4, 6 and 7. Several species have developed supplementary<tei:lb/>rhinaria, particularly on the first flagellomere (Triozamia lamborni, Trioza theroni and the T.<tei:lb/>hargreavesi-group). I suspect this feature is not uniquely derived. The rhinaria are normally</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>10 DAVID HOLLIS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>disc-shaped, with a convex centre, but may have complicated associated sensilla (Figs 22-28).<tei:lb/>Flagellomere 8 bears two terminal setae, which are subequal in length in the primitive condition.<tei:lb/>Throughout the group there is a tendency for one of the pair to become shortened and truncate<tei:lb/>apically, and this condition reaches its greatest development in Trioza anomalicornis where one<tei:lb/>of the setae is reduced to a flat, circular sense organ (Fig. 17) . The overall length of the flagellum<tei:lb/>compared to head width is of use in distinguishing between species, and the relative lengths of<tei:lb/>individual flagellomeres can also be useful. Reduction in the number of flagellomeres is rare but<tei:lb/>does occur in some Pauropsylla species, with 3 and 5, which do not normally bear rhinaria, being<tei:lb/>lost.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The mouthparts are relatively standard throughout the group. The clypeus most commonly<tei:lb/>has a pair of setae but in some species, notably those displaying primitive character states,<tei:lb/>several setae are present (Figs 5,7). The ultimate rostral segment always bears a pair of basal<tei:lb/>setae and one or more pairs of setae along its length. It is rarely devoid of setae supplementary to<tei:lb/>the basal pair (Figs 6,8).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The thorax, in the primitive state, is relatively flat, the pronotum is clearly visible from above<tei:lb/>and rounded down anteriorly behind the occiput (Figs 30, 31). The propleural suture is diagonal,<tei:lb/>with the episternum somewhat larger than the epimeron, but the latter is in contact with the<tei:lb/>posterolateral corner of the pronotum. The mesopraescutum is wider than long, with a broadly<tei:lb/>arcuate anterior margin which is gently rounded down to the pronotum. In the derived state the<tei:lb/>pronotum becomes strongly rounded down behind the occiput and is scarcely visible from<tei:lb/>above. The episternum becomes greatly enlarged and its posterior margin expanded laterally<tei:lb/>and curved forward behind the eye; the epimeron being reduced and displaced ventrally. The<tei:lb/>mesopraescutum is elongated and produced forward, with a strongly arcuate anterior margin<tei:lb/>which is strongly rounded or angled down to the pronotum (Figs 36, 37).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The/orewmg displays a number of distinct trends. The general shape varies from being ovate<tei:lb/>with a rounded apex to elongate oval with an angular apex, but the obovate condition in<tei:lb/>Pauropsylla is probably secondarily derived. The membrane may be heavily spinuled (Fig. 241)<tei:lb/>through to being devoid of spinules apart from the radular areas. The latter are normally present<tei:lb/>at the margin of the wing in cells mi , ra 2 and cu\ , although more primitively they also occur in r 2<tei:lb/>(Fig. 65). They may be diffuse and broad or sharply defined and narrow triangular (Figs 249,<tei:lb/>178). The wing veins are usually sparsely clothed with short setae (Fig. 126) but may bear long<tei:lb/>setae (Figs 183, 254); the latter condition is not always associated with a dense pilosity on the<tei:lb/>integument. In the most primitive form of venation (Fig. 268) Rs is long, M branches proximally<tei:lb/>to the Rs-Cui a line (see p. 16) with a consequently high m\ cell value, Cu is short with a<tei:lb/>consequently low cu l cell value, and the claval suture reaches the wing margin close to the distal<tei:lb/>apex of Cw lb . In the most derived condition (Fig. 126) Rs is short, M branches distal to the<tei:lb/>Rs-Cui a line with a consequently low mi cell value, Cu is long with a consequently high cui cell<tei:lb/>value and the claval suture reaches the hind margin distant from the apex of Cw lb and more<tei:lb/>proximal to the base of the wing. These trends are not always associated and there are many<tei:lb/>combinations.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The hindwing, in the primitive state, is two-thirds or more as long as the forewing. The costal<tei:lb/>margin is more densely setose, with the setae distal to the costal break not clearly divided into<tei:lb/>two groups (Fig. 44). In the derived state the hindwing is much shorter than the forewing and, in<tei:lb/>the Trioza obsoleta group, it can be completely reduced and scale-like (Figs 179, 184, 189).<tei:lb/>Reduction in length is congruent with the displacement of the apex of the claval suture of the<tei:lb/>forewing towards the base of the wing. The costal margin is sparsely setose, with the setae distal<tei:lb/>to the costal break clearly divided into two groups (Fig. 42).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The/ore and mid legs offer few characters of taxonomic significance, although the Pauropsylla<tei:lb/>willcocksi-group has the extraordinary development of a ventroapical spur on the fore coxa (Fig.<tei:lb/>45). One or other of the tarsal segments may be elongated.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The hind leg bears several useful characters. The coxa usually bears a well-developed<tei:lb/>meracanthus, although this is weak in Triozamia lamborni and in the Trioza etiennei-group, and<tei:lb/>there is often an anterior lobe developed (Figs 46, 47). The latter structure has, in the past, been</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>AFROTROPICAL JUMPING PLANT LICE 11</tei:p>
         <tei:p>used to group species but the feature has probably evolved several times. The three ventral sense<tei:lb/>organs on the femur, which are probably stretch receptors, are usually in a medial position (Fig.<tei:lb/>49) but in Triozamia lamborni they are in the more primitive basal position (Fig. 48). The tibia<tei:lb/>has a basal spine or tubercle, or a raised area bearing one or more small spines. The presence of a<tei:lb/>large basal spine has been used in generic diagnoses, but I consider this to be the primitive state.<tei:lb/>Apical tibial spurs (Figs 52, 53) are normally present and are divided into an outer group of one<tei:lb/>spur and an inner group of up to four spurs. In Triozamia lamborni the outer spur is lost and the<tei:lb/>inner group consists of up to five spurs. There is a tendency towards reduction of the number of<tei:lb/>inner spurs and there can be some variation within a species, e.g. some species which normally<tei:lb/>have three inner spurs occasionally have only two on one or other leg. Few species have these<tei:lb/>spurs completely lacking but again I think this is a feature which has arisen more than once.<tei:lb/>Spurs at the apex of the basitarsus, a common feature in the rest of the Psylloidea, are, with the<tei:lb/>exception ofAfrotrioza, absent in the family.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The abdomen, in psyllids generally, has setae on all visible abdominal tergites but this<tei:lb/>condition occurs in very few triozids (four species in the Afrotropical Region). The usual<tei:lb/>condition in this family is for setae to be present only on the first, or the first two, visible tergites,<tei:lb/>i.e. tergites 2 and 3 in males and 3 and 4 in females. Trichochermes insleyi, some of the Trioza<tei:lb/>obsoleta-group and T. guiera, have setae on all tergites except the pregenital; T. mimusops has<tei:lb/>setae only on tergites 6 to 8; T. chiangae has setae on tergites 3 to 5; and the abdominal tergites of<tei:lb/>T. afrosersalisia are apparently devoid of setae. This character is not directly associated with<tei:lb/>general body pilosity because T. medleri, probably the most setose Afrotropical species, has<tei:lb/>only the first visible abdominal tergite setose.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The male genitalia provides the most useful character suite for defining species. As in most<tei:lb/>psyllids, the proctiger is normally unsegmented (unipartite), but a bipartite proctiger occurs in<tei:lb/>Triozamia species and is almost developed in the Trioza etiennei-group . I consider a bipartite<tei:lb/>proctiger to be the derived condition (Fig. 59). The unipartite proctiger can be a simple, almost<tei:lb/>cylindrical tube (Fig. 242) but more commonly the basal part is swollen and often bears lateral<tei:lb/>expansions which sometimes have modified setae on their inner surfaces (Figs 76, 97, 135). The<tei:lb/>shape of the paramere and its chaetotaxy is usually definitive for a species. The aedeagus is<tei:lb/>composed of two articulated segments, as in most psyllids, but the apical segment is subdivided<tei:lb/>into two parts in Triozamia lamborni and in the Trioza etiennei-group (Figs 64, 200). The apical<tei:lb/>part of the aedeagus is usually definitive for each species, and in some cases is quite complex<tei:lb/>(Figs 88, 91, 136).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The female genital complex is usually conoid, with a subacute posterior apex (Fig. 127). The<tei:lb/>anal pore ring usually consists of a double ring of wax-producing cells and is rarely modified; in<tei:lb/>Triozamia species it is very convoluted (Fig. 62), in the litseae-group and some species of the<tei:lb/>neoboutonia-group of Trioza it is reduced to a single ring, and in Trioza tundavalae it is<tei:lb/>incomplete anteriorly and forms multiple rows posteriorly (Fig. 274) . The base of the proctiger is<tei:lb/>much less sclerotised than in other groups of psyllids, and is sometimes membraneous around<tei:lb/>the anterior arch of the anal pore ring. The apical part of the proctiger is usually narrowed to a<tei:lb/>subacute apex but may be modified in various ways (Figs 138, 253, 274). The subgenital plate is<tei:lb/>triangular in profile and usually has a narrowly arcuate or subacute posterior margin. Occa-<tei:lb/>sionally the posterior margin is truncate or emarginate (Figs 89, 138). The lower valves of the<tei:lb/>ovipositor sometimes have teeth or ridges developed (Figs 128, 138, 273) which can be useful in<tei:lb/>species diagnosis.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>

         <tei:p>Figs 45-53 Afrotropical Triozidae, leg structure. 45, Pauropsylla trichaeta, fore coxa, anteroventral<tei:lb/>view. 46, 50, Trioza etiennei; 46, hind coxa, lateral view; 50, hind tibia, anterodorsal view. 47, T. gonjae,<tei:lb/>hind coxa, lateral view. 48, Triozamia lamborni, hind femur, posteroventral view. 49, 52, Trioza<tei:lb/>erytreae; 49, hind femur, posteroventral view; 52, apex of hind tibia, posteroventral view. 51, T. karroo,<tei:lb/>hind tibia, anterodorsal view. 53, T. capensis, apex of hind tibia, posterodorsal view.</tei:p>

      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>18 DAVID HOLLIS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Identification</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The key presented below is intended to facilitate identification of Afrotropical triozid species; it<tei:lb/>does not reflect phylogenetic relationships. The concept of the 'genus' Trioza, used here, is<tei:lb/>admittedly artificial, hence Trioza species key out both before and after the other included<tei:lb/>genera.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Undoubtedly the user will have difficulty identifying species in the erytreae- and anomalicor-<tei:lb/>ms-groups of Trioza (couplets 57-65) because of their morphological homogeneity. As T.<tei:lb/>erytreae is of economic importance a summary of characters used to identify species of the<tei:lb/>erytreae-group is given in Table 4. Apart from anomaticomis, which has distinctive antennal<tei:lb/>characters, the other four species in this group can be separated on the basis of the shape of the<tei:lb/>male paramere and the apical segment of the aedeagus (see quadruplet 61, p. 22). No reliable<tei:lb/>characters were found which would discriminate between females of this group.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>T. bussei and T. similis are excluded from the key because of insufficient data (see p. 69).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to species of Afrotropical Triozidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 Forewing with extensive brown-pigmented area either as a speckled pattern over most of wing,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>or as an infuscation along the medial vein and extending over posterior half of wing (Figs 69,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>216,245,249) 2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Forewing hyaline, if brown-pigmented areas are present they are restricted to the very base of<tei:lb/>wing (Fig. 188), or along course of R and R l veins (Figs 169, 194, 233, 272), or at points where<tei:lb/>veins meet wing margin (Fig. 202) 5</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 Forewing with brown speckled pattern over most of surface (Fig. 69); long and narrow, more</tei:p>
         <tei:p>than 3-5 times longer than wide ; Rs strongly curved towards M } before reaching margin</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trichochermes insleyi Capener (p. 26)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Forewing with brown infuscation along M stem and across posterior half of wing; broader, at<tei:lb/>most slightly more than 3 times longer than wide; Rs continuously divergent from M stem<tei:lb/>(Figs 216, 245, 249) 3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 Small species, forewing not more than 1-8 mm long; antennal flagellum short, about as long as</tei:p>
         <tei:p>head width; genal cones absent Trioza pitkini sp. n. (p. 59)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Larger species, forewing more than 2 mm long; antennal flagellum more than 1-5 times longer</tei:p>
         <tei:p>than head width ; genal cones well developed 4</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4 Hind tibia with well-developed apical spurs; cu cell value 1-07-1-40; $ proctiger blunt,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>rounded apically in profile Trioza laingi sp. n. (p. 64)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hind tibia without apical spurs but with a crown of stout setae; cu cell value 1-48-1-79; $<tei:lb/>proctiger acute, extended apically in profile Trioza karroo sp. n. (p. 63)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5 Forewing with a radular area present in cell r 2 as well as in cells m\, ra 2 and cu 2 , but if absent</tei:p>
         <tei:p>then apex of claval suture in close proximity to apex of Cu\ b (Figs 56, 65); C+Sc greatly</tei:p>
         <tei:p>thickened along its whole length and more than twice as thick as R stem 6</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Forewing with radular area absent from cell r 2 and apex of claval suture distant from apex of<tei:lb/>Cw lb ; C+Sc not or hardly thickened and at most slightly thicker than R stem 9</tei:p>
         <tei:p>6 Metabasitarsus with a single apical spur; antenna short, flagellum 0-91-0-98 times as long as</tei:p>
         <tei:p>head width, 1st flagellomere without rhinaria; aedeagus 2-segmented</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Afrotrioza bersama sp. n. (p. 25)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Metabasitarsus without apical spurs; antennal flagellum 1-5-2-0 times longer than head width,<tei:lb/>1st flagellomere bearing several rhinaria and often thickened (Figs 19-21); aedeagus<tei:lb/>3-segmented ( Triozamia spp.) 7</tei:p>
         <tei:p>7 First flagellomere not at all thickened and bearing only 4-8 rhinaria basally; $ proctiger</tei:p>
         <tei:p>relatively short, 0-97-1-01 times as long as head width Triozamia usambarensis sp. n. (p. 24)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>First flagellomere thickened and almost completely covered with rhinaria; $ proctiger longer,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1-2-1-54 times longer than head width 8</tei:p>
         <tei:p>8 First flagellomere 1-39-1-47 times longer than 2nd flagellomere; apical aedeagal segment</tei:p>
         <tei:p>0-52-0-56 times as long as medial aedeagal segment Triozamia vondraceki sp. n . (p. 24)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>First flagellomere 0-63-0-76 times as long as 2nd flagellomere; apical aedeagal segment longer<tei:lb/>than medial aedeagal segment Triozamia lamborni (Newstead) (p. 23)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>9 Vertex dish-like, evenly and roundly concave, not at all raised or interrupted along median</tei:p>
         <tei:p>suture, margin of 'dish' complete, sharp, finely serrate Trioza afrosersalisia sp. n. (p. 54)</tei:p>

         <tei:p>TRIOZAMIA Vondracek</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Triozamia Vondracek, 1963: 266. Type-species: Rhinopsylla lamborni Newstead, by original designation<tei:lb/>and monotypy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION . Head , from above , slightly narrower than mesoscutum , in profile at 90 to longitudinal axis of<tei:lb/>body; occipital margin angular, occiput concave; vertex with a median suture, without frontal lobes;<tei:lb/>median ocellus not visible from above, frons just visible in anterior view; genae slightly swollen ventrally;<tei:lb/>1st flagellomere bearing several rhinaria, flagellomeres 4, 6 and 7 bearing a single subapical rhinarium;<tei:lb/>clypeus prominent, densely setose. Thorax, in profile, weakly arched; pronotum clearly visible from above<tei:lb/>and strongly rounded down anteriorly behind occiput; propleural suture diagonal but both pleurites in<tei:lb/>contact with lateral margin of pronotum; forewing elongate oval with a subangular apex, C+Sc strongly<tei:lb/>thickened, M branching proximally to Rs-Cu^ line, claval suture reaching hind margin of wing at same<tei:lb/>point as apex of C lb , radular spines present in cells r 2 (sometimes weak or absent), m\, m 2 and cu\;<tei:lb/>hindwing well developed, costal margin densely setose both proximally and immediately distal to the costal<tei:lb/>break. Hind coxa with a weakly developed meracanthus and without anterior lobe; hind femur not<tei:lb/>thickened medially, ventral sense organs basally positioned with the most distal organ slightly separated<tei:lb/>from the proximal pair; hind tibia with well-developed basal spine, and an inner apical group of</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>AFROTROPICAL JUMPING PLANT LICE 23</tei:p>
         <tei:p>well-developed spurs. Abdomen with setae on all tergites; cf proctiger bipartite; aedeagus 3-segmented;<tei:lb/>anal pore of $ proctiger with a double, convoluted ring of wax-producing cells.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. When Vondracek described this genus he placed it in the Bactericerinae of the<tei:lb/>Ciriacreminidae (sensu Heslop-Harrison, 1958; nee Hollis, 1976). Klimaszewski (1964) rightly<tei:lb/>removed the Bactericerinae to the Triozidae, recognising the true relationships of the group,<tei:lb/>and Bekker-Migdisova (1973) separated Triozamia from the other Bactericerinae on a suite of<tei:lb/>both derived (bipartite cf proctiger, 3-segmented aedeagus) and primitive (proximity of apex of<tei:lb/>claval suture to apex of Cw lb , radulae area in r^ characters. The genus has retained many<tei:lb/>primitive features in addition to those mentioned by Bekker-Migdisova, notably the flattened<tei:lb/>thorax and unmodified prosternum, the basal position of the ventral sense organs on the hind<tei:lb/>femur and the presence of setae on all abdominal tergites. Her statement of a 'distinct<tei:lb/>sclerotisation of the pterostigma' is probably a misinterpretation of the thickening of C+Sc, a<tei:lb/>true pterostigma being absent. Other derived features of the genus include the large number of<tei:lb/>rhinaria on the first flagellomere and the usual absence of a rhinarium on flagellomere 2, but<tei:lb/>these offer no indication of the relationships of the genus to the rest of the Triozidae.<tei:lb/>Three included species are treated below.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Triozamia lamborni (Newstead)<tei:lb/>(Figs 5, 6, 19, 48, 63, 64, 275, 276)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Rhlnopsylla lamborni Newstead, 1914: 520; Eastop, 1961: 168. Holotype cf , NIGERIA: 'Lagos, 70m. E. nr</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Oni clearing' [not traced].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Triozamia lamborni (Newstead); Vondracek, 1963: 266, partim; Akanbi, 1981: 113.<tei:lb/>Triozamia lambourni [sic] (Newstead); Roberts, 1969: 78.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Adult. Having generic characters stated above. Integument of thoracic dorsum sparsely<tei:lb/>short-haired but mesoscutellum and metascutum more densely haired. Vertex pentagonal, steeply sloping<tei:lb/>downwards, slightly concave; ultimate rostral segment 4-5 times longer than apical flagellomere, densely<tei:lb/>haired; antennal flagellum 1-71-2-04 times longer than head width, 1st flagellomere 0-63-0-76 times as long<tei:lb/>as 2nd flagellomere, thickened and with a large number of rhinaria, 2nd flagellomere without a rhinarium,<tei:lb/>flagellomeres 4, 6 and 7 each with a single subapical rhinarium, apical flagellomere with one moderately<tei:lb/>long and pointed seta and one shorter and truncate seta terminally. Mesopraescutum, from above,<tei:lb/>rounded rhomboidal, wider than long and with a broadly arcuate anterior margin; forewing 2-66-2-81<tei:lb/>times longer than wide, apart from radular areas there is a patch of spinules in c+sc, veins moderately<tei:lb/>densely setose, R s long, M branching proximal to /? s Cu la line, m\ cell value 4-9-6-0, cu\ cell ratio 0-4-0-5;<tei:lb/>costal setae of hindwing, distal to costal break, divided into two groups; hind tibia with an inner apical<tei:lb/>group of 5-6 strongly developed spurs and an outer apical group of about 10 thickened setae; hind<tei:lb/>basitarsus elongate. Abdomen with a pair of lateral eversible sacs on segment 4; cf proctiger and genitalia<tei:lb/>as in Figs 59, 63, 64, apical segment of aedeagus 1-12-1-23 times longer than medial segment; $ genital<tei:lb/>segment with proctiger 1-20-1-27 times longer than head width, ovipositor valves smooth.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Measurements (7 cf, 5 &lt;j&gt;). Maximum width of head, cf 1-23-1.30, &lt;j&gt; 1-30-1-35; length of antennal<tei:lb/>flagellum, cf 2-22-2-51, $ 2-31-2-51; length of ultimate rostral segment, cf 0-41-0-46, $ 0-45-0-50; length<tei:lb/>of forewing, cf 4-05-4-33, $ 4-21-4-58; length of hind tibia, cf 0-90-1-00, $ 0-95-1-05.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fifth instar larva (Figs 275-277). Body clearly divided into head, thorax and abdomen, about 1-1 times<tei:lb/>longer than wide. Antenna with 8 flagellomeres. Small prothoracic sclerites present behind cephalo-<tei:lb/>prothorax, meso- and metathoracic sclerites separated. Forewing bud about 0-92 mm long, humeral lobes<tei:lb/>not at all developed. Caudal plate about half as long as wide and does not include first 4 abdominal<tei:lb/>segments; anus terminal or terminodorsal, anus and pore ring as in Fig. 277, caudal plate with a<tei:lb/>complicated arrangement of wax pores on dorsal and ventral surfaces (Fig. 276). No sectasetae present but<tei:lb/>caudal plate bears 8 small dorsomarginal lanceolate setae positioned as in Fig. 276.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST PLANT. Larvae and adults collected from Antiaris toxicaria africana var. africana<tei:lb/>(Moraceae). The larvae are free-living and produce copious wax strands.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Senegal, Ivory Coast, Ghana, Nigeria, Zaire and Tanzania.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. T. lamborni may be distinguished from the other two known species in the genus by<tei:lb/>the characters given in Table 2.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>24 DAVID HOLLIS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Table 2 Characters for the separation of the three African species of Triozamia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The material upon which Vondracek based his redescription of this species was a mixed series,<tei:lb/>the Ugandan specimens and his figs 18 and 26 being vondraceki.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The presence of three clearly recognisable species of Triozamia in Africa raises some<tei:lb/>interesting questions on the taxonomy of the host plant genus Antiaris. In a recent review of<tei:lb/>African Moraceae Berg (1977) recognises one African species, Antiaris toxicaria, which also<tei:lb/>occurs in Asia and Australia. Berg refers the African populations to the subspecies africana and<tei:lb/>further recognises three varieties, africana, welwitschii and usambarensis, all with partially<tei:lb/>overlapping distributions (Berg, 1977: fig. 8).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Of the three Triozamia species on Antiaris, lamborni is known from Senegal, Ivory Coast,<tei:lb/>Ghana, Nigeria, northern Zaire and Tanzania (Pare Mountains and Uluguru Mountains);<tei:lb/>vondraceki is described from Uganda and the Central African Republic; and usambarensis is<tei:lb/>described from Tanzania (Usambara Mountains). It seems likely that the three psyllid species<tei:lb/>maintain their genetic independence each on one of three 'varieties' of Antiaris toxicaria<tei:lb/>africana.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Triozamia usambarensis sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 21, 56-58)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Adult. Very similar to T. lamborni but slightly larger. First flagellomere 1-10-1-26 times<tei:lb/>longer than 2nd flagellomere, not thickened and bearing only 4-12 rhinaria on basal half, a subapical<tei:lb/>rhinarium rarely present on 2nd flagellomere. Apical segment of aedeagus 0-96-0-97 times as long as<tei:lb/>medial aedeagal segment, paramere as in Fig. 57; $ proctiger short, 0-97-1-01 times as long as head width.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Measurements (2 cf , 2 $). Maximum width of head, cf 1-41-1-43, $ 1-48-1-51; length of antennal<tei:lb/>flagellum, cf 2-4, $ antennae incomplete; length of ultimate rostral segment, cf 0-37-0-39, 9 0-40; length<tei:lb/>of forewing, Cf 5-51-5-57, $ 6-10-6-12; length of hind tibia, cf 1-11 $ 1-17-1-20.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Larva. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST PLANT. Adults collected from Antiaris toxicaria africana var. usambarensis (Moraceae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf, Tanzania: Lushoto, 23. vi. 1977, Antiaris usambarensis (Wadudu Msituni) (BMNH; slide<tei:lb/>mounted).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. Tanzania: 1 cf, 1 $, same data as holotype; 1 cf, 1 ?, Lushoto, 22. ix. 1977, 'ex scales on<tei:lb/>Hirus' [probably an error of transliteration from a handwritten label]; 1 cf, 1 $, Lushoto Silv. Arb.<tei:lb/>22. ix. 1980, Antiaris usambarensis (Wadudu Msituni) (BMNH; slide and dry mounted).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS (see also under T. lamborni). This species is described from seven rather poorly<tei:lb/>preserved specimens, all from approximately the same locality. However, they were collected<tei:lb/>on three separate occasions over a period of three years and the population is clearly maintaining<tei:lb/>its morphological identity from the other two species of the genus. The type-locality is close to<tei:lb/>that of Antiaris usambarensis (see Berg, 1977: 318).</tei:p>

         <tei:p>AFROTRIOZA gen. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Type-species: Afrotrioza bersama sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Head, from above, narrower than mesoscutum, in profile continuing axis of anterior part of<tei:lb/>thorax; occipital margin sharp; median suture of vertex moderately developed, frontal lobes well<tei:lb/>developed; median ocellus visible from above, frons completely covered by genal cones; latter large and<tei:lb/>well developed, constricted basally and in parallel plane to vertex; antenna with a single subapical<tei:lb/>rhinarium on each of flagellomeres 2, 4, 6 and 7; clypeus not prominent, with several short setae. Thorax, in<tei:lb/>profile, strongly arched; pronotum clearly visible from above and scarcely rounded down behind occiput,<tei:lb/>prothoracic suture diagonal with both pleurites in contact with lateral margin of pronotum; forewing<tei:lb/>elongate oval, narrowing to subangular apex, radular areas present in cells r 2 , m\, m 2 and cu { , C+Sc<tei:lb/>strongly thickened, M branching proximal to Rs Ci a line, claval suture reaching hind margin a short<tei:lb/>distance proximal to apex of Cw lb ; hindwing well developed, costal margin densely setose proximal to<tei:lb/>costal break, costal setae distal to costal break not clearly grouped; hind coxa with a well-developed<tei:lb/>meracanthus, anterior lobe absent; ventral sense organs of hind femur medially placed; hind tibia with a<tei:lb/>small basal spine, with one outer and four inner apical spurs; hind basitarsus with an outer apical spur.<tei:lb/>Abdomen with setae on all tergites; cf proctiger unipartite, aedeagus 2-segmented.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. This monotypic genus shows a mixture of both primitive and derived character states<tei:lb/>and is clearly defined from all other described triozids by the presence of an apical spur on the<tei:lb/>hind basitarsus. The shape of the genal cones is similar to that of Trichochermes but the thorax is<tei:lb/>strongly arched. It shares such primitive character states with Trlozamia as the presence of a<tei:lb/>radular area in r and an unmodified prothorax.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Afrotrioza bersama sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 1, 32, 33, 44, 65-68, 278, 279)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Adult. Having generic characters stated above. Large species, head width 0-91-0-97 mm.<tei:lb/>Integument of thoracic dorsum almost devoid of setae but genal cones, legs and abdomen densely setose.<tei:lb/>Vertex pentagonal, with a deep concavity on either side of median suture; antennal flagellum short,<tei:lb/>0-91-0-98 times as long as head width, apical flagellomere with one moderately long pointed seta and one<tei:lb/>very short truncate seta terminally; ultimate rostral segment about twice as long as apical flagellomere,<tei:lb/>sparsely haired. Mesopraescutum, from above, rounded rhomboidal and almost as long as wide, with an<tei:lb/>arcuate anterior margin; forewing 2-27-2-40 times longer than wide, membrane moderately densely<tei:lb/>covered with spinules, veins densely short haired, Rs long, m\ cell value 2-73-3-07, cu\ cell value 0-73-0-83;<tei:lb/>hind tibia with one outer and four inner apical spurs; hind basitarsus short, cf genitalia and proctiger as in<tei:lb/>Figs 66-68; 9 genital segment conical, proctiger slightly attenuate apically, anal pore with a double ring of<tei:lb/>wax-producing cells, ovipositor valves smooth.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Measurements (6 cf , 3 9). Maximum width of head, cf 0-91-0-95, 9 0-91-0-97; length of antennal<tei:lb/>flagellum, cf 0-86-0-91, 9 0-87-0-89; length of ultimate rostral segment, cf 0-16-0-17, 9 0-16-0-18; length<tei:lb/>of forewing, cf 4-13-4-37, 9 4-48^-64; length of hind tibia, cf 0-74-0-80, 9 0-76-0-78.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>26 DAVID HOLLIS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fifth instar larva (Figs 278, 279). Dorsal surface outline broadly oval, about 1-1 times longer than wide.<tei:lb/>Antenna with two flagellomeres. Forewing pad 2-2 mm long; narrow prothoracic sclerites present between<tei:lb/>cephaloprothorax and mesothorax, meso- and metathoracic sclerites as in Fig. 278; humeral lobe strongly<tei:lb/>extended forward and reaching beyond anterior margin of cephaloprothorax. Caudal plate about 0-6 times<tei:lb/>as long as wide; anus ventral, a short distance from posterior margin of abdomen, anus and pore ring as in<tei:lb/>Fig. 279. Pointed sectasetae forming a dense fringe along anterior margin of cephaloprothorax and caudal<tei:lb/>plate, wing buds with a sparse fringe of very short simple setae; sectasetae absent from dorsum.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST PLANT. Larvae and adults collected from Bersama sp. (Melianthaceae); the larvae cause<tei:lb/>severe leaf-rolling and distortion.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype d", Tanzania: E. Usambara mts, Amani Res. Sta. 19-27. vi. 1974, c. 3,000' Bersama sp. (D.<tei:lb/>Hollis) (BMNH; dry mounted).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. 56 cf, 33 9&gt; larvae, same data as holotype. (BMNH; slide and dry mounted, and stored in<tei:lb/>80% ethanol).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TRICHOCHERMES Kirkaldy</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trichopsylla Thomson, 1877: 823. Type-species: Trioza walked Forster, by monotypy. [Homonym of</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trichopsylla Kolenati, 1863.]<tei:lb/>Trichochermes Kirkaldy, 1904: 280; Kuwayama, 1910: 54; Loginova, 1964: 473. [Replacement name for</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trichopsylla Thomson.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Head, from above, narrower than mesoscutum, in profile in same plane as longitudinal axis<tei:lb/>of thorax; occipital margin sharp, occiput concave; frontal lobes of vertex well developed, median suture<tei:lb/>well defined; median ocellus visible from above, frons completely covered by genal cones; latter well<tei:lb/>developed, in parallel plane to vertex, clavate and constricted basally; antenna with a single subapical<tei:lb/>rhinarium on each of flagellomeres 2, 4, 6 and 7. Thorax, in profile, very weakly arched; pronotum clearly<tei:lb/>visible from above and not rounded down behind occiput, prothoracic suture diagonal, episternum greatly<tei:lb/>enlarged, epimeron reduced and not in contact with lateral margin of pronotum; forewing narrow elongate<tei:lb/>oval, with subacute apex, membrane with extensive brown pattern, C+Sc not thickened, Rs sinuous or<tei:lb/>arched strongly toward M stem, M branching distal to Rs Cw la line, claval suture reaching hind margin a<tei:lb/>long distance proximal to apex of Cu ib ; hindwing well developed, costal setae separated into groups distal<tei:lb/>to costal break; hind femur with ventral sense organs medially placed, hind tibia with apical spurs separated<tei:lb/>into two groups, hind basitarsus without spurs. Abdomen with setae on tergites 2-7 in cf , and 3-7 in $ ; cf<tei:lb/>proctiger unipartite, aedeagus 2-segmented; anal pore of $ with a double ring of wax-producing cells.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. Trichochermes may be distinguished from other triozids by the shape of the genal<tei:lb/>cones, the flattened thorax, the patterned forewing and the sinuous or displaced Rs vein. The<tei:lb/>genus is similar in appearance to Leuronota but the latter has simple genal cones and a relatively<tei:lb/>straight Rs.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Four Palaearctic species, all apparently developing on different species ofRhamnus, and one<tei:lb/>Afrotropical species are recognised. It is doubtful if either of the two Japanese species,<tei:lb/>described by Kuwayama (1910), are true Trichochermes and Crawford (1919: 185) regarded<tei:lb/>them both as Trioza species. From Kuwayama's original description it seems that Trichochermes<tei:lb/>bicolor Kuwayama, 1910: 54 is identical with Petalolyma basalts (Walker, 1858: 275), from<tei:lb/>India, but formal synonymy cannot be established until Kuwayama's type-material has been<tei:lb/>examined.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trichochermes insleyi Capener<tei:lb/>(Figs 3, 69-71)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trichochermes insleyi Capener, 1973: 59. Holotype $, SOUTH AFRICA: 'Rustenburg, Tvl, 15 Sept. 1971'<tei:lb/>(NCI) [not examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Adult. Having generic characters given above. Medium size, head width 0-50. Integument of<tei:lb/>head, body and legs sparsely covered with long setae. Vertex pentagonal with a well-developed concavity<tei:lb/>on either side of median suture; genal cones well developed; antennal flagellum 1-22 times longer than<tei:lb/>head width; clypeus not prominent, bearing two setae. Anterior margin of pronotum angular medially;<tei:lb/>mesopraescutum about as long as wide, with arcuate anterior margin. Forewing (Fig. 69) 3-72 times longer</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>AFROTROPICAL JUMPING PLANT LICE 27</tei:p>
         <tei:p>than wide, with mottled brown pigmentation over whole membrane, veins densely long-haired, Rs arched<tei:lb/>strongly toward M, mi cell value 1-31, cu\ cell value 0-45; hindwing with five setae on C+Sc proximal to<tei:lb/>costal break, setae distal to costal break divided into two groups; hind coxa with a well-developed<tei:lb/>meracanthus and incipient anterior lobe; hind tibia with a well-developed basal spine, with one outer and<tei:lb/>two inner apical spurs, cf proctiger narrow, lateral margins not expanded, genitalia as in Figs 70, 71; 9<tei:lb/>genital segment short, conical, ventral valves of ovipositor serrate at extreme apices.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Measurements (19). Maximum width of head, 0-5; length of antennal flagellum, 0-61; length of ultimate<tei:lb/>rostral segment, 0-11; length of forewing, 2-97; length of hind tibia, 0-56.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fifth instar larva. See Capener, 1973: 60, figs 122, 123.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST PLANT. Larvae and adults collected from Ziziphus mucronata (Rhamnaceae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION AND MATERIAL EXAMINED. Known only from the type-series of which 1 cf and 2 9 paratypes<tei:lb/>(BMNH) have been examined.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>PAUROPSYLLA Riibsaamen</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pauropsylla Riibsaamen, 1899: 262; Kieffer, 1905: 167; Crawford, 1915: 258, partim; Crawford, 1919: 142,<tei:lb/>partim; Enderlein, 1921: 115, partim; Loginova, 1972a: 839; Mathur, 1975: 72 partim. Type-species:<tei:lb/>Pauropsylla udei Riibsaamen, by monotypy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Sympauropsylla Enderlein, 1921: 116. Type-species: Pauropsylla triozoptera Crawford, by original<tei:lb/>designation. Syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Head, from above, as wide as mesoscutum, in profile inclined almost at 90 to longitudinal<tei:lb/>axis of body; vertex pentagonal, with sharp occipital margin medially, rounded down anteriorly to genae,<tei:lb/>median suture weak or absent, dorsal depressions well developed, lateral ocelli placed on outer surfaces of<tei:lb/>raised tubercles, median ocellus visible from above; frons visible from anterior view; genae rounded,<tei:lb/>sometimes weakly expanded laterally below eyes; latter prominent, rounded; antenna short, with 8 or,<tei:lb/>more rarely, 6 flagellomeres. Thorax strongly arched dorsally; pronotum just visible from above, strongly<tei:lb/>rounded down below anterior margin of mesopraescutum and behind occiput, propleural suture diagonal<tei:lb/>with epimeron reduced and not in contact with lateral margin of pronotum; mesopraescutum, from above,<tei:lb/>with broadly arcuate anterior margin, in profile anterior margin sharply rounded down to pronotum;<tei:lb/>forewing obovate with narrow proximal part, not more than 2-3 times longer than wide, a very short M+Cu<tei:lb/>stem often present, M branches distally to Rs-Cu ia line, w t cell value less than 1, Cu stem always more<tei:lb/>than twice as long as C lb , wing membrane devoid of spinules except for radular areas; hindwing at least<tei:lb/>two-thirds as long as forewing; legs slightly elongate, meracanthus present on hind coxa, hind femur<tei:lb/>narrow with ventral sense organs medial, hind tibia elongate with a group of small weak spines basally and<tei:lb/>one outer and two inner spurs apically (2 + 2 in P. udei), hind basitarsus without apical spurs. Abdomen<tei:lb/>with setae on tergites 2 and 3 in cf , and 3 and 4 in 9 ; cf proctiger unipartite, mostly simple, flask-shaped,<tei:lb/>basal part rarely expanded; anal pore of 9 normally with a double ring of wax-producing cells.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. Pauropsylla may be distinguished from other triozid genera by the shape and<tei:lb/>venation of the forewing (Figs 75, 80, 83, 84, 86).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The most recent and comprehensive review of psyllid systematics (Bekker-Migdisova, 1973)<tei:lb/>places Pauropsylla in the tribe Pauropsyllini, together with the Microceropsyllini, in the<tei:lb/>subfamily Pauropsyllinae and in the family Carsidaridae. This largely follows Klimaszewski<tei:lb/>(1964) rather than Heslop-Harrison (1958) who placed the genus within his diffuse group the<tei:lb/>Ciriacreminae (see Hollis, 1976).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In a recent revision of the Pauropsyllini, Loginova (19720) concludes that the group is closely<tei:lb/>related to the Phacopteronini and contains the genera Pauropsylla, Sympauropsylla, Leptynop-<tei:lb/>tera, Microceropsylla, Pelmatobrachia and Paurocephala. Including Paurocephala in this group<tei:lb/>is consistent with Crawford's (1915; 1919) interpretation, but other workers (Vondracek, 1957;<tei:lb/>Heslop-Harrison, 1958; Klimaszewski, 1964) disagreed with this and placed Paurocephala in the<tei:lb/>Aphalaridae. After examining several species of Paurocephala, including the type-species, P.<tei:lb/>psylloptera Crawford, the structure of the adult head, thorax and wing venation, and the 5th<tei:lb/>instar larva (Table 3) suggest this genus should be placed in the Aphalaridae close to the genera<tei:lb/>Haplaphalara and Moraniella. Of the five remaining genera in Loginova's (1972a) Pauropsyllini,<tei:lb/>Microceropsylla and Pelmatobrachia (Bekker-Migdisova's 1973 Microceropsyllini) are transfer-<tei:lb/>red to the Calophyinae; Sympauropsylla is synonymised with Pauropsylla which, together with</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>28</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DAVID HOLLIS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Leptynoptera, is transferred to the Triozidae. Following Klimaszewski (1964) the Phacoptero-<tei:lb/>nini is placed in the Aphalaridae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mathur (1975), in his account of Indian psyllids, reviews the Pauropsyllinae (auctt.) and<tei:lb/>includes four genera, Apsylla, Paurocephala, Pauropsylla and Phacopteron. Apsylla was placed<tei:lb/>in the Anomalopsyllini by Vondracek (1963) and into the Aphalaridae by Klimaszewski (1964).<tei:lb/>Of the species Mathur included in Paurocephala only minuta Crawford, psylloptera Crawford,<tei:lb/>phalaki Mathur and russellae Mathur should remain in that genus. P. menoni Mathur and<tei:lb/>trimaculata Mathur are here transferred to Haplaphalara as H. menoni (Mathur, 1975) comb, n.,<tei:lb/>and H. trimaculata (Mathur, 1975) comb. n. Of the 14 species Mathur placed in Pauropsylla,<tei:lb/>depressa Crawford,/zc/co/fl Kieffer, globuli Kieffer , purpurescens Mathur and reticulata Mathur<tei:lb/>should remain. P. brevicornis (Crawford) and nigra (Crawford) were placed in Microceropsylla<tei:lb/>by Boselli (1930a); longispiculata Mathur, maculata Mathur and verrucosa Mathur are here<tei:lb/>transferred to Microceropsylla as M. longispiculata (Mathur, 1975) comb. n. M. maculata<tei:lb/>(Mathur, 1975) comb. n. and M. verrucosa (Mathur, 1975) comb. n. P. spondiasae (Crawford)<tei:lb/>was placed in Pelmatobrachia by Enderlein (1921), and tuberculata (Crawford) was placed in<tei:lb/>Pseudophacopteron, also by Enderlein (1921). P. beesoni Laing is here transferred to Trioza as<tei:lb/>T. beesoni (Laing, 1930) comb. n. P. stevensi Laing is here transferred to the genus Diceraeopsyl-<tei:lb/>la as D. stevensi (Laing, 1930) comb, n., and the genus is referred to the Aphalaridae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The description and figures of Pauropsylla shiwapuriensis Miyatake (1981: 53) show that this<tei:lb/>species is wrongly assigned and, more likely, belongs in the Aphalaridae near the Haplaphalara/<tei:lb/>Diclidophlebia-group .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Most Pauropsylla species are recorded from species of Ficus (Moraceae) although udei, the<tei:lb/>type-species, was described from a member of the Rubiaceae. Uichanco (1921: 265) regards this<tei:lb/>host record as a misidentification but Mathur (1975: 105) has described reticulata from<tei:lb/>Anthocephalus indicus (Rubiaceae). I have examined specimens from the same sample as the<tei:lb/>type-series of reticulata and suspect that this species is synonymous with udei. Further material,<tei:lb/>including larvae, from Anthocephalus indicus will be needed before this synonymy and host<tei:lb/>plant record can be confirmed.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eleven described species are regarded here as congeneric in Pauropsylla, mainly from the</tei:p>

         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>AFROTROPICAL JUMPING PLANT LICE 29</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Oriental region, but two species of doubtful validity, nussex Carmin and biki Carmin, occur in<tei:lb/>the Palaearctic Region. P. willcocksi and trichaeta occur in Africa and a further eleven<tei:lb/>Afrotropical species are described below. They may be identified using couplets 39-50 in the key<tei:lb/>(p. 20).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The willcocksi-group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Defined by the presence of a strong ventroapical spur on the fore coxa. Three species with an<tei:lb/>Afrotropical distribution belong in this group, willcocksi, trichaeta and tatrichea. Two poorly<tei:lb/>described species from Palestine also belong here (see comment under willcocksi).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pauropsylla willcocksi Dcbski<tei:lb/>(Figs 72-74, 280, 281)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pauropsylla willcocksi Dcbski, 1918 [71923]: 14; Willcocks, 1922: 275; Samy, 1972: 458. Syntypes, cfs, $s,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>larvae, EGYPT [not traced].<tei:lb/>[Pauropsylla trichaeta Pettey; Awadallah &amp; Swailem, 1971: 193;? Loginova, 1972o: figs 40, 41. Misiden-</tei:p>
         <tei:p>tifications.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Adult. Having generic characters given above. Integument shiny, sparsely covered with very<tei:lb/>short setae. Median suture of vertex absent; antenna with eight flagellomeres, flagellum 1-34-1-61 times<tei:lb/>longer than head width, apical flagellomere with one long and one moderately long and truncate terminal<tei:lb/>seta; clypeus bearing several hairs, ultimate rostral segment bearing a long basal pair and a short subapical<tei:lb/>pair of setae. Forewing 1-92-2-06 times longer than wide, veins very sparsely clothed with very short setae,<tei:lb/>mi cell value 0-79-0-99, cu\ cell value 1-15-1-69; costal margin of hindwing with 1-2 setae proximal to<tei:lb/>costal break, setae distal to costal break clearly divided into two groups; forecoxa with a well-developed<tei:lb/>ventroapical spur; tarsal segments subequal. cf proctiger flask-shaped with weak basal expansions, the<tei:lb/>inner surface of each expansion bearing up to 22 thickened peg-like setae (Fig. 72) ; paramere and aedeagus<tei:lb/>as in Figs 73, 77 (trichaeta); $ genital segment short, triangular in profile, subgenital plate with a ventral<tei:lb/>transverse groove in apical third.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Measurements (10 cf , 10 $). Maximum width of head, cf 0-44-0-51, $ 0-46-0-57; length of antennal<tei:lb/>flagellum, cf and $, 0-65-0-80; length of ultimate rostral segment, cf 0-07-0-10, $ 0-09-0-11; length of<tei:lb/>forewing, cf 1-75-2-15, $ 2-07-2-55; length of hind tibia, cf 0-51-0-67, $ 0-56-0-71.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fifth instar larva (Figs 280, 281). Dorsal surface outline broadly oval, about 1-3 times longer than wide.<tei:lb/>Antennal flagellum unsegmented. Cephalothorax entire. Forewing pad about 0-47 mm long, humeral lobe<tei:lb/>extending forward but not as far as anterior margin of eye. Caudal plate about 0-6 times as long as wide,<tei:lb/>anus ventral and distant from posterior margin of abdomen, anus and pore ring as in Fig. 281. Marginal<tei:lb/>fringe consisting of moderately dense truncate sectasetae of varying lengths; postocular truncate sectasetae<tei:lb/>present; dorsum sparsely covered with truncate sectasetae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST PLANTS. Adults and larvae collected from Ficus ?gnaphalocarpa and Ficus sp. in Senegal,<tei:lb/>and Ficus sycomorus in Egypt (Moraceae). The larvae live in pit-galls on the undersides of the<tei:lb/>leaves.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Material has been examined from Cape Verde Is., Senegal, Egypt, Sudan and<tei:lb/>Saudi Arabia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. Pauropsylla willcocksi is very close to P. trichaeta. Adults of the two species appear<tei:lb/>to be almost indistinguishable, but males of trichaeta tend to have more peg-like setae on the<tei:lb/>inner surface of the lateral expansions of the proctiger (25-30 on each side as opposed to a<tei:lb/>maximum of 22 on each side in willcocksi). However, the larvae of the two species appear to be<tei:lb/>quite distinct (see Figs 280, 282).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Carmin (1951: 1-3) described two species, P. nussex and P. bikii, from Palestine, but the<tei:lb/>descriptions are not diagnostic from one another or from willcocksi and the type-material is<tei:lb/>apparently lost. In the BMNH collection are several adult specimens labelled 'Palestine, Drs. D.<tei:lb/>Scheinkin and J. Carmin, on Ficus sycamorus\ some bear the number S.108, others S.109. If<tei:lb/>these specimens are not part of the original syntypic series of nussex and bikii they certainly<tei:lb/>represent Carmin's two species. This material is indistinguishable from willcocksi. Recently</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>30 DAVID HOLLIS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>collected Pauropsylla specimens from Israel (Bet Dagan) on Ficus sycomorus, consisting of<tei:lb/>adults and larvae, do not resolve the problem. The adults are not distinguishable from willcocksi<tei:lb/>but the larvae are distinct from both willcocksi and trichaeta. They have the narrower dorsal<tei:lb/>surface outline and uneven marginal fringe of willcocksi, but lack sectasetae on the dorsal<tei:lb/>surface, as in trichaeta.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thus we have a series of populations of Pauropsylla species from South Africa, throughout<tei:lb/>Africa and extending into the Middle East. The adults of these populations are morphologically<tei:lb/>very similar but three distinct forms of larvae can be identified, and names are available for these<tei:lb/>three larval types. I have therefore decided to name those populations from Africa, south of the<tei:lb/>Sahara, on Ficus sur (= F. capensis) and Ficus spp. as P. trichaeta; those populations from<tei:lb/>Senegal, North Africa, Saudi Arabia and Cape Verde Is. on Ficus sycomorus and F. gnaphalo-<tei:lb/>carpa (H. C. D. de Wit in a personal communication, suggests these two species may be<tei:lb/>synonymous) as P. willcocksi; and the Palestinian populations on F. sycomorus, as either P.<tei:lb/>nussex or bikii or both.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pauropsylla trichaeta Pettey</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 4, 45, 75-78, 282)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pauropsylla trichaeta Pettey, 1924: 29; 1925: 137; Capener, 1970: 199. Holotype (? sex), SOUTH AFRICA:<tei:lb/>Tanzeen, Transvaal, on a native fig tree, associated with galls' (SAM) [not examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Adult. Similar in most features to P. willcocksi. Differs in that 25-30 peg-like setae are<tei:lb/>present on inner surface of each lateral expansion of the cf proctiger (Fig. 76).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Measurements (10 d", 10 &lt;j&gt;). Maximum width of head, cf 0-40-0-51, $ 0-44-0-56; length of antennal<tei:lb/>flagellum, cf 0-67-0-80, $ 0-63-0-80; length of ultimate rostral segment, cf 0-07-0-09, $ 0-08-0-11; length<tei:lb/>of forewing, cf 1-83-2-31, $ 2-12-2-77; length of hind tibia, cf 0-50-0-67, $ 0-53-0-69.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fifth instar larva (Fig. 282). Dorsal surface outline almost circular, about 1-2 times longer than wide.<tei:lb/>Antennal flagellum unsegmented. Cephalothorax entire. Forewing pad 0-64 mm long, humeral lobe<tei:lb/>extending forward but not reaching anterior margin of eye. Caudal plate about half as long as wide, anus<tei:lb/>ventral and distant from posterior margin of abdomen, anus and pore ring as in willcocksi (Fig. 281).<tei:lb/>Truncate tubular sectasetae forming an even dense marginal fringe, postocular tubular sectaseta present,<tei:lb/>sectasetae absent from dorsum.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST PLANTS. Adults and larvae collected from Ficus sur (= F. capensis) , Ficus spp. (Moraceae).<tei:lb/>The larvae from pit-galls on the undersides of the leaves.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Material has been examined from South Africa, Mozambique, Zimbabwe,<tei:lb/>Angola, Tanzania, Kenya, Uganda, Sudan, Cameroun, Nigeria, Ghana, Ivory Coast, Sierra<tei:lb/>Leone and Senegal.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENT. See under P. willcocksi.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pauropsylla tatrichea sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 79)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Adult. Very similar to P. willcocksi but larger. Glypeus with a pair of setae, ultimate rostral<tei:lb/>segment with a pair of small setae subapically. Costal margin of hindwing with 3-4 setae proximal to costal<tei:lb/>break. $ genital segment (Fig. 79) rounded triangular in profile, subgenital plate without ventral<tei:lb/>transverse groove, cf unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Measurements (3 $). Maximum width of head, $ 0-55-0-57; length of antennal flagellum, $ 0-79-0-88;<tei:lb/>length of ultimate rostral segment, $ 0-09; length of forewing, $ 2-77-3-08; length of hind tibia, $<tei:lb/>0-65-0-70.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Larva and host plant unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype $, Cameroun: Bamenda, 6.H.1957, yellow tray (V. F. Eastop) (BMNH; slide mounted).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. Cameroun: 1 $, same data as holotype. Ivory Coast: 1 $, 24. iv. 1969 (A. Pollet). (BMNH;<tei:lb/>slide mounted.)</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>AFROTROPICAL JUMPING PLANT LICE 31</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The fr/gemma-group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Defined by having highly modified antennae which are reduced in length, some of the<tei:lb/>flagellomeres bearing double rhinaria with bifid sensilla; anal pore of 9 with an incomplete outer<tei:lb/>ring of wax-producing cells. Three species are included: trigemma, ngongae and breviantennata.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pauropsylla trigemma sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 11, 80-82)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Adult. Integument with a dense covering of short setae. Median suture of vertex present and<tei:lb/>complete; antennal flagellum (Fig. 11) very short, 0-84-0-88 times as long as head width, flagellomere 2<tei:lb/>with a single rhinarium bearing a very short bifid sensillum, flagellomeres 4 and 6 each with a pair of<tei:lb/>rhinaria and each of these bears a long bifid sensillum, flagellomere 7 with a single rhinarium which bears a<tei:lb/>bifid sensillum of moderate length, both terminal setae on apical flagellomere long; clypeus with a pair of<tei:lb/>setae, ultimate rostral segment without setae. Forewing (Fig. 80) 2-24-2-26 times longer than wide, veins<tei:lb/>bearing short setae, m v cell value 0-94-1-04; fore coxa without a ventroapical spur; tarsal segments<tei:lb/>subequal. cf proctiger narrow tubular, without lateral expansions or thickened setae, paramere and<tei:lb/>aedeagus as in Figs 81, 82; 9 unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Measurements (2 cf). Maximum width of head, 0-48-0-55; length of antennal flagellum, 0-42-0-46;<tei:lb/>length of ultimate rostral segment, 0-06-0-08; length of forewing, 1-82-1-91; length of hind tibia,<tei:lb/>0-32-0-39.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Larva and host plant unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , Angola: Bruco, 26.ii.-2.iii. 1972, at light (D. Hollis) (BMNH; slide mounted).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratype. Tanzania: 1 cf , Kilimanjaro, Bismark Hut, 2,500-3,000 m, S. Mawenzi, at foot of high<tei:lb/>pasture, ii.1912 (Chr. Schroder] (MNHU; slide mounted).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. P. trigemma and ngongae are regarded as sister-species. They may be<tei:lb/>separated from one another by the shape of the forewing and the chaetotaxy of the forewing<tei:lb/>veins. Both species form the sister-group of breviantennata.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pauropsylla ngongae sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 29, 83)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Adult. Very similar to trigemma. Integument covered with long setae. Antennal flagellum<tei:lb/>0-77 times as long as head width, flagellomere 7 (Fig. 29) with a supplementary long conical sensillum<tei:lb/>adjacent to rhinarium. Forewing (Fig. 83) 1-79 times longer than wide, veins bearing long setae in proximal<tei:lb/>two-thirds of wing, cf unknown. 9 genital segment short, triangular in profile; subgenital plate with a<tei:lb/>truncate posterior margin which bears long setae, inner fold connecting ventral ovipositor valve sclerotised<tei:lb/>and extended as a triangular projection beyond posterior margin of subgenital plate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Measurements (1 9)- Maximum width of head, 0-48; length of antennal flagellum, 0-37; length of<tei:lb/>ultimate rostral segment, 0-05; length of forewing, 1-75; length of hind tibia, 0-46.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Larva and host plant unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype $, Kenya: Nairobi, June. Magadi-Langata Rd, c. 5,400', 26.vii.1974 (D. Hollis) (BMNH; dry<tei:lb/>mounted).<tei:lb/>Paratypes. 2 9 , same data as holotype (BMNH; slide and dry mounted).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENT. See under P. trigemma.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pauropsylla breviantennata sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 12, 84, 85)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Adult. Similar to P. trigemma. Integument covered with short setae. Median suture of vertex<tei:lb/>weak and incomplete towards occipital margin; antennal flagellum (Fig. 12) 6-segmented, 0-76-0-84, times<tei:lb/>as long as head width, two rhinaria present apically on flagellomeres 2, 3 and 4, a single rhinarium present<tei:lb/>on flagellomere 5, rhinaria of flagellomeres 2, 3 and 5 bear large bulbous sensillae, rhinaria of flagellomere<tei:lb/>4 bear bifid sensillae, rhinarium of flagellomere 5 with an associated conical sensillum, terminal setae of<tei:lb/>apical flagellomere of equal length, very long, about 0-75 times as long as whole flagellum. cf proctiger,</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>32 DAVID HOLLIS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>paramere and aedeagus as in Fig. 85; 9 genital segment damaged in specimen available, posterior margins<tei:lb/>of both proctiger and subgenital plate densely clothed with long setae.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Holotype, cf Ghana: Tafo, 29.V.1957 (V. F. Eastop) (BMNH; slide mounted).<tei:lb/>Paratype. Nigeria: 1 $, Mokwa, 6-12. ix. 1964, Moericke bowl (/. A' Brook) (BMNH; slide mounted).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. P. breviantennata is regarded as the sister-species of both trigemma and ngongae. It<tei:lb/>differs from both of these in that the antennal flagellum is even more reduced with the loss of<tei:lb/>flagellomeres 3 and 5, these being the non-rhinarium-bearing flagellomeres of the primitive<tei:lb/>antenna. In all three species, congruent with the reduction in length of the antenna, is the<tei:lb/>development of complex rhinaria and lengthening of the terminal setae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The septima-group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Defined by the complex form of the apical segment of the aedeagus and the emarginate posterior<tei:lb/>margin of the female subgenital plate. Two species are included: P. septima and P. proxima.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pauropsylla septima sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 86-89)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Adult. Integument sparsely covered with short setae. Median suture of vertex present;<tei:lb/>antennal flagellum 1-14-1-40 times longer than head width, rhinaria simple, apical flagellomere with one<tei:lb/>long and one short and truncate terminal seta; clypeus with a pair of setae, ultimate rostral segment with a<tei:lb/>pair of short setae. This species resembles those of the willcocksi-group in lacking a median suture on<tei:lb/>the vertex and having peg-like setae on the inner surfaces of the lateral expansions of the male<tei:lb/>proctiger, but differs in lacking a ventroapical spur on the forecoxa. It is readily distinguished<tei:lb/>from other Afrotropical Pauropsylla species by the proportions of the tarsal segments.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pauropsylla mistura sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 102-104)</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Measurements (3 cf , 6 9)- Maximum width of head, cf 0-50-0-51, 9 0-51-0-53; length of antennal<tei:lb/>flagellum, cf 0-62-0-64, 9 0-61-0-67; length of ultimate rostral segment, cf 0-07, 9 0-07-0-08; length of<tei:lb/>forewing, cf 2-49-2-64, 9 2-58-2-78; length of hind tibia, cf 0-58-0-60, 9 0-59-0-66.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>COMMENTS. P. mistura is larger than senegalensis, has the male paramere and aedeagus of a<tei:lb/>different shape, and a rounded conical female genital segment. It may be separated from<tei:lb/>angolensis on the form of the male genitalia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pauropsylla senegalensis sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 105- 108, 285, 286)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Adult. Integument granular, sparsely covered with very short setae. Median suture of vertex<tei:lb/>weak, evanescing before reaching occiput; antennal flagellum 1-06-1-27 times longer than head width,</tei:p>
