      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>AFROTROPICAL JUMPING PLANT LICE 35</tei:p>
         <tei:p>rhinaria simple, apical flagellomere with one long and one short and truncate seta; clypeus with a pair of<tei:lb/>setae, ultimate rostral segment without setae.          <tei:p>Measurements (7 d", 4 $).          <tei:p>COMMENTS. This species is very similar to mistura and angolensis, but it may be distinguished<tei:lb/>from these by its smaller size, the incomplete median suture of the vertex and the form of the<tei:lb/>male and female genitalia (Figs 105-108).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TRIOZA Foerster</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trioza Foerster, 1848: 67. Type-species: Chermes urticae Linnaeus, by subsequent designation of Oshanin,<tei:lb/>1912: 128.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Powellia Maskell, 1879: 223. Type-species: Powellia vitreoradiata Maskell, by monotypy. [Synonymised by<tei:lb/>Maskell, 1890: 167.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Phylloplecta Riley, 1884: 319. Type-species: Psylla tripunctata Fitch, by monotypy. [Synonymised by<tei:lb/>Tuthill, 1943: 546.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Phyllopecta Ferris, 1926: 16. [Misspelling of Phylloplecta Riley; Tuthill, 1943: 546.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Spam'ozaEnderlein, 1926: 400. Type-species: Trioza galii Foerster, by original designation. [Synonymised<tei:lb/>by Tuthill, 1943:546.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colopelma Enderlein, 1926: 400. Type-species: Trioza thomasii Low, by original designation. [Synony-<tei:lb/>mised by Tuthill, 1943: 546.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Siphonaleyrodes Takahashi, 1932: 48. Type-species: Siphonaleyrodes formosanus Takahashi, by original<tei:lb/>designation. [Synonymised by Mound &amp; Halsey, 1978: 252.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Only established synonymy is stated above but the following references, given under the<tei:lb/>synonymy of the family Triozidae (p. 8), contain regional revisions of Trioza: Vondracek,<tei:lb/>1957 (Czechoslovakia); Ramirez-Gomez, 1960 (Spain); Dobreanu &amp; Manolache, 1962 (Ruma-<tei:lb/>nia); Loginova, 1964 (European U.S.S.R.); Klimaszewski, 1973 (Palaearctic check-list); 1975<tei:lb/>(Poland); Sulc, 1910; 1911; 1912; 1913 (revision of Palaearctic species); Crawford, 1919<tei:lb/>(Oriental, Australo-oriental and Pacific); Mathur, 1975 (India); Froggatt, 1901 (Australia);<tei:lb/>Tuthill, 1952 (New Zealand); Zimmermann, 1948 (Hawaii); Crawford, 1914 (New World);<tei:lb/>Tuthill, 1943 (N. America); 1944 (Mexico); 1959; 1964 (Peru).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tuthill's argument (1943: 547) that Phylloplecta Riley is a nomen nudum is not accepted here<tei:lb/>as Riley's statement 'Phylloplecta tripunctata, which crumbles the tips of blackberry' makes<tei:lb/>clear he is referring to Psylla tripunctata and validates Phylloplecta Riley, 1884 under Article<tei:lb/>16(v) of the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>As the following species are here placed in Trioza on a temporary basis, a detailed description<tei:lb/>of the genus is of no systematic value. These species differ from Afrotropical species placed in<tei:lb/>other triozid genera as follows.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Median suture of vertex present and normally complete; genal cones, when present, not<tei:lb/>constricted basally. Propleural suture diagonal, episternum enlarged, epimeron reduced,</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>36 DAVID HOLLIS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>displaced ventrally and not in contact with lateral margin of pronotum. Forewing shape mostly<tei:lb/>elongate elipsoid and narrowing to a subangular apex, if with rounded apex then more than 2-3<tei:lb/>times longer than wide (exception T. guiera, p. 62); radular areas present only in cells m\, m 2<tei:lb/>and cu\\ claval suture reaching hind margin of wing some distance from apex of Cw lb . Ventral<tei:lb/>sense organs of hind femur in median position; basal tarsal segment of hind leg without apical<tei:lb/>spurs. Male proctiger unipartite.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>For the species treated below the grouped species are considered before those not placed in<tei:lb/>groups. The erytreae-group is dealt with first as it contains the major pest species and, probably,<tei:lb/>is most closely related to the type-species. Other species-groups are treated in descending order<tei:lb/>of apparent relationship to the erytreae-group. The ungrouped species are treated in alphabeti-<tei:lb/>cal order.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The erjtreae-group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A difficult group to define, the 10 species included having no single character which will delimit<tei:lb/>them from other Trioza species, and therefore the grouping may be artificial. The description of<tei:lb/>erytreae serves to define the group. The species included are: erytreae, catlingi, menispermicola,<tei:lb/>gregoryi, ata, kilimanjarica, tiliacora, carvalhoi, capeneriandeafra.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Known host plant families are Rutaceae, Menispermaceae, Araliaceae and possibly Sali-<tei:lb/>caceae. This is a rather wide range but there may be chemical similarities within these families<tei:lb/>(Thorne, 1976: 85; Dahlgren, 1977: 260).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trioza erytreae (Del Guercio)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 2, 7-9, 34, 35, 40-42, 49, 52, 54, 55, 109-111, 126, 127, 289, 290)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Citrus Psylla (Trioza); Lounsbury, 1897: 116.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>'Psyllidengalle'; Citrus aurantium; Riibsaamen, 1899: 266.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Aleurodes erytreae Del Guercio, 1918: 167. Syntypes, larvae, ETHIOPIA 'Eritrea' [not traced].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trioza citri Laing; Waterston, 1922: 49, 55. [Nomen nudum.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trioza merwei Pettey, 1923: 30. Syntypes SOUTH AFRICA 'Natal, Durban, on orange and Toddalia</tei:p>
         <tei:p>lanceolata" (SAM; USNM) [not examined]. [Synonymised by Pettey, 1933: 19.]<tei:lb/>Spanioza merwei (Pettey); Enderlein, 1926: 400.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Spanioza erythreae (Del Guercio); Boselli, 1930ft: 228; Pettey, 1933: 19; Harris, 1936: 498.<tei:lb/>Citrus Psylla (Spanioza erytreae} Del Guercio; Van der Merwe, 1941: 5.<tei:lb/>Trioza erytreae (Del Guercio); Capener, 1970: 200.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Only primary taxonomic references are quoted above. Further references on the biology and<tei:lb/>economic aspects of this species are given in the introduction (p. 4).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Adult. Integument sparsely covered with short setae. Head, in profile, almost at 90 to<tei:lb/>longitudinal axis of body, from above almost as wide as mesoscutum; occipital margin rounded; vertex<tei:lb/>pentagonal with anterior margin deeply incised by median suture, rounded down to frons, lateral ocelli on<tei:lb/>outer sides of raised tubercles, a shallow concavity present on either side of median suture; median ocellus<tei:lb/>not visible in dorsal view; frons completely covered by genae in anterior view; genal cones well developed,<tei:lb/>elongate conical with rounded apices; antennal flagellum 2-08-2-81 times longer than head width, head<tei:lb/>width to length of 1st flagellum in c? 1-26-1-70, in $ 1-30-1-82; a single rhinarium present subapically on<tei:lb/>flagellomeres 2, 4, 6 and 7, apical flagellomere with a long pointed seta and a short truncate seta apically;<tei:lb/>clypeus with a pair of setae, ultimate rostral segment with two pairs of setae. Thorax strongly arched;<tei:lb/>pronotum just visible from above, in profile strongly rounded down behind occiput. Mesopraescutum<tei:lb/>about as wide as long, its anterior margin strongly arcuate in dorsal view, in profile strongly downcurved to<tei:lb/>pronotum; forewing hyaline, elongate oval and narrowing to a rounded rectangular apex, 2-79-3-09 times<tei:lb/>longer than wide, radular areas elongate triangular, remainder of membrane devoid of spinules; veins<tei:lb/>bearing short setae, R branch acutangular, M branch distal to RsCu^ line, Cu stem 2-75^-20 times<tei:lb/>longer than Cu lb , mi cell value 1-10-1-38, cu\ cell value 2-56-3-71; forewing 1-59-1-82 times longer than<tei:lb/>hindwing, costal margin of hindwing with up to two setae proximal to costal break, setae distal to costal<tei:lb/>break clearly divided into two groups; hind coxa with a well-defined meracanthus and without anterior<tei:lb/>lobe ; hind tibia with a moderately developed basal spine , with one outer and three (rarely two) inner apical</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>AFROTROPICAL JUMPING PLANT LICE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>37</tei:p>
         <tei:p>spurs. Abdomen with setae on tergites 2 and 3 in cf , and 3 and 4 in $ ; cf proctiger (Fig. 109) with a laterally<tei:lb/>expanded basal part and a very short and narrow apical part; paramere as in Fig. 110; apical segment of<tei:lb/>aedeagus simple (Fig. Ill); $ genital segment (Fig. 127) short, conical, subgenital plate with a ventral<tei:lb/>bulge, ventral valves of ovipositor weakly serrate apically.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Figs 54, 55 Scatter diagrams comparing characters of Trioza erytreae, T. catlingi and T. menispermicola.<tei:lb/>54, adults, length of 1st flagellomere against head width. 55, larvae, number of sectasetae on forewing<tei:lb/>pad against length of forewing pad.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>38</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DAVID HOLLIS</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>AFROTROPICAL JUMPING PLANT LICE 39</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fifth instar larva (Figs 289, 290). Dorsal surface outline oval, about 1-5 times longer than wide. Antenna<tei:lb/>with 4-5 flagellomeres. Cephaloprothorax separate from rest of thorax which is entire. Forewing pad about<tei:lb/>0-8 mm long, humeral lobe extending forward beyond anterior margin of eye. Caudal plate about 0-65<tei:lb/>times as long as wide, anus ventral and distant from posterior margin of abdomen, anus and pore ring as in<tei:lb/>Fig. 290. Truncate tubular sectasetae forming a dense, entire marginal fringe, postocular seta absent,<tei:lb/>sectasetae absent from dorsum.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST PLANTS. Larvae, which form pit-galls on the lower surfaces of the leaves, and adults have<tei:lb/>been collected from Clausena anisata, Fagara capensis, Vepris undulata and Citrus spp.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Widely distributed in the Afrotropical Region and specimens have been ex-<tei:lb/>amined from Cameroun, Zaire, Angola, Ethiopia, Ruanda, Uganda, Kenya, Tanzania, Mala-<tei:lb/>wi, Zimbabwe, South Africa, Sao Tome, St Helena, Reunion and Madagascar.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. T. erytreae is the only member of this group known to develop on members of the<tei:lb/>Rutaceae. Apart from citrus I have collected adults and larvae from Clausena anisata in East<tei:lb/>Africa but Van Der Merwe (1941) records the insect from Vepris undulata (as Toddalia<tei:lb/>lanceolata), Fagara capensis and Clausena anisata (as C. inaequalis) in South Africa, stating that<tei:lb/>the last seemed to be the preferred host. Moran (1968) concludes that V. undulata and/or C.<tei:lb/>anisata were probably the indigenous host plants in South Africa.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Members of the erytreae-group are morphologically homogeneous and male genitalia charac-<tei:lb/>ters are not always species diagnostic. These characters can be used to separate erytreae from<tei:lb/>gregoryi (Figs 114, 115), kilimanjarica (Fig. 118), carvalhoi (Figs 122-124) and eafra (Fig. 125)<tei:lb/>but not the rest of the group. T. tiliacora is easily separated as it has setae on all abdominal<tei:lb/>tergites and a relatively broader forewing; capeneri has a lower cu cell value and a relatively<tei:lb/>longer hindwing; in ata the clypeus has two pairs of setae and a relatively shorter ultimate rostral<tei:lb/>segment. It is extremely difficult to separate catlingi and menispermicola from erytreae: in<tei:lb/>catlingi the first flagellomere is longer (head width to length of 1st flagellomere 1-06-1-23) and<tei:lb/>the marginal sectasetae of the 5th instar larva are less dense (Fig. 54); in menispermicola the<tei:lb/>adults appear identical to erytreae but the marginal sectasetae are less dense (Fig. 55). A<tei:lb/>summary of the characters used to separate members of the erytreae-group is given in Table 4.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trioza catlingi sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 54, 55, 112, 113, 291, 292)<tei:lb/>Trioza sp.; Catling, 1969ft: 220; McDaniel &amp; Moran, 1972: 299.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Very similar to T. erytreae. First flagellomere longer, head width to length of 1st flagellomere<tei:lb/>ratio in cf 1-06-1-23 and 1-11-1-25 in 9- Marginal sectasetae of 5th instar larva less dense (Figs 55, 291).</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Trioza tiliacora sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 119-121, 129, 293, 294)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Adult. Of similar general appearance to erytreae and catlingi. Integument slightly more<tei:lb/>densely haired. Genal cones less elongate; antennal flagellum 2-05-2-41 times longer than head width.<tei:lb/>Forewing with an even yellowish infuscation in mature specimens, 2-46-2-61 times longer than wide; veins<tei:lb/>with slightly longer setae; Cu stem 2-35-3-10 times longer than Cw lb ; m t cell value 1-08-1-26, cu\ cell value<tei:lb/>2-37-2-82. Abdomen with setae present on all visible tergites; cf genitalia as in Figs 119-121; $ proctiger<tei:lb/>slightly less elongate apically than in erytreae and subgenital plate with less pronounced ventral bulge.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Measurements (4 cf , 7 $). Maximum width of head, cf 0-40-0-42, $ 0-41-0-44; length of antennal<tei:lb/>flagellum, cf 0-92-1-0, $ 0-88-1-01; length of ultimate rostral segment, cf 0-10-0-11, $ 0-11-0-12; length<tei:lb/>of forewing, Cf 2-46-2-81, $ 2-61-3-09; length of hind tibia, cf 0-56-0-62, $ 0-54-0-62.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fifth instar larva (Figs 293, 294). Dorsal surface outline broadly oval, slightly emarginate posteriorly,<tei:lb/>about 1-4 times longer than wide. Antenna with 5-6 flagellomeres. Cephaloprothorax separated from rest<tei:lb/>of thorax which is entire. Forewing pad about 0-8 mm long, extending forward anterior to anterior margin<tei:lb/>of eye. Caudal plate about 0-56 times as long as wide, anus posteroventral (Fig. 294). Truncate tubular<tei:lb/>sectasetae forming a moderately dense marginal fringe but absent on posteromedial margin, postocular<tei:lb/>setae absent, sectasetae absent from dorsum.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST PLANT. Adults and larvae collected from Tiliacora sp. (Menispermaceae) in association<tei:lb/>with ants of the genus Technomyrmex . The larvae were causing severe leaf curl.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , Tanzania: E. Usambara Mtns, Amani Res. sta., 19-27. vi. 1974, c. 3,000', Tiliacora sp., in<tei:lb/>association with Technomyrmex sp. (D. Hollis) (BMNH; dry mounted).<tei:lb/>Paratypes. 5 cf , 13 9 , larvae, same data as holotype (BMNH; slide and dry mounted).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. Unlike other species in the erytreae-group, tiliacora has the chaetotaxy of the<tei:lb/>abdominal tergites in the primitive condition. Furthermore the anus of the 5th instar larva is in a<tei:lb/>posteroventral position which is normally regarded as a primitive state. However, in this case I<tei:lb/>believe it to be secondarily derived and associated with ant-tending.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trioza carvalhoisp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 122-124, 130,295,296)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Adult. In general appearance very similar to erytreae. Antennal flagellum slightly shorter,<tei:lb/>1-95-2-27 times longer than head width. Cu stem 2-19-3-06 times longer than Cw lb , cu v cell value 1-6-2-26;<tei:lb/>hindwing relatively longer, ratio of length of forewing to length of hindwing 1-42-1-54. cf genitalia as in<tei:lb/>Figs 122-124; $ subgenital plate without ventral bulge.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Measurements (13 cf , 19 $).          <tei:p>HOST PLANTS. Adults and larvae collected from Cussonia spicata, C. angolensis and C.<tei:lb/>paniculata. The larvae form pit galls on the lower surfaces of the leaves and cause severe leaf<tei:lb/>distortion.</tei:p>

Hollis) ; 7 cf , 7 $, larvae, 29.x. 1970, Cussonia angolensis; 1 cf, 4 $,i. 1971, vagrants (A. van<tei:lb/>Marten); 3 cf, 5 9 8. i. 1973, Cussonia angolensis (L. Amorim). L.<tei:lb/>Capener); 1 cf , 1 9, Swaziland, M.R.S., iv.1966, Cussonia sp. (R.C.H. Sweeney). (BMNH, NCI; NMK;<tei:lb/>slide and dry mounted, and stored in 80% ethanol.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trioza capenerisp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 297)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Adult. Very similar to erytreae and carvalhoi. Antennal flagellum 1-95-2-28 times longer<tei:lb/>than head width. Cu stem 2-27-3-40 times longer than C lb ; m t cell value 1-26-1-55, cui cell value<tei:lb/>1-91-2-45. Forewing 1-46-1-58 times longer than hindwing. cf genitalia not distinguishable from erytreae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Measurements (6 cf , 6 $). Maximum width of head, cf 0-38-0-41, 9 0-41-0-43; length of antennal<tei:lb/>flagellum, cf 0-79-0-91, 9 0-84-0-89; length of ultimate rostral segment, cf 0-09-0-10, 9 0-10-0-11; length<tei:lb/>of forewing, cf 2-54-2-80, 9 2-93-3-12; length of hind tibia, cf 0-48-0-51, 9 0-50-0-53.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fifth instar larva. Very similar to carvalhoi, anal pore area as in Fig. 297.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST PLANT. One sample of adults and larvae collected from Seemannaralia gerrardii (Ara-<tei:lb/>liaceae). The larvae were forming pit galls on the fruit.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , South Africa: Natal, vii. 1972, from pit galls on fruits of Seemannaralia gerrardii (A. L.<tei:lb/>Capener) (NCI; slide mounted).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. 13 Cf , 18 $, larvae, same data as holotype (NCI; BMNH; slide mounted and stored in 80%<tei:lb/>ethanol).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. The male genitalia of this species are very similar to erytreae but the cu\ cell value<tei:lb/>and relatively longer hindwing are similar to carvalhoi. Its host plant is a member of the<tei:lb/>Araliaceae and I am regarding it as the sister species of carvalhoi.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trioza eafra sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 125)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Adult. Very similar to carvalhoi. Differs in having shorter antennae, antennal flagellum<tei:lb/>1-62-1-97 times longer than head width. Forewing membrane covered with spinules except for narrow<tei:lb/>areas bordering wing veins; cui cell value 1-61-2-45; forewing 1-37-1-56 times longer than hindwing. cf<tei:lb/>paramere as in Fig. 125.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Measurements (11 cf, 10 9)- Maximum width of head, cf 0-35-0-40, 9 0-35-0-42; length of antennal<tei:lb/>flagellum, cf 0-59-0-71, 9 0-60-0-80; length of ultimate rostral segment, cf and $,0-08-0-09; length of<tei:lb/>forewing, cf 1-87-2-41, $ 1-99-2-70; length of hind tibia, cf 0-36-0-43, 9 0-36-0-47.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Larva unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST PLANT. Adults collected from Cussonia spicata (Araliaceae). The leaves of the host trees<tei:lb/>were heavily pitted but no larvae were found.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , Kenya: L. Naivasha, W. shore rd, c. 6,200', 21-22. vi. 197 '4, Cussonia spicata (D. Hollis)<tei:lb/>(BMNH; dry mounted).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. Kenya: 9 cf, 16 $, same data as holotype; 5 cf , 8 $, Thomson's Falls, path into gorge, c.<tei:lb/>7,800', 15-16. vii. 1974, Cussonia sp.; 1 9, Mt Londiani For., 57 km W. Nakaru, c. 8,500', 20. vii. 1974 (D.<tei:lb/>Hollis); 2 cf , 2 $, Muguga, vi.1953, trapped. Tanzania: 5 cf , 6 9, Nachingwea, xi.1953-iii.1954, trapped<tei:lb/>(V. F. ostop);3cf,69,E.UsambaraMtns, Amani-Muhezard, below Kiswani,c. 2,000', 21-24.vi. 1974,<tei:lb/>Cussonia sp. (D. Hollis). (BMNH; NMK; slide and dry mounted.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. This species is the only member of the erytreae-group to have retained (or reverted<tei:lb/>to) the primitive condition of having spinules on the forewing membrane. It has the relatively<tei:lb/>longer hindwing and low cu\ cell value of carvalhoi and capeneri and I regard it as the<tei:lb/>sister-species of this pair.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>AFROTROPICAL JUMPING PLANT LICE 43</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The /itseae-group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Very similar to the erytreae-group but body form and fore wings narrower, the hind tibia has two<tei:lb/>inner apical spurs and the female anal pore has a single ring of wax-producing cells. Two very<tei:lb/>closely related species are included: litseae and xylopia. Host plants of both are in the<tei:lb/>Annonales.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trioza xylopia sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 131-134, 298, 299)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Adult. Integument sparsely covered with very short setae. Head, in profile, almost at 90 to<tei:lb/>longitudinal axis of body, in dorsal view about as wide as mesoscutum; occipital margin rounded; vertex<tei:lb/>rounded pentagonal, strongly rounded downwards, with a deep median suture on either side of which is an<tei:lb/>irregular concavity, lateral ocelli on outer sides of raised humps; median ocellus not visible from above, in<tei:lb/>anterior view frons completely covered by genae; genal cones well developed, downward pointing, conical<tei:lb/>with rounded apices; antenna! flagellum 1 -97-2-53 times longer than head width, a single rhinarium present<tei:lb/>subapically on flagellomeres 2, 4, 6, and 7, apical flagellomere bearing one long pointed and one short<tei:lb/>truncate seta terminally; clypeus with a pair of short setae, ultimate rostral segment with a pair of setae.<tei:lb/>Thorax strongly arched; pronotum visible from above, strongly rounded down behind occiput; mesopraes-<tei:lb/>cutum, in profile, angled down to pronotum, in dorsal view anterior margin strongly arcuate; forewing<tei:lb/>elongate oval, narrowing to a subacutangular apex, 2-94-3-43 times longer than wide, membrane with<tei:lb/>spinules in all cells apart from c+sc and r l5 radular areas narrow, veins bearing very short setae, R branch<tei:lb/>acutangular, M branching distal to RsCui a line, Cu stem 1-78-2-17 times longer than Cw lb , m\ cell value<tei:lb/>1-09-1-38, cu\ cell value 1-73-2-19; forewing 1-54 times longer than hindwing, costal margin of hindwing<tei:lb/>without setae proximal to costal break, setae distal to costal break clearly divided into two groups. Hind<tei:lb/>coxa with a well-developed meracanthus, without anterior lobe; hind tibia with 1-2 small basal spines and<tei:lb/>one outer and two inner apical spurs. Abdomen with setae on tergites 2-3 in cf and 3-4 in $ ; cf proctiger<tei:lb/>(Fig. 132) roundly expanded laterally, paramere and apical segment of aedeagus as in Figs 133, 134; $<tei:lb/>genital segment short, conical, ventral surface of ventral valve of ovipositor smooth.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Measurements (7 cf, 6 $). Maximum width of head, cf 0-34-0-38, $ 0-36-0-41; length of antennal<tei:lb/>flagellum, cf 0-76-0-86, $ 0-75-0-84; length of ultimate rostral segment, cf 0-06-0-07, $ 0-07; length of<tei:lb/>forewing, cf 1-94-2-22, $ 2-34-2-59; length of hind tibia, cf 0-34-0-43, $ 0-41-0-44.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fifth instar larva (Figs 298, 299). Dorsal surface outline oval but with clear indentations at posterior<tei:lb/>margin of eye and at base of abdomen, about 1-75 times longer than wide. Antenna with four flagello-<tei:lb/>meres. Cephaloprothorax separate from rest of thorax which is entire. Forewing pad about 0-6 mm long,<tei:lb/>humeral lobe weakly extended forward to just beyond posterior margin of eye. Caudal plate about 0-7<tei:lb/>times as long as wide; anus ventral, a short distance from posterior margin of caudal plate, anal pore area as<tei:lb/>in Fig. 299. Narrow tubular sectasetae forming an even and moderately dense marginal fringe, postocular<tei:lb/>tubular sectaseta present, sectasetae absent from dorsum.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST PLANT. Larvae and adults swept from Xylopia sp. (Annonaceae) ; the larvae are apparently<tei:lb/>free-living as no evidence of galls was observed.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , Tanzania: E. Usambara Mtns, Amani Res. sta., c. 3,000', 19-27.vi.1974, Xylopia sp. (D.<tei:lb/>Hollis) (BMNH; dry mounted).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. Tanzania: 14 cf , 17 $ , same data as holotype. Kenya: 1 cf , W. slope Mt Kenya, Naro Moru<tei:lb/>lodge area, c. 6,500', 11-14. vii. 1974, Cussonia spicata (D. Hollis). (BMNH; slide and dry mounted.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. T. xylopia is very closely related to litseae and the two species can be separated only<tei:lb/>by the form of the 5th instar larvae (Figs 298-301). Both are similar to eafra (p. 42), in the<tei:lb/>erytreae-group , but have only two inner apical spurs on the hind tibia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trioza litseae Bordage<tei:lb/>(Figs 300, 301)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trioza litseae Bordage, 1898: 524; 1914: 409. Syntype[s] [? sex], REUNION: Litsea (Tetranthera) laurifolia</tei:p>
         <tei:p>[not traced].<tei:lb/>Trioza eastopi Orian, 1972: 4. Holotype cf , MAURITIUS: Litsea glutinosa (BMNH) [examined]. Syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Adult. Very similar to xylopia and, apart from its smaller size, not morphologically distinct<tei:lb/>from that species.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>44 DAVID HOLLIS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Measurements (5 cf , 8 9). Maximum width of head, cf 0-28-0-32, 9 0-30-0-34; length of antennal<tei:lb/>flagellum, cf 0-66-0-73, 9 0-61-0-70; length of ultimate rostral segment, cf 0-06-0-07, 9 0-07-0-08; length<tei:lb/>of forewing, cf 1-39-1-79, 9 1-78-2-06; length of hind tibia, cf 0-29-0-35, $ 0-31-0-36.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fifth instar larva (Figs 300, 301). Similar to xylopia but broader, about 1-5 times longer than wide in<tei:lb/>dorsal view. Forewing pad about 0-5 mm long. Anus ventral and distant from posterior margin of caudal<tei:lb/>plate, anal pore area as in Fig. 301 . Marginal setae consisting of a moderately dense fringe of broad tubular<tei:lb/>sectasetae of varying lengths; postocular tubular sectaseta present; dorsum with a sparse covering of<tei:lb/>sectasetae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST PLANT. Larvae and adults collected from Litsea glutinosa [= L. laurifolia]; the larvae<tei:lb/>damage the flower buds and flowers of the host; adults are also known to damage Vanilla.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED. Reunion (Litsea glutinosa); Mauritius (L. glutinosa and 'citrus'). Bor-<tei:lb/>dage's type-series was not traced and may have never been preserved. Orian's holotype and<tei:lb/>some of the paratypes, which are slide-mounted, are damaged in that the gum mountant has<tei:lb/>become opaque.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS (see also p. 43). Orian (1972) regarded Trioza litseae Gd as a nomen dubium and I<tei:lb/>have not been able to trace this description. However, Bordage (1898) described the work of this<tei:lb/>insect so the name Trioza litseae Bordage, 1898, becomes available under Article 16 (a)(viii) of<tei:lb/>the Code.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The anomalicornis-group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Defined by the form of the ovipositor (Fig. 138), otherwise the five included species, anomali-<tei:lb/>cornis, kakamegae, thibae, tavandula and luvandata, are similar to those of the erytreae-group.<tei:lb/>Two species are known to develop on Apodytes dimidiata (Icacinaceae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trioza anomalicornis sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 17, 135-138)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Adult. Integument sparsely covered with long setae. In profile, head moderately depressed<tei:lb/>from longitudinal axis of body, in dorsal view almost as wide as mesoscutum; occipital margins rounded;<tei:lb/>vertex pentagonal, gently rounded downwards, median suture clearly defined, lateral concavities weak,<tei:lb/>lateral ocelli on outer sides of strongly raised humps, frontal lobes absent; median ocellus visible from<tei:lb/>above, frons completely covered by genae in anterior view; genal cones elongate conical, slender, with<tei:lb/>narrowly rounded apices; antennal flagellum 1-84-2-0 times longer than head width, each flagellomere<tei:lb/>with a pair of long setae apically, apart from apical flagellomere which bears one long pointed seta and one<tei:lb/>large campaniform sensillum apically (Fig. 17), a single rhinarium present subapically on flagellomeres 2,<tei:lb/>4, 6 and 7; clypeus with one pair of setae, ultimate rostral segment densely setose. Thorax strongly arched;<tei:lb/>pronotum just visible from above, in profile strongly downcurved behind occiput and well below plane of<tei:lb/>vertex and mesopraescutum; mesopraescutum, in profile, strongly rounded down to pronotum, in dorsal<tei:lb/>view its anterior margin narrowly arcuate; forewing elongate oval and narrowing to rounded acutangular<tei:lb/>apex, 2-88-3-12 times longer than wide, radular areas narrow elongate, remainder of membrane devoid of<tei:lb/>spinules; veins bearing very short setae, R branch acutangular,' M branching distal to RsCu^ line, Cu<tei:lb/>stem 2-81-3-94 times longer than Cwi b , m t cell value 1-08-1-17, cui cell value 2-14-3-00; forewing<tei:lb/>1-88-1-98 times longer than hindwing, costal margin of hindwing with 1-2 setae proximal to costal break,<tei:lb/>setae distal to costal break clearly divided into two groups. Hind coxa with a well-developed meracanthus<tei:lb/>and without anterior lobe; hind tibia relatively long, 1-49-1-69 times longer than head width, with a pair of<tei:lb/>small spines basally and one outer and three inner apical spurs, the middle spur of the inner trio being less<tei:lb/>developed than the remaining two. Abdomen with setae on tergite 3 in cf , and 4 in $; cf proctiger with a<tei:lb/>greatly expanded basal part (Fig. 135), para'mere and apical segment of aedeagus as in Figs 136, 137; 9<tei:lb/>genital segment (Fig. 138) short, truncate, ventral valve of ovipositor with saw-like teeth on ventral and<tei:lb/>lateral surfaces, posterior margin of subgenital plate deeply incised ventrally.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Measurements (1 cf , 3 $). Maximum width of head, cf 0-38, 9 0-35-0-40; length of antennal flagellum,<tei:lb/>Cf 0-70, 9 0-70-0-76; length of ultimate rostral segment, cf and 9 0-09; length of forewing, cf 2-72, 9<tei:lb/>2-94-3-05; length of hind tibia, cf 0-59, 9 0-59-0-60.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Larva and host plant unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>AFROTROPICAL JUMPING PLANT LICE 45</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf, Nigeria: Ibadan, Moor plntn, 25-26. xi. 1957, yellow tray (V. F. Eastop) (BMNH; slide<tei:lb/>mounted).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. Nigeria: 1 9, vi.1956 (V. F. Eastop); 1 9, v.1959; 1 $, 2.vi.l961 (F. A. Squire). Cameroun:<tei:lb/>1 9, Bamenda, l.ii.1957, yellow tray (V. F. Eastop). (BMNH; slide and dry mounted.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENT. T. anomalicornis and the following four species described below seem to form a<tei:lb/>natural group, having a similarly derived ovipositor and a slightly thickened antennal flagellum.<tei:lb/>In other respects they resemble the erytreae-group. T. anomalicornis is easily distinguished by its<tei:lb/>antennal structure, the relatively short hindwing, the elongate hind tibia, the form of the cf<tei:lb/>proctiger, paramere and apical aedeagal segment, and the deeply emarginate $ subgenital<tei:lb/>plate. The remaining four species in the group can only be separated from one another on cf<tei:lb/>genital characters.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trioza kakamegaesp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 139-141, 302, 303)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Adult. Integument sparsely covered with moderately long setae. In profile, head depressed<tei:lb/>from longitudinal axis of body, in dorsal view as wide as mesoscutum; occipital margins rounded; vertex<tei:lb/>pentagonal, rounded downwards, without frontal lobes, median suture clearly defined, lateral ocelli on<tei:lb/>outer sides of raised humps; median ocellus visible from above, frons completely covered by genae in<tei:lb/>anterior view; genal cones elongate conical, broad, with broadly rounded apices; antennal flagellum<tei:lb/>2-05-2-47 times longer than head width, each flagellomere with a pair of short setae apically apart from<tei:lb/>apical flagellomere which bears a long pointed seta and a short truncate seta, a single rhinarium present<tei:lb/>subapically on flagellomeres 2, 4, 6 and 7; clypeus with a pair of setae, ultimate rostral segment with a pair<tei:lb/>of setae. Thorax strongly arched; pronotum just visible from above, in profile strongly rounded down<tei:lb/>behind occiput and well below plane of vertex and mesopraescutum; mesopraescutum with anterior<tei:lb/>margin narrowly arcuate in dorsal view and strongly rounded down to pronotum in lateral view; forewing<tei:lb/>elongate oval, narrowing to rounded acutangular apex, 2-69-2-86 times longer than wide; Cu stem<tei:lb/>2-89-3-51 times longer than Cu ib , m l cell value 1-18-1-29, cu^ cell value 1-74-2-48; forewing 1-55-1-65<tei:lb/>times longer than hindwing, costal margin of hindwing with 0-1 seta proximal to costal break, setae distal to<tei:lb/>costal break clearly divided into two groups; hind coxa with a well-developed meracanthus and without<tei:lb/>anterior lobe; hind tibia 1-16-1-36 times longer than head width, with a pair of small basal spines, with one<tei:lb/>outer and three inner apical spurs , latter of equal development. Abdomen with setae on tergite 3 in cf and 4<tei:lb/>in 9 ; basal part of cf proctiger (Fig. 139) weakly expanded, apical segment of aedeagus and paramere as in<tei:lb/>Figs 140, 141; 9 genital segment short, truncate, posterior margin of subgenital plate truncate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Measurements (6 cf, 5 9).          <tei:p>Fifth instar larva (Figs 302, 303). Dorsal surface outline broadly oval, about 1-4 times longer than wide.<tei:lb/>Antenna with four flagellomeres .          <tei:p>Measurements (3 cf , 1 9)- Maximum width of head, d" 0-40-0-41, 9 0-40; length of antennal flagellum,<tei:lb/>d" (incomplete), $ 0-85; length of ultimate rostral segment, d" 0-08-0-10, 9 0-09; length of forewing, d"<tei:lb/>2-83-2-86, 9 2-75; length of hind tibia, d 1 0-44-0-48, 9 0-44.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Larva and host plant unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype d", Angola: Tundavala, 9 mis NW. Sa da Bandeira, 5.iii.l972, swept (D. Hollis) (BMNH; slide<tei:lb/>mounted).<tei:lb/>Paratypes. 2 d", 1 9 &gt; same data as holotype (BMNH; slide mounted).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The neoboutonia-group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Defined by the relatively short 3rd flagellomere and the presence of only two inner apical spurs<tei:lb/>on the hind tibia. Females of this group show a tendency towards a reduction of the outer ring of<tei:lb/>wax-producing cells around the anal pore. Six species are included: neoboutonia, harteni,<tei:lb/>chiangae, bamendae, dinaba and nachingweae. Known host plants are in the Euphorbiaceae and<tei:lb/>Uapacaceae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trioza neoboutonia sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 14, 151-155,304,305)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Adult. Integument sparsely covered with short setae. Head, in profile, moderately depressed<tei:lb/>from longitudinal axis of body, in dorsal view narrower than mesoscutum; occipital margin subangular<tei:lb/>dorsomedially, rounded dorsolaterally and laterally; vertex pentangular, with an irregular concavity on<tei:lb/>either side of median suture, latter more strongly developed anteriorly, frontal lobes weakly developed;<tei:lb/>median ocellus just visible from above; frons completely covered by genae in anterior view; genal cones<tei:lb/>short, conical, in lateral view their longitudinal axis slightly depressed from plane of vertex; clypeus with</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>AFROTROPICAL JUMPING PLANT LICE 47</tei:p>
         <tei:p>one pair of setae, ultimate rostral segment with two pairs of setae; antennal flagellum 1-95-2-12 times<tei:lb/>longer than head width, 3rd flagellomere very short, ratio of length of 2nd flagellomere to 3rd 1 -76-2-35, a<tei:lb/>single rhinarium is present subapically on flagellomeres 2, 4, 6 and 7, apical flagellomere bearing one long<tei:lb/>pointed seta and one short truncate seta apically.          <tei:p>Fifth instar larva (Figs 304, 305). Dorsal surface outline oval, about 1-5 times longer than wide. Antenna<tei:lb/>with 5-6 flagellomeres. Cephaloprothorax separate from rest of thorax which is entire. Forewing pad about<tei:lb/>0-65 mm long, humeral lobe extending forward to just behind anterior margin of eye. Caudal plate about<tei:lb/>0-65 times as long as wide, anus ventral and distant from posterior margin of abdomen, anal pore area as in<tei:lb/>Fig. 305. Short, truncate, tubular sectasetae forming an even, dense marginal fringe; postocular seta<tei:lb/>absent; sectasetae absent from dorsum.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST PLANT. Larvae, which form pit galls on the lower surfaces of the leaves, and adults swept<tei:lb/>from Neoboutonia sp. (Euphorbiaceae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , Tanzania: E. Usambara Mtns, Amani Res. sta., c. 3,000', 19-27. vi. 1974, Neoboutonia sp.<tei:lb/>(D. Hollis) (BMNH; dry mounted).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. Tanzania: 10 cf , 8 9, larvae, same data as holotype; 1 9, yellow tray (BMNH; slide and dry<tei:lb/>mounted).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. Within this species-group neoboutonia displays the most derived condition of head<tei:lb/>and thorax structure, wing venation and abdominal chaetotaxy. Of the three known larvae in the<tei:lb/>group, that of neoboutonia is the most highly evolved and adapted to living in a pit gall.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trioza hartenisp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 156-158, 306, 307)</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Fifth instar larva (Figs 306, 307). Dorsal surface outline showing head, thorax and abdomen clearly<tei:lb/>defined, about 1-6 times longer than wide.          <tei:p>HOST PLANT. Larvae taken from large, enclosed galls on Uapaca nitida (Uapacaceae); adults<tei:lb/>reared from these larvae (van Harten, pers. comm.).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , Angola: Chinaga, 19.x. 1970, galls of Uapaca nitida (A. van Harten) (BMNH; slide mounted).<tei:lb/>Paratypes. 1 cf , 3 $, larvae, same data as holotype (BMNH; slide mounted).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENT. T. harteni displays primitive character states for the Cu stem and, therefore, a low cui<tei:lb/>cell value, and abdominal chaetotaxy. The larva is very non-triozid in general appearance but<tei:lb/>this is almost certainly due to the fact that it develops in an enclosed gall.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trioza chiangae sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 159-161, 308)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION (only slide-mounted material available for study). Adult. Very similar to harteni but smaller.<tei:lb/>Clypeus with a pair of short setae, ultimate rostral segment without setae.          <tei:p>Fifth instar larva (Fig. 308). Very similar to harteni.          <tei:p>HOST PLANT. Larvae and adults collected from Uapaca nitida (Uapacaceae); the larvae are<tei:lb/>free-living among unfolded leaves on the growing points (A. van Harten, pers. comm.).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , Angola: Chianga, 12. ix. 1973, Uapaca nitida (A. van Harten) (BMNH; slide mounted).<tei:lb/>Paratypes. 5 cf , 6 9, larvae, same data as holotype (BMNH; slide mounted).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENT. T. chiangae has a relatively long Cu stem and, therefore, a relatively higher cui cell<tei:lb/>value than harteni, but the chaetotaxy of the abdominal tergites is intermediate between harteni<tei:lb/>and neoboutonia. The free-living larva is relatively unmodified for a triozid.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>COMMENTS. T. nachingeae is distinguished from other members of the neuboutonia-group by the<tei:lb/>presence of brown pigmentation along the course of R and RI and at the bases of M and Cu on<tei:lb/>the forewing. This feature has apparently arisen independently in many groups of triozids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Aargreavesi-group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Defined by the extraordinary development of supplementary antennal rhinaria which have<tei:lb/>associated bulbous or mushroom-shaped sensilla (Figs 22, 23). Two species, hargreavesi and<tei:lb/>mirificornis , are included. Larvae and host plants are not known but original collection data<tei:lb/>suggest that the larvae of both species form pit galls on a forest climbing plant.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trioza hargreavesi sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 22, 173-175)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Adult. Integument densely covered with short setae. Head, in profile, almost at 90 to<tei:lb/>longitudinal axis of body, in dorsal view slightly narrower than mesoscutum; occipital margin sharp<tei:lb/>dorsomedially; vertex pentagonal, rounded downwards, with a deep irregular concavity on either side of<tei:lb/>median suture which is deep and well defined, frontal lobes not developed; median ocellus visible from<tei:lb/>above, frons just visible between genae in anterior view; genal cones small, rounded; antennal flagellum<tei:lb/>approximately 1-8 times longer than head width (no complete antennae in type-series), with a single<tei:lb/>rhinarium subapically on flagellomeres 2, 4, 6 and 7, 1st flagellomere with 30-35 rhinaria along its length<tei:lb/>(Fig. 22), each bearing a small mushroom-shaped sensillum; clypeus with a pair of setae, ultimate rostral<tei:lb/>segment with at least four pairs of setae. Thorax, in profile, strongly arched; pronotum, from above, hardly<tei:lb/>visible, in profile strongly rounded down behind occiput; mesopraescutum, from above, longer than wide,<tei:lb/>its anterior margin strongly arcuate and, in profile, strongly angled down to pronotum; forewing elongate<tei:lb/>oval, narrowing to rounded obtusangular apex, 2-36-2-45 times longer than wide, radular areas narrow and<tei:lb/>elongate, remainder of membrane devoid of spinules; veins bearing short setae, R branch acutangular, M<tei:lb/>branching distal to RsCui a line, Cu stem 1-24-1-72 times longer than Cw lb , m\ cell value 1-32-1 -6, cu^ cell<tei:lb/>value 1-78-1-98; forewing 1-66-1-77 times longer than hindwing, costal margin of hindwing with 0-2 setae<tei:lb/>proximal to costal break, setae distal to costal break clearly divided into two groups; hind coxa with a<tei:lb/>well-developed meracanthus and without anterior lobe; hind tibia with 2-4 small spines basally and with<tei:lb/>one outer and two inner apical spurs. Abdomen with setae on tergite 3 or 3 and 4 in cf , and on 4 or 4 and 5 in<tei:lb/>$ ; Cf proctiger with weak lateral expansions, paramere and aedeagus as in Figs 174, 175; $ genital segment<tei:lb/>short, conical, ventral valves of ovipositor regularly saw-toothed on ventral and lateral surfaces in apical<tei:lb/>half, subgenital plate short and with truncate posterior margin.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Measurements (5 cf , 5 $). Maximum width of head, cf 0-65-0-74, $ 0-69-0-76; length of antennal<tei:lb/>flagellum, $ 1-25 (approx.); length of ultimate rostral segment, cf and $ 0-13-0- 16; length of forewing, cf<tei:lb/>4-45-5-02, $ 5-02-5-42; length of hind tibia, cf 0-72-0-81, $ 0-81-0-84.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Holotype cf , Uganda: F. Kawanda, 14. ii. 1940, nymphs in pits in leaf of forest climber (H. Hargreaves)<tei:lb/>(BMNH; slide mounted).</tei:p>

      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>AFROTROPICAL JUMPING PLANT LICE 51</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. Uganda: 8 cf , 6 9, same data as holotype. Nigeria: 1 $, NE. State, Ngel Nyaki, 31.iii.1970,<tei:lb/>5,000'; 1 $, K[wara] State, 20 mis W. Lokaja, 21.iii.1970; 1 $, SE. State, Obudu CR, 21.iii.1971 (/. T.<tei:lb/>Medler). (BMNH; slide and dry mounted, and stored in 80% ethanol.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. T. hargreavesi and mirificornis are grouped together as sister-species because they<tei:lb/>both share the extraordinary development of multiple supplementary rhinaria on the antennal<tei:lb/>flagellum. At present I can find no further derived characters relating this group with other<tei:lb/>species in the genus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trioza mirificornis sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 23, 176, 177)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Adult. Very similar to hargreavesi but smaller. Flagellomeres 1-7 bearing many rhinaria,<tei:lb/>each rhinarium bearing a bulbous sensillum (Fig. 23), 1st flagellomere with about 60 rhinaria, 2nd with<tei:lb/>18-25, 3rd with 7-15, 4th with 5-20, 5th with about 11, 6th with about seven, and 7th with one, apical<tei:lb/>flagellomere with a long pointed seta and a short truncate seta apically; ultimate rostral segment with a pair<tei:lb/>of setae. Pronotum more clearly visible from above, anterior margin of mesopraescutum less strongly<tei:lb/>arcuate and less pushed forward, rounded down to pronotum; forewing narrower, 2-51-2-7 times longer<tei:lb/>than wide, Cu stem 1-70-2-32 times longer than Ci b , mi cell value 1-13-1-29, cu\ cell value 1-75-2-36;<tei:lb/>forewing 1-56-1-64 times longer than hindwing. cf paramere and aedeagus as in Figs 176, 177; $ subgenital<tei:lb/>plate with acutangular posterior margin, ventral valves of ovipositor smooth.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Measurements (7 cf , 4 $). Maximum width of head, cf 0-47-0-55, $ 0-51-0-60; length of antennal<tei:lb/>flagellum, cf 0-84 (only one complete specimen); length of ultimate rostral segment, cf and $ 0-08-0-10;<tei:lb/>length of forewing, cf 3-21-3-83, $ 4-17^-53; length of hind tibia, cf 0-54-0-65, $ 0-66-0-67.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Larva and host plant unknown. (The Uganda type-material of this species was found in the BMNH<tei:lb/>bearing similar data relating to larvae as the previous species.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , Uganda: F. Kawanda, 24.x. 1939, nymphs in pits in leaf of forest climber (H. Hargreaves)<tei:lb/>(BMNH; slide mounted).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. Uganda: 16 cf , 25 9 , same data as holotype. Cameroun: 1 9 , Bamenda, 6.ii.l957, yellow tray<tei:lb/>(V. F. Eastop). (BMNH; slide mounted and stored in 80% ethanol.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The obsoleta-group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A poorly defined group in which the species usually have greatly reduced hindwings, well-<tei:lb/>developed anterior lobes on the hind coxae and two inner apical spurs on the hind tibia. Five<tei:lb/>Afrotropical species are included: afrobsoleta, gonjae, boxi, afrosersalisia and mimusops, the<tei:lb/>latter two only tentatively. All five species have host plants in the Sapotinae (Ebenaceae and<tei:lb/>Sapotaceae). Another Afrotropical member of this group is represented in BMNH by five<tei:lb/>specimens, which are too badly damaged for description, standing under a Heslop-Harrison<tei:lb/>manuscript name.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A North American species, T. diospyri (Ashmead, 1881), is also known to develop on<tei:lb/>Diospyros. Although this species shows a general resemblance to those of the obsoleta-gToup<tei:lb/>and in particular to gonjae and boxi, its hindwings are more normally developed. It may<tei:lb/>represent the sister-species of the Old World group.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trioza obsoleta (Buckton, 1900), described from India, and Megatrioza swezeyi Crawford,<tei:lb/>1927, described from Samoa, clearly belong to this group; the South East Asian species Trioza<tei:lb/>asiatica Crawford, 1915 and Megatrioza magnicauda Crawford, 1919 probably belong here, but I<tei:lb/>have no material for examination. Trioza diptera Crawford, 1919, from Singapore, also has<tei:lb/>completely reduced hindwings but, from its description, this species appears to be more closely<tei:lb/>related to Leptynoptera sulfurea Crawford and both develop on Calophyllum inophyllum<tei:lb/>(Guttiferae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Earlier authors almost certainly would have placed all these species in Megatrioza but as I<tei:lb/>have not examined the type-species, M. armata Crawford, I am not sure of the status of the<tei:lb/>genus.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>52 DAVID HOLLIS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trioza afrobsoleta sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 13, 178-182)<tei:lb/>Tsyllidengalle'; Diospyros mespiliformis; Riibsaamen, 1899: 271 (Eritrea [series not traced].)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Adult. Integument shiny, sparsely covered with short setae. Head, in profile, strongly<tei:lb/>depressed from longitudinal axis of body, in dorsal view as wide as mesoscutum; occipital margin sharp;<tei:lb/>vertex pentagonal, rounded downwards, lateral concavities displaced posteriorly to occipital margin and<tei:lb/>greatly reduced, median suture weak; median ocellus hardly visible in dorsal view, frons small but visible<tei:lb/>between bases of genal cones in anterior view; genal cones in parallel plane to vertex, short, broadly<tei:lb/>rounded apically; antennal flagellum 1-66-1-94 times longer than head width in cf and 1-44-1-77 times<tei:lb/>longer in $ , a single rhinarium present subapically on flagellomeres 2, 4, 6 and 7, apical flagellomere with<tei:lb/>two long setae apically ; clypeus with a pair of setae , ultimate rostral segment with a pair of setae . Thorax , in<tei:lb/>profile, moderately arched; pronotum hardly visible from above, strongly downcurved behind occiput;<tei:lb/>mesopraescutum, in profile, strongly rounded down to pronotum, in dorsal view with arcuate anterior<tei:lb/>margin; forewing elongate oval, narrowing to a rounded obtusangular apex, 2-46-2-87 times longer than<tei:lb/>wide, radular areas very narrow and attenuate, remainder of membrane devoid of spinules, veins bearing<tei:lb/>short setae, R branch obtusangular, M branching at or slightly distal to Rs C la line, Cu stem 2-0-2-7<tei:lb/>times longer than Cw lb , m t cell value 1-97-2-41, cu^ cell value 1 -42-2-05, claval suture reaching hind margin<tei:lb/>of wing very close to wing base; hindwing (Fig. 179) greatly reduced, scale-like, costal margin bearing one<tei:lb/>seta proximal to costal break, setae distal to costal break clearly divided into two groups; hind coxa with a<tei:lb/>well-developed meracanthus and a moderately long anterior lobe; hind tibia with a group of 3-4 small<tei:lb/>pointed tubercles basally, with one outer and two inner apical spurs. Abdomen with setae on tergites 3-7 in<tei:lb/>O" and 4-8 in $ ; cf proctiger, paramere and aedeagus as in Figs 180-182; $ genital segment short, conical,<tei:lb/>ovipositor valves smooth.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Measurements (16 cf, 10 $). Maximum width of head, cf 0-42-0-56, $ 0-48-0-54; length of antennal<tei:lb/>flagellum, cf 0-74-0-93, $ 0-75-0-88; length of ultimate rostral segment, cf and 9 0-09-0-15; length of<tei:lb/>forewing, cf 2-75-3-79, $ 3-01-3-93; length of hind tibia, cf 0-59-0-78, $ 0-65-0-79.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fifth instar larva. Dorsal surface outline almost circular, about 1 1 times longer than wide. Antenna with<tei:lb/>six flagellomeres. Cephaloprothorax incompletely separated from rest of thorax which is entire. Forewing<tei:lb/>pad about 0-9 mm long, humeral lobe extending well forward of anterior margin of eye, hindwing pad<tei:lb/>greatly reduced and without sectasetae on lateral margin. Caudal plate about twice as wide as long, anus<tei:lb/>ventral and distant from posterior margin of abdomen. Truncate tubular sectasetae forming an even, dense<tei:lb/>marginal fringe, marginal sectasetae on cephaloprothorax longer than those on forewing pad and<tei:lb/>abdomen, postocular seta absent, sectasetae absent from dorsum.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST PLANT. Larvae, which form pit galls on the lower leaf surface, and adults collected from<tei:lb/>Diospyros mespiliformis (Ebenaceae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , Angola: Rocadas, R. Cunene, 19-22. ii. 1972, Diospyros mespiliformis (D. Hollis) (BMNH;<tei:lb/>dry mounted).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. Angola: 11 cf, 18 &lt;j&gt;, same data as holotype; 17 cf, 12 $, 3 mis N. Santa Clara,<tei:lb/>30.iii.-l.iv.1972; 1 $, Bruco, 26-29. ii. 1972, swept in riverine forest area (D. Hollis). Tanzania: 9 cf , 5 $,<tei:lb/>Nachingwea, x.l953-iii.!954, trapped (V. F. Eastop). Sudan: larvae, SW. side Jebel Marra, Wadi Golol,<tei:lb/>l.v.1981, Diospyros mespiliformis; 1 cf , swept, 28.iv.1981 (J. H. Martin). Nigeria: 1 cf , Bunga, 20.X.1956,<tei:lb/>Salix ledermanni (V. F. Eastop); 2 cf, Ibadan, 4.vi.l961, yellow tray; 1 cf, 2 $, 5-19.iv.1963; 1 cf,<tei:lb/>2.V.1963; 5 cf, 8 $, 3-9.iv.1964 (F. A. Squire); 1 $, B.P. State, Gindiri, 28.X.1968 (J. T. Medler); 1 cf,<tei:lb/>Zaria, Samaru, 24.xi.1970 (/. C. Deeming); 1 $, Lagos, Ikoyi, 7.iii.l975, at light (M. A. Comes). Ghana:<tei:lb/>1 $,Tafo,29.v.l957(V. F. Eastop). Ivory Coast: 2 cf, 1 ?, lO.iv. 1969 (A. Pollet). (BMNH; MNHN; slide<tei:lb/>and dry mounted and stored in 80% ethanol.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. This species is very closely related to T. obsoleta (Buckton, 1900) which is known<tei:lb/>from India and Ceylon on Diospyros melanoxylon and D. tomentosa. The Indian species differs<tei:lb/>in having a longer and slightly sinuous Rs, and the paramere has two sclerotised teeth apically<tei:lb/>instead of the transverse ridge as found in the Africa species. This latter point of difference,<tei:lb/>although slight, appears very consistent in all specimens examined. T. afrobsoleta shows<tei:lb/>considerable variation in the length of the ultimate rostral segment through its geographical<tei:lb/>range, that of specimens from Angola and Tanzania being relatively longer than in specimens<tei:lb/>from Sudan and West Africa.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>AFROTROPICAL JUMPING PLANT LICE 53</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trioza gonjae sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 38, 47, 183-187, 309, 310)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Adult. Integument sparsely covered with long setae (Fig. 38). Longitudinal axis of head and<tei:lb/>body in one plane; head, from above, almost as wide as mesoscutum; occipital margin sharp; vertex<tei:lb/>pentagonal, with an irregular concavity on either side of a well-defined median suture; median ocellus<tei:lb/>visible from above, frons not visible between genae; genal cones well developed, elongate conical with<tei:lb/>rounded apices, densely setose, in profile their longitudinal axis is slightly inclined upwards from that of<tei:lb/>vertex, in dorsal view cones slightly convergent apically; antennal flagellum 1-87-2-00 times longer than<tei:lb/>head width in cf and 1-68-1 -78 times longer in $ , a single rhinarium present subapically on flagellomeres 2,<tei:lb/>4, 6, and 7, apical flagellomere with a long pointed seta and a short truncate seta apically; clypeus<tei:lb/>prominent, with a pair of setae, ultimate rostral segment with two pairs of setae. Thorax, in profile, weakly<tei:lb/>arched; pronotum narrow and inclined vertically down behind occiput, just visible in dorsal view;<tei:lb/>mesopraescutum, from above, longer than wide and with a subangular anterior margin, in profile anterior<tei:lb/>margin angularly bent down to pronotum; forewing elongate oval, strongly narrowing to acutangular apex,<tei:lb/>2-98-3-29 times longer than wide, radular areas narrow, remainder of membrane devoid of spinules; veins<tei:lb/>bearing a few long setae in proximal third of wing, R branch a right-angle, M branching proximal to<tei:lb/>Rs-Cu^ line, Cu stem 2-36-3-21 times longer than Cw lb , raj cell value 1-91-2-08, ci cell value 1-96-2-63;<tei:lb/>hindwing greatly reduced and scale-like (Fig. 184); hind coxa (Fig. 47) with a well-developed meracanthus<tei:lb/>and a well-developed anterior lobe; hind tibia with a group of small pointed tubercles basally and one outer<tei:lb/>and two or three inner spurs apically. Abdomen with setae on tergites 3-7 in cf and 4 and 6-8 in $; cf<tei:lb/>proctiger, paramere and aedeagus as in Figs 185-187; $ genital segment conical, dorsal surface of dorsal<tei:lb/>valve of ovipositor finely serrate apically.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Measurements (5 cf, 4 $). Maximum width of head, cf 0-46-0-48, $ 0-47-0-51; length of antennal<tei:lb/>flagellum, cf 0-88-0-94, $ 0-81-0-91; length of ultimate rostral segment, cf 0-12-0-13, $ 0-12-0-15; length<tei:lb/>of forewing, cf 3-73-3-89, $ 4-01^-37; length of hind tibia, cf 0-70-0-77, $ 0-71-0-78.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fifth instar larva (Figs 309, 310). Dorsal surface outline elongate oval with clear indentations at anterior<tei:lb/>margin of eye and at base of abdomen, about 1-7 times longer than wide. Antenna 3-segmented (flagellum<tei:lb/>not divided). Cephaloprothorax separate from rest of thorax which is entire but does show partial<tei:lb/>separation of prothoracic sclerite (Fig. 309). Forewing pad about 0-9 mm long, humeral lobe extending<tei:lb/>almost to anterior margin of eye. Caudal plate about 0-75 times as long as wide, anus ventral and close to<tei:lb/>posterior margin of abdomen, anal pore area as in Fig. 310. Truncate tubular sectasetae of varying lengths<tei:lb/>forming a dense marginal fringe, a pointed postocular sectaseta or lanceolate seta present, dorsum bearing<tei:lb/>a sparse covering of tubular sectasetae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST PLANT. Larvae and adults swept from Diospyros squarrosus (Ebenaceae) ; no galling of the<tei:lb/>host plant was observed and the larvae are apparently free-living.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , Tanzania: S. Pare Mtns, hillside above Gonja, c. 3,000', 12-16. vi. 1974, Diospyros squarro-<tei:lb/>sus (D. Hollis} (BMNH; dry mounted).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. Tanzania: 11 cf, 10 $, larvae, same data as holotype; 1 $, ArushaNP,Ngurdoto Crater rim,<tei:lb/>c. 5,000', 8.vi.l974 (D. Hollis}. (BMNH; slide and dry mounted.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trioza boxisp. n.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Trioza afrosersalisia sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 190-193, 313, 314)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Adult. Integument sparsely covered with long setae. Head, in profile, slightly depressed<tei:lb/>from longitudinal axis of body, from above slightly narrower than mesoscutum; occipital margin sharp;<tei:lb/>vertex oval, evenly and smoothly concave and surrounded by a sharp, finely serrate ridge, integument<tei:lb/>within this depression shiny and devoid of setae, median suture just indicated; median ocellus just visible<tei:lb/>from above, frons completely covered by genae; genal cones moderately developed, conical, extending<tei:lb/>forward in parallel plane to vertex; antennal flagellum 1-75-2-00 times longer than head width, a single<tei:lb/>rhinarium present subapically on flagellomeres 2, 4, 6, and 7, apical flagellomere with one short truncate<tei:lb/>seta and one very short truncate seta apically; clypeus with a pair of setae, ultimate rostral segment with<tei:lb/>two pairs of setae. Thorax, in profile, weakly arched; pronotum hardly visible from above, in profile<tei:lb/>strongly rounded down behind occiput; mesopraescutum, in dorsal view, as long as wide and with a<tei:lb/>narrowly arcuate anterior margin, in profile strongly angled down to pronotum; forewing elongate oval,<tei:lb/>strongly narrowing to angular apex, 2-72-2-93 times longer than wide, radular areas very narrow,<tei:lb/>remainder of membrane devoid of spinules; veins bearing long setae in proximal half of wing, R branch<tei:lb/>acutangular, M branching at Rs C la line, Cu stem 3-29-4-38 times longer than Cw lb , m\ cell value<tei:lb/>1-77-2-07, cu\ cell value 2-47-3-38; forewing 2-14-2-32 times longer than hindwing, costal margin of<tei:lb/>hindwing with 4-5 setae proximal to costal break, setae distal to costal break clearly divided into two<tei:lb/>groups; hind coxa with a well-developed meracanthus and an incipient anterior lobe; hind tibia without or<tei:lb/>with a very small basal spine, with one outer and two inner apical spurs. Abdominal tergites without setae;<tei:lb/>Cf proctiger, paramere and aedeagus as in Figs 191-193; 9 genital segment short, conical, ovipositor valves<tei:lb/>smooth.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Measurements (7 cf , 4 $). Maximum width of head, cf 0-48-0-52, $ 0-49-0-54; length of antennal<tei:lb/>flagellum, cf 0-93-1-04, $ 0-86-1-01; length of ultimate rostral segment, cf 0-08-0-10, $ 0-10; length of<tei:lb/>forewing, Cf 3-40-3-71, $ 3-61^4-13; length of hind tibia, cf 0-70-0-73, $ 0-66-0-73.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fifth instar larvae (Figs 313, 314). Dorsal surface outline oval, about 1-4 times longer than wide.<tei:lb/>Antenna with five flagellomeres. Cephaloprothorax separate from rest of thorax which is entire. Forewing<tei:lb/>pad about 1 -0 mm long , humeral lobe extending well forward of anterior margin of eye .          <tei:p>HOST PLANT. Larvae and adults collected from Afrosersalisia sp. (Sapotaceae) ; galling of the host<tei:lb/>plant was not noticed at the time the series, including the holotype, was collected.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , Tanzania: E. Usambara Mtns, Amani Res. sta., c. 3,000', 19-27. vi. 1974, Afrosersalisia sp.<tei:lb/>(D. Hollis) (BMNH; dry mounted).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. Tanzania: 20 cf , 11 $, larvae, same data as holotype. South Africa: 1 $, C.P., Mossel Bay,<tei:lb/>ix.1921; 1 Cf , 3 $, vi.-vii.1930 (R. E. Turner). (BMNH; slide and dry mounted.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. T. afrosersalisia may be readily distinguished from other Afrotropical Trioza species<tei:lb/>by the peculiar form of the vertex. The species is tentatively placed in the obsoleta-group<tei:lb/>because of its reduced hindwings and the presence of an incipient anterior lobe on the hind coxa.<tei:lb/>Furthermore the host plant is related to Diospyros.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trioza mimusops sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 194-197, 315, 316)<tei:lb/>DESCRIPTION. Adult. Integument sparsely covered with long setae. Head, in profile, moderately depressed</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>AFROTROPICAL JUMPING PLANT LICE 55</tei:p>
         <tei:p>from longitudinal axis of body, from above narrower than mesoscutum; occipital margin sharp; vertex<tei:lb/>rounded rectangular, with a concavity on either side of median suture which is clearly defined, frontal lobes<tei:lb/>not developed but a low transverse ridge is present; median ocellus clearly visible from above, frons<tei:lb/>completely covered by genae in anterior view; genal cones well developed, rounded conical, in profile in<tei:lb/>parallel plane to vertex; antennal flagellum 1-54-1-83 times longer than head width, a single rhinarium<tei:lb/>present subapically on flagellomeres 2, 4, 6 and 7, apical flagellomere with one short and one very short seta<tei:lb/>apically, both of which are truncate; clypeus with a pair of setae, ultimate rostral segment with two pairs of<tei:lb/>setae. Thorax, in profile, moderately arched; pronotum clearly visible from above, only its anterior margin<tei:lb/>downcurved behind occiput; mesopraescutum, from above, wider than long, its anterior margin arcuate, in<tei:lb/>profile gently rounded down to pronotum; forewing elongate oval, narrowing to an acutangular apex,<tei:lb/>2-52-2-92 times longer than wide, radular areas narrow, remainder of membrane devoid of spinules,<tei:lb/>course of R and RI marked with brown pigment; veins bearing long setae in proximal third of wing, R<tei:lb/>branch acutangular, M branching distal to or, at most, at RsCu^ line, Cu stem 2-60-4-57 times longer<tei:lb/>than Cui b , m\ cell value 1-82-2-20, c^ cell value 2-00-2-93; forewing 1-99-2-17 times longer than<tei:lb/>hindwing, costal margin of hindwing with 2-6 setae proximal to costal break, no setae immediately distal to<tei:lb/>costal break and two curved setae adjacent to retinaculum; hind coxa with a well-developed meracanthus<tei:lb/>and an incipient anterior lobe; base of hind tibia swollen dorsally and bearing several small, blunt<tei:lb/>tubercles, with one outer and two inner spurs apically.          <tei:p>Measurements (6 cf, 6 $). Maximum width of head, cf 0-54-0-59, $ 0-57-0-61; length of antennal<tei:lb/>flagellum, cf 0-90-1-06, $ 0-88-1-00; length of ultimate rostral segment, cf and $ 0-09-0-10; length of<tei:lb/>forewing, cf 3-59-4-08, $ 3-93^-53; length of hind tibia, cf 0-61-0-79, $ 0-65-0-75.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fifth instar larva (Figs 315, 316). Dorsal surface outline very broadly oval, about 1-3 times longer than<tei:lb/>wide. Antenna with five flagellomeres. Cephaloprothorax separate from rest of thorax which is entire.<tei:lb/>Forewing pad about 0-62 mm long, humeral lobe strongly extended forward to anterior margin of<tei:lb/>cephaloprothorax. Caudal plate about 0-65 times as long as wide, anus ventral and distant from posterior<tei:lb/>margin of abdomen, anal pore area as in Fig. 316. Narrow, tubular, truncate sectasetae forming a<tei:lb/>moderately dense fringe on anterior margin of cephaloprothorax and caudal plate and a sparse fringe on<tei:lb/>the wing pads, postocular seta absent, sectasetae absent from dorsum.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST PLANTS. Adults and larvae collected from Mimusops obovata and M. zeyheri, adults only<tei:lb/>collected from M. caffra (Sapotaceae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , South Africa: Transvaal, Hartebeestpoort Dam, Bet El Park, 17.viii.1974, Mimusops zeyheri<tei:lb/>(B. R. Pitkin) (BMNH; dry mounted).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. South Africa: 14 cf , 12 $ , same data as holotype; 7 cf , 6 $ , larvae, Natal, Durban Botanical<tei:lb/>Gardens, 23.viii.1974, Mimusops obovata (B. R. Pitkin); 1 $, Port St John, Pondoland, l-ll.vi.1923<tei:lb/>(R. E. Turner); 5 cf, 9 $, Transvaal, Rustenburg, 20.ii.1965, Mimusops zeyheri; 5 cf, 8 $, larvae,<tei:lb/>27-30.X.1966; 5 cf , 5 $, larvae, ll-15.ix.1971; 1 $, ll-15.ix.1971, Fagara capensis; 15 cf, 11 $, Pretoria,<tei:lb/>Hartebeestpoort, 20.V.1965, Mimusops zeyheri; 3 cf, 3 $, 6.viii.l965; 2 cf, 2 $, Natal, Umtentweni,<tei:lb/>29.ix.1965, Mimusops caffra; 1 $, Umkomaas, 29.ix.-3.x.l965, Bersama lucens (A. L. Capener).<tei:lb/>(BMNH; NCI; slide and dry mounted and stored in 80% ethanol.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENT. This distinctive species is easily recognised by the shape, venation and pigmentation<tei:lb/>of the forewing (Fig. 194), and the unusual chaetotaxy of the abdominal tergites. It is tentatively<tei:lb/>placed in the obsoleta-group because the hindwing is only half the length of the forewing, the<tei:lb/>hind coxa has an incipient anterior lobe and the hind tibia has two inner apical spurs, and<tei:lb/>because of its host plant association.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The cocfcere///-group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>For a discussion of this group see p. 56.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trioza capensis sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 27, 53, 225-228)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Adult. Integument sparsely covered with short setae. Head, in profile, strongly depressed<tei:lb/>from longitudinal axis of body, from above narrower than mesoscutum; occipital margin sharp; vertex</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>56 DAVID HOLLIS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>trapezoidal, gently rounded down anteriorly, without frontal lobes or ridge, with a crescent-shaped<tei:lb/>depression on either side of the shallow median suture; median ocellus visible from above, frons visible in<tei:lb/>anterior view; genae slightly swollen ventrally ; antennal flagellum 1 -36-1-49 times longer than head width,<tei:lb/>a single rhinarium present subapically on flagellomeres 2, 4, 6 and 7, that of 2 with a large curved sense cone<tei:lb/>(Fig. 27), apical flagellomere with a moderately long and a short truncate seta apically; clypeus with a pair<tei:lb/>of setae, ultimate rostral segment with two pairs of setae. Thorax moderately arched; pronotum clearly<tei:lb/>visible from above; mesopraescutum, from above, much wider than long, anterior margin broadly arcuate,<tei:lb/>in profile shallowly rounded down to pronotum; forewing elongate oval, strongly narrowing to rounded<tei:lb/>rectangular apex, 2-44-2-57 times longer than wide, radular areas narrow elongate, remainder of<tei:lb/>membrane devoid of spinules; veins bearing very short setae, R branch acutangular, M branching distal to<tei:lb/>Rs Cui a line, Cu stem 3-54-4-71 times longer than Cw lb , m\ cell value 1-20-1-33, cu\ cell value 1-71-2-22;<tei:lb/>forewing 1-44-1-51 times longer than hindwing, costal margin of hindwing with 3-4 setae proximal to costal<tei:lb/>break, setae distal to costal break clearly divided into two groups; hind coxa with a well-developed<tei:lb/>meracanthus and a very small anterior lobe; hind tibia with a well-developed basal spine, a very<tei:lb/>well-developed preapical outer spur and two inner apical spurs (Fig. 53).          <tei:p>Measurements (2 cf , 3 &lt;j&gt;). Maximum width of head, cf 0-53-0-54, $ 0-50-0-52; length of antennal<tei:lb/>flagellum, cf 0-79, $ 0-68-0-77; length of ultimate rostral segment, cf and $ 0-09-0-10; length of forewing,<tei:lb/>Cf 2-31-2-38, $ 2-54-2-72; length of hind tibia, cf 0-38, $ 0-38-0-40.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Larva unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST PLANTS. Adults collected from Lycium salinicola and Lycium ? tetrandrum (Sola-<tei:lb/>naceae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf, South Africa: Cape Province, Aliwal North, xii.1922 (R. E. Turner} (BMNH; slide<tei:lb/>mounted).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. South Africa: 1 $, same data as holotype; 1 $, 25 mis SSE. Merweville, 2. v. 1972, Lycium ?<tei:lb/>tetrandum (D. Hollis); 1 $, Nuwerus, 10.xi.1971 (/. G. Theron); 1 CM $, OFS, Philippolis, Vaalbank,<tei:lb/>19-30. xi. 1969, Lycium salinicolum (A. L. Capener). (BMNH; NCI; slide and dry mounted.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. T. capensis apparently belongs to the same species-group as the New World<tei:lb/>Paratrioza cockerelli (Sulc, 1909) and the Palaearctic species of Paratrioza, which all develop on<tei:lb/>solanaceous hosts. The paramere is very similar to lycii Loginova, 1970, described from Georgia<tei:lb/>and Tadzhikistan, but capensis may be distinguished by the structure of the rhinarium on the 2nd<tei:lb/>flagellomere, the development and displacement of the outer apical spur on the hind tibia and<tei:lb/>the form of the apical segment of the aedeagus. Furthermore capensis completely lacks genal<tei:lb/>cones and has a more primitive form of thorax, the Paratrioza species having the mesopraescu-<tei:lb/>tum more produced anteriorly.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Previous authors would have placed this species in Paratrioza but I am not sure of the validity<tei:lb/>of the genus and prefer to place capensis under Trioza.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The etfeiMiei'-group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A distinctive group of small species defined by the absence of genal cones, bifid sensilla<tei:lb/>associated with the antennal rhinaria, forewing with a broadly rounded apex, reduced meracan-<tei:lb/>thi and a 3-segmented (at least partially) aedeagus. Six species are included: etiennei, messarati-<tei:lb/>na, seranistama, nestasimara, camerounensis and pitkini. Host plants, both members of the<tei:lb/>Sapotaceae, are known for two of the species, and the only known larva, that of etiennei, is very<tei:lb/>distinctive (Fig. 317).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trioza etiennei sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 46, 50, 198-201, 317, 318)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Adult. Integument sparsely covered with very short setae.          <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>AFROTROPICAL JUMPING PLANT LICE 57</tei:p>
         <tei:p>latter not visible from above, frons visible in anterior view; genae smooth, rounded, without trace of cones;<tei:lb/>antennal flagellum short, 1-06-1-23 times longer than head width, a single subapical rhinarium present on<tei:lb/>flagellomeres 2, 4, 6 and 7, the proximal three each with a bifid sensillum, the distal one with a short conical<tei:lb/>sensillum, apical flagellomere with two long setae apically; clypeus with a pair of setae, ultimate rostral<tei:lb/>segment with two pairs of setae.          <tei:p>COMMENT. T. etiennei and messaratina seem to be a sister pair, distinguished from the rest of the<tei:lb/>group by the presence of tubercles or projections on the pronotum. The two species may be<tei:lb/>separated from one another by the characters given in key couplet 23.</tei:p>

The specimen upon which this species is based was collected in the same yellow tray,<tei:lb/>during the same period as the type-series of seranistama and, possibly, it is an aberrant<tei:lb/>specimen of the latter. However, it would be most unusual for a psyllid species to have such<tei:lb/>variable antennal and cf genitalia structure, and for this reason two species are recognised here.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>The g/aftea-group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Differs from the etiennei-group in that the aedeagus is 2-segmented with the apical segment<tei:lb/>thickened basally, and the forewing has a rounded acutangular apex. Two species, glabea and<tei:lb/>usambarica, are included but larvae and host plants are unknown.</tei:p>
