         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>60 DAVID HOLLIS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>heavily sclerotised and bilobed base; $ genital segment short, conical, dorsal surface of dorsal valve of<tei:lb/>ovipositor weakly serrate apically.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Measurements (1 cf , 1 $). Maximum width of head, cf 0-40, $ 0-44; length of antennal flagellum, cf<tei:lb/>0-68, $ 0-71; length of ultimate rostral segment, cf 0-10, $ 0-11; length of forewing, cf 2-48, $ 2-82; length<tei:lb/>of hind tibia, Cf and $0-39.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Larva and host plant unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , Angola: 7 mis W Gabela, 16-18.iii.1972, at light (D. Hollis} (BMNH; slide mounted).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. Angola: 1 $ , same data as holotype. Zaire ('Congo Beige'): 1 $ , P.N.G. , Miss. H. de Saeger,<tei:lb/>Pidigala, 23. iv. 1952 (H. de Saeger). (BMNH; MRAC; slide mounted.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. T. glabea and usambarica are obviously closely related and I regard them as a sister<tei:lb/>pair. Both lack genal cones, have bifid sensilla on the antennal rhinaria, and the apical segment<tei:lb/>of the aedeagus has a thickened base. The presence of bifid sensilla suggests a possible<tei:lb/>sister-group relationship with the etiennei-group.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A third species belonging to this group is represented by four specimens, from Zaire,<tei:lb/>deposited in MRAC, but this material is too badly damaged for description.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trioza usambarica sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 223, 224)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Adult. Very similar to glabea. Integument more densely covered with slightly longer setae.<tei:lb/>Antennal flagellum 1-54 times longer than head width. Forewing with r 2 devoid of spinules; veins bearing<tei:lb/>slightly longer setae, Cu stem 0-66-0-73 times as long as C lb , mi cell value 1-57-1-58, cu\ cell value<tei:lb/>0-74-0-86. cf paramere and aedeagus as in Figs 223, 224, apical segment of aedeagus with a less expanded<tei:lb/>base; dorsal surface of dorsal valve of ovipositor smooth.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Measurements (1 cf , 1 $). Maximum width of head, cf 0-46, $ 0-51; length of antennal flagellum, cf<tei:lb/>0-71 ($ damaged); length of ultimate rostral segment, cf 0-13, $ 0-14; length of forewing, cf 2-64, $ 2-95;<tei:lb/>length of hind tibia, cf 0-41, $ 0-44.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Larva and host plant unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , Tanzania: E. Usambara Mtns, Amani Res. sta., c. 3,000', 19-27. vi. 1974, yellow tray (D.<tei:lb/>Hollis) (BMNH; slide mounted).<tei:lb/>Paratype. Tanzania: 1 cf , similar data as holotype but swept (BMNH; slide mounted).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ungrouped species</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Twelve species are described in this section. Some may be grouped together in pairs on the basis<tei:lb/>of overall similarity due to common possession of characters in the primitive state. The species<tei:lb/>are ordered alphabetically and each may represent a distinct species-group.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trioza ficiola sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 229-232, 319, 320)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION (only slide-mounted material available for study). Adult. Integument sparsely covered with<tei:lb/>moderately long setae. Head with broadly conoid, well-developed genal cones; antennal flagellum<tei:lb/>1-27-1 -35 times longer than head width, a single rhinarium present subapically on flagellomeres 2, 4, 6 and<tei:lb/>7, apical flagellomere with one long and one short and truncate seta apically; clypeus with a pair of setae,<tei:lb/>ultimate rostral segment with several pairs of setae. Forewing elongate elipsoid, strongly narrowing distally<tei:lb/>to a rounded obtusangular apex, 2-52-2-92 times longer than wide, radular areas narrow triangular,<tei:lb/>remainder of membrane devoid of spinules; veins bearing short setae, R branch acutangular, M branch<tei:lb/>distal to Rs-Cu { . d line, Cu stem 1-21-1-53 times longer than Cw lb , m { cell value 1-53-1-64, cw t cell value<tei:lb/>1-67-2-20; forewing 1-73-1-78 times longer than hindwing, costal margin of hindwing with 0-2 setae<tei:lb/>proximal to costal break, setae distal to costal break weakly divided into two groups; hind coxa with a<tei:lb/>well-developed meracanthus and without anterior lobe; hind tibia with a weak basal tubercle bearing<tei:lb/>several small conical spines, with one outer and three inner apical spurs. Abdomen with setae on tergites 2<tei:lb/>and 3 in cf , and 3 and 4 in 9 ; Cf proctiger, paramere and aedeagus as in Figs 230-232; $ genital segment<tei:lb/>very short, conoid, subgenital plate truncate apically, ventral surface of ventral valve of ovipositor saw-like<tei:lb/>and dorsal surface serrate apically.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>AFROTROPICAL JUMPING PLANT LICE 61</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Measurements (3 cf, 1 $). Maximum width of head, cf 0-62-0-66, $ 0-66; length of antennalflagellum,<tei:lb/>Cf 0-86-0-89, $ 0-84; length of ultimate rostral segment, cf and $ 0-11; length of forewing, cf 4-01-4-11, $<tei:lb/>4-40; length of hind tibia, cf 0-64-0-65, 0-64.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fifth instar larva (Figs 319, 320). Dorsal surface outline almost circular, about 1-1 times longer than<tei:lb/>wide. Antenna about 0-3 mm long (segmentation not clear in specimens available). Cephaloprothorax<tei:lb/>separated from rest of thorax which is entire. Forewing pad 0-92 mm long, humeral lobe extended forward<tei:lb/>beyond anterior margin of eye. Caudal plate about 0-5 times as long as wide, anus ventral and distant from<tei:lb/>posterior margin of abdomen, anal pore area as in Fig. 320. Elongate truncate tubular sectasetae forming a<tei:lb/>dense, entire marginal fringe, post-ocular seta absent, sectasetae absent from dorsum.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST PLANT. Adults and larvae collected from Ficus sp. (Moraceae). There is no information as<tei:lb/>to whether or not the larvae form pit galls on the host plant but this is highly likely judging from<tei:lb/>their shape and the arrangement of sectasetae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf, Mozambique: Musape River Valley, 7.vii.l968, Ficus sp. (C. J. Hodgeson) (NCI; slide<tei:lb/>mounted).<tei:lb/>Paratypes. 2 cf , 1 $ , larvae, same data as holotype (NCI; BMNH; slide mounted).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. Apart from the male paramere and aedeagus this species has few diagnostic<tei:lb/>features. It resembles species of the erytreae-group but the venation of the forewing has a higher<tei:lb/>mi cell value and a lower cu\ cell value, and the structure of the female ovipositor is more derived<tei:lb/>than that of other members of the group.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trioza fuscivena sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 233-236)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Adult. Integument sparsely covered with moderately long hairs. Head, in profile, slightly<tei:lb/>depressed from longitudinal axis of body, from above at least as wide as mesoscutum; occipital margin<tei:lb/>obtuse; vertex flattened but deeply divided anteriorly by median suture, frontal lobes weakly developed;<tei:lb/>median ocellus not visible from above, frons just visible in anterior view; genal cones narrow, conical, well<tei:lb/>developed, in profile depressed strongly from plane of vertex; antennal flagellum 1-59-1-98 times longer<tei:lb/>than head width, a single rhinarium present subapically on flagellomeres 2, 4, 6 and 7, apical flagellomere<tei:lb/>with two subequal terminal setae, the shorter with a truncate apex; clypeus with a pair of setae, ultimate<tei:lb/>rostral segment with two pairs of setae. Thorax weakly arched; pronotum, from above, with a rhomboid<tei:lb/>dorsal disc and narrowing strongly on each side; mesopraescutum, from above, longer than wide, anterior<tei:lb/>margin strongly arcuate, in profile strongly rounded down to pronotum; forewing elongate elipsoid,<tei:lb/>narrowing to rounded acutangular apex, 2-65-2-92 times longer than wide, membrane devoid of spinules<tei:lb/>apart from narrow triangular radular areas, course of R stem and R\ and bases of M stem and Cu stem<tei:lb/>brown pigmented; veins sparsely clothed with moderately long hairs in basal half of wing, R branch<tei:lb/>acutangular, M branch distal to /?s-Cw la line, Cu stem 1-51-1-77 times longer than Cw lb , mi cell value<tei:lb/>1-07-1-26, cu\ cell value 1-86-2-08; forewing 1-66-1-78 times longer than hindwing, costal margin of<tei:lb/>hindwing with 4-7 setae proximal to costal break, setae distal to costal break sparse but clearly divided into<tei:lb/>two groups; hind coxa with a well-developed meracanthus and without anterior lobe; hind tibia with 3-4<tei:lb/>small but clearly developed spines, with one outer and two inner apical spurs. Abdomen with setae on<tei:lb/>tergite 3 in cf , and tergite 4 in $ ; cf proctiger very weakly expanded laterally, paramere and aedeagus as in<tei:lb/>Figs 234, 235; 9 genital segment (Fig. 236) short, conoid, proctiger strongly downcurved apically,<tei:lb/>subgenital plate with truncate posterior margin, lower valve of ovipositor with three dorsolateral<tei:lb/>transverse ridges apically.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Measurements (4 cf , 2 $). Maximum width of head, cf 0-50-0-54, $ 0-54-0-56; length of antennal<tei:lb/>flagellum, cf 0-94-1-05, $ 0-86-0-93; length of ultimate rostral segment, cf 0-07, $ 0-08; length of<tei:lb/>forewing, cf 3-25-3-46, 9 3-76-3-89; length of hind tibia, cf 0-66-0-70, $ 0-68-0-70.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Larva and host plant unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , Cameroun: Bamenda, i-ii.1957, yellow trays (V. F. Eastop) (BMNH; slide mounted).<tei:lb/>Paratypes. 4 cf , 2 9 , same data as holotype (BMNH; slide and dry mounted).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENT. This species is superficially similar to nachingweae (p. 49), principally because of the<tei:lb/>forewing pigmentation. However, the third flagellomere is not greatly reduced and fuscivena is<tei:lb/>not considered a member of the neoboutonia-group. Other differences from nachingweae may</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>62 DAVID HOLLIS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>be found in the short ultimate rostral segment, the longer setae on the fore wing veins and the<tei:lb/>form of the male and female genitalia (Figs 234-236). No close association with any other species<tei:lb/>can be found.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Triozaghanaensissp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 28, 237-240)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Adult. Integument sparsely covered with very short setae. Head, from above, almost as wide<tei:lb/>as mesoscutum, in profile depressed at 90 from longitudinal axis of body; vertex pentagonal, flattened<tei:lb/>dorsally, rounded down to frons, with sharp occipital margins and clearly defined median suture, lateral<tei:lb/>concavities weak, frontal lobes absent; median ocellus not visible from above, frons just visible in anterior<tei:lb/>view; genae rounded, without cones; antennal flagellum 1-44-1 -47 times longer than head width, a single<tei:lb/>rhinarium present subapically on flagellomeres 2, 4, 6 and 7, those on 2 and 7 with an oval sense cone, those<tei:lb/>on 4 and 6 each with a long bifid sense cone, apical flagellomere with two long subequal terminal setae;<tei:lb/>clypeus with a pair of setae, ultimate rostral segment with two pairs of setae. Thorax strongly arched;<tei:lb/>pronotum strongly curved down behind occiput; mesopraescutum, from above, almost as long as wide,<tei:lb/>anterior margin broadly arcuate and strongly rounded down to pronotum; forewing elongate elipsoid,<tei:lb/>strongly narrowing to obtusangular apex, 2-54-2-55 times longer than wide, radular areas elongate and<tei:lb/>narrow, rest of membrane devoid of spinules apart from small area at base of claval suture; veins bearing<tei:lb/>short setae, R branch acutangular, M branch proximal to RsCu\ &amp; line, Cu stem 0-36-0-42 times as long as<tei:lb/>Cu lb , mi cell value 2-09-2-34, cui cell value 0-75-0-82; forewing 1-74-1-80 times longer than hindwing,<tei:lb/>costal margin of hindwing with 3-6 setae proximal to costal break, 10-12 setae immediately distal to costal<tei:lb/>break and 4-6 setae adjacent to retinaculum; hind coxa with a well-developed meracanthus and without<tei:lb/>anterior lobe; hind tibia with a pair of unequally developed basal tubercles and one outer and two inner<tei:lb/>apical spurs. Abdomen with setae on tergites 2 and 3 in cf and 3 and 4 in $ ; cf proctiger, paramere and<tei:lb/>aedeagus as in Figs 238-240; 9 genital segment conical, dorsal valves of ovipositor serrate apically.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Measurements (2 cf , 2 &lt;j&gt;).          <tei:p>Trioza guiera sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 241-244, 321, 322)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Adult. Integument covered with moderately long setae. Head, in profile, slightly depressed<tei:lb/>from longitudinal axis of body, from above slightly narrower than mesoscutum; occipital margin sharp;<tei:lb/>vertex with anterior margin incised by median suture, latter with an irregular concavity on either side<tei:lb/>dorsofrontally; median ocellus visible from above, frons visible in anterior view; genal cones very short,<tei:lb/>rounded; antennal flagellum short, 0-9-1-21 times as long as head width, a single rhinarium present<tei:lb/>subapically on flagellomeres 2, 4, 6 and 7, apical flagellomere.with a long pointed seta and a short truncate<tei:lb/>seta terminally; clypeus with a pair of weak setae, ultimate rostral segment long, devoid of setae.          <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>AFROTROPICAL JUMPING PLANT LICE 63</tei:p>
         <tei:p>tibia with a group of 2-3 very small spines basally and without strongly developed apical spurs. Abdomen<tei:lb/>with setae on tergites 2-7 in cf and 3-8 in 9 ; Cf proctiger, paramere and aedeagus as in Figs 242-244; $<tei:lb/>genital segment short, conical, apex of proctiger upcurved and hook-like, valves of ovipositor smooth.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Measurements (10 cf , 10 $). Maximum width of head, cf 0-40-0-45, 9 0-43-0-47; length of antennal<tei:lb/>flagellum, cf 0-37-0-51, $ 0-41-0-50; length of ultimate rostral segment, cf 0-10-0-13, $ 0-11-0-13; length<tei:lb/>of forewing, cf 1-62-1-84, $ 1-86-2-14; length of hind tibia, cf 0-27-0-31, $ 0-30-0-34.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fifth instar larva (Figs 321, 322). Dorsal surface outline oval, about 1-4 times longer than wide, with<tei:lb/>indentations on either side at posterior margin of eye and at base of abdomen, posterior margin of<tei:lb/>abdomen with a deep indentation medially. Antenna with 4-5 flagellomeres. Cephaloprothorax separate<tei:lb/>from rest of thorax which is entire. Forewing pad about 0-37 mm long, humeral lobe weakly extending<tei:lb/>forward to posterior margin of eye. Caudal plate about 0-65 times as long as wide, anus apico-dorsal, anal<tei:lb/>pore area as in Fig. 322. Pointed conical sectasetae of unequal length forming an uneven dense marginal<tei:lb/>fringe interrupted posteromedially; blunt conical sectasetae present on either side of dorsal mid line from<tei:lb/>cephaloprothoracic suture to posterior margin of abdomen; a single conical sectaseta present on each<tei:lb/>lateral margin of the abdominal tergite immediately anterior to caudal plate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST PLANT. Adults and larvae collected from Guiera senegalensis (Combretaceae). The larvae<tei:lb/>are apparently free-living and one sample collected was associated with a species of the ant genus<tei:lb/>Crematogaster .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf, Senegal: Manpalago, 12.55N/16.00W, 13. i. 1981, Guiera senegalensis (J. Etienne} (BMNH;<tei:lb/>dry mounted).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. Senegal: 43 cf , 31 $, larvae, same data as holotype; 7 cf , 7 $, numerous larvae, Goudemp,<tei:lb/>23. vi. 1981, Guiera senegalensis (J. Etienne). Gambia: 2 cf, 2 $, larvae (V. F. Eastop). Chad: 5 $, larvae,<tei:lb/>Bebedjia8.40N/16.33E, 10.xi.l974(fl. M. Bink-Moenen). Sudan: 15 cf, 14 $, larvae, 50km W. ElObeid,<tei:lb/>19. iv. 1981, Guiera senegalensis, tended by Crematogaster sp.; 6 cf , 13 $, larvae, 140 km W. El Obeid,<tei:lb/>21.iv.1981; 9 cf, 8 ?, larvae S. Darfur, Ed Da'ein, 3.V.1981; 1 cf, 1 $, larvae, Ed Da'ein to Babanusa<tei:lb/>Road, 4.V.1981; larvae, 40 km SW. El Muglad, 6.V.1981 (/. H. Martin}. (BMNH; MNHN; slide and dry<tei:lb/>mounted and stored in 80% ethanol.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. The shape and venation of the forewing (Fig. 241) and the dense complete covering<tei:lb/>of spinules on the membrane serve to distinguish this species from other Afrotropical triozids.<tei:lb/>Furthermore the anus of the 5th instar larva is in a dorsal position, possibly to facilitate<tei:lb/>ant-tending.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trioza karroo sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 51, 245-248)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Adult. Integument sparsely covered with short setae.          <tei:p>Trioza laingisp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 249-253)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Adult. Body sparsely covered with short setae, genal cones and legs bearing longer setae.<tei:lb/>Head, in profile, depressed almost at 90 to longitudinal axis of body, from above narrower than<tei:lb/>mesoscutum; occipital margin obtuse but defined; vertex with a well-developed concavity on either side of<tei:lb/>median suture which is deeper towards median ocellus, frontal lobes not developed; median ocellus not<tei:lb/>visible from above, frons completely covered by genae; genal cones well developed, in profile depressed<tei:lb/>from axis of vertex; antennal flagellum 1-74 times longer than head width, a single rhinarium present<tei:lb/>subapically on flagellomeres 2, 4, 6 and 7, apical flagellomere with one long and one short and truncate seta<tei:lb/>apically; clypeus with a pair of setae, ultimate rostral segment with two pairs of setae. Thorax weakly<tei:lb/>arched; pronotum clearly visible from above and rounded down behind occiput; mesopraescutum, from<tei:lb/>above slightly wider than long, anterior margin broadly arcuate, in profile gently rounded down to<tei:lb/>pronotum; forewing (Fig. 249) elongate oval with rounded apex, 2-83-3-16 times longer than wide,<tei:lb/>membrane with an even brown pigmentation extending over posterior half of wing from the line of<tei:lb/>R+M+Cu, M stem and M 1+2 , evenly covered with spinules and with diffuse radular areas; veins bearing<tei:lb/>short setae, R branch acutangular, M branching at or proximal to Rs-Cu ia line, Cu stem 1-45-1-86 times<tei:lb/>longer than Cu lb , m l cell value 1-19-1-22, cu v cell value 1-07-1-40; forewing 1-23-1-25 times longer than<tei:lb/>hindwing, costal margin of hindwing with 0-1 seta proximal to costal break, setae distal to costal break<tei:lb/>clearly divided into two groups; hind coxa with a well-developed meracanthus and without anterior lobe;<tei:lb/>hind tibia with a weakly developed basal spine, with one strong outer and three inner apical spurs; basal<tei:lb/>segment of hind tarsus elongate. Abdomen with setae on tergites 2 and 3 in cf and 3 and 4 in 9; Cf<tei:lb/>proctiger, paramere and aedeagus as in Figs 250-252; 9 genital segment (Fig. 253) very short, proctiger<tei:lb/>with rounded apex, apicodorsal surface of ventral valves of ovipositor weakly serrate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Measurements (2 cf , 2 9). Maximum width of head, cf 0-55-0-57, $ 0-59-0-61; length of antennal<tei:lb/>flagellum, cf 0-96, $ 1-06; length of ultimate rostral segment, cf 0-10-0-11, 9 0-11-0-12; length of<tei:lb/>forewing, cf 2-91-3-14, 9 3-36-3-47; length of hind tibia, cf 0-45-0-48, 9 0-47-0-49.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Larva unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST PLANT. Possibly Bartsia longiflora (Scrophulariaceae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf , Kenya: Mt Elgon, 10,300', i.1974, on yellow flowers (S. Collins) (BMNH; slide mounted).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. Kenya: 1 9&gt; same data as holotype. Ethiopia: 1 9 (without head), Simien, Lori, 11,500',<tei:lb/>beaten from low yellow-flowered bushes, Bartsia longiflora; 1 cf , 3 $, 'Abyssinia', Mt Zuquala, c. 9,000',<tei:lb/>22.x. 1926, beaten from trees near lake shore (H. Scott). Zaire ('Congo Beige'): 1 9 Ruanda, Lac N'Gando<tei:lb/>('pied vole. Karisimbi'), 2,400 m, 8. in. 1935 (G. F. de Witte 1216); 1 cf Terr. Rutshuru, 7.iv.l937 (Miss.<tei:lb/>Prophylactique). (BMNH; MR AC; slide and dry mounted.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. This species most closely resembles T. obscura Tuthill, 1952, and some undescribed<tei:lb/>species which develop on Hebe spp. (Scrophulariaceae) in New Zealand, but this resemblance<tei:lb/>may be due to characters of the head, thorax and forewing being in the primitive state. Within<tei:lb/>the African fauna laingi is similar to karroo (p. 64) but the two species may be separated by the<tei:lb/>characters given in key couplet 4.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The material from Mt Zuquala, Ethiopia, was deposited in the BMNH under the Laing<tei:lb/>manuscript name ' Trioza semibrunneipennis' .</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>AFROTROPICAL JUMPING PLANT LICE 65</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trioza medleri sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 10, 39, 254, 7255)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Adult. Integument densely covered with long setae (Fig. 39). Head, in profile, depressed at<tei:lb/>90 to longitudinal axis of body, from above narrower than mesoscutum; occipital margin rounded; vertex<tei:lb/>deeply divided into two bulbous halves by median suture, eyes very prominent and rounded; median<tei:lb/>ocellus not visible from above, frons completely covered by genae; genal cones long, conical, with subacute<tei:lb/>apices; antennal flagellum (Fig. 10) 1-66 times longer than head width, a single rhinarium present<tei:lb/>subapically on flagellomeres 2, 4, 6 and 7, 1-6 with very long setae, apical flagellomere with one long and<tei:lb/>one extremely short and truncate seta apically; clypeus with a pair of setae, ultimate rostral segment with<tei:lb/>several pairs of setae. Thorax, in profile, strongly arched; pronotum, from above, with a rhomboid dorsal<tei:lb/>disc and strongly narrowing laterally, in profile strongly rounded down behind occiput; mesopraescutum,<tei:lb/>from above, slightly wider than long, anterior margin broadly arcuate, in profile rounded down to<tei:lb/>pronotum; forewing (Fig. 254) obovoid, broadly rounded distally, 2-29 times longer than wide, radular<tei:lb/>areas elongate, cell c+sc with a narrow diagonal band of spinules, remainder of membrane devoid of<tei:lb/>spinules; veins densely clothed with long setae, R branch acutangular, M branching proximal to Rs Cw ia<tei:lb/>line, Cu stem 0-39 times as long as Cw lb , m t cell value 2-61, cui cell value 0-76; forewing 1-38 times longer<tei:lb/>than hindwing , costal margin of hindwing with 0-1 seta proximal to costal break , setae distal to costal break<tei:lb/>clearly divided into two groups; hind coxa with a well-developed meracanthus and without anterior lobe;<tei:lb/>hind tibia without basal spines and with one outer and two inner apical spurs, cf unknown; $ abdomen<tei:lb/>with setae on tergite 3, genital segment short, conoid, proctiger strongly sclerotised apically, ovipositor<tei:lb/>valves smooth.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Measurements (1 $). Maximum width of head, 0-7; length of antennal flagellum, 1-16; length of ultimate<tei:lb/>rostral segment, 0-14; length of forewing, 3-85; length of hind tibia, 0-67.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Larva and host plant unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype $, Nigeria: NE. State, Ngel Nyaki, 31.iii.1970 (/. T. Medler} (BMNH; dry mounted).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. 2 $ , same data as holotype (BMNH; slide and dry mounted).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Non-paratypic material. Zaire ('Congo Beige'): 1 cf , PNG, Miss. H. de Seager, II/fe/7, 4.vii. 1952, 3729;<tei:lb/>1 cf , PFNK 7/9, 28.vii.1952, 3842 (H. de Saeger] (MRAC).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. This is a very distinctive species which may be easily recognised by the structure of<tei:lb/>the head, pronotum and forewing, the latter resembling those of the Hawaiian genera Hevaheva<tei:lb/>and Hemischizocranium. In overall appearance medleri is similar to the Indian species Petaloly-<tei:lb/>ma basalis (Walker, 1858) but the latter has a less cleft head which is more adpressed to the<tei:lb/>thorax, the pronotum is completely hidden dorsally, the mesonotum is less arched or produced<tei:lb/>forward, and the tibial spurs are much more strongly developed.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Apart from the type-series I have examined 2 cf from Zaire, deposited in MRAC, which may<tei:lb/>be conspecific but have a much shorter m\ cell (value 1-85). The genitalia are shown in Fig. 255.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trioza schroederi sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 256-260)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Adult. Integument sparsely clothed with short setae. Head, in profile, depressed almost to<tei:lb/>90 from longitudinal axis of body, from above almost as wide as mesoscutum; occipital margin broadly<tei:lb/>obtusangular; vertex rounded pentagonal, anteriorly incised by median suture and strongly rounded to<tei:lb/>genae, secondary diagonal grooves present from median ocellus backwards to lateral concavities, latter<tei:lb/>weak; median ocellus just visible from above, frons just visible in anterior view; genal cones elongate<tei:lb/>conoid, with rounded apices, in parallel plane to vertex; antennal flagellum 2-33-2-64 times longer than<tei:lb/>head width, a single rhinarium present subapically on flagellomeres 2, 4, 6 and 7, apical flagellomere with<tei:lb/>two long subequal setae apically; clypeus with a pair (rarely with a second very short pair) of setae, ultimate<tei:lb/>rostral segment with a pair of setae. Thorax weakly arched; pronotum strongly rounded down behind<tei:lb/>occiput; mesopraescutum, from above, about as long as wide, with arcuate anterior margin, in profile<tei:lb/>strongly rounded down to pronotum; forewing (Fig. 256) elongate oval with rounded obtusangular apex,<tei:lb/>2-76-2-87 times longer than wide, membrane devoid of spinules apart from a small cloud around base of<tei:lb/>claval suture and triangular radular areas; veins bearing short setae, R branch acutangular, Rs long and<tei:lb/>sinuous, M branching proximal to RsCu ia line, Cu stem 1-32-1-71 times longer than Cw lb , m\ cell value<tei:lb/>1-47-1-65, cu } cell value 1-29-1-68; forewing 1-5 times longer than hindwing, costal margin of hindwing</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Measurements (4 cf , 2 &lt;j&gt;). Rhodesia'): 1 Cf, Harare<tei:lb/>('Salisbury'), iii.1957, Myrica conifera (N. L. H. Krauss). (BMNH; MNHU; MRAC; slide mounted and<tei:lb/>stored in 80% ethanol.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Non-paratypic material (damaged specimens). Tanzania: 1 $, 1 ?, 'D. O. Afrika, Kilimandscharo',<tei:lb/>3000-4000 m, i.1906; 2 $, Amani, xii.1905 (Chr. Schroder) (MNHU). Zaire ('Congo Beige'): P.N.A.,<tei:lb/>Secteur Tshiaberimu, riv. Kalivina affll., Talia Nord, 2,350 m, 29.iii.1954 (P. Vanschuytbroek &amp; H.<tei:lb/>Synave) (MRAC).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. This species shows no clear relationships to other Afrotropical species, having<tei:lb/>several features of the wing in the primitive state. It is superficially similar to theroni (p. 67),<tei:lb/>from which it differs in having long, well-developed genal cones and lacking supplementary<tei:lb/>rhinaria on the first flagellomere.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trioza tangaesp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 18, 261-264)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Adult. Integument covered with long setae.          <tei:p>AFROTROPICAL JUMPING PLANT LICE 67</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENT. This species is distinguished by its relatively long apical flagellomere and male<tei:lb/>genitalia, the latter resembling those of the nigricornis-group (sensu Hodkinson, 1981) in the<tei:lb/>Palaearctic Region.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trioza tenuissp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 36, 37, 43, 265-267)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Adult. Integument very sparsely covered with very short setae. Head, in profile (Fig. 37), at<tei:lb/>90 to longitudinal axis of body, from above (Fig. 36) almost as wide as mesoscutum; occipital margin sharp<tei:lb/>dorsomedially and strongly indented by median suture of vertex; vertex also deeply cleft by median suture,<tei:lb/>lateral concavities weak; median ocellus just visible in dorsal view, frons visible between genae in anterior<tei:lb/>view; genal cones very poorly developed, rounded; antennal flagellum 1-51-1-63 times longer than head<tei:lb/>width, a single rhinarium present subapically on flagellomeres 2,4,6 and 7, apical flagellomere with a long<tei:lb/>pointed seta and a short truncate seta apically; clypeus with a pair of setae, ultimate rostral segment long<tei:lb/>and densely setose. Thorax (Figs 36, 37) moderately arched; from above the pronotum is more clearly<tei:lb/>visible at its lateral margins, the mesopraescutum being strongly produced forward medially, in profile<tei:lb/>pronotum strongly rounded down behind occiput and mesopraescutum angled down to pronotum;<tei:lb/>forewing (Fig. 265) elongate oval, strongly narrowing to acutangular apex, 3-08-3-19 times longer than<tei:lb/>wide, radular areas elongate triangular, remainder of membrane devoid of spinules; veins bearing short<tei:lb/>setae, R branch acutangular, M branching proximal to Rs Cw la line, Cu stem 0-28-0-35 times as long as<tei:lb/>Cw lb , ra t cell value 2-33-2-55, cu\ cell value 1-01-1-08; forewing 1-71-1-75 times longer than hindwing,<tei:lb/>costal margin of hindwing with up to four setae proximal to costal break, setae distal to costal break clearly<tei:lb/>divided into two groups; hind coxa with a well-developed meracanthus and an extremely well-developed<tei:lb/>anterior lobe; hind tibia with a well-developed basal spine and one outer and three (rarely two on one tibia<tei:lb/>only) inner spurs apically. Abdomen with setae on tergites 2 and 3 in cf and 3 and 4 in $ ; cf proctiger<tei:lb/>weakly expanded laterally, paramere and aedeagus as in Figs 266, 267; $ genital segment short, conical,<tei:lb/>subgenital plate with truncate apex, ovipositor valves smooth.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Measurements (2 cf , 2 $). Maximum width of head, cf and $ 0-67-0-70; length of antennal flagellum,<tei:lb/>Cf 1-09, 9 1-04-1 -06; length of ultimate rostral segment, Cf 0-19-0-20, $ 0-20; length of forewing, cf 4-4, $<tei:lb/>4-66-4-74; length of hind tibia, cf 0-64-0-66, $ 0-65-0-66.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Larva unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST PLANT. Few adults collected from Haplocoelum foliolosum (Sapindaceae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype cf, Angola: Bruco, 28.ii.-2.iii. 1972, Haplocoelum foliolosum (D. Hollis) (BMNH; dry<tei:lb/>mounted).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. Angola: 5 cf , 2 $, same data as holotype; 1 $, swept in riverine forest area, 26-29. ii. 1972;<tei:lb/>1 cf , Rocadas, 30.iii.1972 (D. Hollis). (BMNH; slide and dry mounted and stored in 80% ethanol.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENTS. This species shares many primitive character states with ghanaensis (p. 62) but has<tei:lb/>a more slender build, the forewing is narrower and the hind tibia has three inner apical spurs.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trioza theronisp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 24, 268-271)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Adult. Integument sparsely covered with short setae. Head, in profile, at almost 90 to<tei:lb/>longitudinal axis of body, from above as wide as mesoscutum; occipital margin rounded; vertex pentago-<tei:lb/>nal, with a well-developed irregular concavity on either side of a shallow median suture, frontal lobes<tei:lb/>weakly developed; median ocellus just visible from above, frons just visible between genae in anterior<tei:lb/>view; genae slightly swollen and genal cones poorly developed; antennal flagellum 2-60-3-23 times longer<tei:lb/>than head width, 1st flagellomere (Fig. 24) with an apical group of 1-3 rhinaria and often with an extra<tei:lb/>rhinarium two-thirds along its length, a single rhinarium present subapically on flagellomeres 2, 4, 6 and 7,<tei:lb/>apical flagellomere with one long and one short and truncate seta apically; clypeus with several short setae,<tei:lb/>ultimate rostral segment with two pairs of setae.          <tei:p>COMMENTS. The arrangement of supplementary rhinaria on the first flagellomere in theroni is<tei:lb/>distinctive, but the species shows no apparent relationships to other triozids which have<tei:lb/>developed supplementary rhinaria. T. schroederi (p. 65} is superficially similar to theroni but<tei:lb/>has well-developed genal cones and a primitive arrangement of rhinaria.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trioza tundavalaesp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 272-274, 323, 324)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DESCRIPTION. Adult. Integument densely covered with long setae. Head, in profile, slightly depressed from<tei:lb/>longitudinal axis of body, from above narrower than mesoscutum; occipital margin obtusangular; vertex<tei:lb/>quadrate, its anterior margin rounded downwards and deeply incised by median suture, lateral concavities<tei:lb/>shallow but clearly defined; median ocellus visible from above, frons visible in anterior view; genal cones<tei:lb/>short, broadly rounded, in profile depressed from plane of vertex; antennal flagellum 2-2 times longer than<tei:lb/>head width, a single rhinarium present subapically on flagellomeres 2, 4, 6 and 7, apical flagellomere with a<tei:lb/>long pointed seta and a short truncate seta apically; clypeus with a pair of setae, ultimate rostral segment<tei:lb/>with four pairs of setae. Thorax strongly arched; pronotum clearly visible from above, in profile rounded<tei:lb/>down to occiput; mesopraescutum, from above, slightly wider than long, anterior margin broadly arcuate;<tei:lb/>forewing (Fig. 272) ovoid with rounded apex, 2-33 times longer than wide, radular areas triangular,<tei:lb/>remainder of membrane devoid of spinules, course of/? and RI brown pigmented; veins bearing long setae<tei:lb/>in proximal third of wing, R branch acutangular, RI about 1-5 times longer than R stem, M branching<tei:lb/>proximal to RsCui a line, Cu stem 0-88-1-11 times as long as Cw lb , m\ cell value 1-44-1-48, cu\ cell value<tei:lb/>1-29-1-34; forewing 1-72-1-76 times longer than hindwing, costal margin of hindwing with up to 11 setae<tei:lb/>proximal to costal break, setae distal to costal break clearly divided into two groups; hind coxa with a<tei:lb/>well-developed meracanthus and without anterior lobe; hind tibia without basal spine and with one outer<tei:lb/>and 2-3 inner apical spurs, cf unknown; $ abdomen with setae on tergites 3 and 4; $ genital segment (Fig.<tei:lb/>273) short; proctiger (Fig. 274) short, rounded, emarginate posteriorly, anal pore ring of wax-producing<tei:lb/>cells incomplete anteriorly and forming multiple rows posteriorly; subgenital plate very short, with<tei:lb/>truncate posterior margin; ventral valve of ovipositor triangularly expanded apically and this expansion<tei:lb/>with 15-16 saw-like teeth on ventrolateral surface, dorsal surface with serrations.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Measurements (2 9). Maximum width of head, 0-83; length of antennal flagellum, 1-84; length of<tei:lb/>ultimate rostral segment, 0-17; length of forewing, 6-13-6-25; length of hind tibia, 0-95-0-99.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fifth instar larva (Figs 323, 324). Dorsal surface outline very broadly oval with indentations on either<tei:lb/>side at base of abdomen and a weak indentation medially on the posterior margin, about 1-2 times longer<tei:lb/>than wide. Antenna with six flagellomeres. Cephaloprothorax separate from rest of thorax which has<tei:lb/>mesothorax and metathorax almost completely divided. Forewing pad about 2-1 mm long, humeral lobe<tei:lb/>extending forward to anterior margin of eye which is close to anterior margin of cephaloprothorax. Caudal<tei:lb/>plate 0-6 times as long as wide, anus ventral and close to posterior margin of abdomen, anal pore area as in<tei:lb/>Fig. 324. Narrow, elongate, truncate, tubular sectasetae, with roundly swollen bases, forming an even<tei:lb/>dense marginal fringe; lanceolate postocular sectaseta present, sectasetae absent from dorsum.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>AFROTROPICAL JUMPING PLANT LICE 69</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST PLANT. Larvae collected in midrib galls on upper surfaces of leaves of Syzygium<tei:lb/>benguellense (Myrtaceae); adults emerged from these galls.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype $, Angola: Tundavala, 8-10 mis NW. Sa da Bandeira, 27-29. iii. 1972, emerged from leaf gall of<tei:lb/>Syzygium benguellense (D. Hollis) (BMNH; dry mounted).<tei:lb/>Paratypes. 3 $ , larvae, same data as holotype (BMNH; slide and dry mounted).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>COMMENT. This large, robust, pilose species has the distinctive feature that R { is considerably<tei:lb/>longer than R stem, giving r 1 a very broad proximal area. It has a similar general appearance to<tei:lb/>Trioza palaquii (Laing, 1930), described from specimens reared from galls of Palaquium gutta<tei:lb/>(Sapotaceae) from Malaya, but this may be convergence as both species live in enclosed galls.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Doubtful species<tei:lb/>Trioza bussei Zacher, 1915</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trioza bussei Zacher, 1915: 526; 1916: 419. Syntypes, larvae and adults, CAMEROON: Soppo, on Kickxia<tei:lb/>(not traced).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The first published indication of this species was a brief description of the larva and a figure of the<tei:lb/>adult wing. Zacher (1916) gives a further description of the egg, all larval stages and the adult<tei:lb/>female. No diagnostic features are mentioned. The type-series was not traced and no reply was<tei:lb/>received to enquiries at the Institut fur Pflanzenschutzforschung, Eberswalde.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trioza similis Heslop-Harrison, 1961</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trioza similis Heslop-Harrison, 1961: 530. Holotype $, SOUTH AFRICA: 'Cape Prov., Tzitzikama Forest,<tei:lb/>Stormsrivierpiek, 13. i. 1951, Loc. no. 137. In indigenous forest' (lost).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The original description and fig. 12 (I) mentions an anteriorly projecting epiphysis on the ventral<tei:lb/>surface of the subgenital plate, but this is not shown in fig. 12 (H). No other diagnostic features<tei:lb/>are mentioned.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>reticulata 28<tei:lb/>Rhegmoza 3<tei:lb/>Rhinopsylla 3, 9</tei:p>
         <tei:p>russellae 28</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Schedoneolithus 3<tei:lb/>Schedotrioza 3<tei:lb/>schroederi 7, 19, 65-66, 68<tei:lb/>schwarzii 3<tei:lb/>semibrunneipennis 64<tei:lb/>senegalensis 5, 21, 33, 34-35<tei:lb/>septimaS, 21,32<tei:lb/>seranistama 7, 20, 56, 58<tei:lb/>shiwapuriensis 28<tei:lb/>sideroxyli 2<tei:lb/>similis7, 18,69<tei:lb/>Siphonaleyrodes 8, 35<tei:lb/>Siphonaleyrodinae 8<tei:lb/>Smirnovia 2<tei:lb/>sonchi 2<tei:lb/>Spanioza 35<tei:lb/>spondiasae 28<tei:lb/>Stenopsylla 3<tei:lb/>stevensi 28<tei:lb/>sulfurea3, 51<tei:lb/>Swezeyana 3<tei:lb/>swezeyi51<tei:lb/>Sympauropsylla 27<tei:lb/>Synoza 8</tei:p>

         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>British Museum (Natural History)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Milkweed butterflies: their cladistics and biology</tei:p>
         <tei:p>P. R. Ackery &amp; R. I. Vane- Wright</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Danainae, a subfamily of the Nymphalidae, contains only some 150 species, yet aspects of<tei:lb/>their biology have stimulated far more attention than can be justified by species numbers<tei:lb/>alone. In recent years, an expansive literature has grown, considering aspects of their<tei:lb/>courtship and pre-courtship behaviour, migration, larval hostplant associations, mimicry and<tei:lb/>genetics. The popularity of danaines among biologists can certainly be attributed to this<tei:lb/>combination, within one small group, of so many of the factors that make butterflies such an<tei:lb/>interesting group to study. The obvious need to place this wealth of biological data within an<tei:lb/>acceptable systematic framework provided the impetus for this volume.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Started eight years ago within the conventions of evolution by natural selection and<tei:lb/>Hennig's phylogenetic systematics, the book is now largely about natural history (what the<tei:lb/>animals have and do, where they live and how they develop) and natural groups - as revealed<tei:lb/>by a form of analysis approaching that practised by the new school of 'transformed cladistics'.<tei:lb/>The authors have prepared a handbook that will appeal to a wide range of biologists, from<tei:lb/>museum taxonomists to field ecologists.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>424 pp (approx.), 12 pp colour, 73 h/vv plates, line and graphic illustrations, maps, extensive bibliography.<tei:lb/>ISBN 565 00893 5. Publication September 1984. Price 50, prepublication price 45.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>Titles to be published in Volume 49</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Afrotropical jumping plant lice of the family Triozidae (Homoptera: Psylloidea).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>By David Hollis.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>27JUL1984</tei:p>
         <tei:p>History)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The taxonomy of the western<tei:lb/>European grasshoppers of the genus<tei:lb/>Euchorthippus, with special reference<tei:lb/>to their songs (Orthoptera: Acrididae)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>D. R. Ragge &amp; W. J. Reynolds</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Vol 49 No 2 26 July 1984</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>The Bulletin of the British Museum (Natural History), instituted in 1949, is issued in four<tei:lb/>scientific series, Botany, Entomology, Geology (incorporating Mineralogy) and Zoology,<tei:lb/>and an Historical series.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Papers in the Bulletin are primarily the results of research carried out on the unique and<tei:lb/>ever-growing collections of the Museum, both by the scientific staff of the Museum and by<tei:lb/>specialists from elsewhere who make use of the Museum's resources. Many of the papers are<tei:lb/>works of reference that will remain indispensable for years to come.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Parts are published at irregular intervals as they become ready, each is complete in itself,<tei:lb/>available separately, and individually priced. Volumes contain about 300 pages and several<tei:lb/>volumes may appear within a calendar year. Subscriptions may be placed for one or more of<tei:lb/>the series on either an Annual or Per Volume basis. Prices vary according to the contents of<tei:lb/>the individual parts. Orders and enquiries should be sent to:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Publications Sales,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>British Museum (Natural History),<tei:lb/>Cromwell Road,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>London SW75BD,<tei:lb/>England.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>-</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I</tei:p>
         <tei:p>World List abbreviation: Bull. Br. Mus. nat. Hist. (Ent.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trustees of the British Museum (Natural History), 1984</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Entomology series is produced under the general editorship of the</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Keeper of Entomology: Laurence A. Mound</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Assistant Editor: W. Gerald Tremewan</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ISBN 565 06004 X</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ISSN 0524-6431 Entomology series</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Vol 49 No 2 pp 103-151<tei:lb/>British Museum (Natural History)<tei:lb/>Cromwell Road<tei:lb/>London SW7 5BD Issued 26 July 1984</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>The taxonomy of the western European grasshoppers<tei:lb/>of the genus Euchorthippus, with special reference to<tei:lb/>their songs (Orthoptera: Acrididae)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>D. R. Ragge &amp; W. J. Reynolds</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Department of Entomology, British Museum (Natural History), Cromwell Road, London<tei:lb/>SW75BD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Contents</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Synopsis 103</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Introduction 103</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acknowledgements 104</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Material 105</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Methods 105</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Morphology 105</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Song 106</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Presentation and evaluation of the data 110</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Characters studied Ill</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Morphology Ill</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour pattern 117</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cytology 117</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Song 117</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euchorthippus Tarbinskii 121</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to the western European and North African species</tei:p>
         <tei:p>and subspecies of Euchorthippus 122</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Descriptions of the species 125</tei:p>
         <tei:p>General discussion 139</tei:p>
         <tei:p>References 141</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Index 151</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Synopsis</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The taxonomy of the western European species and subspecies of the Gomphocerine genus Euchorthippus<tei:lb/>is re-examined on the basis of both morphological and song characters , making full use of such visual aids as<tei:lb/>bar-charts and scatter diagrams. It is shown that the past emphasis on the male subgenital plate as a<tei:lb/>diagnostic character has resulted in the frequent misidentification of the three main species, declivus,<tei:lb/>pulvinatus and chopardi. This has been particularly true in Spain, where pulvinatus and chopardi have<tei:lb/>often been misidentified as declivus and pulvinatus, respectively. It is also shown that the Jersey form<tei:lb/>elegantulus, previously synonymized with declivus, is actually a form of pulvinatus, and that a further<tei:lb/>population of it occurs in southern Brittany. Analyses of the songs of these species, previously thought to<tei:lb/>be of little taxonomic value, have provided strong support for these conclusions. The study embraces four<tei:lb/>further taxa known only from the western Mediterranean islands or North Africa, and the song of the<tei:lb/>Balearic species angustulus is fully described and analysed for the first time. Keys are given for the<tei:lb/>identification of all these species and subspecies, and their evolution and rather anomalous present<tei:lb/>distribution are briefly discussed.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Introduction</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euchorthippus belongs to the Gomphocerinae, a group that includes most of the common<tei:lb/>European grasshoppers of open grassland. They are well known for their characteristic - and<tei:lb/>taxonomically useful - songs, and are frequently used in ecological and cytological studies. The<tei:lb/>subfamily includes about 150 European species, of which over 20 are pests in parts of their range,<tei:lb/>seven of them being regarded as major ones (Tsyplenkov, 1970).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bull. Br. Mus. nat. Hist. (Ent.) 49 (2): 103-151 Issued26 July 1984</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>104 D. R. RAGGE &amp; W. J. REYNOLDS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euchorthippus is a widespread Palaearctic genus, including 14 species living in habitats<tei:lb/>ranging from moist grassland to steppe and barren hillside. Five species occur in western Europe<tei:lb/>and one of these, E. pulvinatus, becomes a pest when it occurs in sufficiently dense populations,<tei:lb/>causing damage to pastureland, hayfields, cereal grasses, alfalfa and other cultivated plants in<tei:lb/>western and, especially, eastern Europe (Bei-Bienko &amp; Mishchenko, 1951; Tsyplenkov, 1970).<tei:lb/>This species sometimes reaches densities of over 10/m 2 in the Stipa-steppe areas of the Ukraine<tei:lb/>and northern Kazakhstan, where it is by far the most numerous grasshopper (Chetyrkina, 1954;<tei:lb/>Bei-Bienko, 1961).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euchorthippus is quite easy to recognize as a genus, but its species are much more difficult to<tei:lb/>identify and have frequently been confused with one another. E. dedivus, E. pulvinatus and E.<tei:lb/>chopardi form a group of closely similar species that are very difficult to separate using the keys<tei:lb/>at present available. Among more recent studies of this group, those of Mafan (1957),<tei:lb/>Descamps (1968), Litvinova (1972) and Defaut (1982) have much improved our knowledge of<tei:lb/>their taxonomy, ecology and geographical variation. The songs of these species have been<tei:lb/>described briefly by Descamps (1968), Luquet (1978) and Schmidt &amp; Schach (1978), but these<tei:lb/>authors attached little or no taxonomic importance to the differences between them. The main<tei:lb/>aim of our study has been to refine further the best methods for distinguishing morphologically<tei:lb/>between these species and to demonstrate the taxonomic importance of their songs.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Although we have concentrated our study on this group of three species, for each of which we<tei:lb/>have been able to study the song, we have also included morphological information on all the<tei:lb/>other species occurring in western Europe and North Africa and, in the case of E. angustulus,<tei:lb/>have been able to give full information on the song for the first time. The geographical area<tei:lb/>covered by our study consists of southern Europe and the Mediterranean Region from Italy<tei:lb/>westwards, including North Africa.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Morphological recognition of the species of Euchorthippus depends mainly on differences in<tei:lb/>size and proportion, and we have chosen to present this information in the form of visual aids<tei:lb/>such as bar-charts and scatter diagrams so that the most important differences can be seen at a<tei:lb/>glance and a specimen can be identified quickly by entering its key measurements on the<tei:lb/>appropriate diagram. Similar visual aids have been used to illustrate the significance of the<tei:lb/>differences in song.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>E. pulvinatus pulvinatus, which does not occur in western Europe, is excluded from our<tei:lb/>study, and where the specific name 'pulvinatus' is used in our text it refers only to the west-<tei:lb/>ern subspecies E. p. gallicus and E. p. elegantulus unless otherwise indicated.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acknowledgements</tei:p>
         <tei:p>We are much indebted to the following, who have kindly lent us type-specimens or other<tei:lb/>material from their respective institutions:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Drs A. Cejchan, G. Demoulin, M. Donskoff, M. J. Gonzalez, K. K. Giinther, L. Herrera, G.<tei:lb/>Kruseman, V. Llorente and E. Tremblay.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>We are also grateful to Dr A. Nadig for lending us the holotype of E. sardous from his private<tei:lb/>collection in Chur, Switzerland; to Dr B. Defaut, who lent us specimens of Euchorthippus from<tei:lb/>Brittany and Teruel province in Spain; and to Mr D. W. Baldock, who gave us, among other<tei:lb/>specimens, a female Euchorthippus from Guerande in southern Brittany and thus alerted us to<tei:lb/>the occurrence there of the interesting small form of E. pulvinatus (see p. 131). We thank<tei:lb/>Mr J. F. Burton for very kindly making available to us a tape recording of the song of a<tei:lb/>male Euchorthippus from Jersey.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Our thanks are due to Messrs W. G. Tremewan and B. C. Townsend, who collected live males<tei:lb/>for us from Spain and Jersey, respectively, and thus enabled us to make studio song recordings<tei:lb/>from them; to Mr E. C. M. Haes, who collected specimens for us from France; to Mr W. B. Lee,<tei:lb/>who helped us to obtain data from specimens and song oscillograms; to Dr M. Hills of the British<tei:lb/>Museum (Natural History) Biometrics and Computing Section, who advised us on statistical<tei:lb/>methods; and to Dr F. Willemse for information on the distribution of Euchorthippus in Greece.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE TAXONOMY OF THE WESTERN EUROPEAN EUCHORTHIPPUS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>105</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Finally we should like to thank Mr P. H. Ward for his skilful preparation of the drawings<tei:lb/>shown in Figs 25-30.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Material</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Our study is based almost entirely on material in the British Museum (Natural History),<tei:lb/>amounting to about 1500 western European specimens of Euchorthippus . Many of these<tei:lb/>specimens were collected by us during recent visits to France and Spain.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The song analyses were based on tape recordings made by us in the field in France and Spain,<tei:lb/>and in the BMNH Acoustic Laboratory from males brought back from Jersey, France, Spain<tei:lb/>and Majorca; we were also able to make use of a tape recording kindly made available to us by<tei:lb/>Mr J. F. Burton.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>We have used the following abbreviations for depositories of type-specimens.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BMNH British Museum (Natural History), London</tei:p>
         <tei:p>IE A Istituto di Entomologia Agraria, Portici</tei:p>
         <tei:p>IRSNB Institut Royal des Sciences Naturelles de Belgique, Brussels</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MNHN Museum National d'Histoire Naturelle, Paris</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MNHU Museum fur Naturkunde der Humboldt-Universitat, Berlin</tei:p>
         <tei:p>NM NarodniMuzeum, Prague</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Methods</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Morphology</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The morphological measurements were made using a Wild M5 microscope with a graduated<tei:lb/>eyepiece. The lengths of the head and pronotum were measured along the mid-line. The length<tei:lb/>of the fore wing was measured from the tip to the point where the fused subcostal, radial and<tei:lb/>medial veins of the flexed wing pass under the edge of the pronotum (Fig. 1 , f) . The length of the<tei:lb/>hind wing was measured (also when flexed) from the tip of the wing to the median posterior point<tei:lb/>of the pronotum rather than to the base of the hind wing, since this is hidden under the fore wing<tei:lb/>when the wings are flexed (Fig. 1 , h) . The distance from the stigma to the tip of the fore wing was<tei:lb/>measured from the centre of the stigma, which is more easily determined than its edge (Fig. 1, s).<tei:lb/>The distance by which the fore wing projected beyond the hind wing was determined by<tei:lb/>illuminating the flexed wings from below and measuring the distance between the tips of the fore<tei:lb/>and hind wings (Fig. 1, g). When the hind wing projected beyond the fore wing, the<tei:lb/>measurement was regarded as negative. The length of the hind femur was measured from the<tei:lb/>most proximal to the most distal points.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 2 3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Figs 1-3 Diagrams of (1) the flexed wings and (2, 3) male terminal abdominal segments in species of<tei:lb/>Euchorthippus, showing the method of measuring the length of the fore wing (f), length of the hind wing<tei:lb/>(h), distance from the stigma to the tip of the fore wing (s), projection of the fore wing beyond the hind<tei:lb/>wing (g), length of the male subgenital plate (sp) and length of male abdominal tergites 9+10 (at). R =<tei:lb/>radius. (See also the explanation in the text.)</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>106 D. R. RAGGE &amp; W. J. REYNOLDS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>When counting the stridulatory pegs it was sometimes necessary to relax the leg and to move it<tei:lb/>away from the body so that the stridulatory file was visible. The pegs were viewed from above, in<tei:lb/>profile, and were counted as they moved past a line on the microscope eyepiece scale. Following<tei:lb/>Perdeck (1957), bristles were included in the row and, in determining the ends of the file, a peg<tei:lb/>or bristle was excluded if its distance from the preceding peg was twice, or more than twice, the<tei:lb/>distance between the two preceding ones. The length of the stridulatory file was measured from<tei:lb/>one terminal peg or bristle (determined as above) to the other.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The lengths of the male subgenital plate and abdominal tergites 9+10 were measured<tei:lb/>following the method used by Descamps (1968) (Fig. 2) except that, when the proximal dorsal<tei:lb/>edge of the subgenital plate was hidden, the length of only the visible part of the plate was<tei:lb/>measured (Fig. 3).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>As we had at our disposal well over 500 specimens of each of the two common species dedivus<tei:lb/>and pulvinatus , we measured only a sample of them, following the principle that all the localities<tei:lb/>from which the specimens came should be represented by at least one measured specimen. We<tei:lb/>restricted our measurements of albolineatus to 10 specimens of each sex, since this North<tei:lb/>African species was outside the main scope of our study.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Song</tei:p>
         <tei:p>All the field recordings of the songs used in this study were made while the insects were in full<tei:lb/>sunshine using a Uher 4000, 4200 or 4200IC tape recorder and an AKG D202 microphone. Most<tei:lb/>of the studio recordings were made in the BMNH Acoustic Laboratory using a Kudelski Nagra<tei:lb/>IV tape recorder and Sennheiser MKH405 microphone. Recording 163 was made from a captive<tei:lb/>insect by Mr J. F. Burton using a Nagra III tape recorder. The only other recordings not made in<tei:lb/>the field (179/6, 179/9, 180/1, 180/2) were recorded at the Station Biologique d'Arcachon,<tei:lb/>Gironde, France, using a Uher 4000 tape recorder and AKG D202 microphone. For all the<tei:lb/>studio recordings a bench lamp was used to provide light and radiant heat. Further data are given<tei:lb/>in Tables 1 and 2.<tei:lb/>The acoustic terms we have used are defined as follows.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Calling song. The song produced by an isolated male.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Courtship song. The special song produced by a male when close to a female.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Syllable. The sound produced by one complete up and down movement of the hind legs</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 4).<tei:lb/>Echeme. A first-order assemblage of syllables (Fig. 4). (Term introduced by Broughton,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1976.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>All the song measurements were taken from oscillograms made with a Mingograf 34T ink-jet<tei:lb/>recorder. Echeme duration was measured from the end of the first clearly visible syllable to the<tei:lb/>end of the last (Fig. 6). This measurement was divided by the number of syllables between these<tei:lb/>two points to give the mean syllable duration for the echeme. 'Gaps' (momentary breaks in the<tei:lb/>sound - see Fig. 4) were counted if they occurred during the louder second part of the syllable<tei:lb/>and were at least 1-25 ms in duration (Fig. 6).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Echeme repetition rate was determined only from periods of regular echeme repetition. To<tei:lb/>put this on an objective basis we used only sequences of four or more echemes during which no<tei:lb/>two successive intervals between echemes differed from one another by more than 10 per cent of<tei:lb/>the smaller of the two . The duration of each regular sequence of echemes was measured from the<tei:lb/>end of the first echeme to the end of the last; the number of echemes included (one fewer than<tei:lb/>the total number of echemes in the sequence) was then divided by this measurement to give the<tei:lb/>echeme repetition rate (Fig. 5).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In the field singing usually stops when the sun is hidden by a cloud, and in the studio the lack of<tei:lb/>radiant heat from a nearby bench lamp usually has a similar effect. If singing does continue in<tei:lb/>such conditions, the echeme repetition rate is normally much lower and the duration of both the<tei:lb/>echemes and syllables much greater; the number of gaps per echeme does not change<tei:lb/>noticeably. Because of this effect we have based our song data only on recordings made when the</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE TAXONOMY OF THE WESTERN EUROPEAN EUCHORTHIPPUS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>107</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Table 1 Data for the field recordings of male calling songs of Euchorthippus used in this study. All these<tei:lb/>recordings were made from different males. Recordings 236/3, 236/4 and 236/6 were made at the<tei:lb/>type-locality of E. chopardi.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>insect was in full sunshine or receiving radiant heat from a bench lamp, and we suggest that any<tei:lb/>recordings compared with our data should be made under similar conditions. Ambient air<tei:lb/>temperatures are also important, but less so than radiant heat as the insects can regulate their<tei:lb/>body temperature to some extent by adjusting their orientation to the incident radiation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>When combining the data from the various recordings of each species in order to find the<tei:lb/>range, overall mean and standard deviation, we treated the mean obtained from each male as an<tei:lb/>individual observation, thus minimizing the effect of variation in the songs. When comparing a<tei:lb/>song with our data, it is thus desirable to use mean values taken from as much of the song as<tei:lb/>possible.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>We excluded from our analysis any echemes that were obviously atypical, such as those<tei:lb/>produced when the insect was just beginning to sing. We based our figures for echeme repetition<tei:lb/>rate on all the regular sequences in each recording, but the number of echemes used for</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>108</tei:p>
         <tei:p>D. R. RAGGE &amp; W. J. REYNOLDS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Table 2 Data for the studio recordings of male calling songs of Euchorthippus used in this study. All these<tei:lb/>recordings were made from different males except for the following four pairs: (313/4, 316/2), (314/2,<tei:lb/>316/1), (179/6, 180/2), (179/9, 180/1).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>measuring the number of gaps per echeme, echeme duration and syllable duration was generally<tei:lb/>limited to 50 per recording. When we had two recordings taken from the same male, the mean of<tei:lb/>each character was calculated separately for each recording and these means were then<tei:lb/>combined to give a single grand mean for that male.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE TAXONOMY OF THE WESTERN EUROPEAN EUCHORTHIPPUS<tei:lb/>ECHEMES</tei:p>

         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>110 D. R. RAGGE &amp; W. J. REYNOLDS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Presentation and evaluation of the data</tei:p>
         <tei:p>We have chosen to present the morphological and acoustic data in the form of bar-charts (Figs<tei:lb/>20, 82-88) because they make it possible to compare at a glance our samples of the taxa and their<tei:lb/>constituent regional populations. The components of each bar are explained in Fig. 7 (but note<tei:lb/>that in some bars the range does not extend beyond the standard deviation on one side of the</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MINIMUM MEAN STANDARD DEVIATION MAXIMUM</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I</tei:p>
         <tei:p>STANDARD ERROR OF MEAN</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 7 Diagram explaining the components of the bars used in the bar-charts (Figs 20, 82-88) . Note that in<tei:lb/>some of these bars the range does not extend beyond the standard deviation on one side of the mean and<tei:lb/>that, when the number of observations is fewer than five, the bar is given as a simple line with no<tei:lb/>statistical information beyond the range and mean.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>mean). The scale used for each bar-chart was chosen to make the fullest use of the space<tei:lb/>available, and the resulting differences in scale should be taken into account when comparing<tei:lb/>the variability of different characters. All morphological measurements are given in millimetres<tei:lb/>and all temporal ones in milliseconds. For each sample, n represents the number of specimens<tei:lb/>measured or whose songs have been analysed, and on the bar-charts of acoustic data (Fig. 20) n e<tei:lb/>represents the total number of echemes analysed. Where n&lt;5 the bar is given as a simple line<tei:lb/>with no statistical information beyond the range and mean.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>We found the bar-charts to demonstrate so clearly and quickly the differences between the<tei:lb/>taxa, and which characters are most useful in separating them, that we decided it would be<tei:lb/>pointless to subject the same data to multivariate analysis. We have occasionally applied 't' tests<tei:lb/>to determine more objectively which of two characters (or combinations of characters) gave the<tei:lb/>best separation between two taxa, but in every case these did no more than confirm what was<tei:lb/>obvious from the bar-charts.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The bar-charts also suggested combinations of characters that would give improved separa-<tei:lb/>tions and we have plotted a selection of these in the form of scatter diagrams (Figs 8-13, 21-24).<tei:lb/>Fig. 8 shows particularly clearly the contrast in the males between declivus and the remaining<tei:lb/>species in the projection of the fore wing beyond the hind wing. Fig. 9 gives a complete<tei:lb/>separation of the males of declivus, pulvinatus and chopardi, especially if the French samples are<tei:lb/>considered alone. Figs 10 and 11 achieve a similar result for both sexes, but the French and<tei:lb/>Spanish samples have to be considered separately in order to obtain a complete separation in the<tei:lb/>males. Figs 21-24 show rather more clearly than the acoustic bar-charts (Fig. 20) the difference<tei:lb/>between the songs of declivus, pulvinatus and chopardi.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The best morphological separation between males of declivus, pulvinatus and chopardi was<tei:lb/>achieved by plotting three characters as percentages on a triangular graph (Fig. 12). The<tei:lb/>procedure for this is described by Mayr (1969) and is best explained by an example. For one<tei:lb/>specimen the following figures were obtained: number of stridulatory pegs 148, length of<tei:lb/>pronotum/length of head 1-09 and distance of stigma from tip of fore wing 2-68 mm. Since the<tei:lb/>figures for the last two characters are small compared with the first, they were multiplied by 100<tei:lb/>and 25, respectively. The three figures used were thus 148, 109 and 67, giving the sum 324. The<tei:lb/>three characters represent 45-7 per cent, 33-6 per cent and 20-7 per cent of their sum and these<tei:lb/>percentages were used to enter a single point on the graph, the axes being arranged so that the<tei:lb/>sum of the three coordinates of each point was always 100. The graph thus shows proportions<tei:lb/>rather than absolute sizes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Figure 12 gives perhaps the most convincing demonstration that declivus, pulvinatus and<tei:lb/>chopardi do not constitute a single, continuously variable species, though it does not of course</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE TAXONOMY OF THE WESTERN EUROPEAN EUCHORTHIPPUS</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Fig. 8 Scatter diagram showing a plot of the number of stridulatory pegs against the projection of the fore<tei:lb/>wing beyond the hind wing in males of Euchorthippus . The negative values on the horizontal axis are for<tei:lb/>specimens in which the hind wing projects beyond the fore wing.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>rule out polymorphism. Figure 13 shows that, using the same combination of characters,<tei:lb/>albolineatus and angustulus resemble chopardi, while sardous is nearer to pulvinatus .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>It should be noted that in some scatter diagrams the number of points entered is smaller than<tei:lb/>the number of specimens measured (as shown in the bar-charts), because in a few specimens<tei:lb/>both (or, in the case of the triangular graphs, all four) of the characters were not available.<tei:lb/>Where two different population symbols would have coincided exactly, only one symbol is<tei:lb/>shown in the morphological scatter diagrams; the symbol chosen is the one considered to be<tei:lb/>more useful or informative (e.g. near the edge of the cluster concerned). In the song scatter<tei:lb/>diagrams (Figs 21-24), for which fewer points were available, coincident symbols have been<tei:lb/>moved apart slightly so that both can be seen.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Characters studied<tei:lb/>Morphology</tei:p>
         <tei:p>We have concentrated on morphological characters that are easy to use with pinned specimens<tei:lb/>and have therefore excluded those characters of the fore wing that are often hidden behind the<tei:lb/>hind legs (e.g. the width of the medial and cubital areas) or are difficult to measure without<tei:lb/>opening and flattening the wings (e.g. the width of the fore wing). We have also tried to avoid<tei:lb/>characters that tend to change as the body shrinks after death, and have therefore used the<tei:lb/>length of the hind femur as a measure of size in preference to body length, which is often greatly<tei:lb/>altered by post mortem shrinkage (and in the females is also much influenced by gravidity). We<tei:lb/>have, however, included the lengths of the male subgenital plate and abdominal tergites 9+10<tei:lb/>because of the emphasis placed on these measurements by Descamps (1968), although we have</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>112</tei:p>
         <tei:p>170<tei:lb/>160<tei:lb/>150</tei:p>
         <tei:p>/&gt; 140<tei:lb/>O</tei:p>
         <tei:p/>
         <tei:p>130</tei:p>
         <tei:p>120</tei:p>
         <tei:p>100</tei:p>
         <tei:p>90</tei:p>
         <tei:p>80</tei:p>
         <tei:p>70</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(A ranc<tei:lb/>pu/v/nafus ga//icus| ,, .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>D. R. RAGGE &amp; W. J. REYNOLDS<tei:lb/>France .. France</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- pu/vinafus e/egan;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>angustulus (o)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>a/bo/ineafus a/bo/ineafus ()</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Fig. 9 Scatter diagram showing a plot of the number of stridulatory pegs against the distance from the<tei:lb/>stigma to the tip of the fore wing in males of Euchorthippus . To facilitate comparison broken lines are<tei:lb/>used for the two Iberian samples.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>found that their usefulness is much reduced by shrinkage during drying. We suspect that the<tei:lb/>distance by which the fore wing projects beyond the hind wing is also affected by post mortem<tei:lb/>shrinkage, but this does not prevent it from being a useful character.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head and pronotum</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The lengths of the head and pronotum are not very useful taxonomic characters other than as<tei:lb/>measures of size or when taken as a ratio of one to the other. This ratio is frequently useful for<tei:lb/>separating chopardi from the other mainland species and was used by Descamps (1968) to<tei:lb/>distinguish chopardi from angustulus, albolineatus albolineatus and a. siculus. However, the<tei:lb/>pronotum/head ratios of Iberian chopardi show a large overlap with those of the other taxa (Figs<tei:lb/>82, 86).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The prominence of the median and, especially, lateral carinae of the pronotum is often useful<tei:lb/>in distinguishing between species, but this character is rather difficult to use until one is familiar<tei:lb/>with the differences shown. We have attempted to show in diagrammatic cross-section (Figs<tei:lb/>31-34) the degree of prominence of these carinae in declivus, pulvinatus gallicus, chopardi and<tei:lb/>albolineatus albolineatus. Figures 31-39 also show dorsal views of the pronotum of males of all<tei:lb/>the taxa dealt with in this paper. In most species the lateral carinae are almost straight but in<tei:lb/>sardous they are distinctly incurved in the prozona (Fig. 38). They are also somewhat incurved in<tei:lb/>angustulus, but less so in specimens from Majorca than in those from Formentera.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>12</tei:p>
         <tei:p>T10</tei:p>
         <tei:p>THE TAXONOMY OF THE WESTERN EUROPEAN EUCHORTHIPPUS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>albolineatus albolineatus ()</tei:p>
         <tei:p>113</tei:p>
         <tei:p>France<tei:lb/>a</tei:p>
         <tei:p>... ... I A Fran</tei:p>
         <tei:p>pulvinatus gamcus 4 . .</tei:p>

         <tei:p>angusfu/us (o)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>pulvinatus elegantulusi .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I ^ Brittan</tei:p>
         <tei:p>sardous (*)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>234<tei:lb/>DISTANCE FROM STIGMA TO TIP OF FORE WING (mm)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 10 Scatter diagram showing a plot of the length of the hind femur against the distance from the stigma<tei:lb/>to the tip of the fore wing in males of Euchorthippus. To facilitate comparison broken lines are used for<tei:lb/>the two Iberian samples.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fore wing</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The absolute and relative lengths of the fore wing are useful characters and have been much used<tei:lb/>by previous authors (e.g. Defaut, 1982). The position of the tip of the fore wing in relation to the<tei:lb/>hind knee or, less reliably, the apex of the abdomen provides one of the easiest methods of<tei:lb/>distinguishing between typical declivus, pulvmatus gallicus and chopardi in the field (Figs<tei:lb/>25-30) . The length of the fore wing is more useful when taken as a ratio with the length of the<tei:lb/>hind femur; this is particularly true in the female, in which the range of our sample of p. gallicus<tei:lb/>does not overlap with those of chopardi or a. albolineatus (Fig. 87).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The fore wings are short in declivus and become progressively longer in both sexes in the<tei:lb/>sequence declivus, p. gallicus, chopardi and a. albolineatus (Figs 83, 87).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The distance from the stigma to the tip of the fore wing is, to some extent, proportional to the<tei:lb/>length of the fore wing but provides an even better character, especially when used as a ratio with<tei:lb/>the length of the hind femur (Figs 84, 85, 88). When these two characters are plotted against each<tei:lb/>other in a scatter diagram, there is no overlap in our male samples of the populations of the three<tei:lb/>species occurring in France (declivus, pulvinatus and chopardi) or between the two occurring<tei:lb/>commonly in Spain (pulvinatus and chopardi) (Fig. 10). In females there is no overlap at all<tei:lb/>between our samples of declivus, pulvinatus and chopardi (Fig. 11), though a. albolineatus is<tei:lb/>very closely associated with chopardi in both sexes. E. p. elegantulus agrees with p. gallicus<tei:lb/>rather than with declivus when the measurements are plotted against the length of the hind<tei:lb/>femur (Figs 10, 11) or, in males, against the number of stridulatory pegs (Fig. 9).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>114</tei:p>
         <tei:p>16</tei:p>
         <tei:p>15</tei:p>
         <tei:p>14</tei:p>
         <tei:p>13</tei:p>
         <tei:p>12</tei:p>
         <tei:p>10</tei:p>
