         <tei:p>Fig. 1 1 Scatter diagram showing a plot of the length of the hind femur against the distance from the stigma<tei:lb/>to the tip of the fore wing in females of Euchorthippus . To facilitate comparison broken lines are used for<tei:lb/>the two Iberian samples.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hind wing</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The length of the hind wing is often a useful character (Figs 83, 87), especially when taken as a<tei:lb/>ratio with the length of the hind femur (Figs 84, 87) . In this ratio, for both sexes, p. elegantulus is<tei:lb/>again closer top. gallicus than to declivus, which is distinct from all the other taxa. In the female<tei:lb/>this character separates chopardi from/7, gallicus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Projection of the fore wing beyond the hind wing</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The distinct gap between the tips of the flexed fore and hind wings provides the best character for<tei:lb/>distinguishing declivus from the remaining taxa (Figs 8, 84, 88). This character has been<tei:lb/>mentioned by several authors (Chopard, 1952; Descamps, 1968; Harz, 1975; Luquet, 1978;<tei:lb/>Defaut, 1982) but its significance in showing that elegantulus is distinct from declivus has not<tei:lb/>been previously realized (see p. 132).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hind femur</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The length of the hind femur (Figs 82, 86) is useful only as a measure of size, for which purpose<tei:lb/>we have used it in ratios with the length of the fore wing, the length of the hind wing and the<tei:lb/>distance from the stigma to the tip of the fore wing (Figs 10, 11, 84, 85, 87, 88).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Stridulatory file</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Counting the Stridulatory pegs takes at least a minute per specimen and ideally requires a<tei:lb/>microscope with a movable stage. We have found the effort worthwhile, however, as this<tei:lb/>character, in combination with stigma distance and pronotum/head ratio on a triangular graph,</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE TAXONOMY OF THE WESTERN EUROPEAN EUCHORTHIPPUS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>115</tei:p>
         <tei:p>France &gt;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>&gt; declivus<tei:lb/>o Italy J</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A France i</tei:p>
         <tei:p>&gt;pu/v/nafus gallicus<tei:lb/>T Iberia J</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A Jersey 1</tei:p>
         <tei:p>^pu/vinafuj e/eganfu/us<tei:lb/>v Brittany J r</tei:p>
         <tei:p>France ,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>&gt; chopardi<tei:lb/>D Iberia J</tei:p>
         <tei:p>65,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>30 y</tei:p>
         <tei:p>LENGTH OF PRONOTUM/LENGTH OF HEAD (xlOO)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 12 Triangular graph showing the relationship between males of Euchorthippus declivus, E. pulvina-<tei:lb/>tus and E. chopardi as determined by three diagnostic characters. (See the text for full explanation.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>has provided one of the best means of separating males of declivus, pulvinatus and chopardi (Fig.<tei:lb/>12). The first two of these characters give almost as good a separation in a two-axis scatter<tei:lb/>diagram (Fig. 9). The stridulatory pegs provide another character showing the close relationship<tei:lb/>between p. elegantulus and/?, gallicus (Fig. 83). E. p. elegantulus has, on average, slightly fewer<tei:lb/>pegs than/?, gallicus, as would be expected from the difference in size, but in both of the two-axis<tei:lb/>scatter diagrams and in the triangular graph/?, elegantulus is clearly more closely associated with<tei:lb/>/?. gallicus than with declivus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>We have found it necessary to examine the female stridulatory pegs only in order to find the<tei:lb/>best means of separating a. siculus and pulvinatus . The pegs are smaller in females and are more<tei:lb/>likely to be replaced by hairs, but it is still usually possible to count them by viewing the file in<tei:lb/>profile. In cases where this is difficult a replica of the file can be made (see Pitkin, 1976).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>We did not find the length of the stridulatory file to be a useful character, the very short file of<tei:lb/>sardous simply reflecting the generally small size of this species and in particular its short hind<tei:lb/>femora (cf. Figs 82 and 83).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>116</tei:p>
         <tei:p>D. R. RAGGE &amp; W. J. REYNOLDS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>a/bo/ineafus a/bo/ineafus<tei:lb/>O a/bo/ineafus sicu/us</tei:p>
         <tei:p>* sardous</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$ angusfulus</tei:p>
         <tei:p>65</tei:p>
         <tei:p>35</tei:p>
         <tei:p>30.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>declivus</tei:p>
         <tei:p>a/bo/ineafus sicu/us</tei:p>
         <tei:p>angusfu/us</tei:p>
         <tei:p>a/bolineafus a/bo/ineafus</tei:p>
         <tei:p>. v t . . &gt; \ . &gt;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>LENGTH OF PRONOTUM/LENGTH OF HEAD (xlOO)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 13 Triangular graph showing the relationship between males of Euchorthippus as determined by<tei:lb/>three diagnostic characters. The detailed plots for E. declivus, E. pulvinatus and E. chopardi are shown<tei:lb/>in Fig. 12. (See the text for full explanation.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male subgenital plate and abdominal tergites 9+10</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The shape of the male subgenital plate has been used as a key character by all previous authors.<tei:lb/>Descamps (1968) tried to make this character more objective by comparing the length of the<tei:lb/>subgenital plate with that of abdominal tergites 9+10, and concluded that in declivus and<tei:lb/>pulvinatus the dorsal part of the subgenital plate was longer than abdominal tergites 9+10 in<tei:lb/>profile, while in chopardi, a. albolineatus, a. siculus, angustulus and sardous these tergites were<tei:lb/>longer than, or subequal to, the subgenital plate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>We have found that measuring the subgenital plate accurately in dried specimens is difficult,<tei:lb/>since post mortem shrinkage may cause the proximal end of the subgenital plate to be covered by<tei:lb/>the supra-anal plate. Another problem is caused by the way in which variation in the degree of<tei:lb/>curvature of the abdomen affects the measurement of the length of tergites 9+ 10. Perhaps partly<tei:lb/>because of these difficulties, we have not found the ratio of the length of the subgenital plate to<tei:lb/>that of abdominal tergites 9+10 to be particularly useful; for declivus and/?, gallicus the ratio is<tei:lb/>in fact less useful than the length of the subgenital plate alone (Fig. 85).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE TAXONOMY OF THE WESTERN EUROPEAN EUCHORTHIPPUS 117</tei:p>
         <tei:p>We have found the shape of the male subgenital plate to be more useful than its dimensions. It<tei:lb/>is always distinctly pointed in declivus, bluntly rounded in chopardi and intermediate in<tei:lb/>pulvinatus (Figs 25, 27, 29), but without some experience of the group it is easy to be misled by<tei:lb/>this character. The frequent misidentification of Spanish p. gallicus as declivus has doubtless<tei:lb/>been the result of using the male subgenital plate as the principal distinguishing character.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Internal male genitalia</tei:p>
         <tei:p>We have examined the internal male genitalia of all the species included in this study and have<tei:lb/>found no taxonomically useful character.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour pattern</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Most specimens show some degree of dark longitudinal striping, especially on the head, and in<tei:lb/>chopardi these stripes are particularly conspicuous (Fig. 40). We have seen a few conspicuously<tei:lb/>striped specimens that seem to be pulvinatus on other characters, but well-developed stripes of<tei:lb/>the kind shown in Fig. 40 are characteristic of chopardi.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cytology</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In common with other Gomphocerinae of the Chorthippus-group, the species of Euchorthippus<tei:lb/>in which the chromosomes have been studied have complements of 17 in the male (XO) and 18 in<tei:lb/>the female (XX) (Hewitt, 1979, Santos etal. , 1983). The chromosomes of pulvinatus have been<tei:lb/>examined by McClung (1932), Arana etal. (1980), Ferrer etal. (1981), Santos &amp; Giraldez (1982)<tei:lb/>and Santos et al. (1983), while those of albolineatus have been described by Carlson (1936)<tei:lb/>(Carlson's specimens were identified by Hebard as pulvinatus, but as they came from Algeria<tei:lb/>they were almost certainly albolineatus, the only species of Euchorthippus known to occur in<tei:lb/>North Africa). Santos et al. (1983) have also examined the chromosomes of Spanish chopardi<tei:lb/>and have shown that the C-banding patterns differ quite markedly from those of Spanish<tei:lb/>pulvinatus (these authors refer to chopardi as 'albolineatus' , but Dr Santos has kindly shown us<tei:lb/>the specimens and we consider them to be chopardi). Although the number and gross<tei:lb/>morphology of the chromosomes are likely to be uniform throughout the genus, it would clearly<tei:lb/>be interesting to study the C-banding patterns in other species; careful comparison may also<tei:lb/>reveal differences in chiasma frequency, relative lengths of chromosomes or DNA content of<tei:lb/>equivalent nuclei (John &amp; Hewitt, 1966; White, 1972).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Santos et al. (1983: 73) have succeeded in rearing artificial hybrids between pulvinatus and<tei:lb/>chopardi. This raises the possibility of natural hybrids occurring between these species, which<tei:lb/>quite often occur together. We have seen a few specimens that are intermediate between the two<tei:lb/>in some morphological characters, but in order to recognize natural hybrids with any confidence<tei:lb/>it would be necessary to investigate them genetically and, in the case of males, to analyse the<tei:lb/>calling song.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Song</tei:p>
         <tei:p>There has been no comprehensive study of the acoustic behaviour of Euchorthippus, but several<tei:lb/>authors have published comments on the songs of one or more species. Chopard (1952) briefly<tei:lb/>outlined the calling song of pulvinatus and Faber (1953) described its complete acoustic<tei:lb/>repertoire, including calling, courtship and rivalry songs. Descamps (1968) published oscillo-<tei:lb/>grams of one echeme each of declivus, pulvinatus and chopardi, but found no noticeable<tei:lb/>difference between them and gave a single description of the calling and courtship songs for all<tei:lb/>three species. Luquet (1978) gave a diagram of one echeme for each of these species and<tei:lb/>suggested that the echeme was longest in declivus, almost as long in chopardi and shortest in<tei:lb/>pulvinatus (our own analyses, however, show the echemes to be longer in chopardi than in<tei:lb/>declivus - see Fig. 20). Luquet also found that pulvinatus had a more rapid 'cadence' (?<tei:lb/>echeme repetition rate) than the other two species, but he considered these differences to be</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>118</tei:p>
         <tei:p>D. R. RAGGE &amp; W. J. REYNOLDS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>insufficient to permit identification in the field. Schmidt &amp; Schach (1978) gave oscillograms of<tei:lb/>the courtship song of pulvinatus and declivus, and described differences in the duration of the<tei:lb/>syllables and echemes, but neither these authors nor any others have seriously suggested using<tei:lb/>the song as a taxonomic character.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Figs 14-19 Oscillograms of typical male calling songs of (14, 17) Euchorthippus declivus, (15, 18) E.<tei:lb/>pulvinatus and (16, 19) E. chopardi. Figs 17-19 are faster oscillograms of the single echemes indicated in<tei:lb/>Figs 14-16. The oscillograms were taken from recordings 233/6, 232/4 and 236/8, for which full<tei:lb/>information is given in Table 1 (p. 107).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE TAXONOMY OF THE WESTERN EUROPEAN EUCHORTHIPPUS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>119</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 20 Data for four characters of the male calling songs of Euchorthippus declivus, E. pulvinatus and E.<tei:lb/>chopardi. For explanation of the bars see Fig. 7; n = number of males, n e = number of echemes from<tei:lb/>which data were taken. Note that in compiling these charts the mean values obtained from each male<tei:lb/>were treated as individual observations. (For further explanation see p. 110.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>While our own observations are broadly in agreement with those of these authors, our more<tei:lb/>detailed analyses have revealed good, taxonomically useful differences between the songs of<tei:lb/>declivus, pulvinatus and chopardi. Figures 14-19 show oscillograms of typical sequences of<tei:lb/>echemes from the male calling songs of these three species, followed by much faster oscillograms<tei:lb/>of single echemes selected from these sequences. The full data from all our recordings are given<tei:lb/>in Fig. 20 and scatter diagrams from four selected pairs of song characters are shown in Figs<tei:lb/>21-24. The most striking difference is between the large number of gaps per echeme in declivus<tei:lb/>and the much smaller number in pulvinatus. This difference has not previously been observed<tei:lb/>although it is clearly visible in the oscillograms given by Descamps (1968: Fig. 23 - but note that<tei:lb/>the oscillogram for declivus is shown backwards) . The number of gaps per echeme in chopardi is<tei:lb/>also lower than in declivus, but the difference is less striking and our recordings of chopardi show<tei:lb/>a high degree of variability in this character. Both the syllables and echemes are of shorter<tei:lb/>duration in pulvinatus than in declivus, the syllables showing the clearer contrast (Fig. 20). In all<tei:lb/>these characters the bar-charts and scatter diagrams show a close association between p. gallicus<tei:lb/>and p. elegantulus (Figs 20-24).</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Figs 21-24 Scatter diagrams showing plots of four pairs of characters of the male calling songs of<tei:lb/>Euchorthippus declivus, E. pulvinatus and E. chopardi. Note that each point represents the mean values<tei:lb/>of the two characters obtained from one male. The symbols are explained in Fig. 21.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>None of these differences in song can be measured without the help of recording and analysing<tei:lb/>equipment - indeed the gaps , which last for little more than a millisecond , are quite undetectable<tei:lb/>by the unaided human ear (though being easily resolved by the insects themselves - see, for<tei:lb/>example, the review of Autrum, 1963). The only song character that can be used as an aid to field<tei:lb/>identification is the echeme repetition rate, which can be quite easily measured using the second<tei:lb/>hand (or digital count) of a wrist- watch. As shown in Fig. 20 this character does not show striking<tei:lb/>contrasts between the species but, when they are singing in similar warm, sunny conditions,<tei:lb/>chopardi has a slower rate than the other two, and pulvinatus usually has a faster rate than<tei:lb/>declivus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>It should be emphasized that, for taxonomic use, measurements of all these characters should<tei:lb/>be based on as many echemes as possible and should always be taken from songs produced by<tei:lb/>isolated males singing in warm sunshine (or in a warm laboratory with a source of radiant heat).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE TAXONOMY OF THE WESTERN EUROPEAN EUCHORTHIPPUS 121</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The echeme repetition rate should be based only on regular sequences of echemes (see p. 106)<tei:lb/>and, for each male, it is the mean values of all these song characters that should be compared<tei:lb/>with the bar-charts and scatter diagrams (Figs 20-24).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The number of syllables in each echeme (usually 6-7, occasionally 5 or 8) appears to have little<tei:lb/>or no taxonomic value. We counted the syllables in the course of calculating the syllable<tei:lb/>duration, and it soon became clear that intraspecific variation would obscure any trend towards<tei:lb/>an interspecific difference.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>EUCHORTHIPPUS Tarbinskii</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euchorthippus Tarbinskii, 1925: 192; Uvarov, 1926: 341 [redescription]. Type-species: Oedipoda pulvi-</tei:p>
         <tei:p>nata Fischer de Waldheim, by original designation.<tei:lb/>Sinhippus Ramme, 1939: 132. Type-species: Sinhlppus alinl Ramme [= Euchorthippus unicolor (Ikonni-</tei:p>
         <tei:p>kov)], by original designation. [Synonymized by Bei-Bienko &amp; Mishchenko, 1951: 543.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS, cf $ Fastigium of vertex rather rounded and relatively blunt; foveolae rather short and<tei:lb/>shallow, each with weak carinula leading inwards and backwards from its posterior end. Antennae not<tei:lb/>clubbed. Lateral carinae of pronotum straight or slightly incurved. Pleura coarsely rugose and punctate.<tei:lb/>Inner and outer tarsal claws of different lengths. Brachypterous to macropterous. Precostal area of fore<tei:lb/>wings with small bulge on anterior margin; medial area not conspicuously widened, without intercalary<tei:lb/>vein and with irregular cross-veins. Hind wings transparent and colourless. Subgenital plate bluntly to<tei:lb/>acutely conical. Ovipositor short, without lateral teeth. General coloration brown, straw-coloured or grey<tei:lb/>(sometimes with greenish tinge but never clearly green or reddish in western European species), with<tei:lb/>longitudinal dark and light stripes on head and sometimes pronotum. Female usually with white linea<tei:lb/>scapularis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male calling song. In the four species whose stridulation we have studied (declivus, pulvinatus, chopardi<tei:lb/>and angustulus) the calling songs have the same basic structure though differing in detail (Fig. 4). They<tei:lb/>consist of a sequence of echemes repeated at a rate of 0-5-1-5 per second for an indefinite period,<tei:lb/>sometimes a minute or more. Oscillographic analysis shows that each echeme begins quietly, lasts about<tei:lb/>150-350 ms and is composed of 5-8 syllables, each of which has a quiet first part and a louder second part; in<tei:lb/>at least the later part of each echeme, the louder second part of each syllable contains momentary breaks in<tei:lb/>the sound, referred to in this paper as 'gaps' (Fig. 4).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISCUSSION. Euchorthippus is an easily recognized genus to the experienced acridologist, but its<tei:lb/>morphological diagnostic characters are rather subtle and difficult to describe. In comparison<tei:lb/>with Chorthippus, with which it is most easily confused, Euchorthippus has a more elongate<tei:lb/>head when viewed from the side, with the eyes produced anterodorsally into a more pronounced<tei:lb/>and acute angle. The foveolae are rather weakly (sometimes very weakly) developed, and from<tei:lb/>the posterior end of each one arises a feeble carinula, usually extending inwards and backwards<tei:lb/>towards the mid-line of the head, where there is often another feeble median carinula, especially<tei:lb/>on the fastigium; these carinulae are quite absent in Chorthippus. The difference in size between<tei:lb/>the inner and outer tarsal claws has been used by some authors as a key character, but there is<tei:lb/>sometimes a tendency towards this size difference in Chorthippus. The western European<tei:lb/>species of Euchorthippus are always brown, straw-coloured or grey and, although sometimes<tei:lb/>showing a greenish tinge, never have the clear green or reddish colours common in Chorthippus<tei:lb/>and other Gomphocerinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The calling song of the male provides a particularly good character for recognizing Euchor-<tei:lb/>thippus in the field. The long sequences of rapidly repeated echemes are highly characteristic<tei:lb/>and quite unlike the songs of any other European Gomphocerinae we have heard. Some other<tei:lb/>Gomphocerinae (e.g. Chorthippus parallelus (Zetterstedt), C. montanus (Charpentier), C.<tei:lb/>dorsatus (Zetterstedt), C. dichrous (Eversmann), Chrysochraon dispar (Germar)) have calling<tei:lb/>songs composed of long sequences of echemes, but in all these cases the repetition rate is much<tei:lb/>lower, never higher than one every two seconds. The echeme-sequences of Euchorthippus are in<tei:lb/>fact more strongly reminiscent of those produced by some Tettigoniidae, especially such<tei:lb/>Decticinae as Metrioptera brachyptera (L.), Platycleis sabulosa Azam and P. albopunctata<tei:lb/>(Goeze), all of which are at least partially diurnal singers; P. sabulosa even has a similar number<tei:lb/>of syllables per echeme (usually 6-7), but all these species have a higher echeme repetition rate</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>122 D. R. RAGGE &amp; W. J. REYNOLDS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>when singing during the day, usually more than 2 echemes/s in warm sunshine. Although<tei:lb/>isolated males of Euchorthippus can maintain a fairly regular echeme repetition rate for quite<tei:lb/>long periods, they never quite achieve the almost mechanical regularity and very long duration<tei:lb/>(often many minutes) of the echeme-sequences of these Decticine bush-crickets.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>There is no elaborate courtship song but in the presence of a female the male produces a<tei:lb/>somewhat modified song in which the echemes are quieter and the sequences longer than usual.<tei:lb/>Faber (1953) described a second stage in the courtship song of pulvinatus in which there is a<tei:lb/>gradual increase in the intensity, repetition rate and duration of the echemes, and in the number<tei:lb/>of syllables per echeme. Just before jumping on to the female, the male produces two or three<tei:lb/>quiet sounds, each consisting of one or two syllables, and then one loud and more extended<tei:lb/>sound of uniform intensity.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Southern Europe, most of the larger Mediterranean islands, Madeira, North<tei:lb/>Africa and temperate Asia as far as China.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>INCLUDED SPECIES. E. albolineatus (Lucas), E. angustulus Ramme, E. arabicus Uvarov, E.<tei:lb/>chenbaensis Tu &amp; Cheng, E. cheui Hsia, E. chopardi Descamps, E. declivus (Brisout), E.<tei:lb/>madeirae Uvarov, E. pulvinatus (Fischer de Waldheim), E. sardous Nadig, E. transcaucasicus<tei:lb/>Tarbinskii, E. unicolor (Ikonnikov), E. weichowensis Chang, E. yungningensis Cheng.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to the western European and North African species and subspecies of Euchorthippus</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The two mainland taxa pulvinatus gallicus and chopardi, both common in southern France and the Iberian<tei:lb/>Peninsula, are particularly difficult to distinguish from each other, and for reliable identification of<tei:lb/>specimens from these regions (even including females thought to be declivus} we recommend taking the<tei:lb/>relevant measurements and plotting them on the scatter diagrams shown in Figs 10 and 11. For males the<tei:lb/>use of the triangular graph shown in Fig. 12, although requiring more effort, will produce an even more<tei:lb/>reliable result.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>E. albolineatus albolineatus (Lucas) (p. 135)<tei:lb/>- Known only from the Balearic Islands. Smaller: length of hind femur usually less than 9.4 mm in</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>

         <tei:p>THE TAXONOMY OF THE WESTERN EUROPEAN EUCHORTHIPPUS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>125</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Descriptions of the species</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euchorthippus declivus (Brisout)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 25, 26, 31)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acridium declivum Brisout, [1849]: 420. LECTOTYPE $, FRANCE: near Paris, St-Germain (MNHN,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paris), here designated [examined].<tei:lb/>Stenobothrus pulvinatus var. gracilis Azam, 1901: 46. LECTOTYPE cf , FRANCE: near Clermont-Ferrand,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Puy de Crouelle, viii.1896 (M. H. du Buyssoh) (MNHN, Paris), here designated [examined]. [Synony-</tei:p>
         <tei:p>mized by Chopard, 1952: 303.]<tei:lb/>Euchorthippus declivus (Brisout) Uvarov, 1926: 341.<tei:lb/>Euchorthippus declivus merldlonalis Jannone, 1937: 57. LECTOTYPE cf , ITALY: Puglia, Monte Angeli,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2.ix.l935 (TEA, Portici), here designated [examined]. [Synonymized by La Greca, 1959: 138.]<tei:lb/>Euchorthippus declivus stichai Mafan, 1954: 137. Holotype cf, CZECHOSLOVAKIA: Kamemin, viii.1952</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(/. Mafan) (NM, Prague) [examined]. [Synonymized by Harz, 1975: 924.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS, cf $. Pronotal lateral carinae relatively low and broad; length of pronotum usually 0-98-1-41<tei:lb/>times length of head. Fore wings relatively short, not or hardly reaching apical quarter of hind femora in cf ,<tei:lb/>middle of hind femora in 9 , but usually projecting beyond hind wings by at least 0-8 mm in cf , at least 0-5<tei:lb/>mm in $ ; distance from stigma to tip of fore wing usually less than 0-21 times length of hind femur in cf , less<tei:lb/>than 0-25 in $ . Length of hind wing usually less than 0-87 times length of hind femur in cf , less than 0-78 in<tei:lb/>$. Male stridulatory file usually with 75-120 pegs. Male subgenital plate relatively long and pointed, as in<tei:lb/>Fig. 25. (Full data for measurements, ratios and number of stridulatory pegs are given in the bar-charts on<tei:lb/>pp. 144-150.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male calling song (see Figs 14, 17, 41-^45). Each echeme usually with 10-15 gaps. Other song characters<tei:lb/>as shown in bar-charts (p. 119).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ml</tei:p>
         <tei:p>41 180/3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>#</tei:p>
         <tei:p>42 232/2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>43 233/6</tei:p>
         <tei:p>44 241/1</tei:p>
         <tei:p>45 484/4</tei:p>
         <tei:p>20 Hz</tei:p>
         <tei:p>0-1 s</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Figs 41-45 Oscillograms of single echemes from the calling songs of five French males of Euchorthippus<tei:lb/>declivus. The small numbers refer to the recordings from which the oscillograms were made and can be<tei:lb/>used to obtain the full data from Tables 1 and 2 (pp. 107, 108).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>126 D. R. RAGGE &amp; W. J. REYNOLDS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISCUSSION. This is the most easily recognizable of the mainland species of Euchorthippus in<tei:lb/>western Europe. As can be seen in Figs 8, 84 and 88, the projection of the fore wings beyond the<tei:lb/>hind wings (when both pairs of wings are flexed) enables the males, and usually the females, to<tei:lb/>be identified at once. In all the other western Palaearctic species (except madeirae - see below)<tei:lb/>the tips of the two pairs of flexed wings are coincident or almost so in live or freshly killed<tei:lb/>specimens, though a very small gap often develops in dried specimens. The length of the hind<tei:lb/>wing and the distance from the stigma to the tip of the fore wing, both taken as a ratio with the<tei:lb/>length of the hind femur, also provide good characters in both sexes (see Figs 10, 11, 84, 85, 87,<tei:lb/>88). The male is further characterized by the relatively long and pointed subgenital plate (Fig.<tei:lb/>25).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The endemic Madeiran species E. madeirae Uvarov resembles dedivus in having rather low,<tei:lb/>broad pronotal lateral carinae and short wings, with the fore wings extending well beyond the<tei:lb/>hind wings. However, the males have a much shorter and blunter subgenital plate than dedivus,<tei:lb/>and the pronotal lateral carinae are more clearly incurved in both sexes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>There is a rare macropterous form of dedivus in which the fore wings reach a length of 11-13<tei:lb/>mm in the male and 13-15 mm in the female. This form has been recorded from the<tei:lb/>south-western Slovakian steppe in Czechoslovakia by Mafan (1957: 189) and from Gran Sasso,<tei:lb/>Abruzzi, Italy by Baccetti (1958: 426-428); we have seen further specimens from Rome and<tei:lb/>from near Banja Luka in Yugoslavia. In the specimens we have examined the fore wings project<tei:lb/>beyond the hind wings by much less than is typical of dedivus and the distance from the stigma to<tei:lb/>the tip of the fore wing is usually larger, but they can be distinguished from pulvinatus by the<tei:lb/>relatively low pronotal lateral carinae and , in the male , the shape of the subgenital plate . Dr J . J .<tei:lb/>Presa has kindly informed us that he now believes that his records of this form from the Sierra de<tei:lb/>Guadarrama, Spain (Presa, 1978: 125) were based on misidentifiedpw/vmflfaj.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The calling song of the male (see Figs 14, 41-45) cannot be recognized as dedivus with the<tei:lb/>unaided ear, but oscillographic analysis shows that it has a larger number of gaps per echeme<tei:lb/>than both pulvinatus and chopardi (see p. 119 for further discussion).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In France dedivus occurs further north than pulvinatus and chopardi and seems, as one would<tei:lb/>expect, to be more hygrophilous. It probably shows a similar ecological preference in northern<tei:lb/>Spain, but in Italy, where it is apparently the only species of Euchorthippus to occur on the<tei:lb/>mainland, it seems to be able to tolerate drier conditions, tending to occupy the habitats<tei:lb/>associated with all three species in France and Spain.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>For discussion of the transfer of the subspecies elegantulus from dedivus to pulvinatus see p.<tei:lb/>131.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>We have examined seven female specimens, three from the MNHN, Paris and four from the<tei:lb/>IRSNB, Brussels, that have been regarded in these institutions as syntypes of Acridium<tei:lb/>dedivum Brisout. We have also examined a number of further specimens of both sexes from the<tei:lb/>IRSNB that had previously been in the collection of de Selys Longchamps (who had earlier<tei:lb/>acquired Brisout's collection) and that could therefore also be regarded as possible syntypes of<tei:lb/>this species. Of all these specimens only one is labelled as being from one of the four<tei:lb/>type-localities named by Brisout (1849: 420); this is one of the three female specimens from the<tei:lb/>MNHN and is labelled 'St Germain'. We feel that this is the only specimen we have examined<tei:lb/>that can be regarded with confidence as a syntype and we have accordingly selected and labelled<tei:lb/>it aslectotype.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>We have examined the male and female syntypes of Stenobothrus pulvinatus var. gracilis<tei:lb/>Azam, and have selected and labelled the male as lectotype.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>We have also selected and labelled a male lectotype from the type-series of Euchorthippus<tei:lb/>dedivus meridionalis Jannone. This specimen, from Monte Angeli, is in much better condition<tei:lb/>than the male specimen labelled 'Tipo' by Jannone, which was from Altamura.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Primary types (see synonymy) and 558 other specimens from the following localities.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>France. Marne (no further data). Paris. Yvelines: St-Germain. Essonne: Lardy. Seine-et-Marne:<tei:lb/>Fontainebleau; Fontainebleau Forest; Episy. Haute-Marne: Colombey-les-Deux-Eglises. Loire-</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE TAXONOMY OF THE WESTERN EUROPEAN EUCHORTHIPPUS 127</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Atlantique: Varades. Yonne: 33 km E. of Sens, near Villeneuve-l'Archeveque. Cher: 23 km S. of Briare.<tei:lb/>Nievre: LaCharite. Puy-de-D6me: 12kmN. of Thiers; near Besse-en-Chandesse, Saurier; near Clermont-<tei:lb/>Ferrand, Puy de Crouelle; near Issoire, Clemensat. Dordogne: Bergerac; near Le Bugue, Campagne.<tei:lb/>Savoie: Flumet. Haute-Loire: St-Paulien; 5 kmN. of LePuy; 16kmS. of Cascades de la Baume. Lot: near<tei:lb/>Souillac. Ardeche: nearPrivas. Lozere: 34 kmN. of Mende; near Mende, Col deMontmirat. Drome: near<tei:lb/>Valdrome. Landes: near Arcachon, Biscarrosse; near Morcenx. Vaucluse: Mont Ventoux; near Carpen-<tei:lb/>tras, Bedoin. Alpes-de-Haute-Provence: N. of Digne, La Rouine, 760-1070 m. Herault: 5 km E. of<tei:lb/>Montpellier. Haute-Garonne: 15 km N. of Toulouse. Alpes-Maritimes: near St-Dalmas-de-Tende; Col de<tei:lb/>Vence, 930 m; near Grasse, Greolieres; Mt Courmette; Thorenc; St-Martin-Vesubie; Auron, 1580 m. Var:<tei:lb/>c. 4 km W. of Cannes, Esveral; near Comps-sur-Artuby, Bargeme. Pyrenees-Orientales: Vernet-les-<tei:lb/>Bains, near Le Perthus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Spain. Santander: Playa de Cobreces. Leon: Riano. Huesca: Ordesa. Teruel: Montoro de Mezquita,<tei:lb/>Masada del Cerro, 1300 m; Villarluengo, 1270 m.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Italy. Piemonte: Voltaggio. Liguria: Chiavari; Portofino, Vetta; near Sestri, Bracco Pass, 600 m. Emilia<tei:lb/>Romagna: Vetto. Toscana: nearM. Amiata,4kmSW. of Bagni San Fillipo; 17kmE. of Siena; Siena, near<tei:lb/>Colleverde camp site; near Firenze, Futa Pass. Abruzzi: Gran Sasso d'ltalia, Fonte Cerreto, near Staz<tei:lb/>Funivia, 340 m; G.S.I. , 2 km SW. of Valle Fredda; Civitella del Tronto. Lazio: Roma; near Casa del Corta;<tei:lb/>between Acquapendente and Lake Bolzena. Puglia: Monte Angeli; Altamura. Basilicata: Venosa, 420 m;<tei:lb/>Varco di Pietrastretta, near Potenza, 850 m.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION (see Fig. 81). All France except for the north-western peninsulas and the extreme<tei:lb/>north and north-east; northern and north-eastern Spain; southern Switzerland; most of Italy;<tei:lb/>Sicily and Sardinia. Central and eastern Europe (as far north as southern and eastern Austria,<tei:lb/>southern Czechoslovakia and south-western Ukraine); most of the Balkan Peninsula; Asia<tei:lb/>Minor. E. declivus seems to be the only species of Euchorthippus occurring in mainland Italy,<tei:lb/>where it is widespread.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>There have been a number of published records of declivus from various parts of Spain; the<tei:lb/>more recent ones include those of Gangwere &amp; Morales (1970: 58), Presa (1978: 125), Herrera<tei:lb/>(1979: 59), Gonzalez (1981: 61), Presa &amp; Garcia (1982: 130) and Defaut (1982: 82, 85). In his<tei:lb/>recent catalogue Herrera (1982: 105) lists for declivus eight widely scattered Spanish provinces.<tei:lb/>Following an examination of specimens kindly lent to us by Drs L. Herrera and M. J. Gonzalez,<tei:lb/>we consider their records for the provinces of Navarra and Salamanca, respectively, to be based<tei:lb/>in misidentifiedpw/vmarws, and Dr J. J. Presa has informed us that he now believes the same to<tei:lb/>apply to his records from the Sierra de Guadarrama and the record from Murcia province cited<tei:lb/>in his joint paper with Dr M. D. Garcia. Dr B. Defaut has kindly lent us the specimens on which<tei:lb/>his record from Teruel province was based and we agree with his identification. We have not<tei:lb/>been able to check the basis for the remaining records but, in view of the frequent confusion<tei:lb/>between these two species in Spain, are inclined to regard all Spanish records of declivus as<tei:lb/>needing confirmation. Apart from those mentioned above from Teruel province, the only<tei:lb/>Spanish specimens of declivus we have seen were from Santander, Leon and Huesca provinces<tei:lb/>and were kindly lent to us by Dr G. Kruseman of the Instituut voor Taxonomische Zoologie,<tei:lb/>Amsterdam, Dr V. Llorente of the Institute Espanol de Entomologia, Madrid, and Dr J. L.<tei:lb/>Santos of the Universidad Complutense, Madrid. The 97 specimens of Euchorthippus from the<tei:lb/>Iberian Peninsula in the BMNH are all either pulvinatus or chopardi, and we have not seen<tei:lb/>declivus during our own visits to Spain.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euchorthippus pulvinatus (Fischer de Waldheim)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 27, 28, 32, 35, 36)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Oedipoda pulvinata Fischer de Waldheim, 1846: 305. Type-material lost. Type-localities, U.S.S.R.: near</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Moscow; Kazan? ('Casan'); Karabag? ('Karabagh'); Caucasus.<tei:lb/>Euchorthippus pulvinatus (Fischer de Waldheim) Tarbmskii, 1926: 192.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The nominate subspecies of pulvinatus does not occur in western Europe and has thus been<tei:lb/>excluded from this study. We have considered it best not to take it into account in the diagnosis<tei:lb/>given below, which is therefore based only on the two western subspecies gallicus and</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>128 D. R. RAGGE &amp; W. J. REYNOLDS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>elegantulus. Most of the characters given in the diagnosis are probably equally true of p.<tei:lb/>pulvinatus, but this subspecies has longer wings, the fore wings usually reaching the tips of the<tei:lb/>hind femora in both sexes. The brief diagnoses given ioigallicus and elegantulus include only the<tei:lb/>characters by which these two subspecies differ from each other.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. cf $. Pronotal lateral carinae relatively high and narrow; length of pronotum usually 0-88-1-20<tei:lb/>times length of head in cf , 0-97-1-32 in $. Fore wings not usually reaching tips of hind femora in cf , not<tei:lb/>reaching bases of genicular lobes in $; distance from stigma to tip of fore wing usually 0-20-0-33 times<tei:lb/>length of hind femur in cf , 0-26-0-37 in $. Length of hind wing usually 0-91-1-16 times length of hind<tei:lb/>femur in d", 0-79-1-00 in $. Stridulatory file usually with 115-165 pegs in d", 115-145 pegs or hairs in $.<tei:lb/>Male subgenital plate of moderate length and tending to be slightly pointed, as in Fig. 27. (Full data for<tei:lb/>measurements, ratios and number of Stridulatory pegs are given in the bar-charts on pp. 144-150.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male calling song (see Figs 15, 18, 46-64, 66-70). Echeme repetition rate usually 0-8-1-6/s. Syllables<tei:lb/>usually lasting 20-35 ms. Other song characters as shown in bar-charts (p. 119).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISCUSSION. This species can be easily distinguished from declivus by the characters listed and<tei:lb/>discussed under that species. Distinguishing pulvinatus from chopardi where their ranges<tei:lb/>overlap in southern France and the Iberian Peninsula is much more difficult, especially if a<tei:lb/>reliable reference collection is not available. E. pulvinatus almost always lacks the strong<tei:lb/>longitudinally striped colour pattern typical of chopardi (Fig. 40). The shorter fore wings (Figs<tei:lb/>27, 28, 83, 87) and prominent, narrow pronotal lateral carinae (Fig. 32) provide good<tei:lb/>morphological characters, and the distance from the stigma to the tip of the fore wing, taken as a<tei:lb/>ratio with the length of the hind femur, is usually much smaller than in chopardi (Figs 85, 88).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The best numerical method we have found for separating males of these two species is by<tei:lb/>combining the number of Stridulatory pegs, the distance from the stigma to the tip of the fore<tei:lb/>wing and the ratio of the length of the pronotum to the length of the head, and plotting the result<tei:lb/>on a triangular graph (Fig. 12; see p. 110 for a full explanation). A simpler but rather less<tei:lb/>effective separation can be obtained by plotting two of these characters, Stridulatory pegs and<tei:lb/>stigma distance, on a two-axis graph (Fig. 9); this gives a particularly good separation for French<tei:lb/>specimens. Both sexes can be separated quite well by plotting stigma distance against length of<tei:lb/>hind femur, as shown in Figs 10, 11; there is no overlap within our French and Iberian samples,<tei:lb/>but in the male there is a slight overlap between our samples of Iberian pulvinatus and French<tei:lb/>chopardi.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Because of the variable effect of shrinkage during drying, we have not found either the shape<tei:lb/>or the dimensions of the male subgenital plate to be particularly useful in distinguishing between<tei:lb/>dried specimens of pulvinatus and chopardi (see Fig. 85 for a comparison of the dimensions).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The male calling song of pulvinatus can usually be distinguished from that of chopardi by the<tei:lb/>faster echeme repetition rate, as shown in Figs 15, 16. Oscillographic analysis shows that the<tei:lb/>duration of the echemes, and especially of the syllables, is shorter than that of declivus and<tei:lb/>chopardi (Figs 18-20).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In France the range of pulvinatus extends much further north than that of chopardi and<tei:lb/>Descamps (1968) has suggested that the former is less xerophilous than the latter (while being<tei:lb/>more so than declivus). There is, however, some indication from the material we have examined<tei:lb/>that this may not be so in Spain. Nearly all the specimens we have seen from the extreme south of<tei:lb/>Spain have been pulvinatus and, although Pascual (1978) has shown that chopardi occurs in the<tei:lb/>Sierra Nevada, he found it only at altitudes of 1800-2000 m, -whereas pulvinatus occurred at the<tei:lb/>lower altitudes of 1250-1450 m.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION (see Fig. 81). In western Europe this species occurs in Jersey, France and the<tei:lb/>Iberian Peninsula. The eastern subspecies, p. pulvinatus, occurs as far west as Czechoslovakia<tei:lb/>(Cejchan, 1981; 1982), eastern Austria and the Balkan Peninsula, and extends eastwards<tei:lb/>through the Ukraine, southern Russia, Asia Minor, Kazakhstan and Central Asia to China. The<tei:lb/>range of this species thus appears to be divided into two by quite a large gap, approximately<tei:lb/>between longitudes 7E and 13E and including Switzerland, western Austria and the whole of<tei:lb/>Italy; there have been some references in the literature to the occurrence of pulvinatus in Italy</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE TAXONOMY OF THE WESTERN EUROPEAN EUCHORTHIPPUS</tei:p>

If this gap is indeed a real one, it would clearly<tei:lb/>account for the morphological divergence between/?, gallicus and the nominate subspecies (see<tei:lb/>also p. 140).</tei:p>

         <tei:p>THE TAXONOMY OF THE WESTERN EUROPEAN EUCHORTHIPPUS 131</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euchorthippus pulvinatus gallicus Mar an</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 27, 28, 32)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euchorthippus pulvinatus gallicus Mafan, 1957: 187. Holotype cf, FRANCE: Draguignan, 1898 (N. Kheil)<tei:lb/>(NM, Prague) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. cf $ . Length of head usually more than 2-4 mm in cf , more than 3-2 mm in $ . Length of fore<tei:lb/>wing usually more than 9-2 mm in cf , more than 11-3 mm in $ . Length of hind femur usually more than 8-4<tei:lb/>mm in cf , more than 11-8 mm in $. (See also bar-charts on pp. 144-150.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISCUSSION. For the best methods of distinguishing p. gallicus from the closely similar species<tei:lb/>chopardi, see the species 'Discussion' for pulvinatus (p. 128). The relationship between this<tei:lb/>subspecies and/?, elegantulus is discussed under that subspecies.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype (see above) and 573 other specimens from the following localities.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION (see Fig. 81). Central and southern France; Iberian Peninsula. The specimens on<tei:lb/>which Ebner (1931: 501) based his record of pulvinatus from Majorca have been lost and we<tei:lb/>consider the occurrence of this species in the Balearic Islands to be doubtful.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euchorthippus pulvinatus elegantulus Zeuner<tei:lb/>(Figs 35, 36)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euchorthippus elegantulus Zeuner, 1940: 107. Holotype cf , JERSEY: Ouaine Bay, 4.ix.l938 (F. E. Zeuner)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(BMNH, London) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euchorthippus declivus elegantulus Zeuner; Mafan, 1957: 189; Descamps, 1968: 5.<tei:lb/>[Euchorthippus declivus (Brisout); Harz, 1975: 924. Erroneous synonymy.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS, c?$. Length of head usually less than 2-4 mm in cf , less than 3-2 mm in $. Length of fore wing<tei:lb/>usually less than 9-2 mm in cf, less than 11 -3 mm in $. Length of hind femur usually less than 8 -4 mm in cf,<tei:lb/>less than 11-8 mm in $ . (See also bar-charts on pp. 144-150.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISCUSSION. This subspecies is essentially a small form of pulvinatus, the head showing the size<tei:lb/>difference most clearly (see Figs 82, 86).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>One of the more interesting conclusions to emerge from this study has been the fact that<tei:lb/>elegantulus, which has hitherto always been associated with declivus, is much closer to pulvinatus<tei:lb/>in both morphological characters and song. When Zeuner (1940) originally described elegantu-<tei:lb/>lus (as a full species) he stated that it was related to declivus and compared the two in several</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>132</tei:p>
         <tei:p>D. R. RAGGE &amp; W. J. REYNOLDS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>characters while making no mention of pulvinatus. Chopard (1952) suggested that it 'n'est sans<tei:lb/>doute qu'une sous-espece de dedivus' and, probably following this lead, Mafan (1957) and<tei:lb/>Descamps (1968) treated it formally as a subspecies of dedivus. Harz (1975) went even further,<tei:lb/>regarding it as no more than a synonym of dedivus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This association of elegantulus with dedivus probably stemmed from the fact that the<tei:lb/>subgenital plate of the Jersey males is usually more pointed than is typical oi pulvinatus and is<tei:lb/>sometimes nearer in shape to dedivus. However, in all other morphological characters<tei:lb/>elegantulus is closer \.o pulvinatus than to dedivus, and in some characters resembles pulvinatus<tei:lb/>very closely; this is well shown by the bar-charts of the projection of fore wing beyond hind wing<tei:lb/>(Figs 84, 88), by those of ratios (Figs 81 , 83-87), in which the effect of size is largely eliminated,<tei:lb/>and by all the scatter diagrams, including the triangular graph (Figs 8-13). Zeuner (1940) even<tei:lb/>included in his description of elegantulus the fact that the median and lateral carinae of the<tei:lb/>pronotum are 'very pronounced for the genus', another character shared with pulvinatus but not<tei:lb/>with dedivus. The close relationship with pulvinatus is confirmed by the song of elegantulus,<tei:lb/>which agrees closely with that of pulvinatus gallicus in all respects, while showing a marked<tei:lb/>contrast with dedivus in the number of gaps per echeme and the duration of both the echemes<tei:lb/>and the syllables (Figs 20-24, 65-70).</tei:p>
         <tei:p/>
         <tei:p>I</tei:p>
         <tei:p>65 dedivus</tei:p>
         <tei:p>66 pulvinatus gallicus</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Figs 65-70 Oscillograms of single echemes from the calling songs of four males of Euchorthippus<tei:lb/>pulvinatus elegantulus, with typical echemes from the male calling songs of E. dedivus and E. pulvinatus<tei:lb/>gallicus added for comparison. The small numbers refer to the recordings from which the oscillograms<tei:lb/>were made and can be used to obtain the full data from Table 2 (p. 108).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE TAXONOMY OF THE WESTERN EUROPEAN EUCHORTHIPPUS 133</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A further point of interest resulting from this study is that a form closely resembling the Jersey<tei:lb/>population of elegantulus occurs in the southern part of Brittany, in the region extending from<tei:lb/>Quiberon to Le Croisic. The Breton specimens are, on average, not quite as small as specimens<tei:lb/>from Jersey, and the male subgenital plate is usually blunter, more like typical pulvinatus.<tei:lb/>However, the bar-charts of absolute measurements (Figs 82-88) show that the Breton popula-<tei:lb/>tion is generally much closer to Jersey elegantulus than to French gallicus, and we think it<tei:lb/>reasonable, at least for the time being, to recognize these two populations as together<tei:lb/>constituting the subspecies elegantulus. When the distribution and ecology of these forms have<tei:lb/>been more thoroughly studied, it may prove to be more sensible to regard the Jersey and<tei:lb/>Brittany populations as representing no more than island and coastal forms of gallicus, living<tei:lb/>under rather unfavourable conditions at the northern limit of the climatic tolerance of this<tei:lb/>subspecies. A statistical comparison between our samples of gallicus and elegantulus gives t<tei:lb/>values of 9-5 for head length, 8-8 for fore wing length and 9-0 for hind femur length in the male,<tei:lb/>and corresponding values of 7-7, 7-3 and 6-7 in the female. The table given by Gery (1962) shows<tei:lb/>that all these values indicate a non-overlap between these samples of between 75 per cent and 90<tei:lb/>per cent, which does not lend very strong support to their recognition as separate subspecies.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype (see p. 131) and 39 other specimens from the following localities.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Jersey. Quennevais; Blanches Banques; St Ouen's Pond; Ouaine Bay; St Helier.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>France. Morbihan: Quiberon; Malanzac. Loire- Atlantique: 3 km SW. of Guerande; near Guerande, Le<tei:lb/>Croisic.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION (see Fig. 81). Known only from Jersey and the extreme south of Brittany. In<tei:lb/>addition to the four Breton localities listed above, the record of pulvinatus from 'landes de<tei:lb/>Plescop, environs de Vannes' given by Sellier (1947) almost certainly refers to this subspecies.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euchorthippus chopardi Descamps<tei:lb/>(Figs 29, 30, 33, 40)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euchorthippus chopardi Descamps, 1968: 8. Holotype cf , FRANCE: Vaucluse, Cavaillon, route forestiere<tei:lb/>du Luberon, 150 m (M. Descamps) (MNHN, Paris) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. O"$. Head and pronotum usually with conspicuous dark and light longitudinal stripes (Fig.<tei:lb/>40). Pronotal lateral carinae relatively low and broad, almost straight and parallel in metazona; length of<tei:lb/>pronotum usually 0-85-1-25 times length of head. Fore wings relatively long, usually reaching at least tips<tei:lb/>of hind femora in cf, bases of genicular lobes in $; distance from stigma to tip of fore wing usually<tei:lb/>0-33-0-46 times length of hind femur in cf , 0-40-0-54 in $. Length of hind wing usually 0-98-1-32 times<tei:lb/>length of hind femur in cf, 1-01-1 -29 in $. Male stridulatory file usually with 95-160 pegs. Male subgenital<tei:lb/>plate relatively short and blunt, as in Fig. 29. (Full data for measurements, ratios and number of<tei:lb/>stridulatory pegs are given in the bar-charts on pp. 144-150.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male calling song (see Figs 16, 19, 71-77). Echeme repetition rate usually 0-5-0-7/s. Other song<tei:lb/>characters as shown in bar-charts (p. 119).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISCUSSION. For the easy separation of this species from declivus see the 'Discussion' under that<tei:lb/>species. The much more difficult separation of chopardi from pulvinatus is discussed fully under<tei:lb/>the latter species. The usual longitudinally striped colour pattern of chopardi (Fig. 40) provides a<tei:lb/>strong indication of its identity, and this can be confirmed for males by plotting their relevant<tei:lb/>measurements and peg-counts on the triangular graph shown in Fig. 12, and for either of the<tei:lb/>sexes by plotting their measurements on the scatter diagrams shown in Figs 9-11. For the best<tei:lb/>means of distinguishing chopardi from albolineatus see the 'Discussion' under that species.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION (see Fig. 81). A species occurring widely in the Iberian Peninsula and extending its<tei:lb/>range north-eastwards into the French departments bordering the Mediterranean Sea, and<tei:lb/>Vaucluse. The only published record from the extreme south of Spain is from the Sierra Nevada<tei:lb/>at altitudes of 1800-2000 m (Pascual, 1978).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euchorthippus albolineatus (Lucas)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 34, 37)<tei:lb/>Oedipoda albo lineata Lucas, 1849: 38.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In view of the major differences between the Sicilian taxon siculus and the North African<tei:lb/>populations of albolineatus (see especially Figs 8-11), we have strong doubts about the current</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE TAXONOMY OF THE WESTERN EUROPEAN EUCHORTHIPPUS 135</tei:p>
         <tei:p>treatment of siculus as a subspecies of albolineatus (Descamps, 1968; Harz, 1975). We have<tei:lb/>therefore not attempted to give a diagnosis that includes both these taxa, but have given each of<tei:lb/>them diagnoses as if they were distinct species. However, as this study is not primarily concerned<tei:lb/>with either of these taxa, and we have no information on their songs, we prefer to retain the<tei:lb/>currently used nomenclature for them until their relationships can be more firmly established.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euchorthippus albolineatus albolineatus (Lucas)<tei:lb/>(Fig. 34)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Oedipoda albo lineata Lucas, 1849: 38. LECTOTYPE cf , ALGERIA: Cercle de Lacalle, Boghar (H. Lucas}</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(MNHN, Paris), here designated [examined].<tei:lb/>Euchorthippus albolineatus (Lucas) Uvarov, 1926: 341.<tei:lb/>Euchorthippus albolineatus albolineatus (Lucas); Descamps, 1968: 5.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS, cf $. Pronotal lateral carinae relatively high and narrow; length of pronotum usually 1-00-1-32<tei:lb/>times length of head. Fore wings relatively long, usually extending beyond tips of hind femora; distance<tei:lb/>from stigma to tip of fore wing usually 0-34-0-49 times length of hind femur in d" , 0-41-0-50 in 9 Length of<tei:lb/>hind wing usually 1 -10-1-32 times length of hind femur in cf , 1 -04-1 13 in $ . Male stridulatory file usually<tei:lb/>3-28-4-70 mm long, with 100-140 pegs. Male subgenital plate relatively short and blunt (similar to Fig. 29).<tei:lb/>(Full data for measurements, ratios and number of stridulatory pegs are given in the bar-charts on pp.<tei:lb/>144-150.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISCUSSION. E. albolineatus is at present the only species of the genus known from North Africa<tei:lb/>and so in practice identification presents no problems. We consider it doubtful that this species<tei:lb/>occurs in the Iberian Peninsula (see 'Distribution' below), but if it did it could be quite easily<tei:lb/>confused with pulvinatus and chopardi. As shown by the triangular graph (Fig. 13) and two-axis<tei:lb/>scatter diagrams (Figs 9-11), a. albolineatus and chopardi can be distinguished from pulvinatus<tei:lb/>by the same combination of characters, but in all these diagrams a. albolineatus and chopardi<tei:lb/>overlap broadly. The best numerical characters for separating the males are the length of the<tei:lb/>stridulatory file and the ratio of pronotum to head (see Figs 82, 81), but this ratio is less effective<tei:lb/>in separating the females. In qualitative characters both sexes of a. albolineatus usually lack the<tei:lb/>strongly striped colour pattern typical of chopardi and have more prominent and sharply defined<tei:lb/>lateral carinae on the pronotum (cf. Figs 33, 34).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>E. a. albolineatus is clearly a close relative of both chopardi and pulvinatus , and is particularly<tei:lb/>close to chopardi in almost all its characters. If it does not occur in the Iberian Peninsula the<tei:lb/>question arises as to whether it might be better regarded as only subspecifically distinct from<tei:lb/>chopardi. In the absence of any information on the song we can do no more than suggest this as a<tei:lb/>possibility to be borne in mind in future studies on the group.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>We have selected and labelled a male lectotype from the type-series of 10 males and 9 females<tei:lb/>of albolineatus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lectotype (see synonymy) and 124 other specimens from the following localities.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Morocco. Great Atlas Mts, Mouldirt, 1630 m; Oued Kroumane; Meknes district, Ifrane; 10 and 30 km S.<tei:lb/>of Fez; 12 km SE. of Azrou.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Algeria. Near Algiers, Kouba; near Blida, Chrea, 1300 m; S. of Constantine, El Gehra; Djuradjura Mts,<tei:lb/>Bouira; Boghar; Boghari; Hauls Plateaux, Trolarel-Taza, 1100 m; Djelfa; Mascara.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Libya. 30 km SW. of Tripoli, near Bianchi.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION (see Fig. 81). North Africa, from western Morocco to Tripolitania. In view of the<tei:lb/>ease with which this species can be confused with pulvinatus and chopardi, we consider that the<tei:lb/>records of albolineatus from Portugal (Descamps, 1968: 6), Spain (Presa, 1978: 121; Gonzalez,<tei:lb/>1981: 61; Presa et /., 1983) and Majorca (Kruseman, in Harz, 1975: 929) need confirmation.</tei:p>

      </tei:div>

         <tei:p>136 D. R. RAGGE &amp; W. J. REYNOLDS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euchorthippus albolineatus siculus Ramme<tei:lb/>(Fig. 37)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euchorthippus pulvinatus siculus Ramme, 1927: 161. LECTOTYPE cf, SICILY: Fontanamurata,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>17.vii.1924 (W. Ramme &amp; W. Richter) (MNHU, Berlin), here designated [examined].<tei:lb/>Euchorthippus albolineatus siculus Ramme; Descamps, 1968: 5.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. cf 9 . Pronotal lateral carinae relatively high and narrow; length of pronotum usually 1-03-1-16<tei:lb/>times length of head in cf , 1-16-1-24 in $. Fore wings usually reaching bases of genicular lobes of hind<tei:lb/>femora in cf , but usually failing to do so in $ ; distance from stigma to tip of fore wing usually 0-25-0-35<tei:lb/>times length of hind femur in cf , 0-28-0-34 in $ . Length of hind wing usually 0-97-1-09 times length of hind<tei:lb/>femur in cf , 0-90-0-94 in $ . Stridulatory file usually with 85-110 pegs in cf , 60-90 pegs or hairs in $ . Male<tei:lb/>subgenital plate of moderate length, sometimes tending to be slightly pointed (usually intermediate<tei:lb/>between the shapes shown in Figs 27 and 29). (Full data for measurements, ratios and number of<tei:lb/>Stridulatory pegs are given in the bar-charts on pp. 144-150.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISCUSSION. The status of siculus is discussed above under albolineatus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The only other species of Euchorthippus known to occur in Sicily (according to Galvagni,<tei:lb/>1956: 352 and other authors) is declivus, which can be easily distinguished from siculus by the<tei:lb/>characters discussed on p. 126. To judge from the three male specimens we have examined, this<tei:lb/>sex of siculus can be distinguished from most other species of the genus by plotting the number<tei:lb/>of Stridulatory pegs against the stigma distance, as shown in Fig. 9.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The three female specimens we have examined can be separated from chopardi and a.<tei:lb/>albolineatus by the distance from the stigma to the tip of the fore wing, especially when taken as a<tei:lb/>ratio to the length of the hind femur (Figs 1 1 , 88) . The only reliable character we have found for<tei:lb/>separating females of siculus from this sex of pulvinatus is the number of vestigial pegs or hairs in<tei:lb/>the Stridulatory file, as indicated in couplet 6 of the key (p. 124).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>We have selected and labelled a male lectotype from the type-series of siculus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED<tei:lb/>Lectotype (see synonymy) , 2 cf , 3 9 paralectotypes from Fontanamurata and S . Maria de Gesu in Sicily .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Known only from Sicily.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euchorthippus sardous Nadig<tei:lb/>(Fig. 38)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euchortippus [sic] sardous Nadig, in Nadig &amp; Nadig, 1934: 18; La Greca, 1955: 4 [description of $ and<tei:lb/>discussion of relationships]. Holotype cf , SARDINIA: Gennargentu, 1900 m, 17.vii.1930 (A. Nadig) (Coll.<tei:lb/>Nadig, Chur, Switzerland) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS. cf $. Pronotal lateral carinae relatively high and narrow, distinctly incurved in prozona (Fig.<tei:lb/>38); length of pronotum less than 2-1 mm in cf, less than 3-0 mm in $, usually 0-85-1-05 times length of<tei:lb/>head. Length of hind femur usually 6-1-7-1 mm in cf , 8-2-10-4 mm in $ . Fore wings usually reaching bases<tei:lb/>of genicular lobes of hind femora in cf , but just failing to do so in $ ; distance from stigma to tip of fore wing<tei:lb/>usually 0-27-0-33 times length of hind femur in cf , 0-33-0-42 in $ . Length of hind wing usually 0-90-1-15<tei:lb/>times length of hind femur. Male Stridulatory file usually with 85-1 10 pegs. Male subgenital plate relatively<tei:lb/>short and blunt (similar to Fig. 29). (Full data for measurements, ratios and number of Stridulatory pegs are<tei:lb/>given in the bar-charts on pp. 144-150.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISCUSSION. The small size of this endemic Sardinian species, and especially the short pronotum<tei:lb/>and hind femur (Figs 82, 86), enable both sexes to be easily distinguished from all other species<tei:lb/>of Euchorthippus. The only other species of the genus recorded from Sardinia is declivus, which<tei:lb/>is equally easy to recognize (see p. 126).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED<tei:lb/>Holotype (see above) and 30 other specimens from the type-locality.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Known only from the type-locality.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE TAXONOMY OF THE WESTERN EUROPEAN EUCHORTHIPPUS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>137</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euchorthippus angustulus Ramme<tei:lb/>(Fig. 39)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euchorthippus angustulus Ramme, 1931: 191. Holotype cf , BALEARIC ISLANDS: Formentera, Can Marti,<tei:lb/>24-27.vii.1928 (M. Eisentraut) (MNHU, Berlin) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIAGNOSIS, cf $ . Pronotal lateral carinae relatively high and narrow. Fore wings usually extending beyond<tei:lb/>tips of hind femora (usually 1 -25-1 -40 times length of hind femora) ; distance from stigma to tip of fore wing<tei:lb/>usually 0-43-0-56 times length of hind femur in cf , 0-50-0-61 in $ . Length of hind wing usually 1-22-1-37<tei:lb/>times length of hind femur in cf, 1-19-1-32 in $. Male stridulatory file usually with 103-133 pegs (mean of<tei:lb/>25 examined: 119-07-70). Male subgenital plate relatively short and blunt (similar to Fig. 29).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 79</tei:p>
         <tei:p>78</tei:p>
         <tei:p>79 420</tei:p>
         <tei:p>80 417</tei:p>
         <tei:p>20 Hz</tei:p>
         <tei:p>0-1 s</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Figs 78-80 Oscillograms of the calling songs of two males of Euchorthippus angustulus. Fig. 79 is a faster<tei:lb/>oscillogram of the echeme indicated in Fig. 78. Fig. 80 is taken from the song of another male. The small<tei:lb/>numbers refer to the recordings from which the oscillograms were made and can be used to obtain the full<tei:lb/>data from Table 2 (p. 108).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male calling song (Figs 78-80). An analysis of songs recorded from two males from Palma Nova,<tei:lb/>Majorca (not available at the time the bar-charts and scatter diagrams were prepared) gave the following<tei:lb/>mean values for each male. Echeme repetition rate: 0-84 and 0-85/s. Number of gaps per echeme: 5-6 and<tei:lb/>7-4. Duration of echeme: 161 and 164 ms. Duration of syllable: 31 and 32 ms. These figures are based on a<tei:lb/>total of 179 echemes for the repetition rate and 125 echemes for the other song characters. Comparison<tei:lb/>with the bar-charts (Fig. 20) shows that the number of gaps per echeme agrees well with chopardi, the<tei:lb/>duration of both the echemes and the syllables is closer to pulvinatus , and the echeme repetition rate is<tei:lb/>intermediate between the two. This confirms Eisentraut's observations, quoted by Ramme (1931: 192),<tei:lb/>that the song of angustulus showed a slower echeme repetition rate than that of pulvinatus .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MEASUREMENTS. The specimens of angustulus we have examined were not available at the time<tei:lb/>the bar-charts were prepared and so their measurements are given separately below (number</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>138</tei:p>
         <tei:p>D. R. RAGGE &amp; W. J. REYNOLDS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>measured in parentheses; mean followed by standard deviation; all measurements in milli-<tei:lb/>metres). Of the 43 specimens measured, only 5 males and 7 females were available at the time<tei:lb/>the morphological scatter diagrams were prepared. The measurements of four large females of<tei:lb/>doubtful identity from northern Majorca are excluded from this list; these specimens are<tei:lb/>discussed on p. 139.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>mean 0-5610-03</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISCUSSION. This species, originally described from Formentera and since found in Majorca and<tei:lb/>Ibiza, is endemic to the Balearic Islands. With the possible exception of four large females from<tei:lb/>northern Majorca (discussed below), all the specimens we have seen from these islands seem to<tei:lb/>belong to angustulus, although pulvinatus and even albolineatus have been recorded from<tei:lb/>Majorca (Ebner, 1931; Kruseman, in Harz, 1975: 929). Both sexes of angustulus can be<tei:lb/>distinguished from pulvinatus by the relatively long fore and hind wings, and by the large<tei:lb/>distance from the stigma to the tip of the fore wing, all these being taken as ratios to the length of<tei:lb/>the hind femur (Figs 10, 11); the small pronotum and hind femur enable both sexes to be<tei:lb/>distinguished from albolineatus. From chopardi, which could also conceivably occur in the<tei:lb/>Balearic Islands, it can be distinguished by the prominent and narrow pronotal lateral carinae.<tei:lb/>The fact that angustulus males are closely associated with chopardi and well-separated from<tei:lb/>pulvinatus on the triangular graph shown in Fig. 13 suggests the possibility that angustulus is an<tei:lb/>island derivative from Iberian stock of chopardi.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Not surprisingly, the Formenteran and Ibizan specimens we have examined differ slightly<tei:lb/>from the Majorcan ones. The Formenteran holotype and allotype show a tendency for the<tei:lb/>pronotal lateral carinae to be more incurved than is typical of Majorcan specimens, in which<tei:lb/>these carinae are usually straight in the prozona. The single Ibizan male we have examined (from<tei:lb/>Talamanca) is unusually small, giving smaller values than any other male for most of the</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE TAXONOMY OF THE WESTERN EUROPEAN EUCHORTHIPPUS 139</tei:p>
         <tei:p>measurements taken; the two Ibizan females examined (from Santa Eulalia del Rio) were of<tei:lb/>more typical size for angustulus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>We have examined four female specimens from northern Majorca (one from Puerto de<tei:lb/>Pollensa, on loan from the Instituut voor Taxonomische Zoologie, Amsterdam, and three from<tei:lb/>Alcudia, on loan from the MNHU, Berlin) that are considerably larger than any other Balearic<tei:lb/>specimens we have seen. The larger size is shown particularly by the following measurements<tei:lb/>taken from these specimens: length of pronotum 3-6-3-9 mm, length of hind femur 12-1-12-6<tei:lb/>mm, length of fore wing 15-5-16-8 mm, length of hind wing 14-3-16-2 mm, distance from stigma<tei:lb/>to tip of fore wing 0-60-0-71 mm. The hind femora of the largest of these females are as long as<tei:lb/>those of the smallest female we have examined of albolineatus , and there is a small overlap in the<tei:lb/>length of the pronotum; however, the ratios of both the fore and hind wings to the hind femur in<tei:lb/>all four specimens give values that are well outside the range of these ratios in our sample of<tei:lb/>albolineatus . It is impossible to form definite conclusions about these four specimens without<tei:lb/>further material, and in particular associated males, but they could be no more than a large local<tei:lb/>variant of angustulus. It may be significant that the Albufera marsh lies just south of Alcudia;<tei:lb/>this area of marshland, which is quite unique in the Balearic Islands, could conceivably have<tei:lb/>been the source of these specimens.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype (see p. 137) and 42 other specimens from the following localities.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Balearic Islands. Formentera: Can Marti. Ibiza: Talamanca; Santa Eulalia del Rio. Majorca: Palma;<tei:lb/>Palma Nova; Seller; Puerto de Seller; Puerto de Pollensa; Capdella.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DISTRIBUTION. Known only from the Balearic Islands.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>General discussion</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Groups of morphologically very similar species are quite common in the Gomphocerinae. When<tei:lb/>the members of such a group intermingle in the same habitat, there are usually obvious<tei:lb/>differences between the calling songs of the males. This is not surprising since it is now generally<tei:lb/>believed - and has been proved experimentally in some cases - that such song differences<tei:lb/>provide the main reproductive isolating mechanism. The three main western European species<tei:lb/>of Euchorthippus - dedivus, pulvinatus and chopardi - are sufficiently similar morphologically<tei:lb/>for misidentification to be frequent. In attempting to assign the 244 males we had at our disposal<tei:lb/>to one or other of these species on the basis of the shape and length of the subgenital plate (the<tei:lb/>character on which most emphasis has been placed in the past), we soon found that they showed<tei:lb/>a continuous gradation from the longest and most pointed dedivus to the shortest and bluntest<tei:lb/>chopardi, and a large number of males defied identification on this character alone. (In terms of<tei:lb/>length, the overlap in this character can be seen clearly in Fig. 85.) Since we knew it was not<tei:lb/>unusual for two of the species to be found together, and there was no obvious difference in the<tei:lb/>male calling songs, we began to wonder whether they were no more than forms of a single<tei:lb/>species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The clear morphological separation achieved by the combination of characters used in Fig. 12<tei:lb/>made us more confident that three species were involved, and we then turned to the song in the<tei:lb/>hope of finding some evidence of an ethological barrier. Careful analysis gradually revealed<tei:lb/>differences that, although subtle and mostly undetectable by the unaided human ear, seemed<tei:lb/>sufficiently clear to provide a basis for mate recognition. It is perhaps significant that the<tei:lb/>difference in the male calling song is smallest between dedivus and chopardi, which as far as we<tei:lb/>know have never been found together; pulvinatus, which quite often occurs with either dedivus<tei:lb/>or chopardi, has a noticeably higher echeme repetition rate than either of them in addition to the<tei:lb/>further differences revealed by oscillographic analysis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The close resemblance in both morphology and song shown by these three species suggests<tei:lb/>that they evolved from a common ancestor quite recently, probably during the Pleistocene<tei:lb/>Period. The Pleistocene glaciations, during which such an ancestor would no doubt have been<tei:lb/>pushed southwards into the Iberian, Italian and Balkan Peninsulas, seem likely to have</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>140</tei:p>
         <tei:p>D. R. RAGGE &amp; W. J. REYNOLDS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>provided the geographical separations that would have tended to lead to morphological and<tei:lb/>ethological divergence . As can be seen from Fig. 81 , there are some anomalies in the distribution<tei:lb/>of these species that we think can also be explained by the Pleistocene fluctuations in climate.<tei:lb/>These are the apparent absence of dedivus from most of the Iberian Peninsula, in spite of its<tei:lb/>being widespread in Italy and the Balkan Peninsula; the opposite situation in pulvinatus , which<tei:lb/>is common in the Iberian Peninsula but apparently absent from Italy and rare in the Balkans; and<tei:lb/>the large apparent gap between the western and eastern populations of pulvinatus , i.e. between<tei:lb/>p. gallicus and p. pulvinatus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>One possibility is that dedivus evolved from a population of ancestral stock isolated in the<tei:lb/>Italian Peninsula during a prolonged glacial period. In the course of subsequent warmer climatic<tei:lb/>phases such a population would have been able to spread northwards, eventually extending its<tei:lb/>range into much of western and eastern Europe, while leaving in the peninsula the existing<tei:lb/>Italian populations of dedivus (which would have had to become adapted to the ameliorating<tei:lb/>climate). The poor penetration of dedivus into the Iberian Peninsula could well be explained by<tei:lb/>the major barrier of the Pyrenees together with competition by other species of Euchorthippus<tei:lb/>already well adapted to the very hot, dry summers of the Spanish Meseta.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A population of Euchorthippus isolated in the Iberian Peninsula, perhaps during the same<tei:lb/>glacial period, could have given rise to pulvinatus gallicus as a result of a rather smaller<tei:lb/>divergence from the main body of the ancestral stock (now pulvinatus pulvinatus} occurring in<tei:lb/>the Balkan Peninsula and further east. Competition with dedivus, perhaps by then well</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 81 Map showing the distribution of the western European and North African species of Euchorthip-<tei:lb/>pus. We regard as doubtful the past records of E. dedivus from central and southern Spain (see p. 127),<tei:lb/>E. pulvinatus from Italy and Majorca (see pp. 128, 131) and E. albolineatus from Portugal, Spain and<tei:lb/>Majorca (see p. 135), and have therefore not taken them into account in preparing this map.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE TAXONOMY OF THE WESTERN EUROPEAN EUCHORTHIPPUS 141</tei:p>
         <tei:p>established in northern Italy and Yugoslavia, could have prevented the western and eastern<tei:lb/>populations of pulvinatus from coming together again.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The evolution of albolineatus has no doubt been the result of isolation in North Africa, and we<tei:lb/>suspect that chopardi is a comparatively recent northern derivative from albolineatus that has<tei:lb/>managed to cross the Strait of Gibraltar (perhaps at a time when it was narrower than at present)<tei:lb/>and thence spread through Spain and past the eastern end of the Pyrenees into southern France,<tei:lb/>at the same time diverging somewhat from the parental North African stock. Isolation in the<tei:lb/>Balearic Islands, Sardinia and Sicily, respectively, is sufficient to account for the evolution of<tei:lb/>angustulus, sardous and albolineatus siculus. Insular isolation would also account for the<tei:lb/>morphological divergence of the Jersey population of p. elegantulus, though the occurrence of a<tei:lb/>similar population in southern Brittany suggests that elegantulus may be no more than a small<tei:lb/>northern form of p. gallicus occurring in rather unfavourable conditions at the limit of its climatic<tei:lb/>tolerance.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Although we feel we have been able to throw some further useful light on the taxonomic<tei:lb/>problems presented by Euchorthippus , many questions still remain to be answered. We should<tei:lb/>welcome the opportunity to record and analyse the song of albolineatus, so that its relationship<tei:lb/>with the European species, particularly chopardi, could be better understood. An analysis of the<tei:lb/>song of the eastern subspecies p. pulvinatus would help to establish whether this form is truly<tei:lb/>conspecific with the western subspecies of pulvinatus whose songs are described and analysed in<tei:lb/>this paper. Information on the songs of sardous and siculus would also be useful in elucidating<tei:lb/>their affinities. An experimental test of the effectiveness as an isolating mechanism of the song<tei:lb/>differences we have detected would be most valuable, as would a further investigation into the<tei:lb/>related question of hybridization; such studies should take account of the possibility of<tei:lb/>pheromonal reinforcement of mate recognition, which could conceivably account for the<tei:lb/>unusually small interspecific song differences in this group. A comparative study of the<tei:lb/>chromosomes, and particularly the C-banding patterns, of all the western European species<tei:lb/>might well throw some further light on their inter-relationships. Finally, a comprehensive study<tei:lb/>of the eastern Palaearctic and Madeiran species of Euchorthippus, based on morphology,<tei:lb/>cytology and song, would lead nearer to a complete understanding of the taxonomy and<tei:lb/>evolution of this interesting genus.</tei:p>

      <tei:div>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>British Museum (Natural History)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Milkweed butterflies: their cladistics and biology</tei:p>
         <tei:p>P. R. Ackery &amp; R. I. Vane- Wright</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Danainae, a subfamily of the Nymphalidae, contains only some 150 species, yet aspects of<tei:lb/>their biology have stimulated far more attention than can be justified by species numbers<tei:lb/>alone. In recent years, an expansive literature has grown, considering aspects of their<tei:lb/>courtship and pre-courtship behaviour, migration, larval hostplant associations, mimicry and<tei:lb/>genetics. The popularity of danaines among biologists can certainly be attributed to this<tei:lb/>combination, within one small group, of so many of the factors that make butterflies such an<tei:lb/>interesting group to study. The obvious need to place this wealth of biological data within an<tei:lb/>acceptable systematic framework provided the impetus for this volume.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Started eight years ago within the conventions of evolution by natural selection and<tei:lb/>Hennig's phylogenetic systematics, the book is now largely about natural history (what the<tei:lb/>animals have and do, where they live and how they develop) and natural groups - as revealed<tei:lb/>by a form of analysis approaching that practised by the new school of 'transformed cladistics'.<tei:lb/>The authors have prepared a handbook that will appeal to a wide range of biologists, from<tei:lb/>museum taxonomists to field ecologists.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>424 pp (approx. ) , 12 pp colour, 73 b/w plates, line and graphic illustrations, maps, extensive bibliography.<tei:lb/>ISBN 565 00893 5. Publication September 1984. Price 50, prepublication price 45.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
