      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>Titles to be published in Volume 49</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Afrotropical jumping plant lice of the family Triozidae (Homoptera: Psylloidea).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>By David Hollis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The taxonomy of the western European grasshoppers of the genus Euchorthippus, with special<tei:lb/>reference to their songs (Orthoptera: Acrididae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>By D. R. Ragge &amp; W. J. Reynolds</tei:p>
         <tei:p>An historical review of the higher classification of the Noctuidae (Lepidoptera).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>By Ian J. Kitching</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Pimplinae, Xoridinae, Acaenitinae and Lycorininae (Hymenoptera: Ichneumonidae) of<tei:lb/>Australia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>By I. D. Gauld</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The western Palaearctic species of Ascogaster (Hymenoptera: Braconidae)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>By T. Huddleston</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Photoset by Rowland Phototypesetting Ltd, Bury St Edmunds, Suffolk<tei:lb/>Printed in Great Britain by Henry Ling Ltd, Dorchester</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>Bulletin of the</tei:p>
         <tei:p>British Museum (Natura</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BRITi :'.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>IN AU.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 1 ; . i</tei:p>
         <tei:p>^History)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>An historical review of the higher<tei:lb/>classification of the Noctuidae<tei:lb/>(Lepidoptera)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ian]. Kitching</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Entomology series</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Vol 49 No 3 30 August 1984</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>The Bulletin of the British Museum (Natural History), instituted in 1949, is issued in four<tei:lb/>scientific series, Botany, Entomology, Geology (incorporating Mineralogy) and Zoology,<tei:lb/>and an Historical series.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Papers in the Bulletin are primarily the results of research carried out on the unique and<tei:lb/>ever-growing collections of the Museum, both by the scientific staff of the Museum and by<tei:lb/>specialists from elsewhere who make use of the Museum's resources. Many of the papers are<tei:lb/>works of reference that will remain indispensable for years to come.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Parts are published at irregular intervals as they become ready, each is complete in itself,<tei:lb/>available separately, and individually priced. Volumes contain about 300 pages and several<tei:lb/>volumes may appear within a calendar year. Subscriptions may be placed for one or more of<tei:lb/>the series on either an Annual or Per Volume basis. Prices vary according to the contents of<tei:lb/>the individual parts. Orders and enquiries should be sent to:</tei:p>
         <tei:p/>
         <tei:p>30AUGI934</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Publications Sales,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>British Museum (Natural History),<tei:lb/>Cromwell Road,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>London SW75BD,<tei:lb/>England.</tei:p>
         <tei:p/>
         <tei:p>World List abbreviation: Bull. Br. Mus. nat. Hist. (Ent.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trustees of the British Museum (Natural History), 1984</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Entomology series is produced under the general editorship of the</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Keeper of Entomology: Laurence A. Mound</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Assistant Editor: W. Gerald Tremewan</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ISBN 565 06005 8<tei:lb/>ISSN 0524-6431</tei:p>
         <tei:p>British Museum (Natural History)<tei:lb/>Cromwell Road<tei:lb/>London SW7 5BD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Entomology series<tei:lb/>Vol 49 No 3 pp 153-234</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Issued 30 August 1984</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>An historical review of the higher classification of the</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Noctuidae (Lepidoptera)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>*</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ian J. Kitching</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Department of Entomology, British Museum (Natural History), Cromwell Road, London<tei:lb/>SW7 5BD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Contents</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Synopsis .................................................................................................... 153</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acknowledgements ..................................................................................... 153</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Introduction .............................................................................................. 153</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In the beginning .......................................................................................... 154</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The American alternative .............................................................................. 165</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Classifications in conflict ............................................................................... 168</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Development of the Hampsonian monolith ....................................................... 180</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The influence of immatures ............................................................................ 190</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The main assault ......................................................................................... 195</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The neglected arrangement ........................................................................... 210</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Quo vadis, Noctual ..................................................................................... 214</tei:p>
         <tei:p>References ................................................................................................ 227</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Index ........................................................................................................ 233</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Synopsis</tei:p>
         <tei:p>An historical review of the development of the higher classification of the Noctuidae is presented,<tei:lb/>emphasising the interrelationships between the various systems that have been put forward and the<tei:lb/>taxonomic impact of the character complexes that have been employed. A provisional cladistic analysis of<tei:lb/>the higher noctuid taxa is performed and a tentative cladogram proposed. Many of the currently accepted<tei:lb/>subfamilies are rejected as potentially paraphyletic or polyphyletic assemblages. New, cladistic, definitions<tei:lb/>of the families Arctiidae and Noctuidae are suggested, which would necessitate the establishment of the<tei:lb/>Aganaidae and Herminiidae as separate families.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acknowledgements</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This study was carried out during the tenure of a Junior Research Fellowship awarded by the Trustees of<tei:lb/>the British Museum (Natural History), which is gratefully acknowledged. I thank my colleagues at the<tei:lb/>British Museum (Natural History) for their support and comments.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Introduction</tei:p>
         <tei:p>It is exceptional to find any two authors who use the same combination of subfamily<tei:lb/>names within the Noctuidae (Nye, 1975: 10).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The classification of this family [Noctuidae] rests in a state of great confusion, and few<tei:lb/>authors appear to hold similar views regarding the suprageneric taxonomy. I have<tei:lb/>concluded after spending much time (perhaps I should say wasting time) on the problem,<tei:lb/>that it is impossible to present ... a correct suprageneric classification (Zimmerman,<tei:lb/>1958: 197-198).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The subfamily divisions . . . are on the whole natural, but their defining characters<tei:lb/>have far too many exceptions, and some genera may perhaps be completely misplaced<tei:lb/>(Forbes, 1954: 5).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Much of the present grouping of species and genera is still debatable, and reasons for<tei:lb/>groupings are often obscure (Birch, 1972a: 189).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>nj</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ov</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bull. Br. Mus. nat. Hist. (Ent.) 49 (3): 153-234 Issued 30 August 1984</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>154 IAN J. KITCHING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The moths of the family Noctuidae, sometimes known as 'owlets', constitute one of the three<tei:lb/>largest families of Lepidoptera . Estimates of the number of known species vary considerably but<tei:lb/>the most frequently quoted figure of 25,000 is still far in excess of such other groups as the<tei:lb/>butterflies (15,000-20,000) and the land-living vertebrates (about 18,000).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Not only are the noctuids a large family numerically, but they are also extremely important<tei:lb/>economically. The larvae of many genera (e.g. Spodoptera, Heliothis, Euxoa, Earias and<tei:lb/>Trichoplusia) are well known as army- worms, cutworms, bollworms and stem-borers and cause<tei:lb/>many millions of pounds' worth of crop loss each year. Their control, being at present primarily<tei:lb/>chemical, is also expensive. A predictive classification can thus be seen to be an essential<tei:lb/>prerequisite to the efficient use of the resources available to combat the pest species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>However, constructing such a classification is no easy task. The sheer size of the group has<tei:lb/>proved an effective deterrent (one in five lepidopteran genus-group names is noctuid; Nye,<tei:lb/>1975), and its worldwide although primarily tropical distribution has resulted in there being few<tei:lb/>institutions where the work can be pursued on the required scale. Nevertheless, over the years,<tei:lb/>the genera of noctuids have been classified into tribes and subfamilies. Many of these taxonomic<tei:lb/>groupings, particularly the earlier ones, were inadequately characterised and this, together with<tei:lb/>differences of opinion, extensive synonymies at all levels and a dependence upon superficial<tei:lb/>characters, has led to a far from satisfactory situation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This review is primarily historical and aims to trace and describe the development of the<tei:lb/>higher (i.e. suprageneric) classification of the noctuids from its earliest beginnings to the present<tei:lb/>day. The impact and use of the various authors' systems will be discussed, as will the characters<tei:lb/>upon which they were based (where these were reported). Finally, a provisional cladistic<tei:lb/>analysis is performed, using characters drawn from the literature. Each of the noctuid subfami-<tei:lb/>lies is considered in turn, and its relationships assessed and conclusions reached as to where<tei:lb/>future research might be best directed.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Several conventions will be used subsequently and these are listed below.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1. No authors' names are used (if required, these can be found in Nye, 1975, and Watson etal,<tei:lb/>1980).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2. The generic, tribal and subfamilial names used will be those employed in the works discussed<tei:lb/>at that point in the review. If subsequent changes have been made, the most recently<tei:lb/>accepted name will be given in square brackets, immediately following the original, e.g.<tei:lb/>Gonoptera [Scoliopteryx]. Objective synonymies follow Nye (1975). Subjective synonymies<tei:lb/>generally follow Franclemont &amp; Todd (1983) for North American taxa, Kloet &amp; Hincks<tei:lb/>(1972) for British taxa and the BMNH card index for all other groups. Some subjective<tei:lb/>synonymies (e.g. Heliothis/ Helicoverpa) may therefore not agree with the reader's opinions.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3. Where transfer of genera between subfamilies by other authors has been carried out, the<tei:lb/>name given in square brackets is the subfamily to which the genus was assigned by Nye<tei:lb/>(1975). Exceptions to this are: () the Agaristinae and Nolinae are treated here as subfamilies<tei:lb/>of the Noctuidae; and (b) the Acronictinae (s.str.) is separated from the Amphipyrinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In addition, the names Herminiinae, Hypenodinae and Rivulinae are not employed and it<tei:lb/>must therefore be realised that many genera that correctly belong in such subfamilies are treated<tei:lb/>as belonging to others (e.g. the Hypeninae s.l.).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In the beginning<tei:lb/>Early days</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Linnaeus (1758) divided the moths into two large genera, Sphinx and Phalaena. The latter was<tei:lb/>further divided into seven 'subgenera': Bombyx, Noctua, Geometra, Tortrix, Pyralis, Tinea and<tei:lb/>Alucita. Forty species of true noctuids were contained in the section of Noctua described as<tei:lb/>'spirilingues, dorso cristate', together with the thyatirid, Phalaena Noctua [Achylia]flavicornis.<tei:lb/>However, due to Linnaeus' reliance upon superficial characters (e.g. degree of development of</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>REVIEW OF THE HIGHER CLASSIFICATION OF THE NOCTUIDAE 155</tei:p>
         <tei:p>the proboscis and the body vestiture), several noctuid species were placed in Bombyx (e.g. B.<tei:lb/>[Scoliopteryx] libatrix, B. [Colocasia] coryli and B. [Dicycla] oo).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The family Noctuidae was probably first recognised as a distinct unit by Denis &amp; Schiffermul-<tei:lb/>ler (1775). Their division 'Noctuae' was divided into 21 groups, based on characters drawn from<tei:lb/>all developmental stages, including larval foodplants and habits. Each group was assigned a<tei:lb/>letter of the alphabet and accompanied by short diagnoses of the larvae and adults.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Many of the groups were very heterogeneous and some contained species no longer<tei:lb/>considered to be Noctuidae. Most of the remainder combined representatives from several<tei:lb/>current subfamilies. The hypenines were included in the Pyralides as group A, 'Phalaenae<tei:lb/>Pyralides Longipalpes'.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Up to the nineteenth century, classifications were still largely based upon local faunas.<tei:lb/>However, Borkhausen (1792) considered all the European noctuid species and divided them<tei:lb/>into two large groups, the Noctuae fasciatae and the Noctuae non fasciatae . These contained six<tei:lb/>and 20 families respectively. Although characters were drawn from the morphology and habits<tei:lb/>of several life-history stages, Borkhausen utilised only the wing patterns and resting positions of<tei:lb/>the adults and ignored all other structures. As a result, the classification was not particularly<tei:lb/>natural. For example, one group consisted of those species with yellow hindwings, from such<tei:lb/>genera as Noctua, Anarta, Polyphaenis, Panemeria, Thalpophila and various quadrifines.<tei:lb/>Nevertheless, this arrangement, albeit imperfect, was an improvement.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hiibner (1805) divided the noctuids into three sections (the Bombycoides, Genuinae and<tei:lb/>Semigeometrae), while Haworth (1803-28) regarded the family as consisting of only three<tei:lb/>genera: Noctua, Phytometra and Hemigeometra, subdivided into 22, three and two sections<tei:lb/>respectively.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This brief survey of the very early history of noctuid classification is by no means comprehen-<tei:lb/>sive. A more detailed review of this period (1720-1835) can be found in Guenee (1852-4:<tei:lb/>xlix-xc).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Guenee's first classification</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In a paper of six parts, published between 1837 and 1841, Guenee presented the first detailed<tei:lb/>classification of the noctuids, which were variously referred to as the family Nocturni, the<tei:lb/>division Noctuae, or, most frequently, the Noctuelides. As such, this arrangement will be<tei:lb/>considered in more detail than its predecessors. Unfortunately, the system 'evolved' during the<tei:lb/>publication period, for reasons that were never stated, and this makes its description more<tei:lb/>difficult. Initially, Guenee listed 18 tribes. In addition, he also recognised the Noctuo-<tei:lb/>Bombycidae (Table 1). This last tribe mainly contained species of the family Thyatiridae, but<tei:lb/>also included three species of Cosmia [Amphipyrinae]. A fourth Cosmia species, C. trapezina,<tei:lb/>was excluded.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Of the remaining 18 tribes, only the first six were dealt with in the first part of the paper<tei:lb/>(Guenee, 1837) and so these are the only tribes for which his original concepts are known.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Although included in the 1837 list, Guenee discussed neither the Bombycoidi nor the<tei:lb/>Pseudo-Bombycidi, but begin with the third tribe, the monobasic Bryophyagidi. This contained<tei:lb/>only Bryophila [Cryphia], a genus that Guenee found difficult to place within the Noctuelides.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Nonagridi consisted of two genera, Nonagria and Gortyna, the larvae of which are<tei:lb/>root- and stem-borers and, as such, show similar adaptations (smooth, supple integument;<tei:lb/>well-developed prothoracic and anal shields) which Guenee accepted as evidence of close<tei:lb/>relationship.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Leucanidi comprised six genera, representing a mixture of noctuines, hadenines,<tei:lb/>acronictines and amphipyrines. They differed from the Nonagridi chiefly in that the larvae are<tei:lb/>leaf-feeders.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The last tribe dealt with by Guenee in 1837 was the Noctuelidi, consisting of seven genera,<tei:lb/>which are mostly Noctuinae but also including a few hadenines.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Guenee (1838a) continued his classification with the tribes Amphipyridi (four genera) and the<tei:lb/>Miselidi (three genera). The next tribe to be considered (Guenee, 18386) was the Hadenidi. Ten</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>156</tei:p>
         <tei:p>IAN J. KITCHING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Table 1 A comparison of the tribes employed by Guenee in his 'Essai' . The Roman numerals given in<tei:lb/>the second column refer to the order in which the tribes were presented at the beginning of the work<tei:lb/>(Guenee, 1837), while the Arabic numbers given in the third column are those assigned to the tribes<tei:lb/>at the conclusion of the work (Guenee, 18416).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TRIBE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1837 number</tei:p>
         <tei:p>18416 number</tei:p>
         <tei:p>very diverse genera were included, from the Hadeninae, Cuculliinae, Amphipyrinae, Eute-<tei:lb/>liinae, Ophiderinae and Thyatiridae. Guenee recognised the heterogeneous nature of both this<tei:lb/>and the next tribe (Orthosidi), accepting that they were almost completely artificial. Indeed, he<tei:lb/>found difficulty in devising good characters to separate them and even went so far as to label<tei:lb/>them both Tribu IX'. The Orthosidi itself was described in 1839 and contained elements of all<tei:lb/>four major trifine subfamilies.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The second tribe to be considered in 1839, the Xylinidi, was composed primarily of cuculliines<tei:lb/>but also included several hadenines and a single heliothine (Chariclea [Periphanes] delphinii).<tei:lb/>This last species was regarded as a link between the Xylinidi and Orthosidi, and the Heliothidi,<tei:lb/>the tribe that contained the remaining heliothines, together with the hadenine genus, Anarta.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The next tribe in Guenee's 1837 list was the Ctenoceridi. However, he must have reconsidered<tei:lb/>its validity, for its fails to appear in sequence (Guenee, 18410). Instead, the Heliothidi were<tei:lb/>followed by the Plusidi, a tribe corresponding to the current Plusiinae. In contrast, the Calpidi,<tei:lb/>absent from the 1837 list, was included and contained only a single species, Calpe [Calyptra]<tei:lb/>thalictri. This tribe was followed by the Ophiusidi, a mixture of catocalines and ophiderines (e.g.<tei:lb/>Lygephila and Minucia), and the Catocalidi, which consisted only of Catocala and the<tei:lb/>ophiderine Catephia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The final part of the Essai (Guenee, 1841b) considered three tribes. For the first, Guenee used<tei:lb/>the name 'Phalaenoidi' rather than Noctuioidi (as used in Guenee, 1837). This was because he<tei:lb/>thought the sole included genus, Brephos [Archiearis] had much in common with the Pha-<tei:lb/>laenides [Geometridae] and formed a link between the two families. Guenee placed the genus<tei:lb/>within the Noctuelides because it was more similar to this family in all its life-history stages than<tei:lb/>to either the Geometridae or the Pyralidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Acontidi and the Noctuo-Phalaenidi were similar in such characters as the form of the<tei:lb/>larvae, antennae and the relative width of the wings. The latter tribe was seen as the natural link<tei:lb/>between the Noctuelides and the Pyrales.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>REVIEW OF THE HIGHER CLASSIFICATION OF THE NOCTUIDAE 157</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The final classification of the noctuids proposed by Guenee (1841ft) (Table 1) contained a<tei:lb/>number of changes in both the names and contents of the tribes compared to those employed in<tei:lb/>previous parts of the paper. This was true even for that part with which the list appeared. The<tei:lb/>composition of the Bombycoidi was now stated as Colocasia [Pantheinae], Acronicta and Moma<tei:lb/>[Acronictinae], while the Pseudo-Bombycidi had either been omitted or merged with another<tei:lb/>tribe.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The next few tribes had undergone extensive modification and rearrangement. The two<tei:lb/>genera that formed the Nonagridi were separated, with Nonagria placed in the Leucanidi and<tei:lb/>Gortyna included in a new tribe, the Apamidi. Other apamid genera included Glottula [Brithys],<tei:lb/>Xylophasia, Apamea (removed from the Leucanidi) and Mithymna [sic] [now containing only<tei:lb/>[Eriopygodes] imbecilla, not originally included in the genus]. .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Noctuelidi remained more or less intact, although it had gained Rusina from the<tei:lb/>Leucanidi. The Orthosidi gained Scoliopteryx from the Hadenidi, and Tethea [Zenobia] and<tei:lb/>Cosmia from the Noctuo-Bombycidi, together with several other changes, while the Miselidi<tei:lb/>were included within the Hadenidi. Otherwise this last tribe remained virtually unaltered, like<tei:lb/>most of the others. The only significant alteration to the Ophiusidi and the Catocalidi was the<tei:lb/>transfer of Catephia to the former tribe.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Alternatives to Guenee</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Shortly afterwards, Duponchel (1844-6) constructed a classification of the Lepidoptera of<tei:lb/>Europe. He recognised only three families: the Diurnes (butterflies), Crepusculares (mainly<tei:lb/>sphingids) and Nocturnes. The noctuids comprised 24 tribes within the last of these (Table 2),<tei:lb/>corresponding largely to those of Guenee (18416). There were, however, some notable<tei:lb/>differences.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Firstly, Bryophila [Cryphia] was included within the Bombycoides. With regard to the<tei:lb/>Nonagridi, Duponchel placed the genera Gortyna and Hydroeda [Hydraecia] in a separate</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Table 2 The tribes employed by Duponchel (1844-6) for the noctuid moths, within his lepidopteran<tei:lb/>division, Nocturnes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Number Tribe</tei:p>
         <tei:p>XVI Bombycoides</tei:p>
         <tei:p>XVII Noctuo-Bombycides</tei:p>
         <tei:p>XVIII Orthosides</tei:p>
         <tei:p>XIX Gortynides</tei:p>
         <tei:p>XX Nonagrides</tei:p>
         <tei:p>XXI Leucanides</tei:p>
         <tei:p>XXII Caradrinides</tei:p>
         <tei:p>XXIII Apamides</tei:p>
         <tei:p>XXIV Hadenides</tei:p>
         <tei:p>XXV Noctuelides</tei:p>
         <tei:p>XXVI Amphipyrides</tei:p>
         <tei:p>XXVII Xylinides</tei:p>
         <tei:p>XXVIII Heliothides</tei:p>
         <tei:p>XXIX Calpides</tei:p>
         <tei:p>XXX Plusides</tei:p>
         <tei:p>XXXI Catocalides</tei:p>
         <tei:p>XXXII Ophiusides</tei:p>
         <tei:p>XXXIII Anthophilides</tei:p>
         <tei:p>XXXIV Agrophilides</tei:p>
         <tei:p>XXXV Anomalides</tei:p>
         <tei:p>XXXVI Phalenoides</tei:p>
         <tei:p>XXXVII Goniatides</tei:p>
         <tei:p>XXXVIII Acontides</tei:p>
         <tei:p>XXXIX Noctuo-Phalenides</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>158</tei:p>
         <tei:p>IAN J. KITCHING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>tribe, the Gortynides, and Nonagria as the sole genus of the Nonagridi. The Apamides were thus<tei:lb/>equivalent to Guenee's 1841 Apamidi less Gortyna and Hydraecia, while the remaining genera<tei:lb/>of his 1841 Leucanidi were distributed between two tribes, the Leucanides and the Caradrinides.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Duponchel's second innovation was the division of the Noctuo-Phalaenidi into five tribes. The<tei:lb/>first, the Anthophilides, contained four acontiine genera while the Agrophilides included two.<tei:lb/>The latter tribe also included the amphipyrine Metaponia. A second amphipyrine genus<tei:lb/>(Metoptria [Synthymia]) was placed in the Goniatides, together with Euclidia, while two more<tei:lb/>amphipyrines (Haemerosia and Erastria [Hapalotis]) , along with the acontiine Oratoscelis<tei:lb/>[Calymma] and the ophiderine Phytometra, constituted the Noctuo-Phalenides proper. The<tei:lb/>final tribe, the Anomalides, included a single species, Timia [Axia] margarita, which is currently<tei:lb/>placed in the Axiidae (Geometroidea). Thus, some of the heterogeneity of Guenee's Noctuo-<tei:lb/>Phalaenidi was removed by Duponchel, but not all.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In the following year, Herrich-Schaffer (1845) proposed a series of groupings of the moths he<tei:lb/>called the Noctuidae. He excluded the species hitherto placed in the Noctuo-Bombycidi,<tei:lb/>including them in a separate family, the Cymatophoridae [Thyatiridae] . Nevertheless, their<tei:lb/>position at the head of the Noctuidae suggests that Herrich-Schaffer still considered them to be<tei:lb/>intermediate between this family and the preceding Bombyces.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Two other families were associated with the Noctuidae. The first, the Nycteolidae, included<tei:lb/>genera presently placed in the Chloephorinae (Chloephora, Earias), Sarrothripinae (Nycteola),<tei:lb/>Ophiderinae (Rivuld) and Hypeninae (Schrankia [Hypenodes]) . The second family, the Brephi-<tei:lb/>dae, was equivalent to the Phalaenoidi.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Noctuidae were divided into 24 subfamilies (Table 3). Herrich-Schaffer followed<tei:lb/>Duponchel in placing Bryophila [Cryphia] in the Bombycoidae [mainly Acronictinae]. He also<tei:lb/>included Demas [Colocasia] coryli, which Duponchel put in the Liparides [Lymantriidae]<tei:lb/>(although Guenee (18416) placed it in the Bombycoidi), and Diloba caeruleocephala, previously</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Table 3 Herrich-Schaffer's (1845) classification of the noctuid moths.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tribe 1: Cymatophoridae<tei:lb/>Tribe 2: Noctuidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Subtribe 1: Bombycoidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2: Orthosidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3: Hadenidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4: Xylinidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5: Cucullidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>6: Gonopteridae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>7: Cerastides</tei:p>
         <tei:p>8: Amphipyridae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>9: Noctuidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>10: Heliothidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>11: Maniidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>12: Eriopidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>13: Eurhipidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>14: Calpidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>15: Herminidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>16: Metoponidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>17: Plusidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>18: Erastridae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>19: Ophiusidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>20: Acontidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>21: Goniatidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>22: Hypenidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>23: Leptosidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>24: Aglenidae<tei:lb/>Tribe 3: Nycteolidae<tei:lb/>Tribe 4: Brephidae</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>REVIEW OF THE HIGHER CLASSIFICATION OF THE NOCTUIDAE 159</tei:p>
         <tei:p>included in the Notodontides since Linnaeus (1758). Finally, Symira [Simyra] was removed from<tei:lb/>its long-held relationship with the wainscots (Leucanid) (some of which Simyra superficially<tei:lb/>resembles) and placed nearAcronicta, its present position.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The next two subfamilies of Herrich-Schaffer, the Orthosidi and the Hadenidi, contained<tei:lb/>most of the remaining trifine noctuids less those placed in the Noctuidae, Xylinidae and<tei:lb/>Cuculliidae. Mania [Mormo] maura was removed from the Amphipyridi and included with<tei:lb/>Placodes [Eucarta] amethystina (from the Hadenidi) in the Maniidae. Mania [Naenia] typica was<tei:lb/>placed in the genus Neuria in the Hadenidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Noctuidae, Heliothidae, Acontidae, Amphipyridae (less Mania), Plusidae and Calpidae<tei:lb/>were largely unchanged. Very small subfamilies were erected to accommodate Hoporina [Jodia]<tei:lb/>and Cerastis (Cerastides), Eriopus (Eriopides), Eurhipia [Eutelia] (Eurhipidae) and Gonoptera<tei:lb/>[Scoliopteryx] (Gonopteridae). New subfamilies of somewhat larger size were the Metoponi-<tei:lb/>dae, the Leptosidae and the Aglenidae. Erastria [Hapalotis] was removed from the Noctuo-<tei:lb/>Phalaenides of Duponchel and placed in a separate subfamily, the Erastridae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Ophiusidae comprised Catephia and Ophiusa, but because this last genus also included<tei:lb/>species currently assigned to such genera as Lygephila, the Ophiusidae was roughly equivalent<tei:lb/>to Guenee's (18416) Catocalidi and Ophiusidi combined.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The most revolutionary aspect of Herrich-Schaffer's classification was his treatment of the<tei:lb/>deltoids. These were split into two subfamilies, the Herminidae and the Hypenidae (this also<tei:lb/>including several acontiines). The decision to include the deltoid genera within the Noctuidae<tei:lb/>was well ahead of its time and was only slowly to gain acceptance.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Guenee's second classification</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The next major classification of the noctuids was that of Guenee (1852-4). The influence of<tei:lb/>Duponchel and Herrich-Schaffer was evident, for the arrangement proposed (Table 4) incor-<tei:lb/>porated many of their groupings. This classification was to exert a significant influence on the<tei:lb/>ideas of future workers and thus is discussed in detail.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Two major divisions of noctuids were recognised, the Noctuelites and the Deltoides. Guenee<tei:lb/>removed this latter group from the Pyrales because he considered them to have more in common<tei:lb/>with the Noctuelites. However, despite the recognition that the two groups graded almost</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Table 4 Guenee's second classification (1852-4) of the Noctuidae. Two 'divisions' were recognised,<tei:lb/>of which the former was split into two 'phalanges'. Each phalange was further divided into sections<tei:lb/>termed 'tribus', which are not equivalent concepts to the present category of tribe.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DIVISION: NOCTUELITES</tei:p>
         <tei:p>PHALANGE: TRIFIDAE<tei:lb/>TRIBU: 1 Bombyciformes</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Family: 1 Noctuo-Bombycidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 Bryophilidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 Bombycoidae<tei:lb/>TRIBU: 2 Genuinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Family: 1 Leucanidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 Glottulidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 Apamidae<tei:lb/>Subfamily: 1 Gortynides</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 Xylophasides</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 Episemides</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4 Apamides propres</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4 Caradrinidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5 Noctuidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>6 Orthosidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>7 Cosmidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>8 Hadenidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>9 Xylinidae<tei:lb/>10 Heliothidae</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>160 IAN J. KITCHING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Table 4 - cont.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TRIBU: 3 Minores</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Family: 1 Haemerosidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 Acontidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 Erastridae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4 Anthophilidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5 Phalaenoidae<tei:lb/>PHALANGE: QUADRIFIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TRIBU: 1 Sericiae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Family: 1 Palindidae<tei:lb/>2 Dyopsidae<tei:lb/>TRIBU: 2 Variegatae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Family: 1 Eriopidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 Eurhipidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 Placodidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4 Plusidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5 Calpidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>6 Hemiceridae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>7 Hyblaeidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>8 Gonopteridae<tei:lb/>TRIBU: 3 Intrusae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Family: 1 Amphipyridae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 Toxocampidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 Stilbidae<tei:lb/>TRIBU:4Extensae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Family: 1 Polydesmidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 Homopteridae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 Hypogrammidae<tei:lb/>Subfamily: 1 Yridae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 Hypogrammidae propre<tei:lb/>TRIBU: 5 Limbatae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Family: 1 Catephidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 Bolinidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 Hypocalidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4 Catocalidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5 Ophideridae<tei:lb/>Subfamily: 1 Ophideridae propre</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 Phyllodidae<tei:lb/>TRIBU: 6 Patulae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Family: 1 Erebidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 Ommatophoridae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 Hypopyridae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4 Bendidae<tei:lb/>Subfamily: 1 Hulodides</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 Bendides propres<tei:lb/>TRIBU: 7 Serpentiae<tei:lb/>Family: 1 Ophiusidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 Euclididae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 Poaphilidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4 Remigidae<tei:lb/>TRIBU: 8 Pseudo-Deltoidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Family: 1 Focillidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 Amphigonidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 Thermesidae<tei:lb/>DIVISION: DELTOIDES</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Family: 1 Platydidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 Hypenidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 Herminidae</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>REVIEW OF THE HIGHER CLASSIFICATION OF THE NOCTUIDAE 161</tei:p>
         <tei:p>imperceptibly into one another, Guenee did not regard this to be sufficient grounds for uniting<tei:lb/>them into a single division. Thus a graded sequence was identified, passing from the Bombyci-<tei:lb/>formes (through which the Noctuelites were connected to the Bombyces) through to the<tei:lb/>Pseudo-Delto'idae (by which the Noctuelites passed into the Deltoides and thence into the<tei:lb/>pyralids and geometrids).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Noctuelites. Within this division, Guenee recognised two large groups, which he termed<tei:lb/>'phalanges', the Trifidae and the Quadrifidae. These were primarily separated on the now-<tei:lb/>infamous character of the degree of development and position of vein M 2 of the hindwing. In the<tei:lb/>Trifidae, this vein is generally much weaker than those following it, and originates at such a<tei:lb/>position that crossveins mi~m 2 and m 2 -m 3 are approximately equal in length. This gives the<tei:lb/>veins forming the posterior part of the discal cell a trifid appearance. In the Quadrifidae, M 2 is a<tei:lb/>strong vein originating near the posterior angle of the cell, resulting in the quadrifid configura-<tei:lb/>tion.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trifidae. The Trifidae were divided into three tribes: the Bombyciformes, the Genuinae and<tei:lb/>the Minores. Distinctions were based largely upon the superficial appearance of the adults and<tei:lb/>the number of prolegs and hairiness of the larvae. It should be noted that Guenee's concept of a<tei:lb/>'tribe' (or tribu), to which the family was subordinate, is not equivalent to current usage, in<tei:lb/>which the tribe is subordinate to the family.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bombyciformes. The first tribe was split into three families. The Noctuo-Bombycidae<tei:lb/>[Thyatiridae] were envisaged as being intermediate between the Noctuelites and the bombycid<tei:lb/>family, Notodontides, while the Bombycoidae [Acronictinae, part] formed a link with the<tei:lb/>Liparidae [Lymantriidae]. Guenee considered substituting the name Acronyctidae for Bomby-<tei:lb/>coidae but felt that to do so would obscure their relationship with the Bombyces, even though<tei:lb/>the term Acronyctidae would result in a more uniform nomenclature. The third family, the<tei:lb/>Bryophilidae (the Bryophagidae of Guenee, 1837), did, however, have its name changed for<tei:lb/>exactly this reason.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>An advance upon the 1841 list, with regard to the Bombyciformes, was the unification of the<tei:lb/>previously widely scattered elements of the Thyatiridae (= Noctuo-Bombycidae): Thyatira,<tei:lb/>Leptina and Cymatophora [Achlya]. Guenee also followed Herrich-Schaffer (1845) by including<tei:lb/>Simyra in the Bombycoidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Genuinae. The Leucanidae, the first 'genuine' family, comprised those species collectively<tei:lb/>known as 'wainscots'. The adults are pale-coloured, with a simple striate pattern, and the larvae<tei:lb/>are either endophagous, boring in the stems and roots of grasses, sedges and other monocotyle-<tei:lb/>donous plants, or living concealed by day and feeding by night on Poaceae. The larval habits<tei:lb/>formed the basis of two subdivisions. At present, the borers (Nonagrides) are placed in the<tei:lb/>Amphipyrinae, while the rest (Leucanides) are put in the Hadeninae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The larvae of the Glottulidae also feed internally, but in bulbous plants. The family contained<tei:lb/>only four genera (e.g. Glottula [Brithys]} representing a heterogeneous assemblage of hade-<tei:lb/>nines, amphipyrines and ophiderines.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The larvae of the next three families generally conceal themselves by day, emerging only after<tei:lb/>dark to feed, although a few (Gortyna spp.) are root-borers. The first, the Apamidae, shared<tei:lb/>characters of both the Noctuidae and the Hadenidae. Guenee recognised that the Apamidae<tei:lb/>were heterogeneous and possibly subject to future modification and division. In order to<tei:lb/>indicate this, he separated the species into four subfamilies: the Gortynides, the Xylinides, the<tei:lb/>Episemides and the 'Apamides propres'.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In his 1841 classification, Guenee united the next family, the Caradrinidae, with the<tei:lb/>Leucanidae because the latter included the genus Simyra, which he considered to be intermedi-<tei:lb/>ate. However, in the present work, Guenee (1852-4) had removed Simyra to the Bombycoidae<tei:lb/>and this allowed him to reinstate the Caradrinidae as a separate family.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The fifth family, the Noctuidae, generally conformed to the current concept of the Noctuinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>162 IAN J. KITCHING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>It consisted chiefly of three large genera: Agrotis (in the broadest sense), Triphaena [Noctua]<tei:lb/>and Noctua [Amathes, Graphiphora, Diarsia] . Members of the Noctuidae were characterised by<tei:lb/>holding their wings flat over the back at rest, one wing slightly overlapping the other, which<tei:lb/>distinguished them from the Leucanidae and Caradrinidae, in which the wings are held<tei:lb/>roof- wise.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Guenee found the Orthosidae very difficult to differentiate from both the Noctuidae and the<tei:lb/>Hadenidae. Biologically, many of the Orthosidae share the feature of autumn or early spring<tei:lb/>appearance as adults. The family consisted of a mixture of hadenines and cuculliines.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Cosmidae was erected to accommodate a group of genera (e.g. Dicycla, Cosmia) that, in<tei:lb/>his Essai, Guenee had included in the Orthosidi and the Noctuo-Bombycidi, but that were now<tei:lb/>considered to be distantly related.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Like the Orthosidae, the Hadenidae proved very difficult to characterise. In larval features,<tei:lb/>the family approached the Apamidae and Xylinidae, whereas the adults resembled the<tei:lb/>Orthosidae. All the included genera are currently placed in either the Hadeninae or Cuculliinae,<tei:lb/>except for Phlogophora, which is an amphipyrine.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In contrast to the preceding families of the Genuinae, the larvae of the remaining two feed<tei:lb/>exposed on plants (with rare exceptions). The Xylinidae contained Cucullia, Calocampa<tei:lb/>[Xylena], Xylina [Lithophane] and their relatives, with several smaller amphipyrine genera and<tei:lb/>one, Ny stalea, now placed in the Notodontidae. The Heliothidae was characterised additionally<tei:lb/>by diurnally-active adults. The only alteration from the Heliothidi of the Essai (Guenee, 1839)<tei:lb/>was the inclusion of Chariclea [Periphanes], a genus previously placed in the Xylinidi.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Minores. The last of the trifid tribes, the Minores, was divided into five families. All were<tei:lb/>characterised by the small size of the adult insects, which often resembled geometrids, pyralids<tei:lb/>or tortricids, similarities that were not contradicted, in Guenee's opinion, by the early stages.<tei:lb/>The Minores comprised a very mixed group of families, subdivided primarily on the basis of<tei:lb/>whether the adult abdomen was slender or stout.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Of the latter type, the Haemerosidae consisted of only two genera, Haemerosia (now placed<tei:lb/>in the Amphipyrinae) and Lepidomys (currently in the pyralid subfamily, Chrysauginae). The<tei:lb/>other family with stout bodies, the Acontidae, was relatively larger and contained seven genera.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The first of the slender-bodied families, the Erastridae, contained only four genera, mostly<tei:lb/>acontiines but with at least one amphipyrine (Erastria [Elaphria] venustula). Most species of the<tei:lb/>Anthophilidae could be distinguished from the Erastridae by the lack of a forewing areole.<tei:lb/>Those possessing this structure could only be separated with difficulty. Eleven genera were<tei:lb/>included within the Anthophilidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The final family of the Minores was the Phalaenoidae [Archiearinae], which Guenee<tei:lb/>continued to retain in the Trifidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Quadrifidae. The second 'phalange' of noctuids recognised by Guenee was the Quadrifidae.<tei:lb/>Although this group of tribes was 'notablement differente' from the Trifidae, the separation was<tei:lb/>not absolute. Guenee found that placing the quadrifid families into a linear sequence was much<tei:lb/>more difficult than for the Trifidae. Although he attempted to delimit the families as naturally as<tei:lb/>possible, problems still arose, particularly in those groups that seemed to have closer affinities<tei:lb/>with certain trifid genera, for example, the Bolinidae and the Acontidae, and the Eurhipidae<tei:lb/>[Euteliinae] and certain hadenids. In contrast, several families were particularly well defined,<tei:lb/>notably the Catocalidae and the Plusidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Quadrifidae was divided into eight tribes on the basis of the wing venation and pattern,<tei:lb/>general facies and the labial palps.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Sericiae. This tribe consisted of two small, tropical families, the Palindidae (Palindia<tei:lb/>[Eulepidotis] and Homodes) and the Dyopsidae (Dyops and Dyomyx). Both are currently<tei:lb/>placed in the Ophiderinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Variegatae. The second tribe was the largest in the Quadrifidae, comprising eight families.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>REVIEW OF THE HIGHER CLASSIFICATION OF THE NOCTUIDAE 163</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The first of these, the Eriopidae, was small, containing only five genera. On the basis of larval<tei:lb/>characters, Guenee allied it closely with the next family, the Eurhipidae. However, he found it<tei:lb/>impossible to synonymise the two on the grounds of differences between the adults. The<tei:lb/>Eurhipidae itself formed a well-defined family, corresponding to the present Euteliinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Another family in which the constituent genera had, like those of the Eurhipidae, been placed<tei:lb/>in the Hadenidi was the Placodidae. Only two genera were included: Placodes [Eucarta;<tei:lb/>Amphipyrinae] and Diastema [ Acontiinae] .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The largest family of the Variegatae was the Plusidae. In addition to the two genera currently<tei:lb/>assigned to the subfamily Plusiinae (Abrostola and Plusia s.l.), three other genera were also<tei:lb/>included, Basilodes, Thyria and Plusiodonta. Through this last genus, Guenee noted that the<tei:lb/>Plusidae graded into the Calpidae. This family had been extended to include not only Calpe<tei:lb/>[Calyptra] but also Oraesia, Gonodonta and Hapigia. The last of these was considered to have a<tei:lb/>hepialid or notodontid aspect, but Guenee placed it in the Calpidae because of the development<tei:lb/>of the proboscis and the palps. However, present classifications place Hapigia in the Notodonti-<tei:lb/>dae and so it is not surprising that Guenee found that this genus formed a convenient link<tei:lb/>between the Calpidae and the Hemiceridae, another family containing current notodontids<tei:lb/>(Hemiceras and Canodia). Guenee commented on the resemblance between the larvae of<tei:lb/>Hemiceras and Cerura (Notodontidae) and concluded that despite the superficial similarity of<tei:lb/>the adult insects to noctuids, the genera of the Hemiceridae, and Hemiceras in particular, could<tei:lb/>belong elsewhere. The transfer of Hemiceras and Hapigia to the Notodontidae was effected by<tei:lb/>Druce (1887), while Canodia was moved by Schaus (1901). Of the three remaining hemicerid<tei:lb/>genera, two (Arcyophora and Plusiodes [Westermannia]) are presently assigned to the<tei:lb/>Chloephorinae while the third, Achantodes, (a genus Guenee described as having the overall<tei:lb/>appearance of a large species of Chilo) presently resides in the Pyralidae: Glaphyriinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The seventh family of the Variegatae was a group of moths whose relationships are still<tei:lb/>uncertain today. Until Guenee, the Hyblaeidae had been classified in such families as the<tei:lb/>Calpidae, Ophideridae or Gonopteridae. However, Guenee's general conclusion was that the<tei:lb/>group was of uncertain position within the Noctuelites. In present-day classifications, the two<tei:lb/>constituent genera are widely separated with Phy codes placed in the Glyphipterigidae. The<tei:lb/>development of the current location of Hyblaea will be discussed in greater detail below.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The last family in the Variegatae contained seven genera (e.g. Gonoptera [Scoliopteryx] ,<tei:lb/>characterised by angled wings.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Intrusae. The third quadrifid tribe Guenee termed the Intrusae. It was divided into three<tei:lb/>families on the basis of the general facies of the larvae and adults. The first of these, the<tei:lb/>Amphipyridae, contained four genera, the majority now being placed in the Trifinae (mainly<tei:lb/>Amphipyrinae), although Barydia has been transferred to the Notodontidae (Nye, 1975).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Toxocampidae showed great similarity to the last family (in Guenee's opinion) and like it,<tei:lb/>was divided into two groups based upon the larvae. Five genera were included, all of which are<tei:lb/>currently assigned to the Ophiderinae. The final family, the Stilbidae, was composed of a single<tei:lb/>species, Stilbia hybridata [anomala]. Consideration of all characters led Guenee to conclude<tei:lb/>that, like Brephos [Archiearis], Stilbia was totally isolated within the Noctuelites. At present,<tei:lb/>Stilbia is an amphipyrine.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Extensae. Three families were recognised within this tribe on the basis of wing shape and size<tei:lb/>of the legs.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The first family, the Polydesmidae, comprised three genera (Pantydia, Polydesma and<tei:lb/>Diatenes) which had marked affinities with certain genera of the Intrusae, from which they could<tei:lb/>be distinguished by the wing venation. The Polydesmidae were seen as a link between the<tei:lb/>Amphipyridae and the Homopteridae. This latter family was established by Boisduval (1840)<tei:lb/>for several genera, the larvae of which resemble those of the Catocalidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Hypogrammidae was considered to be somewhat heterogeneous and Guenee thought<tei:lb/>that it might eventually have to be split. In order to draw attention to this, he established two<tei:lb/>subfamilies, the Yridae and the 'Hypogrammidae propre'.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>164 IAN J. KITCHING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Limbatae. This tribe was another group Guenee considered might have to be split. It consisted<tei:lb/>of five families, of which the Catocalidae and the Ophiusidae were thought to perhaps warrant a<tei:lb/>separate tribe. They were believed to be related, through several genera, to the Patulae, and<tei:lb/>through the Catephidae to the Extensae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Catephidae and the Bolinidae were considered to have much in common. Seven genera<tei:lb/>comprised the former. Three (Stictoptera, Odontodes and Lophoptera) are currently assigned to<tei:lb/>the Stictopterinae, while of the other four, three are ophiderines, and one (Cocytodes) is a<tei:lb/>catocaline. There were only four genera in the Bolinidae: Leucanitis, Panula, Bolina [Aleucani-<tei:lb/>tis] and Syneda [Drasteria], of which the first is presently a catocaline, the other three<tei:lb/>ophiderines.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The genus Hypocala was the sole component of the Hypocalidae and superficially resembled<tei:lb/>the hyblaeids. Guenee was uncertain as to its relationships, but on the basis of the form of the<tei:lb/>palps suggested a link with the Bolinidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Two genera, Parthenos [Euparthenos] and Catocala, were placed in the Catocalidae. Similar-<tei:lb/>ities in wing pattern suggested a relationship with the Hypocalidae and the Ophideridae. The<tei:lb/>latter family contained some species that showed similarities to the Calpidae and others that<tei:lb/>tended towards the Erebidae (Patulae) and the Ophiusidae (Serpentiae). Two subfamilies were<tei:lb/>recognised, the 'Ophideridae propre' and the Phyllodidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Patulae. All quadrifids that, despite their large size, presented an essentially phalaeniform (=<tei:lb/>geometriform) aspect, were placed in this tribe. Four families were recognised. The Erebidae<tei:lb/>was a large family of many genera that was difficult to define using absolute structural characters,<tei:lb/>although Guenee felt that the overall facies was unmistakeable. The Ommatophoridae was<tei:lb/>similarly well defined in general appearance due to the large eyespot on the forewings of most<tei:lb/>species. Guenee considered this family to be very natural, despite the aberrant wing venation of<tei:lb/>genera such as Cyligramma (the only quadrifid genus to lack an areole) and Argiva [Erebus,<tei:lb/>part] (in which the hindwing venation is much reduced in the males).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Like the last family, the Hypopyridae was considered to form a link between the Erebidae and<tei:lb/>the Ophiusidae (Serpentiae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Within the Bendidae, Guenee recognised two distinct subfamilies. The Hulodides comprised<tei:lb/>species of the genera Homaea and Hulodes, which are South East Asian and resemble certain<tei:lb/>species of Hypopyra, while the 'Bendides propres' , inhabiting the Americas, included Itonia and<tei:lb/>Bendis [Lesmone].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Serpentiae. The seventh tribe of the Quadrifidae principally contained species previously<tei:lb/>recognised under the name Ophiusa, a genus that until then had been rather vaguely defined.<tei:lb/>The tribe was divided into four families, an arrangement Guenee considered provisional at best,<tei:lb/>because he knew so few of the larvae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>By far the largest family in the tribe (and also in the Quadrifidae) was the Ophiusi-<tei:lb/>dae, comprising those species with elongate larval prolegs and large, impressive adults,<tei:lb/>with velvet-like, apically-pointed forewings. It included a mixture of catocalines and ophi-<tei:lb/>derines.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The sole European representative of the Euclididae (Eudidia [Euclidia + Callistege] was once<tei:lb/>placed in the Noctuo-Phalaenidi. Duponchel (1844-6) had separated it into the Goniatides but<tei:lb/>Guenee rejected that name on the grounds that it was not based upon an included genus (but see<tei:lb/>his own Bombycoidae). The six included genera were distinguished from other groups primarily<tei:lb/>by a reduced number of larval prolegs (three pairs).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The larvae of the Poaphilidae, in contrast, were characterised by four pairs of prolegs,<tei:lb/>although the adults were similar to those of the Euclididae. Seven genera were included, of<tei:lb/>which four are currently catocalines and three ophiderines.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Distinguished primarily by the form of the hindleg in the males, which is clothed with dense<tei:lb/>hair arranged in a single compressed line on each surface, the Remigidae included genera that<tei:lb/>are presently placed in both the Catocalinae and Ophiderinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>REVIEW OF THE HIGHER CLASSIFICATION OF THE NOCTUIDAE 165</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pseudo-Deltoidae. The last tribe in the Noctuelites graded almost imperceptibly into the<tei:lb/>division Deltoi'des, although the two groups could apparently be distinguished using certain<tei:lb/>characters of the head. Three families were recognised.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Thermesidae were the largest and that which approached most closely in general facies<tei:lb/>the Delto'ides. Certain genera also showed some resemblance to genera of the Remigidae,<tei:lb/>Ophiusidae and Bolinidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The other two families were characterised by features of the palps and body vestiture. The<tei:lb/>Focillidae was recognisable by the form of the last palpal segment and by the somewhat angled<tei:lb/>wings. It contained four genera of ophiderines. The three genera of the second family, the<tei:lb/>Amphigonidae, bore a superficial resemblance to Gonoptera [Scoliopteryx] libatrix and are now<tei:lb/>placed in the Ophiderinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Deltoi'des. The second great division of noctuid moths was termed the Delto'ides. Guenee<tei:lb/>considered the distinction between the last listed Noctuelites (e.g. Palyna, now a hypenine) and<tei:lb/>the first deltoids to be very fine but the two groups could be distinguished. As was discussed<tei:lb/>above, such was not the opinion of Herrich-Schaffer (1845) but Guenee could not countenance<tei:lb/>such a decision.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Delto'ides were divided into three families that were not assigned to tribes. The<tei:lb/>Platydidae comprised only three genera: Trigonia [Claterna], Macrodes and Platydia [Yidalpta].<tei:lb/>As if to confirm Guenee's opinion regarding the fine distinction between the Noctuelites and the<tei:lb/>Delto'ides, these genera are currently classified in the Ophiderinae. He believed that the<tei:lb/>Platydidae were the most noctuid-like of the deltoids, although on the basis of palp, antenna,<tei:lb/>body, leg and wing characters they were unequivocally deltoids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Hypenidae were considered by Guenee to be intermediate between the other two<tei:lb/>families and to epitomise the concept of the Delto'ides. Most of the Hypenidae are currently in<tei:lb/>the Hypeninae but Rhodina, Madopa [Colobochyla] and Pterhemia are ophiderines.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Herminidae was the largest and most varied family of deltoids, and that which Guenee<tei:lb/>thought most closely approached the Pyrales. He also considered it to be the most interesting<tei:lb/>family because of the great diversity of structure found within it. Many genera have specialised<tei:lb/>structures on the antennae or eversible hair-pencils on the legs of the males, which have led one<tei:lb/>group to be termed the 'fan-foots'. Most of the herminid genera are presently classed as<tei:lb/>hypenines but two (Cyclopteryx, Rivula) are placed in the Ophiderinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This then was the second arrangement of the noctuids proposed by Guenee. It was followed<tei:lb/>by Stainton (1857), as well as by Walker (1856-8) in his influential, if controversial, list of<tei:lb/>specimens in the British Museum. Not all workers, however, accepted Guenee's classification so<tei:lb/>readily, and criticism was not long in coming.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The American alternative<tei:lb/>The opening move</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Packard (1869) described many morphological characters of the family Noctuidae that he<tei:lb/>considered to be of use in classification , drawn mostly from the head, thorax and wings. It was by<tei:lb/>far the most detailed comparative study conducted up to that time. Packard divided the<tei:lb/>Noctuidae into two subgroups, approximating Guenee's Trifidae and Quadrifidae. However, he<tei:lb/>criticised Guenee's use of venational characters and condemned the divisions of the Trifidae in<tei:lb/>particular, calling them 'trivial groups of genera'. Packard preferred characters such as the<tei:lb/>length and narrowness of the clypeus and the form of the antennae to those from the venation or<tei:lb/>palps. At least he felt this was true for the temperate noctuid fauna, but expressed no opinion<tei:lb/>regarding those from other areas.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Consequently, Packard removed both the Sericiae and Variegatae (less then Gonopteridae)<tei:lb/>to the Trifidae. This combined group he termed the Noctuinae , while the remainder of Guenee's<tei:lb/>quadrifids became the Catocalinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>166 IAN J. KITCHING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Development of Crete's classifications (1874-1890)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1874. In his list of North American noctuids, Grote (1874) employed Packard's two subfami-<tei:lb/>lies. However, Grote also included the deltoids within the Noctuae and also associated two other<tei:lb/>groups with the family: the Noctuo-Phalaenidae [Archiearinae] and the Bombyciae [Thyatiri-<tei:lb/>dae]. He also agreed with Packard's opinions concerning Guenee's tribal and family groups and<tei:lb/>employed no subdivisions in the Noctuae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>These criticisms had little or no effect on English authors (e.g. Butler, 1881; Meldola, 1881;<tei:lb/>Moore, 1881; Pryer, 1883-5), who continued to follow Walker (1856-8) and hence remained<tei:lb/>faithful to Guenee.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1882. A brief resume of the classification of the noctuids was provided by Grote (1882a). He<tei:lb/>disagreed with Lederer (1857), who had removed the Cymatophoriden [Thyatiridae] and<tei:lb/>Brephiden [Archiearinae] from the Noctuidae and established them as separate families, and<tei:lb/>chose to include the Cymatophorina [Thyatiridae] and Brephina [Archiearinae] within the<tei:lb/>Noctuae. This was followed by the New check list (Grote, 1882ft), in which the noctuids were<tei:lb/>subdivided although no reasoning was given.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Two major groups were recognised in the Noctuae: the Bombyciae [Thyatiridae] and the<tei:lb/>Noctuelitae (Table 5).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Within the latter, two subgroups were recognised, the Nonfasciatae and the Fasciatae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Table 5 The classification of the Noctuidae employed by Grote (18826) .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>NOCTUAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bombyciae<tei:lb/>Noctuelitae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Non-Fasciatae)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dicopinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bombycoidea</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Noctuinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hadeninae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Nonagriinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pyrophilinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Taeniocampinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Orthosiinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cuculliinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Nolaphaninae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Anomiinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Litoprosopinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euteliinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ingurinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Calpinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Plusiinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Stiriinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Heliothinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eustrotiinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hyblaeinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Noctuo-Phalaenidi<tei:lb/>(Fasciatae)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Catocalinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ophiderinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Toxocampinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Erebiinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Brotiinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pangraptinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Deltoides</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hypeninae</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>REVIEW OF THE HIGHER CLASSIFICATION OF THE NOCTUIDAE 167</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Packard's Noctuinae and Catocalinae), which were further divided into 21 and eight subfami-<tei:lb/>lies respectively. Many of the groups employed by Grote corresponded to Guenee's families<tei:lb/>but, because the New check list was the first to subdivide the American noctuid fauna, Grote<tei:lb/>found it necessary to erect a number of new subfamilies, which can be summarised as follows:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dicopinae: Eutolype, Dicopis [Psaphida, part], Copipanolis [Cuculliinae];<tei:lb/>Pyrophilinae: Pyrophila [Amphipyra], Caradrina [e.g. Athetis] [Amphipyrinae];<tei:lb/>Nolaphaninae: Adipsophanes [Catabena], Crambodes, Nolaphana [Balsa]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>[Amphipyrinae];<tei:lb/>Anomiinae: Anomis, Aletia [Anomis], Pteraetholix [Amyna], Chytoryza [Illatia]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>[the first two are ophiderines; the third an acontiine; and the last an</tei:p>
         <tei:p>amphipyrine] ;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Litoprosopinae: Litoprosopus [Ophiderinae];<tei:lb/>Ingurinae: Ingura [Paectes] [Euteliinae];</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Stiriinae: Stilbadium, Stiria, Acopa, Fala, Plagiomimicus [Amphipyrinae];<tei:lb/>Brotiinae: Brotis [Sphacelodes] vulneraria [Geometridae: Ennomiinae];<tei:lb/>Pangraptinae: Syllectra, Pangrapta, Phalaenostola [the first two are now<tei:lb/>ophiderines, the last a hypenine].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In addition, several genera were moved between subfamilies. For example, the Plusiinae now<tei:lb/>included Anarta [Anarta, Sympistis, Hada], Telesilla [Eucarta] and Lepipolys. The deltoid<tei:lb/>genera were divided into two groups. The first, the Deltoides, contained many hypenine genera<tei:lb/>and some ophiderines (e.g. Rivula) while the second, the Hypeninae, consisted of Hypena and<tei:lb/>its relatives. The deltoids were classified within the Noctuelitae but, unlike Herrich-Schaffer<tei:lb/>(1845), Grote kept the two subgroups together at the end of the list.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In the same year, Smith (1882-3) published a synopsis in which he explicitly stated the<tei:lb/>characters used at each level of subdivision of the Noctuidae. He recognised three primary<tei:lb/>divisions characterised by the eyes being naked, hairy or lashed. Finer divisions were based upon<tei:lb/>tibial armature, clypeal modifications and the palps. However, Smith did not attach any formal<tei:lb/>names to his groups. Indeed, he considered these divisions [to be] entirely artificial and the<tei:lb/>sequence of genera in the synopsis is not that to be followed in the systematic arrangement of the<tei:lb/>group, the object being only to enable the collector to place any unknown Noctuid into its proper<tei:lb/>genus with but little trouble.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1883. The next year, Grote (1883) considered in more detail the structural characters he had<tei:lb/>used in his previous works. He reverted to Lederer's (1857) three families, in that the<tei:lb/>Noctuo-Phalaenidae were elevated to family status (as Brephidae). Also, the Bombyciae of<tei:lb/>Grote (18826) was renamed the Thyatiridae (Cymatophoridae being inapplicable for reasons<tei:lb/>given in Harvey, 1874).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Noctuidae themselves were divided as before but only the nonfasciate subfamilies were<tei:lb/>discussed in detail. Most were unaltered from the New check list but several changes had been<tei:lb/>made. For consistency, the Bombycoidea were renamed the Apatelinae, while the Euteliinae<tei:lb/>and Pyrophilinae became the Eurhipinae and Caradrinae respectively. The Bryophilinae<tei:lb/>(Bryophila [Cryphia] and its relatives) were split from the Apatelinae, while four genera<tei:lb/>(Trichotarache [Acontia, part], Tar ache [Acontia, part], Chamyris [Cerma] and Xanthodes<tei:lb/>[Bagisara]) were removed from the Eustrotiinae as the Acontiinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Two new subfamilies were erected. The Arzaminae, comprising Sphida and Arzama [both<tei:lb/>Bellura] (previously placed in the Nonagriinae), and the Scolecocampinae, containing Scoleco-<tei:lb/>campa, Eucalyptera [Gabara, part], Cilia [Gabara, part], Amolita, Dory odes and Phiprosopus<tei:lb/>[Phyprosopus].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1886. Meyrick (1886) was the first English author to adopt the characters advocated by Grote.<tei:lb/>However, Meyrick also employed Guenee's major divisions (based upon the development of<tei:lb/>hindwing vein A/ 2 ), calling them the Noctuidae and Plusiadae. No further subordinate groups<tei:lb/>were used.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>168 IAN J. KITCHING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1890. A revised checklist of North American noctuids was published by Grote in 1890. Two<tei:lb/>subfamilies were considered, the Thyatirinae and the Noctuinae (relegated from the rank of<tei:lb/>family). The latter was divided into 25 tribes. Most of these corresponded to those of Grote's<tei:lb/>previous works but there were discrepancies.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Arsilonche [Simyra] and Raphia were separated from the Apatelinae and, together with<tei:lb/>Demas [Colocasia] , comprised the Bombycoidi. Not only was this name potentially confusing (cf<tei:lb/>the Bombycoidae of Guenee, 1852-4) but it was not based upon the name of an included genus<tei:lb/>and therefore ran counter to Grote's (1883) previous assertions regarding the correct formation<tei:lb/>of suprageneric names.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In addition, the Noctuinae were renamed the Agrotini, and the Eurhipidae reverted to the<tei:lb/>Euteliini, with the Ingurinae being included within it. New tribes were formed for Lithophane,<tei:lb/>Calocampa [Xylena], Lithomia [Lithomoia] and Xylomiges [Egira] (Calocampini); and<tei:lb/>Cleophana [Copicucullia] (Cleophanini). The Tarachinae lost Trichotarache [Acontia, part] to<tei:lb/>the Heliothini, while interposed between the former tribe and the Eustrotiinae was the new<tei:lb/>monobasic Cerathosiini (Cerathosia tricolor). This species had been described as an arctiid by<tei:lb/>Smith, near Utetheisa, but on the basis of wing venation and clypeal ornamentation, Grote felt<tei:lb/>certain that it was actually a noctuid. Cerathosia currently resides in the Acontiinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Grote (1890) gave only an outline of his classification of the rest of the family. More details<tei:lb/>were given in another paper (Grote, 1889-90). The Catocalinae were divided into two tribes.<tei:lb/>The Catocalini were characterised by their often brightly-coloured hind-wings and included the<tei:lb/>New check list subfamilies Catocalinae, Ophiderinae and Toxocampinae. The second tribe, the<tei:lb/>Pheocymini, comprised the Erebinae of the New check list. The wings of the included genera<tei:lb/>were generally concolorous and crossed by sinuous lines. Grote was unwilling to assign the<tei:lb/>remaining catocaline subfamilies of the New check list, the Brotiinae and the Pangraptinae,<tei:lb/>preferring to await a more thorough study of the Neotropical fauna.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Two tribes were recognised in the Deltoidinae. The herminiines could be distinguished by<tei:lb/>their concolorous wings, marked with continuous lines. The Hypenini, in contrast, had<tei:lb/>unicolorous hindwings while the forewings displayed the usual noctuid markings, albeit<tei:lb/>subdued.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The fourth subfamily of the Noctuidae, the Brephinae, now contained two genera, Brephos<tei:lb/>[Archiearis] and Leucobrephos . Grote recognised certain resemblances to some Geometridae<tei:lb/>(hairy abdomen, predominantly diurnal flight period, larvae with five pairs of prolegs [!] and<tei:lb/>similar habits) but still retained them in the Noctuidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thus, by 1890, there were two competing, if somewhat internally unstable and inconsistent,<tei:lb/>systems for the classification of the Noctuidae. The first, based upon the work of Guenee, was<tei:lb/>widely accepted in Europe; the second, arising from the studies of Grote, was the primary<tei:lb/>system in use in North America. The stage was set for a comparative assessment.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Classifications in conflict<tei:lb/>Tutt's comparison</tei:p>
         <tei:p>After consideration of the available options, Tutt (1891-2) decided to adopt the system of<tei:lb/>Guenee, not because he thought it was more correct but because it was based upon characters of<tei:lb/>the early stages as well as the adult insect. Grote's system relied entirely on adult features. Only<tei:lb/>the points of contention as seen by Tutt will be discussed further.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trifidae: Bombyciformes. Tutt considered as irrelevant the debate as to whether the<tei:lb/>Cymatophoridae [Thyatiridae] were to be placed as the last tribe in the Bombyces (Staudinger &amp;<tei:lb/>Wocke, 1871) or as the first in the Noctuae (Guenee, Grote). He did explicitly note, however,<tei:lb/>that the eggs were of the geometrid type, and that the removal of the Cymatophoridae from the<tei:lb/>Noctuae would render the latter group more homogeneous.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tutt concluded most authors to be in agreement over retaining the Bombycoidae (=<tei:lb/>Apatelini) and Bryophilidae in the Noctuae although Butler (1879) had dispersed the British</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>REVIEW OF THE HIGHER CLASSIFICATION OF THE NOCTUIDAE 169</tei:p>
         <tei:p>species of Acronycta [Acronicta] amongst the Arctiidae, Liparidae [Lymantriidae], Notodonti-<tei:lb/>dae and Noctuae (a position he later rescinded; Butler, 1893). Tutt also agreed with Staudinger<tei:lb/>&amp; Wocke's (1871) inclusion ofMoma orion [alpinum] in the Bombycoidae but expressed doubts<tei:lb/>regarding Demas [Colocasia] coryli and Diloba caeruleocephala, which he thought might belong<tei:lb/>elsewhere. He also rejected Grote's Bombycoidi on the grounds that Chapman (18930) had<tei:lb/>demonstrated Arsilonche [Simyra] albovenosa [venosa} to be congeneric with Acronycta<tei:lb/>[Acronicta] rumicis and so Arsilonche henrici (the American species) could not therefore be<tei:lb/>placed in a separate tribe to the genus Acronycta [Acronicta].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trifidae: Genuinae. Tutt considered this group to be far more natural, although he had<tei:lb/>reservations concerning the arrangements and contents of some of the families. He felt that, on<tei:lb/>the basis of larval habits and mode of pupation, Staudinger &amp; Wocke's (1871) placing of the<tei:lb/>Gonopteridae in the Trifidae was correct. Tutt also believed that Mania [Mormo + Naenia] and<tei:lb/>Amphipyra might be better placed in the Trifidae, but that the Plusidae should remain in the<tei:lb/>Quadrifidae. This last point was the major difference between Guenee's Genuinae and Grote's<tei:lb/>Noctuinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trifidae: Minores. Tutt acknowledged the anomalous nature of the Phalaenoidae (Brephi-<tei:lb/>dae) but retained it in the Trifidae. He considered Meyrick's (1892) transfer of this group to the<tei:lb/>Geometrina (as Monocteniadae) erroneous because the larvae have five pairs of prolegs (even<tei:lb/>though those on abdominal segments 3, 4 and 5 are reduced).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Quadrifidae: Limbatae. Tutt disagreed with Grote's suggestion that the Ophiderinae be-<tei:lb/>longed in the Catocalini, considering that association to be based upon superficial characters. He<tei:lb/>also believed that the Toxocampinae, allied with the Catocalinae by Grote (1890), were nearer<tei:lb/>the Deltoides, a position about which 'there can be no doubt' when the larvae are examined.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Quadrifidae: Intrusae. This was the subclass about which Tutt had most doubts, especially<tei:lb/>when just the British representatives of the three families (Amphipyridae, Stilbidae and<tei:lb/>Toxocampidae) were examined. He did not believe that Mania [Mormo] and Naenia belonged<tei:lb/>in the Hadenidae (where they had been placed by Staudinger &amp; Wocke, 1871) although he was<tei:lb/>reasonably satisfied with the position of Amphipyra in the Caradrinidae. Tutt also refused to<tei:lb/>accept Aventia [Laspeyria] flexuosa and Boletobia [Parascotia] fuliginaria ('an admitted geo-<tei:lb/>meter' - now an ophiderine) in the Noctuae, and thought the Stilbidae were sufficiently isolated<tei:lb/>to require special treatment, similar to the Brephides.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Deltoides. Tutt agreed with those who placed this group as an integral part of the Noctuae, and<tei:lb/>concurred with Grote's division of the subclass into the Herminiidae and Hypenidae, groups<tei:lb/>that Tutt considered to be very natural.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Overall, Tutt's general conclusions supported Guenee's classification, but with the following<tei:lb/>suggestions.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1. Demas [Colocasia] and Diloba were not Noctuae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2. The Bryophilidae had no close relationship with the Bombycoidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3. The Leucanidae was unnatural, Leucania belonged in the Noctuidae and the Nonagriae in<tei:lb/>the Apamidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4. The Hadenidae and Apamidae were essentially identical.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5. The Xylinidae should be divided, because Xylina [Lithophane] and Calocampa ]Xylena]<tei:lb/>were not closely related.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>6. The Amphipyridae should be divided, with Mania [Mormo] and Naenia being placed in the<tei:lb/>Noctuidae and Amphipyra near the Caradrinidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>7. The Plusidae were less closely related to the Xylinidae than were the Heliothidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>8. The Toxocampidae were closer to the Deltoides than to the Catocalidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>9. The Deltoides were unequivocally noctuids.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>170 IAN J. KITCHING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Smith's comparison</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Smith (1891) held altogether different views. The Noctuina included three families: the<tei:lb/>Thyatiridae, the Noctuidae and the Brephidae. No subdivision was used because Smith<tei:lb/>considered Grote's subfamilies to be of no use because of their 'unequal value and impossibility<tei:lb/>of accurate definition'. Guenee's classification was not even considered. Smith's position had<tei:lb/>not altered two years later (Smith, 1893).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hampson's Fauna of British India</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The next major work on the higher classification of the Noctuidae introduced a new name but<tei:lb/>one which was to have a considerable impact in future years. The first arrangement of noctuid<tei:lb/>genera proposed by Hampson (1893-5) pioneered an entirely novel approach to family level<tei:lb/>interrelationships. Hampson believed that the three families Agaristidae, Arctiidae and Noc-<tei:lb/>tuidae were very closely related and difficult to separate clearly in some instances. In particular,<tei:lb/>he thought that the 'primitive' forms of the last two families (the Nolinae and Sarrothripinae<tei:lb/>respectively) graded into each other somewhat. The Nolinae were later considered to be worthy<tei:lb/>of a separate family, based upon larval characters (Packard, 1895).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Also included within the Arctiidae, as the subfamily Nycteolinae, were nine genera currently<tei:lb/>referable to the noctuid subfamily Chloephorinae. This group of genera had always been<tei:lb/>enigmatic and had generally been placed in the Bombyces as a separate family (e.g. Smith,<tei:lb/>1891). Hampson (1893-5) noted that they approached the Acontiinae in the structure of the<tei:lb/>hindwing vein Sc + RI but on the basis of their 'tree-frequenting habits', retained them in the<tei:lb/>Arctiidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Table 6 The first classification of the Noctuidae proposed by Hampson (1893-5).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>NOCTUIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trifinae<tei:lb/>Acontiinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Palindidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Sarrothripinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euteliinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Stictopterinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gonopterinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Quadrifinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Focillinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Deltoidinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Noctuidae were divided into 10 subfamilies (Table 6). Two (the Acontiinae and the<tei:lb/>Trifinae) were characterised by an obsolete hindwing vein A/ 2 , while in the other eight this vein<tei:lb/>was well developed. Hampson thus used Guenee's major subdivisions rather than Packard's.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Agaristidae [Noctuidae: Agaristinae] were considered to be a development from the<tei:lb/>Noctuidae, the first occasion on which such a relationship had been postulated. Previously, they<tei:lb/>had been considered to be near the Arctiidae and in the Bombyces (e.g. Smith, 1891).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trifinae. This subfamily approximated Guenee's Genuinae and was defined primarily on the<tei:lb/>basis of wing venation (as were many of Hampson's categories). It contained those genera<tei:lb/>presently referable to the Noctuinae, Heliothinae, Hadeninae, Cuculliinae and Amphipyrinae.<tei:lb/>The Trifinae also included Acronycta [Acronicta], but not the bryophilines (see below), and also<tei:lb/>Toxocampa [Lygephila], a view almost diametrically opposed to that held by Tutt (1891-2;<tei:lb/>1902).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acontiinae. This subfamily was distinguished from the last by the presence of a slender vein M 2<tei:lb/>in the hindwing. The larvae generally have four pairs of prolegs but reduction of those on</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>REVIEW OF THE HIGHER CLASSIFICATION OF THE NOCTUIDAE 171</tei:p>
         <tei:p>abdominal segments 3 and 4 occurs in some species. Most of the 29 genera are still acontiines,<tei:lb/>but the subfamily also included two acronictines (Diphthera [Moma] and Bryophila [Cryphia\)\<tei:lb/>three amphipyrines (Megalodes, Cosmia and Pachylepis); two ophiderines (Rivula and<tei:lb/>Tathodeltd) and a hypenine (Perciand) .</tei:p>
