         <tei:p>Palindiinae. Ten genera were included in this , the first of the quadrifine groups , representing a<tei:lb/>mixture of ophiderines and chloephorines, with one sarrothripine (Bryophilopsis) and one<tei:lb/>amphipyrine (Callynd).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Sarrothripinae. Seventeen genera constituted this subfamily. The majority are still sarrothri-<tei:lb/>pines, although Ariola is a chloephorine, Nolasena an ophiderine and Chlumetia a euteliine.<tei:lb/>Also included was the genus Hyblaea. None of the defining characters of this subfamily was<tei:lb/>constant but most had raised scales on the wings and a bar-shaped retinaculum in the male.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euteliinae. Only three genera were included in this subfamily (Ingura [Paectes], Anuga and<tei:lb/>Eutelid) and all three presently reside here.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Stictopterinae. This was another very small subfamily, of seven genera. Apart from venational<tei:lb/>characters, the constituent genera also had fairly well-developed scale tufts on the forewing and<tei:lb/>frequently a hyaline area at the base of the hindwing. Only four of the genera are still<tei:lb/>stictopterines (Stictoptera, Odontodes, Sadarsa and Gyrtond). The others comprised a<tei:lb/>chloephorine (Maceda), an ophiderine (Cymatophoropsis) and a sarrothripine (Risoba).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gonopterinae. Eighteen genera comprised this subfamily. Again, characterisation was vague,<tei:lb/>with most of the characters also occurring in some genera of other subfamilies. Seven of the 18<tei:lb/>genera listed are now ophiderines, the remainder being chloephorines.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Quadrifinae. This subfamily was by far the largest in the Noctuidae, comprising 81 genera in<tei:lb/>all. Most are now placed in the Catocalinae or Ophiderinae but the subfamily also included<tei:lb/>genera assigned to the Plusiinae (Plusia, Abrostola), Amphipyrinae (Cetola), Pantheinae<tei:lb/>(Moma [Trichosea], Trisuloides] and Chloephorinae (Pseudocalpe [Arcyophora]).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Focillinae. In common with many genera of the previous subfamily, the larvae of the<tei:lb/>Focillinae are semi-loopers. The legs of the adults are also modified, possessing short, stout<tei:lb/>tibiae and tarsi. Thirteen genera were included, all ophiderines.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Deltoidinae. This group was relatively variable regarding wing venation and showed consider-<tei:lb/>able complexity in male secondary sexual characters. Hampson considered groups such as the<tei:lb/>Trifinae, Acontiinae, Focillinae and Quadrifinae to have arisen from this subfamily.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Deltoidinae contained 40 mainly ophiderine and hypenine genera but also two acon-<tei:lb/>tiines, Araeoptemm [Araeopteron] and Niaccaba.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Archiearinae are absent from India and were therefore not considered by Hampson. The<tei:lb/>Cymatophoridae [Thyatiridae] comprised a separate family, placed near the Notodontidae and<tei:lb/>the Sesiidae [Aegeriidae]. Although not placed near the Noctuidae, Hampson stated that were<tei:lb/>he to arrange the moth families in a linear sequence, then the Cymatophoridae would/o//ow the<tei:lb/>Noctuidae, rather than precede them as had been more or less standard practice in the past. This<tei:lb/>was because he considered them to be a side-branch from the main stem leading from the<tei:lb/>tortricids, through the noctuids and notodontids, and thence to the Bombycoidea and Geo-<tei:lb/>metroidea (Fig. 1) . As can also be seen from Fig. 1 , Hampson dismissed a direct link between the<tei:lb/>noctuids and either the pyralids or the geometrids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Further development of Grote's classification</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In the meantime, Grote had been reappraising his noctuid classification. On the basis of</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>172</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cymatophoridae-</tei:p>
         <tei:p>IAN J. KITCHING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Sphingidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bombycidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Saturniidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Geometroidea</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Notodontidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Noctuidae Trifidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>'aristidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lymantriidae<tei:lb/>Arctiidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Noctuidae Quadrifidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hypeninae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Nycteolinae [Chloephorinae]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Limacodidae<tei:lb/>Endromidae<tei:lb/>asiocampidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pyralidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Nolinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tortricinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tineidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 1 Phylogeny of the higher Lepidoptera, with particular reference to the Noctuidae, proposed by<tei:lb/>Hampson (1893-5). Note that the Noctuidae are placed internally on the main stem leading from the<tei:lb/>tortricines to the geometroids and sphingids, while the arctiids form the terminus of a side-branch that<tei:lb/>splits off from the main stem below the noctuids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>[unstated] larval characters, he elevated part of the Apatelini to family status (Grote, 18950) but<tei:lb/>continued to place them at the head of the Noctuidae. The Apatelidae, in addition to Acronicta<tei:lb/>and its relatives, also included Leptina [Baileya] (a sarrothripine), Raphia (an ophiderine), three<tei:lb/>pantheines (Demos [Colocasia], Panthea and Charadrd) and three cuculliines (Feralia,<tei:lb/>Arthrochlora [Feralia] and Momaphana [Momophana]).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Noctuidae became the Agrotidae on the grounds that the name Noctua was preoccupied<tei:lb/>in the birds. This began a long argument as to the correct family-group name for the noctuids.<tei:lb/>The subfamilies Catocalinae and Deltoidinae were not discussed in this paper (Grote, 18950)<tei:lb/>but the remaining group (= Noctuinae) was divided into 24 tribes (Table 7), as follows.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>REVIEW OF THE HIGHER CLASSIFICATION OF THE NOCTUIDAE 173</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Table 7 The classification of the Agrotidae [Noctuidae] followed by Grote (1895a, b). The first<tei:lb/>publication dealt with the tribes up to and including the Hyblaeini, the second considered the<tei:lb/>subfamily Catocalinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>THYATIRIDAE<tei:lb/>APATELIDAE<tei:lb/>AGROTIDAE<tei:lb/>Agrotinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Jaspidiini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agrotini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Psaphidini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hadenini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bellurini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Nonagriini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Heliophilini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scolecocampini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Balsini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Caradrinini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Orthosiini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cleophanini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cuculliini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euteliini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Anomiini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Litoprosopini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Plusiini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Calpini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Stiriini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Heliothini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acontiini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cerathosiini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eustrotiini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hyblaeini<tei:lb/>Catocalinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euclidiini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Melipotini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eulepidotini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Stictopterini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascalaphini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Catocalini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ophiderini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Toxocampini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thysaniini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pheocymini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pangraptini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hexerini<tei:lb/>Boletobiini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Jaspidiini. This tribe of seven genera (the Bryophilinae of Grote, 1883) had been excluded from<tei:lb/>the Apatelidae when this was raised to family rank. The name was based upon Jaspidia<tei:lb/>Hiibner [1806], which Grote (1895a) had substituted for Bryophila Treitschke 1825.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agrotini. The large genus Agrotis and four smaller genera (Anytus [Sutyna], Richia, Eucoptoc-<tei:lb/>nemis, Agrotiphild) constituted this tribe, which thus approximated the Agrotini of Grote<tei:lb/>(1890). The following were transferred out: Adita (Hadenidi), Copablepharon (Helio-<tei:lb/>thini), Ufeus and Pteroscia [Anomogyna] (both Heliophilini).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Psaphidini. This was the Dicopini of Grote (1890).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hadenini. Equivalent to the Hadenini of Grote (1890), the genera of this tribe had undergone<tei:lb/>considerable rearrangement and renaming.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>174 IAN J. KITCHING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bellurini. This was the Arzamini of Grote (1890).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Nonagriini. This tribe now contained only the first five genera (Nonagria - Tapinostold) of the<tei:lb/>tribe of the same name in Grote (1890).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Heliophilini. The remaining three nonagriines (Ommatostola, Heliophila [Mythimna] and<tei:lb/>Zosteropodd) , together with Ufeus and Pteroscia [Anomogyna], constituted this new tribe.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scolecocampini. There had been no change from the Scolecocampini of Grote (1890).<tei:lb/>Balsini. This was the Nolaphanini of Grote (1890).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Caradrinini. This tribe was essentially unchanged from the Caradrini of Grote (1890). However,<tei:lb/>Monodes [Elaphria] had been transferred to the Nonagriini (and sunk to Platysenta).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Orthosiini. This tribe was equivalent to the combination of the Orthosiini and Calocampini of<tei:lb/>Grote (1890).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The remaining 13 tribes were unchanged from Grote (1890) although the Tarachini had been<tei:lb/>renamed the Acontiini and lost Trileuca [Schinia, part] to the Orthosiini.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Smith on the deltoids</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Smith (1895), in his revision of the deltoids, recognised this group of moths to be devoid of<tei:lb/>exclusive defining characters, although the general facies was relatively distinctive. As restricted<tei:lb/>by him, Smith considered that the group might merit subfamily rank within the noctuids.<tei:lb/>However, he refrained from formally proposing such a grouping. Three (to Smith) very distinct<tei:lb/>tribes were included: the Heliini (Epizeuxis only), the Herminiini and the Hypenini. Two genera<tei:lb/>were excluded, Pseudorgyia and Rivula, both of which are now considered as ophiderines.<tei:lb/>Smith also felt that the assignment of the latter to the Nycteolidae [Sarrothripinae] might not<tei:lb/>have been the error most previous workers had considered it to be.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Grote on the deltoids (and other noctuid groups)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Grote (18956) considered that no stable classification could ever be achieved for the Noctuidae<tei:lb/>until the North American and European faunas were studied together. In a paper written as a<tei:lb/>conclusion to that of 1883, many of his ideas concerning noctuid classification were expanded<tei:lb/>and reinterpreted.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Thyatiridae were omitted, support being drawn from Dyar's work on larvae, which<tei:lb/>showed the group to be structurally related to the Geometridae and Platypterigidae [Drepani-<tei:lb/>dae]. The noctuid moths, therefore, consisted of three families, the Apatelidae, Agrotidae and<tei:lb/>Brephidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agrotidae: Agrotinae. Harrisimemna was removed from the Jaspidiini and placed in the<tei:lb/>Apatelidae, while Raphia was moved from the latter group to the Hadenini. Grote postulated a<tei:lb/>relationship between Raphia and Episema [Diloba] although he had not examined the European<tei:lb/>species of those genera.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Calocampini was resurrected but only contained Lithomia [Lithomoia] and Calocampa<tei:lb/>[Xylena]. Lithophane remained in the Orthosiini.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pyrophila [Amphipyra] was removed to a monobasic tribe, the Pyrophilini. Grote agreed with<tei:lb/>Smith's placement of Pseudorgyia in the Scolecocampini, but having failed to find a satisfactory<tei:lb/>position for Rivula (he could not place it in either the Nycteolidae [Sarrothripinae] or the<tei:lb/>Pseudoipsidae [Chloephorinae]), Grote was forced to erect a new tribe to receive it, the<tei:lb/>Rivulini.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agrotidae: Catocalinae. Thirteen tribes were recognised in this subfamily (Table 7).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euclidiini: a mixture of eleven genera of catocalines and ophiderines (e.g. Parallelia, Drasteria,<tei:lb/>Phurys [Ptichodis], Poaphila [Argyrostrotis]) .</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>REVIEW OF THE HIGHER CLASSIFICATION OF THE NOCTUIDAE 175</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Melipotini: Grote included six genera in this tribe (e.g. Hypocala, Melipotes [Bolina]), all of<tei:lb/>which are now ophiderines. He considered the distinction between this tribe and the last to<tei:lb/>be difficult.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eulepidotini: Eulepidotis and Palindia [Eulepidotis] [Ophiderinae].<tei:lb/>Stictopterini: Stictoptera and Magusa (the latter now an amphipyrine).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascalaphini: ten genera constituted this tribe, of which most are now ophiderines but Remigia is<tei:lb/>a catocaline, Argillophora an acontiine and Fagitana an amphipyrine.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Catocalini: Allotria, Andrewsia [Catocala, part] and Catocala [Catocalinae].<tei:lb/>Ophiderini: Ophideres [Ophiderinae] and Euparthenos [Catocalinae].<tei:lb/>Toxocampini: Toxocampa [Lygephila] and Eutoreuma [Isogona] [Ophiderinae].<tei:lb/>Thysaniini: Erebus [Ascalapha] [Catocalinae], Thysania and Letts [Ophiderinae].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pheocymini: this tribe was relatively large, containing 12 genera (e.g. Zale, Yrias [Metria]), of<tei:lb/>which four are now placed in the Ophiderinae and the remainder in the Catocalinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pangraptini: Phalaenostola [Hypeninae], Zethes, Syllectra and Pangrapta [Ophiderinae].<tei:lb/>Hexerini: this tribe contained only Hexeris [Triprora], now classified in the family Thyrididae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Boletobiini: of the four included genera, two (Boletobia [Parascotia] and Aventia [Laspeyria]<tei:lb/>are ophiderines, Acherdoa is an amphipyrine and Dyaria [Coenodomus] is placed in the<tei:lb/>pyralid subfamily Epipaschiinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agrotidae: Hypeninae. Grote considered the subfamily name, Deltoidinae, which he had<tei:lb/>proposed himself in 1890, to be objectionable because it was not based upon any included genus.<tei:lb/>He thus substituted Hypeninae. Two of Smith's three tribes were retained, the Heliini being<tei:lb/>considered insufficiently distinct from the Herminiini to warrant separate status.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The position of Nycteola</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The nycteolines had originally been placed among the tortricids but by the late nineteenth<tei:lb/>century were generally included in the Bombyces as a separate family, most commonly known as<tei:lb/>the Nycteolidae (e.g. Smith, 1891). Frequently, a group of genera including Earias and<tei:lb/>Pseudoips was also included, but more often these genera were placed in a distinct though<tei:lb/>related family, the Pseudoipsidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Nycteola had also been referred to the Noctuidae but as a deltoid. Grote (1895b) disagreed<tei:lb/>with this. Examination of the immature stages revealed similarities to Pseudoips [Bena]<tei:lb/>bicolorana [prasinana] but peculiarities in the wing shape and venation led Grote to believe that<tei:lb/>Nycteola did not belong in either the Pseudoipsidae [Noctuidae: Chloephorinae] (which Grote<tei:lb/>recognised as distinct) or the Noctuidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A study of the larval chaetotaxy of Nycteola by Dyar, which was communicated by Grote,<tei:lb/>bore out the latter's opinions regarding the close relationship between this genus and the<tei:lb/>Pseudoipsidae, and even suggested that the two groups might not be distinct. However, Grote<tei:lb/>retained the family rank of the Nycteolidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hampson (1893-5) considered the nycteolines to be a subfamily of the arctiids, closely related<tei:lb/>to the Nolinae and this postulated relationship was to recur later.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The three classifications</tei:p>
         <tei:p>By 1900, there were three main arrangements of the noctuid genera in use, those of Grote,<tei:lb/>Hampson and Tutt.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Grote's classification was the only one not based upon the families of Guenee, groups that<tei:lb/>Grote still maintained had no value. The use of his classification was largely confined to North<tei:lb/>America.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>176 IAN J. KITCHING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hampson's classification was a less well-resolved version of Guenee's. It was followed without<tei:lb/>alteration by Leech (1900) while Staudinger &amp; Rebel (1901) modified it slightly. They reintro-<tei:lb/>duced the Acronyctinae, with the usual constituent genera - Panthea, Trichosea, Moma, Demas<tei:lb/>[Colocasia], Acronycta [Acronicta], Simyra, etc. - but retained Bryophila [Cryphia] in the<tei:lb/>Trifinae. The latter subfamily was expanded to include the Acontiinae and Euteliinae of<tei:lb/>Hampson. With no European representative, the Palindiinae and Stictopterinae were not<tei:lb/>considered. The Sarrothripinae were united with the chloephorines (e.g. Earias) and placed in a<tei:lb/>separate family, the Cymbidae, between the Nolidae and the Syntomidae [Arctiidae: Ctenuchi-<tei:lb/>nae]. Thus, where the sarrothripines were concerned, Staudinger &amp; Rebel chose to accept<tei:lb/>Dyar's conclusions. The Gonopteridae and Deltoidinae were retained while the Focillinae were<tei:lb/>included in the Quadrifinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Whereas the other two systems had undergone only minor alterations, Tutt (1902) introduced<tei:lb/>considerable changes into his classification of the Noctuidae (Table 8).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Noctuides. Despite the opinions of Grote and Hampson, Tutt still clung to the earlier<tei:lb/>ideas regarding the evolution of the noctuids. The Deltoides were considered to be the most<tei:lb/>primitive group from which at least two independent lines had evolved. One of these lines<tei:lb/>proceeded through the Minores, Genuinae and Bombycoidae to the Arctiidae and Lyman-</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Table 8 The classification of the Noctuidae followed by Tutt (1902) . It represents a modified version<tei:lb/>of Guenee's second classification.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Family: 1 Bombycoidae<tei:lb/>Family: 2 Noctuidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Subfamily: 1 Noctuinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tribe: 1 Leucaniidi</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 Agrotidi</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Subfamily: 2 Caradrinae<tei:lb/>Tribe: 1 Stilbidi</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 Caradrinidi</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Subfamily: 3 Amphipyrinae<tei:lb/>Subfamily: 4 Apameinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tribe: 1 Nonagriidi</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 Apameidi</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 Carpocapsidi</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4 Bryophilidi</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5 Hadenidi<tei:lb/>Subfamily: 5 Orthosiinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tribe: 1 Orthosiidi</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 Cosmiidi<tei:lb/>Subfamily: 6 Calocampinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tribe: 1 Xylocampidi</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 Calocampidi</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 Cuculliidi</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Subfamily: 7 Heliothinae<tei:lb/>Subfamily: 8 Plusiinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Family: 3 Acontiidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Subfamily: 1 Acontiinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Subfamily: 2 Erastriinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Subfamily: 3 Anthophilinae<tei:lb/>Family: 4 Catocalinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Subfamily: 1 Catocalinae<tei:lb/>Family: 5 Aventiidae<tei:lb/>Family: 6 Phalenidae<tei:lb/>Family: 7 Euclididae<tei:lb/>Family: 8 Poaphilidae</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>REVIEW OF THE HIGHER CLASSIFICATION OF THE NOCTUIDAE 177</tei:p>
         <tei:p>triidae, while the other passed through the Catocalinae to the geometrids. The Geometridae<tei:lb/>were therefore highly evolved noctuids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bombycoidae. Tutt considered that the larvae of this group resembled the Arctiidae and<tei:lb/>Liparidae [Lymantriidae] and that these families may therefore have evolved from bombycoid<tei:lb/>stock. Following Grote, rather than Hampson, Tutt accorded this group family status.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Noctuidae. This family was essentially the equivalent of Guenee's Genuinae but with the<tei:lb/>addition of the Bryophilini, Stilbidi, Amphipyrinae and Plusiinae. Eight subfamilies were<tei:lb/>recognised.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Noctuinae. Although Tutt divided the subfamily into three tribes (Leucaniidi, Agrotidi and<tei:lb/>Noctuidi), he treated the genera of the last two together as the Agrotidi. The Leucaniidi<tei:lb/>contained the hadenine wainscots and the Agrotidi coincided for the most part with the present<tei:lb/>Noctuinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Caradrininae. Two tribes of small inconspicuous moths formed this subfamily. The Stilbidi<tei:lb/>included Stilbia, Hydrilla [Hydrillula] and their relatives, while the Caradrinini included such<tei:lb/>genera as Laphygma [Spodoptera, part].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Amphipyrinae. This tribe contained only two species, Amphipyra pyramided and A. tragopo-<tei:lb/>gonis, characterised by their ability to secrete themselves into narrow crevices.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Apaminae. Tutt considered this family to have been 'wonderfully muddled by British<tei:lb/>authors'. He recognised the superficial similarities between the Nonagriidi and the Leucaniidi<tei:lb/>(Noctuinae) as convergent. Five tribes were included.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Nonagriidi consisted of those wainscots with stem-boring larvae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Apameidi were dull-coloured and had larvae that were either root-borers or fed on low<tei:lb/>plants, often on their roots (e.g. Gortyna, Xylophasia [Apamea] and Miana [Oligia]. Most are<tei:lb/>now amphipyrines but there are some hadenines and noctuines.).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Carpocapsidi (Dianthoecia [Hadena]) were distinguished by the larvae feeding exclusive-<tei:lb/>ly on the seed-capsules of the Caryophyllaceae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tutt removed Bryophila [Cryphia] from its usual place near Acronicta and placed it in a<tei:lb/>separate tribe in the Apameinae, the Bryophilidi. He considered Bryophila to be a hadenoid<tei:lb/>genus, related to Hecatera [Hadena].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The last tribe of this group, the Hadenidi, was one that had been merged with the Apameidi by<tei:lb/>other authors but which many British lepidopterists thought deserved family rank. Tutt<tei:lb/>concurred with the former, being unable to find any significant distinction between the two<tei:lb/>groups, but he nevertheless retained the Hadenidi as a separate entity. Included were amphipy-<tei:lb/>rines, cuculliines, and hadenines.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Orthosiinae. The moths that comprised this subfamily were characterised by being on the wing<tei:lb/>either very late or very early in the year. Two tribes were recognised.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Orthosidi was a mixed bag of genera, with representatives from the present Hadeninae<tei:lb/>(e.g. Taeniocampa [Orthosia]}, Cuculliinae (e.g. Xylina [Lithophane]) and Ophiderinae<tei:lb/>(Gonoptera [Scoliopteryx]}.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The second tribe, the Cosmidi, was distinguished from the last by the larval habit of spinning<tei:lb/>leaves together. All are now placed in the Amphipyrinae and include such genera as Dicycla and<tei:lb/>Calymnia [Cosmia].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Calocampinae. Tutt followed Grote (1895b) by separating Xylina [Lithophane] from the other<tei:lb/>genera previously placed in the 'Xylininae'. The remaining group was termed the Calocampinae<tei:lb/>and consisted of three tribes: the Xylocampidi (Xylocampa) , the Calocampidi (Calocampa<tei:lb/>[Xylena] and Lithomia [Lithomoia]} and the Cuculliidi (Cucullia).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>178 IAN J. KITCHING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Heliothinae. The moths of this subfamily were characterised by the generally diurnally-active,<tei:lb/>colourful adults and flower-feeding larvae. All the British species currently assigned to the<tei:lb/>Heliothinae were included, together with the hadenine Anarta and the amphipyrine Heliaca<tei:lb/>[Panemeria].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Plusiinae. Tutt now considered this subfamily to be a highly-developed group of heliothines.<tei:lb/>The reduction in the number of larval prolegs (which also occurs in other groups of noctuids) was<tei:lb/>explained as the result of convergent evolution. Only the species currently placed in this<tei:lb/>subfamily were included. Its position in the Trifidae agreed with Grote's system rather than with<tei:lb/>Guenee's.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acontiidae. This family was believed by Tutt to be closely related to the Deltoides, from which<tei:lb/>they might have arisen. Three subfamilies were recognised.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Acontiinae contained Agrophila [Emmelia] and Acontia \Tytd\. Erastria [Lithacodia,<tei:lb/>Elaphria] and Banksia [Eustrotia] comprised the Erastriinae while the Anthophilinae contained<tei:lb/>Hydrelia [Eustrotia] and Thalpochares [Eublemma]. All except Tyta (Ophiderinae) and<tei:lb/>Elaphria (Amphipyrinae) are currently acontiines.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Geometriform noctuides. At this point in the family, Tutt's nomenclature and ranking broke<tei:lb/>down, mainly because the groups concerned were poorly represented in the British fauna.<tei:lb/>Nevertheless, he considered the British species could still give some indications as to the<tei:lb/>evolutionary history and development of the Geometridae. The families discussed below,<tei:lb/>together with the Trifidae, were considered to have all arisen independently from the<tei:lb/>deltoids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Catocalidae. Only one subfamily, the Catocalinae, was represented in Britain. This was the<tei:lb/>group Tutt considered to be closest to the geometrids, a relationship he thought was more<tei:lb/>obvious in certain exotic groups than in the single British genus, Catocala.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>t</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Aventiidae. This family contained only Aventia [Laspeyria] flexula and was erected because<tei:lb/>Tutt was unable to determine the nearest relatives of the species. The larvae have only three<tei:lb/>pairs of prolegs ('like some geometers') and a lateral row of fleshy filaments above the prolegs as<tei:lb/>in Catocala. The adult is deltoid in its general facies.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Phalenidae. Tutt retained this name for the family in preference to Brephidae. He interpreted<tei:lb/>the group as either being at a point early in the geometrid line of evolution or an isolated lineage,<tei:lb/>having undergone considerable parallel evolution with the Geometridae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Serpentides. This group consisted of two families. The Euclididae contained the single genus<tei:lb/>Eudidia [Euclidia, Callistege], with larvae that Tutt considered to be 'remarkably geometri-<tei:lb/>form'. He did not comment on the second family, the Poaphilidae, with its single species,<tei:lb/>Prothymia [Phytometra] viridaria. The former family is now part of the Catocalinae, the latter<tei:lb/>part of the Ophiderinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Deltoides. Tutt interposed the Geometridae between this group and the Noctuidae. He<tei:lb/>considered the Deltoides as a group, but not the individual species, to be ancestral to the other<tei:lb/>noctuid families. Three deltoid families were recognised.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Toxocampidae. This was a group of moths (Toxocampa [Lygephila] and Ophiodes [Minucia])<tei:lb/>which Tutt considered to be essentially deltoid, but that also had certain affinities with the<tei:lb/>noctuids. Tutt was probably the only lepidopterist to associate these genera with the deltoids. At<tei:lb/>present, the former genus is ophiderine, the latter catocaline.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hypenidae. Five genera (Madopa [Cclobochyla], Hypena, Bomolocha, Hypenodes and</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>REVIEW OF THE HIGHER CLASSIFICATION OF THE NOCTUIDAE 179</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thylomiges [Tholomiges]) comprised this family. Of these, the last four are still hypenines,<tei:lb/>while the first is placed in the Ophiderinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Herminiidae. This family was divided into two subfamilies: the monobasic Rivulinae (Rivula,<tei:lb/>now an ophiderine) and the Herminiinae, a group of three genera (Hermina [Zanclognatha,<tei:lb/>Paracolax], Zanclognatha and Pechipogon [Herminia]), commonly referred to as the 'fan-<tei:lb/>foots'.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Miscellanea. The Nolidae were considered to be related to the lithosiine arctiids, whilst the<tei:lb/>Nycteolidae [?Chloephorinae, ?Sarrothripinae] were a 'very highly developed group which has<tei:lb/>evidently been evolved from the Plutellidae or the Tortrices'.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Demas [Colocasia] coryli was placed in the Lymantriidae, while Diloba caemleocephala was<tei:lb/>classified in the notodontid subfamily, Dilobinae. Also placed in a subfamily of the Notodonti-<tei:lb/>dae (as the Asterocopinae) were the two species of Asterocopus [Brachionycha]. Although<tei:lb/>noctuids according to virtually all previous authors, Tutt found it difficult to consider them as<tei:lb/>true noctuids despite their being 'undoubtedly closely allied'.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Cymatophoridae [Thyatiridae] were considered to be equally closely allied to the<tei:lb/>Notodontidae and the Noctuidae (cf. Fig. 1).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>These then were the three main systems for classifying the noctuids in use at the beginning of<tei:lb/>the twentieth century. However, in the period since the publication of The Fauna of British<tei:lb/>India, Hampson had also reassessed the interrelationships of the noctuid genera. This culmin-<tei:lb/>ated in the publication of a system that was to become almost universally accepted and, in the<tei:lb/>long term, put the higher systematics of the Noctuidae into virtual stasis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Demas [Colocasia} coryli- noctuid or lymantriid?</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Before proceeding with Hampson's second classification, I shall return to the early 1890s to<tei:lb/>consider, in more detail, the controversy that surrounded the position of Demas [Colocasia]<tei:lb/>coryli.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Chapman (18930) suggested that Demas should be returned to the family Liparidae [Lyman-<tei:lb/>triidae], basing his conclusions upon the eggs, larvae and pupae. He also associated Panthea<tei:lb/>coenobita and Diphthera [Trichosea] ludifica with Demas, a group that was eventually to form<tei:lb/>part of the subfamily Pantheinae (see below).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tutt (1895) criticised Smith (1893) for retaining Demas in its 'obsolete position . . . among the<tei:lb/>Noctuae', preferring to place the genus in the Lymantriidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dyar (1895ft) disagreed, drawing support from the studies of Poulton (1887). An investigation<tei:lb/>of the larvae of several Liparidae [Lymantriidae] had demonstrated the presence of dorsal<tei:lb/>eversible glands on abdominal segments 7 and 8 (more rarely on 8 only) in all species examined<tei:lb/>except Demas. If these structures proved characteristic of the family, then Demas had to be<tei:lb/>excluded. Dyar (1895a) had also found chaetotactic differences between the Noctuidae and the<tei:lb/>Lymantriidae, and showed that Demas conformed to the noctuid type. In addition, he (1895ft)<tei:lb/>considered the adult to be more similar to the Noctuidae than to any other family.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tutt (1896) replied to this, basing his conclusions upon the work of Chapman (1893,ft), then<tei:lb/>shortly afterwards, retired from the debate, having felt he had made his point. It thus befell Dyar<tei:lb/>(1896) to continue to press for the inclusion of Demas in the Noctuidae, by a reanalysis of<tei:lb/>Chapman's findings.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The eggs of Demas are vertically ribbed as in other noctuids, rather than obscurely ribbed or<tei:lb/>smooth as in the Lymantriidae. Chapman used characters such as the length and density of the<tei:lb/>setae, the form of the tubercles, especially the anterior trapezoidal (Dl sensu Hinton, 1946), and<tei:lb/>the colour. Dyar dismissed the first and last of these as being too likely to be subject to<tei:lb/>convergence while he suggested Chapman had been mistaken regarding the tubercle. In fact,<tei:lb/>Demas shows the strong tubercle of the noctuids rather than the condition found in the<tei:lb/>lymantriids, in which it is reduced or lost.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dyar disputed Chapman's interpretation of homology between the dorsal glands of lymantriid</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>180 IAN J. KITCHING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>larvae and the mid-dorsal depressions found in Demas. To Dyar, the general fades of the larva<tei:lb/>of Demas was, if anything, arctiid rather than lymantriid. Overall, he concluded that Chapman's<tei:lb/>study supported the inclusion of Demas in the Noctuidae and not the Lymantriidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Grote (1896) followed Dyar, retaining Demas (as well as several other genera now considered<tei:lb/>to be pantheines) within the group he called the Apatelidae. However, no good adult character<tei:lb/>was given to differentiate the group from the Noctuidae and the larval characters upon which the<tei:lb/>Apatelidae was based were insubstantial.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Smith &amp; Dyar (1898), using the conclusions reached previously by the latter author, restricted<tei:lb/>the family to include only Demas, Panthea, Charadra, Harrisimemna, Merolonche, Arsilonche<tei:lb/>[Simyra], and Acronycta [Acronicta]. Raphia and Feralia were rejected on larval characters,<tei:lb/>Momophana and Moma on adult characters. Of these four, the first is now an ophiderine, the<tei:lb/>next two cuculliines and Moma an acronictine.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Two series were recognised by Smith &amp; Dyar. The first, the Pantheini, contained only Demas,<tei:lb/>Panthea and Charadra and was distinguished primarily by a quadrifine hindwing venation.<tei:lb/>Other characteristic features included hairy eyes, pectinate male antennae and a similar facies<tei:lb/>and pattern. Raphia also possessed these features although the hairs on the eyes are microscopic<tei:lb/>and the male genitalia are distinct. Raphia could not be placed satisfactorily and was therefore<tei:lb/>omitted from the Apatelidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The second series, the Acronyctini, consisted of the residual apatelid genera. It was<tei:lb/>characterised by a trifine hindwing venation. As this is also found in several other subfamilies,<tei:lb/>only the distinct larvae allowed Smith &amp; Dyar to maintain the Acronyctini as a separate entity.<tei:lb/>In contrast, the Pantheini was a very distinct group of moths as adults, resembling the<tei:lb/>Acronyctini only in the larval stage. Smith &amp; Dyar concluded that there was no real basis for a<tei:lb/>continued association between the two groups, as far as the adults were concerned. The two<tei:lb/>tribes were nevertheless collected into the noctuid subfamily Pantheinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The position of Demas in the Noctuidae was consolidated by the works of Staudinger &amp; Rebel<tei:lb/>(1901) and Hampson (1898-1913). Only Tutt (1902) continued to regard the genus as a<tei:lb/>lymantriid.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Development of the Hampsonian monolith<tei:lb/>The precursor</tei:p>
         <tei:p>During the latter part of the 1890s, Hampson had been reappraising the classification of the<tei:lb/>Noctuidae. The new system, which appeared in part in Hampson (1900), was given in full in<tei:lb/>Hampson (1902).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A close relationship was still postulated between the Arctiadae [Arctiidae], Agaristidae<tei:lb/>[Noctuidae: Agaristinae] and the Noctuidae, and additionally, the Syntomiidae [Arctiidae:<tei:lb/>Ctenuchinae]. All these families agreed in having forewing vein M 2 approximating the lower<tei:lb/>angle of the discal cell. This character was also found in the Pterothysanidae, Lymantriadae<tei:lb/>[Lymantriidae] and Hypsidae [Arctiidae: Aganainae] and defined what Hampson termed the<tei:lb/>'Noctuid group of families'. This grouping largely agrees with the present superfamily Noc-<tei:lb/>tuoidea (if one accepts the Notodontoidea as separate). The only exception to this is the<tei:lb/>Pterothysanidae, which is now placed in the Geometroidea, although the sole species con-<tei:lb/>sidered by Hampson, Pterocerota virginea, may possibly be a eupterotid (R. Carcasson,<tei:lb/>manuscript note).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hampson (1902) did not detail the reasoning behind his new system. The characters used to<tei:lb/>separate the subfamilies were given in a key (Table 9) and were based upon those of Lederer and<tei:lb/>Grote, although employed in a novel fashion.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Agrotinae [Noctuinae] also included some of the species currently referable to the<tei:lb/>Heliothinae (e.g. Melideptria [Heliothis]) . The other trifine subfamilies were the Mamestrinae<tei:lb/>[Hadeninae], Polianae [Cuculliinae] and Caradrininae [Acronictinae + Amphipyrinae].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The quadrifine subfamilies comprised the Eutelianae [Euteliinae], Stictopterinae, Sarrothri-<tei:lb/>pinae, Acontianae [Chloephorinae], Homopterinae [Catocalinae], Mominae [Pantheinae],<tei:lb/>Plusinae [Plusiinae], Noctuinae [Ophiderinae] (and the chloephorine, Earias), Erastianae</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>REVIEW OF THE HIGHER CLASSIFICATION OF THE NOCTUIDAE 181</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Table 9 Key to the subfamilies of the Noctuidae recognised by Hampson in his second classification of the<tei:lb/>family (modified from Hampson, 1902).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 Maxillary palps absent 2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Maxillary palps present Hyblaeinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 M 2 hindwing obsolescent, crossveins m 1 -m 2 and m 2 -m 3 subequal 3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- M 2 hindwing well-developed 6</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 Mid- and hind-tibiae spined Agrotinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mid- and hind-tibiae not spined 4</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4 Eyes hairy Mamestrinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eyes not hairy 5</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5 Eyes with long, overhanging cilia Polianae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eyes not ciliated Caradrininae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>6 Hindwing M 2 approximated to M 3 at base 7</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- Hindwing M 2 parallel to M 3 Hypeninae</tei:p>
