         <tei:p>Male retinaculum not bar-shaped 11</tei:p>
         <tei:p>10 Forewing with tufts of raised scales in cell Sarrothripinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- Forewing without tufts of raised scales in cell Acontianae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>11 Midtibiae spined Homopterinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Midtibiae not spined 12</tei:p>
         <tei:p>12 Eyes hairy Mominae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- Eyes not hairy 13</tei:p>
         <tei:p>13 Eyes with long, overhanging cilia Plusianae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eyes not ciliated 14</tei:p>
         <tei:p>14 Hindwing M 2 strong, from close to lower angle of cell Noctuinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hindwing M 2 rather weak , from well above lower angle of cell Erastrianae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>[Acontiinae] (and several amphipyrines, e.g. Cnodifrontia and Callopistrid) and Hypeninae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hampson retained the name Noctua but applied it to the ophiderine Noctua strix [Thysania<tei:lb/>agrippina]. This was the first species listed by Linnaeus (1758) in the 'genus' Noctua and so was<tei:lb/>designated the type-species, following Hampson's personal rule (that is, the first listed species<tei:lb/>when the genus was described; McDunnough, 1916). Thus, the group then currently known as<tei:lb/>the Noctuinae was termed the Agrotinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hampson's Catalogue</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The basic system of subfamilies was unchanged in Hampson's major work, the monumental<tei:lb/>Catalogue of the Lepidoptera Phalaenae in the British Museum (1898-1913). (Subsequent<tei:lb/>references to the Hampsonian system, unless qualified, refer to that proposed in this work.) The<tei:lb/>scheme of the phylogeny of the Lepidoptera as a whole had undergone some rearrangement<tei:lb/>from that published in Fauna of British India. The relevant parts of this new phylogenetic tree<tei:lb/>are shown in Fig. 2.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The major difference between Figs 1 and 2 is that, in the latter, the Noctuidae and related<tei:lb/>families were considered as terminal on the main stem, rather than being intermediate stages of<tei:lb/>development culminating in the Geometroidea. The relationship between the Noctuidae and<tei:lb/>Geometridae, as espoused by Tutt (1902), was thus rejected. The subgroups of the noctuids are<tei:lb/>discussed in detail below.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Volume 2 - Arctiadae: Nolinae [Noctuidae: Nolinae]. The nolines were retained by Hampson<tei:lb/>as a subfamily of the Arctiadae [ Arctiidae] . They were considered to have arisen from very early<tei:lb/>arctiid stock, close to the noctuids Hypena and Sarrothripus [Nycteola] (with which they share<tei:lb/>the character of tufts of scales in the forewing cell). The similarity between the cocoons of the</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>182</tei:p>
         <tei:p>IAN J. KITCHING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Syntomidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agaristidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Notodontidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Uraniadae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Zygaenidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lymantriidae, Pterothysanidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>^Sphingidae<tei:lb/>Thyatiridae<tei:lb/>^Eupterotidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>.Geometridae<tei:lb/>Bombycidae<tei:lb/>^Saturniidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cossidae<tei:lb/>'Limacodidae<tei:lb/>LLasiocampidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Rhopalocera</tei:p>
         <tei:p>r Pyralidae<tei:lb/>Tortricidae<tei:lb/>Drepanidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tineidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 2 Phylogeny of the higher Lepidoptera, with particular reference to the Noctuoidea, proposed by<tei:lb/>Hampson (1898-1913). There are several important differences from the previous phylogeny (Fig. 1).<tei:lb/>The noctuoid families are now considered to be terminal on the main stem and the arctiids are derived<tei:lb/>from the noctuids. In addition, the notodontids are now ancestral to the noctuids (the reverse<tei:lb/>relationship was postulated in Fig. 1). (Redrawn from Hampson, 1898-1913, 1: 16.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>nolines and certain sarrothripines and chloephorines was also noted. Hampson excluded the<tei:lb/>latter two groups from the Arctiidae, considering them better placed in the Noctuidae because<tei:lb/>of the presence of ocelli and the free origin of hindwing vein Sc + R { .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Volume 4 - Noctuidae: Agrotinae [Noctuinae]. This subfamily was characterised by a trifine<tei:lb/>hindwing venation and spined hind (and occasionally mid-) tibiae. Some species also had hairy<tei:lb/>or lashed (ciliated) eyes, characters of the Hadeninae and Cuculliinae respectively. This<tei:lb/>highlights a peculiar feature of the classificatory process as employed by Hampson. The major</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>REVIEW OF THE HIGHER CLASSIFICATION OF THE NOCTUIDAE 183</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(key) characters were treated as hierarchical. Thus, any trifine species with spined tibiae was<tei:lb/>placed in the Agrotinae irrespective of whether it also had the defining characteristics of the<tei:lb/>other subfamilies. Of the remaining species, any with hairy eyes were hadenines, though some<tei:lb/>also had lashed eyes. The cuculliines were those of the remainder with lashed eyes, while the<tei:lb/>residue , with none of these characters were , by default , acronyctines [ Acronictinae + Amphipy-<tei:lb/>rinae]. A similar but less hierarchical principle applied within the quadrifines.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This method of allocating genera to subfamilies can thus be seen to be arbitrary in those<tei:lb/>instances in which two or more characters conflict, due to the arbitrary order in which the key<tei:lb/>characters were ranked. Many of the species were misplaced (as considered by recent works)<tei:lb/>and it was from this realisation that the dissatisfaction with the system largely grew.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Agrotinae contained two groups of genera corresponding to the present Noctuinae and<tei:lb/>Heliothinae (less the pyrrhine amphipyrines).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Volume 5 - Hadeninae. This group corresponded to the Mamestrinae of Hampson (1902) . The<tei:lb/>included genera were hairy-eyed trifines with unspined tibiae, and a few (e.g. Trichopolia and<tei:lb/>Stretchid) also had lashed eyes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Volume 6 - Cucullianae [Cuculliinae]. This trifine subfamily, previously referred to by<tei:lb/>Hampson (1902) as the Polianae, was characterised by bare, lashed eyes and unspined tibiae. In<tei:lb/>addition, many of the species appear as adults in the autumn or early spring, sometimes<tei:lb/>hibernating.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Volumes 7-9 - Acronyctinae [Acronictinae -I- Amphipyrinae]. This immense subfamily<tei:lb/>contained almost half of the then described genera of trifine noctuids. It was characterised by<tei:lb/>absences; no tibial spining and eyes devoid of hair and lashes. Hampson placed no special<tei:lb/>emphasis on the diverse hairy larvae of the acronictas, which were incorporated within the<tei:lb/>amorphous mass.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Acronictinae were interpreted as the most primitive trifine subfamily from which the<tei:lb/>other three, together with the Agaristidae, had evolved as separate lineages.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Volume 10 - Erastrianae [Acontiinae]. This subfamily was the first of the Hampson quadrifine<tei:lb/>groups. Most genera had a strongly developed hindwing vein M 2 , approximated at the base to<tei:lb/>A/3, but some had an almost typical trifine venation (e.g. Eupseudomorpha, Cydosia, Graeperia<tei:lb/>[Heliodora], Tarachidia). The last three of these remain acontiines but the first is now<tei:lb/>considered to be an agaristine. Overall, the subfamily was homogeneous in general facies but<tei:lb/>not well defined structurally. In many ways, it was intermediate between the trifine and the<tei:lb/>remaining quadrifine subfamilies. The larvae of most of the genera had the first one or two pairs<tei:lb/>of prolegs reduced or missing.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Volume 11 - Eutelianae [Euteliinae]. Characterised by a quadrifine wing venation, simple<tei:lb/>female frenulum and the presence of anal hair tufts in the males, this subfamily was essentially<tei:lb/>similar to that in Hampson (1893-5). He now considered this subfamily to be a parallel<tei:lb/>development, with the Stictopterinae, from the Noctuinae [Ophiderinae].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Volume 11 - Stictopterinae. This subfamily had also undergone little change. Its constituent<tei:lb/>genera also possessed the reduced female frenulum but had tufts of raised scales in the forewing<tei:lb/>cell and lacked the euteliine anal hair pencils.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Volume 11 - Sarrothripinae. This group was characterised by a bar-shaped retinaculum in the<tei:lb/>male and by tufts of raised scales in the forewing cell. An exception was Eligma, a genus now<tei:lb/>placed in the Chloephorinae (see below and also Mell, 1943). The larvae of the Sarrothripinae<tei:lb/>are sparsely covered in long hair and pupate in a boat-shaped cocoon.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Volume 11 - Acontianae [Chloephorinae]. Many genera of this subfamily also have a</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>184 IAN J. KITCHING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>bar-shaped retinaculum in the male. However, in Earias, Tyana and several other genera, this<tei:lb/>has been replaced by a tuft of hair. All are smooth-scaled except for Cerala [Kerala], which has<tei:lb/>slight scale tufts in the forewing cell. (Despite this, it was not placed in the Sarrothripinae, and<tei:lb/>still is not.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The larvae of the Acontiinae, like those of the previous subfamily, have five pairs of pro-<tei:lb/>legs and spin a boat-shaped cocoon on a twig, except for Acontia [Xanthodes], Leocyma and<tei:lb/>possibly Armactica, in which the larvae are semi-loopers and pupation takes place under-<tei:lb/>Hampson considered these genera might be better placed in the Erastrianae, which<tei:lb/>would then take the name Acontianae, whence the original Acontianae would become the<tei:lb/>Eariasinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Volumes 12-13 - Catocalinae. The Catocalinae was the first of two large sections into which<tei:lb/>Hampson divided the Quadrifinae of 1893-5. They were characterised by bare, unlashed eyes,<tei:lb/>normal frenulum and retinaculum, and spines on the mid-tibiae. Those Plusianae [Plusiinae]<tei:lb/>with spined tibiae could be distinguished by the presence of lashed eyes. However, Hampson did<tei:lb/>observe that many catocaline genera were closely allied to genera in the Noctuinae [Ophideri-<tei:lb/>nae] and he considered it probable that either the Catocalinae were polyphyletic, with mid-tibial<tei:lb/>spines being multiply convergent, or that the Noctuinae were polyphyletic, characterised by<tei:lb/>multiple independent loss of spines. Either way, Hampson felt the two large subfamilies might<tei:lb/>have to be united as one large subfamily. Subdivision would then have to be on other grounds.<tei:lb/>Many of the larvae of the Catocalinae are semi-loopers, a feature Hampson considered to be<tei:lb/>convergent in this group and others such as the Plusianae [Plusiinae], Noctuinae [Ophiderinae]<tei:lb/>and Hypeninae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Volume 13 - Mominae [Pantheinae]. This subfamily was equivalent to the tribe Pantheini of<tei:lb/>Smith &amp; Dyar (1898). Hampson considered hindwing venation to be a more important character<tei:lb/>than larval facies and so removed the group from its association with Acronicta and its allies to a<tei:lb/>place among the quadrifine subfamilies.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hampson considered the Mominae to be very natural and well characterised with two<tei:lb/>exceptions. Of these, Elydnodes is still a pantheine. However, Epicausis was transferred to the<tei:lb/>Cuculliinae by Viette (1962). On the basis of male and female genitalia, he placed it between<tei:lb/>Daphoenura and Eudaphaenura, genera that Epicausis also resembles in colour pattern. Viette<tei:lb/>also found that Hampson's interpretation of the hindwing venation was incorrect, for although<tei:lb/>M 2 is present, it is weaker than either MI or A/ 3 . However, Viette neglected the fact that<tei:lb/>Epicausis has distinctly hairy eyes (which the other two do not; Kitching, pers. obs.) and thus<tei:lb/>resembles a third genus, the hadenine Adaphaenura, which also has a colour-pattern similar to<tei:lb/>that of Epicausis. Viette characterised the Hadeninae and Cuculliinae as having hairy and lashed<tei:lb/>eyes respectively, yet still placed Epicausis in the latter. With the involvement of mimicry a<tei:lb/>distinct possibility, the position of Epicausis and its putative allies must still be considered<tei:lb/>unsettled. Viette (1973) retained the genus in the Cuculliinae, as did Nye (1975).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Volume 13 - Phytometrinae [Plusiinae]. Using his personal rules for type-species designation<tei:lb/>mentioned earlier, Hampson considered it necessary to rename the group of moths that had<tei:lb/>been previously known generally as the Plusiinae. The subfamily consisted of those quadrifines<tei:lb/>with lashed eyes and included the monobasic genus Diloba, in addition to Abrostola, Phy-<tei:lb/>tometra [Plusia s.l., part] and their relatives. Apart from Diloba, which Hampson considered to<tei:lb/>be aberrant (for example, the larvae possessed five pairs of fully developed prolegs), the<tei:lb/>Phytometrinae were well circumscribed.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Diloba itself had been considered to be notodontid, acronictine or even thyatirid. Chapman<tei:lb/>(1893a) found the genus very difficult to place. The egg is macroscopically similar to Acronicta,<tei:lb/>but the sculpturing is different. The larvae of the two groups have little in common, while the<tei:lb/>pupal cremaster has a slight resemblance to Bisulcia [Craniophora] (Acronictinae). Overall,<tei:lb/>Chapman considered Diloba to be more bombycid than noctuid and suggested that it might<tei:lb/>require a family of its own.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>REVIEW OF THE HIGHER CLASSIFICATION OF THE NOCTUIDAE 185</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hampson, however, considered Diloba to be noctuid. Thus, because of a quadrifine hindwing<tei:lb/>venation and lashed eyes, it had to be placed in the Phytometrinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Volumes [14-16] (unpublished) - Noctuinae [Ophiderinae]. The publication of the Catalogue<tei:lb/>was suspended during the First World War for financial reasons. When Hampson retired in<tei:lb/>1920, he left the manuscript covering the subfamily Noctuinae [Ophiderinae] (Gahan, Preface<tei:lb/>to Hampson, 1926). It is from that manuscript that the following is taken.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Noctuinae were quadrifine noctuids with bare, unlashed eyes, which were distinguished<tei:lb/>from the Catocalinae by the unspined tibiae, and from the Polypogoninae [Hypeninae] by the<tei:lb/>third segment of the labial palp not being acuminate (most genera) and by hindwing vein M 2<tei:lb/>being approximated to the lower angle of the cell. The labial palp segment three was always<tei:lb/>acuminate in the Polypogoninae while M 2 arises well above the lower angle of the cell and runs<tei:lb/>parallel to A/ 3 (except in the Mastigophorus-group).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The larvae all move in semi-looper fashion, even if all the prolegs are present (except for<tei:lb/>Raphia, whose affinities are open to question).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hypeninae and Hyblaeinae. Hampson never dealt with these groups, the last two subfamilies<tei:lb/>of the Noctuidae as he conceived it (see Table 9).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The system proposed in Hampson's Catalogue, albeit unfinished, was to exert a profound<tei:lb/>influence on the higher classification of the Noctuidae and is still generally accepted today. But it<tei:lb/>is possible that it too might have gone down in history as just another arrangement, were it not<tei:lb/>for its acceptance and usage by the authors of Seitz' Die Gross-Schmetterlinge der Erde. This,<tei:lb/>more than anything else , was responsible for confirming the primacy of Hampson's classification<tei:lb/>in noctuid systematics.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Seitz' Die Gross-Schmetterlinge der Erde</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The publication of the parts of this huge work that dealt with the Noctuidae spanned the years<tei:lb/>1906 to 1944 and they were written by five authors - Jordan, Warren, Gaede, Draudt and Seitz<tei:lb/>himself.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Volume 3 - Fauna Palaearctica: Agaristidae (Jordan). Jordan (1906-14) followed Hampson<tei:lb/>in allying the Agaristidae [Noctuidae: Agaristinae] with the Noctuidae, considering them as<tei:lb/>merely 'day-flying Noctuidae which have preserved some generalised characters, being in other<tei:lb/>respects more spezialized [sic] than the Noctuids'. This interpretation was also espoused by<tei:lb/>Draudt (1919^4, Fauna Americana) and by Jordan &amp; Gaede (1919-39, Fauna Africana).<tei:lb/>Originally the agaristines were placed at the head of the Bombyces, as a result of Linnaeus'<tei:lb/>(1758) opinion that antennal shape (i.e. clubbed) was of primary importance in the classification<tei:lb/>of the Noctuidae (Seitz, 1909).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Noctuidae (Warren). For convenience, Warren (1906-14) initially adhered to the five<tei:lb/>subfamilies used by Staudinger &amp; Rebel (1901). The only change Warren introduced was to use<tei:lb/>the terms Trifidinae' and 'Quadrifidinae' for 'Trifinae' and 'Quadrifinae' respectively, because<tei:lb/>he considered the syllable 'fid' to be an integral part of the word upon which the name was based<tei:lb/>and not part of the family ending 'idae'.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>With the publication of the first noctuid volume of Hampson's Catalogue, Warren chose to<tei:lb/>follow the new system as closely as possible but employing as few changes as possible also. As a<tei:lb/>result, complete correspondence with Hampson's subfamilies was not achieved (Table 10).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Acronictinae, which also included the Pantheinae, was recognised as heterogeneous in<tei:lb/>wing venation but was accepted on the grounds that the included species had hairy larvae, which<tei:lb/>feed exposed, and that pupation takes place in a cocoon above ground.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Metachrostinae, equivalent to the Bryophilidi of Tutt (1902), included only Metachrostis<tei:lb/>[Cryphia]. For the remaining noctuids, Warren thought it generally advisable to follow<tei:lb/>Hampson's arrangement.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>186 IAN J. KITCHING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Table 10 Sequence of noctuid subfamilies adopted by Warren (1906-14) in Seitz' The Macrolepidop-<tei:lb/>teraofthe World.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>NOCTUIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acronictinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Metachrostinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euxoinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hadeninae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cucullianae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Amphipyrinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Melicleptrinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Heliothidinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Erastrianae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eutelianae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Stictopterinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Sarrothripinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acontianae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Catocalinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Phytometrinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Noctuinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Agrotinae was renamed the Euxoinae, for unstated reasons. The Hadeninae and<tei:lb/>Cucullianae [Cuculliinae] were unaltered, while the Amphipyrinae represented the residue of<tei:lb/>Hampson's 'Acronyctinae' after removal of the Acronictinae (s.str.) and the Metachrostinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Melicleptrinae, roughly equivalent to the present Heliothinae, was composed primarily<tei:lb/>of those trifine genera with curved fore-tibial claws.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The next subfamily, the Heliothidinae, has no modern equivalent. The genera that comprised<tei:lb/>it were characterised by small, reniform eyes (although Meyrick, 1912, regarded them as being<tei:lb/>more correctly termed ovate), a distinctly hairy vestiture and a primarily arctic-alpine distribu-<tei:lb/>tion. Six unnamed divisions were recognised.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I. Anartomorpha. This genus combined the noctuine spined tibiae with the hadenine hairy<tei:lb/>eyes. Following Hampson's character hierarchy, it is currently placed in the Noctuinae<tei:lb/>(although it is treated as a hadenine, near Anarta, in the BMNH collection).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>II. Schoyenia, Orosagrotis [Euxoa subgenus], Grumia, Oxytypia. Characterised by noctuine<tei:lb/>features, all these genera are currently placed in the Noctuinae (although Grumia is in the<tei:lb/>Heliothinae in the BMNH collection).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>III. Anarta, Panolis. This division was characterised by hairy eyes and unspined, unclawed<tei:lb/>tibiae. Both genera are presently placed in the Hadeninae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>IV. Omia, Sympistis, Hypsophila, Cteipolia. These four lashed-eyed genera are currently<tei:lb/>placed in the Cuculliinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>V. Heliothis [Schinia, part], Pyrocleptria [Schinia, part]. These two genera bear the spined<tei:lb/>tibiae of the Noctuinae and the clawed fore-tibiae of the Melicleptrinae [Heliothinae]. They<tei:lb/>are currently placed in the latter subfamily.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>VI. Xanthothrix, Apaustis, Panemeria, Janthinea, Stenoecia, Micriantha, Stemmaphora, Omor-<tei:lb/>phina, Mesotrosta. These genera comprised those with unadorned eyes and tibiae, and thus<tei:lb/>qualified as amphipyrines. All are currently accepted as such except Omorphina, which was<tei:lb/>classified by Hampson in the Plusiinae (Kostrowicki, 1961 , considered it better placed in the<tei:lb/>Acontiinae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Warren recognised the heterogeneous nature of this new subfamily, in that its members<tei:lb/>displayed all the features used to define the previous five groups. However, he considered the<tei:lb/>shared characters to be more important. The group was conceived to be the 'scattered remnants<tei:lb/>of archaic types, the conditions of whose existence synchronised with the more rigorous climate<tei:lb/>and scantier light of an earlier cosmic period'.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>REVIEW OF THE HIGHER CLASSIFICATION OF THE NOCTUIDAE 187</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Palaearctic genera of the Erastrianae [Acontiinae] were recognised to straddle the<tei:lb/>trifine-quadrifine border, in that they possess a strongly-developed hindwing vein M 2 (in<tei:lb/>contradiction to Hampson's key, Table 9) but the larvae, as far as were known, had a reduced<tei:lb/>number of prolegs. Warren treated them as intermediate between the other two large noctuid<tei:lb/>groups.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The remaining quadrifine subfamilies recognised by Warren coincided generally with those of<tei:lb/>Hampson. However, no distinction was made between the Noctuinae [Ophiderinae] and the<tei:lb/>Hypeninae, the combined group being referred to under the former name. Diloba was included<tei:lb/>with reservations within the Cymatophoridae [Thyatiridae] (Warren &amp; Seitz, 1906-12).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Volume 7 - Fauna Americana: Noctuidae (Draudt). Draudt also largely adhered to Hamp-<tei:lb/>son's arrangement. However, the 'Acronyctinae' group [Acronictinae] was published before the<tei:lb/>volume in which Hampson merged it with the Amphipyrinae and so the division was maintained<tei:lb/>by Draudt. The Acronictinae was divided into two 'subordinate groups', the Mominae [Pan-<tei:lb/>theinae] and the Acronictinae, which Draudt recognised as probably not being closely related<tei:lb/>but which were kept together in order to maintain the coherency of the entire work.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Warren's heliothidine genera were distributed among the other subfamilies (e.g. Orosagrotis<tei:lb/>[Euxoa subgenus] to the Agrotinae [Noctuinae] and Anarta to the Hadeninae). As a result, the<tei:lb/>group Warren termed the Melicleptrinae, which now contained Heliothis [Schinia, part], was<tei:lb/>renamed the Heliothinae and must have added greatly to the confusion of those using the work.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Unlike Warren, Draudt did separate the Noctuinae [Ophiderinae] and Hypeninae as distinct<tei:lb/>subfamilies (1919-44: 17) although only the ophiderine part was ever published.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Volume 11 -Fauna Indo-Australia: Agaristidae (Jordan). In this volume, Jordan (1912-14),<tei:lb/>in addition to his previous comments regarding this family, also added that it possibly ought to be<tei:lb/>merged with Hampson's Acronyctinae. Indeed, the latter author (Volume 9) included several<tei:lb/>agaristine genera in the Acronyctinae (e.g. Xerocerus to Zalissa inclusive). Jordan also thought<tei:lb/>it feasible that the Agaristidae were polyphyletic, with Old and New World forms representing<tei:lb/>distinct lineages.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Noctuidae (Warren, Gaede &amp; Draudt). The trifine subfamilies were dealt with by Warren<tei:lb/>(1912-38), who retained the system he had used in the Palaearctic volume. The only alteration<tei:lb/>was the renaming of the Metachrostinae as the Bryophilinae. The majority of the quadrifine<tei:lb/>subfamilies, up to the Catocalinae, were described by Gaede (1937-38) and the remainder left to<tei:lb/>Draudt (1938). However, of the latter, only four lines of the introduction to the Phytometrinae<tei:lb/>[Plusiinae] were produced, the rest never being published. Both authors followed Hampson's<tei:lb/>arrangement of subfamilies.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Volume 15 - Fauna Africana: Noctuidae (Gaede). Several modifications were made to the<tei:lb/>arrangement employed in the previous volumes. Gaede (1913-39) followed Hampson in<tei:lb/>separating the acronictines and the momines [pantheines] into distinct subfamilies, although the<tei:lb/>two were still placed contiguously at the head of the family. In addition, the Sarrothripinae were<tei:lb/>divided into four informal groups:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(1) Sarrothripus-group: mostly very small with broad wings;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(2) Eligma-group: large and brightly coloured;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(3) Gadirtha-group: allied to the last in having long, subuliform palps and a dorso-ventrally<tei:lb/>flattened body, but being only half the size and cryptically coloured;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(4) Blenina-group: with cylindrical bodies and very broad, cryptically coloured wings.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gaede also recognised the arbitrary nature of the division between the Catocalinae and<tei:lb/>Noctuinae [Ophiderinae] but considered that combining them, and perhaps also incorporating<tei:lb/>the Erastriinae [Acontiinae] and Hypeninae, would result in a very unwieldy group. Otherwise,<tei:lb/>Gaede saw no reason for separating such generic pairs as Hypocala-Catocala, Fodina-<tei:lb/>Grammodes and Arcte-Cocytodes .</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>188 IAN J. KITCHING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This work, like many other volumes of Seitz, remained unfinished due to the destruction of<tei:lb/>the press and manuscript in the Second World War.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Satisfaction and apparent stability</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The authors of 'Seitz' were not the only enthusiastic proponents of Hampson's subdivisions of<tei:lb/>the Noctuidae. Dyar (1904), in his review of the agrotine [noctuine] volume, considered<tei:lb/>Hampson's arrangement and use of characters 'highly commendable'. However, he was far from<tei:lb/>content with the nomenclatural changes imposed upon his native American fauna. In particular,<tei:lb/>Dyar objected to Hampson's refusal to adopt the names used by Hiibner in the Tentamen.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Meyrick (1912), however, concurred with Hampson, reasoning that Hiibner's names were<tei:lb/>invalid because they were published without accompanying descriptions. Meyrick did disagree<tei:lb/>with Hampson regarding the potential use of sexual characters to define genera, characters that<tei:lb/>were totally eschewed by the latter author. As a result, Meyrick found it difficult to accept many<tei:lb/>of Hampson's generic groupings. He did find some points of agreement with regard to the higher<tei:lb/>classification of the Noctuidae, which he was able to incorporate into his own arrangement of the<tei:lb/>New Zealand Caradrinina.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Meyrick employed the term 'Caradrinina' to cover the group today known as the Noctuoidea<tei:lb/>(s.str.), maintaining his view that the generic name Noctua and its associated group-names were<tei:lb/>inapplicable to this group of moths. In addition to the Arctiadae [Arctiidae] and the Hypsidae<tei:lb/>[Arctiidae: Aganainae], two other families were recognised. These were the Caradrinidae and<tei:lb/>the Plusiadae, direct equivalents of the Noctuidae and Plusiadae of his earlier (1887) work. In<tei:lb/>the present study, Meyrick chose to divide the families into subfamilies, largely following<tei:lb/>Hampson's usage. He did employ different names, however (Table 11). Of these, the Plusiades<tei:lb/>also included the ophiderines. Meyrick (1928) later employed the same scheme in his British<tei:lb/>Lepidoptera.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Table 11 The classification of the superfamily Caradrinina proposed by Meyrick (1912), the contents<tei:lb/>of which correspond to the current superfamily Noctuoidea, less the Lymantriidae and several small<tei:lb/>groups.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CARADRININA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Arctiadae<tei:lb/>Hypsidae<tei:lb/>Caradrinidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agrotides</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Poliades</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Melanchrides</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Caradrinides<tei:lb/>Plusiadae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hypenides</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Catocalides</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Plusiades</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Forbes (1914) implicitly adopted the Hampsonian subfamilies although he did not employ the<tei:lb/>names as such. He was also not impressed by the vagueness of the trifine-quadrifine border and<tei:lb/>referred to those in which the condition was doubtful as 'intermediid'.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Barnes &amp; McDunnough (1917) were more faithful to Hampson's system. The only alteration<tei:lb/>was the substitution of Erebinae for Noctuinae [Ophiderinae].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Turner (1920: 120) went much further in his praise of Hampson: 'It would be difficult to<tei:lb/>over-estimate the debt which we owe to Sir George Hampson's great work. By it the study of the<tei:lb/>Noctuidae as a whole has been for the first time placed on a scientific basis'. Despite these words,<tei:lb/>Turner found it difficult, as did many other authors, to define the noctuid subfamilies precisely<tei:lb/>without recourse to 'distinctions of relatively trivial importance' (e.g. hairy eyes, spined tibiae,<tei:lb/>etc.). Overall, however, Turner considered it advisable to adopt Hampson's arrangement,<tei:lb/>primarily because no better system was available. This attitude was to become entrenched.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>REVIEW OF THE HIGHER CLASSIFICATION OF THE NOCTUIDAE 189</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Turner formally relegated the agaristines to the rank of subfamily within the Noctuidae, and<tei:lb/>thus agreed with Mosher's (1916) findings on pupae (see below). He dismissed one of the usual<tei:lb/>defining characters (clubbed antennae) and could thus include several genera placed by<tei:lb/>Hampson in the Acronyctinae (as did Jordan, 1912-14). However, having done so, Turner was<tei:lb/>then quite unable to define the group.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The remaining subfamilies dealt with (up to the Acontianae [Chloephorinae]) remained<tei:lb/>unaltered, apart from the substitution of Hadeninae by Melanchrinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hampson's arrangement was also accepted by Lhomme (1923-35) although again, the names<tei:lb/>of certain subfamilies had been changed (the Acronyctinae, Stictopterinae, Acontianae and<tei:lb/>Mominae became the Zenobiinae, Odontodinae, Westermanniinae and Diphtherinae respec-<tei:lb/>tively). This was in line with Hampson's supplement to the Catalogue (Hampson, 1918).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Similarly, minor nomenclatural changes apart, Hampson's subfamilies were adopted by<tei:lb/>Blackmore (1927). He agreed with Barnes &amp; Benjamin (1923), in accepting that the Linnaean<tei:lb/>generic name Phalaena applied to the noctuids (rather than the geometrids, where it had more<tei:lb/>frequently been used). Hence, the family became the Phalaenidae and the subfamilies Agro-<tei:lb/>tinae and Noctuinae [Ophiderinae] became the Phalaeninae and Erebinae respectively. (The<tei:lb/>family name Noctuidae was not finally stabilised until the suppression of Phalaena Linnaeus,<tei:lb/>1758, by the International Commission for Zoological Nomenclature in 1957, Opinion 450.)<tei:lb/>Also, the Acronyctinae were referred to as the Apatelinae, presumably because Blackmore<tei:lb/>accepted Hiibner's Tentamen and thus considered Apatela [Apatele] to have priority over<tei:lb/>Acronycta [Acronicta].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Finally, as an example of a study following Hampson almost to the letter, that of Prout (1929)<tei:lb/>might be mentioned. The only alteration employed was that she followed Comstock (1925) and<tei:lb/>regarded the hyblaeines as a family distinct from the noctuids (see also below).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Noctuoidea or Noctuidae?</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A rather interesting variant of the Hampsonian system of families and subfamilies of the<tei:lb/>noctuoid group of moths was supported by some South African lepidopterists, notably Janse<tei:lb/>(1937-9). He considered the differences between the noctuoid families to be far too small<tei:lb/>compared to those found in other orders, and thus, following Handlirsch's (1929) suggestions<tei:lb/>regarding ranking, reduced them all to subfamilial level in a more inclusive Noctuidae (Table<tei:lb/>12).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Inevitably, there were conflicts with Hampson's arrangement. The sarrothripines (as Nyc-<tei:lb/>teolini) were removed from the Noctuidae on the basis of a venational character (despite the<tei:lb/>'shape of the forewings somewhat resembling those of the Acontinae' [Chloephorinae]) and<tei:lb/>placed as a tribe in the Arctiinae [Arctiidae]. Also the hypenines were recognised as a tribe of<tei:lb/>the Noctuinae, equivalent in rank to the trifines (Trifini) and the quadrifines (Quadrifini).<tei:lb/>Consequently, most of Hampson's subfamilies were relegated to the status of subtribes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>As to Hampson's subfamilial characters, Janse considered hairy eyes and tibial spines to be<tei:lb/>fairly reliable, at least with regard to excluding genera from his Acronyctae, while lashed eyes<tei:lb/>and the condition of hindwing vein M 2 were much less dependable. He also disapproved of the<tei:lb/>use Hampson made of thoracic and abdominal tufts and crests, preferring to delimit genera on<tei:lb/>the basis of structural characters, particularly those drawn from the male genitalia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Only the Agaristinae and Noctuinae: Trifini: Acronyctae were covered by Janse (1937-9).<tei:lb/>The study was discontinued due to lack of material of non-South African type-species (Janse,<tei:lb/>1942).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This arrangement of genera was also used by Van Son (1933), Janse (1939), and, in a modified<tei:lb/>form, by Kiriakoff (1963). The last of these works will be discussed in greater detail in a later<tei:lb/>chapter.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hampson to the present day</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Despite considerable reservations regarding the naturalness or, in practical terms, even the<tei:lb/>usefulness, of Hampson's subfamilial classification, most workers have continued to use it, for</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>190</tei:p>
         <tei:p>IAN J. KITCHING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Table 12 The concept of the Noctuidae employed by Janse (1937-9), which is almost identical to the<tei:lb/>current superfamily Noctuoidea. However, Janse did not consider the differences between the<tei:lb/>constituent groups (his subfamilies) to be great enough to warrant family rank.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>NOCTUIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Syntominae<tei:lb/>Callimorphinae<tei:lb/>Liparidinae<tei:lb/>Arctiinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lithosiini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Nolini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Arctiini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Nycteolini<tei:lb/>Agaristinae<tei:lb/>Noctuinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trifini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Quadrifini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hadenae<tei:lb/>Agrotides<tei:lb/>Cuculliae<tei:lb/>Acronyctae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Momae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euteliae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Stictopterae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acontiae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Catocalae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Plusiae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Noctuae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Erastriae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hypenini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>example, Zimmerman (1958), Common (1968), Pinhey (1975) and Leraut (1980). Several<tei:lb/>others have made only small modifications: Viette (1962-7) separated the Melicleptrinae<tei:lb/>[Heliothinae] from the Noctuinae; Boursin (1964) additionally accepted the Apatelinae [Acro-<tei:lb/>nictinae] (moves that were subsequently followed by Kloet &amp; Hincks, 1972 and Bretherton et<tei:lb/>al., 1979); while Forster &amp; Wohlfart (1971) recognised the Apatelinae and the Bryophilinae but<tei:lb/>not the Heliothinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thus it seems that, minor differences in opinion regarding the precise names of the<tei:lb/>subfamilies apart, Hampson's subdivision of the family could be regarded as definitive and<tei:lb/>dominant. However, although apparently stable and imperturbable, the system was challenged,<tei:lb/>even during its publication. Hampson's classification was based largely upon superficial charac-<tei:lb/>ters of the adults and larvae. Detailed morphological and anatomical studies of all life-history<tei:lb/>stages were to cast serious doubt on the edifice. This doubt was eventually to lead to the proposal<tei:lb/>of a new system which, although still very much dependent upon that of Hampson, was to be<tei:lb/>more securely based in structural morphology.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The influence of immatures<tei:lb/>Emergence</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Most classifications of Lepidoptera have been derived using primarily adult characters. How-<tei:lb/>ever, in several groups, of which the Noctuidae are one, the economic importance of the larvae<tei:lb/>resulted in studies from which grew the realisation that not only could larval characters be useful<tei:lb/>in identification but also in classification.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Forbes (1910) was one of the first to investigate thoroughly larval morphology. Several<tei:lb/>noctuid subfamilies were considered in detail and within the Noctuinae (sensu the Trifinae) in<tei:lb/>particular, Forbes discovered a highly uniform structure, despite much individual variation.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>REVIEW OF THE HIGHER CLASSIFICATION OF THE NOCTUIDAE 191</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Only the tribes Acronyctini [ Acronictinae] and Cuculliini [Cuculliinae] could be delimited using<tei:lb/>larval characters.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fracker (1915) also investigated larval morphology but with special emphasis upon the<tei:lb/>chaetotaxy. He agreed with Hampson that the Nycteolidae ought to be reduced to a subfamily of<tei:lb/>the Noctuidae (Sarrothripinae), having found no significant chaetotactic differences between<tei:lb/>members of the two families. The larvae of the Agaristidae [Noctuidae: Agaristinae] , apart from<tei:lb/>their bright transverse striping (also found in some other noctuids, e.g. Acronicta alni), were<tei:lb/>also indistinguishable from those of the Noctuidae and Fracker considered the family 'should<tei:lb/>meet the same fate as the Nycteolidae'.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Within the Noctuidae itself, Fracker found the same discouraging degree of uniformity. This<tei:lb/>prompted him to write: 'with the exception of half a dozen genera, noctuid larvae are so uniform<tei:lb/>that one can often compare, part for part, every segment and appendage of larvae of two species<tei:lb/>without rinding a difference either of kind or of degree' . Fracker could only divide the family into<tei:lb/>four groups, three of which contained only members of the Acronictinae and Pantheinae, while<tei:lb/>the fourth comprised all the remaining subfamilies.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mosher (1916) found a greater range of variation in pupae and was able to characterise<tei:lb/>tentatively 10 subfamilies (largely Hampsonian). One, the Agaristinae, was included perhaps<tei:lb/>for the first time as an explicit subfamily of the Noctuidae. As had been found for the larvae, no<tei:lb/>structural differences of the pupae could reliably distinguish the agaristines from the noctuids at<tei:lb/>the family level. The Acronyctinae were heterogeneous for, in addition to the acronictines<tei:lb/>Eulonche and A crony eta [both Acronicta} and the amphipyrine Achatodes, the division also<tei:lb/>included three ophiderines (Homopyralis [Metalectra], Plusiodonta and Anomis). However,<tei:lb/>Mosher did not consider that these genera formed a natural group.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Of the remaining subfamilies, members of the Catocalinae were distinguished by the presence<tei:lb/>of an alcohol-insoluble surface bloom, while the Sarrothripinae completely lacked a cremaster<tei:lb/>and spines (although Mosher did not consider this sufficient to warrant separation from the<tei:lb/>Noctuidae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ripley (1923) performed an extensive study of the morphology of larval noctuids but did not<tei:lb/>interpret the results taxonomically.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The larvae of the Hypeninae were examined by Crumb (1934), who discovered two distinct<tei:lb/>types. The first corresponded to Forbes' (1918) Herminiinae while the other was found not only<tei:lb/>in the remaining hypenines but also generally in the catocaline-erebine [ophiderine] complex. In<tei:lb/>this regard, the hypenoid type (as Crumb termed the latter form) was not particularly distinct<tei:lb/>from the majority of the Noctuidae. The herminioid type of larva was divided into two<tei:lb/>subgroups and the hypenoid type into five. On the basis of the larva, it was suggested that Rivula<tei:lb/>might merit a separate subfamily; it certainly was not hypenine.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dethier (1941), in his detailed study of lepidopteran larval, antennae, described those of the<tei:lb/>members of 10 noctuid subfamilies (including the Rivulinae). Apart from noting the great<tei:lb/>similarity between the Agaristidae and the Noctuidae, no further remarks were made regarding<tei:lb/>the higher classification.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The challenge from India</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A major contribution to the understanding of the structure of larvae from outside the Holarctic<tei:lb/>was provided in a series of papers by Gardner on Indian Noctuidae. He subdivided the family,<tei:lb/>on the basis of previously defined larval characters (Gardner, 1941), into four groups, A-D, of<tei:lb/>which the first three were split further (Gardner, 1946a). The groups were not allocated formal<tei:lb/>names because of conflict with Hampson.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Division A (considered mostly in Gardner, 19466) consisted of various trifine genera, the<tei:lb/>Agaristinae and some acontiines [chloephorines]. It comprised six sections.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A I: (described in Gardner, 1946a): Acronictinae, Pantheinae and Cetola (Amphipyrinae).<tei:lb/>The larva of the last genus was not distinctly hairy but was included because it had six<tei:lb/>setae on the external surface of the prolegs rather than three.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>192 IAN J. KITCHING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A II: Amphipyrinae, Hadeninae; also Agrotis [Xestia] c-nigrum (Noctuinae) and Lyncestis<tei:lb/>amphix (Ophiderinae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A III: Noctuinae (Agrotis and Euxoa).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A IV: (described in Gardner, 19460): Heliothinae (Heliothis, Pyrrhia andAdisura).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A V: Acontiinae [Chloephorinae] (Aiteta, Carea, Maurilia, Pseudelydnd).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A VI: Amphipyrinae (Callyna), Hadeninae (Tiracola), Chloephorinae (Churia), Agaristinae<tei:lb/>(Aegocera, Eusemia}.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Division B (mostly dealt with in Gardner, 1947) comprised those larvae in which the prolegs of<tei:lb/>abdominal segment 3 are abruptly reduced or absent. The distinction from the genera of division<tei:lb/>C, in which the prolegs are all equal or are only gradually reduced from segment 6 to 3, was<tei:lb/>considered to be somewhat arbitrary.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>B I: (described in Gardner, 19460): Acontiinae [Chloephorinae] (Acontia [Xanthodes]) ,<tei:lb/>Amphipyrinae (Elydna, Chasmina, Androlymnid) , Erastriinae [Acontiinae] (Amyna)<tei:lb/>and Noctuinae [Ophiderinae] (Boculd).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>B II: (described in Gardner, 19460): Hypeninae (Hypena, Dichromia, Rhynchina, Bomo-<tei:lb/>lochd).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>B III: Plusiinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>B IV: Erastriinae [Acontiinae], Catocalinae (e.g. Parallelia, Achaea), Noctuinae [Ophideri-<tei:lb/>nae] (e.g. Othreis, Anomis) and Hypena [Sarobela] aurotincta [litterata] . Group B IV was<tei:lb/>divided into three subgroups:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>B IVa: lacking prolegs on abdominal segments 3 and 4;<tei:lb/>B IVb: lacking prolegs on 3 only;<tei:lb/>B IVc: prolegs present on 3 and 4, those of 3 distinctly reduced.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Division C (Gardner, 19480), unlike A and B, was not subdivided. Instead, the genera were<tei:lb/>treated according to their Hampsonian subfamily. Included were the subfamilies Euteliinae,<tei:lb/>Sarrothripinae, Stictopterinae, Herminiinae, some Catocalinae and Ophiderinae, together with<tei:lb/>Westermannia (Chloephorinae) and the amphipyrines Sesamia and lambia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The final division, D (Gardner, 1947), differed from the others in setal group VI (part of the<tei:lb/>subventral group of Hinton, 1946) being bisetose on the meso- and metathorax rather than<tei:lb/>unisetose. Gardner considered that division D was artificial (he was eventually to conclude that<tei:lb/>the entire system was artificial; Gardner, 19480), comprising as it did, Brithys (Hadeninae),<tei:lb/>Selepa (Sarrothripinae), and Earias and Eligma (Chloephorinae). These genera snared charac-<tei:lb/>ters with the Lithosiidae [Arctiidae: Lithosiinae], Hypsidae (Digama [now an arctiine]) and the<tei:lb/>genera Argina and Utetheisa (Arctiidae: Arctiinae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gardner (19480) considered that a natural classification of the noctuids should be based upon<tei:lb/>the number of setae in group VII (part of the subventral group of Hinton, 1946) on the first<tei:lb/>abdominal segment. This would divide the Noctuidae into two groups, representing roughly<tei:lb/>divisions A plus B, and C plus D, but with many exceptions.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The larval study was followed by a consideration of the pupae (Gardner, 1948ft). The pupae of<tei:lb/>the Hadeninae, Amphipyrinae, Agrotinae [Noctuinae] and Heliothinae were all found to be<tei:lb/>very similar. Several genera (e.g. Brithys) that were distinct as larvae, proved equally distinct as<tei:lb/>pupae. The relationship between Cetola and the Acronictinae suggested by the larvae was not<tei:lb/>supported by the pupae. The Euteliinae proved to be very well defined by pupal characters. The<tei:lb/>genera of Acontiinae [Chloephorinae], which had been widely dispersed on the basis of larval<tei:lb/>characters, were all very close as pupae, except Acontia [Xanthodes]. They also shared features<tei:lb/>with the Sarrothripinae. No great distinction was found between the pupae of the Catocalinae<tei:lb/>and the Noctuinae [Ophiderinae], thus giving Mosher's surface bloom character wider signi-<tei:lb/>ficance.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>REVIEW OF THE HIGHER CLASSIFICATION OF THE NOCTUIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>193</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Table 13 The division of the British Noctuidae proposed by Timlin (1955), based on larvae. NC = no<tei:lb/>comparison; l 1 = uniordinal, 2 = biordinal; prolegs on abdominal segments 3 and 4 only partly<tei:lb/>developed; 3 except for certain Cucullia species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Proleg<tei:lb/>number</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Secondary<tei:lb/>setae</tei:p>

         <tei:p>segment 1</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Contents</tei:p>

         <tei:p>4</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5 2<tei:lb/>5</tei:p>
         <tei:p>NC Most Acronyctinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>[Acronictinae], Dasycampa<tei:lb/>rubiginea (Cuculliinae)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 Plusiinae (Plusia<tei:lb/>[Autographa] gamma,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>P. [Diachrysia] chrysitis)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 Plusiinae (Polychrysia<tei:lb/>moneta)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 Ophiderinae (Parascotia</tei:p>
         <tei:p>fuliginaria)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 Eustrotiinae [Acontiinae]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 Hypeninae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 Plusiinae (Episema [Diloba]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>caeruleocephala), Ophiderinae<tei:lb/>(part), Acronyctinae<tei:lb/>[Acronictinae] (Apatele<tei:lb/>[Acronicta] alni)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 Agrotinae [Noctuinae],</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hadeninae, Cuculliinae<tei:lb/>(except D. rubiginea)<tei:lb/>Amphipyrinae, Acronyctinae<tei:lb/>[Acronictinae] (Cryphia perla<tei:lb/>[domestica]), Sarrothripinae,<tei:lb/>Westermanniinae [Chloephorinae]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Further conflict</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Timlin (1955) examined the larvae of 142 species of British noctuids, dividing the family into<tei:lb/>eight equivalent groups (Table 13). This arrangement was then contrasted with those of<tei:lb/>Hampson, Meyrick (1928) and Tarns (unpublished). Tarns' classification differed from Hamp-<tei:lb/>son's only in separating the Acronictinae from the Amphipyrinae.<tei:lb/>Timlin found conflicts in the following areas:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(a) the heterogeneity of the Plusiinae, especially regarding Episema [Diloba];</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(b) the similarity between the Hylophilidae [Chloephorinae + Sarrothripinae] and the Noc-<tei:lb/>tuidae;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(c) the reduction of the prolegs in the Eustrotiinae [Acontiinae];</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(d) the lack of a distinction between the Catocalinae and the Ophiderinae;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(e) the high degree of similarity between the trifine subfamilies (less the Acronictinae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In addition, Timlin considered the following genera might have been misplaced in classifica-<tei:lb/>tion based upon adult structures:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1, Dasycampa (Cuculliinae), which has secondary setae;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2, Parascotia (Ophiderinae), considered closer to the Hypeninae because of the reduced<tei:lb/>number of prolegs;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3, Cucullia (Cuculliinae), which is heterogeneous with respect to crotchet ordination;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4, Scoliopteryx (Ophiderinae), in which seta XD1 is nearer the midline than Dl on the<tei:lb/>prothorax, contrary to Fracker's (1915) diagnostic character for the Noctuidae;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5, Episema [Diloba], which, unlike the other plusiines, has five well-developed pairs of prolegs<tei:lb/>and uniordinal crotchets;</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>194 IAN J. KITCHING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>6, Apatele [Acronicta] alni and Cryphiaperla [domestica] (Acronictinae), the only acronictines<tei:lb/>examined lacking secondary setae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The next major work on noctuid larvae was that of Crumb (1956) . He attempted to classify the<tei:lb/>larvae of as many North American genera and species as possible, in order to facilitate the<tei:lb/>identification of crop pests. The arrangement of subfamilies adopted is given in Table 14.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Crumb accepted the Agaristinae as a noctuid subfamily but did not discuss it further. He could<tei:lb/>not distinguish the Pantheinae and the Acronyctinae [Acronictinae] on structural grounds and<tei:lb/>so combined them under the latter name. The Heliothinae were found to be separable into two<tei:lb/>fairly good groups but Crumb did not apply the distinction.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Table 14 Arrangement of the noctuid subfamilies followed by Crumb (1956).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>PHALAENIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agaristinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acronyctinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acontiinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cuculliinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euteliinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bagisarinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hypeninae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Phalaeninae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hadeninae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ufeiinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Amphipyrinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Plusiinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lithacodiinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Sarrothripinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Catocalinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Herminiinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Within the remaining subfamilies, apart from the unorthodox order of listing, several other<tei:lb/>innovations were proposed. New subfamilies were erected for Bagisara (Bagisarinae) and Ufeus<tei:lb/>(Ufeiinae). They are currently considered to be tribes of the Acontiinae and Noctuinae<tei:lb/>respectively (Franclemont &amp; Todd, 1983). The Cuculliinae was restricted to the genera related<tei:lb/>closely to Cucullia, the others being placed in the Amphipyrinae. The Acontiinae was restricted<tei:lb/>to Acontia, Tarachidia, Heliocontia [Spragueia] and Pseudalypia (the Acontiini of Franclemont<tei:lb/>&amp; Todd, 1983) while the remainder constituted the Lithacodiinae. The Amphipyrinae were<tei:lb/>divided into eight informal groups (three of cuculliines, three of amphipyrines and two<tei:lb/>mixtures). One of the mixed groups (number 6, Pseudanarta, Proxenus, Anorthodes, Platyper-<tei:lb/>igea, Xanthia, Sunira andAnathix) was considered to be possibly natural.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Catocalinae (including the Ophiderinae) was divided into six informal groups, which<tei:lb/>partially correlated with the groupings of Forbes (1954) (see also below) as follows:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1, Erebinae: Synedini;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2, Catocalinae: group 3; Erebinae: second miscellaneous series (part) (Tathorhynchus);</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3, Catocalinae: groups 1 and 2 (parts); Erebinae: Erebini and Panopodini (part);</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4, Catocalinae: groups 1, 2 and 4 (parts); Erebinae: Panopodini (part);</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5, Erebinae: first miscellaneous series;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>6, Erebinae: Anomiini and Scoliopterygini.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Beck (1960), in his study of the larvae of European noctuids, used a classification based upon<tei:lb/>Hampson but with several differences. The Noctuinae, Hadeninae and Zenobiinae [Amphipyri-<tei:lb/>nae] were treated as tribes of the Noctuinae (following Borner's (1953) classification of the<tei:lb/>adults). The Cuculliinae and Heliothidinae [Heliothinae] were recognised as distinct trifine<tei:lb/>subfamilies. The Rivulinae and Herminiinae were recognised as separate while the remaining<tei:lb/>ophiderines were classified in the Catocalinae. Two tribes were recognised in the last subfamily,</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p/>
         <tei:p>REVIEW OF THE HIGHER CLASSIFICATION OF THE NOCTUIDAE 195</tei:p>
         <tei:p>the Catocalini (with two informal groups: Laspeyrial Catocalal Mormonial Minucia; and Eucli-<tei:lb/>dimera [Callistege]IEctypa [Euclidia\ILygephila) and the monobasic Scoliopteryginae (S. libat-<tei:lb/>rix). The ophiderine Aediafunesta was established in a separate subfamily, the Aediinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Merzheevskaya (1967) generally accepted an arrangement that was very similar to that of<tei:lb/>Beck (1960). However, the Agrotinae [Noctuinae] were divided into two tribes, the Triphaenini<tei:lb/>[Noctuini] and the Agrotini. One unusual move transferred Amphipyra to the Cuculliinae,<tei:lb/>resulting in the renaming of the Amphipyrinae as the Zenobiinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Godfrey (1972), following Hampson's definition of the subfamily, examined the larvae of<tei:lb/>many of the North American Hadeninae and divided the subfamily into 21 informal groups.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The most recent study of noctuid larvae (Arnold, 1982) was novel in that it looked not at the<tei:lb/>morphology of the larvae but at their haematocytes. Four basic types of cells were identified:<tei:lb/>plasmatocytes (of five varieties: standard, nematoform, lamellar, podoform and vesicular),<tei:lb/>granulocytes, spherulocytes and oenocytoids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The species of Agaristinae, Pantheinae and Acronictinae examined all had only the basic cell<tei:lb/>types, in common with five arctiids, and this complement was interpreted as primitive. The<tei:lb/>Noctuinae fell into three natural groups, which showed little agreement with Forbes' (1954)<tei:lb/>divisions. The hadenines could also be divided into three groups on the basis of plasmatocyte<tei:lb/>type. The few cuculliines examined agreed with Forbes' subdivision; the three Cuculliini had<tei:lb/>only the basic complement while Lithophane hemina (Xylenini, Franclemont &amp; Todd, 1983)<tei:lb/>differed in having lamellar plasmatocytes. The Amphipyrinae proved to be heterogeneous while<tei:lb/>the two heliothidines [heliothines] shared the unusual feature of the absence of spherulocyte<tei:lb/>staining.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Generally, classifications based upon noctuid larvae have proved to be at least partially<tei:lb/>incongruent with the Hampsonian system, while the degree of conformity with the newer<tei:lb/>arrangement exemplified by Franclemont &amp; Todd (1983) remains to be seen. Larvae have<tei:lb/>proved to be potentially very useful in elucidating the higher classification of nymphalid<tei:lb/>butterflies (DeVries, Kitching &amp; Vane-Wright, in prep.; Kitching, 1983, in press) where<tei:lb/>previous systems based upon adult characters have been shown to be incorrect by varying<tei:lb/>amounts. It seems likely, therefore, that no satisfactory arrangement of the noctuid genera into<tei:lb/>tribes and subfamilies can be achieved without reference to the immature stages and much work<tei:lb/>still remains to be carried out in this field.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The main assault<tei:lb/>The gauntlet is thrown down</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tympanal organs: the development</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Workers in noctuid systematics, from Guenee to Hampson, relied largely upon gross morpho-<tei:lb/>logical structures to divide the group-wing venation, tibial spining, etc. The prime reason for the<tei:lb/>lack of study of other features, such as the arrangement of sutures and sclerites, was the presence<tei:lb/>of the characteristic scales of the Lepidoptera. Examination of surface structures would<tei:lb/>necessitate the removal of this vestiture, which was an anathema because of its effect on the<tei:lb/>appearance of cabinet specimens.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>However, around 1910, attitudes began to change. The use of genitalia revolutionised<tei:lb/>lepidopteran systematics at the generic and specific levels, but the system that was to have the<tei:lb/>greatest impact on the higher levels was based on the tympanum.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>It had been known for some time that such an organ existed (it was first referred to by Swinton,<tei:lb/>1877) but it was Forbes (1916) who initially drew attention to the possibility of using it to help<tei:lb/>determine taxonomic relationships. Forbes (1918) employed the form of the tympanic hood to<tei:lb/>argue for the resurrection of the Herminiinae as a subfamily separate from the Hypeninae.<tei:lb/>Tympanal structures were also employed to argue that the anomalous arctiid, Graphylesia, was<tei:lb/>in fact a noctuid, related distantly to certain acontiine [chloephorine] genera (Forbes, 1924).<tei:lb/>The physiology and anatomy of the noctuid tympanum was further investigated by Eggers (1919;<tei:lb/>1925).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>196 IAN J. KITCHING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Application</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The wider systematic implications of the tympanum in the Noctuidae were left to Richards<tei:lb/>(1932). Drawing upon the studies of Shepard (1930), Richards made a highly detailed compari-<tei:lb/>son of the morphology and evolution of the structure and divided the family as follows.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Herminiinae. Richards agreed with Forbes (1918) that this group was distinct from the<tei:lb/>remainder of the noctuids. The included genera all possessed a prespiracular tympanal hood (i.e.<tei:lb/>the first abdominal spiracle is posterior to and therefore outside the hood), as in the other<tei:lb/>noctuoid families (except the Nolidae and Agaristidae, see below), rather than a postspiracular<tei:lb/>hood (in which the spiracle is concealed beneath the hood). The former condition was<tei:lb/>considered to be primitive and led Richards to conclude that the Herminiinae were among the<tei:lb/>earliest offshoots from the noctuid lineage.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Rivulinae. Although the members of this rather ill-defined subfamily possessed the derived<tei:lb/>post-spiracular hood, Richards considered them to represent the most primitive noctuid<tei:lb/>subfamily. The remaining noctuid groups and the Herminiinae were interpreted as having been<tei:lb/>derived from the Rivulinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Rivula itself appeared to be the least specialised of all the Noctuidae examined by Richards,<tei:lb/>differing only slightly from the Hypsidae [Arctiidae: Aganainae] (although the latter has a<tei:lb/>prespiracular hood).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hypeninae. Richards found it immensely difficult to subdivide the large group of genera<tei:lb/>comprising the Hypeninae, Catocalinae and Erebinae [Ophiderinae]. He was able to distinguish<tei:lb/>the genera near Hypena from the remainder of the Erebinae (except Plusiodonta and Scoliop-<tei:lb/>teryx), considering them as a separate subfamily, the Hypeninae. (By way of an aside, Richards,<tei:lb/>in a footnote (10), stated that 'the immediate Hypena group and Scoliopteryx are the only<tei:lb/>quadrifids with lashed eyes outside the Plusiinae'. If this is true, then one can only conjecture as<tei:lb/>to why Hampson did not place at least the latter in the Plusiinae.) The Hypeninae were<tei:lb/>connected to the Rivulinae via Pleonectyptera [Hemeroplanis] and to more typical Erebinae via<tei:lb/>Pangrapta-Herminodes .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Three informal groups were recognised within the Hypeninae:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1, Pleonectyptera [Hemeroplanis], with an unspecialised tympanum;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2, the lashed-eyed hypenines, with a double pocket IV;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3, Hormoschista and its allies, with pocket IV yet further modified.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The erebine-catocaline complex. This group comprised Hampson's Catocalinae and Noc-<tei:lb/>tuinae. Richards, like Gaede (1913-39), considered the distinction based upon tibial spining to<tei:lb/>be completely artificial. However, unlike the latter author, Richards found he was able to divide<tei:lb/>the combined group, albeit based upon a limited sample of genera. Richards was very aware of<tei:lb/>the limitation this placed upon his conclusions.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The genera of the erebine-catocaline complex proved very diverse, falling into a number of<tei:lb/>relatively distinct groups which were connected by intermediate forms. Six such groups were<tei:lb/>recognised.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I. Pangrapta/Gabara/Herminodes group. This was the most primitive, from which the next<tei:lb/>group arose.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>II. AnomislCalpel Plusiodonta group. This was considered to be rather artificial, connecting<tei:lb/>the previous series to the 'higher' erebines. Alabama and Anomis were considered to be<tei:lb/>extreme developments, while Plusiodonta was tentatively placed here, although it had<tei:lb/>more in common with the Hypeninae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>III. Melipotis/Syneda [Drasteria] group. Derived from the last mentioned, this was the most<tei:lb/>well-defined group of erebines, with a characteristic tympanal membrane and nodular<tei:lb/>sclerite. It includes Leucanitis and Syneda [Drasteria], genera currently assigned to the</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>REVIEW OF THE HIGHER CLASSIFICATION OF THE NOCTUIDAE 197</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Catocalinae and Ophiderinae respectively. These genera had tympana that Richards<tei:lb/>considered to afford 'good evidence of the artificiality of any division on spines'.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>IV. EuparthenoslYrias [Metria]! Zale group. Characterised by an overhung or pouched pocket<tei:lb/>I, this group was considered to have given rise to the Stictopterinae and Plusiinae (see<tei:lb/>below).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>V. Catocalal Erebus [Ascalapha\IThysania group. Richards considered this group to be rather<tei:lb/>artificially separated from the last.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>VI. DoryodeslEudidia group. This group, comprised of mainstream Catocalinae, was con-<tei:lb/>sidered to be an independent derivative of group II.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Four genera were found to be very difficult to place: Scoliopteryx, Gonodonta, Noropsis<tei:lb/>[Diphthera] and Litoprosopus . The last of these was described as looking like 'a combination of a<tei:lb/>Notodontid and a Plusiid' and was highly anomalous.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Stictopterinae. Richards considered this subfamily to be derived from the Erebinae of group<tei:lb/>IV, and possibly to have given rise to the Plusiinae, 'for which they would serve as prototype'.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Plusiinae. This subfamily proved to be the most homogenous and distinct of the quadrifines. It<tei:lb/>was characterised by a double hood and a swollen area of the epimeron ventral to the tympanal<tei:lb/>membrane, which was the external manifestation of an enlarged pocket IV. (A similar bulge in<tei:lb/>other genera, notably the Herminiinae, is ventral to pocket IV.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euteliinae. This subfamily proved enigmatic. Generally, it was considered to be a develop-<tei:lb/>ment from the Erebinae, and would thus be placed near the Stictopterinae. However, the<tei:lb/>tympana of the euteliines have much in common with those of the Erastriini. Richards was<tei:lb/>undecided as to the position and affinities of the Euteliinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Erastriinae [Acontiinae]. Richards derived this subfamily from the lineage linking the<tei:lb/>Rivulinae and Hypeninae, and the Erebinae, via Eublemma [Eumicremma + Eublemma].<tei:lb/>From this group could be derived the acontiine [chloephorine]-sarrothripine series and the<tei:lb/>trifine subfamilies. As mentioned above, the Euteliinae could be placed here also.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Two tribes were recognised by Richards. The Erastriini, in which the alula is unmodified, and<tei:lb/>the Tarachini, a very homogeneous group in which the alula is enlarged and strongly sclerotised.<tei:lb/>The tympanal membrane is concealed by the alula and the hood is correspondingly reduced or<tei:lb/>absent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acontiinae [Chloephorinae]. This subfamily combined the characters of both erastriine tribes<tei:lb/>and was considered to be derived from the last subfamily.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Sarrothripinae. Richards agreed with Hampson by placing this group as a derivative of the<tei:lb/>last, with which it shares many characters, especially internally.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pantheinae. The relationships of this tympanally homogeneous subfamily were obscure to<tei:lb/>Richards. The form of the tympanum could be derived from that of the trifines, erastriines or<tei:lb/>even the erebines, and he was unable even tentatively to assign it a place on his phylogenetic<tei:lb/>tree.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The trifine subfamilies. These groups (Agrotinae [Noctuinae], Poliinae [Hadeninae], Cucul-<tei:lb/>liinae and Acronyctinae [Acronictinae + Amphipyrinae]) were not examined in detail but<tei:lb/>appeared to be highly similar. Richards considered them to be developments from the higher<tei:lb/>erastriines with which they share many internal features.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agaristidae. This family was considered to be derived from the Acronyctinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>198 IAN J. KITCHING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Nolidae. Richards concluded that this group did not belong in the Arctiidae, but was in fact<tei:lb/>very close to the Erastriinae, from which it could possibly be derived.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Richards synthesised his findings into a phylogenetic tree (Fig. 3). The arrangement, he<tei:lb/>concluded, was not substantially different from that of Hampson apart from the position of the<tei:lb/>Plusiinae, the unknown position of the Pantheinae and Euteliinae, and the division of the<tei:lb/>Catocalinae + Ophiderinae. However, it should be noted that there are several other major<tei:lb/>conflicts.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1. Hampson placed the Acontiinae [Chloephorinae] and Sarrothripinae between the Strictop-<tei:lb/>terinae and the Catocalinae whereas Richards considered them to be derivatives of the<tei:lb/>Erastriinae [Acontiinae] near the trifines.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2. The Rivulinae, noctuines [ophiderines] according to Hampson, were given subfamilial status<tei:lb/>and considered to be the most primitive noctuids by Richards.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3. The Herminiinae were separated from the Hypeninae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4. The nolids were associated with the 'higher' noctuids rather than with the arctiids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thus Richards' work provided evidence that cast serious doubt upon many of the Hampso-<tei:lb/>nian subfamilial relationships. Nevertheless, it was based, for the most part, on a single organ<tei:lb/>system, the components of which are not readily observable. It was also based upon observa-<tei:lb/>tions on only a very small percentage of the species of Noctuidae, whereas Hampson's<tei:lb/>arrangement was constructed after study of most of the then-known species. The influence that<tei:lb/>Richards' work was to have, and its potential was great, remained to be seen.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The cause is taken up</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Initial acceptance in the U.S.A.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The main proponent of the taxonomic use of tympanal organs in noctuid classification continued<tei:lb/>to be W. T. M. Forbes. However, even he was disinclined to change the accepted classification<tei:lb/>(i.e. Hampson's) to conform with the more recent evidence (cf . Forbes' work on the phylogeny<tei:lb/>of the butterfly subfamily Danainae, reviewed by Ackery &amp; Vane-Wright, 1984). Thus, in his<tei:lb/>study of the Lepidoptera of Barro Colorado Island (Forbes, 1939), he retained the nolids as a<tei:lb/>separate family (placed between the Euchromiidae: Ctenuchinae [Arctiidae: Ctenuchinae:<tei:lb/>Euchromiini] and the Arctiidae: Lithosiinae), despite noting that they possessed a tympanum<tei:lb/>similar to that of the Erastriinae [Acontiinae] . Similarly, the structure of the agaristid tympanum<tei:lb/>was mentioned as being 'of the Noctuid type' but the family status was retained and the group<tei:lb/>was left near the arctiids, between the Pericopidae [Arctiidae: Pericopinae] and the Lyman-<tei:lb/>triidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>McDunnough (1938) employed subfamily concepts (Table 15) based largely upon the work of<tei:lb/>Richards (1932) and the results of comparative studies of male genitalia, which were then being<tei:lb/>widely used following the pioneering work of Pierce (1909). The Pantheinae were associated<tei:lb/>with the Acronictinae at the head of the noctuids, a return to the older concepts of relationships<tei:lb/>rather than anything novel (but see below). The heliothines were separated from the agrotines<tei:lb/>(or phalaenines as McDunnough preferred to call them) and placed relatively distantly. The<tei:lb/>Catocalinae and Ophiderinae were considered to be one subfamily and the rivulines and<tei:lb/>herminiines were treated as distinct. The subfamily Hyblaeinae continued to be included in the<tei:lb/>noctuids, as the last listed. These three changes were revolutionary insofar as they were included<tei:lb/>in a major checklist for the first time and McDunnough's list was thus a step in the right direction .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Lepidoptera of New York and neighboring states</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The next stage in development was published by Forbes (1954). By including the results of the<tei:lb/>most recent studies on the Noctuidae, he was able to produce a classification that was the most<tei:lb/>detailed in its hierarchical structure since that of Tutt (1902) (Table 16). Based loosely upon<tei:lb/>Hampson, the noctuids were split into 14 subfamilies, many of which were further divided into<tei:lb/>tribes. In addition, and contrary to normal taxonomic practice, Forbes established 'miscel-</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>REVIEW OF THE HIGHER CLASSIFICATION OF THE NOCTUIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>199</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Plusiinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Nolidae Agaristidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Group VI Erebinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acronyctinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acontiinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tarachini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agrotinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Poliinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cuculliinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Sarrothripinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Main body Herminiinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Basal herminiine<tei:lb/>genera</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hypena group other</tei:p>
         <tei:p>hypenine<tei:lb/>genera</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pleonectyptera</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Rivulinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 3 Phylogenetic tree of the Noctuidae based upon characters of the tympanal organ (redrawn from<tei:lb/>Richards, 1932). Dashed lines indicate uncertain derivations, while the three arrows suggest three<tei:lb/>equally plausible positions for the subfamily Euteliinae: from the stictopterine-plusiine branch; from the<tei:lb/>group IV Erebinae; or from the Erastriini.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>200 IAN J. KITCHING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Table 15 Classification of the Phalaenidae [Noctuidae] employed by McDunnough (1938).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>AGARISTIDAE<tei:lb/>PHALAENIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pantheinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acronictinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Phalaeninae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hadeninae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cuculliinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Amphipyrinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Heliothinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acontiinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euteliinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Sarrothripinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Plusiinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Catocalinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hypeninae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Rivulinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Herminiinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hyblaeinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>laneous series' and 'isolated genera', which were not assigned to formally named groups within<tei:lb/>subfamilies.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agrotinae. Forbes used the family-group name 'Noctuidae' on the basis of '150 years of almost<tei:lb/>unchallenged use here and nowhere else'. However, he felt that to employ 'Noctuinae' for a<tei:lb/>subfamily would only invite confusion because of the previously diverse applications and so the<tei:lb/>term 'Agrotinae' was retained for the subfamily containing Agrotis, Euxoa and their allies. The<tei:lb/>Noctuinae of Hampson was termed the Erebinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Forbes divided the Agrotinae into two tribes. The first, the Heliothidini, was considered to be<tei:lb/>closely allied to Agrotis, although some authors (e.g. McDunnough, 1938) preferred to separate<tei:lb/>the two groups widely and derive the heliothines from the acronyctine tribe, the Pyrrhiini. The<tei:lb/>Agrotini was divided into three sections based largely upon genitalic characters. The main<tei:lb/>included genera in each were as follows:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>group I: Agrotis, Eucoptocnemis, Copablepheron;<tei:lb/>group 2: Peridroma, Pseudorthosia, Richia;<tei:lb/>group 3: Noctua [Xestia], Eurois, Actebia, Cerastis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The first and last were considered to be fairly homogeneous, despite previous minute subdivi-<tei:lb/>sion.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hadeninae. Defined primarily on the presence of hairy eyes, Forbes considered this group to<tei:lb/>be fairly homogeneous although he had reservations regarding the amaryllidaceous-feeding<tei:lb/>genus Xanthopastis . Three subgroups were recognised on the basis of superficial characters:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1. a Mamestra-type, with rough, mixed vestiture and heavy tufting;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2. a 'Taeniocampa'-type, with very smooth mixed vestiture, dull colouring and complete<tei:lb/>pattern; and</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3. a Leucania-type, with fine, smooth vestiture, striate pattern and a grass-feeding larva.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>However, the male genitalia did not agree with this division but instead suggested a large<tei:lb/>central homogeneous mass, from which individual genera and even species diverged. Also,<tei:lb/>many genera did not fit any of the above groups.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cuculliinae. Forbes considered this subfamily to be possibly polyphyletic, with two series of<tei:lb/>tribes being independently derived from the Acronyctinae [Amphipyrinae -I- Acronictinae].<tei:lb/>The first series (Cuculliini, Oncocnemidini and possibly the Psaphidini) were thought to be<tei:lb/>related to Catabena, Oxycnemis and some Stiriini, while the second series (Lithophanini,</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>REVIEW OF THE HIGHER CLASSIFICATION OF THE NOCTUIDAE 201</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Table 16 The classification of the Noctuidae proposed by Forbes (1954).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>NOCTUIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agrotinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Heliothidini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agrotini (divided into three informal groups)<tei:lb/>Hadeninae (divided into three informal groups)<tei:lb/>Cuculliinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cuculliini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Oncocnemidini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Psaphidini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cleocerini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lithophanini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Antitypini<tei:lb/>Acronyctinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>'First series'</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Septidini</tei:p>
