         <tei:p>Apameini (divided into two unnamed, intergrading subgroups)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Arzamini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Phlogophorini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dipterygiini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Prodeniini<tei:lb/>'Second series'</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Apatelini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Stiriini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eudryini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pyrrhiini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(the Acronyctinae also included many isolated and unplaced genera)<tei:lb/>Acontiinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eublemmini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Erastriini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acontiini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(plus several other unplaced genera)<tei:lb/>Euteliinae<tei:lb/>Sarrothripinae<tei:lb/>Pantheinae<tei:lb/>Plusiinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Catocalinae (divided into four unnamed groups)<tei:lb/>Erebinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Erebini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Panopodini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Synedini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Anomiini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>'First miscellaneous series'</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scoliopterygini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>'Second miscellaneous series'</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Third miscellaneous series'<tei:lb/>Hypenodinae<tei:lb/>Hypeninae<tei:lb/>Herminiinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cleocerini and Antitypini) were conceivably related to such genera as Andropolia, Rhizagrotis<tei:lb/>and some of the Septidini/ Apameini complex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Cuculliini comprised Cucullia only, and appeared to be closely related to the next, the<tei:lb/>Oncocnemidini, into which it intergraded in Europe. Containing six genera, the Psaphidini<tei:lb/>showed similarities to the last two tribes, as well as to the Lithophanini and the Antitypini. The<tei:lb/>Cleocerini contained only Cleoceris [Brachylomia] and Litholomia, while the Lithophanini,<tei:lb/>characterised by the presence of a well-developed digitus, was considered to be the dominant</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>202 IAN J. KITCHING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>group of cuculliines, with 17 included genera. Although the Antitypini formed a well-defined<tei:lb/>tribe in North America, Forbes was of the opinion that such was not the case in Europe.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acronyctinae [Acronictinae 4- Amphipyrinae]. Despite its considerable size and degree of<tei:lb/>homogeneity, Forbes was able to subdivide this subfamily into two series of six and four tribes<tei:lb/>each. In addition, there were many unplaced, isolated genera.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>First series. This group of tribes was polythetically defined by male genitalia with a normal<tei:lb/>corona, free pleurite with muscle-plate, lobed penicillus and a well-developed digitus. Six tribes<tei:lb/>were included: Septidini, Apameini (divided into two intergrading and unnamed groups),<tei:lb/>Arzamini, Phlogophorini, Dipterygiini and Prodeniini. In addition, eight isolated genera, which<tei:lb/>had some of the features of the Septidini, remained unplaced.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Second series. This group of tribes was characterised by the more or less general reduction or<tei:lb/>absence of a corona and digitus, an unlobed penicillus, no free ninth pleurite, a vinculum<tei:lb/>sometimes produced as a narrow strip, and larvae that are never borers or subterranean<tei:lb/>cutworms. Four tribes were recognised: Apatelini (equivalent to the most restrictive Acronicti-<tei:lb/>nae of previous authors), Stiriini (e.g. Stiria, Plagiomimicus) , Eudryini (Eudryas and Psycho-<tei:lb/>morphd) and Pyrrhiini (Pyrrhia and its allies). Three groups of isolated genera were also<tei:lb/>recognised:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(A) e.g. Cosmia, Amphipyra, with high-feeding, usually green, larvae;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(B) Proxenus and Anorthodes, with cryptically-coloured, brown larvae, feeding close to the<tei:lb/>ground or as a cutworm; and</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(C) Galgula, with an unknown larva, about which Forbes would not conjecture.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acontiinae. With regard to this subfamily, Forbes followed Richards (1932), but recognised<tei:lb/>three tribes, not two. The extra tribe, the Eublemmini, was erected to include Eublemma<tei:lb/>[Eumicremma] only which Richards considered to be a link with the deltoids. In addition, the<tei:lb/>Tarachini were renamed the Acontiini.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euteliinae. Containing three genera (Eutelia, Marathyssa and Paectes), this subfamily was<tei:lb/>considered to be homogeneous and was unchanged from previous works.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Sarrothripinae. Considered to intergrade with the Nolidae in the Old World, the Sarrothripi-<tei:lb/>nae were believed to be 'an offshoot of the ancestral Noctuid type' (cf. Richards, 1932).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pantheinae. This subfamily was considered to be generally well defined, although Raphia<tei:lb/>differed in its naked larva and in the hair on its eyes being microscopic.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Plusiinae. Despite being a distinctive subfamily, Forbes considered the Plusiinae might well<tei:lb/>be combined with the primarily Old World group, the Stictopterinae. In addition to the usual<tei:lb/>genera (Abrostola and Plusia s.l.), Forbes included Phyprosopus, because this aberrant genus<tei:lb/>would key out to this subfamily and a better position could not be suggested.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Catocalinae. Forbes recognised that the distinction between this subfamily and the Erebinae<tei:lb/>[Ophiderinae] broke down outside the Holarctic region but found it a useful concept within the<tei:lb/>North American fauna. On the basis of genitalic characters, the Catocalinae were divided into<tei:lb/>four relatively distinct groups, which were not formally named.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Erebinae. Forbes used Richards' analysis as a basis for his classification of this group. He<tei:lb/>agreed with Richards that all the other quadrifine subfamilies, bar possibly the Herminiinae,<tei:lb/>could be derived from it. Because the North American genera represented diverse elements and</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>REVIEW OF THE HIGHER CLASSIFICATION OF THE NOCTUIDAE 203</tei:p>
         <tei:p>any classification based upon these alone would be meaningless, Forbes chose to remove only<tei:lb/>five distinct groups as tribes and left the remainder in three 'miscellaneous series' corresponding<tei:lb/>to those groups to which they had been assigned by Richards.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Erebini. This tribe was characterised by such features as very short discal cells and distinctive<tei:lb/>tarsal spining and included Erebus [Ascalapha], Thysania and Bendis [Lesmone].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Panopodini. From the North American fauna, only Panopoda was included in this tribe.<tei:lb/>However, the group was much larger in the tropics, where Forbes suggested it might need<tei:lb/>subdivision. He also considered that the catocaline group 4 (Zale and Euparthenos) could<tei:lb/>be derived from a subgroup of the Panopodini.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Synedini. This tribe coincided with Richards' erebine-catocaline group III and, in Forbes<tei:lb/>opinion, was very homogeneous, with the exception of Phoberia and Hypocala.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Anomiini. This was another tribe Forbes considered to be well founded but for which he failed to<tei:lb/>elucidate the interrelationships within the subfamily. Consisting of Anomis and Alabama,<tei:lb/>the tribe corresponded to Richards' 'extreme development of group II'. Forbes also noted a<tei:lb/>possible affinity with the BagisaralElydnodes group of the Acronyctinae, and felt also that<tei:lb/>the genera Amyna and Xanthodes might belong in the Anomiini.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>'First miscellaneous series'. This group represented those genera of Richards' group II that<tei:lb/>lacked the enlarged alula of the Anomiini.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scoliopterygini. This erebine tribe (containing only Scoliopteryx libatrix) was characterised by<tei:lb/>strongly lashed eyes and a mixture of erebine and hypenine features.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>'Second miscellaneous series'. The genera comprising this series were interpreted as the most<tei:lb/>primitive erebines by Richards but Forbes considered them to grade into the first miscel-<tei:lb/>laneous series, via Hypsoropha.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>'Third miscellaneous series' . Approximately equivalent to Richards' Rivulinae , this group was a<tei:lb/>mixture of primitive erebines.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hypenodinae. This group was composed of the smallest of the noctuids and was characterised<tei:lb/>by the absence of ocelli (also missing in the sarrothripine Comachard). Forbes was uncertain<tei:lb/>whether the group deserved subfamilial or tribal rank.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hypeninae. After removal of the Hypenodinae and the Herminiinae from the deltoids, the<tei:lb/>residue was placed in the Hypeninae, distinguished by long labial palps and lashed eyes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Herminiinae. Forbes included 13 genera in this subfamily, which was characterised by a<tei:lb/>prespiracular tympanal hood.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The following were considered by Forbes (1960).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agaristidae. The great similarity between this family and the Noctuidae (they were 'hardly<tei:lb/>distinct from the Eudryas-group of the Noctuidae'; but see below) did not influence Forbes and<tei:lb/>he maintained the two as separate entities.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Nolidae. This family was dealt with by Franclemont, who considered it to be derived from the<tei:lb/>sarrothripine noctuids and linked to them in the Old World by such genera as Barasa. Thus, any<tei:lb/>resemblance to the Lithosiinae (Arctiidae) was convergent. Nevertheless, the Nolidae were<tei:lb/>allocated their time-honoured position between the lithosiine arctiids and the Euchromiidae<tei:lb/>[Arctiidae: Ctenuchiinae: Euchromiini].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The system of Forbes was generally adopted by Inoue &amp; Sugi (1958-61), although it differed<tei:lb/>in detail in several respects:</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>204 IAN J. KITCHING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1, the Heliothidinae [Heliothinae], Apatelinae and Cryphiinae [both Acronictinae] were<tei:lb/>elevated to subfamily status;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2, Forbes' informal groupings of hadenines were recognised as distinct tribes: the Poliini,<tei:lb/>Orthosiini and Leucaniini;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3, no subdivisions were used in the Amphipyrinae, Acontiinae or Catocalini (which also<tei:lb/>included Forbes' Erebinae);</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4, the Hypenodinae were not recognised.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In addition, the Sarrothripinae and Chloephorinae were merged as a single subfamily, the<tei:lb/>Nycteolinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This usage was important insofar as it represented the first occasion on which the new<tei:lb/>American classification had been applied to an Old World fauna.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tympanal organs in Europe</tei:p>
         <tei:p>While tympanal organs were having far-reaching consequences in noctuid taxonomy in North<tei:lb/>America, they were being virtually ignored on the other side of the Atlantic. Only Kiriakoff paid<tei:lb/>them any attention. In a series of 15 papers between 1948 and 1960, he studied many groups of<tei:lb/>the Noctuoidea, of which four are of direct relevance to the higher systematics of the Noctuidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The first (Kiriakoff, 1953) concerned the Hyblaeidae and will be considered further later.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The second (Kiriakoff, 1955) concluded that the Agaristidae were very close to the Noctuidae<tei:lb/>but separable on the basis of several structures, such as the pleural bulla (a large swelling at the<tei:lb/>base of the abdomen, visible externally).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Richards (1932) was uncertain whether the tympanal hood of the nolids was pre- or<tei:lb/>postspiracular, but Kiriakoff (1958) demonstrated the latter to be the case. He concurred with<tei:lb/>Richards and placed the nolids as part of the noctuid evolutionary line.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The final groups to be studied (Kiriakoff, 1960) were the herminiines, hypenines and<tei:lb/>rivulines. He agreed with Richards' distinction of the Herminiinae on the basis of the position of<tei:lb/>the tympanal hood but could not find any specific characters to allow either the separation of the<tei:lb/>Hypeninae from the Rivulinae or the differentiation of these two subfamilies from the<tei:lb/>erebine-catocaline complex. Characters such as the double pocket IV were considered to be<tei:lb/>unreliable because they 'occur in all the groups indiscriminantly'. As a result, and contrary to<tei:lb/>Richards, the Herminiinae rather than the Rivulinae were interpreted as the most primitive<tei:lb/>noctuids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Kiriakoff (1963) eventually went even further. He proposed a classification of the Noctuoidea<tei:lb/>based upon the 'reduced rank' system of Janse (1937-9). Endrosa [Setina], a lithosiine with an<tei:lb/>unusual tympanum, was given family status in the Noctuoidea, equivalent in rank to a more<tei:lb/>inclusive Noctuidae. This family was divided into two subfamilies, the Arctiinae and the<tei:lb/>Noctuinae. The former, characterised by a prespiracular hood and a noctuid-type tympanum,<tei:lb/>also contained, in addition to the infra-families Arctiidi and Lymantriidi, the Herminiini. Within<tei:lb/>the Noctuinae, three infra-families were recognised: the Nolidi, the Noctuidi and the Agaristidi.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Kiriakoff considered his classification superior to older schemes 'because the tympanic<tei:lb/>structures undoubtedly are the most significant single set of characters that can be found in the<tei:lb/>Lepidoptera'. However, this confidence was not shared by other lepidopterists, who treated the<tei:lb/>single character complex-based classification with scepticism. It was never adopted as a serious<tei:lb/>alternative.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Recent developments in the U.S.A.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The latest higher classification of North American Noctuidae was presented by Franclemont &amp;<tei:lb/>Todd (1983) (Table 17). Contrary to both Richards and Forbes, they consider the Herminiinae<tei:lb/>to be an advanced group of quadrifine noctuids, while the subfamilies closest to the ancestral<tei:lb/>stock of the Noctuidae are the Sarrothripinae and Acontiinae: Eustrotiini. Franclemont also<tei:lb/>recognises the very close similarity between the trifine subfamilies and would possibly advocate<tei:lb/>their amalgamation into a single subfamily, the Noctuinae. At most, perhaps two subfamilies</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>REVIEW OF THE HIGHER CLASSIFICATION OF THE NOCTUIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>205</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Table 17 The most recent classification of the Noctuidae, employed by Franclemont &amp; Todd (1983).<tei:lb/>The 'Unassociated genera' of Amphipyrinae are those the authors did not assign to a particular<tei:lb/>tribe.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>NOCTUIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Herminiinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Rivulinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hypenodinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hypeninae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Catocalinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Plusiinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Abrostolini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Plusiini<tei:lb/>Euteliinae<tei:lb/>Sarrothripinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Risobini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Sarrothripini<tei:lb/>Collomenini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Nolinae<tei:lb/>Acontiinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cydosiini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eustrotiini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eublemmini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acontiini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bagisarini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pantheinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acronictinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acronictini<tei:lb/>Bryophilini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agaristinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Amphipyrinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Apameini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Amphipyrini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Stiriini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cuculliinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hadeninae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Noctuinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Heliothinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Nocloini<tei:lb/>'Unassociated genera'</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Xylenini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Feraliini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Psaphidini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Oncocnemidini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cuculliini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hadenini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eriopygini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Glottulini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agrotini<tei:lb/>Aniclini<tei:lb/>Noctuini<tei:lb/>Ufeini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>[Heliothini]<tei:lb/>Grotellini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>could be recognised, the Noctuinae and the Acronictinae, the latter also including the<tei:lb/>pantheines.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Deltoids and Catocalinae. The deltoid subfamilies (Herminiinae, Hypeninae and Hypenodi-</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>206 IAN J. KITCHING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>nae) are largely unaltered, but there are many discrepancies with Forbes' classification<tei:lb/>regarding the remainder of the family. The Rivulinae represent the third miscellaneous series of<tei:lb/>Forbes' Erebinae, together with one genus from the second and three others. The remaining<tei:lb/>catocalines and ophiderines are combined into one large subfamily, the Catocalinae, which is<tei:lb/>not subdivided.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Plusiinae. The division of this subfamily follows Eichlin &amp; Cunningham's (1978) revision<tei:lb/>although their Argyrogrammini and Autographini are merged to form one tribe, the Plusiini.<tei:lb/>Phyprosopus is transferred to the Catocalinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euteliinae. This small subfamily is unaltered.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Sarrothripinae. Three tribes are recognised in this group. The Risobini comprises only<tei:lb/>Bailey a; the Sarrothripini contains Characoma, Nycteola and Iscadia; while the Collomenini<tei:lb/>includes Motya and Collomena (two genera not considered by Forbes).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Nolinae. Franclemont &amp; Todd include this erstwhile arctiid group in the Noctuidae and thus<tei:lb/>finally make one of the moves, which although mooted for decades, no-one had previously dared<tei:lb/>to perform.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acontiinae. In addition to the three tribes (Eublemmini, Eustrotiini (Erastriini in Forbes,<tei:lb/>1954) and Acontiini) previously employed, two more are also considered. The Cydosiini<tei:lb/>included only Cydosia, briefly discussed by Forbes under Xanthoptera [Thioptera], a genus of<tei:lb/>the Erastriini, while the Bagisarini included only Bagisara. This genus had been variously<tei:lb/>treated as an amphipyrine and an acontiine (the suggestion that it may belong in the latter<tei:lb/>subfamily was first made by Heinrich, 1926). Whereas Forbes treated Bagisara as an amphipy-<tei:lb/>rine (although as an 'isolated genus'), Franclemont &amp; Todd consider it to be an acontiine.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pantheinae. This is the last quadrifine subfamily listed. The Pantheinae are removed from<tei:lb/>their Hampsonian position (before the Plusiinae, a placing followed by Forbes) and put next to<tei:lb/>the trifine subfamily Acronictinae. It would thus seem that the classification concerning the<tei:lb/>relative positions of these two groups has come full-circle.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acronictinae. This subfamily is interpreted in the strict sense and is divided into two tribes, the<tei:lb/>Acronictini (Acronicta, Simyra and their allies, Forbes' Apatelini) and the Bryophilini, contain-<tei:lb/>ing only Cryphia, a genus unconsidered by Forbes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agaristinae. Despite Mosher (1916) and Turner (1920), only lip-service had been paid to the<tei:lb/>high degree of similarity between this group and the Amphipyrinae. The inclusion of the<tei:lb/>agaristines as a subfamily of the Noctuidae was, like the Nolinae, the first occasion on which this<tei:lb/>had occurred in a major checklist. It is hoped that the false link with the Arctiidae and the<tei:lb/>unnecessary family rank have finally been laid to rest.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Amphipyrinae. The largest trifine subfamily is divided into four tribes followed by a large<tei:lb/>group of 'unassociated genera'. The Apameini is approximately equivalent to the tribes<tei:lb/>comprising Forbes' 'first series' combined, but also includes some of the 'isolated genera'. The<tei:lb/>classification of the Stiriini follows Hogue (1963) and corresponds to Forbes' Stiriini except for<tei:lb/>the removal of Stiriodes to the Amphipyrini. Seven genera constitute the Nocloini, none of<tei:lb/>which were treated by Forbes. The Eudryini are transferred to the Agaristinae (which Forbes<tei:lb/>considered they resembled) while the Pyrrhiini are incorporated into the Heliothinae. Of the<tei:lb/>remaining 55 genera, 30 form the Amphipyrini and 25 are 'unassociated'.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cuculliinae. This subfamily is divided into five tribes. The Xylenini represents the combina-<tei:lb/>tion of Forbes' Cleocerini, Lithophanini and Antitypini. Feralia is removed from the Psaphidini</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>REVIEW OF THE HIGHER CLASSIFICATION OF THE NOCTUIDAE 207</tei:p>
         <tei:p>to a tribe of its own (the Feraliini). This former tribe, and the Oncocnemidini and the Cuculliini,<tei:lb/>are largely unchanged.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hadeninae. Unlike Forbes, Franclemont &amp; Todd divide this group into three tribes: the<tei:lb/>Hadenini, the Eriopygini and the Glottulini. However, these groups do not correspond to<tei:lb/>Forbes' informal sections. The Eriopygini consists of a series of genera related to Orthodes,<tei:lb/>Tricholita and Ulolonche, while the Glottulini contains only Xanthopastis , a genus about which<tei:lb/>Forbes was unsure.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Noctuinae. The heliothines are excluded from this subfamily and the remaining genera are<tei:lb/>split among four tribes. The first three, the Agrotini, the Aniclini and the Noctuini, correspond<tei:lb/>to the first, second and third sections respectively into which Forbes divided the subfamily. The<tei:lb/>fourth tribe, the Ufeini, contains only the aberrant genus Ufeus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Heliothinae. This subfamily comprises two tribes, most genera being included in the presumed<tei:lb/>Heliothini (the name is omitted). Following Hardwick (1970), Forbes' acronyctine tribe, the<tei:lb/>Pyrrhiini are also assigned here.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The second heliothine tribe, the Grotellini, contains only Grotella, Hemigrotella and Neo-<tei:lb/>grotella, none of which was considered by Forbes. These genera were omitted from<tei:lb/>the Heliothidinae [Heliothinae] by Hardwick (1970), who suggested that they belonged<tei:lb/>in the Stiriinae [Stiriini] near Stiriodes (a genus Franclemont &amp; Todd place in the Amphipy-<tei:lb/>rini).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This then is the latest classification of the Noctuidae. It was produced from the results of many<tei:lb/>studies and is highly commendable. However, it must only be considered a starting point and it<tei:lb/>remains to be seen how well it will stand up in the face of future studies of noctuids from other<tei:lb/>parts of the world. What noctuid systematists outside North America cannot afford to do is to<tei:lb/>bury their heads in the Hampsonian sand and ignore this higher classification.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Novel character complexes</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Scent brushes and hair pencils</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The presence of various brushes, hair pencils and coremata, presumed to be associated with<tei:lb/>disseminating pheromones, have long been known in the Noctuidae (e.g. Pierce, 1909). Varley<tei:lb/>(1962) reviewed the structure and function of the brush organs of a number of noctuids and,<tei:lb/>unlike Pierce (1909), considered these organs to be potentially of great taxonomic value and<tei:lb/>urged further investigation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Such a study was eventually carried out by Birch (1972), who described the scent-brushes of a<tei:lb/>number of trifine groups. In a second paper, Birch (1972ft) dealt with the relationship between<tei:lb/>chemistry and taxonomy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The brush-organs were found to be composed of five separate structures. Birch considered<tei:lb/>there to be a particular order in which these components were lost and from this evidence<tei:lb/>concluded that the brush-organs of the trifine noctuids had arisen only once and that if a species<tei:lb/>lacked them, then it must be because of subsequent loss. The Acronyctinae [Acronictinae] were<tei:lb/>also found to lack these organs but in their case, Birch believed that this was due to their having<tei:lb/>split from the trifine lineage before the brush-organs first arose. On the basis of the most varied<tei:lb/>structure, the Cuculliinae were considered to have diverged next, followed closely by the<tei:lb/>Noctuinae. Most genera of the latter subfamily then lost their brushes. The apex of the<tei:lb/>phylogenetic tree was composed of the hadenines and the amphipyrines, which were impossible<tei:lb/>to subdivide. Hence, despite being extremely critical of the Hampsonian subfamilies, Birch,<tei:lb/>too, eventually had to use them in his final analysis. He therefore avoided the most controversial<tei:lb/>aspect of his work, that is, that the brush-organs could have suggested groupings of genera that<tei:lb/>were considerably at variance with those currently accepted.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>208 IAN J. KITCHING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Compound eyes</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In an impressive study of the lepidopteran compound eye, Yagi &amp; Koyama (1963) examined<tei:lb/>several noctuid species. Three groups of genera were recognised. Group 1 comprised catoca-<tei:lb/>lines and ophiderines only, while group 2 included five trifines, a plusiine and a hypenine. The<tei:lb/>species in these two groups are all nocturnal. The third group comprised the diurnally-active<tei:lb/>genus Hyblaea. On the basis of eye structure, Yagi &amp; Koyama considered the hyblaeines (and<tei:lb/>also the agaristines) ought to be separated as distinct families (see also below).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This study, although superficial from the point of view of the Noctuidae, provided yet another<tei:lb/>means by which the higher classification of the Noctuidae might in future be tested.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A variation on the Sarrothripinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Most workers in noctuid systematics recognise the great similarity between the Sarrothripinae<tei:lb/>and the Chloephorinae, in such features as the bar-shaped retinaculum (Hampson, volume 11),<tei:lb/>pupae (Gardner, 19486) and tympanal organs (Richards, 1932). On several occasions, they had<tei:lb/>even been placed together in a separate family, the Hylophilidae (e.g. Staudinger &amp; Rebel,<tei:lb/>1901). Within the Hampsonian framework, the two groups were regarded as subfamilies of the<tei:lb/>Noctuidae, distinguished from each other on the basis of the presence or absence of tufts of<tei:lb/>raised scales in the fore wing cell.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>However, Mell (1943) considered the genera comprising the Sarrothripinae and the Wester-<tei:lb/>manniinae [Chloephorinae] not to be sufficiently distinct to be worth regarding as separate<tei:lb/>subfamilies. Nor did he consider that they warranted even tribal status. Instead, Mell divided the<tei:lb/>more-inclusive Sarrothripinae into eight tribes and one species group, thus:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1, Eligmini - Eligma, Selepa, Triorbis, Gadirtha, Lampothripa;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2, Sarrothripini - Sarrothripus [Nycteola], Bryophilopsis;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3, Risobini-Risoba;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4, Blenini- Blenina;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5, Hylophilini - Earias, Hylophilodes, Clethrophora, Hylophora [Pseudoips], Chloephora;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>6, Cymatophoropsiini - Cymatophoropsis;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>7, Ariolicini - Sinna, Gabala, Siglophora, Ariolica;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>8, Species-group Tatothripa-Tympanistes;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>9, Careini - Cam*, Nertobriga.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Of these, 2-4 contain only sarrothripines; 5, 7 and 9 only chloephorines; 1 is mainly<tei:lb/>sarrothripine with one chloephorine (Eligma); 8 also contains representatives of both<tei:lb/>(Tympanistes is the chloephorine); while 6 contains a genus currently assigned to the Ophi-<tei:lb/>derinae. Unfortunately, no comparison is possible between the tribes of Mell and those of<tei:lb/>Francelement &amp; Todd (1983) because there are no genera held in common except Sarrothripus<tei:lb/>[Nycteola].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This expanded concept of the Sarrothripinae was employed by Aubert &amp; Boursin (1953),<tei:lb/>although the impoverished European fauna resulted in only two tribes being required, which,<tei:lb/>perhaps conveniently, corresponded to the previously accepted groups of the Sarrothripinae (as<tei:lb/>Sarrothripini) and the Chloephorinae (as Benini, = Hylophilini sensu Mell). Probably because<tei:lb/>the genera are mostly tropical, Mell's divisions have been largely ignored, and their usefulness,<tei:lb/>if any, must await a world- wide reappraisal of the group.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mell (1943) also erected a new noctuid subfamily, the Camptolominae. This contained only<tei:lb/>Camptoloma, a genus that had until then been considered to be arctiid. Mell included it in the<tei:lb/>Noctuidae on the basis of fore wing venation, and considered it close to the hylophiline<tei:lb/>sarrothripines because of similarities in the genitalia and immature stages. Inoue &amp; Sugi<tei:lb/>(1958-61) considered the genus to be worthy of a separate family, while Nye (1975) and Inoue et<tei:lb/>al. (1982) place it in the Arctiinae. The systematic position of this genus remains in doubt but<tei:lb/>Inoue (pers. comm. to A. Watson) believes it to be more closely related to the Arctiidae than to<tei:lb/>the Noctuidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>REVIEW OF THE HIGHER CLASSIFICATION OF THE NOCTUIDAE 209</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The removal of Hyblaea</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The hyblaeines are small moths that superficially resemble stocky tortricids or miniature<tei:lb/>hypocalas (Noctuidae: Ophiderinae). On the basis of the latter resemblance, the group had long<tei:lb/>been considered to belong to the Noctuidae. Its position, as a subfamily of the Noctuidae, was<tei:lb/>virtually stabilised when it was accepted by Hampson. This was in spite of the well-developed<tei:lb/>maxillary palps, a feature unique in the Noctuidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The edict was first challenged by Comstock (1925) who considered the hyblaeines to be more<tei:lb/>closely related to the Thyrididae and placed the group accordingly after the pyraloids. The pupa<tei:lb/>was examined by Forbes (1933) and the supposed pyraloid affinities strengthened.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A thorough morphological study of the adult teak moth, Hyblaea puera, was performed by De<tei:lb/>Koning &amp; Roepke (1949). They rejected the noctuid status of the species on the basis of:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1, absence of tympanum;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2, presence of three-segmented maxillary palps;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3, presence of an unusual secondary sexual organ on the male hind-tibia;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4, a tridentate uncus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This last character agreed with the Thyatiridae (Pierce, 1909) but De Koning &amp; Roepke could<tei:lb/>not include Hyblaea in this family because of venational differences. They also disagreed with<tei:lb/>Forbes (1933) contention that Hyblaea was pyraloid, although they were unable to suggest an<tei:lb/>alternative position.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Kiriakoff (1953) also noted a tympanum to be lacking in Hyblaea and therefore could not<tei:lb/>include the genus in either the Noctuoidea or in the Pyraloidea. Kiriakoff also reappraised the<tei:lb/>other structural characters of the Hyblaeidae. Although the family had much in common with<tei:lb/>the Tortricoidea, he eventually decided it represented a new superfamily, the Hyblaeoidea,<tei:lb/>related to the Notodontoidea and the Noctuoidea ('dans la sous-cohorte des Noctuiformes') but<tei:lb/>which had diverged from the main stem before the development of the thoracic tympanal organ<tei:lb/>in the latter groups. Later (Kiriakoff, 1963), he changed his mind, placing the Hyblaeidae in the<tei:lb/>Tortricoidea, and concluding that the family had nothing to do with the Noctuiformes after all.<tei:lb/>Despite this, most authors continued to regard the hyblaeids as either a family near the<tei:lb/>Noctuidae (e.g. Inoue &amp; Sugi, 1958-61; Yagi &amp; Koyama, 1963) or as a subfamily thereof (e.g.<tei:lb/>Viette, 1961).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Brock (1971) also excluded the hyblaeids from the Pyraloidea, including them in a new<tei:lb/>superfamily, the Aegerioidea, together with the Aegeriidae and the Dudgeoneidae. Pinhey<tei:lb/>(1975) noted the transfer but retained the hyblaeids at the head of the Pyraloidea.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Although Common (1975) criticised some of Brock's conclusions, the Hyblaeidae were not<tei:lb/>mentioned. However, Nye (1975) considered the Dudgeoneidae and the Hyblaeidae as<tei:lb/>pyraloid. Until the early stages are better known, the exact position of the Hyblaeidae remains<tei:lb/>doubtful.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Diloba: full circle - and back again?</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The early history of the aberrant species Diloba caeruleocephala was briefly discussed above.<tei:lb/>Several shifts in its systematic position had left it in the Plusiinae (Hampson, volume 13).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Richards (1932) examined the tympanum and found it to be typical of the Acronyctinae<tei:lb/>[Acronictinae -I- Amphipyrinae] and particularly similar to that of Trachea. Beck (1960) also<tei:lb/>included Diloba in the Apatelinae [Acronictinae] although the larva was aberrant in no less than<tei:lb/>six characters. However, most authors continued to consider it as either a pantheine (e.g.<tei:lb/>Aubert &amp; Boursin, 1953; HesLop, 1960) or as a plusiine (South, 1961). Pierce &amp; Beirne (1941)<tei:lb/>alone placed the species in the Lymantriidae, on the basis of the male and female genitalia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Kiriakoff (1970) disagreed with Richards' (1932) conclusions, considering the tympanal organ<tei:lb/>of Diloba to be distinctly notodontid. However, Diloba differed from the Notodontidae in<tei:lb/>possessing 'a paired abdominal bulla operculated by the counter-tympanum, not unlike the<tei:lb/>structure found in the family Agaristidae' [Agaristinae]. Thus Kiriakoff found it necessary to<tei:lb/>place Diloba in the monobasic family, Dilobidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>210 IAN J. KITCHING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tarns (quoted in Varley, 1962, and pers. comm. to I. W. B. Nye, 1970) believed Diloba to be<tei:lb/>related to the cuculliine Psaphida. Minet (1982) reappraised the previous work on the<tei:lb/>tympanum and concluded that Richards (1932) had been correct in his interpretation and that<tei:lb/>Kiriakoff (1970) had been wrong. In addition, Minet (1982) suggested that Diloba fitted<tei:lb/>perfectly into the Cuculliinae (lashed eyes, obsolescent M 2 on the hindwing, cf. Hampson) and<tei:lb/>thus supported Tarns' contention. Additional characters from the immature stages were used to<tei:lb/>support the inclusion of Diloba in the Noctuidae: eggs with radial ribs from the micropyle; larva<tei:lb/>with a prothoracic gland produced 'vertically' (as opposed to 'transversely' as in the Notodonti-<tei:lb/>dae) and having only a single pair of MD setae in the last larval instar (although this last<tei:lb/>character is plesiomorphic and therefore 'n'est pas significatif). Minet did not apparently<tei:lb/>compare the genitalia of Diloba with those of cuculliines such as Psaphida.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Overall, however, the current consensus places Diloba either in the Notodontidae (a position<tei:lb/>followed by Kloet &amp; Hincks, 1972; Bretherton et al., 1979; Nye, 1975) or as a separate family<tei:lb/>(followed by Watson etal., 1980; Leraut, 1980).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>It would thus seem that, like the Hyblaeidae, the systematic position of Diloba is open to<tei:lb/>question yet. However, unlike the former, the problem of the affinities of Diloba is still firmly<tei:lb/>within the field of noctuid systematics.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The neglected arrangement<tei:lb/>Preamble</tei:p>
         <tei:p>By the 1920s, Hampson's system seemed to be the final word in noctuid higher classification.<tei:lb/>However, even before the dissatisfaction of workers such as Forbes set in, not all taxonomists<tei:lb/>were happy to accept the Hampsonian subfamilies. In particular, the amateur English lepi-<tei:lb/>dopterists rejected them, preferring to follow Meyrick, or even Guenee. After all, a new<tei:lb/>arrangement would have meant them re-ordering their collections. Eventually a classification<tei:lb/>arose that evolved into an arrangement of subfamilies which, although currently almost<tei:lb/>forgotten, bears much in common with the divisions of the Noctuidae employed recently by<tei:lb/>Franclemont &amp; Todd (1983).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The demise of the systems of Guenee, Staudinger &amp; Rebel and Tutt</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The early part of the twentieth century saw the virtual disappearance of the noctuid classification<tei:lb/>of Guenee (1852-4) and those derived directly from it.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In his Moths of the British Isles, South (1908-9) followed the division of the Noctuidae<tei:lb/>employed by Staudinger &amp; Rebel (1901). This survived until the revision by Edelsten &amp; Fletcher<tei:lb/>(South, 1961), when the classification of Hampson was substituted.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Following the death of Tutt in 1911, a supplement to his British Noctuae was produced by<tei:lb/>Turner (1926-48). Although he discussed the classifications of the noctuids used by Hampson<tei:lb/>and in 'Seitz', in order to be consistent with Tutt's earlier work, Turner employed the<tei:lb/>arrangement used therein, namely that of Guenee. Thus Tutt's classification of 1902 fell into<tei:lb/>disuse. It was eventually followed by that of Guenee; Turner's usage was its last.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The English 'amateur' system</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Origins</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In 1907, Kirby published his Butterflies and Moths of Europe. In this, he acknowledged the<tei:lb/>classification of Staudinger &amp; Rebel (1901) but preferred to use one of his own. This divided the<tei:lb/>Lepidoptera into 'macros' and 'micros'. The former was then further split into five 'superf ami-<tei:lb/>lies': Rhopalocera, Sphinges, Bombyces, Noctuae and Geometrae. Although Kirby removed<tei:lb/>the Cymatophoridae [Thyatiridae] from the Noctuae to the Bombyces (this heterogeneous<tei:lb/>group also contained the Nycteolidae [Sarrothripinae] and Chloephoridae [Chloephorinae]),<tei:lb/>the Noctuae still included the Brephidae [Geometridae: Archiearinae]. The remaining noctuids</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>REVIEW OF THE HIGHER CLASSIFICATION OF THE NOCTUIDAE 211</tei:p>
         <tei:p>were distributed among 18 subfamilies (Table 18), which appeared to have something in<tei:lb/>common with those of Herrich-Schaffer (1845) and part with those proposed by Grote in the<tei:lb/>1880s and 1890s (see Tables 5 and 7), but also included some apparent influence from Hampson.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Bombycoidae, a name which in various forms had previously been used to refer to several<tei:lb/>groups, here contained Diloba and the pantheines. These were followed by the Acronyctidae<tei:lb/>[Acronictinae] which, although it included Bryophila [Cryphia], omitted Arsilonche [Simyra]<tei:lb/>and Simyra. These last two genera were placed at the head of the subsequent group, the<tei:lb/>Orthosidae. This subfamily, which had previously been regarded as five (Leucaniidae, Caradri-<tei:lb/>nidae, Orthosiidae, Cerastidae, Amphipyridae; Herrich-Schaffer, 1845), consisted mainly of<tei:lb/>hadenines, cuculliines (e.g. Agrochola) and amphipyrines, with minor representation from the<tei:lb/>Acronictinae (e.g. Simyra) and Ophiderinae (Scoliopteryx).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Agrotidae, comprising mainly Agrotis (s.l.) and Triphaena [Noctua], was broadly<tei:lb/>equivalent to the Noctuinae, although it did include Brithys, a hadenine. The Hadeninae<tei:lb/>contained the balance of the hadenines and amphipyrines.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>There followed several small subfamilies. The Xylinidae (e.g. Xylina [Lithophane], Calocam-<tei:lb/>pa [Xylena]), Cleophanidae (e.g. Calophasia, Cleophana [Calophasia, part]) and Cuculliidae<tei:lb/>(Cucullia only) contained most of the present Cuculliinae, although the first also included<tei:lb/>Xylomiges [Egira] (Hadeninae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Euteliidae (cf. Eurhipiidae in the introduction to Kirby, 1907, and Table 18) and the<tei:lb/>Heliothidae corresponded to the present subfamilies of the same names (the latter included<tei:lb/>Pyrrhia and its relatives). The next subfamily, the Anartidae, conformed to the residue of<tei:lb/>Warren's (1906-14) Heliothidinae after the removal of the true heliothines and it may be that<tei:lb/>Warren took over the concept from Kirby and expanded it. The Anartidae included representa-<tei:lb/>tives of the Amphipyrinae (Euterpia [Enterpia], Heliaca [Panemeria]) , Noctuinae (Cyrebia),<tei:lb/>Hadeninae (Anarta) and Cuculliinae (Omia).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Plusiidae included Telesilla [Eucarta], as well as the usual genera, Abrostola and Plusia<tei:lb/>(s.l.), while the Calpidae contained only Calpe [Calyptra]. The Acontiidae, including Acontia<tei:lb/>[Tyta], Armada [Tarachepia] and Acontiola [Eustrotia and Ozarba], was a mixture of<tei:lb/>ophiderines and acontiines. Most of the remaining catocalines and ophiderines were divided<tei:lb/>between the Catocalidae (e.g. Catocala, Zethes, Aedia) and the Ophiusidae (e.g. Apopestes,<tei:lb/>Ophiusa [Lygephila]). These two groups also contradicted those that Kirby, in his introduction<tei:lb/>(Table 18), said he was going to use (Ophiusidae and Toxocampidae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Table 18 The subdivisions of the Noctuae [Noctuidae] employed by Kirby (1907).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>NOCTUAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bombycoidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acronyctidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Orthosidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agrotidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hadenidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Xylinidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cleophanidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cuculliidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eurhipiidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Heliothidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Anartidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Plusiidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Calpidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acontiidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ophiusidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Taxocampidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Noctuophalaenidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Deltoidae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Brephidae</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>212 IAN J. KITCHING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Noctuophalaenidae included the rest of the acontiines and the ophiderine, Rivula. The<tei:lb/>Noctuae finished with the Deltoidae (including the ophiderines Laspeyria and Parascotia) and<tei:lb/>the Brephidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Development</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The arrangement of Kirby (1907) formed the basis of the system adopted by Heslop (1945) in his<tei:lb/>checklist of British Lepidoptera. It should be noted that Heslop, like many other earlier authors<tei:lb/>of checklists and catalogues, employed no new research, relying entirely upon the studies of<tei:lb/>others. His arrangement of the various groups was probably governed as much by personal taste<tei:lb/>as it was by explicit characters. Whatever his reasons, Heslop, again like many of his<tei:lb/>predecessors and several workers subsequently, never published his argumentation, thus<tei:lb/>rendering it virtually immune from objective criticism.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The noctuids were classed in the superfamily Agrotides and, following Meyrick (1928),<tei:lb/>divided into two families, the Caradrinidae and the Plusiidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ten subfamilies were recognised in the Caradrinidae. Eight corresponded to those of Kirby:<tei:lb/>Mominae (Kirby 's Bombycoidae), Acronictinae (Acronyctidae), Hadeninae, Caradrininae<tei:lb/>(Orthosiidae), Xyleninae (Xylinidae and also including the Cleophanidae), Cuculliinae, Anarti-<tei:lb/>nae and Heliothinae. The Agrotidae was split into two groups, the Agrotinae and the<tei:lb/>Triphaeninae. The Euteliinae have no British representatives.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Plusiidae contained five subfamilies. The Catocalidae and Ophiusidae were combined<tei:lb/>under the Catocalinae, while the Acontiidae and Noctuophalaenidae merged to become the<tei:lb/>Eustrotiinae [Acontiinae]. The Deltoidae became the Hypeninae while the Plusiinae remained<tei:lb/>unaltered. Scoliopteryx was removed from the Orthosiidae and placed in a separate quadrifine<tei:lb/>subfamily, the Gonopterinae. The Brephidae, although listed after the Hypeninae, had been<tei:lb/>moved across to head the Geometridae as a subfamily of the Monoctenidae. In common with<tei:lb/>Kirby, Heslop placed the Westermanniinae [Chloephorinae] and Sarrothripinae, as subfamilies<tei:lb/>of the Hylophilidae, in the Bombyces.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Several changes were evident in the classification employed by Heslop (1960) in his revised<tei:lb/>checklist. Some subfamilies had been renamed as a result of considerable reassessment of the<tei:lb/>application of generic names that had been performed in the interim.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The superfamily was now known as the Noctuoidea, and the Caradrinidae as the Noctuidae.<tei:lb/>Similarly, the Triphaeninae had become the Noctuinae. The Hadeninae and Caradrininae had<tei:lb/>undergone extensive reassortment and had been divided into no less than seven subfamilies:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1, Hadeninae - those currently recognised hadenines, less the next two groups;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2, Orthosiinae - Orthosia and Panolis;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3, Leucaniinae - the hadenine wainscots;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4, Nonagriinae - the amphipyrine wainscots and Stilbia;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5, Caradrininae - Caradrina and its close relatives, Meristis and Laphygma [Spodoptera, part];</tei:p>
         <tei:p>6, Apameinae -Apamea, Luperina and their allies, including also Prodenia [Spodoptera, part] ;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>7, Amphipyrinae - the remaining amphipyrines, e.g. Hydraecia, Cosmia, Mormo.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Two series, 1-3 and 4-7, can be recognised as equivalent to the present Hadeninae and<tei:lb/>Amphipyrinae respectively.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Acronictinae became the Apatelinae and finally, the cuculliine section of Kirby's<tei:lb/>Caradrinidae (e.g. Antitype, Agrochola, Cirrhia) was removed and established as the Dasy-<tei:lb/>poliinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The second family of noctuoids was the Hylophilidae, finally recognised by Heslop as<tei:lb/>correctly belonging with the noctuids, and the third was the Plusiidae. The subfamilies of the<tei:lb/>latter group now largely agreed with those of Hampson, except that the Gonopterinae was<tei:lb/>retained. Consequently, the Pantheinae was moved into the Plusiidae from the Caradrinidae,<tei:lb/>and Parascotia and Laspeyria were transferred from the Hypeninae to the Ophiderinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Apart from combining the Xyleninae and the Dasypoliinae under the former name, the<tei:lb/>arrangement of Heslop (1960) was faithfully followed by Chalmers-Hunt (1962-8).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>REVIEW OF THE HIGHER CLASSIFICATION OF THE NOCTUIDAE 213</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Was Heslop on the right track?</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The most fascinating aspect to Heslop's (1960) classification of the Noctuidae is the degree to<tei:lb/>which it parallels that recently employed by Franclemont &amp; Todd (1983). The two are compared<tei:lb/>in Table 19, demonstrating the considerable concordance, especially in the trifine subfamilies.<tei:lb/>There are, however, several discrepancies, which ought to be discussed further.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The British deltoid fauna is impoverished relative to that in North America (13 species,<tei:lb/>excluding Laspeyria, as opposed to 82) and so it is not perhaps surprising that Heslop did not<tei:lb/>consider it necessary to divide the Hypeninae, particularly as the study of the tympanal organ<tei:lb/>had not been influential in British noctuid systematics.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Table 19 A comparison of the higher classifications of the Noctuidae proposed by Heslop (1960) and<tei:lb/>Franclemont &amp; Todd (1983).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Heslop</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Franclemont &amp; Todd</tei:p>
         <tei:p>PLUSIIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hypeninae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ophiderinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Catocalinae<tei:lb/>Plusiinae<tei:lb/>Eustrotiinae<tei:lb/>Pantheinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>[Nolidae (Bombycoidea)]<tei:lb/>HYLOPHILIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Sarrothripinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Westermanniinae<tei:lb/>NOCTUIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Apatelinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cuculliinae<tei:lb/>Xylenini j</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dasypoliinae I<tei:lb/>Amphipyrinae J<tei:lb/>Caradrininae I<tei:lb/>Apameinae j</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Nonagriinae I<tei:lb/>Leucaniinae \<tei:lb/>Orthosiinae I</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hadeninae<tei:lb/>Anartinae /</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Heliothinae<tei:lb/>Noctuinae<tei:lb/>Agrotinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>NOCTUIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Herminiinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hypenodinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hypeninae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Rivulinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Catocalinae (part)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Catocalinae (part)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Plusiinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acontiinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pantheinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euteliinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Nolinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Sarrothripinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acronictinae<tei:lb/>Agaristinae<tei:lb/>Cuculliinae: Cuculliini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cuculliinae: Xylenini<tei:lb/>Amphipyrinae: Amphipyrini<tei:lb/>Amphipyrinae: Apameini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hadeninae: Hadenini</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Heliothinae: Heliothini<tei:lb/>Noctuinae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Heslop also retained Hampson's division into Catocalinae and Ophiderinae, including in the<tei:lb/>latter, the Rivulinae, another subfamily recognised mainly on the basis of tympanal characters.<tei:lb/>Heslop's reasoning probably coincided with that of Forbes (1954) on the same subject.<tei:lb/>However, Heslop did separate Scoliopteryx into the Gonopterinae. Franclemont &amp; Todd<tei:lb/>included this genus in the Catocalinae. The Plusiinae, Acontiinae, Sarrothripinae and Acronic-<tei:lb/>tinae were recognised by both systems in equivalent terms (allowing for Heslop's inclusion of<tei:lb/>Telesilla [Eucarta] in the Plusiinae and his separation of the sarrothripines, together with the<tei:lb/>Westermanniinae [Chloephorinae], into the family Hylophilidae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Within the trifines, the amphipyrine genera were divided into four subfamilies by Heslop. Of</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>214 IAN J. KITCHING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>these, the Apameinae and the Nonagriinae, are approximately equal to Franclemont &amp; Todd's<tei:lb/>Apameini, although this tribe also includes Hydraecia, a genus Heslop placed in the Amphipyri-<tei:lb/>nae. The second two of Heslop's subfamilies, the Amphipyrinae and the Caradrininae, roughly<tei:lb/>equate to Franclemont &amp; Todd's Amphipyrini, with a few exceptions (e.g. Prodenia [Spodop-<tei:lb/>tera] litura, which is in Heslop's Apameinae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The cuculliine genera were placed by Heslop into three subfamilies. The Cuculliinae is<tei:lb/>equivalent to Franclemont &amp; Todd's Cuculliini, while the Dasypoliinae and Xyleninae com-<tei:lb/>bined approximate their Xylenini. Interestingly, iiJodia and Eupsilia are incorporated from the<tei:lb/>Xyleninae, the Dasypoliinae equates to Forbes' (1954) Antitypini. The residual xylenines are<tei:lb/>then equivalent to Forbes' Lithophanini.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Heslop divided the hadenines into four subfamilies, all of which are included in Franclemont<tei:lb/>&amp; Todd's Hadeninae: Hadenini. The two concepts of the subfamily Heliothinae agree although<tei:lb/>a more accurate equivalence would be between Heslop's Heliothinae and Franclemont &amp;<tei:lb/>Todd's Heliothinae: Heliothini.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>There are no North American representatives of those genera (Mesogona, Euschesis [Noctua,<tei:lb/>part], Noctua and Lampra [Noctua, part]) that Heslop placed in the Noctuinae, and thus his<tei:lb/>Agrotinae equates with the Noctuinae of Franclemont &amp; Todd. However, on nomenclatural<tei:lb/>grounds, the Noctuinae (or at least Noctua) would belong in the Noctuini of Franclemont &amp;<tei:lb/>Todd, which also includes several agrotines sensu Heslop. The two systems are therefore in<tei:lb/>disagreement. Forbes (1954) had already noticed this discrepancy between the European and<tei:lb/>American systems and considered the reason to be that 'European tradition has treated the<tei:lb/>whole group [Noctuinae] as a single genus, except a few species (not in fact closely related to<tei:lb/>each other) with yellow hindwings. There is no agreement [with his classification] as to this<tei:lb/>subdivision'.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>However, overall and considering that the two systems are based upon more or less exclusive<tei:lb/>faunas, the classifications of Heslop (1960) and Franclemont &amp; Todd (1983) are remarkably<tei:lb/>similar. It seems likely that a reassessment of the European fauna along the lines of that of North<tei:lb/>America would result in relatively few changes in subfamily/tribal placings with respect to<tei:lb/>Heslop's groupings. The inescapable conclusion is that the English amateur lepidopterists, in<tei:lb/>refusing to accept Hampson's system, and choosing to follow Kirby and Heslop instead, were<tei:lb/>more correct than perhaps they imagined.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Quo vadis, Noctua!<tei:lb/>Introduction</tei:p>
         <tei:p>That the higher classification of the Noctuidae is in disarray and in need of extensive re-<tei:lb/>evaluation is probably the only point on which all workers in the field agree. The Hampsonian<tei:lb/>system still maintains a considerable influence, despite many efforts to loosen its stranglehold,<tei:lb/>and in this respect very little advance has been made since 1920. However, current changes in<tei:lb/>attitudes probably mean that the days of the Hampsonian system per se are numbered, although<tei:lb/>there remains a vast amount of work to be done before an adequate replacement can be<tei:lb/>proposed.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>To this end, I will first consider the individual subfamilies, illuminating those areas where I<tei:lb/>consider future research could be most usefully directed. Secondly, I present an outline cladistic<tei:lb/>analysis of the higher classification of the Noctuidae. This should not be considered as a 'new<tei:lb/>system', but merely as the first step towards the production of one. I do not expect everyone (or<tei:lb/>even anyone) to agree with all of my interpretations and conclusions, but I hope the result will be<tei:lb/>to generate renewed interest in noctuid higher systematics.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The individual subfamilies</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Arctiidae: Aganainae. This group of moths has been consistently placed in the Arctiidae or<tei:lb/>else treated as a separate family closely related to the arctiids. Its importance regarding the<tei:lb/>higher systematics of the Noctuidae lies in its possible future transfer to that family.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>REVIEW OF THE HIGHER CLASSIFICATION OF THE NOCTUIDAE 215</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A relationship between the Noctuidae and the Aganainae was first tacitly suggested by<tei:lb/>Gardner (1941) on the basis of larval characters. The two current aganaine species that he<tei:lb/>examined, Hypsa [Asota\ alciphron and H. [Psephea]ficus , agree with the Noctuidae in having a<tei:lb/>single subventral seta on the meso- and metathorax (but see below). This contrasts with the<tei:lb/>bisetose condition found in the Arctiidae (the third 'aganaine' examined by Gardner, Digama<tei:lb/>hearseyana, which has a bisetose SV group, is currently placed in the Arctiinae). However,<tei:lb/>Gardner refrained from uniting the Noctuidae and Hypsidae [Aganainae], mainly because the<tei:lb/>latter lacked the ventral prothoracic gland found in the larvae of the former.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The discovery of the tymbal organ in the Arctiidae (Forbes &amp; Franclemont, 1957; Blest et al. ,<tei:lb/>1963) provided a potential apomorphy by which the family could be characterised. However, its<tei:lb/>occurrence is not universal. The structure is conspicuously absent in the aganaines and a few<tei:lb/>wasp-mimicking ctenuchines (A. Watson, pers. comm.). It can be argued that the loss of the<tei:lb/>tymbal organ (and also the tympanal organ in a few species) in the latter group is concurrent with<tei:lb/>the general reduction and high degree of modification of the thoracic sclerites that has occurred<tei:lb/>in order to produce the hymenopteran facies. Tymbal loss cannot be so convincingly argued for<tei:lb/>in the aganaines, especially as it is lacking in all genera and not just a few as in the Ctenuchinae.<tei:lb/>Thus, if the Arctiidae were to be redefined, employing the presence of the tymbal organ as a<tei:lb/>synapomorphy, then the Aganainae would have to be excluded. Franclemont &amp; Todd (1983)<tei:lb/>considered the aganaines to be 'probably an aberrant group of Noctuidae'. However, the<tei:lb/>aganaines have a pre-spiracular tympanal hood (Richards, 1932), and for this reason, I would<tei:lb/>choose to exclude them also from the Noctuidae (see Herminiinae below). The net result of<tei:lb/>these character interpretations would be the reinstatement of the Aganaidae as a separate<tei:lb/>family.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Herminiinae. Recognised as a distinct subfamily of noctuids by several pre-Hampsonian<tei:lb/>authors (e.g. Herrich-Schaffer, 1845; Grote, 1890; Smith, 1895), the Herminiinae were consi-<tei:lb/>dered by Hampson as part of the Hypeninae. Forbes (1918) resurrected the subfamily on the<tei:lb/>grounds of the possession of a pre-spiracular tympanal hood but the exact position of the<tei:lb/>Herminiinae within the Noctuidae remained unsettled.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The primitive position of the hood was used by Kiriakoff (1963) to argue for the exclusion of<tei:lb/>the Herminiinae from the Noctuidae and their placement within a more-inclusive 'Arctiinae'.<tei:lb/>This conclusion, however, is disputed. Richards (1932) did not consider that the Herminiinae<tei:lb/>were the most primitive noctuids, on the grounds that the 'basal group' of genera (Paraherminia<tei:lb/>[Paracolax] and Dercetis [Redectis]} , which were determined as the most primitive herminiines<tei:lb/>on other characters, had the spiracle 'slightly under (ventro-anterior to) the greatly reduced<tei:lb/>hood'. Thus, Richards implicitly treated the pre-spiracular hood in the herminiines as a<tei:lb/>character reversal, a position supported recently, without further elaboration, by Franclemont<tei:lb/>&amp; Todd (1983). I remain unconvinced and maintain that the herminiine pre-spiracular hood<tei:lb/>does represent the plesiomorphic state . If this is accepted , then , in the absence of other evidence<tei:lb/>to the contrary, the subfamily must be considered to form the sister-group of the remaining<tei:lb/>noctuids, and represents an analogous situation to that between the Arctiidae and Aganainae. If<tei:lb/>the Noctuidae were to be defined by the possession of a post-spiracular hood, the herminiines<tei:lb/>would have to be excluded. Characterisation of the resultant 'Herminiidae' would be possible on<tei:lb/>the basis of the swollen metepimeron ventral to pocket IV and perhaps the modifications of the<tei:lb/>forelegs and antennae in the males.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The results of a cladistic analysis under the alternative interpretation of polarity are less<tei:lb/>satisfactory. Following the strict cladistic approach to loss characters (Patterson, 1982),<tei:lb/>reversion of the tympanal hood to a pre-spiracular position could not be used to justify the<tei:lb/>monophyly of the Herminiinae and would also cast doubt on the use of the post-spiracular hood<tei:lb/>to characterise the family Noctuidae. If this latter character state was then rejected, we should<tei:lb/>be left in the extremely unsatisfactory position of having a family of 25,000 species completely<tei:lb/>uncharacterised.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cladistics aside, however, there is little doubt that a pre-spiracular hood is a good diagnostic<tei:lb/>character for recognising the herminiines (assuming that they can be differentiated from the</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>216 IAN J. KITCHING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>aganaines). Their separation from the other 'deltoid' groups has so far only been performed for<tei:lb/>the North American fauna.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Rivulinae. First proposed by Richards (1932), and then also including the genera currently<tei:lb/>assigned to the Hypenodinae (q.v.), the Rivulinae was interpreted as being the most primitive<tei:lb/>noctuid subfamily. However, it was also the most difficult for Richards to characterise and thus<tei:lb/>its status is highly questionable. Forbes (1954) rejected the Rivulinae, referring most of its<tei:lb/>genera to the Erebinae, as his third miscellaneous series. Likewise, Kiriakoff (1960) considered<tei:lb/>the Rivulinae to be insufficiently differentiated and placed both it and the Hypeninae in the<tei:lb/>Catocalinae-Erebinae complex. Recently, only Franclemont &amp; Todd (1983) have employed the<tei:lb/>group.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>At present, there appear to be no good characters on which to base the Rivulinae. Within the<tei:lb/>subfamily, Richards included those 'primitive' noctuids that could not be placed in either the<tei:lb/>Herminiinae or Hypeninae. The rivuline genera were thus characterised by a post-spiracular<tei:lb/>hood, unlashed eyes and short labial palps, characters that can all be interpreted as inapplicable<tei:lb/>at the level of universality relevant to the Rivulinae. Thus, the monophyly of the subfamily is<tei:lb/>unsubstantiated and it remains to be seen whether future studies will reveal any additional<tei:lb/>characters to suggest the Rivulinae is not a non-group.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hypenodinae. Like the preceding two subfamilies, the Hypenodinae had been recognised<tei:lb/>only in the North American fauna. Characterisation of the group is weak. Richards (1932)<tei:lb/>included the hypenodine genera in the Rivulinae, which, given the vague nature of that group, is<tei:lb/>unsatisfactory. Forbes (1954) defined the hypenodines primarily on the lack of ocelli but, as<tei:lb/>mentioned above, such a feature is inadmissable in a strict cladistic framework. Other unifying<tei:lb/>characters may exist and were hinted at by Forbes (the subfamily is 'rather homogeneous<tei:lb/>in other structures'; 1954: 381) but their exact nature is unknown. Overall, while it re-<tei:lb/>mains possible that the Hypenodinae is a real entity, at present it cannot be stated with<tei:lb/>certainty. Further work on other faunas is necessary before a definitive conclusion can be<tei:lb/>reached.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hypeninae. The Hypeninae was characterised by Hampson primarily by the hindwing vein M 2<tei:lb/>arising from well above the lower angle of the cell and running parallel to M 3 . Under such a<tei:lb/>definition, the subfamily also included the hypenodines and the herminiines.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Richards (1932) found the Hypeninae (s.str.) to be reasonably well characterised tympanally,<tei:lb/>and that, in addition, they possessed lashed eyes. The latter state is also found in the Plusiinae,<tei:lb/>Cuculliinae and the ophiderine Scoliopteryx. The tympanum and larvae of the last genus also<tei:lb/>resembled those of the Hypeninae (Richards, 1932: 14). Forbes (1954) added the character state<tei:lb/>of 'long and obliquely porrect [palps], normally twice as long as [the] head, with a rather long,<tei:lb/>porrect third segment'. Although it is probable that the Hypeninae, as restricted by Richards<tei:lb/>and Forbes, and employed recently by Franclemont &amp; Todd (1983), does represent a<tei:lb/>monophyletic unit (sensu Farris, 1974), more work remains to be done. Further studies of the<tei:lb/>other deltoid subfamilies are also required in order to clarify the interrelationships of these much<tei:lb/>underworked and neglected yet phylogenetically important noctuids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Catocalinae. The general consensus of opinion, faunal advantages notwithstanding, is that<tei:lb/>the division of this very large group of moths into the Catocalinae and the Ophiderinae, on the<tei:lb/>basis of mid-tibial spining, is entirely artificial and should be abandoned. However, the result of<tei:lb/>such action is a subfamily containing in excess of 10,000 named species, and probably many more<tei:lb/>awaiting discovery and description. Subdivision of this large group is therefore necessary. There<tei:lb/>are homogeneous groups of genera contained within the Catocalinae (s.l.); based around, for<tei:lb/>example, the genera Catocala, Erebus, Parallelia, Anomis and Drasteria, which can be defined<tei:lb/>by various structural features. However, the genera concerned represent only a very small<tei:lb/>proportion of the subfamily and the work required to completely order the Catocalinae (s.l.) is<tei:lb/>immense. Doubtless, further knowledge of the immature stages will prove invaluable - for</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>REVIEW OF THE HIGHER CLASSIFICATION OF THE NOCTUIDAE 217</tei:p>
         <tei:p>example, the Anomiini have malvaceous-feeding larvae; Forbes (1954: 367) - but so few are<tei:lb/>currently known that even their potential is largely unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>What is required is a piecemeal dissection of the group; the removal of the homogeneous<tei:lb/>generic groupings, perhaps as provisional tribes; followed by studies of the numerous isolated<tei:lb/>genera; leading finally to a coherent system. The task is so vast as to almost deny the possibility<tei:lb/>of success, especially when it is remembered that the Catocalinae may be polyphyletic with<tei:lb/>respect to the Hypeninae, Rivulinae, Hypenodinae and Acontiinae. Nevertheless, the attempt<tei:lb/>must be made, for the current state of knowledge, Richards' and Forbes' work on the North<tei:lb/>American fauna aside, is negligible.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Plusiinae. Of this subfamily, Richards (1932) stated that 'this is the most homogeneous and<tei:lb/>distinct of all the quadrifid groups'. Certainly, the plusiines have been recognised from the very<tei:lb/>earliest days of noctuid systematics as a natural group, but even so, their separation from the<tei:lb/>other subfamilies has been difficult. To Hampson, the plusiines were the lashed-eyed, non-<tei:lb/>deltoid, quadrifine noctuids. However, as previously noted, exceptions to this rule exist. Both<tei:lb/>Scoliopteryx libatrix and Phyprosopus callitrichoides have lashed eyes, while the eyes of the<tei:lb/>plusiine genus Pseudeva 'do not appear to be lashed' (McDunnough, 1944: 213).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Mosher (1916) found that the pupae of the Plusiinae showed a number of differences from<tei:lb/>those of other noctuids, most notably in the position of the labrum and the ventral extension of<tei:lb/>the wings and proboscis beyond the posterior margin of abdominal segment 4. The Plusiinae<tei:lb/>were further characterised by Richards (1932), who discovered that its members possessed a<tei:lb/>double tympanic hood and a swollen metepimeron formed by a greatly enlarged pocket IV.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Recently, Eichlin &amp; Cunningham (1978) proposed three tribes within the Plusiinae. Of these,<tei:lb/>the Abrostolini is the best candidate for monophyly, based on the form of the clavus in the male<tei:lb/>genitalia. The Argyrogrammini is demonstrably paraphyletic, while there are doubts as to the<tei:lb/>monophyly of the Plusiini (Eichlin &amp; Cunningham's 'Autographini') because it is primarily<tei:lb/>based on a character loss (absence of prolegs on abdominal segments 3 and 4). However, this is<tei:lb/>perhaps excusable given that the authors did not propose a cladistic classification. All three<tei:lb/>tribes may yet prove to be monophyletic but the study needs to be extended to the tropical<tei:lb/>faunas before this can be confirmed.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>As to the position of the subfamily within the Noctuidae, the Plusiinae lack the proposed<tei:lb/>apomorphies of the Catocalinae (the fused pleural sclerite, J. D. Lafontaine, pers. comm.; and<tei:lb/>the bloom on the pupa, Mosher, 1916) and so it is likely that their affinities will prove not to be<tei:lb/>with that subfamily. It is possible that the plusiines will be demonstrated to be related to certain<tei:lb/>trifine groups, possibly parts of the Cuculliinae, Amphipyrinae or Heliothinae (see also below),<tei:lb/>but this is presently speculative.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Stictopterinae. Hampson characterised this subfamily primarily by the simplified female<tei:lb/>frenulum (the frequently used description 'single' is misleading, as the frenulum in female<tei:lb/>strictopterines often consists of more than one bristle, which are closely appressed and very<tei:lb/>difficult to discern; A. H. Hayes, pers. comm.) and the presence of tufts of raised scales in the<tei:lb/>forewing cell. Richards (1932) considered the stictopterines to be very close to the plusiines but<tei:lb/>he only examined two species of the genus Stictoptera (S. melanistis, from the Old World, and S.<tei:lb/>clara, a Neotropical species that should be referred to a separate genus; J. D. Holloway, pers.<tei:lb/>comm.). Both were found to possess a tympanal hood with a ventral second lobe. In S.<tei:lb/>melanistis, this lobe was large enough to give the impression of a double tympanal hood, similar<tei:lb/>to that found in the Plusiinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The lack of stictopterines in North America has resulted in very little structural information<tei:lb/>being collected for the group (5. clara probably never reaches north of Mexico and Cuba,<tei:lb/>despite a paratype of S. phryganealis [a synonym of 5. clara] in the BMNH bearing the locality<tei:lb/>'West Coast of America'. This designation of Walker's often meant the west coast of Central<tei:lb/>America, or even the Galapagos Islands; Hayes, 1975: 165-7). This situation will be partially<tei:lb/>alleviated in a forthcoming revision of the Bornean stictopterines by J. D. Holloway. Neverthe-<tei:lb/>less, further study is required to ascertain the interrelationships of the genera and the position of</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>218 IAN J. KITCHING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>the subfamily within the Noctuidae. It is likely that the Stictopterinae will prove to be closely<tei:lb/>related to the Plusiinae, but whether it represents the sister-group of the latter remains to be<tei:lb/>demonstrated conclusively.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Euteliinae. Unlike many other noctuid subfamilies, several good apomorphies are known for<tei:lb/>the Euteliinae. However, none of these occurs in the morphology of either the tympanal organs<tei:lb/>or the larvae. Richards (1932) found that the tympana of the euteliines could be derived from<tei:lb/>either the catocaline (s.l.) or the acontiine types and he was unable to place them on his<tei:lb/>phylogenetic tree (Fig. 3). Similarly, Gardner (1948a) discovered no unifying characters in the<tei:lb/>larvae. In contrast, he (Gardner, 19486) found a combination of characters in the pupae that<tei:lb/>sharply defined the Euteliinae, of which the complete lack of a cremaster was the most<tei:lb/>characteristic (although the cremaster is also absent in the Sarrothripinae and Chloephorinae;<tei:lb/>Mosher, 1916; Gardner, 19486). Forbes (1954) noted that the larvae were almost completely<tei:lb/>restricted in their foodplants to members of the Anacardiaceae (although some feed on<tei:lb/>Combretaceae and Hamamelidaceae; Mell, 1943) and that the adults typically 'rest with the fore<tei:lb/>wings crumpled and partly rolled about the hind wings, and standing out obliquely to the<tei:lb/>strongly upcurved abdomen'.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The subfamily is probably monophyletic on the basis of the above characters and other, as yet<tei:lb/>undescribed, structural features (J. D. Holloway, pers. comm.). The problem of where the<tei:lb/>Euteliinae fit within the Noctuidae remains, however. The reduced female frenulum could<tei:lb/>represent a synapomorphy linking the euteliines and stictopterines, but as a loss character, it<tei:lb/>does not form very strong evidence. Similarly, the lack of a cremaster, a feature also shared with<tei:lb/>the Sarrothripinae, Chloephorinae and possibly the Nolinae is also weak. Otherwise, the<tei:lb/>euteliines are very distinct and their interrelationships with other noctuid groups are far from<tei:lb/>clear.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Chloephorinae. With the transfer of Bagisara to the Acontiinae (Heinrich, 1926) or Amphipy-<tei:lb/>rinae (Forbes, 1954), and Ipimorpha to the Amphipyrinae (Forbes, 1954), the Chloephorinae<tei:lb/>ceased to be represented in the North American fauna. Consequently, little is known of the<tei:lb/>morphology of the group. Richards (1932) found the chloephorines combined the characters of<tei:lb/>both the acontiine tribes (Erastriini [Eustrotiini] and Tarachini [Acontiini] and believed the<tei:lb/>group to be derived from the higher Acontiinae. Mell (1943) considered the Chloephorinae to<tei:lb/>be indistinct from the Sarrothripinae and treated the two groups as a single subfamily. A study of<tei:lb/>the larvae led Gardner (1946; 1948) to disperse the genera of chloephorines widely among his<tei:lb/>noctuid groups but subsequent examination of the pupae and cocoons (Gardner, 19486) caused<tei:lb/>him to revise his decision. He finally placed all the chloephorines in a single group near the<tei:lb/>sarrothripines, although he considered Acontia [Xanthodes] to perhaps belong elsewhere.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>There appears to be little doubt now that the Chloephorinae is very closely related to the<tei:lb/>Sarrothripinae. They share such probable apomorphies as a bar-shaped retinaculum in the<tei:lb/>males and the characteristic boat-shaped cocoon. Whether the Chloephorinae deserves sub-<tei:lb/>familial rank (based at present on the lack of the tufts of raised scales in the fore-wing cell found<tei:lb/>in the Sarrothripinae - not only an absence but also a highly homoplasious character in that<tei:lb/>similar tufts occur in the nolines and stictopterines) or merely tribal rank within the Sarrothripi-<tei:lb/>nae, or whether, as Mell (1943) proposed, the two-way division itself is artificial and should be<tei:lb/>replaced, is as yet debatable.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Sarrothripinae. This subfamily was separated from the last by Hampson on the basis of the<tei:lb/>presence of raised scales in the forewing cell. Richards (1932) found that the Sarrothripinae and<tei:lb/>Chloephorinae were tympanally very close and, like Hampson, considered the former to be<tei:lb/>derived from the latter. Gardner (19486) could find only minor differences between the two<tei:lb/>subfamilies while Forbes (1954) suggested that the Sarrothripinae intergraded in the Old World<tei:lb/>with the Nolinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Apart from Mell's (1943) subdivision, the Sarrothripinae had always been treated as a single<tei:lb/>homogeneous entity. However, Franclemont &amp; Todd (1983) divided the subfamily into three</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>REVIEW OF THE HIGHER CLASSIFICATION OF THE NOCTUIDAE 219</tei:p>
         <tei:p>tribes: the Risobini, the Sarrothripini and the Collomenini. Forbes (1954) considered Baileya<tei:lb/>(the sole member of the Risobini) to be totally isolated within the North American fauna and<tei:lb/>most closely allied to the Old World Risoba. The larvae of both genera were said to resemble<tei:lb/>those of the Euteliinae and might prove to form some sort of link between the two groups. The<tei:lb/>justification of the Collomenini is not clear. The two constituent genera (Collomena and Motyd)<tei:lb/>were not dealt with by either Mell or Forbes, and Franclemont &amp; Todd (1983) do not give any<tei:lb/>reasons for employing the tribe.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Nolinae. The Nolinae also has affinities with the Sarrothripinae. Forbes (1960) derived the<tei:lb/>former from the latter, while Richards (1932) (Fig. 3) preferred an independent development<tei:lb/>from the Acontiinae. However, the boat-shaped cocoon of the nolines, together with tufted<tei:lb/>setae (similar to those found in certain sarrothripines; Forbes, 1960: 52) point towards a<tei:lb/>relationship with the Sarrothripinae, and hence the Chloephorinae. There appears to be a<tei:lb/>potentially monophyletic group of three subfamilies, which may also possibly be related to the<tei:lb/>euteliines, through the Risobini. However, such a relationship is as yet largely unverified.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acontiinae. This subfamily was Hampson's least well-defined group as adults, falling as it did<tei:lb/>across the trifine-quadrifine boundary. However, he did note that 'the larvae of such as are<tei:lb/>known [have] the anterior [pair of] prolegs aborted, which is the essential distinction between<tei:lb/>the two subfamilies' [Acontiinae and Amphipyrinae + Acronictinae]. This character was of<tei:lb/>limited use, however, because so few acontiine larvae were known at the time, and reduction of<tei:lb/>the anterior prolegs is widespread in other noctuid subfamilies. Also, there are several<tei:lb/>acontiines (e.g. Neoerastria [Homophoberia]) in which all the prolegs are present (Forbes, 1954:<tei:lb/>270).</tei:p>
