         <tei:p>Richards (1932: 23) considered the acontiines 'to have been derived from some point between<tei:lb/>the Rivulinae and Hypeninae with Eublemma [Eumicremma] as the connecting link' (but see<tei:lb/>Fig. 3), and which then gave rise to the sarrothripine-chloephorine series, the Nolinae, the<tei:lb/>trifine subfamilies and the Agaristinae. The Acontiinae itself was divided into three sections:<tei:lb/>Eublemma [Eumicremma], the Erastriini [Eustrotiini] and the Tarachini [Acontiini]. Of the two<tei:lb/>tribes, probably only the second is monophyletic on the basis of the enlarged, chitinised alula.<tei:lb/>The Eustrotiini was characterised by the lack of such an alula and is therefore undoubtedly at<tei:lb/>least paraphyletic.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Forbes (1954) characterised the Eublemmini (Eublemma [Eumicremma]) using probable<tei:lb/>plesiomorphies ('pocket IV double as in the deltoids, hood and alula normal, no corona or<tei:lb/>penicillus' [on the valve of the male genitalia]) and did not improve upon the definition of the<tei:lb/>Erastriini [Eustrotiini]. Franclemont &amp; Todd (1983) largely accepted Richards' and Forbes'<tei:lb/>classification but employed two additional monobasic tribes, the Cydosiini and the Bagisarini,<tei:lb/>erected to contain two presumably, somewhat aberrant genera.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The higher classification of the Acontiinae leaves much to be desired. Only the Acontiini and<tei:lb/>the monobasic tribes are likely to be monophyletic. The Eustrotiini appears to represent a<tei:lb/>heterogeneous assemblage of genera that do not fit any of the other tribes. However, the crucial<tei:lb/>position of the subfamily in understanding the higher systematics of the Noctuidae as a whole<tei:lb/>means that a thorough (cladistic) analysis should be accorded high priority.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pantheinae. As adults, apart from dubious differences in hindwing venation, the members of<tei:lb/>the Pantheinae share the same Hampsonian defining characters as the Hadeninae: unspined<tei:lb/>tibiae and hairy eyes. The larvae, however, are quite different, being clothed, except for Raphia,<tei:lb/>in dense tufts of secondary setae on the body and head. In the latter respect, the Pantheinae<tei:lb/>differ from the Acronictinae. Richards (1932) found them tympanally very homogeneous but<tei:lb/>highly isolated from the rest of the noctuids; so much so that he was unable to even tentatively<tei:lb/>assign them a place on his phylogenetic tree. Forbes (1954) also noted the well-defined nature of<tei:lb/>the Pantheinae, although he had reservations regarding Raphia. This genus corresponded to the<tei:lb/>other pantheines in its tympanum, wing venation and general facies, but differed in the<tei:lb/>microscopic hair on the eyes and the larva lacking secondary setae. Nye (1975), following</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>220 IAN J. KITCHING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hampson, placed Raphia in the Ophiderinae. Raphia may belong in the Panth.einae, but it could<tei:lb/>equally belong elsewhere and only a thorough understanding of the rest of the family will finally<tei:lb/>resolve the question.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Franclemont &amp; Todd (1983) follow Forbes (1954) but also suggest the possibility of merging<tei:lb/>the Pantheinae and Acronictinae. If Richards (1932) were correct regarding the tympanal<tei:lb/>structure of the two groups, then such a move would be premature, which is not to rule it out.<tei:lb/>The two subfamilies were long considered closely related (e.g. Smith &amp; Dyar, 1898) and the<tei:lb/>presence of secondary setae in the larvae may be a synapomorphy. However, Mosher (1916)<tei:lb/>noted that the pupa of Charadra deridens (the only species examined) was more arctiid than<tei:lb/>noctuid, in the shape of the body, the presence of setae arranged around the scars of the larval<tei:lb/>verrucae, the absence of an epicranial suture and in the labial palps and prothoracic femora<tei:lb/>being visible. However, the cremaster is more noctuid than arctiid, in being long and provided<tei:lb/>with hooked setae. Additionally, the pantheines have never been recorded as possessing tymbal<tei:lb/>organs. The sum total of these characters, together with Mosher's highly restricted sample,<tei:lb/>suggest that, until further information has been gathered, the pantheines are best left in the<tei:lb/>Noctuidae. Their position with regard to the other subfamilies, however, remains unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acronictinae. The Acronictinae is the first of the trifine subfamilies, all of which are highly<tei:lb/>uniform structurally. This has resulted in much confusion in their classification and has led to an<tei:lb/>over-reliance upon superficial characters (hairy/lashed eyes, spined tibiae). However, some<tei:lb/>order can be discerned within the trifines and one group of genera that has long been recognised<tei:lb/>as a distinctive subgroup is the Acronictinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Originally, the acronictines were distinguished by the presence of secondary setae on the body<tei:lb/>of the larvae. The subsequent inclusion of the bryophilines confused matters, because the larvae<tei:lb/>of these genera possess only long, primary setae. Hampson placed no emphasis on larval<tei:lb/>vestiture and included the acronictines, together with the amphipyrines and certain heliothines<tei:lb/>in a more inclusive 'Acronyctinae', where they have generally remained.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gardner (1946a) distinguished the acronictines as his group AI. He also included the<tei:lb/>pantheine Diphthera [Trichosea] champa; the amphipyrine Cetola dentata and the ophiderine<tei:lb/>Thiacidas postica (this genus appears superficially to resemble Raphia and may thus be better<tei:lb/>placed in the Pantheinae - assuming Raphia belongs in that subfamily). Examination of the<tei:lb/>pupae led Gardner (1948ft) to exclude Cetola from the Acronictinae and he placed it instead in<tei:lb/>the Amphipyrinae. Mosher (1916) found the pupae to be of little use in distinguishing the<tei:lb/>Acronictinae; so much so, that she also included an amphipyrine (Achatodes) and three<tei:lb/>catocalines (s.l.) (Homopyralis [Metalectra] , Anomis and Plusiodonta) . However, she was well<tei:lb/>aware of the unnatural nature of this grouping.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Forbes (1954) followed Hampson and treated the acronictines as a tribe (the Apatelini) within<tei:lb/>his second series of 'Acronyctinae', but the trend was reversed by Franclemont &amp; Todd (1983).<tei:lb/>They reinstated the Acronictinae as a separate subfamily, containing two tribes, the Acronictini<tei:lb/>and the Bryophilini. As mentioned above, Franclemont suggested that the trifine noctuids might<tei:lb/>be better treated as comprising only two subfamilies: the Acronictinae (including the Pan-<tei:lb/>theinae) and the Noctuinae (comprising the remainder). Unfortunately, he did not elaborate on<tei:lb/>his reasoning.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Acronictinae, as restricted by Franclemont &amp; Todd, probably represents a monophyletic<tei:lb/>unit but its limits are presently poorly defined. Whether it indeed is related to the Pantheinae, or<tei:lb/>is a convergent offshoot from somewhere within the Amphipyrinae, remains to be discovered.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Agaristinae. For a long time, these brightly-coloured, largely diurnal and aposematic moths<tei:lb/>were accorded family rank near the Arctiidae. However, Mosher (1916) could not discover any<tei:lb/>differences in the pupae to distinguish the agaristines from the Noctuidae and thus placed them<tei:lb/>in the latter as a subfamily. Richards (1932) found the agaristine tympanal organ to be similar to<tei:lb/>those of the Acronyctinae [Acronictinae + Amphipyrinae], although the counter-tympanal<tei:lb/>cavities of the agaristines were much enlarged. Nevertheless, he retained the family status of the<tei:lb/>group and considered the agaristines to be derived from the Acronyctinae (Fig. 3).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>REVIEW OF THE HIGHER CLASSIFICATION OF THE NOCTUIDAE 221</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gardner (1946ft) examined two agaristine genera (Aegocera and Eusemia [Episteme]) and<tei:lb/>placed them in his group AVI, together with Callyna (Amphipyrinae), Tiracola (Hadeninae)<tei:lb/>and Churia (Chloephorinae). In his subfamily summaries, Gardner (19480) listed the Agaristi-<tei:lb/>nae between the Noctuinae and the Cuculliinae, suggesting that he considered the group to be<tei:lb/>merely aberrant trifine noctuids. Forbes (1960) retained the family status whereas Franclemont<tei:lb/>&amp; Todd (1983) treated them as a noctuid subfamily. It is probable that the Agaristinae is<tei:lb/>monophyletic, although the involvement of mimicry might complicate superficial resemblances.<tei:lb/>The relationships of the subfamily to other trifine groups is currently poorly understood.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Amphipyrinae. To Hampson, this subfamily (including the Acronictinae and the Pyrrhia-<tei:lb/>group heliothines) was characterised entirely by absences: hindwing vein M 2 reduced, the tibiae<tei:lb/>unspined and the eyes bare and unlashed. As such, the group can be seen to be a prime candidate<tei:lb/>within the Noctuidae for paraphyly or polyphyly. Unfortunately, like the Catocalinae (s.l.), the<tei:lb/>large size of the group (it contained nearly 2,400 species in Hampson's Catalogue, a number that<tei:lb/>has considerably increased since; Forbes, 1954) has resulted in a long period of classificatory<tei:lb/>stasis. Richards (1932) found a high degree of uniformity in the tympanum and could not suggest<tei:lb/>any interrelationships beyond that they appeared to be derived from the higher Acontiinae, a<tei:lb/>group that itself is probably not monophyletic.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gardner (1946a, ft; 1947; 1948a) found a great deal of diversity within the larvae and allocated<tei:lb/>amphipyrines to his groups AI, All, AVI, BI and C. In contrast, the pupae of this subfamily<tei:lb/>were, for the most part, indistinguishable from those of the Hadeninae, Noctuinae and<tei:lb/>Heliothinae that he examined.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The first attempt to subdivide the Amphipyrinae, in which the characters used were stated,<tei:lb/>was provided by Forbes (1954). On the basis of the genitalia and larvae, he erected two series,<tei:lb/>each divided into several tribes. Franclemont &amp; Todd (1983) reduced the number of tribes to<tei:lb/>four. The Apameini corresponded to Forbes' first series less the Prodeniini. This latter tribe,<tei:lb/>together with many of Forbes' isolated genera, formed the Amphipyrini, while the Stiriini was<tei:lb/>largely unchanged. Franclemont &amp; Todd's fourth tribe, the Nocloini, the basis for which is<tei:lb/>unclear, contained seven genera not dealt with by Forbes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Of these four tribes, the Stiriini is almost certainly monphyletic (Hogue, 1963) and the<tei:lb/>Apameini (and Nocloini?) may also prove to be. The Amphipyrini appears to be a somewhat<tei:lb/>more restricted 'dustbin' than was the Amphipyrinae and is therefore likely to be at least<tei:lb/>paraphyletic. It may even be polyphyletic given that the other trifine subfamilies are thought to<tei:lb/>have arisen from within its limits, as presently defined.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cuculliinae. The Cuculliinae is also a prime candidate for having a polyphyletic origin<tei:lb/>(Forbes, 1954). It was circumscribed by Hampson on the basis of bare, lashed eyes and unspined<tei:lb/>tibiae, not the most convincing of characters, especially as, venation apart, it applies equally well<tei:lb/>to the majority of the Plusiinae. Lack of material prevented both Mosher (1916) and Gardner<tei:lb/>(19480) from reaching more than highly tentative conclusions regarding both the internal and<tei:lb/>external relationships of the Cuculliinae based on larvae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Forbes (1954) divided the subfamily into two series, each comprising three tribes, which he<tei:lb/>thought to have been independently derived from the 'Acronyctinae'. The Cuculliini, Oncocne-<tei:lb/>midini and Psaphidini were considered to be related to certain Stiriini (q.v.) and the genera<tei:lb/>Oxycnemis and Catabena (the latter an 'isolated genus' of acronyctines, the former not<tei:lb/>mentioned elsewhere). This latter relationship was recently strengthened by the inclusion of<tei:lb/>Catabena and Oxycnemis in the Oncocnemidini (Franclemont &amp; Todd, 1983). The remaining<tei:lb/>three tribes, the Lithophanini, Cleocerini and Antitypini, apparently showed affinities with such<tei:lb/>genera as Andropolia, Rhizagrotis and some elements of the Apamea-Septis complex (all of<tei:lb/>which are currently placed in the Apameini; Franclemont &amp; Todd, 1983). The latter authors<tei:lb/>retained the Cuculliini, Oncocnemidini and Psaphidini but considered the other three as<tei:lb/>constituting a single tribe, the Xylenini. In addition, Feralia was placed in the monobasic<tei:lb/>Feraliini.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Given the highly uncertain nature of the trifine subfamilies in general, to find the Cuculliinae</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>222 IAN J. KITCHING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>polyphyletic would be no great surprise. Of the constituent tribes, the Psaphidini (fore-tibial<tei:lb/>modification) and the Feraliini (by virtue of it containing a single, assumed monophyletic genus)<tei:lb/>are probably monophyletic taxa. The Cuculliini and Oncocnemidini taken together may also<tei:lb/>prove monophyletic but the latter may be paraphyletic with respect to the former ('they tend to<tei:lb/>intergrade in Europe'; Forbes, 1954: 122). The Xylenini, as currently conceived, is probably<tei:lb/>paraphyletic, although the Lithophanini (sensu Forbes, 1954) may prove a monophyletic unit,<tei:lb/>based upon the form of the digitus in the male genitalia and the biological characteristic of an<tei:lb/>autumn adult emergence followed by hibernation. These tentative conclusions are unaffected by<tei:lb/>the nature of the Cuculliinae as a whole.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hadeninae. The hadenine genera were originally separated into a number of subfamilies by<tei:lb/>early authors (e.g. the Orthosiinae, Leucaniinae, Hadeninae; see also Heslop, 1960). However,<tei:lb/>they were all brought together into a single trifine subfamily by Hampson, defined by hairy eyes<tei:lb/>and unspined tibiae. As with the other trifine groups, tympanal organs and immature stages<tei:lb/>provided little information. Mosher (1916) characterised the Hadeninae by pupae possessing<tei:lb/>'stout straight setae or spines at the caudal end of the body'. However, she also included the<tei:lb/>heliothines Chloridea [Heliothis], Pyrrhia and Rhodophora [Schinia], the noctuine Lycophotia<tei:lb/>and the amphipyrines Eriopus [Callopistria] and Laphygma and Prodenia [both Spodoptera].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Forbes (1954) recognised three general facies within what he considered 'a homogeneous<tei:lb/>group', but also noted that a large proportion of the genera did not fit into any of them.<tei:lb/>Consequently, he did not formally subdivide the hadenines, unlike Franclemont &amp; Todd (1983),<tei:lb/>who recognised three tribes. The Glottulini comprised only Xanthopastis , an aberrant genus<tei:lb/>Forbes considered might not be closely related to the other hadenines. The Eriopygini contained<tei:lb/>Orthodes, Tricholita and their relatives, while the Hadenini consisted of the residue. The<tei:lb/>Glottulini are probably monophyletic given, for example, their amaryllidaceous-f ceding larvae<tei:lb/>(this tribe undoubtedly also includes the Old World genus Brithys). From the available<tei:lb/>information, the basis of the Eriopygini is unknown and consequently its status cannot be<tei:lb/>commented upon. Such is therefore also the case for the Hadenini but it is almost certainly at<tei:lb/>least paraphyletic, even assuming the Eriopygini to be adequately characterised. Within the<tei:lb/>Hadeninae, there are 'centres of monophyly', around such genera as Xanthopastis, Mythimna,<tei:lb/>Hadena and Orthosia, but their limits and interrelationships have yet to be established.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Noctuinae. This was the fourth and last trifine subfamily recognised by Hampson, on the basis<tei:lb/>of spined tibiae. Both Mosher (1916) and Gardner (19466; 1948a) found no characters by which<tei:lb/>they could distinguish the larvae and pupae of the noctuines from those of most other trifine<tei:lb/>genera. The heliothine section of the Agrotinae (sensu Hampson) had long been recognised by<tei:lb/>early authors as a discrete group but only slowly re-emerged as a distinct entity, which varied<tei:lb/>from being classed as a tribe of the Noctuinae (Forbes, 1954) to a separate subfamily that was<tei:lb/>isolated from the Noctuinae (e.g. McDunnough, 1938). Discussion of the 'heliothine Noctuinae'<tei:lb/>is deferred to the next section.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The remaining genera of Noctuinae were split by Heslop (1960) into two groups, following<tei:lb/>European tradition, one (Noctuini) characterised by yellow hindwings, the other (Agrotini) by<tei:lb/>hindwings of a different colour (usually brown). Forbes (1954) disagreed with this system,<tei:lb/>preferring instead to recognise three informal groups based around Agrotis, Peridroma and<tei:lb/>Noctua, which were formalised by Franclemont &amp; Todd (1983) as the Agrotini, Aniclini and<tei:lb/>Noctuini respectively. In addition, they recognised a fourth tribe, the Ufeini, to accommodate<tei:lb/>the aberrant genus Ufeus (The genus is not really an Agrotid, but fits no better elsewhere';<tei:lb/>Forbes, 1954: 74).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The three large tribes are relatively well defined by larval and genitalic characters but it is not<tei:lb/>clear how well these would stand up to a critical cladistic analysis. Indeed, the monophyly of the<tei:lb/>Noctuinae itself has yet to be adequately demonstrated.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Heliothinae. The Heliothinae was formed largely from the union of two subgroups of trifine<tei:lb/>noctuids, classified widely apart by Hampson, based around the genera Heliothis and Pyrrhia.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>REVIEW OF THE HIGHER CLASSIFICATION OF THE NOCTUIDAE 223</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The former, because of their spined tibiae, were placed in the Noctuinae, while the latter, which<tei:lb/>lacked all Hampson's 'definitive characters', were relegated to 'acronyctine' obscurity.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>However, the larvae of the Heliothinae are relatively distinctive. Their habit of feeding more<tei:lb/>or less exclusively on the flowers and fruits of low-growing plants had long been recognised, but<tei:lb/>this information was subsequently supplemented by structural features (Crumb, 1926; 1956;<tei:lb/>Gardner, 1946a,6). Of prime importance among these were the biordinal crotchets, a feature<tei:lb/>that the group shares with most Plusiinae and some Cuculliinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The North American Heliothinae were revised by Hardwick (1970). He excluded Grotella,<tei:lb/>Neogrotella and Hemigrotella from the subfamily, because of their slender build, distinctly<tei:lb/>quadrifine hindwing venation and the presence of multiple cornuti on the vesica, features that<tei:lb/>Hardwick considered linked the three genera with the Stiriini. However, Franclemont &amp; Todd<tei:lb/>(1983) retained them in the Heliothinae as the Grotellini, possibly as an interim measure.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The relationship between the Stiriini, the Heliothinae and, possibly, the Plusiinae warrants<tei:lb/>further consideration, due to its potential profound effects upon the higher classification of the<tei:lb/>Noctuidae generally. Hogue (1963) considered the Stiriini were derived from generalised<tei:lb/>noctuine stock via forms similar to either certain Heliothinae or Oncocnemidini, with the latter<tei:lb/>more likely (both groups possess an angled vesica bearing numerous cornuti). Furthermore,<tei:lb/>Hogue treated any resemblance to the Plusiinae to be entirely convergent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hardwick (1970) discussed the relationship between the Stiriini and the Heliothinae in<tei:lb/>considerable detail and concluded that there were 'a sufficient number of features in common to<tei:lb/>suggest some immediate common ancestry'. No mention was made of the Plusiinae with<tei:lb/>reference to a relationship with the stiriines and heliothines. That such a possibility can be<tei:lb/>entertained rests on somewhat equivocal evidence. Both the Heliothinae and the Plusiinae have<tei:lb/>larvae with biordinal crotchets, which could be interpreted as synapomorphic. However, the<tei:lb/>larvae of the tentative sister-group of the plusiines, the Stictopterinae, have uniordinal crotchets<tei:lb/>(Gardner, 19480), while the larvae of most stiriines are unknown and the crotchets of such that<tei:lb/>are have never been examined. Biordinal crotchets may, therefore, be homoplasious in the two<tei:lb/>groups. Perhaps the only overall conclusion that can be reached, like so many concerning the<tei:lb/>higher classification of the Noctuidae, is that it all depends on the results of investigations yet to<tei:lb/>be done.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The higher classification of the Noctuidae - fact or fiction?</tei:p>
         <tei:p>No adequate higher classification of the Noctuidae can yet be proposed that will serve as a<tei:lb/>replacement for the Hampsonian system. However, it is possible to construct a tentative<tei:lb/>cladogram (Fig. 4) to serve as a suitable starting-point. Only those apomorphies that can be<tei:lb/>reasonably positively identified are included, although those on several branches are highly<tei:lb/>suspect. The relative paucity of synapomorphies results in a number of extensive polychotomies<tei:lb/>and several of the groups being uncharacterised (see below). The individual branches, 1-34, will<tei:lb/>be discussed and justified seriatim, and their relative merits assessed.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1. The Arctiidae generally can be characterised by three apomorphies, none of which are<tei:lb/>present in all genera. Two are perhaps quite reliable: the presence of the tymbal organ<tei:lb/>(although this is absent/lost in some of the ctenuchines and a few other groups) and the<tei:lb/>presence of two subventral (SV) setae in the larvae on the meso- and metathorax. Only one<tei:lb/>SV seta is present in this position in the aganaids, herminiids and noctuids (Gardner, 1941),<tei:lb/>and examination of five notodontids (Stauropusfagi, Notodonta dromedarius, Eligmodonta<tei:lb/>ziczac, Peridea anceps and Pheosia tremula; Kitching, unpublished) showed these also<tei:lb/>possess only a single seta. The latter evidence was used in an outgroup comparison to<tei:lb/>establish the bisetose condition as apomorphic. The third arctiid apomorphy, a swollen<tei:lb/>hindwing vein Sc + R^ is more uncertain, especially as 'swollen' has never been precisely<tei:lb/>defined.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2. No apomorphies have been discovered in the literature for the aganaid genera. As such,<tei:lb/>they are of uncertain position and it is possible for some to be more closely related to the</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>224</tei:p>
         <tei:p>IAN J. KITCHING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Arctiidae<tei:lb/>Aganaidae<tei:lb/>Herminiidae<tei:lb/>Rivulinae<tei:lb/>Hypenodinae<tei:lb/>Hypeninae<tei:lb/>Catocalinae<tei:lb/>Anomis/ Alabama<tei:lb/>Catocala/Othreis</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fig. 4 Cladogram illustrating the relationships between the various noctuid subgroups. For details<tei:lb/>regarding the characters defining each of the numbered branches, 1-34, see pp. 223-226. Seven<tei:lb/>branches are undefined by apomorphies; those subtending the Rivulinae, Catocalinae, Acontiinae,<tei:lb/>Amphipyrinae, Acronictinae, Cuculliinae and Hadeninae. For discussion of the undefined branch 2, see<tei:lb/>pp. 214-215,223-225.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>REVIEW OF THE HIGHER CLASSIFICATION OF THE NOCTUIDAE 225</tei:p>
         <tei:p>arctiids and some to the noctuids. It may even be that some represent the sister-group of the<tei:lb/>herminiids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3. The exclusion of the 'fan-foots' and their relatives from the Noctuidae (branch 4) is<tei:lb/>primarily on the basis of the plesiomorphic pre-spiracular hood. In addition, they may be<tei:lb/>characterised by two apomorphies: modified fore-tibiae in the males of most genera<tei:lb/>(although the exact nature of the modification is deliberately left unspecified) and a swollen<tei:lb/>metepimeron ventral to pocket IV.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4. The Noctuidae is restricted to those groups possessing a post-spiracular hood, although this<tei:lb/>is absent in the Pantheinae (q.v.) and is greatly reduced in many other genera scattered<tei:lb/>among the other subfamilies. These can be interpreted as secondary losses but require<tei:lb/>further analysis. Two uncharacterised paraphyletic/polyphletic assemblages are recognised<tei:lb/>within the heptachotomy that terminates branch 4, the Rivulinae and the Acontiinae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5 . The Hypenodinae are characterised by the lack of ocelli , an unsatisfactory situation but the<tei:lb/>best that can be done at present.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>6. A similar situation pertains to the Hypeninae. Its putative apomorphies of long, 'deltoid'<tei:lb/>palps and lashed eyes are not particularly convincing.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>7. The Catocalinae (s.l.) are better characterised (fused pleural sclerite in the male genitalia<tei:lb/>and pupa with a whitish bloom) but the majority of genera and species of this vast subfamily<tei:lb/>have yet to be examined, especially with regard to the pupal character.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>8 &amp; 9. These branches represent two of the many genus-groups that can be recognised in the<tei:lb/>Catocalinae (s.l.). Anomis and Alabama (the Anomiini of Forbes, 1954) are defined by an<tei:lb/>enlarged but unsclerotised alula and malvaceous-feeding larvae. Catocala and Othreis both<tei:lb/>possess a chitinous projection from the inner margin of the tympanal frame (the 'Biigel';<tei:lb/>Eggers, 1919).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>10. Of the acontiine groups, only the Acontiini is well-characterised: tympanal hood reduced/<tei:lb/>lost, alula enlarged and sclerotised, male with paired anal hair-masses; cf. Euteliinae<tei:lb/>(Forbes, 1954: 271).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>11. This branch includes four subfamilies, tentatively grouped on the absence of a cremaster.<tei:lb/>However, this has not been confirmed for the Nolinae. The Euteliinae also bear a<tei:lb/>general resemblance in venation and the larvae of certain sarrothripine genera (Forbes,<tei:lb/>1954: 288).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>12. The Euteliinae are perhaps the most well-defined subfamily of noctuids: frenulum reduced<tei:lb/>in the female; larvae feeding mainly on Anacardiaceae; pair of anal hair pencils present in<tei:lb/>the male; and the attitude of the adults at rest. There can be little doubt they represent a<tei:lb/>monophyletic taxon.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>13. The Nolinae, Sarrothripinae and Chloephorinae are united by the common possession of a<tei:lb/>boat-shaped cocoon with a vertical exit slit.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>14-17. Unfortunately, the relationships within the above group of subfamilies are unclear. The<tei:lb/>Chloephorinae and Sarrothripinae agree in the possession of a bar-shaped retinaculum in<tei:lb/>the male but the latter also agrees with the Nolinae in the presence of tufts of raised scales in<tei:lb/>the forewing cell. As the second character also occurs elsewhere in the Noctuidae (e.g. the<tei:lb/>Stictopterinae and the Plusiinae: Abrostolini), the first character is preferentially taken to<tei:lb/>represent a synapomorphy. However, it is probable that the group needs to be split up in a<tei:lb/>different manner, possibly along the lines suggested by Mell (1943). In addition, the nolines<tei:lb/>lack ocelli in the adult and have larvae with tufted setae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>18. The 'higher noctuids' can generally be characterised by the presence of a clavus in the male<tei:lb/>genitalia. However, this structure is absent in many genera and uncertainties regarding<tei:lb/>genitalic homologies decrease confidence in this character. Secondly, the larval silk-pore of</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>226 IAN J. KITCHING</tei:p>
         <tei:p>the included subfamilies is not concealed (Crumb, 1956) and may represent a good<tei:lb/>apomorphy, although the condition in the Stictopterinae is unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>19-21. The Stictopterinae and Plusiinae share a double tympanal hood and tufts of raised scales<tei:lb/>in the forewing cell (present in the Plusiinae only in the Abrostolini). The stictopterines can<tei:lb/>be distinguished by the reduced female frenulum and possibly by the caudal extremity of the<tei:lb/>pupa being produced as 'two divergent attenuated spines borne together on a thicker<tei:lb/>median stem' (Gardner, 1948ft: 88). The plusiines are relatively well defined, with four<tei:lb/>apomorphies: lashed eyes, a metepimeral bulge formed by an enlarged pocket IV, biordinal<tei:lb/>crotchets in the larvae and pupae in which the wings and proboscis project beyond the<tei:lb/>posterior margin of abdominal segment 4 ventrally.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>22. The subfamilies subtended by this branch, the Trifinae', are held together on rather<tei:lb/>dubious grounds. Of the obsolescent hindwing vein M 2 , nothing more needs to be said. The<tei:lb/>tympanal organs of all forms (except the Pantheinae, see branch 24) are extremely uniform<tei:lb/>and similar to those of the 'higher Erastriinae' [Acontiinae] (Richards, 1932: 29). The exact<tei:lb/>nature of this homogeneity and whether it includes any structures that can be regarded as<tei:lb/>synapomorphies was not elucidated by Richards.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>22-24. The Acronictinae and Pantheinae are grouped on the basis of the presence of secondary<tei:lb/>setae on the larval trunk. However, the absence of such setae in the Acronictinae:<tei:lb/>Bryophilini weakens this argument, and the two subfamilies may not be closely related at<tei:lb/>all. The pantheines are further distinguished by their hairy eyes, the presence of secondary<tei:lb/>setae on the larval head, the reduction/absence of the tympanal hood and the highly<tei:lb/>modified tympanal morphology (Richards, 1932: 28).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>25-30. Three branches (25, 26 and 29) subtend three of the currently recognised trifine<tei:lb/>subfamilies, the Noctuinae, Cuculliinae and Hadeninae respectively. This was done, not<tei:lb/>because there are good synapomorphies for the included genera (the characters employed<tei:lb/>are the classic ones of spined tibiae, lashed eyes and hairy eyes), but because to omit them<tei:lb/>would create a vast, uncharacterised group of genera (cf . the Catocalinae). In addition, it is<tei:lb/>probable that some of the groups will eventually be able to be defined by good apomor-<tei:lb/>phies. Two tribes are split out of the Cuculliinae: the Lithophanini (well-developed digitus<tei:lb/>in the male genitalia, adult emergence generally autumnal, followed by hiberation) and the<tei:lb/>Psaphidini (fore-tibia with a terminal claw on the inner side, usually with an oblique, flat<tei:lb/>plate continuous with it; Forbes, 1954: 127); and one tribe from the Hadeninae: the<tei:lb/>Glottulini (larvae brightly-coloured, black, transversely spotted with yellow/white; feeding<tei:lb/>on the bulbs of the Amaryllidaceae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>31-33. The amphipyrine tribe, the Stiriini, and the Heliothinae are associated by the clawed<tei:lb/>fore-tibiae (single in the former, multiple in the latter) and the larval preference for feeding<tei:lb/>on flowers and young fruits. The Stiriini are characterised by an angled vesica with multiple<tei:lb/>cornuti and a heavily chitinised frons in the adult, with a raised ring and various projections.<tei:lb/>The larvae of the Heliothinae have biordinal crotchets.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>34. The final noctuid subfamily to be considered is the Agaristinae. This is a highly apomorphic<tei:lb/>group: counter-tympanum several times the size of the tympanal membrane; hood very<tei:lb/>reduced/absent; adults active by day, generally brightly coloured, usually with clubbed<tei:lb/>antennae; larvae also brightly coloured, feeding largely on Vitaceae and Onagraceae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I do not claim that the apomorphies employed in Fig. 4 are all that could be used to reconstruct<tei:lb/>the higher classification of the Noctuidae. However, they do represent all those extracted from<tei:lb/>the literature in which I have more than minimal confidence regarding the polarity, although it<tei:lb/>must be remembered that few are known to be present in all members of the group that they are<tei:lb/>being used to characterise. Many more characters are known at the subfamily level (see, for<tei:lb/>example, those cited by Forbes, 1954) but their usefulness has yet to be assessed. In addition,</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>REVIEW OF THE HIGHER CLASSIFICATION OF THE NOCTUIDAE 227</tei:p>
         <tei:p>there are certainly a considerable number of features known that are as yet undocumented,<tei:lb/>which must therefore necessarily fall outside the scope of this analysis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>To return to the title of this section, it would perhaps be more appropriate to refer to the<tei:lb/>Hampsonian classification as 'classifiction'. The system proposed by Franclemont &amp; Todd<tei:lb/>(1983), which ranks as the main contender as an alternative, has much to commend it. However,<tei:lb/>it is of limited application until extended to encompass the world fauna and, unfortunately, until<tei:lb/>such time as the defining characters/apomorphies of the included groups are reported, such<tei:lb/>development is impossible. That there is a higher classification for this group of moths is not in<tei:lb/>question, but until careful character analyses, performed within a cladistic methodological<tei:lb/>framework, are published, the present state of confusion will reign. I hope that noctuid<tei:lb/>systematists will rise to meet the challenge.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>References</tei:p>

      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>British Museum (Natural History)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Milkweed butterflies: their cladistics and biology</tei:p>
         <tei:p>P. R. Ackery &amp; R. I. Vane- Wright</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Danainae, a subfamily of the Nymphalidae, contains only some 150 species, yet aspects of<tei:lb/>their biology have stimulated far more attention than can be justified by species numbers<tei:lb/>alone. In recent years, an expansive literature has grown, considering aspects of their<tei:lb/>courtship and pre-courtship behaviour, migration, larval hostplant associations, mimicry and<tei:lb/>genetics. The popularity of danaines among biologists can certainly be attributed to this<tei:lb/>combination, within one small group, of so many of the factors that make butterflies such an<tei:lb/>interesting group to study. The obvious need to place this wealth of biological data within an<tei:lb/>acceptable systematic framework provided the impetus for this volume.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Started eight years ago within the conventions of evolution by natural selection and<tei:lb/>Hennig's phylogenetic systematics, the book is now largely about natural history (what the<tei:lb/>animals have and do, where they live and how they develop) and natural groups - as revealed<tei:lb/>by a form of analysis approaching that practised by the new school of 'transformed cladistics'.<tei:lb/>The authors have prepared a handbook that will appeal to a wide range of biologists, from<tei:lb/>museum taxonomists to field ecologists.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>424 pp (approx. ), 12 pp colour, 73 b/w plates, line and graphic illustrations, maps, extensive bibliography.<tei:lb/>ISBN 565 00893 5. Publication September 1984. Price 50, prepublication price 45.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>Titles to be published in Volume 49</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Afrotropical jumping plant lice of the family Triozidae (Homoptera: Psylloidea).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>By David Hollis</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The taxonomy of the western European grasshoppers of the genus Euchorthippus, with special<tei:lb/>reference to their songs (Orthoptera: Acrididae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>By D. R. Ragge &amp; W. J. Reynolds</tei:p>
         <tei:p>An historical review of the higher classification of the Noctuidae (Lepidoptera).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>By Ian Kitching</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Pimplinae, Xoridinae, Acaenitinae and Lycorininae (Hymenoptera: Ichneumonidae) of<tei:lb/>Australia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>By I. D.Gauld</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Palaearctic species of Ascogaster (Hymenoptera: Braconidae)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>By T. Huddleston</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Photoset by Rowland Phototypesetting Ltd, Bury St Edmunds, Suffolk<tei:lb/>Printed in Great Britain by Henry Ling Ltd, Dorchester</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>Bulletin of the</tei:p>
         <tei:p>British Museum (Natural History)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Pimplinae, Xoridinae,<tei:lb/>Acaenitinae and Lycorininae<tei:lb/>(Hymenoptera: Ichneumonidae)<tei:lb/>of Australia</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I. D. Gauld</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Entomology series</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Vol49 No 4 20 December 1984</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>The Bulletin of the British Museum (Natural History), instituted in 1949, is issued in four<tei:lb/>scientific series, Botany, Entomology, Geology (incorporating Mineralogy) and Zoology,<tei:lb/>and an Historical series.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Papers in the Bulletin are primarily the results of research carried out on the unique and<tei:lb/>ever-growing collections of the Museum, both by the scientific staff of the Museum and by<tei:lb/>specialists from elsewhere who make use of the Museum's resources. Many of the papers are<tei:lb/>works of reference that will remain indispensable for years to come.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Parts are published at irregular intervals as they become ready, each is complete in itself,<tei:lb/>available separately, and individually priced. Volumes contain about 300 pages and several<tei:lb/>volumes may appear within a calendar year. Subscriptions may be placed for one or more of<tei:lb/>the series on either an Annual or Per Volume basis. Prices vary according to the contents of<tei:lb/>the individual parts. Orders and enquiries should be sent to:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Publications Sales,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>British Museum (Natural History),<tei:lb/>Cromwell Road,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>London SW75BD,<tei:lb/>England.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>World List abbreviation: Bull. Br. Mus. nat. Hist. (Ent.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Trustees of the British Museum (Natural History), 1984</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Entomology series is produced under the general editorship of the</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Keeper of Entomology: Laurence A. Mound</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Assistant Editor: W. Gerald Tremewan</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ISBN 565 06006 6<tei:lb/>ISSN 0524-6431</tei:p>
         <tei:p>British Museum (Natural History)<tei:lb/>Cromwell Road<tei:lb/>London SW75BD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Entomology series<tei:lb/>Vol49No4pp235-339</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Issued 20 December 1984</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>The Pimplinae, Xoridinae, Acaenitinae and<tei:lb/>Lycorininae (Hymenoptera: Ichneumonidae) of<tei:lb/>Australia</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Subfamily Acaenitinae 322</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Zoogeography 322</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Biology 322</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Subfamily Lycorininae 327</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acknowledgements 331</tei:p>
         <tei:p>References 331</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Index to hosts 338</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Index to Ichneumonidae 338</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Synopsis</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Australian species of the ichneumonid subfamilies Pimplinae, Xoridinae, Acaenitinae and Lycorini-<tei:lb/>nae are revised and keys provided to the 20 genera and 76 species occurring on the continent. A total of 35<tei:lb/>species are newly described but four are not formally named as their status needs further investigation. The<tei:lb/>remaining 41 species are redescribed and their diagnostic features emphasized. Five new specific synonyms<tei:lb/>are proposed. For each species notes are given about geographical distribution, habitat preference and<tei:lb/>host range. Introductory sections for each subfamily include notes on zoogeography and a brief discussion<tei:lb/>of group biology. A checklist of Australian species, and indexes to hosts and parasitoids, complete the<tei:lb/>work.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Introduction</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Amongst the most important of the natural enemies of insect pests are the parasitic Hymenop-<tei:lb/>tera, a very large group of animals whose larvae develop at the expense of other insects (Askew,<tei:lb/>1971). Under normal circumstances the populations of many injurious insects are severely<tei:lb/>limited by the attacks of Parasitica and in several countries, including Australia, the ravages of<tei:lb/>accidentally imported pests have been curtailed by the introduction of one or more hymenopter-<tei:lb/>ans (Muldrew, 1967; Taylor, 1978). Other introduced pests have been severely attacked by</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bull. Br. Mus. not. Hist. (Ent.) 49 (4): 235-339 Issued 20 December 1984</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>236 I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>native Australian parasitoids (Tryon, 1900). During the past 20 years there has been an upsurge<tei:lb/>in interest in using Hymenoptera and other organisms for purposes of pest control (Wilson,<tei:lb/>1960; Huffaker &amp; Messenger, 1976) as an alternative to costly, ineffective and environmentally<tei:lb/>destructive chemical methods (Bosch, 1978). However, for biological control programmes to be<tei:lb/>successful an intimate knowledge is necessary of the life history and interactions of the pest and<tei:lb/>its parasites. A sound taxonomic basis is vital for the development of such knowledge (Hardy,<tei:lb/>1982), for such work permits the accurate identification of an organism and hence provides<tei:lb/>constancy and universality in the usage of names, a prerequisite for the national and internation-<tei:lb/>al communication of information.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The present work is a taxonomic study of four rather distantly related subfamilies of<tei:lb/>Australian Ichneumonidae, one of the largest groups of Parasitica. The primary aim of the paper<tei:lb/>is to provide practical keys for the identification of these insects and to collate information<tei:lb/>concerning their distribution, habitat preference and host range.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>These subfamilies, the Pimplinae, Acaenitinae, Lycorininae and Xoridinae, contain a<tei:lb/>number of species common in agricultural, horticultural and forest ecosystems, including<tei:lb/>several that parasitize notorious lepidopterous and symphytan pests. No comprehensive<tei:lb/>account of the Australian species of these subfamilies has ever been published, although one or<tei:lb/>two of the pimpline genera have been revised recently for the whole of the Indo-Australian<tei:lb/>region (Gupta, 1962;'Townes &amp; Chiu, 1970; Gupta &amp; Tikar, 1978). Several new Australian<tei:lb/>species of these genera are described herein, and simpler local keys provided for identification.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The inclusion of the four taxa Pimplinae, Acaenitinae, Lycorininae and Xoridinae together in<tei:lb/>a single work is largely a matter of convenience. The first subfamily is by far the largest and<tei:lb/>constitutes the major part of the study; the remaining three taxa are very small and share certain<tei:lb/>superficial similarities, making it sensible to deal with them at the same time. Although not<tei:lb/>closely related, these four subfamilies, together with the Banchinae and part of the Labeninae,<tei:lb/>were included by older authors (e.g. Morley, 19130; Szepligeti, 1914) in one of the five classical<tei:lb/>ichneumonid subfamilies, the Pimplinae s.l. This heterogeneous taxon was characterized by<tei:lb/>possession of a fairly broad first tergite with subcentral or antecentral spiracles (sessile gaster)<tei:lb/>and, in females, by possession of a long ovipositor (though in fact the ovipositor is very short in<tei:lb/>some species ofXanthopimpla). All Australian species will run to 'Pimplinae' in Riek's (1970)<tei:lb/>key. The subfamilies may easily be separated by reference to Gauld's (1984) recent monograph<tei:lb/>on Australian ichneumonids. The Lycorininae, Xoridinae and Acaenitinae are extremely<tei:lb/>distinctive taxa and easily recognized by the possession of unique features (the co-adapted<tei:lb/>'catch' between the metathorax and propodeum of lycorinines; the transcarinate scuto-scutellar<tei:lb/>groove and geniculate female flagellum of xoridines; the elongate female subgenital plate and<tei:lb/>accessory tooth on the tarsal claw of acaenitines). Care is required to separate some Pimplinae<tei:lb/>from Labeninae but species of the latter group have a larger clypeus and higher position of<tei:lb/>insertion of the gaster than pimplines (Townes, 1969; Gauld, 1984). None of these subfamilies<tei:lb/>should be confused with the other 'pimpline' taxon, the Banchinae, as all banchines have a<tei:lb/>dorsal subapical notch in the ovipositor; such a notch is not present in any Pimplinae,<tei:lb/>Acaenitinae, Lycorininae, Xoridinae or Labeninae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The terminology in this work follows that of Gauld (1984).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Material examined</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The study is based on examination of almost all specimens available in collections of Australian<tei:lb/>ichneumonids. Special attention was paid to collections in agricultural institutions that contain<tei:lb/>large numbers of reared specimens. Examination of these collections has been supplemented by<tei:lb/>extensive collecting, particularly in Tasmania and the south-east. Although the resulting sample<tei:lb/>is thought to be fairly representative of the fauna of the more humid eastern part of the<tei:lb/>continent, relatively little material has been seen from the north and west. Smaller, cryptic<tei:lb/>species, such as many polysphinctines, are probably very unrepresented.<tei:lb/>The following abbreviations have been used for museums containing Australian material.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>AM Australian Museum, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>ICHNEUMONIDAE OF AUSTRALIA 237</tei:p>

         <tei:p>BMNH British Museum (Natural History), London, U.K.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>BPBM Bernice P. Bishop Museum, Honolulu, Hawaii, U.S.A.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DAR Department of Agriculture, Rydalmere, New South Wales, Australia</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DAT Department of Agriculture, Hobart, Tasmania, Australia</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DFT Department of Forestry, Hobart, Tasmania, Australia</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DPIQ Department of Primary Industries, Indooroopilly, Queensland, Australia</tei:p>
         <tei:p>LSL Linnean Society, London, U.K.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MNHN Museum National d'Histoire Naturelle, Paris, France</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MNHU Museum fur Naturkunde der Humboldt-Universitat, Berlin, D.D.R.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>NM Naturhistorisches Museum, Vienna, Austria</tei:p>
         <tei:p>NMV National Museum of Victoria, Melbourne, Victoria, Australia</tei:p>
         <tei:p>PANS Philadelphia Academy of Natural Sciences, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, U.S.A.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>QM Queensland Museum, Fortitude Valley, Queensland, Australia</tei:p>
         <tei:p>QUM Queensland University Museum, Brisbane, Queensland, Australia</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TC Townes Collection, Ann Arbor, Michigan, U.S.A.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TM Termeszettudomanyi Museum, Budapest, Hungary</tei:p>
         <tei:p>UL Universite Laval, Quebec, Canada</tei:p>
         <tei:p>UM University Museum, Oxford, U.K.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>USNM United States National Museum, Washington D.C. , U.S.A.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>UZM Zoologisk Museum, Copenhagen, Denmark</tei:p>
         <tei:p>WAM Western Australian Museum, Perth, Western Australia, Australia</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ZMA Zoologisch Museum, Amsterdam, The Netherlands</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Genus</tei:p>
         <tei:p>canfeerrae sp. n.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>species 1</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Subfamily PIMPLINAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Pimplinae is a moderately large subfamily, but as certain genera contain one or two large,<tei:lb/>strikingly patterned and common species, it is often the numerically best represented subfamily<tei:lb/>in general collections. Such collections will be found to be dominated by only three or four<tei:lb/>species, typically Pimplini, that are common in suburban situations, and also, less frequently, by<tei:lb/>rhyssines, conspicuous on account of their exceptional size and long ovipositors. Such a situation<tei:lb/>applies throughout most of the world. In Australia, collections are dominated by species of the<tei:lb/>genera Lissopimpla and Echthromorpha, whilst in Palaearctic collections the related and</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p/>
         <tei:p>ICHNEUMONIDAE OF AUSTRALIA 239</tei:p>
         <tei:p>biologically similar genera Pimpla and Itoplectis predominate. The numerous other smaller or<tei:lb/>more cryptic pimplines are less often collected and, although many appear to be quite<tei:lb/>widespread, few are usually present in most museums. Malaise traps generally yield small<tei:lb/>numbers, but good series can often only be taken by more specialist collecting, such as careful<tei:lb/>examination of tree bark inhabited by spiders, or 'stalking' the brightly coloured arboreal<tei:lb/>Xanthopimpla species in forest understorey vegetation. Many species are only ever encountered<tei:lb/>in one particular habitat and these 'rare' taxa may prove to be very common when one knows<tei:lb/>just where to look. This ecological specialization coupled with the great range of biological<tei:lb/>diversity exhibited by the subfamily makes the Pimplinae one of the most attractive of all<tei:lb/>ichneumonid groups for biological investigation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Pimplinae is currently subdivided into seven tribes, Delomeristini, Ephialtini, Rhyssini,<tei:lb/>Pimplini, Neoxoridini, Polysphinctini and Diacritini, but authors have not reached agreement<tei:lb/>about their exact limits (compare Finlayson, 1967 and Townes, 1969) . The Ephialtini is probably<tei:lb/>the most primitive group, and is the paraphyletic 'grade-group' from within which all the other<tei:lb/>groups have probably arisen. The Delomeristini appears to be a polyphyletic assemblage and, as<tei:lb/>it is not yet possible to unambiguously assign its members to other taxa, for the present it is left<tei:lb/>intact as a tribe. The remaining five tribes seem to be natural holophyletic (in the sense of<tei:lb/>Hennig, 1966) groups, although the definition of one, the Polysphinctini, can be altered<tei:lb/>depending upon whether a classification is formulated on larval or adult characters (Townes,<tei:lb/>1969; Gupta &amp; Tikar, 1978). Throughout the world approximately 76 genera are recognized, but<tei:lb/>disagreement over some generic limits means this number is liable to fluctuate for some time.<tei:lb/>Only 17 of these genera are known to occur in Australia (Gauld, 1984), and several of these (e.g.<tei:lb/>Alophopimpla, Acropimpla and Camptotypus] are restricted to tropical Queensland; others,<tei:lb/>such as Xanthopimpla and Zatypota, appear to be more diverse in the north.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In the following account 62 Australian named species are formally described, of which 23 are<tei:lb/>new. One morphological segregate of Lissopimpla is keyed separately and described but its<tei:lb/>taxonomic status remains uncertain.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Zoogeography</tei:p>
         <tei:p>For the Indo-Australian region as a whole the general picture of pimpline distribution is one of<tei:lb/>rapid decrease, both in number of species and genera, from the Asian continental shelf<tei:lb/>eastwards. This is particularly the case for the Ephialtini which is represented by 20 genera in<tei:lb/>South East Asia, six in New Guinea and five in Australia, and for the Rhyssini which has seven<tei:lb/>genera in Asia, five in New Guinea but only one present in Australia. Acropimpla is represented<tei:lb/>by 27 species in South East Asia, two in New Guinea and one in Australia whilst Gupta (1962)<tei:lb/>demonstrated a progressive west-east reduction in numbers of species and species-groups of<tei:lb/>Theronia. In some groups New Guinea has apparently acted as a centre for secondary radiation.<tei:lb/>This is particularly noticeable in the case of Xanthopimpla for the splendens-group (Townes &amp;<tei:lb/>Chiu, 1970) and is possibly also true for Camptotypus. In both these cases the genera seem to<tei:lb/>have had an Asian origin.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>There is a marked relationship between the pimpline fauna of Australia and New Guinea. Of<tei:lb/>a total of 42 species (excluding polysphinctines) found in Australia, 17 (i.e. 40%) also occur in<tei:lb/>New Guinea. Many of the species apparently endemic to Australia have their closest or very<tei:lb/>close relatives to the north. This is particularly obvious for many species of Xanthopimpla,<tei:lb/>Zaglyptus, Acropimpla and Alophopimpla. In none of these genera is there any indication of<tei:lb/>substantial radiation in Australia, though in a few cases (e.g. Zaglyptus) sister-species pairs do<tei:lb/>occur there.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The most obvious interpretation of this data is to suggest that the Australian fauna has been<tei:lb/>derived from that of the Old World tropics, presumably within the last five million or so years, as<tei:lb/>before that time the continent was remote from South East Asia (Audley-Charles et al. , 1981).<tei:lb/>Any hypothesis that advocates a southern origin for these pimplines needs to account for their<tei:lb/>rapid spread into South East Asia and their extreme radiation, despite possible competitive<tei:lb/>pressure from numerous Old World pimplines (as many genera are not present in Australia).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>240 I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Furthermore there are no obvious affinities between the Australian pimpline fauna and that of<tei:lb/>the southern neotropics. The only endemic Australian genus, Parvipimpla, seems to be related<tei:lb/>to Camptotypus and most pimpline and ephialtine Australian genera are not present in South<tei:lb/>America. The few that are (e.g. Xanthopimpla, Zaglyptus) are tropicopolitan taxa and the<tei:lb/>Australian species belong to quite different species-groups from New World taxa. The same is<tei:lb/>true for Theronia; Neotropical species belong to an exclusively Neotropical subgenus (Townes<tei:lb/>&amp; Townes, 1966) and are not at all closely related to Australian species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The polysphinctines have been excluded from the above discussion for the reason that<tei:lb/>virtually nothing is known of them in any region other than north temperate areas. The<tei:lb/>Australian Dreisbachia is probably very closely related to a New Guinea species (Momoi, 1966)<tei:lb/>and Eriostethus has numerous northern congeners. This latter genus was thought by Gauld<tei:lb/>(1984) to have possible close phylogenetic affinity with some Neotropical species, but subse-<tei:lb/>quent study suggests that the apparent similarities may be the result of evolutionary convergence<tei:lb/>(seep. 259).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Biology</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Biologically the Pimplinae is both one of the most diverse and one of the more primitive<tei:lb/>subfamilies of Ichneumonidae. Pimplines utilize a wide range of holometabolous insect larvae<tei:lb/>and pupae as hosts, though a few even attack spiders' egg sacs. One specialized group, the<tei:lb/>Polysphinctini, is unique amongst ichneumonids in parasitizing immature spiders. In general<tei:lb/>pimplines attack relatively mature hosts and usually curtail further host-development by<tei:lb/>envenomation during parasitization (Chrystal &amp; Skinner, 1932; Morgan &amp; Stewart, 1966;<tei:lb/>Spradbery, 1968; Price, 1973). The pimpline's venom, produced by accessory glands associated<tei:lb/>with the reproductive system (Togashi, 1963), is injected by the ovipositor prior to oviposition.<tei:lb/>It may kill the host or induce permanent paralysis (Cushman, 1926). Smithers (1956) observed<tei:lb/>that larvae of a psychid stung by Sericopimpla (but not parasitized) remained immotile but<tei:lb/>usually 'fresh' for over two months. The majority of pimplines are ectoparasites of concealed<tei:lb/>endopterygotes and such immobilization is presumably necessary to prevent the host damaging<tei:lb/>the pimpline egg or young larva. Smithers (1956) observed that Sericopimpla eggs artificially<tei:lb/>placed on unparalysed psychid larvae were destroyed prior to eclosion. Envenomation by the<tei:lb/>endoparasitic Pimplini may be necessary to reduce the host's haemocyte reaction which is<tei:lb/>usually more pronounced in more mature larvae (Puttier, 1961; Bosch, 1964). However, Carton<tei:lb/>(1973) observed that careful placement of the egg was necessary for Pimpla to minimize<tei:lb/>encapsulation, whilst Fiihrer &amp; Kilincer (1972) noted that the newly hatched larvae of some<tei:lb/>other species migrate rapidly to the host's head and destroy the cephalic ganglion by histolysis.<tei:lb/>Unlike other pimplines, polysphinctines generally do not curtail host development. Species of<tei:lb/>Polysphincta andAcrodactyla have a powerful paralysing venom which they use to immobilize a<tei:lb/>spider. After stinging and attaching an egg the pimpline departs and the spider recovers and lives<tei:lb/>actively (Nielsen, 1923; Cushman, 1926).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Parasitoids, such as most Pimplinae, that adopt the strategy of attacking mature hosts,<tei:lb/>generally lay large, well-developed eggs (Price, 1975) and undergo quite rapid larval develop-<tei:lb/>ment. The size of pimpline eggs can readily be appreciated from the tables given by Iwata (1958).<tei:lb/>A species of Sericopimpla has 'sausage-shaped' eggs 2-4 x 0-4 mm whilst a specialist endoparasi-<tei:lb/>toid of similar body size (e.g. Meniscus) has eggs between 0.33 x 0.08 mm and 0.71 x 0. 16 mm,<tei:lb/>that is around one-twentieth of the volume. Even very small pimplines, such as Zatypota, have<tei:lb/>eggs 0.74 x 0.22 mm in size. Many very large species, such as Megarhyssa, have extremely<tei:lb/>elongate eggs (up to 14 mm long) which deform to facilitate passage down the long ovipositor<tei:lb/>(Spradbery, 1970). To successfully form such large eggs many female pimplines need protein-<tei:lb/>rich food. In addition to feeding at flowers, like the males, these females frequently consume<tei:lb/>haemolymph exuding from the punctures they make in pupae used as hosts (Graham, 1947;<tei:lb/>Leius, 1960). Some pimplines seek out and kill prey to obtain such fluid nourishment (Cole,<tei:lb/>1967) and, as the prey is often the larvae or pupae of the host species, the ichneumonid is often a<tei:lb/>more important mortality factor than estimation of percentage of parasitism may suggest.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>ICHNEUMONIDAE OF AUSTRALIA 241</tei:p>
         <tei:p>As pimpline eggs are large, adult females have relatively few mature oocytes in the oviduct at<tei:lb/>any one time. Iwata (1960) calculated the average number to be about six with a maximum of<tei:lb/>generally less than 20, except in a few species such as Iseropus which are gregarious parasites.<tei:lb/>Banchines, which are similar-sized ichneumonids, but specialist endoparasites, have on average<tei:lb/>53 mature oocytes, with a maximum of 176. The eggs of many pimplines are deposited on or near<tei:lb/>the paralysed larva (Smithers, 1956; Morgan &amp; Stewart, 1966) though those of Pimplini are<tei:lb/>placed within the host's haemocoel, often in the thorax (Carton, 1973). One striking feature of<tei:lb/>some pimplines is their apparent inefficiency in oviposition. Smithers (1956) observed that<tei:lb/>Sericopimpla may attempt to sting a psychid larva over 100 times, and is often engaged for an<tei:lb/>hour or more attacking a single individual. Morgan &amp; Stewart (1966) observed that Rhyssa made<tei:lb/>between five and 12 insertions of the ovipositor to make a single successful attack.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pimpline eggs hatch quite rapidly, often one or two days after oviposition, and early larval<tei:lb/>development proceeds very rapidly with generally only one or two days between ecdyses<tei:lb/>(Rosenberg, 1934; Smithers, 1956; Rojas-Rousse &amp; Benoit, 1977). The final larval instar is of<tei:lb/>longest duration, frequently exceeding the length of the sum of all others. This contrasts<tei:lb/>markedly with some specialist endoparasitoids where the first larval instar is extremely<tei:lb/>protracted (Tothill, 1922). The exact number of instars pimpline larvae pass through is difficult<tei:lb/>to ascertain (Rojas-Rousse &amp; Benoit, 1977) but may often be five or six; individual intraspecific<tei:lb/>variation may occur (Smithers, 1956). The cocoon of pimplines is generally only rudimentary<tei:lb/>though some polysphinctines spin thick and very characteristic ones (Figs 98, 99). Diapause,<tei:lb/>when it occurs, is usually in the prepupal stage though at least one European species aestivates as<tei:lb/>an adult (Cole, 1967).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>As most pimplines incapacitate their hosts they need little physiological or cytological<tei:lb/>compatibility with the latter as do many specialist endoparasites (Salt, 1968). Consequently<tei:lb/>pimplines often utilize a very wide range of hosts. This is particularly true for some Pimplini<tei:lb/>which search disturbed habitats for pupae. For example Echthromorpha intricatoria has been<tei:lb/>reared from pupae of Anthelidae, Lymantriidae, Noctuidae and Nymphalidae. Many species of<tei:lb/>Ephialtini and some Theroniini are specialized, not immunologically, but in their adaptations<tei:lb/>for reaching particular hosts. In such groups the apex of the ovipositor is often characteristic of a<tei:lb/>species (Townes &amp; Townes, 1960). Although these morphological adaptations are associated<tei:lb/>with a particular niche (e.g. decaying wood), within each niche quite different species may be<tei:lb/>used as hosts. For example, one Nearctic species of Dolichomitus is restricted to timber-borers<tei:lb/>in certain trees, but will parasitize larvae of Buprestidae, Cerambycidae and Sesiidae if available<tei:lb/>(Townes &amp; Townes, 1960). Pimplinae not only often utilize a wide range of hosts, but many<tei:lb/>attack a variety of different-sized hosts. Consequently size variation in adults of some species<tei:lb/>may be very large. For example, females of Rhyssa persuasoria in Europe have a fore wing<tei:lb/>length range of 9 to 25 mm. Females of some species are facultatively arrhenotokous, laying<tei:lb/>fertilized (i.e. female) eggs in large hosts and unfertilized (male) eggs in smaller ones. Thus the<tei:lb/>females are, on average, larger than the males.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The evolutionary biology of the Pimplinae is a fascinating subject, and although incompletely<tei:lb/>known both from phylogenetic and biological standpoints, more information exists for the group<tei:lb/>than probably any other ichneumonid subfamily. The ancestral ichneumonoids are believed to<tei:lb/>have been parasites of wood-borers (Konigsmann, 1978) such as cerambycid or siricid larvae.<tei:lb/>Such habits are retained by a number of structurally rather primitive ephialtines. The Rhyssini<tei:lb/>and Poemeniini are biologically similar though the adults are somewhat more specialized<tei:lb/>morphologically than ephialtines. They are difficult to place phylogenetically (each being<tei:lb/>characterized by several autapormorphies) but may represent early branches from the ephial-<tei:lb/>tine stock. Several evolutionary lineages of ephialtines have given rise to single species that<tei:lb/>parasitize aculeates nesting in old borings in timber (e.g. Jussila &amp; Kapyla, 1975). Such a switch<tei:lb/>from timber-boring larvae to larvae (usually aculeate) inhabiting timber borings is a common<tei:lb/>feature in ichneumonids and occurs amongst labenines (Gauld, 1983) and gabuniine mesoste-<tei:lb/>nines (Gupta &amp; Gupta, 1983). A large number of species related to ephialtine parasites of<tei:lb/>timber-borers have become associated with endopterygotes that pupate on cracks in trees,<tei:lb/>under bark etc. (Rosenberg, 1934; Perkins, 1942). Further evolutionary change has followed</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>242 I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>one of three major biological pathways - progressive association with cocoons; association with<tei:lb/>borers in non-ligneous or partially lignified tissue; or specialization on more or less exposed<tei:lb/>hosts. Whilst in evolutionary terms the latter may have been derived from either of the former<tei:lb/>these different biological adaptations represent three alternative areas of specialization for<tei:lb/>pimplines. One apparent phyletic lineage of Ephialtini (the Tromatobia-subgroup) has special-<tei:lb/>ized in being cocoon parasites. Oviposition is apparently stimulated by the presence of silk on<tei:lb/>which the ichneumonid alights prior to probing for a host. Several species in this group are<tei:lb/>gregarious (Iwata, 1961). Amongst the hosts used are psychid larvae, various lepidopterous<tei:lb/>cocoons and also spider egg-sacs. The polysphinctines are probably derived from this lineage.<tei:lb/>Presumably the Tromatobia-subgroup arose from ephialtines that probed for cocoons through<tei:lb/>bark or other plant tissue.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Other ephialtines attack borers in non-lignified or partially lignified tissue such as Pseudopim-<tei:lb/>pla, which attacks cephids (Bruzzese, 1982) mining Rubus stems, and Alophosternum, which<tei:lb/>parasitizes leaf miners (Townes, 1969). Many Scambus species attack hosts of this type. One<tei:lb/>European species attacks immature larvae of a bud-mining tortricid (Winter, 1979) whilst<tei:lb/>another species probably attacks gall-forming Diptera in reed beds. Some species are gregarious<tei:lb/>(Iwata, 1961).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The species that attack fairly exposed hosts include the majority of Pimplini. They are<tei:lb/>endoparasitic (a common feature of parasitoids of exposed hosts) but exhibit few of the<tei:lb/>specialized immunological mechanisms of more advanced endoparasitic ichneumonids. The<tei:lb/>host is little more than 'a piece of meat' and is either virtually killed by envenomation prior to<tei:lb/>oviposition or has its cephalic region destroyed at the earliest opportunity by the newly hatched<tei:lb/>parasitoid larva (Fiihrer &amp; Kilincer, 1972). One genus of Pimplini, Itoplectis, includes a number<tei:lb/>of species that are facultative hyperparasites. A similar adaptation occurs in Australia in some<tei:lb/>species of Theronia, a genus whose species exhibit a considerable range of biological adapta-<tei:lb/>tions. It is possible that all Theronia species are parasites of hymenopterous larvae, either of<tei:lb/>Parasitica as hyperparasites through Lepidoptera, or in aculeate nests (Gupta, 1962; Short,<tei:lb/>1978). A rather similar host range is found in the family Trigonalidae (Clausen, 1940). It is quite<tei:lb/>possible that all of the Delomeristini are parasitic only on Hymenoptera and the initially<tei:lb/>apparently heterogeneous facies presented by the genera of this group is an indirect result of<tei:lb/>specialization on different hymenopterous hosts, such as sawflies in the case of Delomerista<tei:lb/>(Furniss &amp; Dowden, 1941), rhyssines in the case of Pseudorhyssa (Spradbery, 1969), and<tei:lb/>stem-nesting aculeates in the case ofPerithous (Danks, 1971).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A great deal of additional work needs to be undertaken to develop this subject. Particularly<tei:lb/>valuable would be studies of the comparative anatomy of the reproductive systems, analyses of<tei:lb/>venoms and studies of larval morphology. Biological observations on the poorly known<tei:lb/>Australian fauna would also be invaluable, especially if they involved such virtually unstudied<tei:lb/>genera as Alophopimpla, Acropimpla, Camptotypus, Parvipimpla and Epirhyssa. One of the<tei:lb/>principal aims of this work is to stimulate such investigations.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to genera of Pimplinae occurring in Australia</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The tribal groupings in the Pimplinae are based to a large extent on structures of the final instar larvae<tei:lb/>(Finlayson, 1967; Short, 1978). The characters used to place adults in tribes are subtle, subject to variation<tei:lb/>and difficult for an inexperienced person to appreciate. For ease of identification the key given below is<tei:lb/>direct to genus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 Mesoscutum without sharp, transverse wrinkles or rugae; last visible tergite of $ gaster not</tei:p>
