         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>244 I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tribe EPHIALTINI<tei:lb/>(= Pimplini sensu Townes)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Ephialtini is undoubtedly a paraphyletic assemblage as it is the group from within which the<tei:lb/>Polysphinctini has arisen. It also is possibly paraphyletic with respect to the Pimplini. As a<tei:lb/>paraphyletic 'group' the Ephialtini can only be characterized by its lack of the apomorphic<tei:lb/>features of other tribes, but like that notorious paraphyletic taxon, the Reptilia, the Ephialtini is<tei:lb/>both practically recognizable and a functionally useful category (vide Charig, 1981).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ephialtines are mostly moderately large to large insects and usually possess an ovipositor that<tei:lb/>is as long as or longer than the gaster; this organ is slender, parallel-sided and tapered only<tei:lb/>apically, unlike that of the Polysphinctini which is elongately tapered. The fore wing may or may<tei:lb/>not lack 3r-m (this vein is usually present in the Pimplini) and the first abscissa of Cu\ in the hind<tei:lb/>wing is more than 0-6 times the length of cu-a (it is less than 0-5 in Pimplini). Ephialtines do not<tei:lb/>have specialized pulvilli as do polysphinctines, nor the reduced larval hypostoma characteristic<tei:lb/>of pimplines.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Currently 32 genera are recognized; these are divisible into four generic groups, the<tei:lb/>Ephialtes-group, the Alophosternum-group, the Pseudopimpla-group and the Camptotypus-<tei:lb/>group. The Ephialtes-group, characterized by a more or less complete occipital carina and basal<tei:lb/>lobes present on all female claws, comprises two ill-defined subgroups, the Ephialtes-subgroup<tei:lb/>with a medianly dipped occipital carina, flat clypeus, centrally membranous female subgenital<tei:lb/>plate and less oblique ovipositor teeth, and the Tromatobia-subgroup with a less obviously<tei:lb/>dipped occipital carina, more convex clypeus, fairly evenly sclerotized female subgenital plate<tei:lb/>and a very oblique proximal tooth on the ovipositor. The former subgroup is primarily Holarctic<tei:lb/>and Neotropical and contains 15 genera, including Scambus, Ephialtes and Dolichomitus. It is<tei:lb/>not represented in Australia. The Tromatobia-subgroup is cosmopolitan and contains seven<tei:lb/>genera, three of which, Acropimpla, Sericopimpla and Zaglyptus, occur in Australia. Two other<tei:lb/>genera, Tromatobia and Clistopyga, occur in New Guinea. The other three generic groups differ<tei:lb/>from the Ephialtes-group in having a broadly incomplete occipital carina. The monobasic<tei:lb/>Pseudopimpla-group is Palaearctic whilst the Alophosternum-group, which contains two<tei:lb/>genera, is primarily eastern Palaearctic and Nearctic. Only the Camptoty pus -group, charac-<tei:lb/>terized by the incomplete occipital carina, glabrous mesosternum and long straight ovipositor, is<tei:lb/>represented in Australia. This group is tropicopolitan. It comprises seven genera, three of which<tei:lb/>are Old World/Australian and the remaining four are Neotropical. Of the Palaeotropical<tei:lb/>genera, Hemipimpla is restricted to Africa, Parvipimpla to Australia, whilst Camptotypus is<tei:lb/>Indo- Australian.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Biologically there is some difference between the five groupings listed above, though little is<tei:lb/>known of the Camptoty pus-group. The Alophosternum-group is associated with leaf-mining<tei:lb/>larvae (Cushman, 1933), whilst Pseudopimpla is a parasite of cephid stem-miners (Bruzzese,<tei:lb/>1982). The Ephialtes-subgroup is parasitic on a variety of holometabolous insect larvae and<tei:lb/>pupae concealed in plant tissue (e.g. stem-borers, fruit-miners); oviposition is thus through the<tei:lb/>plant tissue. The Tromatobia-subgroup is parasitic in 'cocoons' of various kinds, including<tei:lb/>psychid larval cases, lepidopterous cocoons and spider egg-sacs. Not only is oviposition through<tei:lb/>silk but, unlike the previous subgroup, the adult ichneumonid is usually in contact with the silk.<tei:lb/>Many members of this group are gregarious.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gauld (1984) recognized five ephialtine genera as occurring in Australia; a species of<tei:lb/>Liotryphon, purported to have been introduced from Europe was in fact not liberated in<tei:lb/>Australia (Froggatt, 1909). The majority of Australian ephialtines occur in tropical Queensland<tei:lb/>where they are encountered fairly frequently. Some species of Sericopimpla and Zaglyptus are<tei:lb/>more widely distributed, particularly in the wet sclerophyll forests of the eastern part of the<tei:lb/>continent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ACROPIMPLA Townes</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Selenaspis Roman, 1910: 191. Type-species: Hemipimpla alboscutellaris Szepligeti, by original designa-<tei:lb/>tion. [Homonym of SelenaspisBletker, 1858.]</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>ICHNEUMONIDAE OF AUSTRALIA 245</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acropimpla Townes, 1960ft: 159. Type-species: Charitopimpla leucostoma Cameron, by original designa-<tei:lb/>tion.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Medium-sized species, fore wing length 7-8 mm; clypeus with a median apical notch; eye weakly indented<tei:lb/>opposite antennal socket (Fig. 5); malar space 0-3 times as long as basal mandibular width; occipital carina<tei:lb/>complete. Epomia short; epicnemial carina strong; propodeum without carinae, spiracle circular. Female<tei:lb/>with claws basally lobate; fore wing with 3r-m present, enclosing a broad rhombic areolet; hind wing with<tei:lb/>first abscissa of Cu\ longer than cu-a. Lateromedian carina of tergite 1 not reaching to end of segment;<tei:lb/>tergites 2-4 with lateromedian swellings; ovipositor straight, projecting beyond apex of gaster by 1-5 times<tei:lb/>length of hind tibia. Wings infumate with pterostigma black.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. A moderately large genus most species of which occur in the Oriental region. A few<tei:lb/>are Holarctic and some Ethiopian. Gupta &amp; Tikar (1978) recognized 26 Oriental species but<tei:lb/>none from south-east of Mindanao.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I have seen two apparent species from east of Weber's line, one from New Guinea and a<tei:lb/>second, closely related one from Australia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acropimpla species are known to parasitize a variety of Microlepidoptera, especially Pyrali-<tei:lb/>dae (Gupta &amp; Tikar, 1978). Oviposition may be through silk (Townes, 1969).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acropimpla xantha sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig- 5)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Face very weakly convex, sparsely punctate; malar space 0-3 times basal mandibular width; occipital carina<tei:lb/>very weakly dipped mediodorsally. Mesoscutum with notauli fairly strong, reaching posteriorly to near<tei:lb/>level of centre of tegulae; scutellum smooth, convex; mesopleuron highly polished, virtually impunctate<tei:lb/>with subtegular ridge normally convex; metapleuron smooth and polished, submetapleural carina present<tei:lb/>but only slightly raised. Propodeum abruptly declivous, smooth and polished; lateromedian longitudinal<tei:lb/>carinae absent, pleural carina present. Fore wing with cu-a opposite base of Rs&amp;M; hind wing with first<tei:lb/>abscissa of Cu\ longer than cu-a, distal abscissa of Cui present but weak. Gaster with tergite 1 with<tei:lb/>lateromedian carinae extending about 0-8 times length; lateral carina present, virtually complete except for<tei:lb/>petiolar spiracle; tergites 2+ with weak tubercles, with coarse shallow punctures on tergite 2, the punctures<tei:lb/>on succeeding tergites progressively more obscure; subgenital plate centrally membranous; ovipositor<tei:lb/>projecting beyond apex of gaster by 1-5 times length of hind tibia, its most proximal tooth oblique,<tei:lb/>subtending an angle of 30 to shaft.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female yellow, scape dorsally, pedicel and flagellum entirely, frons above antennal insertion, vertex and<tei:lb/>most of genae above lower margin of eye, shining black; ovipositor sheath black. Wings strongly infumate,<tei:lb/>pterostigma dark brown. Male unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. A distinctive species easily recognized from all other Indo- Australian species by its<tei:lb/>colour. It belongs to group A of Gupta &amp; Tikar (1978), a group of species characterized by the<tei:lb/>smooth convex propodeum.<tei:lb/>A. xantha is only known from a single specimen collected in tropical Queensland.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST RECORDS. None.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED<tei:lb/>Holotype 9, Australia: Queensland, Atherton, ii.1975 (Howden) (TC).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>CAMPTOTYPUS Kriechbaumer</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Camptotypus Kriechbaumer, 1889: 311. Type-species: Camptotypus sellatus Kriechbaumer, by subsequent</tei:p>
         <tei:p>designation, Viereck, 1914: 27.<tei:lb/>Erythropimpla Ashmead, 1900a: 57. Type-species: Erythropimpla abbottii Ashmead (= Pimpla olynthia</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cameron), by original designation.<tei:lb/>Trichiothecus Cameron, 1903: 136. Type-species: Trichiothecus ruficeps Cameron (= Ichneumon rugosus</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DeGeer), by monotypy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Medium-sized to moderately large species, fore wing length 9-14 mm; clypeus with a median apical notch;<tei:lb/>eye weakly indented opposite antennal socket; malar space 0-5-1-0 times as long as basal mandibular<tei:lb/>width; occipital carina obsolescent or absent dorsally, present laterally and ventrally. Epomia weak;<tei:lb/>epicnemial carina present, not strong; propodeum virtually without carinae, spiracle subcircular (Fig. 9).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>246 I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female with claws basally lobate; fore wing with 3r-m present, enclosing a broad, rhombic areolet; hind<tei:lb/>wing with first abscissa of Cu t longer than cu-a . Lateromedian carinae of tergite 1 reaching end of segment ;<tei:lb/>tergites 2, 3 and to a lesser extent 4 with diagonal furrows delimiting raised central areas; tergites 3-5<tei:lb/>sometimes with a small incision laterally so posterolateral corner is produced as a blunt tooth; ovipositor<tei:lb/>straight, projecting beyond apex of gaster by 2-2-3-2 times length of hind tibia. Wings strongly infumate<tei:lb/>with pterostigma yellow.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Camptotypus is a moderately large genus containing 24 recognized species restricted<tei:lb/>to the Indo-Australian region. It is very closely related to the Afrotropical genus Hemipimpla<tei:lb/>Saussure. Although now treated as separate genera (Gupta &amp; Tikar, 1978; Gauld, 1984), some<tei:lb/>authors (e.g. Townes, 1969) consider Hemipimpla a subgenus of Camptotypus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gauld (1984) listed five nominate species as occurring in Australia but remarked that two<tei:lb/>names, sellatus Kriechbaumer and bicolor Kriechbaumer, had remained unassociated as the<tei:lb/>whereabouts of the type-material was not known (Gupta &amp; Tikar, 1978). Study of the species<tei:lb/>now known to occur in Australia, and examination of Kriechbaumer 's original descriptions, has<tei:lb/>enabled these two species to be identified with reasonable certainty and this has necessitated<tei:lb/>synonymizing two of the other names.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Camptotypus species are conspicuous ichneumonids that can be observed flying in clearings in<tei:lb/>rain forest. Their colour pattern and mottled wings are reminiscent of some braconines and I<tei:lb/>have collected both flying in the same clearing. Few host records exist for the genus. One Asian<tei:lb/>species have been reared from Hyblaea sp. (Lepidoptera: Hyblaeidae) (Sonan, 1930), whilst<tei:lb/>one African species of Hemipimpla parasitizes an Epicampoptera (Lepidoptera: Drepanidae)<tei:lb/>(LePelley, 1954); a second species has been reared from Belonogaster nests (Hymenoptera:<tei:lb/>Vespidae) (Keeping &amp; Crewe, 1983).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to Australian species of Camptotypus</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 Hind tibia strongly flattened and broadened so it is less than 6-0 times as long as apically broad</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 55); tergite 4 of gaster closely punctate, the punctures virtually contiguous (Fig. 63); $</tei:p>
         <tei:p>with ovipositor 2-2-2-6 times as long as hind tibia bicolor Kriechbaumer (p. 246)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hind tibia subcylindrical, not obviously flattened, at least 7-0 times as long as apically broad<tei:lb/>(Fig. 54); tergite 4 or gaster more sparsely punctate, the punctures separated by at least 0-5<tei:lb/>times their own diameters (Fig. 64); $ with ovipositor 2-8-3-2 times as long as hind tibia 2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 Gaster more or less entirely black, or with tergite 1 brownish; head dorsally whitish yellow; hind</tei:p>
         <tei:p>legs black sellatus Kriechbaumer (p. 248)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gaster with anterior and posterior tergites brownish, the 9 w ith tergites 3 and 4, the<tei:lb/>Cf with tergites 4-6 blackish or infuscate; head dorsally black; hind legs brown, only tarsus<tei:lb/>blackish lachesis (Morley) (p. 247)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Camptotypus bicolor Kriechbaumer<tei:lb/>(Figs 55, 63)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Camptotypus bicolor Kriechbaumer, 1889: 311. Holotype $ , AUSTRALIA (depository unknown).<tei:lb/>Hemipimpla atropos Morley, 1914: 94. Lectotype 9, AUSTRALIA (BMNH), designated by Townes et al.,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1961: 21 [examined]. Syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Camptotypus (Camptotypus) atropos (Morley) Townes etal., 1961: 21.<tei:lb/>Camptotypus atropos atropos (Morley) Gupta &amp; Tikar, 1978: 213.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fore wing length 12-14 mm ; upper tooth of mandible slightly broader than the lower but approximately the<tei:lb/>same length. Mesoscutum with notauli strongly impressed anteriorly, reaching to level of centre of tegulae;<tei:lb/>submetapleural carina fairly strongly broadened and thickened anteriorly; propodeum abruptly declivous,<tei:lb/>posteriorly slightly convex. Hind tibia less than 6-0 times as long as maximally broad, flattened, with spurs<tei:lb/>slightly shorter than apical breadth (Fig. 55). Tergite 1 of gaster in profile dorsally centrally angulate, the<tei:lb/>surface of the petiole and postpetiole meeting at about 130, in dorsal aspect with carinae extending to<tei:lb/>posterior margin, the area between them smooth, with scattered punctures posteriorly; tergites 3 and 4<tei:lb/>centrally coarsely and very closely punctate (Fig. 63); posterolateral corners of tergites 3-5 slightly<tei:lb/>truncated, not developed into teeth; ovipositor projecting beyond apex of gaster by 2-2-2-6 times length of<tei:lb/>hind tibia.<tei:lb/>Female and male head, alitrunk, tergites 1, 2 and often 3 of gaster yellowish brown; flagellum brown,</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>ICHNEUMONIDAE OF AUSTRALIA 247</tei:p>
         <tei:p>centrally infuscate, distally pale; legs orange, hind tarsus sometimes infuscate; remainder of gaster<tei:lb/>blackish. Wings strongly infumate, clear at extreme proximal end and below pterostigma; pterostigma<tei:lb/>yellow.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. C. bicolor has previously remained as an unrecognized species as the location of the<tei:lb/>type is unknown (Gupta &amp; Tikar, 1978). However, Kriechbaumer's original description leaves<tei:lb/>little doubt as to its identity. The phrase 'Fulvis . . . abdomine basi excepta . . . nigris' clearly<tei:lb/>identifies it as this species and although not all specimens have the hind tarsus black some do. C.<tei:lb/>lachesis, which to some extent resembles this species, is unlikely to be conspecific with C. bicolor<tei:lb/>as in lachesis the head is black dorsally. Kriechbaumer does not state head colour except<tei:lb/>by the general statement 'fulvis'. Furthermore, the gaster of lachesis is fulvous anteriorly and<tei:lb/>posteriorly.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gupta &amp; Tikar (1978) recognized three subspecies on minor colour differences, but for the<tei:lb/>present these are ignored as one may expect colour variation in any sexually reproducing species<tei:lb/>that has a fairly wide and discontinuous geographical distribution.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The rather shortened, flattened hind tibia and tarsus make C. bicolor one of the most<tei:lb/>distinctive species of Camptotypus .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This species is uncommon in Australia; it also occurs in the Moluccas, New Guinea and New<tei:lb/>Britain (Gupta &amp; Tikar, 1978).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST RECORDS. None.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Australia: 1 $ (lectotype ofatropos), Queensland, Mackay (Turner) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Australia: 1 $, Northern Territory, Daly River Mission, x.1974 (Hutchinson) (ANIC); 2 $, Queens-<tei:lb/>land, Redlynch, xi.1938 (Sternitzky) (BMNH); 3 $ (paralectotypes) , same data as lectotype (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Camptotypus lachesis (Morley)<tei:lb/>(Fig. 54)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hemipimpla lachesis Morley, 1914: 94. Lectotype 9&gt; AUSTRALIA (BMNH), designated by Townes et al.,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1961: 23 [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Camptotypus (Camptotypus) lachesis (Morley) Townes etal. , 1961: 23.<tei:lb/>Camptotypus lachesis (Morley); Gupta &amp; Tikar, 1978: 209.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fore wing length 9-13 mm; upper tooth of mandible slightly broader than the lower, of more or less the<tei:lb/>same length. Mesoscutum with notauli strongly impressed anteriorly, reaching to level of centre of tegulae;<tei:lb/>submetapleural carina anteriorly parallel-sided, posteriorly evenly tapered; propodeum abruptly decli-<tei:lb/>vous, posteriorly biconcave. Hind tibia cylindrical, about 7-0 times as long as apically broad, with spurs<tei:lb/>slightly longer than apical breadth (Fig. 54). Tergite 1 of gaster in profile dorsally from fairly abruptly<tei:lb/>rounded to angulate, in dorsal aspect with carinae complete to posterior margin of segment, the area<tei:lb/>between them smooth, with scattered punctures posteriorly; tergites 3 and 4 centrally coarsely punctate,<tei:lb/>the punctures separated by about 0-5 or more times their own diameter; posterolateral corners of tergites<tei:lb/>3-5 slightly truncated, not developed into teeth; ovipositor projecting beyond apex of gaster by 3-0-3-2<tei:lb/>times length of hind tibia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female head dorsally black, ventrally yellow; antenna black, distal apices yellowish brown; alitrunk,<tei:lb/>tergites 1-3 and 6+ of gaster and legs brownish orange; hind tarsi and tergites 3 and 4 of gaster black. Wings<tei:lb/>infumate distal to about cu-a except for an area below pterostigma; pterostigma yellow. Male similar to<tei:lb/>female but with tergites 4-6 infuscate, remainder of gaster fulvous.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species is quite easily recognized on account of its colour pattern, especially the<tei:lb/>dorsally black head and centrally black gaster. The holotype is labelled 'Victoria' but I doubt<tei:lb/>that this is correct as all other specimens of Camptotypus are tropical. However, I have<tei:lb/>previously had no reason to doubt the veracity of French's locality data.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>C. lachesis is otherwise known only from Northern Territory and north Queensland.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Australia: 1 $ (lectotype), 'Victoria' (French) (BMNH); 1 cf (paralectotype), Queensland, Mackay<tei:lb/>(Turner) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Australia: 14 $ , 5 O" , Northern Territory, Queensland (AM; ANIC; BMNH; TC) (Map 4).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>248 I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Camptotypus sellatus Kriechbaumer<tei:lb/>(Figs 9, 64)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Camptotypus sellatus Kriechbaumer, 1889: 311. Holotype $, AUSTRALIA (depository unknown).<tei:lb/>Erythropimpla flaviceps Cameron, 1911a: 206. Lectotype 9 &gt; AUSTRALIA (ZMA), designated by Townes et</tei:p>
         <tei:p>al., 1961: 22. [Junior secondary homonym of Camptotypus flaviceps (Smith).] Syn. n.<tei:lb/>Hemipimpla clotho Morley, 1914: 93. Lectotype $, AUSTRALIA (BMNH), designated by Townes et a/.,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1961: 22 [examined]. Syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Camptotypus (Camptotypus) clotho (Morley) Townes etal. , 1961: 22.<tei:lb/>Camptotypus (Camptotypus) flaviceps (Cameron) Townes et al. , 1961: 22.<tei:lb/>Camptotypus (Camptotypus) sellatus Kriechbaumer; Townes et al. , 1961 : 24.<tei:lb/>Camptotypus flaviceps (Cameron); Gupta &amp; Tikar, 1978: 204.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fore wing length 13-14 mm; upper tooth of mandible slightly broader and longer than the lower.<tei:lb/>Mesoscutum with notauli weakly impressed anteriorly; submetapleural carina quite narrow, slightly<tei:lb/>broadened anteriorly; propodeum abruptly declivous, posteriorly rather flat. Hind tibia subcylindrical,<tei:lb/>about 7-0 times as long as maximally broad, with spurs longer than apical breadth. Tergite 1 of gaster in<tei:lb/>profile dorsally convex, without a central angulation, in dorsal aspect with carinae extending more or less to<tei:lb/>hind margin, the area between them smooth, at most with superficial punctures posteriorly; tergites 3 and 4<tei:lb/>centrally with large punctures separated by 0-5-1-0 times their own diameters (Fig. 64); posterolateral<tei:lb/>corners of tergites 3-5 slightly incised, produced into blunt teeth; ovipositor projecting beyond apex of<tei:lb/>gaster by 2-8-3-2 times length of hind tibia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female and male head whitish yellow; flagellum blackish, often with scape reddish brown; alitrunk and<tei:lb/>anterior two pairs of legs orange brown; gaster and hind legs black. Wings strongly and relatively uniformly<tei:lb/>infumate; pterostigma yellow.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>VARIATION. In some specimens tergite 1 of the gaster is reddish brown; the mid tarsus may be<tei:lb/>infuscate. A small hyaline area may be present below the pterostigma. One New Guinea<tei:lb/>specimen has the propodeum strongly infuscate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. C. sellatus has previously remained as an unrecognized species because the location of<tei:lb/>the type is unknown (Gupta &amp; Tikar, 1978; Gauld, 1984). Only three species of Camptotypus<tei:lb/>seem to occur in Australia, and as the type-locality of sellatus is given as Australia (Kriech-<tei:lb/>baumer, 1889) presumably the name must refer to one of them. Kriechbaumer's original<tei:lb/>description states 'pedibus posticis et abdomine nigris' and this is the only Australian species that<tei:lb/>has the hind legs and gaster black. This species has previously been known under the name C.<tei:lb/>flaviceps (Cameron) (Gupta &amp; Tikar, 1978), despite the fact thai flaviceps (Cameron) is a junior<tei:lb/>secondary homonym of flaviceps (Smith). The fact that flaviceps (Smith) is a rejected name as it<tei:lb/>is a junior primary homonym of Pimpla flaviceps Brulle does not affect its availability for<tei:lb/>purposes of secondary homonomy so therefore Gupta &amp; Tikar (1978) should have used clotho<tei:lb/>(Morley) as the name for this species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Structurally C. sellatus is very similar to C. basalis Cameron, a New Guinea species. Probably<tei:lb/>basalis is only a colour variation of sellatus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In Australia C. sellatus is easily recognized on account of its colour pattern. In profile tergite 1<tei:lb/>of the gaster is dorsally more evenly rounded than either other Australian species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>C. sellatus occurs in New Guinea and tropical Queensland.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST RECORDS. In New Guinea this species was found 'attacking larva on leaf of Cassia grandis'<tei:lb/>(BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Australia: 1 $ (lectotype of clotho), Queensland, Cairns, Hi. 1902 (BMNH); 2 $, same data (BMNH);<tei:lb/>6 $, 6 C?, Mackay (Turner) (BMNH) (all paralectotypes).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Australia: 13 $, 3 d", Northern Territory, Queensland (AM; ANIC; BMNH; TC) (Map 3). Papua New<tei:lb/>Guinea: 3 $ (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>ICHNEUMONIDAE OF AUSTRALIA 249</tei:p>
         <tei:p>PARVIPIMPLA Gauld<tei:lb/>Parvipimpla Gauld, 1984: 67. Type-species: Parvipimpla minuta Gauld, by original designation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lower face subquadrate; clypeus flat, apically bilobed with a median apical notch; apical margin of clypeus<tei:lb/>thin ; malar space shorter than basal mandibular width ; mandibles of moderate length , weakly tapered with<tei:lb/>upper tooth slightly the longer. Occipital carina absent. Antennae rather short, those of male without<tei:lb/>tyloids.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Alitrunk highly polished, very sparsely punctate and with only scattered hairs; epomia present but short;<tei:lb/>mesoscutum in profile abruptly rounded, notauli strongly impressed, reaching back to level of centre of<tei:lb/>tegulae; epicnemial carina absent; propodeum without carinae; submetapleural carina absent.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>All tarsal claws of female with conspicuous basal lobe, those of male simple; distal tarsal segments<tei:lb/>slightly broadened.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fore wing with 3r-m absent; cu-a more or less opposite base ofRs&amp;M. Hind wing with distal abscissa of<tei:lb/>Cui present; first abscissa of Cui about 0-6 times length of cu-a.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gaster smooth and highly polished; tergite 1 relatively long, without obvious lateromedian longitudinal<tei:lb/>carinae; tergite 2 with oblique grooves cutting off anterior corners and a pair of weaker diagonal<tei:lb/>impressions posteriorly cutting off hind corners so that the centre of the tergite is a convex rhombus;<tei:lb/>tergites 3 and 4 with grooves on posterior 6 ; hind margin of tergites 3-5 incised , the membranous incision<tei:lb/>narrow medially, broadest close to lateral margin but not extending laterally right to corner. Male<tei:lb/>subgenital plate transverse, simple; female with ovipositor about as long as gaster, cylindrical, with a nodus<tei:lb/>and with about seven strong oblique teeth on lower valve.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Parvipimpla belongs to the Camptotypus genus-group (Townes, 1969), a group<tei:lb/>represented in the Indo-Australian region by only this genus and Camptotypus. The absence of<tei:lb/>3r-m, lack of epicnemial carina and long cu-a in the hind wing serve to distinguish Parvipimpla<tei:lb/>from Camptotypus.<tei:lb/>A single endemic Australian species is known. Nothing is known of the biology of this insect.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Parvipimpla petita Gauld<tei:lb/>Parvipimpla petita Gauld, 1984: 68. Holotype $, AUSTRALIA (DPIQ) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fore wing length 6-7 mm. Head highly polished with few scattered punctures; ocelli forming a nearly<tei:lb/>equilateral triangle; flagellum of female with 20 segments, male with 19. Alitrunk highly polished, almost<tei:lb/>without punctures and with long pale sparse hairs. Legs with conspicuous long hairs. Gaster smooth and<tei:lb/>polished with a few minute hair-bearing punctures posteriorly and laterally on the tergites.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female head , alitrunk and anterior two pairs of legs reddish brown ; pedicel , flagellum , tergites of gaster ,<tei:lb/>hind tibia and tarsus and ovipositor sheath black; remainder of hind leg blackish red; membranous incision<tei:lb/>of tergites 3+ white. Wings infumate, pterostigma blackish. Male similar except face white, all coxae<tei:lb/>yellowish brown, hind femur and tibia yellowish with indistinct infumation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The striking colour pattern is like that of many other similar-sized Australian<tei:lb/>Parasitica (e.g. Eriostethus, one species of Philogalleria, some Braconinae etc.). It is character-<tei:lb/>istic of Australia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST RECORDS. None.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Australia: 1 $ (holotype), New South Wales, Urbenville, Tooloom scrub, 22-23. iii. 1975 (Cantrell)<tei:lb/>(DPIQ); 1 cf (paratype), Queensland, Mt Nebo, ii. (TC).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>SERICOPIMPLA Kriechbaumer</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Sericopimpla Kriechbaumer, 1895: 135. Type-species: Pimpla sericata Kriechbaumer, by monotypy.<tei:lb/>Charitopimpla Cameron, 1902: 48. Type-species: Charitopimplaflavobalteata Cameron, by monotypy.<tei:lb/>Philopsyche Cameron, 1905: 137. Type-species: Philopsyche albobalteata Cameron (= Pimpla sagrae<tei:lb/>Snellen van Vollenhoven), by monotypy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Moderately large species, fore wing length 11-15 mm; clypeus with median apical notch; eye large, strongly<tei:lb/>indented opposite antennal socket (Fig. 4); malar space very short; occipital carina complete. Epomia<tei:lb/>strong; epicnemial carina complete; propodeum without distinct carinae except laterally (Fig. 10);<tei:lb/>propodeal spiracle circular. Female with claws basally lobate; fore wing with 3r-m present, enclosing</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>250 I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>triangular areolet; first abscissa of Cu\ in hind wing, longer than cu-a (Fig. 8). Lateromedian carinae of<tei:lb/>tergite 1 not reaching to posterior margin; tergites 2-4 of gaster with lateromedian swellings; ovipositor<tei:lb/>slightly decurved, projecting beyond apex of gaster by 1 -8-2-2 times length of hind tibia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Sericopimpla is a moderately large Palaeotropical genus containing 13 Indo-Austra-<tei:lb/>lian species and one widespread Afrotropical species. One of the Oriental species extends as far<tei:lb/>north as Korea and Japan and in Australia species occur in the temperate south. The species are<tei:lb/>very similar to each other, differing primarily in colour and superficial sculpture, and a number<tei:lb/>may prove to be extreme variants of other, more widespread species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Sericopimpla belongs to the Acropimpla-group of genera (Townes, 1969), species of which<tei:lb/>usually oviposit through silk. As far as is known the hosts of Sericopimpla are psychids. Only the<tei:lb/>biology of one species, the Afrotropical 5. sericata Kriechbaumer (= abdominalis Morley), has<tei:lb/>been studied in detail (Skaife, 1921; Smithers, 1956). This species was observed to repeatedly<tei:lb/>insert its ovipositor into the psychid 'bag' in an attempt to sting the larva. If stung, the larva<tei:lb/>became paralysed and remained alive but immotile. An egg would then be laid either on the host<tei:lb/>larva or else enmeshed in the innermost strands of the 'bag'. After eclosion the parasitoid larva<tei:lb/>commenced feeding, usually on the abdomen of the host. It underwent four or five rapid larval<tei:lb/>instars and then a more protracted final instar. The mature larva is furnished with clusters of<tei:lb/>hooks on the dorsum of the abdominal segments which enable it to move around within the bag.<tei:lb/>Although the Afrotropical species is apparently solitary (and Smithers (1956) observed destruc-<tei:lb/>tion of supernumerary Sericopimpla larvae by the most developed parasitoid larva), at least one<tei:lb/>Oriental species, 5. albicincta (Morley), is gregarious as there is a psychid case (lEumetd) in the<tei:lb/>BMNH from which 10 male and five female specimens emerged.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Three species occur in Australia. One, 5. lutea, is particularly distinctive, both in colour and<tei:lb/>morphology, whilst the other two are structurally similar and seem to be very closely related to<tei:lb/>several Oriental species. These two species are widely distributed in Australia and also occur in<tei:lb/>New Guinea; the third, 5. lutea, is only known from tropical Queensland.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to Australian species of Sericopimpla</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 Alitrunk and gaster predominantly yellow; mesopleuron swollen below subalar prominence;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>scutellum strongly convex in profile (Fig. 61) lutea sp. n. (p. 252)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Alitrunk and gaster black with tegulae and posterior margins of gastral tergites yellow-marked;<tei:lb/>mesopleuron not swollen below subalar prominences ; scutellum almost flat (Fig. 62) 2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 Hind tibia with black band near proximal 0-2; mesoscutum with sparse punctation, the</tei:p>
         <tei:p>punctures widely interspaced (Fig. 57) australis Townes, Townes &amp; Gupta (p. 250)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Hind tibia with proximal 0-6 white, without a proximal black band; mesoscutum densely<tei:lb/>punctate, the punctures interspaced by only about their own diameters (Fig. 56)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>crenator(F.)(p. 251)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Sericopimpla australis Townes, Townes &amp; Gupta<tei:lb/>(Fig. 57)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Philopsyche annulipes Cameron, 1912: 186. Holotype $, AUSTRALIA (BMNH) [examined]. [Secondary</tei:p>
         <tei:p>homonym of Charltopimpla annulipes Cameron, 1905.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Sericopimpla australis Townes et al. , 1961: 17. [Replacement name for annulipes Cameron, 1912.]<tei:lb/>Sericopimpla annulipes (Cameron) Gupta &amp; Tikar, 1978: 176.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fore wing length 1 1-14 mm. Mandible evenly tapered with lower tooth very slightly shorter than the upper;<tei:lb/>lower face elongate; about 0-8 times as broad as long; face sparsely punctate; genae moderately strongly<tei:lb/>narrowed behind eyes. Mesoscutum centrally sparsely and shallowly punctate, the punctures separated by<tei:lb/>more than their own diameters (Fig. 57); scutellum coarsely punctate posteriorly. Mesopleuron quite finely<tei:lb/>punctate, not swollen below subalar prominences. Propodeum centrally smooth, laterally and posteriorly<tei:lb/>closely punctate, with lateromedian carinae vestigial. Tergite 1 of gaster with scattered punctures, tergites<tei:lb/>2-4 fairly closely punctate. Ovipositor projecting beyond apex of gaster by 2-0-2-2 times length of hind<tei:lb/>tibia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Black; scape ventrally in part, palpus, hind corner of pronotum, tegula, anterior two pairs of legs, hind<tei:lb/>trochanter, trochantellus, much of tarsus and hind margin of gastral tergites, yellow; hind tibia whitish</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>ICHNEUMONIDAE OF AUSTRALIA 251</tei:p>
         <tei:p>yellow, distal 0-3 and band near proximal 0-2 black; distal hind tarsal segments blackish. Wings hyaline,<tei:lb/>pterostigma black.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species is structurally very similar to 5. crenator and, although the differences<tei:lb/>given in the key work well for material to hand, I have some doubt as to whether they are really<tei:lb/>distinct. They appear to be synchronous and sympatric and attack, at least some of the time, the<tei:lb/>same host species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5. aus trails is somewhat less common than 5. crenator but it is similarly widely distributed,<tei:lb/>though I have seen no material from Northern Territory, South Australia or Tasmania.<tei:lb/>Although Gupta &amp; Tikar (1978) mentioned that this species occurs in New Guinea they did not<tei:lb/>validate their record by reference to any material or collection. There is in the BMNH a recently<tei:lb/>collected female of this species from Popondetta, Papua New Guinea, confirming that S.<tei:lb/>aus trails occurs on that island.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST RECORDS. Clanla Ignobllls (Walker) (Chadwick &amp; Nikitin, 1976); Hyalarcta huebnerl<tei:lb/>(Westwood) (Chadwick &amp; Nikitin, 1976), both Lepidoptera: Psychidae. In both cases the<tei:lb/>material on which these records were based has been examined in DAR and the identity of the<tei:lb/>ichneumonids confirmed.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Australia: 1 $ (holotype of annulipes) , New South Wales, Mittagong (Froggatt) (BMNH).</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Sericopimpla crenator (F.)<tei:lb/>(Figs 1,56, 62)</tei:p>

         <tei:p>REMARKS. I have seen material from all states except South<tei:lb/>Australia. It is also widely distributed throughout New Guinea and the New Hebrides (Gupta &amp;<tei:lb/>Tikar, 1978).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST RECORDS.          <tei:p>Sericopimpla lutea sp. n.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>REMARKS. A distinctive species on account of its colour pattern. The swollen mesopleuron,<tei:lb/>convex scutellum, broad face and weakly punctate mesoscutum are other characteristic features<tei:lb/>of this species. It is only known to occur in northern Queensland.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>ZAGL YPTUS Foerster</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Zaglyptus Foerster, 1869: 166. Type-species: Polysphincta varipes Gravenhorst, by subsequent designa-<tei:lb/>tion, Woldestedt, 1877: 17.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Medium-sized species, fore wing length 4-8 mm; clypeal margin concave; occipital carina complete.<tei:lb/>Epomia weak; epicnemial carina complete; propodeum without carinae but with lateral subapical<tei:lb/>tubercles (Fig. 11); propodeal spiracle subcircular. Female with claws basally lobate, male with fore femur<tei:lb/>ventrally with a small tubercle near distal end, the area distal to this concave; fore wing with 3r-m absent;<tei:lb/>hind wing with distal abscissa of Cu\ present or absent, if present then with first abscissa of Cui about equal<tei:lb/>in length to cu-a or very slightly shorter, or if absent with Cu\ and cu-a confluent, smoothly arcuate.<tei:lb/>Lateromedian carinae of tergite 1 not reaching to posterior margin; tergite 2 of gaster with oblique grooves<tei:lb/>delineating a central, raised, rhombic area; tergites 3-4 with transverse tubercles; ovipositor straight,<tei:lb/>projecting beyond apex of gaster by about 1-2 times length of hind tibia, with most proximal tooth of lower<tei:lb/>valve with an elongate free tip.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Zaglyptus is a moderately small cosmopolitan genus with nine described species in the<tei:lb/>Indo-Australian region. Two species occur in Australia, Z. glabrinotum and Z. hollowayi. They<tei:lb/>are closely related and belong to the nigrolineatus-group as defined by Gupta (1961). The two<tei:lb/>Australian species seem to be very closely related to the New Guinea species Z. grandis Gupta.<tei:lb/>Zaglyptus species are believed to attack spiders in retreats; the spider is stung to death and the<tei:lb/>ichneumonid larvae are believed to consume both the spider's eggs and body (Nielsen, 1935;<tei:lb/>Townes, 1969). European species have been reared from Clubionidae and Araneidae (Aubert,<tei:lb/>1969).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to Australian species of Zaglyptus</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Zaglyptus glabrinotum (Girault)<tei:lb/>(Figs 11, 59)</tei:p>

Wings hyaline; pterostigma black, proximal and distal<tei:lb/>corner pale.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. A distinctive species easily recognized by the hind wing venation. It appears to be the<tei:lb/>more common of the two Australian species. It is known from Queensland, Northern Territory<tei:lb/>and northern New South Wales.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST RECORDS. None.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Zaglyptus hollowayisp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 60)</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Z. hollowayi is very similar to Z. glabrinotum except for the characters mentioned in the key<tei:lb/>and in having less extensively infuscate hind legs. It is known from forests in Queensland and<tei:lb/>New South Wales.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>254 I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. Australia: 1 9, Queensland, Mt Tambourine, xi.1977 (Galloway) (BMNH); 1 cf , Shipton's<tei:lb/>Flat, x.1980 (Cardale) (ANIC).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tribe POLYSPHINCTINI</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Polysphinctini is a holophyletic group of genera characterized by the possession of enlarged<tei:lb/>pulvilli, inflated tarsal segments and an evenly tapered, very sharply pointed ovipositor. Most<tei:lb/>species lack vein 3r-m in the fore wing. Larval polysphinctines are external parasites of spiders<tei:lb/>and they are furnished with 'holdfast organs' used to maintain the larva on the host (Nielsen,<tei:lb/>1923; Short, 1978). These holdfast organs are single or paired dorsal tubercles covered in curved<tei:lb/>spines. The cocoon of many polysphinctines is unusual in having a small hole in the ventral end<tei:lb/>via which the meconium is voided. The supposedly primitive polysphinctines (e.g. Schizopygd)<tei:lb/>attack spiders in retreats whilst many genera attack free-living araneids. A prospective host is<tei:lb/>stung and immobilized before an egg is attached to the body. Subsequently, the spider recovers<tei:lb/>from envenomation and continues its normal life but with a polysphinctine egg and eventually<tei:lb/>larva developing externally. As the larva grows it is visible as a whitish 'muffler' usually near the<tei:lb/>anterior end of the opisthosoma. The spider host is not killed until the parasite reaches its final<tei:lb/>larval instar (Townes, 1969).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Polysphinctini is a specialized offshoot of the Ephialtini and many steps in the biological<tei:lb/>and morphological evolution of the group are extant (Townes, 1969). This means that it is<tei:lb/>difficult to decide where to delineate the tribe. Larval holdfasts are found in several genera of<tei:lb/>Ephialtini such as Sericopimpla, though this is traditionally regarded as an ephialtine genus<tei:lb/>(Baltazar, 1961; Townes, 1969; Gupta &amp; Tikar, 1978). More controversial is the placement of<tei:lb/>the genera Tromatobia, Zaglyptus and Clistopyga. Some authors (Finlayson, 1967; Gupta &amp;<tei:lb/>Tikar, 1978) place these genera in the Polysphinctini; others (Townes, 1969; Aubert, 1969) treat<tei:lb/>them as ephialtines. Like the Polysphinctini these genera often lack an areolet and are<tei:lb/>associated with spiders, though apparently as carnivores devouring eggs in egg sacs. Unlike the<tei:lb/>polysphinctines none has a specialized tarsus and pulvilli. Tromatobia and Zaglyptus have<tei:lb/>typical ephialtine ovipositors with a parallel-sided shaft abruptly tapering to a point distally . The<tei:lb/>ovipositor of Clistopyga is more like that of a polysphinctine but is finely sculptured, not smooth.<tei:lb/>Although the delineation of the Polysphinctini is somewhat arbitrary it is suggested that the term<tei:lb/>be used for only the genera known (or believed) to attack spiders (rather than their eggs), that<tei:lb/>have modified pulvilli and distal tarsal segments and that possess tapered, polished ovipositors.<tei:lb/>This definition excludes Tromatobia, Zaglyptus and Clistopyga.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>World-wide the Polysphinctini contains 13 genera, four of which, Acrodactyla, Dreisbachia,<tei:lb/>Eriostethus and Zatypota, occur in Australia. Eriostethus is a moderately large genus confined to<tei:lb/>the Indo-Australian region. The other taxa are probably cosmopolitan but they are rather<tei:lb/>infrequently collected and consequently little is known about their distribution other than<tei:lb/>isolated records from widely separated areas.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In Australia polysphinctines are predominantly tropical and moist forest insects. Except for<tei:lb/>some species of Eriostethus, which can be very common in Queensland, most are rather<tei:lb/>uncommon and seldom collected though Malaise traps at suitable sites generally take several<tei:lb/>species in a year. Nielsen (1923) remarks on a high incidence of parasitism being observed<tei:lb/>amongst spiders but I believe this was an exceptional observation. Collecting evidence, based<tei:lb/>mostly on Palaearctic experience, suggests some species may be locally common for a short<tei:lb/>period, then not be seen in numbers for several years. The large number of Dreisbachia taken on<tei:lb/>Black Mountain, Canberra in November-December, 1978 and the subsequent virtual dis-<tei:lb/>appearance of the species (two specimens collected since then despite considerable collecting<tei:lb/>activity) suggests such population fluctuations may occur in Australia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ACRODACTYLA Haliday</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acrodactyla Haliday, 1839: 117 [as a subgenus ofPimpla F.]. Type-species: Pimpla (Acrodactyla) degener</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Haliday, by subsequent designation, Westwood, 1840: 57.<tei:lb/>Acrodactyla Haliday; Westwood, 1840: 57 [raised to genus].</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>ICHNEUMONIDAE OF AUSTRALIA 255</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colpomeria Homgren, 1859: 126. Type-species: Colpomeria laevigata Holmgren (= Ichneumon quadris-</tei:p>
         <tei:p>culptus Gravenhorst), by monotypy.<tei:lb/>Symphylus Foerster, 1871: 105. Type-species: Symphylus hadrodactylus Foerster (= Pimpla (Acrodactyla)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>degener Haliday), by original designation. [Homonym of Symphylus Dallas, 1851.]<tei:lb/>Polemophthorus Schulz, 1911: 22. [Replacement name for Symphylus Foerster.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Small to medium-sized insects, fore wing length 3-6 mm; palp formula 5, 4 or 5, 3; clypeus convex, apically<tei:lb/>slightly flattened; eye surface bare; occipital carina complete. Epomia strong; mesoscutum polished,<tei:lb/>glabrous to sparsely pubescent, with a crest near anterior end of notaulus; epicnemial carina present;<tei:lb/>propodeum in profile long, dorsally with some traces of carinae, often coarsely sculptured. Tarsal claws of<tei:lb/>female basally lobate; hind tibia of female internally uniformly hirsute; fore wing with 3r-m absent; hind<tei:lb/>wing with distal abscissa of Cui present or absent, first abscissa of Cu\ longer than cu-a. Tergites 2-4<tei:lb/>polished, sparsely punctate with weakly defined central rhombic areas; ovipositor straight or slightly<tei:lb/>up-curved, projecting beyond apex of gaster by 0-3-0-6 times length of hind tibia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. A moderate-sized genus with most species in the Holarctic and Oriental regions.<tei:lb/>Townes (1969) recognized three species-groups - the madida-group, the degener-group and the<tei:lb/>quadrisculpta-group. Several authors (e.g. Aubert, 1969; Carlson, 1979) treat the latter group as<tei:lb/>a separate genus, Colpomeria, but intermediates do occur (Townes, 1969). Furthermore, the<tei:lb/>quadrisculpta-group seems to grade into Pterinopus Townes, a Madagascan genus and the status<tei:lb/>of this as a distinct group needs critical re-evaluation in the light of recent collecting in India and<tei:lb/>South East Asia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Four species of Acrodactyla occur in Australia. Two, A. quadrisculpta and A. micans, belong<tei:lb/>to the quadrisculpta-group; A. cursor apparently belongs to the degener-group whilst A. zekhem<tei:lb/>appears to be intermediate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>No hosts are recognized for Australian Acrodactyla species but in Europe species have been<tei:lb/>reared from Araneidae, Linyphiidae and Tetragnathidae (Aubert, 1969). The latter family also<tei:lb/>serves as host for a Nearctic species (Howell &amp; Pienkowski, 1972).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to Australian species of Acrodactyla</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 Ocelli large, the posterior one separated from the eye by about 0-3 times its minimum diameter</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 81); face narrow, its minimum width 0-5-0-6 times distance from apex of clypeus to<tei:lb/>insertion of antenna zekhem sp. n.(p. 257)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- Ocelli not exceptionally large, the posterior one separated from the eye by at least its minimum</tei:p>
         <tei:p>diameter (Fig. 82); face moderately wide, its minimum width 0-7-0-8 times distance from apex<tei:lb/>of clypeus to insertion of antenna</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 Metapleuron fairly smooth, at most with traces of wrinkling; fore and mid femora slender, not</tei:p>
         <tei:p>inflated and specialized ventrally; hind wing with distal abscissa of Cui absent, not even<tei:lb/>represented by an angulation at junction of Cu\ and cu-a (Fig. 79) cursor sp. n. (p. 255)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- Metapleuron coarsely reticulo-rugose (Fig. 85); fore and mid femora inflated, distally con-</tei:p>
         <tei:p>stricted ventrally and with a blunt median ventral tooth (Fig. 80); hind wing with distal<tei:lb/>abscissa of Ci present, at least discernible as a short stub at junction of Cu\ and cu-a (Fig. 78) 3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 Alitrunk entirely black; tergite 1 of gaster rather stout, 1-4-1-5 times as long as posteriorly</tei:p>
         <tei:p>broad; hind leg with third tarsal segment 1 -7-1 -8 times as long as broad</tei:p>
         <tei:p>quadrisculpta (Gravenhorst) (p. 256)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Alitrunk predominantly orange , only propodeum , metapleuron and mesosternum black ; tergite<tei:lb/>1 of gaster slender, 1-7-1-8 times as long as posteriorly broad; hind leg with third tarsal<tei:lb/>segment about 2-0 times as long as broad micans sp. n. (p. 256)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acrodactyla cursor sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 79)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fore wing length 3 mm; face moderately wide, about 0-8 times as broad as long; clypeus apically truncate;<tei:lb/>malar space about 0-8 times basal mandibular width; ocelli small, the lateral one separated from eye by<tei:lb/>about 2-0 times its minimum diameter. Mesopleuron smooth and shining; metapleuron more or less<tei:lb/>smooth, with isolated punctures and traces of wrinkling posteriorly; propodeum fairly smooth with<tei:lb/>lateromedian longitudinal carinae obsolescent. Fore and mid legs with femora cylindrical, slender,<tei:lb/>unspecialized; hind leg with trochantellus bearing a small ridged protuberance ventrally; third hind tarsal</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>256 I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>segment 2-0-2-3 times as long as broad. Hind wing with distal abscissa of Cu\ absent, not even discernible<tei:lb/>as an angulation at junction of Cu\ and cu-a (Fig. 79). Gaster with sternite 1 smooth; tergite 1 about 1-8<tei:lb/>times as long as posteriorly broad, with weak longitudinal carina reaching to near centre, tergites 2-4 with<tei:lb/>weak convex areas; ovipositor straight, projecting beyond the apex of the gaster by 0-4-0-5 times length of<tei:lb/>hind tibia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female head, alitrunk and tergite 1 of gaster black, tergites 2+ blackish brown; fore and mid legs<tei:lb/>brownish orange, coxae, distal ends of trochanters and mouthparts whitish; hind legs brownish, trochanter<tei:lb/>and trochantellus slightly paler. Male unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This small species is easily recognized on account of its dark colour and slender<tei:lb/>femora. It belongs to the degener-group of Townes (1969) though it differs from any described<tei:lb/>species in having only sparse hair on tergite 4. It is only known to occur in Tasmania.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST RECORDS. None.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype $, Australia: Tasmania, Roseberry, iv. (TC).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. Australia: 1 $, Tasmania, Hellyer Gorge, i-ii. (TC); 1 $, Waldheim, 800m, i-ii.<tei:lb/>(BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acrodactyla micans sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 80, 82, 85)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fore wing length 3-6 mm; face moderately wide, 0-7-0-8 times as broad as long; clypeus apically truncate;<tei:lb/>malar space about 1-0 times basal mandibular width; ocelli moderately small, the lateral one separated<tei:lb/>from eye by about 1-0 times its minimum diameter (Fig. 82). Mesopleuron smooth and polished,<tei:lb/>metapleuron coarsely reticulo-rugose (Fig. 85); propodeum rugulose, with lateromedian carinae long and<tei:lb/>strong, usually with a small area superomedia separated from an elongate area petiolaris. Fore and mid legs<tei:lb/>with femora inflated, abruptly tapered distally and ventrally, bearing a median tooth-like process (Fig. 80);<tei:lb/>hind leg with trochantellus ventrally unspecialized; third hind tarsal segment about 2-0 times as long as<tei:lb/>broad. Hind wing with distal abscissa of Cu\ present, rather faintly pigmented but reaching almost to<tei:lb/>margin of wing. Gaster with sternite 1 rugose; tergite 1 1-7-1-8 times as long as posteriorly broad, with<tei:lb/>quite well-defined lateromedian longitudinal carinae extending for 0-8 of its length; tergites 2-4 with<tei:lb/>obvious convex areas and conspicuous shallow transverse furrows; ovipositor very slightly up-curved,<tei:lb/>extending beyond apex of gaster by 0-5-0-6 times length of hind tibia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female and male head, mesosternum, propodeum, metapleuron and first segment of gaster black,<tei:lb/>remainder of alitrunk orange, tergites 2+ of gaster brownish; mouthparts, coxae and trochanters white,<tei:lb/>remainder of fore and most of mid legs orange or brownish, mid tarsus infuscate; hind femur, tibia and<tei:lb/>tarsus dark brown or blackish.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>VARIATION. Some females have an indication of a median pale band on the hind tibia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. A. micans is very similar to A. quadrisculpta except that it is more slender, the<tei:lb/>propodeal sculpture is slightly coarser, the terminal four segments of the gaster are more evenly<tei:lb/>hirsute and the tarsi are more elongate. The most striking difference is in colour pattern.<tei:lb/>This species seems to be restricted to the south-east of Australia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST RECORDS. None.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype $, Australia: New South Wales, Kiandra, Alpine Creek, iii.1962 (Riek) (ANIC).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. Australia: 1 &lt;j&gt;, Australian Capital Territory, Blundell's, iv.1930 (Graham) (ANIC); 1 $,<tei:lb/>Blunders, iv.l930(7omw&gt;) (ANIC); 2 $,Blundell's,xi. 1930 (Gra/mm)( ANIC); 1 $, New South Wales,<tei:lb/>Kiandra, Alpine Creek, iii.1962 (Riek) (BMNH); 1 $, Kiandra, ii.1963 (Riek) (ANIC); 1 cf, Tasmania,<tei:lb/>Mole Ck., ii.1923 (Edwards) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acrodactyla quadrisculpta (Gravenhorst)<tei:lb/>(Fig. 78)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ichneumon quadrisculptus Gravenhorst, 1820: 378. Holotype cf , ITALY (lost).<tei:lb/>Colpomeria quadrisculpta (Gravenhorst) Schmiedeknecht, 1907: 1178.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>ICHNEUMONIDAE OF AUSTRALIA 257</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Polysphincta quadrisculpta (Gravenhorst) Meyer, 1934: 96.<tei:lb/>Acrodactyla quadrisculpta (Gravenhorst) Townes etal., 1965: 35.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fore wing length 3-4 mm; face moderately wide, 0-80-0-85 times as broad as long; clypeus apically<tei:lb/>truncate; malar space about 1-0 times basal mandibular width; ocelli small, the lateral one separated from<tei:lb/>eye by 1-2-1-4 times its own minimum diameter. Mesopleuron finely punctate, polished, metapleuron<tei:lb/>coarsely reticulo-rugose; propodeum rugulose, with lateromedian longitudinal carinae strong, usually with<tei:lb/>a small rectangular area superomedia separated from an elongate area petiolaris. Fore and mid legs with<tei:lb/>femora inflated, abruptly tapered distally and ventrally, bearing a median tooth-like process; hind leg with<tei:lb/>trochantellus ventrally unspecialized, third hind tarsal segment 1-7-1-8 times as long as broad. Hind wing<tei:lb/>with distal abscissa of Cu\ present but faint (Fig. 78). Gaster with sternite 1 rugulose; tergite 1 1-4-1-5 times<tei:lb/>as long as posteriorly broad, with strong lateromedian carina extending about 0-8 of its length; tergites 2-4<tei:lb/>with moderately weak convexities; ovipositor very slightly up-curved, extending beyond apex of gaster by<tei:lb/>0-3-0-5 times length of hind tibia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female and male black; legs pale yellowish, hind tibia centrally white, proximally and distally infuscate;<tei:lb/>mouthparts yellowish.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species was described from Europe and is known to occur quite widely<tei:lb/>throughout the western Palaearctic region (Aubert, 1969). Presumably it was inadvertently<tei:lb/>introduced into Australia. The Australian specimens differ from 'typical' European specimens<tei:lb/>in having the scape dark, not ventrally pale marked.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST RECORDS. In Europe this species attacks tetragnathid spiders (Nielsen, 1937; Capener,<tei:lb/>1938).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Australia: 1 $, 4 cT, Queensland, Kuranda, vi-vii.1913 (Turner) (BMNH). Europe: 5 $, 5 cf , various<tei:lb/>localities (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acrodactyla zekhem sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 81)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fore wing length 3 mm; face narrow, 0-5-0-6 times as broad as long; clypeus narrowly truncate, almost<tei:lb/>evenly convex; malar space short, less than 0-4 times basal mandibular width; ocelli large, the lateral one<tei:lb/>separated from eye by about 0-3 times its own minimum diameter (Fig. 81). Mesopleuron smooth and<tei:lb/>polished; metapleuron coriaceous, with few rugae posteriorly; propodeum almost smooth with lateral<tei:lb/>longitudinal carinae strong, defining an elongate area, the area superomedia not clearly delineated. Fore<tei:lb/>and mid legs with femur very slightly inflated, otherwise unspecialized; hind leg with tibia slightly flattened<tei:lb/>ventrally; third hind tarsal segment about 3-0 times as long as broad. Hind wing with distal abscissa of Cu\<tei:lb/>exceptionally weak, discernible as a slight angling and stub at junction of Cu\ and cu-a. Gaster with sternite<tei:lb/>1 rugose; tergite 1 1-8-1-9 times as long as broad, with strong lateromedia longitudinal carinae reaching 0-8<tei:lb/>of its length; tergites 2-4 with weak convexities; ovipositor straight, its apex up-curved, ovipositor<tei:lb/>projecting beyond apex of gaster by 0-4-0-5 times length of hind tibia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female yellowish brown, head black, gaster infuscate; flagellum brown, scape yellowish, mouthparts<tei:lb/>whitish; legs concolorous with alitrunk and coxae slightly paler. Male similar to female but with base of<tei:lb/>antenna and coxae white.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This small species from tropical Queensland is immediately recognizable by its<tei:lb/>enlarged ocelli and short malar space. The enlarged ocelli and eyes suggest a nocturnal habit.<tei:lb/>The holotype was collected at light.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST RECORDS. None.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype 9j , Australia: Queensland, Moses Ck, 45 km N. by E. Mt Finnigan (1547'S; 14517'E), x. 1980<tei:lb/>(Car dale) (ANIC).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. Australia: 1 $, Queensland, same data as holotype (ANIC); 3 C?, Gap Ck, 5 km ESE. Mt<tei:lb/>Finnigan v.1981 (Naumann) (ANIC); 1 d" , Mt Webb N.P., 50 km N. Cooktown, vii.1976 (Monteith &amp;<tei:lb/>Monteith) (ANIC); 1 cf , 4 km SSE. Cape Tribulation, nr Daintree, xi.1981 (Colless) (ANIC).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>258 I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>DREISBACHIA Townes</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Law/e/oTosquinet, 1903: 381. Type-species: Law/e/a w/raTosquinet, by monotypy. [Homonym of Laufeia</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Simon, 1889.]<tei:lb/>Dreisbachia Townes, 1962: 38. [Replacement name for Laufeia Tosquinet.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Small insects, fore wing length 4-5 mm; palp formula 5,3; clypeus of female flat, in same plane as face, its<tei:lb/>apical margin truncate, that of male more clearly separated from face; surface of eye bearing long hairs;<tei:lb/>occipital carina complete. Epomia present; epicnemial carina present but with upper end rather far from<tei:lb/>anterior margin of pleuron; mesoscutum subpolished, with close pubescence; propodeum in profile evenly<tei:lb/>rounded, dorsally without distinct carinae, polished. Tarsal claws of female with basal lobes; hind tibia of<tei:lb/>female internally uniformly hirsute; fore wing with 3r-m absent; hind wing with distal abscissa of Cu\<tei:lb/>absent; tergites 2-4 polished, with weak central rhombic areas; ovipositor weakly but evenly up-curved,<tei:lb/>projecting beyond apex of gaster by 0-6 times length of hind tibia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. A small genus with few species scattered widely throughout the world. The majority<tei:lb/>have 3r-m present in the fore wing though Momoi (1966) described a New Guinea species<tei:lb/>lacking this vein, and the Australian species is similar.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The possession of hair on the eyes and uniformly on the mesoscutum, the rather flattened<tei:lb/>mesoscutum, the inflated fore femora and the broad, evenly narrowed genae, together with the<tei:lb/>flat face and clypeus of the female suggest that Dreisbachia may be related to Afrosphincta and<tei:lb/>the more specialized Schizopyga. Afrosphincta is only known from a single male and if a female<tei:lb/>were available it may prove to be congeneric with Dreisbachia - thus necessitating the placement<tei:lb/>of the name Dreisbachia as a junior synonym.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A single species occurs in eastern Australia. Its hosts are not known, but the ichneumonid's<tei:lb/>external morphology suggests that it attacks spiders in retreats. European species are known to<tei:lb/>attack spiders of the families Drassodidae (Aubert, 1969) and Clubionidae (BMNH collec-<tei:lb/>tions).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Dreisbachia lutea sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fore wing length 4-5 mm; ocelli small, the lateral one separated from eye by 1-6 times its own maximum<tei:lb/>diameter; malar space about 0-3 times basal mandibular width; head in dorsalview with genae moderately<tei:lb/>broad, evenly narrowed behind eyes; occipital carina complete. Mesoscutum with notauli moderately<tei:lb/>strongly impressed; mesopleuron smooth, with few fine scattered punctures; metapleuron highly polished,<tei:lb/>almost entirely smooth; propodeum with transverse carinae absent, metapleural carina complete, spiracle<tei:lb/>adjacent to this carina. Mid legs with tarsal segments 2-4 very short, together not as long as basitarsus;<tei:lb/>tergite 1 of gaster centrally somewhat striate, tergites 2+ quite coarsely punctate centrally; gaster quite<tei:lb/>slender; ovipositor weakly up-curved, projecting beyond apex of gaster by 0-6 times length of hind tibia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female and male head black, face, clypeus, mouthparts and ventral surface of antenna proximally<tei:lb/>yellow; remainder of antenna brownish; alitrunk and gaster yellowish brown, laterally brighter yellow;<tei:lb/>tergites 7+ black; legs yellowish, hind femur distally black, hind tarsi infuscate. Wings hyaline.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>VARIATION. In a few individuals a trace of 3r-m is discernible in the fore wing. It is usually not<tei:lb/>complete and even if it is, it is only present in one wing.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. A distinctive little species on account of its colour pattern. It is only known from<tei:lb/>Malaise trap catches on Black Mt in Canberra.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST RECORDS. None.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype $, Australia: Australian Capital Territory, Canberra, xi.1978 (Tidemanri) (ANIC).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. Australia: 12 $, 2 cf, Australian Capital Territory, Canberra, xi-xii.1978 (Tidemanri)<tei:lb/>(ANIC; BMNH); 1 $, Canberra, i.1979 (Short) (ANIC); 1 cf , Canberra, ix.1981 (Gauld) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ERIOSTETHUS Morley</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eriostethus Morley, 1914: 34. Type-species: Eriostethus pulcherrimus Morley, by monotypy.<tei:lb/>Millironia Baltazar, 1964: 394. Type-species: Millironia trifasciata Baltazar, by original designation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Medium-sized insects, fore wing length 4-13 mm; palp formula 4, 3; clypeus in profile convex, its margin</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>ICHNEUMONIDAE OF AUSTRALIA 259</tei:p>
         <tei:p>slightly rounded; eye surface bare, occipital carina present and strong, or weak or absent. Epomia absent;<tei:lb/>epicnemial carina present; mesoscutum polished, glabrous; propodeum in profile evenly rounded, dorsally<tei:lb/>smooth, without carinae except rarely in some males. Tarsal claws of female basally lobate; hind tibia of<tei:lb/>female with an internal longitudinal glabrous groove; hind wing with distal abscissa of Cu\ absent. Tergites<tei:lb/>2-4 smooth to with rounded lateromedian prominences; ovipositor straight or slightly up-curved near<tei:lb/>apex, projecting beyond apex of gaster by 0-9-1-2 times length of hind tibia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. A moderate-sized genus centred in New Guinea, with a number of species in<tei:lb/>Australia, South East Asia and Samoa.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The systematic position of this genus is somewhat perplexing. Gauld (1984) suggested it might<tei:lb/>be related to some Neotropical genera, including Hymenoepimecis and Acrotaphus which it<tei:lb/>resembles in general appearance. All are elongate insects and have small rather globose heads<tei:lb/>on long prothoraxes which lack epomia; the ovipositors are very long (for polysphinctines) in<tei:lb/>both cases. However, close examination suggests these similarities may be the result of<tei:lb/>evolutionary convergence; both genera have specializations not found in the other. The most<tei:lb/>significant is the possession of the tibial groove in Eriostethus; this structure is presumably used<tei:lb/>to manipulate the ovipositor. Such a feature is not present in the Neotropical genera. Eriostethus<tei:lb/>lacks the distal abscissa of Cui in the hind wing. This feature is particularly significant as some<tei:lb/>Eriostethus are quite large insects and the loss of this vein is, in polysphinctines, closely<tei:lb/>correlated with small size. This loss of a wing vein coupled with the reduction in palp number<tei:lb/>(another feature associated with small size) suggest that Eriostethus may have been derived from<tei:lb/>a group of small polysphinctines such as Zatypota. The males of species of these two genera are<tei:lb/>very similar and differ from other polysphinctines in having a 4, 3 palp formula. Hyme-<tei:lb/>noepimecis and Acrotaphus on the other hand show no reduction in palp formula and have vein<tei:lb/>Ci present in the hind wing. Apart from obvious specializations these two genera have a<tei:lb/>number of features in common with Polysphincta. Thus both Eriostethus and Hymenoepimecis/<tei:lb/>Acrotaphus are undoubtedly highly specialized tropical forest polysphinctines but it is suggested<tei:lb/>they are derived from different ancestors spreading south.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Five species of Eriostethus occur in Australia, though one, E. maximus, exhibits a consider-<tei:lb/>able range of variation and may eventually be found to comprise more than one species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>There are no host records from Australia but recently I have seen a specimen from New<tei:lb/>Guinea reared from Acanthosoma or a similar genus of jewel spiders (Araneidae) (Fig. 97).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to Australian species of Eriostethus</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 Gaster with lateral part of sternites 2-3 weakly sclerotized , not pigmented ; fore wing with Rs&amp;M</tei:p>
         <tei:p>conspicuously bowed or angled so that the concave side is internal; cu-a usually proximal to<tei:lb/>base of Rs&amp;M, oblique; basal cell glabrous except for a band of hair along anterior margin</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 83) maximus sp. n. (p. 260)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Gaster with lateral part of sternites 2-3 with black-pigmented sclerotized patches ; fore wing with<tei:lb/>Rs&amp;M more or less straight; cu-a about opposite base of Rs&amp;M, subvertical; basal cell hirsute<tei:lb/>or with a glabrous central area, always with hairs in posterodistal corner (Fig. 84)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 Occipital carina present as a distinct though often narrow flange 3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- Occipital carina absent or sometimes vestigial but not raised 4</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 Ocelli very large, the lateral one separated from eye by less than 0-2 of its minimum diameter;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>interocellar area yellowish orange; propodeum uniformly orange perkinsi (Baltazar) (p. 262)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- Ocelli of moderate size, the lateral one separated from eye by 0-4-0-5 of its minimum diameter;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>interocellar area blackish; propodeum blue-black carinatus Baltazar (p. 260)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4 Ocelli small, the $ with lateral one separated from eye by at least its own minimum diameter,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>that of cf by 0-8-0-9 times its own diameter; propodeum and mid coxa orange</tei:p>
         <tei:p>minimus sp. n. (p. 261)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ocelli of moderate size, the lateral one separated from eye by 0-4-0-8 times its own minimum<tei:lb/>diameter; propodeum and mid coxa bluish black pulcherrimus Morley (p. 262)</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>260 I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eriostethus carinatus Baltazar</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 90)<tei:lb/>Eriostethus carinatus Baltazar, 1964: 392. Holotype $, AUSTRALIA (BMNH) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fore wing length 6-9 mm; ocelli of moderate size, the lateral one separated from eye by 0-4-0-5 times its<tei:lb/>minimum diameter; malar space 0-9-1-0 times basal mandibular width; genae evenly narrowed behind<tei:lb/>eyes; occipital carina complete but not strongly raised. Pronotum mediodorsally rather short. Fore wing<tei:lb/>with cu-a very slightly oblique , opposite base of Rs&amp;M; Rs&amp;M virtually straight , almost vertical ; basal cell<tei:lb/>with a glabrous central area, peripherally hirsute; hind wing with Cu\+cu-a almost vertical so anterodistal<tei:lb/>corner of subbasal cell is 80-85. Gaster quite stout, tergite 2 of female about 0-7 times as long as posteriorly<tei:lb/>broad; lateral part of sternites 2-3 sclerotized, with conspicuous pigmented spots; ovipositor projecting<tei:lb/>beyond apex of gaster by 1-0 times length of hind tibia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female head, prothorax, mesoscutum and anterior part of mesopleuron reddish brown; antenna,<tei:lb/>interocellar area and remainder of alitrunk black; gaster black; tergite 1 margined laterally and posteriorly<tei:lb/>and tergites 2+ posteriorly margined with white; fore leg reddish brown, hind two pairs black; face, fore<tei:lb/>coxa and tarsus infuscate; wings strongly infumate, especially near base. Male similar to female but with<tei:lb/>tergite 2 very extensively white.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cocoon: silvery grey, fibrous, 16 mm long, 2 mm maximum diameter, tapering evenly from centre;<tei:lb/>posterior end terminating in small hole, 1 mm diameter and anterior to this are seven small fin-like ribs;<tei:lb/>anterior end elongately tapered to a fibrous 'tufted' top, which is almost completely cut off during<tei:lb/>emergence (Fig. 98).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species resembles E. pulcherrimus in colour and has often been mistaken for it in<tei:lb/>collections. E. carinatus is recognizable on account of the presence of a sharp occipital carina<tei:lb/>and by possession by a black interocellar area. The stub of a vein on 2m-cu which Baltazar<tei:lb/>(1964) mentions as a distinguishing feature of this species is a teratological deformity of the<tei:lb/>holotype.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST RECORDS. None.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Australia: 1 $ (holotype), Victoria (French) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Australia: 1 $, New South Wales, Mt Kosciusko, xii.1924 'on snow on summit' (Dunstari) (BMNH);<tei:lb/>3 $, 2 cf, Tasmania, Hobart (Cole) (ANIC); 1 cf, Western Australia, Yallingup, ix-x.1913 (Turner)<tei:lb/>(BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eriostethus maximussp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 2, 83)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fore wing length 4-13 mm; ocelli very large, the lateral ones contiguous or almost contiguous with eye;<tei:lb/>malar space 0-6-0-7 times basal mandibular width; genae very strongly narrowed behind eyes; occipital<tei:lb/>carina complete, very strongly raised laterally and dorsally. Pronotum mediodorsally very long. Fore<tei:lb/>wing with cu-a oblique, proximal to base of Rs&amp;M; Rs&amp;M conspicuously bowed or angled centrally so<tei:lb/>concave side is proximal; basal cell glabrous except for a band of hair anteriorly (fig. 83); hind wing with<tei:lb/>Ci -I- cu-a slightly oblique so anterodistal corner of subbasal cell is 75-80. Gaster relatively slender,<tei:lb/>tergite 2 of female 1-0-1-3 times as long as posteriorly broad; lateral part of sternites 2-3 weakly<tei:lb/>sclerotized, not pigmented; ovipositor projecting beyond apex of gaster by 1-0-1-2 times length of hind<tei:lb/>tibia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female orange-brown with antenna, except at extreme base, blackish, tergites 3-1- blackish, all tergites<tei:lb/>margined posteriorly with white; hind legs brownish, tibia and tarsus infuscate. Wings slightly infumate.<tei:lb/>Male similar to female though often slightly paler.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>VARIATION. Although the majority of specimens closely conform in colour to the description,<tei:lb/>occasional small specimens (particularly females) have been found with tergite 2 and even<tei:lb/>tergite 1 blackish and the hind trochanter and femur also nigrescent. In some extreme cases even<tei:lb/>the hind coxa is infuscate. These specimens have tergite 2 quadrate and have the ovipositor<tei:lb/>projecting beyond the apex of the gaster by about the length of the hind tibia, putting them on<tei:lb/>the extremities of the ranges of both these characters. However, they do not differ in these<tei:lb/>features from small-sized but 'normally coloured' individuals, suggesting that they are merely</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>ICHNEUMONIDAE OF AUSTRALIA 261</tei:p>
         <tei:p>extreme variants. I have chosen to exclude these somewhat atypical specimens from the<tei:lb/>paratype material.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. E. maximus is easily distinguished from other Australian Eriostethus on account of<tei:lb/>the unusual bend in Rs&amp;M and the posteriorly glabrous basal cell. It is apparently closely related<tei:lb/>to two tropical species, E. nodata (Baltazar) and E. krombeini (Baltazar), which occur in the<tei:lb/>Philippines and New Guinea respectively. E. maximus is larger and differs in colour from these<tei:lb/>species. This species seems to be restricted in Australia to tropical Queensland.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST RECORDS. None.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype $, Australia: Queensland, 1 km N. of Rounded Hill (1517'S; 14513'E), v.1981 (Naumann)<tei:lb/>(ANIC).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. Australia: 1 cf , Queensland, Annan R. , 3 km W. by S. Black Mt (1541'S; 14512'E), ix.1980<tei:lb/>(Cardale) (ANIC); 2 $, 1 Cf, Annan R., 3 km W. by S.          <tei:p>Non-paratype material. Australia: 7 $ , 4 cf , Queensland (ANIC).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eriostethus minimus sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fore wing length 4-6 mm; ocelli small, the lateral one separated from eye by 1-0-1 -3 times its minimum<tei:lb/>diameter; malar space 1-2-1-3 times basal mandibular width; genae long, quite evenly narrowed behind<tei:lb/>eye; occipital carina absent dorsally and laterally except at ventro-lateral extremity. Pronotum mediodor-<tei:lb/>sally moderately long. Fore wing with cu-a almost vertical, subopposite base of Rs&amp;M; Rs&amp;M slightly<tei:lb/>curved, somewhat oblique; basal cell uniformly hirsute; hind wing with Cui+cu-a moderately oblique so<tei:lb/>anterodistal corner of subbasal cell is 75-80. Gaster moderately stout with tergite 2 of female 0-8-0-9 times<tei:lb/>as long as posteriorly broad; lateral part of sternites 2-3 sclerotized, with pigmented spots; ovipositor<tei:lb/>projecting beyond apex of gaster by 1-0 times length of hind tibia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female head, alitrunk and anterior two pairs of legs orange; antenna and hind leg black; gaster black,<tei:lb/>tergites margined laterally and posteriorly with white; wings weakly infumate. Male similar to female but<tei:lb/>with ocelli slightly larger, fore and mid coxa whitish and tergite 1 and 2 extensively pale.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species is close to E. pulcherrimus . The males of both species are very similar, the<tei:lb/>most obvious difference being in colour, but the females are readily distinguishable on account<tei:lb/>of their small ocelli. E. minimus is only known from Queensland and New South Wales.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype $, Australia: Queensland, Bundaberg, vii.1971 (Franco) (ANIC).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. Australia: 1 cf , New South Wales, 1920 (Froggatt) (ANIC); 1 $, Springwood, i. (TC); 1 cf ,<tei:lb/>Taralga, i. (TC). Queensland. 1 $, Brisbane, ix.1962 (Lisle) (UQM); 1 $, Bundaberg, vii.1971 (Frauca)<tei:lb/>(BMNH); 4 cf, Mackay, on citrus, v.1959 (Campbell) (ANIC); 1 , Maryborough, on guava, iv.1959<tei:lb/>(Campbell) (ANIC); 1 cf, Mt Glorious, xii. 1976 (Boucek) (BMNH); 2 $&gt;, Mt Tambourine, xii-i. (TC);<tei:lb/>1 $,Stanthorpe,i. (TC).</tei:p>
