         <tei:p>302 I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Xanthopimpla ecaudata Krieger<tei:lb/>(Figs 38, 43)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Xanthopimpla h ispida Krieger, 1899: 70. Holotype $, 'W. MALAYSIA' (MNHU). [Synonymized by Townes</tei:p>
         <tei:p>&amp; Chiu, 1970: 93.]<tei:lb/>Xanthopimpla ecaudata Krieger, 1899: 71; Townes &amp; Chiu, 1970: 93. Lectotype $, MOLUCCAS (MNHU),</tei:p>
         <tei:p>designated by Townes etal, 1961: 54 [examined].<tei:lb/>Xanthopimpla minor Krieger, 1899: 73. Holotype cf , PAPUA NEW GUINEA (MNHU). [Synonymized by</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Townes &amp; Chiu, 1970: 93.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Clypeus rather flat; face quite coarsely punctate. Flagellum with 44-45 segments, the distal one flattened,<tei:lb/>terminally rounded. Lower anterior corner of pronotum obtusely rounded. Mesoscutum with notauli very<tei:lb/>strongly impressed, reaching almost to hind margin, central part of mesoscutum with sparse dark<tei:lb/>pubescence. Scutellum very strongly convex, almost pyramidal, laterally carinate to hind margin.<tei:lb/>Mesopleuron weakly swollen centrally, anteroventrally coarsely and closely punctate, sternaulus mod-<tei:lb/>erately impressed; metapleuron smooth, punctate posteriorly, submetapleural carina complete. Posterior<tei:lb/>transverse carina of mesosternum strongly raised, with a very narrow, V-shaped median notch. Pro-<tei:lb/>podeum moderately long, with posterior transverse carina complete, anterior one strong, absent centrally;<tei:lb/>lateromedian longitudinal carinae usually not present or weak between transverse carinae, rarely distinct<tei:lb/>in larger females; area superomedia elongate; tubercle weak (Fig. 38). Mid coxa unspecialized; hind tibia<tei:lb/>with 0-3 preapical bristles (Fig. 43), largest bristle on hind tarsal claw spatulate. Fore wing length 6-7 mm;<tei:lb/>3r-m present, enclosing a rhombic areolet; 2m-cu joining areolet slightly distal to centre; Rs sinuate; cu-a<tei:lb/>opposite base of Rs&amp;M. Gaster with tergite 11-1 times as long as broad posteriorly, with a strong carina<tei:lb/>extending from near spiracle to anterior end of segment. Tergite 3 closely punctate. Ovipositor barely<tei:lb/>projecting beyond apex of gaster.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female yellow, only interocellar area and antenna black in Australian specimens. Wings strongly<tei:lb/>infumate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>VARIATION. The few Australian specimens examined are quite alike in having dark wings, but<tei:lb/>elsewhere this species does not have such strong alar infumation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. A widespread Melanesian-tropical Australian species occurring as far west as the<tei:lb/>Moluccas and east to the Solomons. X. ecaudata belongs to the splendens-group of Townes &amp;<tei:lb/>Chiu (1970). It is a group easily recognized by the very long, deep notauli. In Australia X.<tei:lb/>ecaudata is easily recognized by its very short ovipositor.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST RECORDS. None.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Indonesia: 1 $ (lectotype of ecaudata), Moluccas, Kai (MNHU).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Australia: 12 $ , 4 cf , Queensland. Indonesia: 9 $ , 7 cf , Moluccas; Irian Jaya. Papua New Guinea: 2 $ ,<tei:lb/>4 cf . Solomon Is: 4 $ (Map 11).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Xanthopimpla ttavolineata Cameron<tei:lb/>(Figs 39, 49)</tei:p>

         <tei:p>ICHNEUMONIDAE OF AUSTRALIA 303</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Clypeus slightly convex near upper margin; face fairly evenly punctate. Flagellum with 36-40 segments, the<tei:lb/>distal one flattened and terminally rounded. Lower anterior corner of pronotum rounded off about 90.<tei:lb/>Mesoscutum with notauli weak, barely reaching to level of anterior margin of tegulae; central part of<tei:lb/>mesoscutum virtually glabrous. Scutellum moderately convex; carinate to posterior margin. Mesopleuron<tei:lb/>weakly convex centrally, anteroventrally finely and closely punctate, sternaulus indistinct; metapleuron<tei:lb/>smooth, submetapleural carina complete. Posterior transverse carinae of mesosternum moderately<tei:lb/>strongly raised, with a median notch. Propodeum long, posterior transverse carina complete, anterior one<tei:lb/>present laterally, lateromedian carinae complete, defining a large elongate area superomedia that is<tei:lb/>1-1-1-2 times as long as broad; tubercle vestigial. Mid coxa unspecialized; hind tibia with 5-6 preapical<tei:lb/>bristles, largest bristle on hind tarsal claw spatulate. Fore wing length 4-8 mm; 3r-m present, enclosing a<tei:lb/>rhombic petiolate areolet; 2m-cu joining areolet near centre; Rs strongly sinuous (Fig. 39); cu-a opposite<tei:lb/>base of Rs&amp;M. Gaster with tergite 1 1-3-1-5 times as long as broad posteriorly, with a carina extending<tei:lb/>from near spiracle to anterior end (Fig. 49). Tergite 3 moderately sparsely punctate. Ovipositor projecting<tei:lb/>beyond apex of gaster by about 0-5 times length of hind tibia.<tei:lb/>Female yellow, interocellar area and ovipositor sheath black. Wings hyaline. Male similar to female.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. X. flavolineata is a widespread Indo-Australian species that frequents open areas of<tei:lb/>coarse grassland and cereal crops. It is placed by Townes &amp; Chiu in the citrina-gToup, a mainly<tei:lb/>Afrotropical complex. In Australia X. flavolineata may be recognized by its slender appearance,<tei:lb/>large elongate area superomedia and sinuous Rs. It is rather similar to X. arealis from which it<tei:lb/>may be distinguished by characters given in the key.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST RECORDS. In Asia this species is a common parasite of pyralids and noctuids that bore in<tei:lb/>rice, maize and sugar-cane (Townes &amp; Chiu, 1970), though it has not been reared in Australia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Indonesia: 1 $ (holotype of flavolineata), Irian Jaya, Merauke (ZMA). India: 1 $ (paratype of<tei:lb/>immaculata), Bengal, Chapra (Mackenzie) (BMNH). Australia: 1 $ (holotype of xanthostigma) , Queens-<tei:lb/>land, Amamoor Forest (QM). New Hebrides: 1 $ (holotype of xara), Malekula (Cheesman) (BMNH).</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Xanthopimpla fraterculus Townes &amp; Chiu</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 19, 24)<tei:lb/>Xanthopimpla fraterculus Townes &amp; Chiu, 1970: 33. Holotype cf , AUSTRALIA (TC) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Clypeus slightly convex near upper end; face strongly punctate. Flagellum with 37-41 segments, the distal<tei:lb/>one slightly flattened, apically rounded. Lower anterior corner of pronotum evenly rounded. Mesoscutum<tei:lb/>with notauli deep but short, barely reaching to level of anterior margin of tegulae; central part of<tei:lb/>mesoscutum sparsely hirsute. Scutellum pyramidal, carinate laterally to hind margin. Mesopleuron<tei:lb/>strongly swollen just above centre, anteroventrally coarsely punctate; sternaulus vestigial (Fig. 19);<tei:lb/>metapleuron smooth, submetapleural carina strong. Posterior transverse carina of mesosternum strongly<tei:lb/>raised, centrally with a broad V-shaped notch. Propodeum rather short with carinae strong, defining a<tei:lb/>short transverse area superomedia that is about 2-7 times as broad as long; propodeum unusual in having a<tei:lb/>strong swelling in front of spiracle; tubercle vestigial (Fig. 24). Mid coxa unspecialized; hind tibia without<tei:lb/>preapical bristles; largest bristle on hind tarsal claws spatulate. Fore wing length 9-11 mm; 3r-ra enclosing<tei:lb/>a fairly large rhombic areolet, 2m-cu joining it about in centre; Rs sinuate; cu-a opposite Rs&amp;M. Gaster<tei:lb/>with tergite 11-1-1 -2 times as long as broad posteriorly, usually with a carina extending forwards from near<tei:lb/>anterior margin of spiracle. Tergite 3 sparsely but coarsely punctate. Ovipositor projecting beyond apex of<tei:lb/>gaster by about 0-7-0-9 times length of hind tibia, noticeably decurved.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female yellow, upper part of scape, interocellar area, vertex, mesoscutum in 3 stripes and a transverse<tei:lb/>posterior bar and ovipositor sheath, black. Wings slightly infumate, apices more darkly so. Male similar to<tei:lb/>female though with at least tergite 3 bearing indistinct blackish spots.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>VARIATION. This is one of the most variable species in the extent of black marking. Some females<tei:lb/>have paired black spots on tergites 2-4 and spots on the hind femora whilst a few have spots on<tei:lb/>tergites 2-6 and black bars on tergites 7 &amp; 8 and paired spots on the hind femora. One specimen<tei:lb/>even has indistinct spots on tergite 1.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. X. fraterculus belongs to the regina-group (Townes &amp; Chiu, 1970) and is one of the</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>304 I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>easiest Australian species to recognize on account of its pyramidal scutellum and the swelling on<tei:lb/>the propodeum in front of the spiracle. The only other species with a relatively long ovipositor<tei:lb/>and strongly transverse area superomedia with which it could be confused is X. australis, which<tei:lb/>has a quite different colour pattern with a single transverse black stripe in the centre of the<tei:lb/>mesoscutum rather than the four marks characteristic of X. fraterculus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST RECORDS. None.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Australia: 1 C? (holotype), Western Australia, Fitzroy R. crossing, v.1969 (Alexander &amp; Otte) (TC); 1 $<tei:lb/>(paratype), Northern Territory, Brock's Creek, iv.1931 (Campbell) (ANIC); 1 C? (paratype), Queens-<tei:lb/>land, Brisbane, xi.1918 (Hacker) (QM).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Australia: 13 $, 3 C?, Northern Territory, Queensland, Western Australia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Xanthopimpla hiatus Townes &amp; Chiu</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 27, 40)<tei:lb/>Xanthopimpla hiatus Townes &amp; Chiu, 1970: 256. Holotype $ , AUSTRALIA (QM) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Clypeus fairly flat; face strongly punctate. Flagellum with 38-39 flagellar segments, the distal one slightly<tei:lb/>flattened and slightly truncated. Lower anterior corner of pronotum sharply angled about 90. Mesoscutum<tei:lb/>with notauli deeply impressed, reaching to level of hind margins of tegulae; central part of mesoscutum<tei:lb/>fairly evenly hirsute. Scutellum quite strongly convex, carinate laterally for its entire length. Mesopleuron<tei:lb/>weakly swollen centrally, anteroventrally finely and closely punctate, sternaulus vestigial; metapleuron<tei:lb/>smooth, submetapleural carina complete. Posterior transverse carina of mesosternum strongly raised,<tei:lb/>centrally with a deep V-shaped notch. Propodeum of moderate length, anterior transverse carinae present<tei:lb/>laterally, curved forward lateromedially to join anterior part of lateromedian longitudinal carinae,<tei:lb/>centrally absent; posterior transverse carina complete, median portion of lateromedian longitudinal carina<tei:lb/>vestigial, indicating a transverse area superomedia that is about 1-6 times as broad as long; tubercle present<tei:lb/>at lateral end of anterior transverse carina above and slightly behind propodeal spiracle (Fig. 27). Mid coxa<tei:lb/>unspecialized; hind tibia with 2-4 preapical bristles; largest bristle of hind tarsal claws spatulate. Fore wing<tei:lb/>length 10-12 mm; 3r-m present, enclosing a small obliquely trapezoidal petiolate areolet; 2m-cu joining<tei:lb/>areolet near outer corner (Fig. 40); Rs moderately arcuate; cu-a virtually opposite Rs&amp;M. Gaster with<tei:lb/>tergite 1 1-1-1-2 times as long as posteriorly broad, without a distinct carina joining spiracle to anterior<tei:lb/>margin of segment. Tergite 3 with close coarse punctures centrally. Ovipositor projecting beyond apex of<tei:lb/>gaster by 0-9-1-0 times length of hind tibia, slightly decurved with its dorsal apex flattened weakly.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female yellow, black-marked on interocellar area, mesoscutum in 3 almost contiguous spots, posterior<tei:lb/>part of tegula and ovipositor sheath. Wings hyaline with infumate distal apex. Male unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. X. hiatus belongs to the elegans-group as defined by Townes &amp; Chiu (1970). It is the<tei:lb/>only Australian representative of this group which is easily recognizable by the sharply angled<tei:lb/>pronotal corner. X. hiatus is also distinctive in having 2m-cu joining the areolet very close to the<tei:lb/>outer corner.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST RECORDS. None.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Australia: 1 $ (holotype), New South Wales, Tooloom, i.1926 (Hacker) (QM); 1 $ (paratype),<tei:lb/>Queensland, Cairns (BMNH); 1 $ (paratype), Mackay, v.1909 (Turner) (BMNH); 1 $ (paratype), Mt<tei:lb/>Glorious, ii.1961 (Gressitt &amp; Gressitt) (TC).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Australia: 6 $ , New South Wales, Queensland.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Xanthopimpla hirsuta (Girault)<tei:lb/>(Figs 21, 33)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Austrapophua hirsuta Girault, 1930: 2. Holotype $, AUSTRALIA (QM) [examined].<tei:lb/>Xanthopimpla hirsuta (Girault) Townes etal, 1961: 56; Townes &amp; Chiu, 1970: 272.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Clypeus flat, more strongly transverse than is usual for the genus; face closely punctate. Flagellum<tei:lb/>incomplete. Lower anterior corner of pronotum about 95, slightly rounded. Mesoscutum with notauli<tei:lb/>strongly impressed, reaching about to level of centre of tegulae; central part of mesoscutum sparsely</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>ICHNEUMONIDAE OF AUSTRALIA 305</tei:p>
         <tei:p>hirsute. Scutellum pyramidal with carina extending almost to posterior margin. Mesopleuron moderately<tei:lb/>weakly swollen centrally, anteroventrally closely and quite coarsely punctate, sternaulus absent; meta-<tei:lb/>pleuron smooth, unusual in not being defined anterodorsally as pleural carina extends only to level of<tei:lb/>spiracle; submetapleural carina strong (Fig. 21). Posterior transverse carina of mesosternum weak, only<tei:lb/>slightly broadened centrally. Propodeum moderately long, anterior transverse carina complete laterally,<tei:lb/>posterior transverse carina complete, strong, lateromedian carinae defining an area superomedia which is<tei:lb/>much narrower posteriorly than centrally, the entire area being as long as centrally broad; tubercle weak<tei:lb/>(Fig. 33). Mid coxa unspecialized; hind tibia with about 4 preapical bristles; largest bristle on hind tarsal<tei:lb/>claw slender, not spatulate. Fore wing length 11 mm; 3r-m absent; Rs simply arcuate; cu-a slightly<tei:lb/>proximal to base of Rs&amp;M. Gaster with tergite 11-2 times as long as posteriorly broad, with carina<tei:lb/>extending from near spiracle to anterior end. Tergite 3 with coarse contiguous punctures centrally.<tei:lb/>Ovipositor projecting beyond apex of gaster by 0-1 times length of hind tibia, the ovipositor apex slightly<tei:lb/>decurved, the lower valve with a distinct median ventral keel, not enclosed by upper valve.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female yellow, black-marked on interocellar area, back of head, mesoscutum in three stripes and on<tei:lb/>scuto-scutellar groove, paired spots on tergites 1, 3-5 and transverse black band on tergite 7. Wings<tei:lb/>hyaline, distally infumate. Male unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. A very distinctive species on account of the complete area superomedia and<tei:lb/>incomplete areolet. Townes &amp; Chiu (1970) placed X. hirsuta in the incompleta-group, but the<tei:lb/>ovipositor is not very like that of the other species as the lower valve is not enclosed by the upper<tei:lb/>valve. I believe it should be placed in the rhopaloceros-group.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST RECORDS. None.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED<tei:lb/>Australia: 1 $ (holotype), Queensland, Herbert River, Macknade? v.1912 (QM).</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Chiu, 1970: 126.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Xanthopimpla (?) caudata (Smith) Krieger, 1899: 65.<tei:lb/>Xanthopimpla (?) ochracea (Smith) Krieger, 1899: 65.<tei:lb/>Xanthopimpla crassa Krieger, 1899: 97. Lectotype $, PAPUA NEW GUINEA (MNHU), designated by</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Townes etal, 1961: 53. [Synonymized by Townes &amp; Chiu, 1970: 126.]<tei:lb/>Xanthopimpla ochracea ochracea (Smith); Townes &amp; Chiu, 1970: 126.<tei:lb/>Xanthopimpla ochracea peterseni Townes &amp; Chiu, 1970: 125. Holotype $, NEW IRELAND (UZM). Syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Clypeus weakly convex; face quite coarsely punctate. Flagellum with 35-38 segments, the distal one<tei:lb/>flattened, rounded off. Lower anterior corner of pronotum fairly abruptly rounded. Mesoscutum with<tei:lb/>notauli short, deep, reaching nearly to level of -centre of tegulae; central part of mesoscutum sparsely<tei:lb/>hirsute. Scutellum moderately strongly convex, carinate laterally to apex. Mesopleuron weakly swollen<tei:lb/>centrally, anteroventrally quite coarsely punctate, sternaulus weak, discernible; metapleuron smooth or<tei:lb/>with some striation, submetapleural carina distinct. Posterior transverse carina of mesosternum very<tei:lb/>abruptly raised near centre, produced into two acute lobes separated by a narrow V-shaped cleft, these<tei:lb/>lobes usually strengthened by a thicker outgrowth from the sternum. Propodeum short, anterior and<tei:lb/>posterior transverse carinae strong; lateromedian carinae present between transverse carinae, enclosing a<tei:lb/>transverse area superomedia that is 1-8-1-9 times as broad as long; tubercle vestigial (Fig. 37). Mid coxa<tei:lb/>unspecialized; hind tibia with 6-8 preapical bristles; largest bristle on hind tarsal claw spatulate. Fore wing<tei:lb/>length 6-9 mm; 3r-m present, enclosing a moderately small, slightly oblique areolet; Im-cu joining areolet<tei:lb/>near centre; Rs very slightly sinuate; cu-a opposite base of Rs&amp;M. Gaster with tergite 1 about as long as<tei:lb/>posteriorly broad, slightly more slender in males; petiolar spiracle without a carina extending from near it<tei:lb/>to anterior margin of segment. Tergite 3 moderately densely punctate. Ovipositor projecting beyond apex<tei:lb/>of gaster by 0-8 times length of hind tibia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female yellow, black-marked at least on interocellar area and ovipositor sheath. Wings weakly<tei:lb/>infumate. Male similar to female but with a pair of lateral spots on propodeum and spots on tergites 3-7<tei:lb/>black.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>VARIATION. Many females are as extensively black marked as the males. Some individuals of</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>306 I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>both sexes have black marks on the mesoscutum and on tergite 1 a pair of faint brownish spots.<tei:lb/>Occasionally males have only the interocellar area black.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species belongs to the ochracea-gioup of Townes &amp; Chiu (1970) and is<tei:lb/>distinguished by the strongly raised posterior transverse carina of the mesosternum. Townes &amp;<tei:lb/>Chiu (1970) recognized seven subspecies. Several of these would seem to warrant specific status<tei:lb/>and in the present work I have restricted ochracea to the ochracea ochracea and ochracea<tei:lb/>peterseni of Townes &amp; Chiu.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST RECORDS. None.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Xanthopimpla pubidorsis Townes &amp; Chiu</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 25)<tei:lb/>Xanthopimpla pubidorsis Townes &amp; Chiu, 1970: 86. Holotype 9, IRIAN JAVA (RHN) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Clypeus flat; face finely punctate. Flagellum with 36-37 segments, the distal segment only slightly<tei:lb/>flattened, terminally rounded abruptly. Lower anterior margin of pronotum obtusely rounded. Mesoscu-<tei:lb/>tum with notauli deeply impressed, reaching to level of hind margin of tegulae; median lobe of mesoscutum<tei:lb/>with fine pale pubescence. Scutellum convex, carinate laterally to entire length. Mesopleuron weakly<tei:lb/>swollen centrally, anteroventrally finely and very sparsely punctate; sternaulus distinct, posteriorly fairly<tei:lb/>shallow; metapleuron smooth, submetapleural carina distinct. Posterior transverse carina of mesosternum<tei:lb/>very broad, with a small median notch. Propodeum moderately long, anterior and posterior transverse<tei:lb/>carinae complete, lateromedian carinae delimiting a large area superomedia that is slightly longer than<tei:lb/>broad; tubercle moderately weak (Fig. 25). Mid coxa unspecialized; hind tibia with 0-1 preapical bristles;<tei:lb/>largest bristle on hind tarsal claw spatulate. Fore wing length 7-8 mm; 3r-ra present enclosing a rather<tei:lb/>broad rhombic areolet; 2m-cu joining very slightly distal to centre; Rs slightly arcuate; cu-a opposite base<tei:lb/>of Rs&amp;M. Gaster with tergite 1 elongate, 1-2 times as long as broad posteriorly, without carina extending<tei:lb/>from near spiracle to anterior end. Tergite 3 with very superficial punctures. Ovipositor projecting beyond<tei:lb/>apex of gaster by about 0-5 times length of hind tibia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female yellow, only scape partially, interocellar area and ovipositor sheath blackish. Wings hyaline,<tei:lb/>apices slightly infumate. Male similar to female.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. X. pubidorsis belongs to the splendens-group and may be recognized by the<tei:lb/>combination of strong notauli, deep sternaulus, complete scutellar carinae, smooth meta-<tei:lb/>pleuron and finely punctate mesopleuron. Unlike X. barak this species always has the area<tei:lb/>superomedia delineated laterally.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Xanthopimpla quadridens Townes &amp; Chiu</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Clypeus flat; face strongly punctate. Flagellum with 36-38 segments, the distal segment evenly rounded<tei:lb/>apically. Lower anterior corner of pronotum very obtusely angled.       </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>ICHNEUMONIDAE OF AUSTRALIA 307</tei:p>
         <tei:p>hairs. Scutellum weakly convex, carinate laterally for its entire length. Mesopleuron weakly swollen<tei:lb/>centrally, anteroventrally quite closely and coarsely punctate; sternaulus vestigial; metapleuron obsoletely<tei:lb/>punctate, submetapleural carina distinct, discernible as a wide flat ridge (Fig. 22). Posterior transverse<tei:lb/>carina of mesosternum weakly raised, centrally with a broad U-shaped notch. Propodeum short; anterior<tei:lb/>transverse and lateromedian longitudinal carinae absent, posterior transverse carina distinct, centrally<tei:lb/>interrupted, laterally raised into flanges; lateral tubercle present above and slightly behind propodeal<tei:lb/>spiracle, the tubercle with conspicuous fine setiferous punctures (Fig. 35).          <tei:p>VARIATION. Some specimens may have minute black spots laterally on tergite 2 and the spots of<tei:lb/>tergite 5 centrally confluent to form a dumb-bell-like mark. A few males are less extensively<tei:lb/>black and only have lateral black spots on tergites 3-6.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species is the largest one without an areolet. It is easily recognized by the<tei:lb/>conspicuous propodeal tubercles, long ovipostor and complete submetapleural carina. X.<tei:lb/>quadridens belongs to the rhopaloceros-group as defined by Townes &amp; Chiu (1970).</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Xanthopimpla rhopaloceros Krieger<tei:lb/>(Figs 28, 52)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Xanthopimpla rhopaloceros Krieger, 1914: 23; Townes &amp; Chiu, 1970: 285. Lectotype cf, AUSTRALIA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(MNHU), designated by Townes et al., 1961: 66 [examined].<tei:lb/>Austrapophua xanthopimploides Girault, 1926: 135. Holotype $, AUSTRALIA (QM) [examined]. [Synony-</tei:p>
         <tei:p>mized by Townes &amp; Chiu, 1970: 285.]<tei:lb/>Xanthopimpla xanthopimploides (Girault) Townes et al., 1961: 72.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Clypeus flat; face strongly closely punctate. Flagellum with 33-34 segments, the terminal segment evenly<tei:lb/>rounded apically. Lower anterior corner of pronotum evenly rounded. Mesoscutum with notauli deep,<tei:lb/>extending only to level of centre of tegulae; central lobe of mesoscutum sparsely hirsute. Scutellum weakly<tei:lb/>convex, carinate almost to hind margin. Mesopleuron centrally very weakly swollen, anteroventrally<tei:lb/>sparsely punctate; sternaulus vestigial; metapleuron smooth, submetapleural carina absent. Posterior<tei:lb/>transverse carina of mesosternum moderately broadened, with a wide V-shaped central notch. Propodeum<tei:lb/>moderately long; anterior and lateromedian carinae absent; posterior transverse carina complete; tubercle<tei:lb/>quite strong (Fig. 28). Mid coxa with a blunt prominence on anterolateral side; hind tibia with 9-15<tei:lb/>preapical bristles; largest bristle on hind tarsal claw not spatulate. Fore wing length 4-11 mm; 3r-m absent;<tei:lb/>Rs almost straight; cu-a opposite base of Rs&amp;M. Gaster with tergite 11-2 times as long as posteriorly<tei:lb/>broad, without a carina joining spiracle to anterior margin of tergite. Tergite 3 with coarse close punctures.<tei:lb/>Ovipositor projecting beyond apex of gaster by about 0-4 times length of hind tibia, its apex subcylindrical.<tei:lb/>Female yellow, black marks on interocellar area, occiput, mesoscutum in three stripes, scutoscutellar<tei:lb/>groove, on anterior transverse band on propodeum, a central band on tergites 1, 3 and 7, paired spots on<tei:lb/>tergites 2, 4 and 6, hind tibia proximally and distally and hind basitarsus proximally. Wings hyaline. Male<tei:lb/>similar to female but with mesoscutal stripes usually fused to form a single black area.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>308 I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>VARIATION. Some specimens have faint black dots on tergite 5 whilst others have no black mark<tei:lb/>on tergite 2. Not infrequently tergites 6 and 7 are almost entirely black.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species belongs to the rhopaloceros-group of Townes &amp; Chiu (1970). X.<tei:lb/>rhopaloceros is easily recognized by the characteristic shape of the mid coxa, the lack of an<tei:lb/>areolet, and the colour pattern. It differs from the related X. summervillei most obviously in<tei:lb/>having a strong black band on tergite 1 (Fig. 52) and in having the occiput black. X. summervillei<tei:lb/>never has a black occiput and at the most only a vague brownish central mark on tergite 1.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST RECORDS. Nolidae: Uraba lugens Walker (DPIQ). Tortricidae: Epiphyas postvittana<tei:lb/>(Walker) (Dumbleton, 1940); Merophyas divulsana (Walker) (DPIQ).</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Xanthopimpla striata Townes &amp; Chiu</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 26)<tei:lb/>Xanthopimpla striata Townes &amp; Chiu, 1970: 91. Holotype 9, AUSTRALIA (BPBM) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Clypeus swollen centrally near upper margin; face coarsely but sparsely punctate. Flagellum with 41<tei:lb/>segments. Lower anterior corner of pronotum fairly evenly rounded but with lower corner of epomia<tei:lb/>right-angled and projecting, appearing superficially like the corner of pronotum. Mesoscutum with notauli<tei:lb/>very strongly impressed almost to hind margin; central part of mesoscutum with sparse dark pubescence.<tei:lb/>Scutellum very strongly convex, carinate laterally about 0-8 of its length. Mesopleuron weakly swollen<tei:lb/>centrally, anteroventrally coarsely and closely punctate; sternaulus deeply impressed; metapleuron<tei:lb/>anteroventrally striate, posteriorly punctate, submetapleural carina complete. Posterior transverse carina<tei:lb/>of mesosternum moderately broad, with a deep median V-shaped notch. Propodeum of moderate length,<tei:lb/>with posterior and anterior transverse carinae strong, the latter absent centrally; lateromedian longitudinal<tei:lb/>carinae indistinct but area superomedia discernible transverse; lateral tubercle indistinct (Fig. 26). Mid<tei:lb/>coxa unspecialized; hind tibia with 6-9 preapical bristles, fewer in male; largest bristle on hind tarsal claw<tei:lb/>spatulate. Fore wing length 7-8 mm; 3r-m present, enclosing a moderately large rhombic areolet; 2m-cu<tei:lb/>joining areolet at centre; Rs arcuate; cu-a virtually opposite base ofRs&amp;M. Gaster with tergite 11-3 times<tei:lb/>as long as broad posteriorly, with a strong carina extending from near spiracle to anterior end of segment.<tei:lb/>Tergite 3 with fine, close, rather elongate punctures. Ovipositor projecting beyond apex of gaster by<tei:lb/>0-3-0-4 times length of hind tibia, its apex subcylindrical.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female yellow, black-marked on interocellar area, vertex, mesoscutum centrally and indistinctly<tei:lb/>laterally, and gaster with spots laterally on tergites 1-3 and 7 centrally. Apex of wings infumate. Male<tei:lb/>similar to female but with only interocellar area, mesoscutum centrally, propodeum centrally, paired spots<tei:lb/>of tergites 2-6 and remaining tergites transversely banded black.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>VARIATION. Some females have paired black spots present on tergites 4 and 5 and have some<tei:lb/>black on the propodeum anteromedially, like the male.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. X. striata belongs to the splendens-group as defined by Townes &amp; Chiu (1970).<tei:lb/>Superficially this species may be mistaken for members of the elegans-group on account of the<tei:lb/>apparently sharply angulate anterior corner of the pronotum. However, this angulation is the<tei:lb/>lower corner of the epomia and not the pronotal margin which underlies this projection and is<tei:lb/>evenly rounded. In species of the elegans-group it is the actual pronotal margin that is sharply<tei:lb/>angled. Unlike X. hiatus, the only Australian member of the elegans-group, X. striata has a<tei:lb/>striate metapleuron, regularly rhombic areolet with 2m-cu joining in centre, a rather short<tei:lb/>ovipositor and strongly impressed sternaulus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST RECORDS. None.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED<tei:lb/>Australia: 1 9 (holotype), Queensland, Cairns (Kusche) (BPBM).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>ICHNEUMONIDAE OF AUSTRALIA 309</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Australia: 1 cf , Queensland, Ellis Beach, N. of Cairns, iv.1967 (Colless) (ANIC). Papua New Guinea:<tei:lb/>2 $, Dumpu, 250 m, i-ii.1979 (Sedlacek) (TC).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Xanthopimpla summervillei (Girault)<tei:lb/>(Figs 30, 53)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Austrapophua summervillei Girault, 1926: 136. Holotype $, AUSTRALIA (QM) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Xanthopimpla summervillei (Girault) Townes etal., 1961: 70.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Xanthopimpla summervillei summervillei (Girault) Townes &amp; Chiu, 1970: 295.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Clypeus flat; face quite strongly, closely punctate. Flagellum with 32-34 segments, the terminal segment<tei:lb/>evenly rounded apically. Lower anterior corner of pronotum evenly rounded. Mesoscutum with notauli<tei:lb/>deep, extending beyond level of centre of tegulae; central lobe of mesoscutum very sparsely hirsute.<tei:lb/>Scutellum moderately strongly convex, carinate for 0-8 of its length. Mesopleuron centrally very weakly<tei:lb/>swollen, anteroventrally smooth; sternaulus vestigial; metapleuron smooth, submetapleural carina absent.<tei:lb/>Posterior transverse carina of mesosternum quite strongly broadened, with a deep median V-shaped<tei:lb/>notch. Fore wing length 4-8 mm;<tei:lb/>3r-m absent ;Rs slightly sinuous \cu-a opposite base of Rs&amp;M. Gaster with tergite 1 1-1-1 -3 times as long as<tei:lb/>posteriorly broad, without a carina joining spiracle to anterior margin of tergite. Tergite 3 with very fine<tei:lb/>sparse setiferous punctures. Ovipositor projecting beyond apex of gaster by 0-7-0-8 times length of hind<tei:lb/>tibia, its apex subcylindrical.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female yellow, black-marked on interocellar area, mesoscutum in a broad transverse band, anterior<tei:lb/>part of propodeum, bands on tergites 3, 4 and 7 and hind tibia proximally. Male similar to female but with<tei:lb/>black spots on tergites 4-6 and proximal black mark on hind tibia less distinct. Apex of fore wing infumate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>VARIATION. In some females the black band on tergite 3 is present as two barely confluent spots.<tei:lb/>A few have a faint brownish mark on tergite 1 centrally.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. X. summervillei belongs to the X. rhopaloceros-group of Townes &amp; Chiu (1970). Like<tei:lb/>two of the other Australian species of this group (X. binodus and X. rhopaloceros) it lacks the<tei:lb/>submetapleural carina. It can be distinguished from these other species most easily by its<tei:lb/>characteristic colour pattern (Fig. 53).<tei:lb/>Townes &amp; Chiu (1970) recognize four subspecies. The nominate one is restricted to Australia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST RECORDS. None.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Australia: 1 $ (holotype), New South Wales, Tweed Heads (QM).<tei:lb/>Australia: 17 $, 11 cf , New South Wales, Queensland (Map 15) (ANIC; BMNH: TC).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Xanthopimpla terminalis (Brulle)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 36, 47)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pimpla terminalis Brulle, 1846: 96. Holotype $, AUSTRALIA (MNHN) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Notopimpla terminalis (Brulle) Krieger, 1899: 107.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Xanthopimpla terminalis (Brulle) Townes etal., 1961: 70; Townes &amp; Chiu, 1970: 300.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Clypeus flat; face rather finely punctate. Flagellum with 37-39 segments, the most distal segment<tei:lb/>somewhat flattened, distally truncate so antenna has a small elliptical flat area at the end (Fig. 47). Lower<tei:lb/>anterior corner of pronotum produced into a sharp tooth. Mesoscutum with notauli deep but short, barely<tei:lb/>reaching to level of anterior margin of tegulae; central part of mesoscutum virtually glabrous. Scutellum<tei:lb/>rather flat, carinate laterally only at extreme base. Mesopleuron very weakly swollen centrally, anteroven-<tei:lb/>trally very finely and sparsely punctate, sternaulus absent; metapleuron smooth, submetapleural carina<tei:lb/>present. Posterior transverse carina of mesosternum slightly raised, with a minute central notch. Pro-<tei:lb/>podeum moderately long, posterior transverse carina complete, anterior and lateromedian carinae absent;<tei:lb/>tubercle strong (Fig. 36). Mid coxa unspecialized; hind tibia with three preapical bristles arranged in a<tei:lb/>straight line; largest bristle on hind tarsal claws spatulate. Fore wing length 12-13 mm; 3r-m present,<tei:lb/>enclosing a small areolet, 2m-cu joining areolet close to proximal side, Rs sinuate; cu-a opposite base of</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>310 I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Rs&amp;M. Gaster with tergite 1 longer than posteriorly broad, without a carina joining spiracle to anterior<tei:lb/>margin of tergite. Tergite 3 with large, shallow, close punctures. Ovipositor projecting beyond apex of<tei:lb/>gaster by 1 -0-1 1 times length of hind tibia, exceptional in having a small swelling on upper valve near apex.<tei:lb/>Female yellow, scape, interocellar area, head behind vertex, three mesoscutal marks and ovipositor<tei:lb/>sheath only, black. Wings slightly infumate, apices more distinctly so. Male similar to female, but<tei:lb/>mesoscutal marks more extensive and tergite 1 with a pair of black spots, tergite 3 with traces of spots.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. X. terminalis belongs to the terminalis-group as defined by Townes &amp; Chiu (1970). In<tei:lb/>Australia it is one of the most distinctive species, easily recognized by the flat acarinate<tei:lb/>scutellum, apically specialized antennae (in both sexes) and nodulate ovipositor. It is quite<tei:lb/>closely related to the Papuan species X. interceptor (Smith). X. terminalis has recently been<tei:lb/>collected flying amongst the understorey vegetation in wet forest. It seems to prefer very shaded<tei:lb/>habitats and often flies quite high, 2-3 m from the ground.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST RECORDS. None.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Australia: 1 $ (holotype), no further data (MNHN).<tei:lb/>Australia: 9 $ , 2 cf , New South Wales, Queensland (Map 16) (AM; ANIC; BMNH; TC).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tribe DELOMERISTINI</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(= Theroniini sensu Townes)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This tribe, a rather heterogeneous assemblage of taxa, includes six genera, Atractogaster,<tei:lb/>Delomerista, Hybomischos, Pseudorhyssa, Perithous and Theronia, placed together on account<tei:lb/>of the absence of a basal tooth on the fore tarsal claw of the female, the unusually elongate male<tei:lb/>subgenital plate and the often delineated, rather long, area superomedia. The final instar larvae<tei:lb/>all possess a large internal tooth on the mandible and have a well developed hypostoma (Short,<tei:lb/>1978).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pseudorhyssa, Delomerista and Atractogaster are north temperate genera whilst Perithous<tei:lb/>and Hybomischos also occur on some higher mountains in the Oriental region (Gupta, 19820,<tei:lb/>b). Theronia, a predominantly tropicopolitan genus, is the only delomeristine genus represented<tei:lb/>in Australia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>THERONIA Holmgren</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Medium to moderately large-sized species, fore wing length 7-14 mm; clypeus with margin slightly<tei:lb/>concave; mandible not twisted, weakly to moderately narrowed; occipital carina complete. Epicnemial<tei:lb/>carina present; mesopleural suture centrally angled; propodeum with strong carinae, spiracles elongately<tei:lb/>oval. Tarsal claws of female without basal lobes, usually large with spatulate bristle. Fore wing with 3r-m<tei:lb/>present, enclosing a rhombic areolet; hind wing with first abscissa of Ci about 0-3 times length of cu-a.<tei:lb/>Tergite 1 rather slender; tergites 2-5 smooth and highly polished; ovipositor projecting beyond apex of<tei:lb/>gaster by 1-2-1-9 times length of hind tibia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Theronia is a large, mainly tropicopolitan genus with a few species occurring in<tei:lb/>temperate areas. Traditionally it has been divided into a number of subgenera (Gupta, 1962;<tei:lb/>Townes, 1969) although these are more reasonably comparable with the species-groups used in<tei:lb/>related genera (e.g. Xanthopimpld) . Gauld (1984) recognized three subgenera as occurring in<tei:lb/>Australia, T. (Theronia), T. (Parema) and T. (Nomosphecia}.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Theronia species are mostly yellowish or green insects which seem to be restricted to forest<tei:lb/>habitats. In flight they are conspicuous amongst the vegetation but some species spend<tei:lb/>protracted periods host-searching on foot, particularly amongst the leaf litter and along earthen<tei:lb/>banks. When caught, Theronia species sink their large claws into their captor (or his net). These<tei:lb/>claws are difficult to disengage and usually break near their bases at the level of an apparently<tei:lb/>fluid filled cavity. Townes (1940) postulated these may function as poison fangs to deter<tei:lb/>predators but as yet this has not been proven.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Species of the subgenus Nomosphecia are known to be parasites of vespids (Gupta, 1962) but<tei:lb/>the majority of Theronia species are associated with Lepidoptera. Although recorded as primary</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>ICHNEUMONIDAE OF AUSTRALIA 311</tei:p>
         <tei:p>parasites (Gupta, 1962) there is increasing evidence to suggest many are hyperparasitic,<tei:lb/>particularly on other pimplines (Townes, 1940; Short, 1978). Whether hyperparasitism is<tei:lb/>obligatory or facultative is not known but in the field T. (T.) maculosa is found in the same<tei:lb/>microhabitat as Echthromorpha intricatoria, at the same time, but in lesser numbers.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Five species of Theronia occur in Australia. One, T. (P.) penetrans is also widespread in<tei:lb/>Sulawesi, the Moluccas and New Guinea whilst the other four are endemic. The tropical species<tei:lb/>T. (N.) melanosoma is very closely related to two Melanesian species, T. (N.) elegans Gupta and<tei:lb/>T. (N.) diligens (Smith).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>As the subgenera occurring in Australia have recently been redefined (Gauld, 1984) the key<tei:lb/>given below is direct to species though the subgenera are shown in brackets.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to Australian species of Theronia</tei:p>

         <tei:p>THERONIA subgenus NOMOSPHECIA Gupta</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Theronia (Nomosphecia) Gupta, 1962: 68. Type-species: Theronia zebroides Krieger, by original designa-<tei:lb/>tion.</tei:p>

      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>312 I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fore wing length 9-14 mm. Genae strongly constricted behind the eyes; posterior ocellus separated from<tei:lb/>eye by 1-1 times maximum ocellar diameter, interocellar distances 0-7 times maximum ocellar diameter,<tei:lb/>the ocellar triangle higher than broad. Occipital carina complete. Antenna setaceous; scape apically<tei:lb/>truncate 45; flagellum with 37-39 segments, the penultimate distal segments transverse. Scutellum<tei:lb/>carinate laterally only at extreme anterior end. Propodeum with lateral longitudinal carinae complete,<tei:lb/>lateromedian carinae divergent posteriorly and confluent with posterior transverse carina which is absent<tei:lb/>centrally; propodeal spiracle elliptical; submetapleural carina strongly broadened anteriorly. Fore<tei:lb/>wing with cu-a slightly distal to base ofRs&amp;M; areolet large and slightly transverse. Ovipositor<tei:lb/>projecting beyond apex of gaster by 1-8-1-9 times length of hind tibia. Head, alitrunk and most of fore leg<tei:lb/>reddish brown; tarsi, antenna, most of hind leg and gaster black; tergites 2-7 margined posteriorly with<tei:lb/>yellow. Wings strongly infumate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>VARIATION. Some specimens have less extensive black areas of coloration and have the hind<tei:lb/>femora, trochanters, coxae and the scapes reddish brown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. A very distinctive species on account of its mandible. T. (N.) melanosoma appears to<tei:lb/>be restricted to the tropical north-east of Australia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST RECORDS. None.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>ICHNEUMONIDAE OF AUSTRALIA 313</tei:p>
         <tei:p>an acute lobe. Fore tibia unspecialized; fore tarsal segments 3 and 4 without stout bristles; hind femur with<tei:lb/>short close hair ventrally. Fore wing with cu-a distal to base of Rs&amp;M; areolet of moderate size, oblique.<tei:lb/>Gaster of female with tergite 1 1-5-1-7 times as long as broad, its sternite reaching almost to centre.<tei:lb/>Ovipositor projecting beyond apex of gaster by 1 -3 times length of hind tibia.<tei:lb/>Orange-brown, the flagellum and hind tarsus blackish. Wings strongly infumate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>VARIATION. The Australian examples are slightly smaller than the Papuan specimens but<tei:lb/>morphologically otherwise virtually identical, although there is a little variation in the shape of<tei:lb/>the area superomedia. Over its range from Sulawesi to Australia there is considerable variation<tei:lb/>in propodeal sculpture, depth of facial punctures, infumation of wings and extent of darker<tei:lb/>markings on the body. Gupta (1962) recognized two subspecies though remarking that<tei:lb/>intergradation occurred at least on many characters.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species can be recognized easily by the form of the ovipositor and closeness of the<tei:lb/>posterior ocelli. It is only known to occur in northern Queensland though it is widespread from<tei:lb/>Sulawesi to New Guinea.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST RECORDS. None.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>REMARKS. A small insect not obviously closely related to other Australian species. The rather</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>314 I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>slender tergite 1 with the elongate sternite immediately distinguishes fraucai from steindachneri<tei:lb/>and although it resembles maculosa more in this feature the propodeal carination is quite<tei:lb/>different.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>T. (T.) fraucai is known only from Queensland.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST RECORDS. None.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>

         <tei:p>I hcronin (Theronia) maculosa Krieger<tei:lb/>(Figs 67, 68, 73)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Theronia maculosa Krieger, 1906: 239. Lectotype $, AUSTRALIA (MNHU), designated by Townes et al.,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1961:74.<tei:lb/>Theronia viridicans Morley, 1914: 46. Holotype $, AUSTRALIA (BMNH) [examined]. [Synonymized by</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Townes etal., 1961:74.]<tei:lb/>Theronia (Theronia) maculosa Krieger; Gupta, 1962: 46.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fore wing length 8-12 mm. Mandible weakly narrowed, the teeth almost equal. Genae evenly constricted<tei:lb/>behind the eyes; posterior ocellus separated from eye by 1-0 times its maximum diameter, interocellar<tei:lb/>distance 0-8 times maximum ocellar diameter, the ocellar triangle almost equilateral. Occipital carina<tei:lb/>complete. Antenna setaceous; scape apically truncate 55; flagellum with 40-42 segments, the penultimate<tei:lb/>distal segments subquadrate. Scutellum carinate 0-2-0-4 of its length. Propodeum with lateral longitudinal<tei:lb/>carinae complete, lateromedian carinae anteriorly strong, almost parallel and with rectilinear area<tei:lb/>superomedia almost closed posteriorly (Fig. 68); propodeal spiracle elliptical; submetapleural carina<tei:lb/>evenly broadened anteriorly (Fig. 67). Fore tibia unspecialized; fore tarsal segments 3 and 4 without strong<tei:lb/>bristles; hind femur with rather short hairs ventrally. Fore wing with cu-a opposite or slightly distal to base<tei:lb/>ofRs&amp;M; areolet rather narrow, oblique. Gaster of female with tergite 1 1-6-1-8 times as long as broad, its<tei:lb/>sternite reaching almost to centre. Ovipositor projecting beyond apex of gaster by 1-4-1-5 times length of<tei:lb/>hind tibia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Yellowish brown, with flagellum, marks on base and apex of hind femur and hind tarsus blackish; gaster<tei:lb/>frequently with black spots on tergites 1-5. Wings moderately infumate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>VARIATION. Whilst alive most specimens have a greenish gaster and frequently also green hind<tei:lb/>legs but this colour fades rapidly after death. Some variation in the distribution of black spots<tei:lb/>occurs but all specimens seem to have them on tergites 2-4.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. A common and rather widespread endemic Australian species (Map 18) found mostly<tei:lb/>in cooler damp woodlands. It is readily distinguished from other Theronia species by the black<tei:lb/>spots on some gastral tergites. It is the only Australian species with a pronounced greenish tinge,<tei:lb/>and freshly emerged females are often brilliant emerald-green.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST RECORDS. Anthelidae: Anthela acuta (Walker). Saturniidae: Antheraea astrophela Walker<tei:lb/>(Chadwick &amp; Nikitin, 1976). Short (1978), on the basis of dissection of a cocoon oiAntheraea sp.<tei:lb/>from which Theronia had emerged, suggested Theronia is hyperparasitic, using Pimplini as<tei:lb/>hosts.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>homonym of Theronia daripennis Cameron, 1911a.] [Synonymized by Townes et al., 1961: 76.]<tei:lb/>Habropimpla anthereae (Cameron) Girault, 1925: 39. [Unjustified emendation.]<tei:lb/>Theronia (Theronia) steindachneri Krieger; Gupta, 1962: 34.<tei:lb/>Theronia (Theronia) fumipennis Morley; Gupta, 1962: 35.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fore wing length 7-12 mm. Mandible weakly narrowed, the teeth almost equal. Genae rounded behind<tei:lb/>eyes, in larger specimens somewhat inflated; posterior ocellus separated from eye by 1-1-1-2 times its<tei:lb/>maximum diameter, interocellar distance 0-7-0-8 times maximum ocellar diameter, the ocellar triangle<tei:lb/>slightly higher than broad. Occipital carina complete. Antenna stout, not distally tapered; scape apically<tei:lb/>truncate 45-50; flagellum with 37-39 segments, the penultimate distal segments slightly broader than long<tei:lb/>(Fig. 70). Scutellum carinate 0-2-0-5 of its length, generally most extensively carinate in the male.<tei:lb/>Propodeum with lateral longitudinal carinae complete; lateromedian carinae present anteriorly, rather far<tei:lb/>apart and divergent posteriorly, confluent with lateral remnants of posterior transverse carina (Fig. 69);<tei:lb/>propodeal spiracle elliptical; submetapleural carina very strongly broadened anteriorly, often bearing<tei:lb/>coarse striae. Fore tibia unspecialized; fore tarsal segments 3 and 4 without stout bristles; hind femur with<tei:lb/>long rather sparse hairs ventrally. Fore wing with cu-a slightly distal to base of Rs&amp;M; areolet quite large,<tei:lb/>oblique. Gaster of female with tergite 1 1-4-1-5 times as long as broad, its sternite extending 0-2-0-3 of its<tei:lb/>length (Fig. 66). Ovipositor projecting beyond apex of gaster by 1-2-1-3 times length of hind tibia, the<tei:lb/>lower valve simple.<tei:lb/>Orange, with antenna and hind tarsus mainly blackish. Wings weakly to moderately infumate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>VARIATION. Specimens from northern Queensland have more strongly infumate wings and often<tei:lb/>slightly narrower genae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Gupta (1962) treated fumipennis as a separate species on account of the slightly<tei:lb/>narrower genae, paler wings and less strongly ridged submetapleural carina. The latter character<tei:lb/>is so variable as to be useless, whilst many specimens of a variety of species have slightly more<tei:lb/>infumate wings in the more equatorial region of their ranges. This leaves only the head shape<tei:lb/>and here intermediates exist so I have chosen to regard fumipennis as a synonym.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>T. steindachneri appears to be a more northerly species than T. maculosa and is most<tei:lb/>frequently collected in Queensland and northern New South Wales. The more southern records<tei:lb/>(e.g. Australian Capital Territory) all refer to specimens collected in late summer.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST RECORDS. Lymantriidae: Teia anartoides Walker (BMNH). Noctuidae: Pericyma cruegeri<tei:lb/>(Butler) (DPIQ). Psychidae: Hyalarcta huebneri (Westwood) (QM). Saturniidae: Antheraea<tei:lb/>astrophela Walker (Cameron, 1912).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Australia: 1 cf (holotype of teiae). New South Wales, Tenterfield, reared ex Teia anartoides (Froggatt)<tei:lb/>(BMNH); 1 $ (holotype of antherae). New South Wales, Richmond, reared ex Antheraea astrophela<tei:lb/>(Froggatt) (BMNH); 1 $ (holotype of fumipennis), Queensland, Townesville (Dodd) (BMNH); 2 $&gt;<tei:lb/>(paratypes), Mackay (Turner) (BMNH); 1 d* (holotype of daripennis) , New South Wales, Sydney, 1856<tei:lb/>(Camming) (BMNH); 1 cf (paratype), Queensland, Mackay (Turner) (BMNH); 1 $ (paratype), Victoria<tei:lb/>(French) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
