      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>316 I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Australia: 53 $, 17 cf , Australian Capital Territory, New South Wales, Queensland (Map 17) (AM;<tei:lb/>ANIC; BMNH; DAR; DPIQ; QM; QUM).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tribe RHYSSINI</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Rhyssini is an apparent holophyletic group of pimplines characterized by the possession of a<tei:lb/>cornute process on the last gastral tergite of the female and by the presence of transverse rugae<tei:lb/>on the mesoscutum. The group includes some of the largest of ichneumonids and females are<tei:lb/>particularly distinctive on account of their very long ovipositor. Rhyssines are all believed to be<tei:lb/>parasites of wood-boring holometabolous insect larvae, and recorded hosts include Siricidae,<tei:lb/>Xiphydriidae, Syntexidae and Cerambycidae. The hosts of the numerous tropical species are<tei:lb/>virtually unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The tribe includes eight genera which are clearly divisible into two groups. These are the<tei:lb/>monobasic Rhyssa-group, characterized by possession of numerous primitive features such as<tei:lb/>having sternite 1 free, possessing a relatively unspecialized pronotum and not having a ridge on<tei:lb/>the median trochantellus, and the Epirhyssa-group containing the genera Lytarmes, Epirhyssa,<tei:lb/>Cyrtorhyssa, Rhyssella, Megarhyssa, Myllenyxis and Triancyra. This latter group is charac-<tei:lb/>terized by several apomorphic features including having sternite 1 fused to the tergite, having a<tei:lb/>flange along the fore margin of the pronotum and possessing a ridge on the median trochantel-<tei:lb/>lus. The least specialized genus, Rhyssa, is Holarctic whilst many of the most highly specialized<tei:lb/>genera of the Epirhyssa-group are tropical. Three genera are known to occur in Australia.<tei:lb/>Rhyssa and Megarhyssa were introduced to Victoria and Tasmania in an attempt to control Sirex<tei:lb/>infestations in Pinus plantations; Epirhyssa is apparently a recently colonist of the north of<tei:lb/>Queensland.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>EPIRHYSSA Cresson</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Epirhyssa Cresson, 1865: 39. Type-species: Epirhyssa speciosa Cresson, by subsequent designation,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Viereck, 1914: 52.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Rhyssonota Kriechbaumer, 1890: 489. Type-species: Rhyssonota tristis Kriechbaumer, by monotypy.<tei:lb/>Hierax Tosquinet, 1903: 255. Type-species: Hierax raptor Tosquinet, by monotypy. [Homonym of Hierax</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Vigors, 1826.]<tei:lb/>Sychnostigma Baltazar, 1961: 75. [Replacement name for Hierax Tosquinet.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Large species, fore wing length (9)15-17 mm; clypeus with a trace of a median apical tooth, laterally<tei:lb/>tuberculate; occipital carina complete, mediodorsally dipped. Pronotum mediodorsally with a deep<tei:lb/>transverse groove separating off recurved anterior lip; epicnemial carina present; propodeum without<tei:lb/>distinct carinae, spiracle elliptical. Female with claws simple; fore wing with 3r-m absent; hind wing with<tei:lb/>first abscissa of Cw t short, less than 0-2 times length of cu-a. Sternites 2-4 of female bearing tubercles near<tei:lb/>anterior edge; tergite 2 with thyridia contiguous with anterior margin; tergites 2-4 smooth; ovipositor<tei:lb/>straight, projecting beyond apex of gaster by about 4-0 times the length of hind tibia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Epirhyssa is a large tropicopolitan genus, the majority of species of which seem to<tei:lb/>inhabit lowland tropical rain forest. Kamath &amp; Gupta (1972) recognized 39 Indo-Australian<tei:lb/>species but a number of unplaced specimens are to hand. These may represent additional species<tei:lb/>or the described species may encompass a greater range of morphological variation than Kamath<tei:lb/>&amp; Gupta discerned. Recently collected material favours the latter suggestion.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Two species occur in New Guinea and it is with slight hesitation that I consider the sole<tei:lb/>Australian specimen conspecific with one of these.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Epirhyssa biroi Mocsary comb. rev.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Epirhyssa biroi Mocsary, 1905: 17. Holotype $ , PAPUA NEW GUINEA (TM) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ahyborhyssa biroi (Mocsary) Enderlein, 1919: 152.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Sychnostigma biroi (Mocsary) Townes et al., 1961: 87; Kamath &amp; Gupta, 1972: 169.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Face transversely striate, tending to vertically striate centrally adjacent to clypeus; fron transversely<tei:lb/>semicircularly wrinkled, vertex sparsely punctate. Flagellum with 37 segments. Mesopleuron with subtegu-<tei:lb/>lar ridge convex, without a pronounced posterior concavity; epicnemial carina present, weak, its upper end</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>ICHNEUMONIDAE OF AUSTRALIA 317</tei:p>
         <tei:p>about on level of mesopleural pit, remote from anterior margin of pleuron; mesopleuron sparsely punctate<tei:lb/>on upper part, ventrally becoming more coarsely and closely obliquely punctate; epicnemium closely<tei:lb/>punctate, the area behind fore coxae striate; metapleuron sparsely punctate. Propodeum dorsally smooth,<tei:lb/>evenly convex, at most with minute punctures. Tergites of gaster smooth and polished, the posterior<tei:lb/>tergites with fine punctures.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Yellow with mandibles and antenna black; vertex black, the area of this colour extending to base of<tei:lb/>antenna, to orbits and down onto the occiput above the foramen. Alitrunk black-marked on hind margin of<tei:lb/>pronotum, fore margin of mesopleuron, mesoscutum anteriorly and centrally and metanotum narrowly;<tei:lb/>fore femur black-striped; hind tarsus brown, the distal segment black; gaster yellowish with anterior and<tei:lb/>often posterior margins of tergites infuscate; ovipositor sheath blackish brown, distally yellowish brown.<tei:lb/>Wings infumate, apices very strongly so; pterostigma black.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Only a single Australian specimen is at hand. It appears to be conspecific with the<tei:lb/>New Guinea material studied but the combination of all specimens encompasses a greater range<tei:lb/>of variation than previously recognized in the genus. However, a considerable range of variation<tei:lb/>is known to occur in one of the few well-studied rhyssines, Rhyssa persuasoria (Spradbery &amp;<tei:lb/>Ratkowsky, 1974), so similar extensive variation may be expected in related taxa. The<tei:lb/>Australian specimen differs from the Papuan examples in having more finely punctate meso- and<tei:lb/>metapleurae and a weaker epicnemial carina. Amongst the Papuan specimens there is consider-<tei:lb/>able variation in the degree of infuscation of the wings. Some exceptionally small specimens<tei:lb/>from Wau have the wings hyaline except distally. Some specimens have well-developed black<tei:lb/>marks at the anterior and posterior margins of the gastral tergites whilst in one specimen the<tei:lb/>gaster is more or less entirely yellow. The hind tarsi are usually infuscate though almost<tei:lb/>imperceptibly so in some individuals.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>E. biroi is known in Australia only from tropical Queensland. It is widely distributed<tei:lb/>throughout New Guinea and is not uncommon in lowland rain forest. It is here recorded for the<tei:lb/>first time from New Britain.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST RECORDS. None.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Papua New Guinea: 1 $ (holotype), Simbang on Huon Gulf (Biro) (TM).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Australia: 1 $, Queensland, Shipton's Flat (1547'S; 14514'E), x.1980 (Cardale) (ANIC). New Britain:<tei:lb/>1 $, Cape Hoskins, vi.1970 (Stibick) (TC). Papua New Guinea: 1 $, Popondetta, x.1968 (Hassan)<tei:lb/>(BMNH); 1 $, Wau, 1200 m, vii-viii.1970 (Robinson) (TC); 1 ?, 1 cT, Wau, 1000 m, x.1979 (Gauld)<tei:lb/>(BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MEGARHYSSA Ashmead</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thalessa Holmgren, 1859: 122. Type-species: Ichneumon clavatus F. (= Ichneumon gigas Laxmann), by</tei:p>
         <tei:p>subsequent designation, Ashmead, 1900a: 53. [Homonym of Thalessa Adams, 1843.]<tei:lb/>Megarhyssa Ashmead, 1900ft: 368. [Replacement name for Thalessa Holmgren.]<tei:lb/>Megalorhyssa Schulz, 1906: 115. [Unjustified emendation.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Very large species, fore wing length 20-30 mm (Australian specimens); clypeus with a weak median apical<tei:lb/>tooth, laterally tuberculate; occipital carina usually obsolescent centrally. Pronotum mediodorsally with a<tei:lb/>deep transverse groove cutting off anterior recurved lip; epicnemial carina present; propodeum without<tei:lb/>distinct carinae, spiracle oval. Female with claws simple; fore wing with 3r-m present, enclosing large,<tei:lb/>triangular areolet; hind wing with first abscissa of Cu^ very short, less than 0-2 times length of cu-a.<tei:lb/>Sternites 2-4 of female bearing tubercles near anterior edge; tergite 2 with thyridia separated from anterior<tei:lb/>margin; tergites 2-4 smooth; ovipositor straight, projecting beyond apex of gaster by about 6-0 times length<tei:lb/>of hind tibia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. A moderate-sized Holarctic and Oriental genus with a single North American<tei:lb/>species, M. nortoni, introduced into Tasmania and Victoria to control Sirex infestations in Pinus<tei:lb/>radiata plantations (Taylor, 1976; Neumann &amp; Minko, 1981). A second species, M. emargina-<tei:lb/>toria (Thunberg), was also introduced into Tasmania in 1964, but the females displayed little<tei:lb/>interest in the Sirex infested timber (Taylor, 1967) and the species has not become established.<tei:lb/>M. nortoni has become an important factor in controlling the population of Sirex in the<tei:lb/>south-east of Australia (Taylor, 1978).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>318 I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Megarhyssa nortoni (Cresson)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Rhyssa nortoni Cresson, 1864: 317. Holotype $, U.S.A. (PANS).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thalessa nortoni (Cresson) Cresson, 1870: 169.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thalessa Quebecensis Provancher, 1873: 447. Lectotype $, CANADA (UL), designated by Barren, 1975:</tei:p>
         <tei:p>543. [Synonymized by Morley, 1913o: 16.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Megarhyssa nortonii (Cresson) Dalla Torre, 1901: 481. [Unjustified emendation.]<tei:lb/>Megarhyssa quebecensis (Provancher) Dalla Torre, 1901: 481.<tei:lb/>Megarhyssa nortoni (Cresson); Townes &amp; Townes, 1960: 417.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Face slightly coriaceous; frons transversely wrinkled; vertex punctate finely, centrally tending to striate<tei:lb/>behind ocellar triangle. Mesopleuron ventrally coarsely punctate; metapleuron smooth, almost impunc-<tei:lb/>tate. Scutellum tranversely striate; propodeum dorsally smooth.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Head black, facial and frontal orbits and gena yellow; alitrunk brown, notauli, margins of most sclerites,<tei:lb/>most of mesopleuron and axilla black; pronotum centrally, metapleuron in part, scutellum, postscutellum<tei:lb/>and hind corners of propodeum yellow; coxae black, remainder of legs yellowish or brownish; gaster<tei:lb/>brown, tergites black-margined and with tergites 3-7 with a pair of yellow spots. Wings weakly, uniformly<tei:lb/>infuscate; pterostigma brown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Carlson (1979) suggests this North American native may be conspecific with the<tei:lb/>Palaearctic species M. gigas (Laxmann) but confirmation of this requires more detailed study.<tei:lb/>M. nortoni is believed to be the only established species of Megarhyssa in Australia. It differs<tei:lb/>from the European species, M. emarginatoria Thunberg, in having a slightly shorter ovipositor<tei:lb/>(that of emarginatoria is about 8 times the length of the hind tibia) and in colour. The genal orbits<tei:lb/>of emarginatoria are black and the coxae orange.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A considerable number of observations have been made on the biology of this species in North<tei:lb/>America (e.g., Essig, 1926; Madden, 1968) whilst its mating behaviour in New Zealand is<tei:lb/>documented by Nuttall (1973).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST RECORDS. Sirex species. In North America it is also known to parasitize other Siricinae such<tei:lb/>as species of Xeris and Urocerus (Carlson, 1979).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Australia: 5 $, 2 cT, Tasmania, Hobart, ii.1967 (Taylor) (BMNH). U.S.A., Canada: 10 $, 10 cf , various<tei:lb/>localities including material compared with the holotype by H. K. Townes (BMNH; TC).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>RHYSSA Gravenhorst</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Rhyssa Gravenhorst, 1829: 260. Type-species: Ichneumon persuasorius L., by subsequent designation,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Westwood, 1840: 59.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cryptocentrum Kirby, 1837: 260. Type-species: Cryptocentrum lineolatum Kirby, by monotypy.<tei:lb/>Pararhyssa Walsh, 1873: 109. Type-species: Ichneumon persuasorius L., by subsequent designation,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Viereck, 1914: 111.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Medium-sized to very large species, fore wing length 7-25 mm; clypeus with a median apical tooth, without<tei:lb/>lateral tubercles; occipital carina mediodorsally incomplete. Pronotum with a mediodorsal depression,<tei:lb/>without a deep transverse furrow separating anterior lip-like portion; epicnemial carina present; pro-<tei:lb/>podeum without distinct carinae, often transversely striate, spiracle oval. Female with claws simple; fore<tei:lb/>wing with 3r-m present enclosing a triangular areolet; hind wing with first abscissa of Cu\ short, less than<tei:lb/>0-3 times length of cu-a. First sternite not fused with tergite; sternites 2-4 of female bearing tubercles near<tei:lb/>centre; tergite 2 with thyridia near to anterior margin; tergites 2-4 smooth; ovipositor straight, projecting<tei:lb/>beyond apex of gaster by more than 4-0 times length of hind tibia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Rhyssa is a relatively small genus, species of which are common parasites of siricids in<tei:lb/>the north temperate region. A species, R. persuasoria, was first introduced into the southern<tei:lb/>hemisphere in 1928-31 in an attempt to control Sirex noctilio in New Zealand (Miller &amp; Clark,<tei:lb/>1935). The discovery of S. noctilio in a Pinus radiata plantation near Hobart, Tasmania in March<tei:lb/>1952 (Gilbert &amp; Miller, 1952) prompted the Tasmanian Department of Agriculture to approach<tei:lb/>the New Zealand authorities (DSIR and the Forest Research Institute) for shipments of R.<tei:lb/>persuasoria. In 1957 this rhyssine was liberated in Tasmania and by 1959 it seemed to have<tei:lb/>become established (Taylor, 1967). In 1961 Sirex was discovered in Victoria (Irvine, 1962) and</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>ICHNEUMONIDAE OF AUSTRALIA 319</tei:p>
         <tei:p>the following year the National Sirex Fund was established to promote an extensive programme<tei:lb/>of research on Sirex and its parasites. In subsequent years many parasites were introduced into<tei:lb/>Australia, including eight species of Rhyssa. These were - R. alaskensis Ashmead (49 9 from<tei:lb/>south western U.S.A.); R. amoena Gravenhorst (12 $ from Europe); R. crevieri (Provancher)<tei:lb/>(31 9 from eastern Canada); R. hoferi Rohwer (34 9 from Arizona and New Mexico); R.<tei:lb/>howdenorum Townes (95 9 from the south-eastern U.S.A.); R. jozana Matsumura (26 9 from<tei:lb/>Japan); R. lineolata (Kirby) (30 9 from New Zealand and 30 9 from Canada and the U.S.A.);<tei:lb/>R. persuasoria (L.) (1622 9 from Europe, Turkey, Morocco, North America, Japan and India)<tei:lb/>(Taylor, 1976). Of these, only R. persuasoria seems to have become firmly established<tei:lb/>(Neumann &amp; Minko, 1981).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Rhyssa persuasoria (L. )</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ichneumon persuosorius L., 1758: 562. Lectotype cf, 'EUROPE' (LSL), designated by Fitton, 1978: 371</tei:p>
         <tei:p>[examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pimpla persuasoria (L.) F., 1804: 112.<tei:lb/>Rhyssa persuasoria (L.) Gravenhorst, 1829: 267; Townes &amp; Townes, 1960: 406.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Face somewhat coriaceous; frons smooth; vertex punctate, more closely and finely so laterally. Meso- and<tei:lb/>metapleurae quite closely punctate; scutellum transversely striate; propodeum transversely weakly striate,<tei:lb/>with a median longitudinal depression. Male with sternites 2-4 undivided.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female blackish; orbits, marks on pronotum, subalar prominence, tegula, hind corner of mesopleuron,<tei:lb/>scutellum, postscutellum, hind part of metapleuron, propodeum posteriorly, hind margin of tergite 1 and<tei:lb/>two pairs of spots on hind margins of tergites 2+ , whitish; legs orange, hind leg distal to femur progressively<tei:lb/>infuscate. Wings more or less hyaline; pterostigma blackish. Male much less extensively pale-marked than<tei:lb/>female, black; face except clypeus, frontal and genal orbits partially, pronotum dorsally and double paired<tei:lb/>spots on tergites 2+ , white. Legs and wings similar in colour to those of female.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This introduced species is established in Pinus plantations in Tasmania and Victoria,<tei:lb/>but there is some danger that others of the various Rhyssa species introduced and presumed not<tei:lb/>to have become established may be overlooked or misidentified as R. persuasoria. This has<tei:lb/>happened in New Zealand where R. lineolata (Kirby), an introduced Nearctic species, has<tei:lb/>recently been rediscovered and appears to have become established (Zondag &amp; Nuttall, 1961).<tei:lb/>It is therefore worth emphasizing the following features.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>R. persuasoria is mainly black and has paired spots or sometimes bars on the hind margins of<tei:lb/>tergites 2-4, the temple is at least partly pale-marked, the antennae are unicolorous blackish and<tei:lb/>the male has sternites 2-4 of the gaster entire. All other species introduced at various times to<tei:lb/>Australia differ in one or more features. R. hoferi is basically brownish and, like R. howdenor-<tei:lb/>um, has continuous pale bands on the hind margins of tergites 2-4 of the gaster. R. alaskensis, R.<tei:lb/>crevieri, R. lineolata, R. amoena and R. jozana have sternites 2-4 of the male gaster longitudinal-<tei:lb/>ly divided into three and often have pale-banded antennae; R. alaskensis has the temple entirely<tei:lb/>black.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>A detailed account of the biology ofR. persuasoria is given by Morgan &amp; Stewart (1966) whilst<tei:lb/>Spradbery (1970) details the host-finding behaviour.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST RECORDS. In Australia, Sirex noctilio F. (Siricidae). In the north temperate region R.<tei:lb/>persuasoria is recorded as a parasite of a variety of other Siricinae. In the U.S.A. it is also<tei:lb/>recorded from Syntexidae (Carlson, 1979) whilst there are a number of early European records<tei:lb/>of this species attacking cerambycid larvae (Aubert, 1969).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Australia: 10 $, 8 cf , Tasmania, (ANIC; BMNH). Europe: 187 $, 174 cf , various localities.<tei:lb/>'Europe': 1 9 (lectotype) (LSL).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Subfamily XORIDINAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Xoridinae is one of the smaller subfamilies containing, world-wide, four genera. Three of<tei:lb/>these are North Temperate, the fourth, Xorides, is quite large and cosmopolitan. It is<tei:lb/>represented in Australia by three species.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>320 I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Zoogeography</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Of the four genera in the Xoridinae only Xorides occurs outside the North Temperate region.<tei:lb/>Species of this genus are not uncommon in temperate and tropical forests. Xorides is currently<tei:lb/>divided into 10 subgenera (Townes, 1969), four of which occur in the Oriental region. Only one<tei:lb/>subgenus, X. (Cyanoxorides), extends to Australia and I have only seen species of this group<tei:lb/>from Queensland and northern New South Wales.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Biology</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Xoridines are parasites of wood-boring Coleoptera and Symphyta. Most usually larvae serve as<tei:lb/>hosts but pupae and even adults within their cocoon may be parasitized. The families Ceramby-<tei:lb/>cidae and Siricidae are the commonest hosts though a number of other coleopterous families are<tei:lb/>also attacked. There are a number of studies on the biology of xoridines in Europe and North<tei:lb/>America and that of Chrystal &amp; Skinner (1931) serves as a typical example. These authors<tei:lb/>observed that the female xoridine oviposited through the bark into the host gallery. A single egg<tei:lb/>was deposited on or near the cerambycid larva. Although it was never observed they consider it<tei:lb/>highly likely that the host larva was stung and paralysed prior to oviposition. Larvae that had<tei:lb/>been oviposited on were virtually immotile but alive, and even if the xoridine egg failed to hatch<tei:lb/>the cerambycid larva remained unmoving for weeks before eventually dying. The elongate,<tei:lb/>fusiform egg hatched about eight days after oviposition and the first instar larva immediately<tei:lb/>began attacking the host. It fed by burying its mandibles in the host's integument and sucking the<tei:lb/>body fluids. Growth was rapid and after six or seven days the larva moulted. The second instar<tei:lb/>larva resembled the first and lasted a further four or five days. At about this time the host larva<tei:lb/>was found to be dead. The third larval instar was stouter with a less well-developed head. This<tei:lb/>continued to feed on the host for six to seven days before moulting. The fourth and final instar<tei:lb/>larva consumed the entire host except for the head capsule and chitinous exoskeleton in five or<tei:lb/>six days. It then remained motionless for several days before spinning a capacious cocoon. The<tei:lb/>larva was observed to overwinter in this cocoon and pupated in the spring of the following year.<tei:lb/>The duration of the pupal stage was short, with the adult emerging after nine or ten days.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The head of the final instar xoridine larva is quite strongly sclerotized and the antennae are<tei:lb/>papilliform, which is probably the plesiomorphic condition for ichneumonids. The epistomal<tei:lb/>arch is incomplete but the other sclerites are well formed. The mandibles are large with<tei:lb/>numerous small accessory teeth. Short (1978) considered xoridine larvae to be structurally<tei:lb/>primitive.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>XORIDES subgenus CYANOXORIDES Cameron<tei:lb/>Cyanoxorides Cameron, 1903: 141. Type-species: Cyanoxorides brookei Cameron, by monotypy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Spiloxorides Cameron, 1903: 143. Type-species: Spiloxorides ruficeps Cameron, by monotypy.<tei:lb/>Xorides (Cyanoxorides) Cameron; Townes &amp; Townes, 1960: 491.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Flagellum of female with subapical angulation, the segment proximal to this angulation bearing peg-like<tei:lb/>seta; flagellum of male filiform with conspicuous long fine pubescence; pronotum specialized with dorsal<tei:lb/>carinae and strong epomia; epicnemial carina present; scuto-scutellar groove with a median carina;<tei:lb/>posterior transverse carina of mesosternum interrupted before mid coxae. Fore wing with cu-a proximal to<tei:lb/>base of Rs&amp;M. Gaster with tergite 2 with anterior corners impressed, with traces of diagonal furrows and a<tei:lb/>central depression which may be raised to form a median longitudinal ridge posteriorly.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The flagellum, pronotum, scuto-scutellar groove and gastral sculpture are distinctive<tei:lb/>features enabling these insects to be easily recognized.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to Australian species of Xorides (Cyanoxorides)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 Alitrunk and gaster entirely orange-brown, only distal margin of tergite 7 pale-banded;<tei:lb/>flagellum unicolorous black; propodeum with carinae sharply raised and straight, clearly<tei:lb/>delineating regular areae species 1 (p. 322)</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>ICHNEUMONIDAE OF AUSTRALIA 321</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Alitrunk and gaster partly to almost completely black; flagellum with a conspicuous white band</tei:p>
         <tei:p>in distal part ; propodeum with irregular and often indistinctly delineated carinae 2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 Alitrunk black; gaster predominantly black, tergite 1 anteriorly reddish, tergites 7+ posteriorly</tei:p>
         <tei:p>white-banded ; propodeum with lateral areae reticulo-rugose australiensis (Szepligeti) (p. 321)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Alitrunk black with large pale marks laterally; gaster black with tergite 1 anteriorly and ter-<tei:lb/>gites 1+ posteriorly pale-banded; propodeum with lateral areae punctate with scattered<tei:lb/>rugae crudelis (Turner)(p. 321)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Xorides (Cyanoxorides) australiensis (Szepligeti)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cyanoxorides australiensis Szepligeti, 1914: 420. Holotype $, AUSTRALIA (TM) [examined].<tei:lb/>Xorides (Cyanoxorides) australiensis (Szepligeti) Townes etal, 1961: 107.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fore wing length 11-13 mm. A shining species with head and much of alitrunk very finely punctate.<tei:lb/>Propodeum with carinae rather weak and irregular with numerous subsidiary carinulae radiating from<tei:lb/>them; lateral areae reticulo-rugose. Gaster almost matt, tergite 1 centrally puncto-coriaceous, posteriorly<tei:lb/>becoming striato-coriaceous.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female black, face except centrally, upper orbits, genae in part and flagellar bands, white; tergite 1<tei:lb/>anteriorly reddish, tergites 7+ posteriorly white-banded. Legs golden yellow, distal 0-5 of hind femur,<tei:lb/>distal 0-4 of hind femur and hind tarsal segment 5 black, remaining hind tarsal segments white. Male similar<tei:lb/>to female except with smaller pale markings on head.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. X. australiensis is easily recognized by its colour pattern, but it is chromatically very<tei:lb/>similar to a mesostenine, Gotra gilberti (Turner). Both species can be found resting on tree<tei:lb/>trunks in rain forest and they are not easily distinguished in the field. However, X. australiensis<tei:lb/>and G. gilberti are quite unalike in detailed morphology (Gauld, 1984). The Gotra species can be<tei:lb/>distinguished by its wedge-shaped areolet and simple female flagellum. Xorides lacks an areolet<tei:lb/>and the female has a subapical angulation in the flagellum. X. australiensis is apparently the most<tei:lb/>common Australian xoridine and is widely distributed in Queensland and south into northern<tei:lb/>New South Wales.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST RECORDS. None.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Australia: 1 $ (holotype of australiensis), 'New South Wales' (TM).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Australia: 1 $, Queensland, Brisbane, xi.1976 (Boucek) (BMNH); 1 $, Brisbane, Long Pocket, 1977<tei:lb/>(Galloway} (BMNH); 1 cT, Bundaberg, Baldwin Swamp, ii.1973 (Frauca) (ANIC); 2 $, Mt Glorious,<tei:lb/>xii.1976 (Boucek) (BMNH); 1 $, Mt Tambourine, i.1936 (Hacker) (BMNH); 1 $, Mt Tambourine,<tei:lb/>x-xi.1978 (Galloway) (BMNH); 3 ?, Watalgan Rg., ix-xii.1972, v.1974 (Frauca) (ANIC).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Xorides (Cyanoxorides) crudelis (Turner)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Xylonomus crudelis Turner, 1919: 553. Holotype $, AUSTRALIA (BMNH) [examined].<tei:lb/>Xorides (Cyanoxorides) crudelis (Turner) Townes &amp; Townes, 1960: 494.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fore wing length 12-14 mm. A weakly polished species with fine punctures laterally on gaster, dorsally<tei:lb/>almost impunctate. Propodeum with carinae rather weak and irregular with numerous subsidiary radiating<tei:lb/>carinulae; lateral areae punctate with scattered rugae. Gaster almost matt, tergite 1 centrally punctate,<tei:lb/>posteriorly becoming puncto-reticulate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female black with flagellar band, face, upper orbits, genae in part, marks on vertex, much of pronotum,<tei:lb/>mesopleuron and propodeum laterally, tergite 1 anteriorly and posteriorly and tergites 2+ posteriorly,<tei:lb/>white-marked. Legs orange, all coxae white-marked; hind trochanteral segments, distal 0-2 of hind femur,<tei:lb/>distal 0-4 of hind tibia and hind tarsal segment 5 blackish, remainder of hind tarsus white. Male unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. X. crudelis can be easily separated from australiensis by the striped black and white<tei:lb/>gaster. It is a rather uncommon insect and possibly restricted to northern Queensland.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST RECORDS. None.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Australia: 1 $ (holotype), Queensland, Kuranda (Turner) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Australia: 1 $ , Queensland, 6 km S. Daintree, in rain forest, x.1966 (Taylor) (ANIC); 1 $ , Gordonvale,<tei:lb/>1919 (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>322 I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Xorides (Cyanoxorides) species 1</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fore wing length 4 mm. A shining species with alitrunk dorsally rather coarsely punctate, laterally finely<tei:lb/>but strongly punctate. Propodeum with carinae very strong, sharply raised, without carinulae, and<tei:lb/>delineating regular areae; lateral areae smooth with few scattered rugae. Gaster weakly polished, tergite 1<tei:lb/>centrally puncto- reticulate, posteriorly tending to obsolescent striations.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Male with head black, face, upper orbits and genae white-marked; flagellum unicolorous blackish;<tei:lb/>alitrunk and gaster orange-brown, only distal margin of tergite 7 whitish. Legs brownish orange, all tibiae<tei:lb/>distally infuscate; hind femur with distal 0-1 blackish, hind basitarsus proximally and tarsal segment 5<tei:lb/>black, remainder of tarsus white.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The single specimen known is a male. Considering the chromatic differences it is<tei:lb/>unlikely to be the unknown male ofcrudelis although structurally the species are fairly similar. I<tei:lb/>have avoided formally naming the species until a female is collected when proper comparison<tei:lb/>may be made with other Australian species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST RECORDS. None.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED<tei:lb/>Australia: 1 d", Queensland, Shipton's Flat (1547'S; 14514'E), x.1980 (Cardale) (ANIC).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Subfamily ACAENITINAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Acaenitinae is a moderately large subfamily, but often one of the most poorly represented<tei:lb/>in general collections. The majority of species are moderately large insects and the females have<tei:lb/>a conspicuous long ovipositor. They are usually brightly coloured and are amongst the most<tei:lb/>striking of all ichneumonids. Acaenitines are parasites of wood-boring insect larvae, particularly<tei:lb/>those of Coleoptera (Townes &amp; Townes, 1962), and most species appear to be restricted to<tei:lb/>forest habitats.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The subfamily is divided into two tribes, the Coleocentrini and the Acaenitini. The latter is<tei:lb/>represented in Australia by a single genus, Yezoceryx.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Zoogeography</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Coleocentrini comprises seven small genera most of which are restricted to the Palaearctic<tei:lb/>region. Two, Coleocentrus and Mesoclistus, are represented in North America. The former also<tei:lb/>occurs in the mountains on the Palaearctic/Oriental interface (Townes, 1971b). The Acaenitini<tei:lb/>comprises 18 genera and includes most species of the subfamily. All genera occur in the Old<tei:lb/>World although three, Arotes, Spilopteron and Yezoceryx, are also represented in North<tei:lb/>America. The former extends as far south as about 15N but otherwise acaenitines are absent<tei:lb/>from the Neotropical region. The greatest diversity of species appears to be in everwet South<tei:lb/>East Asia and one genus in particular, Yezoceryx, is very large. A recent series of short<tei:lb/>collecting trips to Brunei yielded over 20 species of Yezoceryx, most of which were represented<tei:lb/>by single specimens. Yezoceryx seems to be very closely related to the Afrotropical genus<tei:lb/>Phorotrophus; the former is probably paraphyletic with respect to the latter. Several species of<tei:lb/>Yezoceryx occur in New Guinea and in the present work six are believed to occur in Australia.<tei:lb/>Almost certainly the group has spread rather recently to Australia from Asia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Biology</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Virtually nothing is known about the biology of acaenitines except that they are parasites of<tei:lb/>wood-boring holometabolous insect larvae. The most usual hosts appear to be Coleoptera, but<tei:lb/>there are records from Sesiidae and Siricidae (Aubert, 1969). It is not known for certain whether<tei:lb/>acaenitines are endo- or ecto-parasites. Townes (1969: 34) includes them in his 'section IF<tei:lb/>(internal parasites) together with such known endoparasitoids as Diplazontinae, Anomaloni-<tei:lb/>nae, Metopiinae, Collyriinae and Ichneumoninae. However, Aubert (1969) states that several<tei:lb/>European species are 'sans doubte ectoparasite larvaire'. Neither author actually says on what<tei:lb/>evidence his statement is based and both Townes, in later works (e.g. 19716), and other authors<tei:lb/>who have examined larval remains (e.g. Short, 1978) have conspicuously avoided stating</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>ICHNEUMONIDAE OF AUSTRALIA 323</tei:p>
         <tei:p>whether they are ecto- or endoparasites. Observations appear to have been made only on final<tei:lb/>instar larvae found with host remains (Baumann, 1927, 1933; Finlayson, 1970).<tei:lb/>Several features suggest acaenitines may be endoparasitic.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1. The ovipositor tip is rather unspecialized and shows little difference between closely related<tei:lb/>species. Those of many ectoparasites differ strikingly.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2. The ovaries usually contain relatively large numbers of rather small mature oocytes. Iwata<tei:lb/>(1960) gave an average value of 46 for Japanese Acaenitini and stated 'in comparison with its<tei:lb/>body size the mature egg of this group is generally small in size . . .'. Endoparasites generally<tei:lb/>have larger numbers of smaller eggs than similar-sized ectoparasites.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3. The mandibles of the final instar larvae are rather small and simple. Those of many<tei:lb/>ectoparasites are large and often denticulate. The general form of the cephalic capsule of the<tei:lb/>final instar larva is quite different from that of most ectoparasites (Short, 1978).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This evidence is of course circumstantial and the controversy will not be settled until firm<tei:lb/>biological observations are made.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>YEZOCER YX Uchida<tei:lb/>Yezoceryx Uchida, 1928: 25. Type-species: Yezoceryx scutellaris Uchida, by original designation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Small to moderately large insects, fore wing length 6-15 mm; occipital carina complete across midline.<tei:lb/>Propodeum with some carinae but generally with area superomedia and area petiolaris confluent. Tarsal<tei:lb/>claws with a small to large accessory tooth near apical tooth. Fore wing lacking 3r-m. First sternite with a<tei:lb/>weak to strong ventral swelling, the swelling without conspicuous hairs. Female subgenital plate large, in<tei:lb/>profile triangular and extended posteriorly; ovipositor apex without a notch.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Yezoceryx is a large genus with numerous species in the Indo-Australian region,<tei:lb/>several in the eastern Palaearctic and one in North America. Gauld (1984) suggested seven<tei:lb/>species occur in Australia but re-examination of initial sorting and some progress in associating<tei:lb/>sexes has reduced the number to five or possibly six, the putative sixth being only known from<tei:lb/>males.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Three of the species, Y. amaryllyx, Y. coelyx and species A, are closely related and form an<tei:lb/>endemic Australian species-complex. Y. apicipennis belongs to a monobasic species-group<tei:lb/>whilst the remaining two species, Y. tantalyx and Y. dinyx, appear to be closely related to some<tei:lb/>undescribed Indo-Papuan species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to Australian species of Yezoceryx</tei:p>

         <tei:p>distal apex, or teeth not discernible; clypeus without a transverse ridge, or if ridge present it is<tei:lb/>absent above median tooth or the median tooth projects from a ridge; tergites 1-7 usually<tei:lb/>unicolorous , if yellow and black banding is present then it is not on tergite 1 3</tei:p>

         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>324 I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- Ovipositor projecting beyond apex of gaster by approximately 2-0 times length of hind tibia, the<tei:lb/>apex simple; gaster almost entirely ochre-yellow; mesopleuron moderately closely punctate;<tei:lb/>sternite 1 with a strong pointed protuberance (Fig. 100) 5</tei:p>
         <tei:p>5 Metapleuron finely and closely punctate, the punctures tending to be oval and form lines, thus</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Face laterally with punctures discrete, without any trace of striae; mesoscutum with a small<tei:lb/>central black spot amaryllyx sp. n.(p. 324)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Yezoceryx amaryllyx sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 105)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fore wing length 11-15 mm. Orbits moderately strongly, divergent ventrally; face with coarse close<tei:lb/>punctures, without striae ventrolaterally; clypeus quite blunt, without a transverse ridge above the median<tei:lb/>apical tooth; labrum slightly bilobate; mandibles quite stout, striate, the lower tooth about 1-3 times as long<tei:lb/>as the upper; malar space 0-70-0-85 times as long as basal mandibular width, genal sulcus moderately<tei:lb/>strongly impressed. Distal end of flagellum almost parallel-sided, apically rounded. Epicnemium and<tei:lb/>lower part of mesopleuron with close fine punctures that tend to be arranged in rows suggesting striae;<tei:lb/>metapleuron similar but with striae pronounced; submetapleural carina narrow, strongly expanded<tei:lb/>anteriorly (Fig. 105). Propodeum with anterior and posterior transverse carinae developed as lateral<tei:lb/>crests, the area between them concentrically striate. Hind trochantellus unspecialized. Fore wing with<tei:lb/>2r-m generally more than 2-0 times length of M between 2r-m and 2m-cu, often with a slight angulation<tei:lb/>near top; hind wing with distal abscissa of Cu\ slightly curved. Sternite 1 in midline reaching about 0-6 of<tei:lb/>way to spiracles, with a strong, flattened very acutely pointed protuberance. Ovipositor projecting beyond<tei:lb/>apex of gaster by 2-0-2-1 times length of hind tibia, its apex with fine inconspicuous teeth.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female and male yellow-ochre, flagellum black with first two segments orange-marked, mesoscutum<tei:lb/>with a small black mark centrally; proximal end of hind femur, distal apex of hind tibia and hind tarsus<tei:lb/>blackish; ovipositor sheath blackish, proximally and distally paler. Wings slightly infumate, fore wing with<tei:lb/>distal apex strongly infumate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species is very similar to Y. coelyx both in colour and structure. They are the only<tei:lb/>two Australian acaenitines that are predominantly yellow. Y. amaryllyx can be separated from<tei:lb/>coelyx not only by the differences given in the key but also in being slightly larger and 'more<tei:lb/>robust'.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Y. amaryllyx is only known from Queensland.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Yezoceryx apicipennis (Turner)<tei:lb/>(Figs 101, 102)</tei:p>

         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>ICHNEUMONIDAE OF AUSTRALIA 325</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fore wing length 6-5-9-5 mm. Orbits barely divergent ventrally; face with coarse sparse punctures, with a<tei:lb/>slight trace of striation centrally; clypeus with traces of ridge only at lateral extremities, the area above the<tei:lb/>tooth flat; labrum slightly bilobed apically; mandibles stout, striate, with lower tooth about 1-5 times length<tei:lb/>of the upper; malar space 0-75 times as long as basal mandibular width; genal sulcus strongly impressed.<tei:lb/>Distal apex of flagellum slightly clavate. Sternite 1 very short, in the mid-line reaching only 0-4 of way<tei:lb/>to level of spiracle, with a rather weak, fairly blunt protuberance (Fig. 101). Ovipositor projecting beyond<tei:lb/>apex of gaster by 0-9-1-0 times length of hind tibia, its apex bearing about 7 weak teeth on lower valve and<tei:lb/>about 5 on the upper (Fig. 102).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female head and alitrunk orange-brown, interocellar area partially, mesoscutum centrally, scutoscutel-<tei:lb/>lar groove , hind end of scutellum , anterior part of propodeum and posterior part of metapleuron blackish ;<tei:lb/>gaster black, tergites 1 and 2 with white spots near hind margin, tergites 3+ with a pair of such spots,<tei:lb/>tergites 5 and 6 additionally with whitish membranous area present; sternites black, margined with white,<tei:lb/>the anterior ones almost entirely pale; ovipositor sheath black, extreme distal end slightly paler. Legs<tei:lb/>orange, hind tarsus infuscate. Wings hyaline, the fore wing with an infumate patch only at distal apex. Male<tei:lb/>similar to female but with protuberance on sternite 1 more pronounced. Dorsal surface of head and<tei:lb/>alitrunk more extensively dark-marked, propodeum black; pronotum and mesopleuron brownish-<tei:lb/>marked.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This distinctive species is easily recognizable by its short ovipositor and characteristic<tei:lb/>colour pattern. The wings differ from those of other Australian acaenitines in having shorter,<tei:lb/>stouter and more sparsely distributed microtrichia, and the ovipositor is unusual in having teeth<tei:lb/>on the upper valve.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The male herein associated with the female differs strikingly in the colour pattern of the head<tei:lb/>and alitrunk though that of the gaster is similar. The association of sexes is based on locality,<tei:lb/>colour pattern of gaster, similarity in punctation of meso- and metapleurae and resemblance in<tei:lb/>venation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>y. apicipennis is only known from the south-west of Australia; it is the only acaenitine known<tei:lb/>to occur outside Queensland.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Yezoceryx coelyx sp. n.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Yezoceryx dinyx sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fore wing length 6 mm. Orbits strongly divergent ventrally; face with coarse shallow punctures, without<tei:lb/>striae; clypeus with transverse ridge present laterally, centrally absent so part above median tooth is flat;<tei:lb/>labrum concealed; mandibles weakly tapered, slightly striate, with lower tooth about 1-5 times as long as<tei:lb/>the upper ; malar space 1 times as long as basal mandibular width , genal sulcus quite strong .          <tei:p>Female head blackish, face and postorbital marks yellowish; malar space brownish; antenna blackish<tei:lb/>brown, scape ventrally yellowish, distal 9 or so flagellar segments bright yellow; alitrunk and gaster<tei:lb/>blackish brown, hind corners of meso- and metapleurae brownish, scutellum and posterior end of<tei:lb/>propodeum orange-brown; posterior margins of gastral segments narrowly yellow. Wings hyaline, the fore wing with distal apex and region adjacent to stigma infumate. Male<tei:lb/>unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Y. dinyx is a very distinctive little species on account of the long ovipositor, the<tei:lb/>white-banded ovipositor sheath and the rather extensive area of coarse punctures, especially on<tei:lb/>the lateral parts of the alitrunk. The first segment of the gaster is more slender than that of other<tei:lb/>Australian acaenitines and the sternite correspondingly more elongate; the subgenital plate is<tei:lb/>somewhat shorter than that of other Yezoceryx species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED<tei:lb/>Holotype $, Australia: Queensland; Mt Spec, 800 m, iii.1964 (Common &amp; Upton) (ANIC).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Yezoceryx tantalyxsp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 103, 104)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fore wing length 7-12 mm. Orbits strongly divergent ventrally; face coarsely punctate, ventrolaterally<tei:lb/>arranged in rows giving the effect of striae; clypeus with a strong transverse ridge above the median tooth;<tei:lb/>labrum almost evenly rounded apically; mandibles moderately strongly tapered, striate, with lower tooth<tei:lb/>about 1-3 times length of the upper; malar space 0-9-1-0 times as long as basal mandibular width, with a<tei:lb/>strong genal sulcus.          <tei:p>ICHNEUMONIDAE OF AUSTRALIA 327</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female head yellow, dorsally black; antenna black, scape ventrally yellow, distal apex of flagellum<tei:lb/>pallid.          <tei:p>VARIATION. Two specimens are large (fore wing length ca 12 mm) whilst three from the Townes<tei:lb/>collection are notably smaller (fore wing length ca 1 mm). The smaller specimens are slightly<tei:lb/>more extensively yellow-marked, especially on the mesoscutum and mesopleuron. However, in<tei:lb/>structure they closely resemble the larger specimens.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Y. tantalyx is probably the most distinctive Australian Yezoceryx on account of the<tei:lb/>modified hind trochantellus, but it also has a number of other unusual features including the<tei:lb/>positioning of the ovipositor teeth, the sinuous I A in the hind wing and the clypeal ridge.<tei:lb/>This species is only known from Mt Tambourine, Queensland.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Yezoceryx species A</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fore wing length 10-13 mm. Orbits rather weakly divergent ventrally; face coarsely punctate, tending<tei:lb/>towards being striate latero ventrally; clypeus with margin blunt, without a ridge above median apical<tei:lb/>tooth; labrum weakly bilobed; mandibles moderately stout, with lower tooth about 1-3 times length of the<tei:lb/>upper; malar space 0-7 times as long as basal mandibular width, the genal sulcus weak. Distal end of<tei:lb/>flagellum not clavate. Epicnemium and lower part of mesopleuron closely punctate, metapleuron more<tei:lb/>sparsely so; submetapleural carina moderately wide, broadened anteriorly and with a small thickening<tei:lb/>centrally.          <tei:p>Female yellow, with most of flagellum, scape dorsally, vertex of head, three mesoscutal stripes,<tei:lb/>scuto-scutellar groove, anterior edges of tergites 2-7 (either as spots or bars) black. Legs yellow, hind<tei:lb/>femur proximally black, hind tarsus black, hind tibia infuscate. Male unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This group of specimens is structurally rather similar to Y. coelyx, although it is both<tei:lb/>larger and has a slightly different colour pattern. It may be merely an extreme 'form' of coelyx<tei:lb/>but for the present it was thought better to treat it as being tentatively distinct until females can<tei:lb/>be collected. Males of most species of Yezoceryx are structurally very similar and difficult to<tei:lb/>separate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED<tei:lb/>Australia: 3 d", Queensland, Stanthorpe, 700 m, i. (TC).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Subfamily LYCORININAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This small subfamily is taxonomically rather isolated. Townes (1970) placed it close to the<tei:lb/>Banchinae, but the characters supporting this association are plesiomorphic features such as the<tei:lb/>possession of an unspecialized petiole with spiracles placed antecentrally. The egg is most<tei:lb/>curious, being leech-like and sinuous (Iwata, 1958), quite unlike that of any other ichneumonid.<tei:lb/>The structure of the cephalic capsule of the final instar larva (Finlayson, 1976; Short, 1978) is<tei:lb/>unlike that of the Banchinae as the mandibular teeth are denticulate, like those of many species<tei:lb/>of Tryphoninae and Phygadeuontinae. Unlike these ectoparasitoids the Lycorininae lack a<tei:lb/>distinct labral sclerite.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>328 I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Some species have been reared from various Microlepidoptera, most usually pyralids in<tei:lb/>leaf-rolls (Finlayson, 1976), but no details of the biology of the group are known, not even<tei:lb/>whether the larva is endo- or ectoparasitic. Were such observations to be made they would be<tei:lb/>invaluable jn helping to place this enigmatic subfamily.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Townes (1970) recognized three closely related genera, but Gauld (1984) treated all species as<tei:lb/>belonging to a single genus, Lycorina.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>LYCORINA Holmgren</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lycorina Holmgren, 1859: 126. Type-species: Lycorina triangulifera Holmgren, by monotypy.<tei:lb/>Toxophoroides Cresson, 1873: 406. Type-species: Lycorinal apicalis Cresson, by original designation.<tei:lb/>Chlorolycorina Cushman, 1920: 9. Type-species: Glypta scitula Cresson, by original designation.<tei:lb/>Gonioglyphus Seyrig, 1932: 22. Type-species: Lycorina (Gonioglyphus) fid Seyrig, by monotypy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Small to medium-sized insects, fore wing length 3-7 mm; clypeus separated from face by groove, with<tei:lb/>margin slightly concave medially; mandible bidentate; malar space with an impressed groove running from<tei:lb/>eye to mandible; frons simple. Occipital carina complete or narrowly interrupted mediodorsally; genal<tei:lb/>carina joining hypostomal carina above base of mandible. Flagellum cylindrical, unspecialized. Notauli<tei:lb/>vestigial; sternaulus absent; posterior transverse carina of mesosternum absent. Propodeum with dorso-<tei:lb/>lateral corner projecting anteriorly and engaging a small hook on the metanotum; propodeum with or<tei:lb/>without carinae. Fore tibia without a tooth on apical margin; tarsal claws strongly pectinate. Fore wing with<tei:lb/>3r-m absent; 2r-m longer than abscissa of M between 2r-m and 2m-cu\ 2m-cu with one bulla; pterostigma<tei:lb/>broadly triangular; marginal cell moderately long. Hind wing with first abscissa of Rs longer than r-m;<tei:lb/>distal abscissa of Cu\ present or absent. Gaster with tergite 1 broad, dorsally convex with spiracles before<tei:lb/>the centre, sternite not reaching to spiracles; tergites 2-4 with strongly impressed, striate grooves defining<tei:lb/>triangular central areas. Female with subgenital plate large, triangular, centrally membranous; ovipositor<tei:lb/>projecting beyond apex of gaster by 1-15-1 -70 times length of hind tibia, its apex with a strong nodus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lycorina is one of the more distinctive ichneumonid taxa on account of the grooves on tergites<tei:lb/>2-4 and their unique propodeal/metathoracic 'catch'. It is a moderate-sized genus with species<tei:lb/>occurring in almost all zoogeographical regions. Three or perhaps four species occur in<tei:lb/>Australia. These represent two species-groups, the turneri-group with a carinate propodeum<tei:lb/>and long tarsal pectinae, and the canberrae-group with a smooth propodeum and short tarsal<tei:lb/>pectinae. The latter group resemble the Neotropical species (formerly considered a separate<tei:lb/>genus, Toxophoroides) in the lack of propodeal carinae, but it is not possible to decide whether<tei:lb/>this results from evolutionary convergence or is indicative of phylogenetic affinity. The<tei:lb/>turneri-group is tropical, and resembles some Indo-Papuan species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Key to species of Lycorina occurring in Australia</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 Propodeum with distinct carinae, at least with posterior transverse one more or less complete</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 107, 108); hind tarsal claw with long pectinae (Fig. 109); 9 with anterior coxae pale 2</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Propodeum without discernible carinae, rarely with a trace of lateromedian ones anteriorly;<tei:lb/>hind tarsal claw with short sparse pectinae (Fig. 110);$ with all coxae black 3</tei:p>
         <tei:p>2 Scutellum slightly longer than broad anteriorly, centrally sparsely punctate (Fig. 108) ; mesoscu-</tei:p>
         <tei:p>tum black with two yellow longitudinal stripes; upper end of epomia raised into strong crest;</tei:p>
         <tei:p>wings hyaline splendidula sp. n. (p. 329)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- Scutellum transverse, slightly broader anteriorly than long, centrally smooth, impunctate<tei:lb/>(Fig. 107); mesoscutum unicolorous orange-brown; upper end of epomia not raised into a<tei:lb/>strong crest; wings infumate turner! sp. n. (p- 330)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 Alitrunk entirely blue-black ; head orange , interocellar area black species 1 (p . 330)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Alitrunk predominantly reddish brown ; head dorsally extensively blackish canberrae sp . n . (p . 328)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lycorina canberrae sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 110)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fore wing length 5-7 mm. Face moderately strongly convex with a weak median tubercle just below<tei:lb/>antennal insertion, genal carina joining hypostomal carina well away from base of mandible; occipital<tei:lb/>carina mediodorsally obsolescent. Pronotum with upper end of epomia raised into a small crest;<tei:lb/>mesoscutum moderately long, in dorsal view 1-2-1-3 times as long as broad, without discernible notauli,</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>ICHNEUMONIDAE OF AUSTRALIA 329</tei:p>
         <tei:p>smooth and shining, virtually impunctate except for minute setiferous punctures anteriorly and anter-<tei:lb/>olaterally; scutellum distinctly broader anteriorly than long, with isolated minute punctures, lateral carinae<tei:lb/>well developed, reaching about 0-7 of length of scutellum; mesopleuron smooth and polished with isolated<tei:lb/>fine punctures, posteromedially moderately impressed below speculum; metapleuron polished, with fine<tei:lb/>sparse punctures, juxtacoxal carina usually complete. Propodeum convex, without carinae, or at very most<tei:lb/>with only vestiges of lateromedian longitudinal carinae present anteriorly. Hind tarsal claws with short,<tei:lb/>sparse pectinae (Fig. 110). Gaster with triangular areas defined on tergites 2-4, those on 1 and 5 not<tei:lb/>complete, the grooves defining these areas all strongly trans-striate; laterotergites 2 and 3 broad, folded<tei:lb/>under, with strongly pigmented sclerotized central areas; ovipositor projecting beyond apex of gaster by<tei:lb/>1-60-1-65 times length of hind tibia; posterior margin of tergite 8 mediodorsally produced to form a blunt<tei:lb/>process that projects almost as far as cercus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female with head blackish, face, mouthparts and marks above eyes yellow, flagellum distally brown;<tei:lb/>alitrunk orange-brown, margin of pronotum, propleuron and ventral part of metapleuron blackish; gaster<tei:lb/>black with posterior and often lateral margins of tergites whitish, tergite 1 usually extensively white with<tei:lb/>central black spot. Legs black, fore and mid femora and tibiae striped longitudinally with pale yellow, tarsi<tei:lb/>more brownish; ovipositor sheath black, distally pale. Wings infumate, pterostigma brown. Male similar to<tei:lb/>female but with propodeum extensively black, genae ventrally and fore and mid coxae and trochanters<tei:lb/>white-marked.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species is easily distinguished from L. turneri and L. spendidula by the lack of<tei:lb/>propodeal carinae and indistinct pectinae on the tarsal claws. It is morphologically more or less<tei:lb/>identical to 'species 1'.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This is the most widely distributed Australian species, occurring in Australian Capital<tei:lb/>Territory, New South Wales, Queensland, Victoria and Western Australia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOST RECORDS. None.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Lycorina splendidula sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Fig. 108)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fore wing length 3-5 mm. Face moderately convex, without a distinct median tubercle; genal carina<tei:lb/>meeting hypostomal carina just before base of mandible; occipital carina complete. Pronotum with upper<tei:lb/>end of epomia raised into a strong tooth; mesoscutum rather long, in dorsal view 1-3-1-4 times as long as<tei:lb/>broad, with weak notaular indentations and some punctures, in larger specimens the punctures running<tei:lb/>together to form transverse striae; scutellum slightly longer than broad anteriorly, punctate, with strong<tei:lb/>lateral carinae; mesopleuron with isolated punctures, posteromedially strongly impressed below specu-<tei:lb/>lum; metapleuron almost impunctate with juxtacoxal carina almost complete. Propodeum with small but<tei:lb/>distinctly defined area superomedia; posterior transverse carina complete (Fig. 108). Hind tarsal claws<tei:lb/>with long, strong pectinae. Gaster with triangular area defined on tergites 1-5, the grooves transversely<tei:lb/>striate; laterotergites 2 and 3 narrow, folded under, weakly sclerotized and inconspicuous; ovipositor<tei:lb/>projecting beyond apex of gaster by 1-15-1-25 times length of hind tibia; posterior margin of tergite 8<tei:lb/>dorsally truncate forming a more or less straight line between cerci.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female yellow; dorsal surface of antenna, frons centrally, vertex, occiput, mesocutum in three<tei:lb/>longitudinal vittae, ventral part of mesopleuron and extreme anterior corner of propodeum, black;<tei:lb/>pronotum centrally, tergites 6+ of gaster, subgenital plate, ovipositor sheath except distal apex, brownish.<tei:lb/>Wings hyaline; pterostigma brown. Male unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This distinctive species is easily recognized by its extensively yellow colour pattern. It<tei:lb/>is more slender than other Australian lycorinines and has a more strongly sculptured alitrunk<tei:lb/>and a more rigid gaster with slightly coarse sculpture. It appears to be closely related to L. turneri<tei:lb/>which it resembles in the structure of the claws and carination of the propodeum. L. splendidula<tei:lb/>has a smaller, more completely denned area superomedia than L. turneri and differs also in<tei:lb/>having the genal carina joining the hypostomal carina slightly away from the base of the<tei:lb/>mandible.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>330 I. D. GAULD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This species occurs in tropical Queensland.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype $, Australia: Queensland, Cooktown, Mt Cook N.P. (1529'S; 14516'E), x.1980 (Cardale)<tei:lb/>(ANIC).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratype. Australia: 1 $, Queensland, Mackay, 1909 (Turner) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lycorina turner! sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 107, 109)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Fore wing length 4-6 mm. Face moderately convex, without a distinct median tubercle; genal carina<tei:lb/>meeting hypostomal carina at base of mandible; occipital carina complete. Pronotum with upper end of<tei:lb/>epomia slightly raised to form a weak flange; mesoscutum moderately long, in dorsal view 1-1-1-2 times as<tei:lb/>long as broad, without discernible notauli, smooth and shining, impunctate; scutellum distinctly broader<tei:lb/>anteriorly than long, with isolated minute punctures, lateral carinae moderately well developed, reaching<tei:lb/>to near centre; mesopleuron smooth and polished with isolated fine inconspicuous punctures, post-<tei:lb/>eromedially only slightly impressed below speculum; metapleuron smooth with isolated fine punctures,<tei:lb/>with juxtacoxal carina almost complete. Propodeum with a weakly indicated transverse area superomedia;<tei:lb/>posterior transverse carina usually complete but other carina may be absent, weakly indicated or in larger<tei:lb/>specimens distinct (Fig. 107). Hind tarsal claws with long strong pectinae (Fig. 109). Gaster with triangular<tei:lb/>area defined on tergites 2-4, that of tergites 1 and 5 indistinct, the grooves defining these areas not clearly<tei:lb/>trans-striate; laterotergites 2 and 3 moderately wide, folded under, weakly sclerotized, inconspicuous;<tei:lb/>ovipositor projecting beyond apex of gaster by 1-55-1-70 times length of hind tibia; posterior margin of<tei:lb/>tergite 8 dorsally truncate, forming a more or less straight line between cerci.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female orange-brown; head black with mouthparts, face except orbits and marks on vertex pale yellow.<tei:lb/>Gaster with tergites 1 and 2 laterally yellow, 1-5 centrally black, 3+ black also laterally and often also<tei:lb/>posteriorly except for extreme posterolateral margin which is yellow-marked; ovipositor sheath dark<tei:lb/>brown, its distal apex paler. Hind leg blackish, coxa dorsally brownish orange. Wings strongly infumate,<tei:lb/>pterostigma dark brown. Male similar to female but with fore and mid coxae pallid, almost white.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The propodeal carination of this species is rather variable but at least the posterior<tei:lb/>transverse one is distinct, enabling it to be separated from L. canberme. It differs from L.<tei:lb/>splendidula most obviously in colour pattern but the two species also differ in many subtle<tei:lb/>morphological details as can be seen by contrasting the descriptions.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This species is named in honour of the late R. E. Turner who collected a short series in<tei:lb/>Kurandain 1913.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>It occurs in tropical Queensland.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype $, Australia: Queensland, Gap Ck., 5 km ESE. Mt Finnigan (1550'S; 14520E), v.1981<tei:lb/>(Naumann) (ANIC).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Paratypes. Australia: 1 cf , Queensland, same data as holotype (ANIC); 1 9, Mossman, i. (TC); 2 $,<tei:lb/>1 cf , Kuranda, 350 m, v-vi.1913 (Turner) (BMNH).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Lycorina species 1</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Morphologically this is virtually identical to L. canberme though the pleural punctures in the<tei:lb/>Tasmanian specimens are sparser. It differs strikingly in colour pattern.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Female head orange, interocellar area and proximal part of antenna black, flagellum distally brownish;<tei:lb/>alitrunk, legs and gaster black, fore and mid femora and tibiae white-striped, segments of gaster broadly<tei:lb/>infumate, pterostigma dark brown. Male similar to female but with fore and mid coxae and hind tibia<tei:lb/>white-marked.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The characteristic colour pattern occurs in a variety of small temperate Australian<tei:lb/>Hymenoptera. However, as this group of specimens are so similar to L. canberrae I am sceptical<tei:lb/>that they warrant specific recognition. They do not have a clearly separate range and I have not<tei:lb/>formally described them pending further study.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Australia: 1 , New South Wales, Araluen Hill, 100 m, x.1981 (Gauld) (BMNH); 1 $, 1 O", Tasmania,<tei:lb/>Coles Bay, ii-iii.1981 (TC).</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>ICHNEUMONIDAE OF AUSTRALIA 331</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acknowledgements</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I thank the Australian Government who, through the agency of ABRS, provided me with a<tei:lb/>grant to study in Australia. I am particularly grateful to the following Australian entomologists<tei:lb/>for their help and encouragement in a variety of ways: Dr Ian Naumann and Miss Jo Cardale in<tei:lb/>Canberra; Dr Ian Galloway, Dr Ted Dahms, Dr Geoff Monteith and Ms Margaret Schneider in<tei:lb/>Brisbane; Mr Geoff Holloway in Sydney; Mr Dennis Farrugia, Dr Artur Neboiss and Dr Ken<tei:lb/>Walker in Melbourne; Ms Margaret Williams in Hobart and Dr Terry Houston in Perth. The<tei:lb/>whole insect figures were drawn by Jonathan Carter and Andrew Atkins. Dr Ian Common and<tei:lb/>Mr Ted Edwards gave invaluable help concerning Australian Lepidoptera. I am especially<tei:lb/>grateful to Dr Henry Townes for his comments at various stages in the work and to my colleagues<tei:lb/>at the BMNH, particularly Dr Mike Fitton, Mr Mick Day, Dr Andy Austin and Dr Gaden<tei:lb/>Robinson for their helpful discussion of numerous points. Finally I would like to thank Darren<tei:lb/>Gauld for drawing the maps and Ms Pam Mitchell for collating data, typing the manuscript and<tei:lb/>checking references.</tei:p>

      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>British Museum (Natural History)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Milkweed butterflies: their cladistics and biology</tei:p>
         <tei:p>P. R. Ackery &amp; R. I. Vane- Wright</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Danainae, a subfamily of the Nymphalidae, contains only some 150 species, yet aspects of<tei:lb/>their biology have stimulated far more attention than can be justified by species numbers<tei:lb/>alone. In recent years, an expansive literature has grown, considering aspects of their<tei:lb/>courtship and pre-courtship behaviour, migration, larval hostplant associations, mimicry and<tei:lb/>genetics. The popularity of danaines among biologists can certainly be attributed to this<tei:lb/>combination, within one small group, of so many of the factors that make butterflies such an<tei:lb/>interesting group to study. The obvious need to place this wealth of biological data within an<tei:lb/>acceptable systematic framework provided the impetus for this volume.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Started eight years ago within the conventions of evolution by natural selection and<tei:lb/>Hennig's phylogenetic systematics, the book is now largely about natural history (what the<tei:lb/>animals have and do, where they live and how they develop) and natural groups - as revealed<tei:lb/>by a form of analysis approaching that practised by the new school of 'transformed cladistics'.<tei:lb/>The authors have prepared a handbook that will appeal to a wide range of biologists, from<tei:lb/>museum taxonomists to field ecologists.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>424 pp (approx.), 12 pp colour, 73 b/w plates, line and graphic illustrations, maps, extensive bibliography.<tei:lb/>ISBN 565 00893 5. Publication September 1984. Price 50, prepublication price 45.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>Titles to be published in Volume 49</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Afrotropical jumping plant lice of the family Triozidae (Homoptera: Psylloidea).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>By David Hollis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The taxonomy of the western European grasshopper of the genus Euchorthippus, with special<tei:lb/>reference to their songs (Orthopetera: Acrididae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>By D. Ragge &amp; W. J. Reynolds</tei:p>
         <tei:p>An historical review of the higher classification of the Noctuidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>By Ian Kitching</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Pimplinae, Xoridinae, Acaenitinae and Lycorininae (Hymenoptera: Ichneumonidae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>By I. D. Gauld</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Palaearctic species of Ascogaster (Hymenoptera: Braconidae)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>By T. Huddleston</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Bulletin of the</tei:p>
         <tei:p>British Museum (Natural History)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>UM</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Palaearctic species of Ascogaster<tei:lb/>(Hymenoptera: Braconidae)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>T. Huddleston</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Entomology series</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Vol 49 No 5 20 December 1984</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>The Bulletin of the British Museum (Natural History), instituted in 1949, is issued in four<tei:lb/>scientific series, Botany, Entomology, Geology (incorporating Mineralogy) and Zoology,<tei:lb/>and an Historical series.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Papers in the Bulletin are primarily the results of research carried out on the unique and<tei:lb/>ever-growing collections of the Museum, both by the scientific staff of the Museum and by<tei:lb/>specialists from elsewhere who make use of the Museum's resources. Many of the papers are<tei:lb/>works of reference that will remain indispensable for years to come.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Parts are published at irregular intervals as they become ready, each is complete in itself,<tei:lb/>available separately, and individually priced. Volumes contain about 300 pages and several<tei:lb/>volumes may appear within a calendar year. Subscriptions may be placed for one or more of<tei:lb/>the series on either an Annual or Per Volume basis. Prices vary according to the contents of<tei:lb/>the individual parts. Orders and enquiries should be sent to:</tei:p>

         <tei:p>London SW75BD,</tei:p>

         <tei:p>British Museum (Natural History)<tei:lb/>Cromwell Road<tei:lb/>London SW7 5BD</tei:p>

      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>The Palaearctic species of Ascogaster<tei:lb/>(Hymenoptera: Braconidae)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>T. Huddleston</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Department of Entomology, British Museum (Natural History), Cromwell Road, London<tei:lb/>SW75BD</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Contents</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Synopsis 341</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Introduction 341</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Biology 342</tei:p>
         <tei:p>List of host records 342</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Taxonomic history 343</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Synonymic list of species 344</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Taxonomic characters 345</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Depositories 346</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Characteristics of subfamily Cheloninae 347</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster Wesmael 348</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The species-groups 348</tei:p>
