         <tei:p>The semenovi-group 352</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The caucasica-group 353</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The abdominator-group 357</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The annularis-group 360</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The bidentula-group 364</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The quadridentata-group 371</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Species inquirendae 380</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Excluded species 381</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acknowledgements 381</tei:p>
         <tei:p>References 382</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Index... 392</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Synopsis</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The cosmopolitan genus Ascogaster, which is parasitic on Microlepidoptera, is revised for the Palaearctic<tei:lb/>zoogeographical region. A key to species is given. Thirty species are recognized; four of them are described<tei:lb/>as new. Twenty- two synonyms are newly established; one species (nigrator) is transferred to Ascogaster<tei:lb/>from Chelonus and one (maculata) from Ascogaster to Phanerotoma.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Introduction</tei:p>
         <tei:p>It is imperative that biological studies are founded on a basis of sound taxonomy; the results of<tei:lb/>such studies are otherwise vitiated. The taxonomy of the Braconidae has been composed<tei:lb/>piecemeal over the last 200 years or so and relatively few taxa have received comprehensive<tei:lb/>up-to-date attention. Many taxa therefore need to be completely revised, at least within a single<tei:lb/>zoogeographical region. This revision is concerned with the Palaearctic species of Ascogaster, a<tei:lb/>chelonine braconid genus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster is a cosmopolitan genus parasitic upon Microlepidoptera, principally Tortricidae.<tei:lb/>A. quadridentata has frequently been recorded as a parasite of the codling moth (Cydia<tei:lb/>pomonella) and other pests of fruit trees (see Evenhuis &amp; Vlug, 1983). This species and probably<tei:lb/>several others merit consideration for use in biological control programmes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Bull. Br. Mus. nat. Hist. (Ent.) 49 (5): 341-392 Issued 20 December 1984</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>342</tei:p>
         <tei:p>T. HUDDLESTON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Biology</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Very little work has been done on the biology of Ascogaster and, as far as is known, the species<tei:lb/>are solitary endoparasites of Microlepidoptera, principally Tortricidae. They lay their eggs into<tei:lb/>the egg of the host and, as van Achterberg (1976: 47) has pointed out, this is clearly an<tei:lb/>adaptation to the use of hosts whose larvae live in concealment, thereby deriving some<tei:lb/>protection against the attacks of parasites and predators. In his studies of Ascogaster quad-<tei:lb/>ridentata, Rosenberg (1934) found that the development of the parasite is slow and its larva is in<tei:lb/>its first instar when the host larva has completed its development. If the host larva then goes into<tei:lb/>hibernation the parasite remains within as a first-stage larva, otherwise it passes rapidly through<tei:lb/>two further instars and emerges from the host to pupate. Rosenberg's work and that of Cox<tei:lb/>(1932), Boyce (1936) and Allen (1962) are fairly full accounts of the biology of A. quadridentata<tei:lb/>and they also give much information on the larval morphology of the parasite. The larval<tei:lb/>characteristics of chelonines are discussed in more general terms by Short (1952) and Capek<tei:lb/>(1970). Host-searching and egg-laying behaviour has recently been studied in reticulata parasitic<tei:lb/>on the smaller tea tortrix (Adoxophyes sp.), an important pest of tea in Japan (Kainoh &amp;<tei:lb/>Tamaki, 1982; Kainoh, Hiyori &amp; Tamaki, 1982).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>There are many host records in the literature on Ascogaster, collated by Shenefelt (1973).<tei:lb/>Much of this information, however, is of little value because of doubt about the accuracy of<tei:lb/>identification of the parasite species involved; undoubtedly host species are also sometimes<tei:lb/>misidentified. Host data cited here are therefore only from the specimens examined for this<tei:lb/>revision except for the hosts from which the type-specimens of reticulata were reared (as given by<tei:lb/>Watanabe, 1967: 43). These records are listed below.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>List of host records</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOSTS</tei:p>
         <tei:p>LEPIDOPTERA</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TINEIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Infurcitinea argentimaculella (Stainton)<tei:lb/>YPONOMEUTIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Yponomeuta padella (L.)<tei:lb/>COLEOPHORIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Coleophora hornigi Toll<tei:lb/>OECOPHORIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Tubuliferola subochreella (Doubleday)<tei:lb/>GELECHIIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Recurvaria leucatella (Clerck)<tei:lb/>MOMPHIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Sorhagenia lophyrella (Douglas)<tei:lb/>TORTRICIDAE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cydia pomonella (L.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cydia funebrana (Treitschke)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cydia pallifrontana (Lienig &amp; Zeller)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Spilonota ocellana (Denis &amp; Schiffermiiller)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Epiblema uddmanniana (L.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Epiblema roborana (Denis &amp; Schiffermiiller)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Epinotia cruciana (L.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Endothenia gentianaeana (Hiibner)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Endothenia quadrimaculana (Haworth)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pandemis corylana (Fabricius)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pandemis cerasana (Hiibner)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pandemis heparana (Denis &amp; Schiffermiiller)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Pandemis sp.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Archips oporana (L.)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Archips issikii Kodama</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Adoxophyes orana (Fischer von Roslerstamm)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>SPECIES CF Ascogaster</tei:p>
         <tei:p>grahami</tei:p>
         <tei:p>rufidens, quadridentata</tei:p>
         <tei:p>armata</tei:p>
         <tei:p>klugii</tei:p>
         <tei:p>annularis</tei:p>
         <tei:p>grahami</tei:p>
         <tei:p>quadridentata</tei:p>
         <tei:p>quadridentata</tei:p>
         <tei:p>quadridentata</tei:p>
         <tei:p>quadridentata</tei:p>
         <tei:p>quadridentata</tei:p>
         <tei:p>bidentula</tei:p>
         <tei:p>bidentula</tei:p>
         <tei:p>dispar</tei:p>
         <tei:p>canifrons</tei:p>
         <tei:p>rufidens</tei:p>
         <tei:p>rufidens</tei:p>
         <tei:p>rufidens, annularis</tei:p>
         <tei:p>bidentula</tei:p>
         <tei:p>reticulata</tei:p>
         <tei:p>reticulata</tei:p>
         <tei:p>reticulata</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE PALAEARCTIC SPECIES OF ASCOGASTER 343</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Archips pulchra (Butler) reticulata</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Croesia bergmanniana (L.) rufidens<tei:lb/>GEOMETRIC AE</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Eupithecia venosata (Fabricius) bidentula</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Taxonomic history</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster was erected by Wesmael (1835: 226) for 10 species which he described as new.<tei:lb/>Wesmael also correctly recognized that several of Nees von Esenbeck's species of 'Chelonus'<tei:lb/>came within the definition of the new genus but he also included Chelonus dentata [=<tei:lb/>Phanerotoma dentata]. This obviously anomalous placement was based upon the examination of<tei:lb/>only a single specimen and was corrected by Wesmael's (1838: 165) erection of the genus<tei:lb/>Phanerotoma for dentata. Wesmael possessed outstanding taxonomic skill and his discrimina-<tei:lb/>tion of species was always sound even though he worked with few specimens of each species.<tei:lb/>This was the general practice in the nineteenth century and the results are generally considered<tei:lb/>to be more or less inadequate when judged by modern standards.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Latreille (1809) was the first to describe (as Sigalphus) a species which can be unequivocally<tei:lb/>assigned to Ascogaster. The description would no doubt be adequate to differentiate the species<tei:lb/>if one had only Latreille's material of the genus available for study. Unfortunately I have been<tei:lb/>unable to locate Latreille's specimen and the description alone is insufficient for the certain<tei:lb/>identification of the species. Its interpretation must therefore rest upon inference; this question<tei:lb/>is discussed in the text upon rufipes (Latreille).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Nees von Esenbeck (1816) described (as Sigalphus) four species which were subsequently<tei:lb/>transferred by him (1834) to Chelonus and by Wesmael to Ascogaster. Three of Nees von<tei:lb/>Esenbeck's species are certainly identifiable from his descriptions but the other, similis, is not.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Curtis (1837) described four species of Ascogaster. Fortunately his collection is still available<tei:lb/>for study and his inadequate descriptions can therefore be interpreted with confidence. One of<tei:lb/>his species is here considered valid.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Herrich-Schaffer (1838) described (as Chelonus) 10 species of Ascogaster; his original<tei:lb/>material appears to be lost and his descriptions are generally difficult to interpret, but<tei:lb/>Reinhard's paper (see below) is of considerable help in this matter. Two of Herrich-Schaffer's<tei:lb/>species are here considered valid.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>In his revision of Ascogaster, Reinhard (1867) described three new species, one of which I<tei:lb/>consider to be valid. Despite Thomson's (1892: 1715) dismissal of Reinhard's revision as 'unfit<tei:lb/>for use', it includes much useful information. Reinhard's most significant contribution lies in his<tei:lb/>redescriptions and placements of species more or less inadequately described by Herrich-<tei:lb/>Schaffer and Ratzeburg. Reinhard's descriptions are much superior to those of the original<tei:lb/>authors and were often based on syntypic material which no longer exists. Without Reinhard's<tei:lb/>paper the placement of many of those species would be difficult, perhaps impossible.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thomson (1874; 1892) revised the Swedish species of Ascogaster, describing nine species as<tei:lb/>new. However, Thomson appears not to have fully understood Wesmael's species and all his<tei:lb/>names are here placed in synonymy, except for lapponicus which could not be identified.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>There have been only two previous attempts to monograph the Palaearctic species of<tei:lb/>Ascogaster. Marshall (in Andre, 1888) and Fahringer (1934) included the genus in their reviews<tei:lb/>of the Palaearctic braconid fauna. The admirably ambitious scope of these works severely<tei:lb/>limited their usefulness; neither author was able to give sufficiently rigorous attention to the<tei:lb/>large number of species involved. Their interpretation of the species was in general based on the<tei:lb/>descriptions rather than on a critical re-examination of original material. Marshall at least<tei:lb/>realised that some descriptions were inadequate and this left him unable, for instance, to include<tei:lb/>Thomson's species of Ascogaster in his key. Both Marshall and Fahringer exhibited a too facile<tei:lb/>acceptance of the significance of any character proposed as a taxonomic discriminant by original<tei:lb/>authors and made little attempt to search for worthwhile characters. Moreover, Marshall and<tei:lb/>probably Fahringer worked with small numbers of specimens and this made it impossible for<tei:lb/>them to assess intraspecific variation. Thus the contribution of these major works to the<tei:lb/>understanding of the species of Ascogaster has been insignificant.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>344</tei:p>
         <tei:p>T. HUDDLESTON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Telenga (1941) revised the Ascogaster species of the U.S.S.R.; his taxonomy was much<tei:lb/>superior to that of Marshall and Fahringer and his work is still useful. Hellen (1953) reviewed the<tei:lb/>Finnish Ascogaster fauna and established two new synonymies.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Graham (1955), in an unpublished doctoral thesis on the European species of Ascogaster (and<tei:lb/>Chelonus), was the first worker to approach the subject systematically. His arrangement of the<tei:lb/>species was based on the examination of a large amount of material, including the critical<tei:lb/>reappraisal of the available type-specimens. Graham's thesis was considerably superior to<tei:lb/>previous work on the genus and only Tobias (1976) has produced anything of comparable quality<tei:lb/>on Ascogaster (mainly of the eastern Palaearctic region). However, because Graham's work was<tei:lb/>never published, his nomenclatural decisions were never validated. I carried out my revision of<tei:lb/>the Palaearctic species of Ascogaster without first examining his manuscript so as to avoid being<tei:lb/>influenced when solving taxonomic difficulties. Many of the conclusions at which I have thus<tei:lb/>independently arrived agree with those reached by Graham. I have, however, ascribed to some<tei:lb/>species wider limits of variation than did Graham and I have therefore placed in synonymy some<tei:lb/>names which he regarded as representing valid species, albeit sometimes tentatively.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Isolated descriptions by various authors are scattered throughout the literature (Dahlbom,<tei:lb/>1833; Lucas, 1849; Ratzeburg, 1844; 1848; 1852; Ruthe, 1855; Wollaston, 1858; Marshall, 1897;<tei:lb/>Szepligeti, 1896; 1908; Ashmead, 1906). Many of these authors appear to have had but little<tei:lb/>understanding of the species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Synonymic list of species</tei:p>
         <tei:p>semenovi-group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>excavate Telenga</tei:p>

         <tei:p>kyushuensis Yoneda syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>caiicas/ca-group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>bicarinata (Herrich-Schaffer)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>mlokossewitchi Kokujev<tei:lb/>caucasi'ca Kokujev</tei:p>

         <tei:p>longiventris Tobias syn. n.<tei:lb/>kasparyani Tobias<tei:lb/>abdominator-group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>abdominator (Dahlbom)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>instabilis Wesmael</tei:p>

         <tei:p>gibbiscuta Thomson syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>fuscipennis Thomson syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>atamiensis Ashmead syn. n.<tei:lb/>consobrina Curtis<tei:lb/>longicornis sp. n.<tei:lb/>per/tins/ sp. n.<tei:lb/>rufidens Wesmael</tei:p>
         <tei:p>rufipes (Herrich-Schaffer)</tei:p>

         <tei:p>pulchellus (Curtis)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>esenbeckii Curtis syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>luteicornis (Herrich-Schaffer)<tei:lb/>brevicornis Wesmael</tei:p>

         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE PALAEARCTIC SPECIES OF ASCOGASTER 345</tei:p>
         <tei:p>reticulate Watanabe contracta (Ratzeburg)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>rutipes Latreille dentiventris Telenga</tei:p>
         <tei:p>elegans (Nees von Esenbeck) erythrothorax Marshall</tei:p>
         <tei:p>fasciatus (Dahlbom) kabystanica Tobias</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ratzeburgii Marshall syn. n. lapponica Thomson</tei:p>
         <tei:p>soror Telenga syn. n. pallidicornis Curtis</tei:p>
         <tei:p>scabricula (Dahlbom) quadridens (Herrich-Schaffer)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>limitatus Wesmael syn. n. mbripes (Lucas)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>clypealis Thomson syn. n. similis (Nees von Esenbeck)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>SPECIES INQUIRENDAE tersa Reinhard<tei:lb/>atriceps (Ratzeburg)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Taxonomic characters</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Sexual dimorphism. A few species ofAscogaster show little sexual dimorphism; most, however,<tei:lb/>exhibit some generally rather subtle differences between the sexes. Female antenna often<tei:lb/>shorter and broader than that of male, generally with areas of felt-like pubescence on underside<tei:lb/>of medial flagellar segments. Male antenna generally more copiously covered with hairs and<tei:lb/>more richly supplied with tyloids than in female. Carapace of female often shorter, broader and<tei:lb/>more rounded than that of male, with postero ventral rim often closer to apex and therefore less<tei:lb/>rounded postero ventrally. In several species in which the female has large genitalia the<tei:lb/>postero ventral rim of the carapace is modified in various ways in order, presumably, to facilitate<tei:lb/>the extrusion of the ovipositor (e.g. flanged in excavata, semenovi; emarginate in annularis;<tei:lb/>produced in kasparyani); these characteristics are not present in the males of these species. In<tei:lb/>many species facial hair of male longer and much denser than in female.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ocelli. Size of ocelli varies little and therefore of limited use in discrimination of species;<tei:lb/>however, relative positions of ocelli are characteristic at species-group level. Two character-<tei:lb/>states of the ocellar triangle are defined as follows: where a straight line drawn between the<tei:lb/>anterior borders of posterior ocelli also touches anterior ocellus, the ocelli are referred to as<tei:lb/>being 'on line'; where a line between posterior ocelli passes behind anterior ocellus without<tei:lb/>touching it, the ocelli are referred to as being 'not on line'. Variations in size and protuberance of<tei:lb/>the eyes are sometimes useful characteristics for differentiation of species; in none, however, do<tei:lb/>the eyes exhibit a significant degree of convergence.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Clypeus. Shape, sculpture and apical armature of clypeus generally of great significance. Apical<tei:lb/>border of clypeus often bears one or more tubercles which, in some species, are tooth-like.<tei:lb/>There is little variation within a species in the clypeal tubercles which are therefore of<tei:lb/>considerable value as a taxonomic character. The dentate clypeal armature is extremely rare in<tei:lb/>Chelonus although a characteristic feature of many species ofAscogaster. It appears to be largely<tei:lb/>confined to the Palaearctic species of the latter genus and is commoner in those of the eastern<tei:lb/>part of the region.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Facial hair. Hair on face generally pointing downwards except for a patch between bases of<tei:lb/>antennae; in some species, however, the hair points upwards, at least on upper part efface. This<tei:lb/>characteristic varies little within a species and is of considerable use for differentiation of<tei:lb/>species-groups. It is more easily seen in males because their facial hair is generally denser than<tei:lb/>that of females, but it always requires oblique lighting to be properly examined.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Caster. Shape of carapace sometimes varies within a species but nonetheless furnishes useful<tei:lb/>characters for species differentiation if the possibility of variation is constantly borne in mind.<tei:lb/>Specimens with a deformed carapace are of not infrequent occurrence. Hypopygium generally<tei:lb/>small, not projecting beyond apex of carapace, at least in dead specimens. In some species (e.g.<tei:lb/>excisa, semenovi) hypopygium large, projecting beyond apex of carapace. Ovipositor in these<tei:lb/>species generally long and often exserted.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>346 T. HUDDLESTON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Genitalia. In chelonines, the genitalia are often retracted beneath the carapace and are thus<tei:lb/>difficult to see, particularly in dried specimens. It is difficult to determine the sex of such<tei:lb/>specimens, especially in those species which exhibit little secondary sexual dimorphism. If a view<tei:lb/>can be obtained into the carapace, however, the female can be distinguished as such because the<tei:lb/>hypopygium has a convex apical border whereas the corresponding male sternite is strongly<tei:lb/>emarginate. Also, the hypopygium often has a medial longitudinal fold revealing the course of<tei:lb/>the ovipositor beneath. When the latter projects beyond the hypopygium it is usually possible to<tei:lb/>recognise it because the ovipositor sheaths are nearly always close together and apically<tei:lb/>rounded, whereas the corresponding structures in the male genitalia are generally widely<tei:lb/>separated, strongly tapered and curved.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour. In Ascogaster, as in most groups of Braconidae, undue importance has been given to<tei:lb/>colour-characteristics by many authors. In my opinion differences in colour are not sufficient to<tei:lb/>differentiate species of Ascogaster. Shu-Sheng &amp; Carver (1982) have provided experimental<tei:lb/>confirmation of the lability of colour in one species of Aphidiinae and have briefly reviewed<tei:lb/>previous studies of this phenomenon in Parasitica. In some species (e.g. varipes, canifrons) the<tei:lb/>carapace of some females is black, in others distinctly banded with yellow at the base. There are<tei:lb/>no intermediate stages between the two colour-patterns nor any associated morphological<tei:lb/>discriminants. In abdominator, on the other hand, all intermediates between extreme colour-<tei:lb/>variants occur. Presence or absence of strongly contrasted light-coloured bands on the legs<tei:lb/>appears to vary but little within a species, though the colour itself is subject to variation; this is<tei:lb/>therefore a useful characteristic for differentiation of species. Two species in the Palaearctic<tei:lb/>fauna have predominantly light-coloured heads (klugii, gonocephala); although there is con-<tei:lb/>siderable variation in head-colour within these species it is a useful ancillary character for their<tei:lb/>identification.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Wing venation. In much previous work on Ascogaster significance has been ascribed to relatively<tei:lb/>minor differences in venation. Wharton (1980), writing about Alysiinae, has shown the<tei:lb/>probability of error inherent in the use of small differences in venation as taxonomic discrimi-<tei:lb/>nants, and his conclusion is probably equally valid when applied to the chelonines. Yoneda<tei:lb/>(1978) has analysed and illustrated variation in forewing venation in semenovi (= kyushuensis).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Sculpture. In chelonines, sculpture is more strongly developed than that of other groups of<tei:lb/>Braconidae. At first sight the taxonomic significance of the sculpture of Cheloninae is obscured<tei:lb/>by its richness. Differences in sculpture in Ascogaster, however, are of considerable significance,<tei:lb/>particularly at species-group level. Thus sculptural characteristics of face, vertex, mesonotum<tei:lb/>and mesopleuron are of first importance. Sculpture of the carapace is sometimes useful in the<tei:lb/>discrimination of species but the differences are generally rather too subtle to be useful<tei:lb/>taxonomic characters. Presence or absence of rugosity on the hind coxa is sometimes a useful<tei:lb/>specific character.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The morphological terms used are defined in Richards (1977).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Depositories</tei:p>
         <tei:p>AS Academy of Sciences, Leningrad.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>HNHM Hungarian Natural History Museum, Budapest.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>IP Institut fur Pflanzenschutzforschung, Eberswalde.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>IPO Instituut voor Plantenziektenkundig Onderzoek, Wageningen.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>IRSNB Institut Royal des Sciences Naturelles de Belgique, Brussels.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>LC Lukas collection, Trencin.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MC Maeto collection, Ibaraki.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MNHN Museum National d'Histoire Naturelle, Paris.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>

         <tei:p>NR Naturhistoriska Riksmuseet, Stockholm.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>RNH Rijksmuseum van Natuurlijke Historic, Leiden.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>RSM Royal Scottish Museum, Edinburgh.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>SC Stelfox collection in USNM, Washington.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TC Townes collection, American Entomological Institute, Ann Arbor.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>UEI Entomological Institute, Hokkaido University, Sapporo.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>USNM [U.S. National Museum] National Museum of Natural History, Washington D.C.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ZC Zaykov collection, Plovdiv.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ZI Zoological Institute, The University, Lund.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ZMB Zoologisches Museum, Humboldt Universitat, Berlin.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ZMC Zoologisk Museum, Copenhagen.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Characteristics of subfamily Cheloninae</tei:p>
         <tei:p>More than 10,000 species of Braconidae have been described and it is probable that there are at<tei:lb/>least 40,000 species in nature; it is therefore one of the largest families in the Hymenoptera. The<tei:lb/>Cheloninae, with at least 800 described species, is one of the larger subfamilies of the 22 into<tei:lb/>which the Braconidae is at present divided (see van Achterberg, 1976).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Cheloninae are distinguished from all other subfamilies of Braconidae by the possession<tei:lb/>of a complete posterior mesopleural carina. This structure is generally absent in other Braconi-<tei:lb/>dae and, when present, is broadly interrupted in front of the mid coxae. All Cheloninae have a<tei:lb/>heavily sculptured gastral carapace formed by the fusion of tergites 1-3, the remaining parts of<tei:lb/>the gaster being normally concealed beneath the carapace. This feature occurs in a number of<tei:lb/>genera in other subfamilies, most of them not closely related to the Cheloninae; these taxa<tei:lb/>therefore bear a superficial resemblance to the Cheloninae, undoubtedly as a result of<tei:lb/>convergence. This matter has been dealt with in great detail in an excellent review by<tei:lb/>Dudarenko (1974). In the Palaearctic region the genera most likely thus to be confused with<tei:lb/>Cheloninae are Symphya (Alysiinae), easily distinguished by its exodont mandibles, Triaspis<tei:lb/>and Schizoprymnus (Helconinae sensu van Achterberg, 1976), which have only two submargin-<tei:lb/>al cells in the fore wing whereas chelonines have three. In other zoogeographical regions there<tei:lb/>are genera possessing a gastral carapace also in, for example, Braconinae (Physaria), Rogadinae<tei:lb/>(Spinaria), Hormiinae (Cedrid), Microgasterinae (Fornicia, Buluka), Opiinae (Coleopius),<tei:lb/>Meteoridiinae (Urosigalphus). The gastral carapace is nonetheless a valuable characteristic for<tei:lb/>the differentiation of Cheloninae if the possible exceptions are borne in mind. Chelonines also<tei:lb/>always have three submarginal cells in the forewing and the ovipositor is generally not exserted<tei:lb/>or, if it is, it is most often short and always has a slender needle-like apex. In the majority of<tei:lb/>species the ovipositor is thick at the base, abruptly narrowed shortly before the apex, short and<tei:lb/>rarely exserted. In a few species the ovipositor is slender throughout its length and requires but<tei:lb/>little reduction in breadth to attain a fine point; this type of ovipositor is often exserted. In some<tei:lb/>species of Chelonus the ovipositor is thick at the base, evenly tapered to the apex and often<tei:lb/>strongly upcurved.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Two groups of genera of the Cheloninae are represented in the Palaearctic region; the<tei:lb/>Phanerotoma-group, in which the carapace is divided by crenulate sutures into three tergites and<tei:lb/>the body colour is predominantly testaceous, and the Chelonus-group, in which the carapace is<tei:lb/>entire with no trace of sutures (except in occasional deformed specimens) and the body colour is<tei:lb/>predominantly black. The latter group is represented in the Palaearctic region by two genera,<tei:lb/>Ascogaster and Chelonus, which can be distinguished as follows.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 First submarginal cell always divided from first discal cell by vein Rs+M (Fig. 2); eyes never<tei:lb/>conspicuously hairy ASCOGASTER Wesmael</tei:p>
         <tei:p>- First submarginal cell and first discal cell confluent, vein Rs+M never present (Fig. 1); eyes always<tei:lb/>conspicuously hairy CHELONUS Panzer</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>348 T. HUDDLESTON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>There are several ancillary characters which are useful in placing some species in the two genera.<tei:lb/>The clypeus often has apical tubercles in Ascogaster but rarely in Chelonus. The face is generally<tei:lb/>strongly rugose in Chelonus, sometimes punctate in Ascogaster. The hair on the face generally<tei:lb/>points downwards in Ascogaster. upwards in Chelonus. The males of some species of Chelonus<tei:lb/>have a supragenital aperture at the apex of the carapace; this characteristic is never present in<tei:lb/>Ascogaster.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ASCOGASTER Wesmael</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster Wesmael, 1835: 226. Type-species: Ascogaster instabilis Wesmael (= abdominator (Dahl-</tei:p>
         <tei:p>bom)), by subsequent designation (Foerster, 1862: 244).<tei:lb/>Cascogaster Baker, 1926: 482. Type-species: Cascogaster fullawayi Baker, by original designation.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>[Synonymized by Watanabe, 1937: 75.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The species-groups</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The 30 Palaearctic species of Ascogaster are here divided into six informal groups based on the<tei:lb/>sculpture and vestiture of the face and the armature of the clypeus. I have made use of the<tei:lb/>species-group concept because it has the advantage of being flexible - its limits can be extended<tei:lb/>or restricted without nomenclatural disturbance. It therefore seems to me to be ideally suited for<tei:lb/>use in the Braconidae in which the fragmentary knowledge of the species in most genera<tei:lb/>precludes their sensible division into formal subgeneric units.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The semenovi- and caucasica-groups have in common a rather slender habitus with long legs<tei:lb/>and long slender gasters and concomitantly elongate female genitalia. The female carapace is<tei:lb/>often modified posteroventrally either by the development of bizarre flanges or by the strong<tei:lb/>depression of this part of the carapace. Two species in the caucasica-group do not have such<tei:lb/>modification of the carapace, but in these species the hypopygium is grossly elongated in<tei:lb/>caucasica and the ovipositor is elongate in bicarinata, the least modified species of its group. The<tei:lb/>males in the two groups have conspicuously more elongate, slender gasters than their females<tei:lb/>and the male antennae are also considerably more elongate. These species-groups therefore<tei:lb/>exhibit much stronger sexual dimorphism than is usual. The habitus of the abdominator- and<tei:lb/>annularis-groups has certain features in common with the preceding groups. Thus species of the<tei:lb/>abdominator-group are rather slender with elongate legs, though the female carapace is not<tei:lb/>modified and the ovipositor and hypopygium are short. The degree of sexual dimorphism is<tei:lb/>therefore less in the abdominator-group. All the species of the latter group share the upwardly<tei:lb/>directed facial vestiture of the semenovi- and caucasica-groups. The annularis-group also<tei:lb/>consists of species which are rather elongate and slender, but the female carapace is generally<tei:lb/>but little modified and the hypopygium and ovipositor only moderately elongate. The degree of<tei:lb/>sexual dimorphism is even less marked in the annularis-group than in the abdominator-group<tei:lb/>and only three of the five species of the former group have upwardly directed facial vestiture.<tei:lb/>The species of the semenovi-, caucasica-, abdominator- and annularis-groups are evidently more<tei:lb/>closely related to each other than to the remaining species of the genus. The bidentula- and<tei:lb/>quadridentata-groups of species have in common a generally short, squat habitus with rather<tei:lb/>short, thick legs, a short, often deep carapace and a short hypopygium and ovipositor. The facial<tei:lb/>vestiture in these groups is always downwardly directed.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>29(28) Clypeus not distinctly divided from face, apex with a conspicuous dentate tubercle<tei:lb/>medially (Fig. 72); mandible produced ventrally at base with no flange beneath</tei:p>
         <tei:p>dispar Fahringer(p. 375)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Clypeus divided from face by a deep groove, apex forming a blunt point medially but with<tei:lb/>no dentate tubercle (Fig. 76); mandible not produced ventrally at base, with a flange<tei:lb/>beneath (Fig. 71) scabricula (Dahlbom)(p. 379)</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>352 T. HUDDLESTON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The semenovi-group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Face punctate, generally reticulate-punctate, hairs on upper part efface pointing upwards. Clypeus with<tei:lb/>lateral dentate flanges or a broad medial projection, never with dentate tubercles.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The two species of this group are known only from the eastern part of the Palaearctic region, and<tei:lb/>are uncommon. They both have unusually stout female genitalia and the posteroventral part of<tei:lb/>the female carapace is strongly excised and laterally flanged, presumably to facilitate the use of<tei:lb/>these enlarged organs.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster excavata Telenga<tei:lb/>(Figs 3, 4)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster excavatus Telenga, 1941: 311. Lectotype &lt;J&gt;, U.S.S.R.: Voronezh, Shipovo, 17.vi.1898 (Silan-</tei:p>
         <tei:p>t'ev) (AS) [examined]. [Lectotype selected by Tobias.]<tei:lb/>Ascogaster kasachstanicus Tobias, 1964: 183. Holotype cf , U.S.S.R.: Kazachstan, Tselinogr. oblast, 17</tei:p>
         <tei:p>km from mouth of river Shapdara, 21. vi. 1957 {Tobias) (AS) [examined]. Syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The data of the lectotype agree with those cited for one of Telenga's (1941: 312) syntypes of<tei:lb/>excavata. Tobias selected and labelled the lectotype but I have been unable to discover where or<tei:lb/>whether the designation was published.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The holotype of kasachstanica, a male, of course lacks the extremely modified carapace which<tei:lb/>makes excavata so distinctive. Tobias was evidently misled by this extreme dimorphism and so<tei:lb/>described kasachstanica as distinct. The latter species, however, has most of the characteristics<tei:lb/>which distinguish excavata and I have no doubt that they are conspecific. In the original material<tei:lb/>of excavata, Telenga had specimens of this species from Kazachstan.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>9- Antennae missing. Head contracted behind eyes but not strongly so. Temple about equal in length to<tei:lb/>eye in dorsal view, not strongly rounded. Ocelli moderately large, OO = 3-0 OD; ocellar triangle acute.<tei:lb/>Frons behind antennae not strongly excavate, with a strong medial carina from face almost to anterior<tei:lb/>ocellus. Eyes not strongly protuberant. Face about twice as broad as high, not strongly protuberant,<tei:lb/>reticulate-punctate. Hair on upper part of face directed upwards and forwards, sparse. Clypeus about twice<tei:lb/>as broad as high, not strongly protuberant, reticulate-punctate; apical border produced medially into a<tei:lb/>broad, blunt projection without tubercles. Mandibles long, slender, strongly twisted. Pronotum projects in<tei:lb/>front of mesonotum; lateral surface smooth anteroventrally with minute punctures, strongly reticulate-<tei:lb/>rugose dorsally. Notaulices foveolate, rest of mesonotum reticulate-punctate. Precoxal suture distinct,<tei:lb/>foveolate; rest of mesopleuron densely punctate, dorsally reticulate-punctate except anterodorsally<tei:lb/>rugose. Propodeum reticulate-rugose. Carapace long, oval, rather pointed distally in dorsal view;<tei:lb/>posteroventrally rather truncate, the ventral rim only narrowly separated posteriorly and expanded into a<tei:lb/>strong flange which is deeply notched medially; smooth, shining punctate in distal half, dorsally and<tei:lb/>anteriorly reticulate-punctate with some weak rugosity. Hypopygium long, narrow, projecting beyond<tei:lb/>ventral rim of carapace. Ovipositor thick at base, abruptly narrowed shortly before apex; sheaths broad,<tei:lb/>flat. Hind coxa smooth, punctate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour black; gaster and legs brown except tibiae yellow.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf. Same as $ except carapace narrower and with posteroventral flange less strongly raised, not<tei:lb/>emarginate medially.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOSTS. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species is closely related to semenovi from which it can be distinguished by the<tei:lb/>characteristics cited in the key to species. A. excavata is conspicuously smooth - no other<tei:lb/>Palaearctic species of Ascogaster has as smooth and punctate a carapace.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster semenovi Telenga<tei:lb/>(Figs 5, 6)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster semenovi Telenga, 1941: 310. Holotype 9, MONGOLIA: Alashan, Dyn-juan-in, 23. vi. 1908</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Koslov) (AS) [examined].<tei:lb/>Ascogaster kyushuensis Yoneda, 1978: 291. Holotype $, JAPAN: Kyushu, Fukuoka Pref., Fukuoka city,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Wakozaki, 22.V.1975 (Yoneda) (ELKU) [not examined]. Syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE PALAEARCTIC SPECIES OF ASCOGASTER 353</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Telenga cited data for only one specimen of semenovi. I have examined the specimen bearing<tei:lb/>precisely these data and, agreeing with Telenga's description of semenovi, no doubt this<tei:lb/>specimen is the holotype. It has lost its head but is otherwise well preserved. Yoneda's<tei:lb/>description and excellent figures of kyushuensis are quite sufficient for this species to be<tei:lb/>identified and the name placed as a synonym of semenovi.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$. Antenna short, 22-segmented. Flagellum dilated medially, strongly tapered to apex, distally serrate<tei:lb/>beneath; medial segments at least as broad as long, some broader than long, rest of segments distinctly<tei:lb/>longer than broad but only three basal ones as much as twice as long as broad. Head broad, rounded behind<tei:lb/>eyes. Temple about equal to eye in dorsal view. Ocelli small, OO = 4OD; ocellar triangle acute. Frons<tei:lb/>behind antennae moderately depressed, strongly transversely striate-rugose. Eyes moderately protuber-<tei:lb/>ant. Genae contracted below. Face slightly protuberant, about twice as broad as high, reticulate-punctate;<tei:lb/>densely hairy, the hairs on the upper part of face pointing upwards. Clypeus moderately protuberant,<tei:lb/>densely punctate though slightly less densely than face; apical border rounded medially, without teeth or<tei:lb/>incision, produced laterally into broad dentate flanges which point forwards and downwards in front of rest<tei:lb/>of clypeus. Mandible long, twisted, the teeth blunt, broad, not distinctly separated. Pronotum projecting<tei:lb/>little in front of mesonotum; laterally rugose-foveolate. Notaulices deep, foveolate; rest of mesonotum<tei:lb/>punctate except where notaulices coalesce in a reticulate-rugose area. Precoxal suture deep foveolate; rest<tei:lb/>of mesopleuron punctate but with a deep foveolate groove anterodorsally, the anterior end of this groove<tei:lb/>and middle of precoxal suture joined by a further foveolate groove. Propodeum strongly reticulate-rugose,<tei:lb/>with a medial transverse carine dividing it into a short dorsal surface and a long posterior surface; the dorsal<tei:lb/>surface with a medial areola formed by two short medial longitudinal carinae. Carapace long, slender,<tei:lb/>sharply pointed in dorsal and lateral views, finely reticulate-rugose except posterolaterally polished,<tei:lb/>punctate; ventral rim strongly converging posteriorly, with a broad flange which is strongly incised<tei:lb/>medially. Hypopygium very long, projecting beyond ventral rim of carapace. Ovipositor long, broad,<tei:lb/>abruptly narrowed shortly before apex. Hind coxa smooth, punctate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour black; sternites and legs brown except fore tibia yellow, ovipositor sheaths translucent, pale<tei:lb/>brown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf . Same as $ except antenna longer, 27-28 segmented; flagellum less strongly dilated, not distally<tei:lb/>serrate, all segments longer than broad with copious tyloidae and a conspicuous band of light-coloured<tei:lb/>hairs at junction of each segment; occipital carina joins genal carina a little way behind mandibles and<tei:lb/>expanded into a prominent flange beneath base of mandible; ventral rim of carapace not expanded<tei:lb/>posteriorly into a flange, generally less strongly pointed.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>9 Cf, 3 $. Japan: 7 cf , Fukuoka city, Hakozaki, 22.V.1978 (Maeto) (BMNH; MC); 2 cF, Fukuoka city,<tei:lb/>Ohori, 22.V.1976 (Maeto) (MC). Mongolia: holotype $ of semenovi; 2 &lt;j&gt;, 'de Cha Tcheou a Kan Tcheou'<tei:lb/>Nan Chan, north slope, 1000-2000 m, vi.1908 (Vaillanf) (BMNH; MNHN).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOSTS. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This remarkable species is easily distinguished by the dentate flanges on its clypeus<tei:lb/>and by the characteristics of the ovipositor sheaths.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The caucasica-group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Face punctate, generally reticulate-punctate, hairs on upper part of face pointing upwards. Clypeus<tei:lb/>medially excised, with two prominent dentate tubercles.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The four species of this group are commoner in the eastern part of the Palaearctic region though<tei:lb/>the range of excisa extends as far west as France and that of bicarinata to Spain. All species in this<tei:lb/>group have exceptionally long, slender female genitalia and a large hypopygium. The clypeal<tei:lb/>teeth are least well developed in kasparyani which also has the most highly modified female<tei:lb/>carapace of any in the group.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>354 T. HUDDLESTON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster bicarinata (Herrich-Schaffer)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 17, 18, 21)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Chelonus bicarinatus Herrich-Schaffer, 1838: 154. Syntypes. GERMANY (lost).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster mlokossewitchiKokujev, 1895: 78. Holotype $,U.S.S.R.: 'Lagodechi' (Mlokossewitsch) (AS)<tei:lb/>[examined]. [Synonymised by Sz6pligeti, 1908: 409.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Reinhard (1867: 368) redescribed bicarinata after having examined Herrich-Schaffer's original<tei:lb/>material. This detailed redescription is precise and I have based my interpretation of the species<tei:lb/>upon it. I do not believe that Reinhard could have overlooked the conspicuously exserted<tei:lb/>labiomaxillary complex of rostrata (= caucasica) or that he would have failed to mention it had it<tei:lb/>been present in the syntype of bicarinata. I therefore reject Fahringer's (1934: 517) placement of<tei:lb/>rostrata in synonymy with bicarinata.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>9- Antenna long, 25-26 segmented. Flagellum generally evenly tapered from base to apex, occasionally<tei:lb/>slightly dilated medially; all segments considerably longer than broad except terminal three or four which<tei:lb/>are quadrate. Head broad, distinctly broader than mesonotum, roundly contracted behind eyes. Temple<tei:lb/>about equal to eye in dorsal view. Occiput deeply concave. Ocelli small, OO = 5-0 OD; ocellar triangle<tei:lb/>obtuse but ocelli not on line. Frons behind ocelli slightly depressed. Eyes protuberant. Malar space long;<tei:lb/>genae in face view moderately convex. Face moderately protuberant, slightly less than twice as broad as<tei:lb/>high, reticulate-punctate, often with some weak rugosity medially; hair on upper part of face points<tei:lb/>upwards. Clypeus protuberant, slightly less densely punctate than face; apical border folded inwards with<tei:lb/>two strong dentate tubercles medially. Labiomaxillary complex projecting more or less beneath the head;<tei:lb/>exserted part never as long as malar space; labial palps inserted behind mandibles. Mandibles long,<tei:lb/>slender, strongly twisted. Prothorax projecting in front of mesonotum; pronotum dorsolaterally rugose,<tei:lb/>rest punctate. Notaulices foveolate, coalescing posteriorly in a reticulate-rugose area; rest of mesonotum<tei:lb/>punctate. Precoxal suture shallow, foveolate; rest of mesopleuron densely punctate except anterodorsally<tei:lb/>rugose. Propodeum not distinctly divided into dorsal and posterior surfaces; strongly rugose, often the<tei:lb/>longitudinal rugae predominating; with two weak posterolateral tubercles. Carapace oval, rather<tei:lb/>flattened; strongly reticulate-rugose, the longitudinal element predominating except distally where the<tei:lb/>sculpture is weaker and more regular reticulate-rugose. Hypopygium short, not projecting beyond<tei:lb/>posteroventral rim of carapace; distinctly shorter than basal segment of tarsus. Ovipositor long, thin,<tei:lb/>gradually tapered, upcurved. Hind coxa smooth, punctate, sometimes with weak rugae dorsally.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour black. Carapace sometimes orange-testaceous at base; apex of femur, tibia and tarsus of foreleg,<tei:lb/>tibia of midleg and medial band of tibia of hindleg testaceous.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf . Same as 9 except antenna longer, 30-32 segmented; all flagellar segments distinctly longer than<tei:lb/>broad, terminal segments not quadrate; carapace more slender in dorsal view, flatter in lateral view; legs<tei:lb/>darker, generally completely black except for femur at apex and tibia testaceous, occasionally mid and hind<tei:lb/>tibiae somewhat lighter but never testaceous.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED<tei:lb/>32 cf , 35 9. Bulgaria, Greece, Spain, Turkey, U.S.S.R., Yugoslavia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOSTS. No reared material examined.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species is closely similar to caucasica with which it has generally been confused.<tei:lb/>The labiomaxillary complex is often more or less exserted in bicarinata but never as strongly as in<tei:lb/>caucasica', the characteristics of the hypopygium, ovipositor and head that are cited in the key<tei:lb/>serve amply to differentiate the two species. Both bicarinata and caucasica are generally darker<tei:lb/>than most other species of Ascogaster but the 9 carapace of bicarinata is sometimes tinged with<tei:lb/>orange-testaceous, that of caucasica never is.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster caucasica Kokujev<tei:lb/>(Figs 15, 16, 22)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster caucasicus Kokujev, 1895: 82. Holotype 9, U.S.S.R.: 'Lagodechi', v.1881 (AS) [examined].<tei:lb/>Ascogaster rostratus Szepligeti, 1896: 178. Lectotype cf, HUNGARY: Budapest, Gellerth, 19. v. 1895<tei:lb/>(Szepligeti) (HNHM), designated by Papp in Shenefelt, 1973: 817 [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Kokujev stated that he had a single female of caucasica; this specimen, bearing the data cited in<tei:lb/>the description, is now in AS, Leningrad. Fahringer (1934: 517) synonymised rostrata with</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE PALAEARCTIC SPECIES OF ASCOGASTER 355</tei:p>
         <tei:p>bicarinata Herrich-Schaffer and the two species have often been confused in collections, but the<tei:lb/>characteristics distinguishing them are given above in the key to species. Telenga (1941: 316)<tei:lb/>synonymised caucasica with bicarinata, evidently following Fahringer's misinterpretation of the<tei:lb/>latter species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$. Antenna moderately long, 25-26 segmented. Flagellum not conspicuously dilated medially, slightly<tei:lb/>tapered apically; basal segment distinctly more than three times as long as broad, each following segment<tei:lb/>slightly shorter until preapical segment which is about as long as broad. Head contracted behind eyes.<tei:lb/>Occiput deeply concave. Temple about equal to length of eye in dorsal view. Ocelli minute, OO = 5 OD;<tei:lb/>widely separated. Eyes small, round, protuberant. Malar space long, about 1-5 times basal breadth of<tei:lb/>mandible. Genae in face view contracted, not strongly rounded. Face almost twice as broad as high, rather<tei:lb/>flat, not strongly protuberant, densely reticulate-punctate, often with a distinct rugose element. Hair on<tei:lb/>upper part of face directed upwards. Clypeus not protuberant, weakly and evenly convex, apical border<tei:lb/>reflexed backwards at sides, medially produced into two prominent dentate tubercles; polished and<tei:lb/>densely punctate, sometimes reticulate. Mandible long, strongly twisted, ventrally expanded at base.<tei:lb/>Labiomaxillary complex elongate, projecting conspicuously beneath head; exserted part distinctly longer<tei:lb/>than malar space; labial palps inserted at least one third of distance along exserted part, distinctly beyond<tei:lb/>mandibles. Prothorax projecting in front of mesonotum with a strongly impressed foveolate groove<tei:lb/>medially. Notaulices shallow, foveolate, coalescing posteriorly in a coarsely rugose area; rest of mesono-<tei:lb/>tum polished, reticulate-punctate. Precoxal suture irregularly rugose; rest of mesopleuron reticulate-<tei:lb/>punctate. Propodeum rounded, not abruptly divided or posteromedially impressed; coarsely irregularly<tei:lb/>rugose with no distinct carinae but with small lateral tubercles. Carapace long, slightly acuminate, not<tei:lb/>rounded posteroventrally, reticulate-rugose, the longitudinal element predominating anteriorly. Hypopy-<tei:lb/>gium exceptionally long, sometimes projecting beyond the posteroventral rim of carapace. Ovipositor very<tei:lb/>long, slender, gradually tapering to apex; generally covered by hypopygium for most of its length but<tei:lb/>occasionally protruding to a distance at least equal to the length of the hind tibia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour black; wings infumate, legs yellow-marked.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf . Same as $ except that antenna longer, 32-33 segmented; carapace narrower, flatter, slightly rounded<tei:lb/>posteroventrally .</tei:p>

         <tei:p>REMARKS. The strongly exserted labiomaxillary complex of this species immediately disting-<tei:lb/>uishes it from any other Palaearctic species of Ascogaster. The strongly dentate clypeus, the<tei:lb/>upwardly pointing facial vestiture and the elongate, slender habitus of caucasica show its close<tei:lb/>relationship with bicarinata, excisa and kasparyani.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster excisa (Herrich-Schaffer)<tei:lb/>(Figs 14, 23, 24)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Chelonus excisus Herrich-Schaffer, 1834: 154. Syntypes, GERMANY (lost).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster longiventris Tobias, 1964: 184. Holotype cf, U.S.S.R.: Kazachstan, Kokshetay, 15.vi.1957<tei:lb/>(Tobias) (AS) [examined]. Syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The identity of this species is clear from Herrich-Schaffer's description and from his excellent<tei:lb/>figure. The remarkable posteroventral modification of the female carapace makes excisa one of<tei:lb/>the least liable to misinterpretation of all species of Ascogaster.</tei:p>

      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>356 T. HUDDLESTON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$ . Antenna long, 28-31 segmented. Flagellum not dilated medially, strongly tapered apically ; basal five or<tei:lb/>six segments at least twice as long as broad, rest distinctly longer than broad except apical seven or eight<tei:lb/>which are almost quadrate. Head not strongly contracted behind eyes. Temple slightly shorter than eye in<tei:lb/>dorsal view. Occiput deeply concave. Ocelli minute, OO = 4 OD; not on line. Eyes protuberant. Malar<tei:lb/>space only slightly greater than basal breadth of mandible. Face moderately protuberant, about twice as<tei:lb/>broad as high, densely and regularly reticulate-punctate; hairs on upper part of face directed upwards.<tei:lb/>Clypeus moderately protuberant, reticulate-punctate; apical margin incised medially with two blunt<tei:lb/>dentate tubercles flanking the incision, laterally weakly reflexed backwards. Mandible large, only slightly<tei:lb/>twisted, punctate. Pronotum not projecting strongly in front of mesonotum; laterally reticulate-punctate<tei:lb/>except for a medial longitudinal foveolate groove. Notaulices deep, foveolate, coalescing posteriorly in a<tei:lb/>rugose-foveolate area; rest of mesonotum reticulate-punctate. Precoxal suture broad, reticulate-<tei:lb/>foveolate; rest of mesopleuron reticulate-punctate, except dorsally rugose. Propodeum posteromedially<tei:lb/>impressed; anteriorly with two short longitudinal carinae which terminate in two blunt tubercles one on<tei:lb/>each side of medial depressed area; reticulate-rugose. Carapace about twice as long as broad, ventral rim<tei:lb/>produced posteriorly into a broad, bifurcate flange. Hypopygium long and rather narrow in side-view,<tei:lb/>generally extruded and projecting behind the carapace. Ovipositor very long, slender; abruptly upcurved<tei:lb/>shortly before apex. Hind coxa generally smooth, polished with only weak puncturation, occasionally<tei:lb/>reticulate-punctate anterodorsally, sometimes also with obsolescent transverse rugae dorsally.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour black; legs brownish-testaceous except all coxae and trochanters black, hind femur and all tarsi<tei:lb/>infuscate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf . Same as $ except antenna longer; flagellum not tapered apically, all segments distinctly longer than<tei:lb/>broad; carapace narrower in dorsal view, posteroventral rim distinctly in front of apex; legs darker, mid<tei:lb/>and hind femur black, fore femur dark proximally.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>23 cf, 19 $. Bulgaria: 22 cf, 2 $&gt;, Rhodopi, Bojno, 6.vii.l976 (Zaykov) (ZC); 5 $, same data except<tei:lb/>24.vii.1975. France: 3 $, Drome, Col de Macuegne, i.viii.1979 (Graham) (BMNH); 2 $, Lozere, R. Lot,<tei:lb/>Mende, 3-8.vii.1924 (Moseley) (BMNH); 1 $, Chateau Arnoux, 10.viii.1972 (Boudek) (BMNH); 4 $,<tei:lb/>Dept. Vaucluse, Castellet, 20.vii.1974 (Gijswijt) (RNH); 1 $, Var, Montauroux, l.vii.1960 (Van der<tei:lb/>Vecht) (RNH); 1 $, Var, Ste Baume, 19.vii.1951 (Granger) (MNHN). U.S.S.R.: holotype cf of<tei:lb/>longiventris .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOSTS. No reared material examined.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The rounded carapace with the posteroventral rim distinctly in front of the apex is a<tei:lb/>useful supplementary character for distinguishing the male of excisa from those of rostrata and<tei:lb/>bicarinata in which the carapace of the male is not strongly rounded posteriorly and the<tei:lb/>posteroventral rim is only slightly in front of the apex. In describing longiventris, Tobias<tei:lb/>evidently had not appreciated the considerable sexual dimorphism of this species; nonetheless<tei:lb/>he correctly pointed out its relationship with bicarinata.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster kasparyani Tobias<tei:lb/>(Figs 13, 19, 20)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster kasparyani Tobias, 1976: 233. Holotype cf, U.S.S.R.: Gruzia, Bogdanovka, 28.vi.1967<tei:lb/>(Kasparyan) (AS) [examined] .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$. Antenna long, slender, more than 28-segmented. Flagellum slender, not dilated medially, first segment<tei:lb/>about three times as long as broad, next 10 or so segments at least twice as long as broad, rest at least slightly<tei:lb/>longer than broad. Head not strongly contracted behind eyes. Temple slightly shorter than eye in dorsal<tei:lb/>view. Occiput deeply concave. Ocelli small, OO = 3-0 OD; not on line. Eyes small, protuberant. Malar<tei:lb/>space long, about twice basal breadth of mandible. Face about twice as broad as high, moderately<tei:lb/>protuberant, coarsely reticulate-punctate; hairs on upper part of face directed upwards. Clypeus protuber-<tei:lb/>ant, narrower than face; apical margin incised medially, weakly reflexed laterally. Mandible moderately<tei:lb/>twisted. Pronotum projecting strongly in front of mesonotum; laterally reticulate-rugose. Notaulices<tei:lb/>shallow, indistinct reticulate-rugose, coalescing posteriorly in a strongly reticulate-rugose area; rest of<tei:lb/>mesonotum reticulate-punctate. Precoxal suture indistinct, most of mesopleuron laterally irregularly<tei:lb/>reticulate-rugose, ventrally reticulate-punctate. Propodeum rounded, completely regularly reticulate-<tei:lb/>rugose with two weak medial longitudinal carinae at base. Carapace long, slender, about 2-5 times as long<tei:lb/>as broad, gradually diminished in breadth from about proximal third; narrow and rounded distally in dorsal</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE PALAEARCTIC SPECIES OF ASCOGASTER 357</tei:p>
         <tei:p>view; in lateral view rather flat, the proximal tenth strongly dorsoventrally flattened; completely finely<tei:lb/>regularly reticulate-rugose. Hypopygium at least slightly exserted. Ovipositor long, slender, strongly<tei:lb/>upcurved. Hind coxa polished with minute punctures.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour black, antenna at base and legs orange-testaceous, carapace more or less light-marked.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf. Same as female except carapace rounded, not dorsoventrally flattened at apex; colour darker,<tei:lb/>carapace black, legs black except fore tibia yellow, mid and hind tibiae brown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1 Cf, 2 $. Greece: 1 $, Rhodes, Kremasti Hills, 24-30.vi.1958 (Mavromoustakis) (BMNH); 1 $,<tei:lb/>Empona, 18-19.vi.1968 (Mavromoustakis) (BMNH). U.S.S.R.: holotype cf .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOSTS. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The long, exserted hypopygium, the long, slender, upcurved ovipositor and the<tei:lb/>upwardly directed hair on the upper part of the face show the relationship of kasparyani,<tei:lb/>caucasica, excisa and bicarinata. The characteristics of the carapace distinguish kasparyani from<tei:lb/>all other Palaearctic species of the genus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The abdominator-group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Face punctate, often reticulate-punctate, hairs on upper part of face pointing upwards. Clypeus with a<tei:lb/>single prominent dentate tubercle.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Two of the three species of this group are widely distributed in the more northerly parts of the<tei:lb/>Palaearctic region, the third, nachitshevanica, is known only from the U.S.S.R. and Mongolia.<tei:lb/>All species in the group have a short ovipositor and a short hypopygium which are generally<tei:lb/>concealed beneath the carapace. A. dentifer is rather different in head and body-shape from the<tei:lb/>other two species which form a close pair differentiated on small differences in the antennae, the<tei:lb/>notaulices and the genitalia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster abdominator (Dahlbom)<tei:lb/>(Figs 9, 10)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Chelonus abdominator Dahlbom, 1833: 165. Holotype %, SWEDEN: 'Esperod', Fallen colln (ZI) [ex-<tei:lb/>amined]. [Synonymised with instabilis by Thomson, 1874: 583.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster instabilis Wesmael, 1835: 227. Syntypes, BELGIUM: Wesmael colln (IRSNB) [examined]. Syn.<tei:lb/>n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster fulviventris Curtis, 1837: folio 672. Holotype cf , GREAT BRITAIN: England, Curtis colln (NMV)<tei:lb/>[examined]. [Synonymised with instabilis by Fischer, 1965: 11.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Chelonus femoralis Herrich-Schaffer, 1838: 154. Syntypes, GERMANY (lost). [Synonymised with instabilis<tei:lb/>by Reinhard, 1867: 364.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Chelonus rufiventris Herrich-Schaffer, 1838: 154. Syntypes, GERMANY (lost). [Synonymised with instabilis<tei:lb/>by Reinhard, 1867: 364.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster pallida Ruthe, 1855: 293. LECTOTYPE $, GERMANY: 'Freienwalde', 16.vii.1854, Ruthe colln<tei:lb/>(BMNH), here designated [examined]. [Synonymised with instabilis by Reinhard, 1867: 364.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>There is a single $ in Fallen's collection, labelled 'C. abdominator' in Dahlbom's handwriting.<tei:lb/>There is no indication that Dahlbom had more than one specimen before him when describing<tei:lb/>this species and I therefore accept this specimen as holotype of abdominator. Dahlbom<tei:lb/>obviously mistook the sex of his specimen, citing it as male in his description - the holotype bears<tei:lb/>a label upon which this error is repeated. Thomson (1874: 583) Synonymised abdominator with<tei:lb/>instabilis despite the fact that the latter species is clearly a junior synonym of abdominator.<tei:lb/>Thomson's placement has been followed by all subsequent workers, but there is no justification<tei:lb/>for continuing this incorrect usage. Wesmael (1835: 229) stated that he possessed six males and<tei:lb/>two females of instabilis. At present there are six males and five females labelled 'Ascogaster<tei:lb/>instabilis mini' in Wesmael's collection; all of these specimens are conspecific and agree with<tei:lb/>Wesmael's description of instabilis. Obviously, however, there are more female specimens<tei:lb/>labelled as 'instabilis' than Wesmael claimed to possess, thus they cannot all belong to the<tei:lb/>syntype series. A lectotype has not been selected because the species is so distinctive. There is</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>358 T. HUDDLESTON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>one male in Curtis' collection named fulviventris . It agrees in every particular with what Curtis<tei:lb/>wrote about fulviventris and I regard this specimen as the holotype of that species. The specimen<tei:lb/>was labelled as 'type' by Nixon in 1948; it is well within the limits of variation of abdominator.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Reinhard placed femoralis Herrich-Schaffer and rufiventris Herrich-Schaffer in synonymy<tei:lb/>with instabilis without indicating that he had seen the original material of femoralis. (Herrich-<tei:lb/>Schaffer himself stated in his description of rufiventris, that his original specimen of this species<tei:lb/>had been destroyed.) There is nothing in Herrich-Schaffer's descriptions of femoralis and<tei:lb/>rufiventris which precludes Reinhard's placement of them.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>There are two female specimens from Ruthe's collection in the BMNH which agree with his<tei:lb/>description of pallida. One of them bears a label in Ruthe's handwriting 'Asc. pallidus m.<tei:lb/>Freienwalde 16.7.54'; these are precisely the data cited by Ruthe in his description of pallida<tei:lb/>except that he gave the date of capture as '18.7.54'. This discrepancy is probably due to an error<tei:lb/>of transcription, all too easily made when copying figures from a barely legible handwritten<tei:lb/>label. These specimens are undoubtedly syntypic material and the female bearing Ruthe's<tei:lb/>handwritten label is here designated lectotype of pallida.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$. Antenna long, 32-36 segmented. Flagellum dilated medially, strongly tapered to apex; all segments at<tei:lb/>least as long as broad. Head large, roundly contracted behind eyes. Temple about equal to eye in dorsal<tei:lb/>view. Occiput strongly concave. Ocelli small, OO = 3-0-3-5 OD; not on line. Eyes small, protuberant.<tei:lb/>Malar space about half height of eye. Face protuberant, about twice as broad as high, reticulate-punctate,<tei:lb/>sometimes rugose medially and occasionally completely so; pubescence short, fine and directed upwards<tei:lb/>and outwards on upper part of face. Clypeus protuberant, reticulate-punctate, ventral border reflexed<tei:lb/>beneath so that in front view clypeus appears truncate; medially with a large dentate tubercle. Mandible<tei:lb/>strongly twisted with numerous long inwardly-directed hairs at base. Pronotum projecting strongly in front<tei:lb/>of mesonotum; dorsally with a strong transverse fold which becomes laterally a foveolate groove.<tei:lb/>Notaulices largely obsolete, visible at the anterior border of the mesonotum as a small reticulate-rugose<tei:lb/>area, otherwise indistinguishable from the puncturation of the mesonotum. Mesonotum smooth reticulate-<tei:lb/>punctate. Precoxal suture broad, shallow, foveolate-rugose; mesopleuron laterally reticulate-rugose,<tei:lb/>ventrally punctate. Prepectal carina strongly raised into a flange behind each fore coxa, deeply notched<tei:lb/>medially. Propodeum rather flat, reticulate-rugose, carinae inconspicuous; generally with small medial<tei:lb/>and lateral tubercles. Carapace rounded posteriorly, only slightly rounded posteroventrally. Hypopygium<tei:lb/>short, truncate, never projecting strongly beyond end of carapace. Ovipositor short, straight, abruptly<tei:lb/>tapered shortly before apex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour black; antenna at base, forelegs and proximal part of carapace yellow or sometimes the latter<tei:lb/>ivory, mid and hind legs at least partly light-marked; carapace sometimes completely yellow. Occasionally<tei:lb/>clypeus, face and pronotum orange-yellow, at least in part.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf . Same as $ except antenna longer, flagellar segments longer, thinner though the number of segments<tei:lb/>is not greater; pubescence on face longer and white in colour so that it appears much denser than that of $ ;<tei:lb/>carapace longer, narrower, sometimes almost parallel-sided anteriorly; colour darker, antenna generally<tei:lb/>black, carapace often completely dark.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>267 cf , 127 9. Belgium, Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, France, Germany, Great Britain, Ireland, Nether-<tei:lb/>lands, Sweden, U.S.S.R., Yugoslavia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOSTS. No reared material examined</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species is common and widespread in the region. The characteristics of the<tei:lb/>clypeus and the face and the virtual absence of notaulices easily differentiate abdominator from<tei:lb/>all other Palaearctic species. Indeed, the latter characteristic alone is almost diagnostic though in<tei:lb/>some species in the caucasica-gTOup the notaulices are rather weak and in those species of the<tei:lb/>quadridentata-group in which the mesonotum is strongly rugose the notaulices are therefore<tei:lb/>indistinct. This species is extremely labile in colour, varying from almost completely black to<tei:lb/>almost completely yellow, though the majority of specimens are largely black-bodied except<tei:lb/>that the carapace is more or less pale-marked.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE PALAEARCTIC SPECIES OF ASCOGASTER 359</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster dentifer Tobias<tei:lb/>(Figs 7, 12)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster dentifer Tobias, 1976: 236. Holotype cf, U.S.S.R.: Armenia, Kefansky region, Tsav. wood,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>28.vi.1971 (Kulitskij) (AS) [examined].<tei:lb/>Chelonus punctulator Kirchner, 1867: 119. [Nomen nudum; attributed to Foerster.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$. Antenna long, 36-37 segmented, pedicel often protuberant posterolaterally. Flagellum weakly dilated<tei:lb/>medially, proximal segments distinctly longer than broad, 2-0-3-0 times as long as broad at base of<tei:lb/>flagellum, rest of segments about as long as broad, those at apex about half breadth of medial ones. Head<tei:lb/>not strongly contracted behind eyes, rounded. Temple about 1-5 times length of eye in dorsal view. Occiput<tei:lb/>strongly concave. Ocelli small, OO = 3-5-4-0 OD, not on line but in an obtusely angled triangle. Frons<tei:lb/>deeply excavate behind antennae, the depressed area smooth, polished. Strong dentate lamella between<tei:lb/>bases of antennae. Face protuberant, about 1-5 times as broad as high, shining, punctate; hair on upper<tei:lb/>part of face directed upwards. Clypeus about twice as broad as high, convex, shining, punctate; apical<tei:lb/>border slightly reflexed inwards laterally, medially produced into a strong dentate tubercle. Mandible<tei:lb/>strongly twisted. Pronotum projecting distinctly in front of mesonotum; rugose. Propleurae reticulate-<tei:lb/>punctate. Notaulices distinct, foveolate, coalescing posteriorly in a reticulate-rugose area; rest of mesono-<tei:lb/>tum closely, even reticulately, punctate. Precoxal suture shallow, foveolate-rugose; rest of mesopleuron<tei:lb/>punctate except anterodorsally rugose. Propodeum rather depressed, finely and regularly reticulate-<tei:lb/>rugose with two medial longitudinal carinae and one medial transverse carina, the latter raised into blunt<tei:lb/>crests postero-laterally. Carapace oval, rather broadly rounded posteriorly, postero ventral rim consider-<tei:lb/>ably in front of apex. Ovipositor short, straight, stout, abruptly tapered shortly before apex. Sheaths<tei:lb/>clavate with brush of long hairs at apex. Hypopygium short. Hind coxa transversely rugose.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour black; base of antenna testaceous, carapace with two yellow patches anterolaterally; pronotum<tei:lb/>sometimes more or less yellow-marked; fore trochanter, femur at apex, tibia, mid and hind trochanters and<tei:lb/>tibiae at base yellow or testaceous; all tarsi infuscate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf . Same as $ except antenna longer, all segments at least as long as broad, most distinctly longer than<tei:lb/>broad; carapace narrower in dorsal view with no yellow patches anteroventrally; legs often darker, less<tei:lb/>extensively pale-marked.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>77 cf , 1 1 9- Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, France, Germany, Great Britain, Hungary, Italy, Switzerland,<tei:lb/>U.S.S.R., Yugoslavia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOSTS. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species is superficially similar toperkinsi; both have smooth, punctate faces and a<tei:lb/>well-developed medial tubercle on the clypeus and are similar in stature and colour. The facial<tei:lb/>hair of dentifer, however, always points upwards on the upper part of the face while that of<tei:lb/>perkinsi does not, but the sparseness of the facial vestiture in dentifer may result in this<tei:lb/>characteristic being overlooked. However, in dentifer there is a well-developed dentate flange<tei:lb/>between the antennae which is not present in perkinsi, and the latter species has a conspicuous<tei:lb/>longitudinal flange on the basal segment of the hind tarsus which is lacking in dentifer.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I have examined four specimens (1 BMNH; 3 MNHN) of dentifer which are labelled<tei:lb/>'Chelonus punctulator Foerster' in Foerster's handwriting. No description was published by<tei:lb/>Foerster but the name Chelonus punctulator was listed by Kirchner (1867: 119).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster nachitshevanica Abdinbekova<tei:lb/>(Figs 8, 11)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster nachitschevanicus Abdinbekova, 1969: 69. Holotype 9&gt; U.S.S.R.: Azerbaidzhan, Ordubad,<tei:lb/>20. v. 1967 (AdamidzK) (AS) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>9- Antenna short, 27-30 segmented. Flagellum not dilated medially, strongly narrowed at apex, all<tei:lb/>segments distinctly longer than broad except terminal segments which are moniliform. Head broad,<tei:lb/>transverse, roundly contracted behind eyes. Temple 1-0-1-5 times length of eye in dorsal view. Occiput<tei:lb/>strongly concave. Ocelli small, OO = 4-0 OD, almost on line. Eyes small, protuberant. Face slightly<tei:lb/>protuberant, about twice as broad as high, reticulate-punctate, sometimes weakly rugulose medially; hair<tei:lb/>on upper part of face directed upwards. Clypeus transverse, apically impressed and truncate with a strong</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>360 T. HUDDLESTON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>dentate tubercle medially; reticulate-punctate. Mandible long, slender, twisted. Pronotum projecting in<tei:lb/>front of mesonotum; rugose laterally. Notaulices shallow but distinct; rest of mesonotum reticulate-<tei:lb/>punctate. Precoxal suture broad, reticulate-foveolate; mesopleuron anterodorsally rugose, rest densely<tei:lb/>punctate. Propodeum completely coarsely reticulate-rugose with a medial transverse carina and two<tei:lb/>medial longitudinal carinae dorsally but these sometimes indistinct; no distinct propodeal tubercles.<tei:lb/>Carapace strongly narrowed posteriorly, generally also more or less dorsoventrally flattened in lateral<tei:lb/>view; posteroventral rim at apex of carapace; coarsely reticulate-rugose at base, more finely rugose<tei:lb/>towards apex.
