         <tei:p>Colour black; antenna at base, tegula, sometimes carapace anterolaterally and legs orange-testaceous<tei:lb/>except hind coxa dark, at least at base; sometimes mid and hind femora dark medially, hind tibia dark at<tei:lb/>apex; all tarsi infuscate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf . Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>4 $. Mongolia: 3 $, Chovsgol aimak, 8 km N. of Somon Burenchaan, 1450 m, 20.vi.1968 (Kaszab)<tei:lb/>(HNHM). U.S.S.R.: holotype $.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOSTS. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species is closely similar to abdominator . The characteristics cited in the key to<tei:lb/>species, together with differences in the shape of the carapace, are sufficient to distinguish the<tei:lb/>two species, but whether these differences would hold good in a longer series of nachitshevanica<tei:lb/>is open to question.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The a/mu/aris-group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Face punctate, hairs on upper part pointing downwards or rugose, hairs on upper part pointing upwards.<tei:lb/>Clypeus without medial excision or tubercles, apical border more or less convex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The five species in this group are all more or less small in size, rather flat and have long, slender<tei:lb/>ovipositors; the emission of the radius from conspicuously beyond the middle of the stigma is a<tei:lb/>venational feature characteristic of the group. Four of the species of this group are widely<tei:lb/>distributed, at least in north-western Europe, although gonocephala is uncommon. The fifth<tei:lb/>member of the group, exigua, is known only from the holotype from Mongolia. The latter<tei:lb/>species is the most highly modified of the group, having an exceptionally elongate, slender<tei:lb/>carapace; it is also the only one with long antennae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster annularis (Nees von Esenbeck)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 25, 29, 33, 34)<tei:lb/>Sigalphus annularis Nees von Esenbeck, 1816: 264. Syntypes, GERMANY (lost).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Nees von Esenbeck's description of annularis is clear and detailed enough for the species to be<tei:lb/>identified with confidence as the one described below.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$ . Antenna short, 21-24 segmented. Flagellum sometimes slightly dilated medially, moderately tapered to<tei:lb/>apex, all segments distinctly longer than broad except terminal three or four about as long as broad, often<tei:lb/>more or less moniliform. Head broad, slightly broader than mesonotum, roundly contracted behind eyes.<tei:lb/>Temple about as long as eye in dorsal view or slightly longer. Occiput moderately concave. Ocelli<tei:lb/>moderately large, OO = 2-5-3-0 OD; not on line. Frons behind antennae shallowly excavate, polished. A<tei:lb/>weak medial carina extends from a tubercle on upper part of the face, between antennae. Eyes large,<tei:lb/>protuberant. Malar space equal to about half height of eye. Face weakly convex, about twice as broad as<tei:lb/>high, shining, punctate, with sparse, downwardly pointing hairs. Clypeus weakly convex, shining,<tei:lb/>punctate; apical border slightly reflexed, evenly rounded or occasionally more or less straight medially,<tei:lb/>never with any trace of tooth or excision. Mandible small, strongly twisted. Pronotum projecting distinctly<tei:lb/>in front of mesonotum; rugose except ventrolaterally smooth, punctate. Notaulices shallow, foveolate,<tei:lb/>coalescing posteriorly in a finely rugose area; rest of mesonotum smooth punctate. Precoxal suture<tei:lb/>reticulate- foveolate; rest of mesopleuron smooth punctate except anterodorsally rugose. Propodeum<tei:lb/>finely irregularly rugose; divided by a transverse medial carina into dorsal and posterior surfaces, the dorsal</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE PALAEARCTIC SPECIES OF ASCOGASTER 361</tei:p>
         <tei:p>rather flat, with a distinct central areola. Carapace distinctly longer than thorax and propodeum; elongate<tei:lb/>oval and often truncate posteriorly in dorsal view, rather shallow in lateral view; posteroventrally<tei:lb/>emarginate. Hypopygium long, often projecting beyond carapace. Ovipositor long, sheaths slender,<tei:lb/>clavate. Hind coxa finely rugose; hind tibia somewhat swollen. Radius emitted from stigma conspicuously<tei:lb/>beyond middle.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour black; antenna brown, lighter at base; mandibles, foreleg testaceous, midleg testaceous except<tei:lb/>tibia and tarsus infuscate, tibia with a light medial band; hindleg dark except trochanter and femur yellow<tei:lb/>or testaceous, at least in part, and tibia with an ivory or pale yellow band medially; carapace always with<tei:lb/>two yellow patches at base.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf . Same as $ except antenna longer, 22-25 segmented; flagellum not dilated medially, all segments<tei:lb/>about twice as long as broad; carapace not truncate posteriorly or emarginate posteroventrally.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>65 cf , 74 9 Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, France, Germany, Great Britain, Greece, Hungary, Netherlands,<tei:lb/>Sweden.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOSTS. Pandemis heparana (Denis &amp; Schiffermuller) (Lepidoptera: Tortricidae), Recurvaria<tei:lb/>leucatella (Clerck) (Lepidoptera: Gelechiidae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This is one of the smallest Palaearctic species of Ascogaster, averaging about 2-5 mm<tei:lb/>in length. The small size of annularis together with its characteristic colour pattern of yellow at<tei:lb/>the base of the gaster and pale-banded hind tibia make it readily recognisable. The only species<tei:lb/>which shares these characteristics, though it often lacks the yellow on the carapace, is grahami<tei:lb/>which is very closely related to annularis and can be differentiated by the characters cited in the<tei:lb/>key.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster exigua sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 28, 36)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$ . Antenna long, 35 segmented. Flagellum weakly dilated medially, strongly tapered to apex, all segments<tei:lb/>longer than broad, apical ones only slightly longer than broad. Head broader than mesonotum, rounded<tei:lb/>behind eyes. Temple slightly shorter than length of eye in dorsal view. Ocelli large, OO = 2-5 OD; not on<tei:lb/>line. Face protuberant, about twice as broad as high, conspicuously transversely striate-rugose; hair on<tei:lb/>upper part pointing upwards. Clypeus narrow, convex, apical part weakly transversely depressed; smooth,<tei:lb/>punctate; apical border rounded, with no trace of medial tubercles. Mandibles small, strongly twisted.<tei:lb/>Pronotum projecting but little in front of mesonotum; laterally densely punctate, ventrally weakly rugose.<tei:lb/>Notaulices foveolate, coalescing posteriorly in a reticulate-foveolate area; rest of mesonotum shining,<tei:lb/>punctured, rather flat dorsally. Precoxal suture shallow, foveolate; rest of mesopleuron smooth, punctate.<tei:lb/>Propodeum flat dorsally, depressed, with medial transverse carina, two weak medial longitudinal carinae<tei:lb/>and lateral longitudinal carinae; completely finely reticulate-rugose. Carapace elongate, about three times<tei:lb/>as long as broad, broadest at about a third of its length from base; reticulate-rugose proximally, the<tei:lb/>longitudinal element predominant, distally smooth shining with minute punctures; posteroventral rim<tei:lb/>reaching apex. Hypopygium not exserted. Hind coxa largely smooth, punctate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour black: antenna brown except testaceous at base; all legs testaceous except hind tibia, all coxae<tei:lb/>and all tarsi infuscate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf . Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Holotype $ , Mongolia: Zavchan aimak, Choit chunch, 26 km ENE. from See Tehnen nuur, 13.vii.1968<tei:lb/>(Koszab) (HNHM).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOSTS. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The shape of the head, the sculpture and vestiture of the face and the point where the<tei:lb/>radius joins the pterostigma show the relationship of this species to klugii. The shape of the<tei:lb/>carapace and the strongly depressed body distinguish exigua from all other Palaearctic species of<tei:lb/>the genus.</tei:p>

      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>362 T. HUDDLESTON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster gonocephala Wesmael<tei:lb/>(Fig. 26)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster gonocephalus Wesmael, 1835: 240. Holotype cf , BELGIUM: Brussels, Wesmael colln (IRSNB)<tei:lb/>[examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Wesmael stated that he had a single male of this species. Two males in Wesmael's collection bear<tei:lb/>labels in Wesmael's handwriting 'Ascogaster gonocephalus mihi cf '; both are conspecific and<tei:lb/>agree precisely with Wesmael's description except that on the specimen which has complete<tei:lb/>antennae the segments number 31, not 30 as stated as Wesmael. This latter specimen, however,<tei:lb/>bears a small label '12 Jn.' and as Wesmael's original specimen was collected in June, I accept<tei:lb/>this specimen as the holotype of gonocephala.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$ . Antenna long, 30 segmented. Flagellar segments at base at least twice as long as broad; apical segments<tei:lb/>very small, much shorter and narrower than preceding ones. Head broad, strongly contracted behind eyes.<tei:lb/>Temple straight, about half length of eye in dorsal view; produced backwards on each side into a strong<tei:lb/>flange; vertex behind ocelli depressed, occipital carina obsolete. Ocelli large, OO = 2-0-2-5 OD. Eyes<tei:lb/>large, protuberant. Face broad, 2-5-3-0 times as broad as high, not strongly protuberant, rugose, the<tei:lb/>transverse striae predominant; short medial vertical carina produced into a strong dentate tubercle<tei:lb/>between bases of antennae; hair on face pointing upwards. Clypeus not strongly protuberant, distinctly<tei:lb/>divided from face; narrow, about half as broad as face; rugose-punctate; apical border reflexed forwards,<tei:lb/>rounded, without tubercles. Mandibles strongly twisted. Notaulices deep, foveolate, coalescing posterior-<tei:lb/>ly in a broad reticulate-rugose area. Precoxal suture broad, reticulate-foveolate. Propodeum rugose,<tei:lb/>dorsally reticulate with strong medial and lateral tubercles. Carapace rather long, slightly tapered<tei:lb/>posteriorly, not distinctly rounded posteroventrally. Ovipositor thin, slightly upcurved, evenly tapered.<tei:lb/>Ovipositor sheaths slender.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour black; scape ventrally, face (except sometimes medially), genae ventrally, tegula and legs<tei:lb/>reddish-yellow. Coxae, hind femur distally, hind tibia distally and tarsus black or at least infuscate; hind<tei:lb/>tibia at base whitish yellow.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf . Same as $ except that antenna longer, narrower, the apical segments not conspicuously shorter or<tei:lb/>narrower than preceding ones; hindleg more extensively infuscate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>3 Cf , 3 $. Belgium: 2 cf (including holotype), Brussels, colln Wesmael (IRSNB). France: 1 cf , Var,<tei:lb/>Montauroux, l.viii.1970 (Van der Vecht) (RNH). Hungary: 1 $, no data (HNHM).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOSTS. No reared material examined.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Morphologically gonocephala is closely similar to klugii; it differs from all other<tei:lb/>species of Ascogaster by the curious posterior prolongation of the genae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster grahami sp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 30-32)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$. Antenna short, 20-24 segmented. Flagellum only slightly dilated, moderately contracted to apex; all<tei:lb/>segments distinctly longer than broad, apical two or three only slightly longer than broad, almost quadrate.<tei:lb/>Head slightly broader than mesonotum, contracted behind eyes, strongly contracted ventrally in face view.<tei:lb/>Temple shorter than eye in dorsal view. Ocelli large, OO = 2-5-3-0 OD; not on line. Eyes large,<tei:lb/>protuberant. Face about twice as broad as high, moderately protuberant, shining, more or less densely<tei:lb/>punctate, sometimes with weak rugae laterally; hair pointing downwards except between bases of<tei:lb/>antennae ..Clypeus not protuberant, more or less densely punctate; apical border weakly rounded without<tei:lb/>teeth or excision. Mandibles slender, strongly twisted. Pronotum projecting but little in front of<tei:lb/>mesonotum; reticulate-punctate and rugose laterally.          <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE PALAEARCTIC SPECIES OF ASCOGASTER 363</tei:p>
         <tei:p>ventrally. Hypopygium long but generally not exserted. Ovipositor long, about half as long as carapace,<tei:lb/>evenly upcurved, slender; ovipositor sheaths slender. Hind coxa rugose laterally and ventrally.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour black except antenna at base testaceous, palps pale yellow or ivory; tegula and legs yellow or<tei:lb/>testaceous except coxae and tarsi infuscate, at least in part; femur of mid leg sometimes infuscate dorsally;<tei:lb/>femur of hindleg infuscate in dorsal and ventral longitudinal bands; tibia of midleg sometimes and of<tei:lb/>hindleg always infuscate but with a medial pale band. Carapace generally black but occasionally suffused<tei:lb/>with yellow at base, rarely with distinct pale areas.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf . Same as $ except antenna longer, 22-26 segmented; all flagellar segments conspicuously longer than<tei:lb/>broad; carapace more elongate, less rounded; legs often lighter in colour.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>58 Cf , 112 $ . Holotype $ , Great Britain: England, Hampshire, New Forest, Beaulieu Road, 25.vi.1959<tei:lb/>(Clark) (BMNH).</tei:p>

         <tei:p>HOSTS. Infurdtinea argentimaculella (Stainton) (Lepidoptera: Tineidae) [larvae feeding in moss<tei:lb/>on wall]; Sorhagenia lophyrella (Douglas) (Lepidoptera: Momphidae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species is closely similar to annularis with which it has been generally confused in<tei:lb/>collections. The two species are not easy to distinguish and the only differences between them<tei:lb/>are summarised in the key. Waterston (1926: 174) misidentified this species as annularis.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster klugii (Nees von Esenbeck)<tei:lb/>(Figs 27, 35)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Sigalphus klugii Nees von Esenbeck, 1816: 263. Syntypes, GERMANY (lost).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster ruficeps Wesmael, 1835: 242. Holotype $, BELGIUM: Brussels, Wesmael collection (IRSNB)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>[examined]. [Synonymised by Hellen, 1953: 86.]<tei:lb/>Ascogaster neesii Reinhard, 1867: 368. Syntype cf , GERMANY (ZMB) [examined]. Syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Nees von Esenbeck's description of klugii applies equally well to both ruficeps and gonocephala<tei:lb/>save only that he makes no mention of the gross modifications of the head characteristic of the<tei:lb/>latter species. Nees von Esenbeck would certainly have mentioned so striking a feature had it<tei:lb/>been present in the species he was describing, and I therefore accept Hellen's synonymy of<tei:lb/>ruficeps with klugii. Wesmael stated that he had a single female of ruficeps. One specimen in<tei:lb/>Wesmael's collection bears his label 'Ascogaster ruficeps mihi 9' and agrees precisely with his<tei:lb/>description of ruficeps. I accept it as the holotype, which, although in rather poor condition, is<tei:lb/>nonetheless clearly identifiable.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Two specimens (cf $) in Reinhard's collection, named as neesii, are conspecific and agree<tei:lb/>with Reinhard's description. The locality data of the 9 do not agree with those cited by<tei:lb/>Reinhard; the specimen is therefore not syntypic. The specimens assignable to neesii are all<tei:lb/>smaller than typical klugii, their eyes are relatively larger, temples shorter and more strongly<tei:lb/>contracted and the thorax flatter and more depressed. I consider these differences to be<tei:lb/>size-related and neesii therefore to be within the limits of variation of klugii.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>364 T. HUDDLESTON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$. Antenna 27-29 segmented. Flagellum sometimes dilated, the medial segments broader than long,<tei:lb/>sometimes not dilated, the medial segments then longer than broad; strongly tapered, apical six or so<tei:lb/>segments much shorter and narrower than rest of flagellum, generally almost moniliform. Head broad,<tei:lb/>distinctly broader than mesonotum, more or less roundly contracted behind eyes. Temple slightly shorter<tei:lb/>than eye in dorsal view. Occiput strongly concave. Ocelli small, OO = 3-0-3-5 OD; not on line. Frons not<tei:lb/>strongly excavate. Face broad, at least twice as broad as high, slightly protuberant, medially distinctly<tei:lb/>rugose, the transverse element predominating; hair on face fine, inconspicuous, pointing upwards on<tei:lb/>upper half of face. Clypeus only weakly convex, narrow, about half as broad as face, densely rugose-<tei:lb/>punctate with a row of foveae just behind thickened apical border. Mandibles small, strongly twisted.<tei:lb/>Pronotum projecting in front of mesonotum, transverse striate dorsally, laterally largely reticulate-<tei:lb/>punctate with fine rugosity ventrally. Notaulices anteriorly indistinct foveolate, merging with the reticu-<tei:lb/>late-punctate sculpture of mesonotum; posteriorly coalescing in a broad rugose, foveolate area; mesono-<tei:lb/>tum reticulate-punctate. Precoxal suture narrow, rugose foveolate, rest of mesopleuron punctate. Prop-<tei:lb/>odeum rather depressed; strongly, irregularly reticulate-rugose, generally only a medial transverse carina<tei:lb/>distinct though sometimes weak medial longitudinal carinae visible, at least in part, only weak tubercles<tei:lb/>present laterally. Carapace elongate, oval, coarsely reticulate-rugose anteriorly, more finely reticulate-<tei:lb/>rugose posteriorly; rather flat in lateral view; posteroventral rim slightly in front of apex. Ovipositor<tei:lb/>slender; ovipositor sheaths long, slender. Hypopygium not long, produced medially to an apical point.<tei:lb/>Hind coxa smooth, punctate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour black; antenna pale at base, generally yellow or testaceous, occasionally basal flagellar segments<tei:lb/>ivory; head varies from completely pale testaceous or yellow (except stemmaticum black) to completely<tei:lb/>black, except inner orbits pale-marked; pronotum in part and carapace anterolaterally yellow or tes-<tei:lb/>taceous. Legs completely pale yellow or testaceous except sometimes (in darker specimens) apex of hind<tei:lb/>tibia infuscate and occasionally, hind leg completely brown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf. Same as 9 except flagellum not dilated medially, not strongly tapered apically, the six apical<tei:lb/>segments not conspicuously shorter and narrower than preceding ones; carapace narrower.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>93 O*, 124 9. Austria, Belgium, Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, Finland, France, Germany, Great Britain,<tei:lb/>Sweden.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOSTS. Tubuliferola subochreella (Doubleday) (Lepidoptera: Oecophoridae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species and gonocephala are closely similar in structure; the only differences are<tei:lb/>found in the head and are cited in the key. Extensive pale coloration of the head is found only in<tei:lb/>klugii and gonocephala in Palaearctic Ascogaster, thus both species are fairly easy to recognise.<tei:lb/>The colour of the head is very variable, however, and it is not infrequently largely black.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The bidentula-group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Face punctate, hairs on upper part pointing downwards. Clypeus with one, two or three small, dentate<tei:lb/>tubercles or medially produced or emarginate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Four of the eight species of this group are common and widespread; albitarsus is uncommon,<tei:lb/>arisanica is known from China and Japan andperkinsi and longicornis only from Japan. This is<tei:lb/>the most disparate group of species; varipes, perkinsi and longicornis could each be regarded as<tei:lb/>species sola. Indeed, varipes could also be regarded as transitional with the quadridentata-group.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster albitarsus Reinhard<tei:lb/>(Fig. 48)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster albitarsus Reinhard, 1867: 364. LECTOTYPE cf , POLAND: Gdansk (ZMB), here designated<tei:lb/>[examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster leptopus Thomson, 1874: 584. LECTOTYPE $, SWEDEN: Thomson colln (ZI), here desig-<tei:lb/>nated [examined]. [Synonymised by Hellen, 1953: 86.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The single male specimen named albitarsus in Reinhard's collection agrees precisely with<tei:lb/>Reinhard's description and is therefore accepted as a syntype and here designated lectotype.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Four specimens (3 O* , 1 9) are in Thomson's collection above the name leptopus; they are<tei:lb/>conspecific and agree precisely with Thomson's description of that species. I here designate as</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE PALAEARCTIC SPECIES OF ASCOG ASTER 365</tei:p>
         <tei:p>lectotype the female which Graham restricted as type - his decision was not validated by<tei:lb/>publication. I have no doubt that Hellen was correct to synonymise leptopus with albitarsus.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$. Antenna long, 39 segmented. Flagellum tapered, medial segments about as long as broad, segments at<tei:lb/>apex much narrower, slightly longer than broad. Head not strongly contracted behind eyes. Temple<tei:lb/>slightly longer than eye in dorsal view. Occiput concave. Ocelli almost on line, OO = 2-5 OD. Frons<tei:lb/>weakly excavate; strongly striate-rugose. Face about 1-5 times as broad as high; weakly convex;<tei:lb/>reticulate-punctate with a weak median tubercle dorsally. Clypeus weakly protuberant; apical border<tei:lb/>produced medially and slightly reflexed forwards, occasionally with a weak indication of two tubercles;<tei:lb/>smooth, shining, densely punctate but not reticulate. Mandible long, moderately twisted. Pronotum not<tei:lb/>projecting strongly in front of mesonotum; finely, densely rugose laterally. Notaulices foveolate, coalesc-<tei:lb/>ing posteriorly in a large reticulate-rugose area; rest of mesonotum densely reticulate-punctate. Precoxal<tei:lb/>suture broad, strongly reticulate-rugose anteriorly; narrow and rather weak posteriorly. Mesopleuron<tei:lb/>anterodorsally strongly rugose; rest of mesopleuron densely punctate. Propodeum short, broad, divided<tei:lb/>by a medial transverse carina into dorsal and posterior areas, dorsal area coarsely reticulate-rugose;<tei:lb/>posterolaterally with stout, blunt teeth, medially with two rather weak teeth. Carapace long, clavate,<tei:lb/>reaching its maximum breadth in posterior third; coarsely reticulate-rugose; posteroventral rim somewhat<tei:lb/>before apex. Hypopygium and ovipositor short. Hind coxa densely punctate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour black; antenna testaceous in basal half; legs dark except apex of femur, tibia and tarsus of foreleg<tei:lb/>yellow, base of tibia and of tarsus of mid-leg, base of tibia and basal segment of tarsus of hind leg pale<tei:lb/>yellow or ivory.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf. Same as $ except antenna longer, all flagellar segments distinctly longer than broad; fore and<tei:lb/>midlegs more or less light in colour, sometimes completely pale yellow.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>13 cf , 3 $. Ireland: 1 cf , S. Tipperary, Burnt Woods, l.x.1947 (Daltry) (SC). Poland: lectotype cf of<tei:lb/>albitarsus. Sweden: 3 cf , 1 $ (lectotype of leptopus), Thomson colln (ZI); 5 cf, 1 $, Narke, Barsta,<tei:lb/>ll.ix.1931 (Roman) (NR); 1 cf, Uppland, 23.viii.          <tei:p>HOSTS. Unknown.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. I have examined 3 cf , 1 $ from Japan which differ from albitarsus in that the head is<tei:lb/>more rounded behind the eyes, the mesopleuron is less strongly and less extensively rugose, the<tei:lb/>carapace is smooth, punctate posteriorly and the light-coloured basal bands on hind tibia and<tei:lb/>tarsus are less distinct. These differences, too slight to warrant the description of a new species,<tei:lb/>are nevertheless enough to exclude these specimens from albitarsus, at least at present. The<tei:lb/>limits of variation given for albitarsus have, however, been based on the examination of so little<tei:lb/>material that they will probably require revision when more specimens are available for study.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster arisanica Sonan<tei:lb/>(Figs 49, 52, 54)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster arisanicus Sonan, 1932: 79. Holotype cf , TAIWAN: Arisan, 2.V.1917 (Shiraki &amp; Sonan) [not<tei:lb/>examined] .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Reinhard synonymised bidentula with rufipes but I have retained them as separate species.<tei:lb/>Watanabe (1937: 77) synonymised arisanica with rufipes, following Reinhard's interpretation of<tei:lb/>the latter species. I have based my interpretation of arisanica on specimens named as rufipes by<tei:lb/>Watanabe; they are not, however, conspecific with bidentula (= rufipes sensu Reinhard) or with<tei:lb/>rufipes as I have interpreted it.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$. Antenna long, 36-39 segmented. Flagellum dilated medially, moderately contracted at apex; all<tei:lb/>segments longer than broad but medial ones only slightly so. Head distinctly broader than mesonotum;<tei:lb/>often slightly expanded behind eyes; strongly rounded. Temple at least 1-5 times length of eye in dorsal<tei:lb/>view. Occiput strongly concave. Ocelli moderately large, OO = 3-0 OD; almost on line. Face about 1-5<tei:lb/>times as broad as high, evenly convex, densely punctate, sometimes reticulate-punctate, sometimes with<tei:lb/>weak rugosity medially. Clypeus evenly convex, about twice as broad as high, not distinctly divided from<tei:lb/>face; densely punctate, the punctures larger than those on face; apical border produced, with a distinct<tei:lb/>medial excision flanked by two tubercles. Mandible stout, weakly twisted, strongly striate-punctate at</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>366 T. HUDDLESTON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>base. Pronotum projecting strongly in front of mesonotum, with a strongly impressed Y-shaped groove<tei:lb/>dorsally; rugose laterally. Notaulices broad, shallow, rugose, coalescing posteriorly in a reticulate-rugose<tei:lb/>area. Mesonotum narrow; densely punctate, generally reticulate-punctate medially. Precoxal suture<tei:lb/>broad, shallow, reticulate-foveolate; rest of mesopleuron smooth, punctate except dorsally rugose.<tei:lb/>Propodeum rather long dorsally, divided medially by a weak, transverse carina which is raised into strong<tei:lb/>medial and lateral flanges; dorsally coarsely reticulate-rugose. Carapace elongate, distinctly longer than<tei:lb/>thorax and propodeum; generally broadest in distal half; posteroventral rim conspicuously in front of apex.<tei:lb/>Hypopygium and ovipositor short. Hind coxa smooth, punctate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour black; antenna at base testaceous, palps pale yellow; legs testaceous except mid tibia and tarsus<tei:lb/>generally infuscate apically, hind coxa infuscate at base, hind femur, tibia and tarsus infuscate at apex, hind<tei:lb/>tibia generally ivory in basal half, basal segment of hind tarsus ivory or pale yellow except sometimes at<tei:lb/>apex of segment. Hind coxa and femur sometimes almost completely black; in these darker specimens the<tei:lb/>legs are brown rather than testaceous and the mid coxa, femur and tibia are extensively black-marked.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf. Same as $ except antenna shorter, 33-37 segmented; flagellum not dilated medially; head not<tei:lb/>expanded behind eyes; carapace narrower, less rounded, flatter.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED<tei:lb/>29 cf, 40$. Japan.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOSTS. No reared material examined.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species is structurally very close to bidentula, but it can be distinguished by the</tei:p>
         <tei:p>more massive head and the more elongate carapace.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster bidentula Wesmael<tei:lb/>(Figs 50, 51, 53)</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Ascogaster atamiensis Ashmead, 1906: 191. Holotype $. JAPAN: 'Atami' (Koebele) (USNM) [examined].<tei:lb/>Syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Wesmael (1835: 231) stated that he had only one female specimen when describing bidentulus.<tei:lb/>At present, two specimens in Wesmael's collection bear Wesmael's label ' 'Ascogaster bidentulus'<tei:lb/>mihi $ '. One of these has obviously been misplaced , as it is a female of rufidens ; the other agrees<tei:lb/>perfectly with Wesmael's description of bidentulus and is here accepted as the holotype.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Reinhard (1867: 365) regards bidentula and rufipes as conspecific, but this is rejected here (see<tei:lb/>rufipes). Reinhard, however, had correctly identified bidentula and placed multiarticulatus in<tei:lb/>synonymy with it after having examined Ratzeburg's original material. This synonymy is<tei:lb/>accepted here.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thomson (1874: 586) did not state what material he possessed when describing gibbiscuta. In<tei:lb/>his collection there are six specimens so named (2 cT, 4 9). The four females are conspecific and<tei:lb/>I designate as lectotype that which bears Thomson's labels 'gibbiscuta' and 'Skan' and a square<tei:lb/>red label 'type' added by Graham. I can find no structural difference between gibbiscuta and<tei:lb/>bidentula; although gibbiscuta is more extensively pale-marked than typical bidentula I consider<tei:lb/>this to be infraspecific.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The specimen in Thomson's collection which agrees with his description of fuscipennis and<tei:lb/>which was labelled as lectotype by Graham is here designated lectotype. The only significant<tei:lb/>structural difference between fuscipennis and bidentula is the form of the clypeus. In fuscipennis<tei:lb/>the apical border is produced medially but without the paired tubercles or the excision of<tei:lb/>bidentula. However, I have seen specimens in which the structure of the clypeus is intermediate<tei:lb/>-the tubercles are present but not divided by an excision. I therefore consider this characteristic<tei:lb/>to be variable in bidentula and so regard it and fuscipennis as conspecific.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE PALAEARCTIC SPECIES OF ASCOGASTER 367</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$. Antenna long, 33-36 segmented. Flagellum slightly dilated medially, contracted in apical third, medial<tei:lb/>segments about as long as broad, apical ones distinctly longer than broad. Head contracted behind eyes;<tei:lb/>more or less strongly rounded. Temple slightly longer than eye in dorsal view. Frons strongly rugose except<tei:lb/>sometimes medially smooth, punctate (particularly in small specimens). Occiput concave. Ocelli mod-<tei:lb/>erately large, OO = 3-0 OD, ocellar triangle obtuse, ocelli almost on line. Face about 1-5 times as broad as<tei:lb/>high, moderately convex with a small medial tubercle on upper half from which runs a weak carina which<tei:lb/>extends back to the lower part of frons; reticulate-punctate, pubescence very long, silvery. Tentorial pits<tei:lb/>minute with small but distinct tubercles dorsally. Clypeus weakly divided from face; not strongly<tei:lb/>protuberant, smooth, densely punctate; ventral border somewhat retracted but produced medially into<tei:lb/>two small but distinct dentate tubercles. Mandible moderately twisted. Pronotum projects in front of<tei:lb/>mesonotum; weakly rugose. Notaulices distinct foveolate, rest of mesonotum densely punctate except<tei:lb/>posteriorly reticulate-rugose where notaulices coalesce. Precoxal suture coarsely foveolate-rugose, most<tei:lb/>of mesopleuron dorsally strongly rugose (so that precoxal suture is often rather indistinct), ventrally<tei:lb/>smooth, punctate. Propodeum strongly rugose, divided by a strong medial transverse carina which is raised<tei:lb/>medially and laterally into strong dentate flanges. Carapace short, oval, broadest at mid point; coarsely,<tei:lb/>irregularly reticulate-rugose; postero ventral rim distinctly in front of apex. Hypopygium short. Ovipositor<tei:lb/>short, straight, thick at base, abruptly narrowed shortly before apex. Ovipositor sheaths short, strongly<tei:lb/>clavate at apex. Hind coxa smooth, punctate, sometimes reticulate-punctate dorsally but never strongly<tei:lb/>transversely rugose.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour black; proximal half of antenna testaceous, rest brown or brownish-testaceous; legs yellow<tei:lb/>except all coxae dark, at least in part, fore and mid femur slightly infuscate, hind femur dark brown except<tei:lb/>at base, tibiae at least slightly infuscate at apex, tarsi infuscate except hind basitarsus pale yellow or ivory at<tei:lb/>base.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>162 cf, 92 9. Belgium, Bulgaria, Finland, France, Germany, Great Britain, Ireland, Japan, Nether-<tei:lb/>lands, Sweden.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOSTS. Epiblema roborana (Denis &amp; Schiffermiiller), Epinotia cmciana (Linnaeus), Pandemis<tei:lb/>sp. (Lepidoptera: Tortricidae), Eupithecia venosata (Fabricius) (Lepidoptera: Geometridae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. I have examined 10 specimens (4 cf , 6 9) in which the female antenna is longer (39-41<tei:lb/>segmented), the facial sculpture slightly coarser and the legs more extensively yellow-marked<tei:lb/>than in typical specimens of bidentula. They are also slightly larger and the differences may thus<tei:lb/>be related to size.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster consobrina Curtis</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 45-47)<tei:lb/>Ascogaster consobrina Curtis, 1837: folio 672. Holotype d", GREAT BRITAIN: England (NMV) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Curtis did not state how many specimens he had before him when describing consobrina, but 1<tei:lb/>Cf , 2 $ are in his collection above this name. The two females are not accepted as syntypes<tei:lb/>because they differ from Curtis' brief but precise description in several features. The male agrees<tei:lb/>exactly with Curtis' description and I accept this specimen as the holotype of consobrina as there<tei:lb/>is no indication that Curtis had more than one specimen of the species. The two females are<tei:lb/>conspecific and belong to rufidens; one was labelled 'type' by Nixon in 1948.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$ . Antenna long, 33-34 segmented. Flagellum slightly dilated medially, not strongly narrowed at apex, all<tei:lb/>segments longer than broad, generally distinctly so but sometimes medial segments only slightly longer<tei:lb/>than broad. Mandible twisted distally. Pronotum not<tei:lb/>projecting in front of mesonotum; finely, densely rugose laterally. Notaulices distinct, foveolate anteriorly,<tei:lb/>coalescing from about mid-point of mesonotum in a broad, reticulate-rugose area; rest of mesonotum<tei:lb/>punctate.          <tei:p>Ascogasterlongicornissp. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Figs 41, 42)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$ . Antenna long, 47-50 segmented. Flagellum weakly dilated medially. Strongly narrowed at apex, medial<tei:lb/>segments about as long as broad, rest distinctly longer than broad. Head broad, rounded behind eyes, not<tei:lb/>strongly contracted. Temple slightly longer than eye in dorsal view. Occiput deeply concave. Ocelli in line,<tei:lb/>moderately large, OO = 3-5 OD. Eyes large, not protuberant. Malar space short, about one-third height of<tei:lb/>eye. Face about 1 -3 times as broad as high, evenly convex, reticulate-punctate. A weak carina extends from<tei:lb/>a tubercle on the upper part efface to the frons; expanded into a blunt tubercle between antennae. Clypeus<tei:lb/>almost as broad as face; weakly convex, reticulate-punctate; apical border rounded except in medial<tei:lb/>quarter a weakly emarginate projection. Mandible large, slightly twisted. Pronotum projecting in front of<tei:lb/>mesonotum; dorsolaterally reticulate-foveolate. Notaulices foveolate; rest of mesonotum densely punc-<tei:lb/>tate except posteromedially reticulate-rugose. Precoxal suture not distinct because upper part of meso-<tei:lb/>pleuron completely coarsely rugose, generally reticulate, ventral part smooth, punctate. Propodeum<tei:lb/>completely coarsely and evenly reticulate-rugose with prominent medial and lateral tubercles, the medial<tei:lb/>pair pyriform, the lateral ones blunt, dentate. Carapace oval in dorsal view, clavate in lateral view,<tei:lb/>posteroventral rim distinctly in front of apex; finely reticulate-rugose. Hind coxa smooth, punctate; hind tibia<tei:lb/>incrassate; hind tarsus slightly laterally compressed.</tei:p>

Mid and hind<tei:lb/>tibia with ivory band near base.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species is perhaps most closely related to bidentula. A. longicornis is easily<tei:lb/>distinguished from all other Palaearctic species by its conspicuously long antennae and by the<tei:lb/>characteristics of its clypeus. It is a large (up to 7-0 mm) stout species though the males tend to be<tei:lb/>rather smaller on average.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species is morphologically very similar to dentifer (q.v.). A. perkinsi is not closely<tei:lb/>related to any species in the bidentula-group and in the structure of its clypeus it shows affinities<tei:lb/>with the quadridentata-group. I dedicate this species to the memory of the late Dr J. F. Perkins, a<tei:lb/>gifted and generous former colleague.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster rufidens Wesmael<tei:lb/>(Figs 37, 39, 40)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster rufidens Wesmael, 1835: 231. Holotype $, BELGIUM: Charleroy, colln Wesmael (IRSNB)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>[examined].<tei:lb/>Chelonus rufipes Herrich-Schaffer, 1838: 154. Syn types, GERMANY (lost). [Junior secondary homonym of</tei:p>
         <tei:p>rufipes (Latreille, 1809); synonymised by Reinhard, 1867: 366.]<tei:lb/>Chelonus (Ascogaster) laevigator Ratzeburg, 1852: 25. Syntypes, GERMANY (lost). [Synonymised by</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Reinhard, 1867: 365.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Wesmael (1835: 233) stated that he had a single specimen of rufidens. One specimen in<tei:lb/>Wesmael's collection bears his label 'Ascogaster rufidens mihi cf ' and agrees precisely with the<tei:lb/>description of that species except that the antennae are now more mutilated than originally<tei:lb/>stated. It is here accepted as holotype. Wesmael believed this specimen to be a male and so<tei:lb/>labelled it, but I consider it to be a female though the retraction of the genitalia beneath the<tei:lb/>carapace makes it difficult to discern the sex, particularly so as rufidens exhibits no sexual<tei:lb/>dimorphism.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Reinhard stated that he had examined Ratzeburg's original specimen of laevigator and he<tei:lb/>cited characters for rufidens which show that he had correctly identified that species. The above<tei:lb/>synonymy is therefore accepted.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Reinhard (1867: 366) placed rufipes Herrich-Schaffer in synonymy with rufidens although<tei:lb/>apparently without having seen the original material. Herrich-Schaffer's description and figure<tei:lb/>are entirely consistent with Reinhard's placement.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>370 T. HUDDLESTON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>9- Antenna long, 33-35 segmented. Flagellum not distinctly dilated medially, all segments at least as long<tei:lb/>as broad, generally longer than broad. Head contracted behind eyes but not strongly so. Temple about<tei:lb/>equal to eye in dorsal view. Occiput strongly concave. Ocelli small OO = 3 OD, ocellar triangle obtuse,<tei:lb/>ocelli almost on line. Eyes protuberant but not large. Malar space about half height of eye. Face not<tei:lb/>strongly protuberant, densely punctate, sometimes reticulate-punctate, densely hairy; a weak tubercle<tei:lb/>medially below antennal bases, generally with a weak carina extending back between the antennae,<tei:lb/>sometimes almost reaching anterior ocellus. Clypeus not protuberant, sculpture same as face; apical<tei:lb/>border convex, with medially three small dentate tubercles. Mandibles stout, only slightly twisted, ventral<tei:lb/>border reflexed, produced into a stout flange extending from mandibular articulation to base of ventral<tei:lb/>tooth. Pronotum transversely rugose dorsally with a distinct medial pit and a small raised triangular area of<tei:lb/>fine punctures immediately in front of mesonotum; lateral surface of pronotum punctate dorsally, rugose<tei:lb/>ventrally with a medial foveolate groove. Propleuron reticulate-punctate. Notaulices deep, foveolate.<tei:lb/>Mesoscutum broad, reticulate-punctate. Precoxal suture broad, anteriorly rugose-foveolate, posteriorly<tei:lb/>narrow foveolate; mesopleuron rugose dorsally, rest smooth punctate. Propodeum completely strongly<tei:lb/>reticulate-rugose, divided into dorsal and posterior surfaces by a medial transverse carina which is<tei:lb/>produced posterolaterally into two stout blunt crests. Carapace broad, rugose, sometimes with one or two<tei:lb/>faintly impressed lines in positions suggesting the suturiform articulation (such a condition was noted by<tei:lb/>Wesmael in his description of rufidens and is indeed visible in the holotype). Hypopygium short.<tei:lb/>Ovipositor sheaths short, widened apically where there is a brush of long hairs. Hind coxa smooth,<tei:lb/>punctate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour black; antenna at base, mandibles, palps yellow or testaceous. Legs yellow except coxae black, at<tei:lb/>least in part, all tarsi infuscate, hind femur and tibia infuscate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf. Same as 9-</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>81 cf , 4 1 9 Belgium, Czechoslovakia, France, Germany, Great Britain, Hungary, Ireland, Netherlands,<tei:lb/>Sweden.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOSTS. Croesia bergmanniana (L.), Pandemis cerasana (Hiibner), Pandemis corylana (Fabri-<tei:lb/>cius), Pandemis heparana (Denis &amp; Schiffermuller) (Lepidoptera: Tortricidae). Yponomeuta<tei:lb/>padella (L.) (Lepidoptera: Yponomeutidae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The unique clypeal armature of rufidens has ensured that it is one of the least<tei:lb/>misinterpreted species oi Ascogaster. The characteristics of the mandibles, which appear to have<tei:lb/>been overlooked by previous workers, are also invaluable taxonomic discriminants. Evenhuis &amp;<tei:lb/>Vlug (1983) have pointed out that the principal hosts of rufidens belong to the Tortricidae,<tei:lb/>Tortricinae which lay their eggs in batches. In contrast to this quadridentata attacks Tortricidae,<tei:lb/>Olethreutinae the females of which lay their eggs separately on the host plants.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster varipes Wesmael<tei:lb/>(Fig. 38)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster varipes Wesmael, 1835: 234. LECTOTYPE 9, BELGIUM: Brussels, colln Wesmael (IRSNB),<tei:lb/>here designated [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster cavifrons Thomson, 1874: 585. LECTOTYPE 9, SWEDEN: Skane, Torekov, vii.1860 (Thom-<tei:lb/>son) (ZI), here designated [examined]. Syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster sternalis Thomson, 1874: 587. LECTOTYPE 9, SWEDEN: Smaland (Thomson) (ZI), here<tei:lb/>designated [examined]. [Synonymised by Telenga, 1941: 322.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster jaroslawensis Kokujev, 1895: 86. Holotype 9. U.S.S.R.: 'Jaroslaw' (AS) [examined]. Syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Wesmael (1835: 235) stated that he possessed two males and six females of varipes. Two males<tei:lb/>and four females are present above this name in Wesmael's collection, each bearing Wesmael's<tei:lb/>label 'Ascogaster varipes mihi'. They are conspecific and agree precisely with Wesmael's<tei:lb/>description of varipes. Wesmael assigned two of his series of six females to a 'var. 2'; these<tei:lb/>specimens are among the surviving syntypes and there is also a male labelled 'var. 1'. I designate<tei:lb/>as lectotype of varipes the better-preserved of the two females from the main syntypic series.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thomson did not state how many specimens he had before him when describing cavifrons; at<tei:lb/>present six are in his collection above this name. One of these is a male of abdominator and<tei:lb/>cannot be a syntype of cavifrons because it does not agree with the original description;</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE PALAEARCTIC SPECIES OF ASCOGASTER 371</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thomson's remarks upon abdominator show him to have been thoroughly familiar with that<tei:lb/>species. Of the five remaining specimens (2 cf , 3 $) four are certainly conspecific and agree with<tei:lb/>Thomson's description of cavifrons, the fifth (cf) is in poor condition and is impossible to<tei:lb/>identify. I designate as lectotype the female bearing Thomson's labels Tkov., 7 '60' '$'<tei:lb/>cavifrons m.' and a square red label Type' added by Graham. A. cavifrons comes well within the<tei:lb/>range of variation of varipes, agreeing closely with Wesmael's 'var. 2'.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Of the four specimens in Thomson's collection above the name sternalis, I designate as<tei:lb/>lectotype the best preserved specimen that was labelled as 'type' by Graham. The strongly raised<tei:lb/>acetabular carina used by Thomson to differentiate sternalis seems to me to be only of<tei:lb/>infraspecific value; apart from this characteristic, sternalis agrees with varipes in every particular<tei:lb/>and Telenga's synonymy is therefore accepted. The holotype 9 ofjaroslawensis has lost its head<tei:lb/>but I have no doubt that it is conspecific with varipes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$. Antenna long, 34-35 segmented. Flagellum dilated medially, strongly tapered to apex, most distal<tei:lb/>segments about as long as broad. Head rounded behind eyes, often expanded, particularly in larger<tei:lb/>specimens. Temple about 1-0-1-5 times length of eye in dorsal view. Occiput strongly concave. Ocelli in<tei:lb/>obtuse triangle but not on line, OO = 3-0-3-5 OD. Frons behind antennae excavate, the depressed area<tei:lb/>smooth with a weak medial carina which runs from between the antennae to just in front of the fore ocellus.<tei:lb/>Eyes not strongly protuberant. Genae generally convex in face view. Face protuberant, always distinctly<tei:lb/>and evenly convex, about twice as broad as high, generally reticulate-punctate but sometimes finely and<tei:lb/>regularly reticulate-rugose. Clypeus transversely convex dorsally, the ventral half transversely depressed,<tei:lb/>its border slightly reflexed without tooth or impression medially; reticulate-punctate. Mandible large,<tei:lb/>strongly twisted with a deep semicircular depression at base. Pronotum projecting slightly in front of<tei:lb/>mesonotum; rugose-punctate. Notaulices distinct, foveolate, rest of mesonotum punctate except post-<tei:lb/>eriorly reticulate-rugose and ventrally punctate; precoxal suture not easily distinguished from rugosity on<tei:lb/>mesopleuron. Propodeum completely reticulate-rugose, divided by a medial carina which is expanded into<tei:lb/>prominent dentate flanges laterally and two broad low protuberances medially between which dorsal<tei:lb/>surface of propodeum weakly depressed, sometimes with a short, medial longitudinal carina. Carapace<tei:lb/>oval, generally rather deep distally, posteroventral rim distinctly in front of apex; reticulate-rugose at base,<tei:lb/>rugose-punctate apically. Hypopygium short. Ovipositor short, straight, abruptly narrowed shortly before<tei:lb/>apex; ovipositor sheaths short, clavate. Hind coxa strongly transversely rugose.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour black; carapace sometimes pale yellow at base, legs generally predominantly black, only femora<tei:lb/>at apex and tibiae yellow; hind tibia infuscate at apex, occasionally legs predominantly yellow with only<tei:lb/>apex of hind femur and apex of mid and hind tibiae and all tarsi dark.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf . Same as $ except antenna not dilated medially; carapace only rarely pale-marked and then weakly<tei:lb/>and not in a distinct basal patch; legs often darker.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>165 cf , 127 $. Austria, Belgium, Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, France, Germany, Great Britain, Hungary,<tei:lb/>Netherlands, Sweden, U.S.S.R., Yugoslavia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOSTS. No reared material examined.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species is readily recognisable by the semicircular depression at the base of the<tei:lb/>mandible and by the characteristics of its face and clypeus. The mandibular depression is best<tei:lb/>seen if the head is examined in anterolateral view under oblique illumination; it is often invisible<tei:lb/>in full anterior view. A. varipes is a conspicuously short, stout species with a short, deep, strongly<tei:lb/>rounded carapace; reticulata and quadridentata share this characteristic, however, and may thus<tei:lb/>be confused with varipes, particularly those specimens of the latter species which have rather<tei:lb/>rugose faces. Neither reticulata nor quadridentata, however, has a semicircular depression at the<tei:lb/>base of the mandible, quadridentata always has a medial tubercle on the clypeus, and reticulata<tei:lb/>has a smooth, punctate hind coxa.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The quadridentete-group</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Face strongly, irregularly rugose, hair on upper part pointing downwards. Clypeus generally with medial<tei:lb/>dentate tubercle, occasionally with none but never with more than one.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The eight species of this group are all heavily sculptured, having the head and thorax more or less<tei:lb/>completely rugose. The dentate tubercle on the clypeus is absent in armata and reticulata and is</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>372 T. HUDDLESTON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>often weak in scabricula; these species are readily distinguished from all other Palaearctic<tei:lb/>species by the characteristics of the head and carapace, as cited in the key. The species of this<tei:lb/>group are generally widely distributed throughout the Palaearctic region - indeed quadridentata<tei:lb/>is known to be Holarctic - but armata, canifrons and scabricula are uncommon and reticulata is<tei:lb/>as yet known only from Japan and Czechoslovakia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster armata Wesmael<tei:lb/>(Figs 56, 57)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster armatus Wesmael, 1835: 233. LECTOTYPE $, BELGIUM: Brussels, colln Wesmael (IRSNB),</tei:p>
         <tei:p>here designated [examined] .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Chelonus pulchellus Curtis, 1829: 105 [Nomen nudum. ]<tei:lb/>Ascogaster esenbeckii Curtis, 1837: folio 672. LECTOTYPE $, GREAT BRITAIN: England, Glanvilles</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Wootton, vii, grass in meadows (NMV), here designated [examined]. [Replacement name for pulchellus</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Curtis, 1829.] Syn. n.<tei:lb/>Chelonus luteicornis Herrich-Schaffer, 1838: 154. Syntypes, GERMANY (lost). [Synonymised by Reinhard</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1867: 263.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Wesmael (1835: 234) stated that he possessed three females and one male of armata. There are<tei:lb/>three females and two males in Wesmael's collection each bearing his label 'Ascogaster armatus<tei:lb/>mini'; they are conspecific and agree precisely with the description of armata. I designate the<tei:lb/>best preserved female as lectotype and the other two females as paralectotypes. No doubt one of<tei:lb/>the two males is the male syntype referred to by Wesmael but it cannot be differentiated.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I have examined two specimens from Curtis's collection, one labelled 'pulchellus' and the<tei:lb/>other Type of Ascogaster esenbeckii Curtis det G. E. J. Nixon 1948'. These specimens are<tei:lb/>conspecific and agree precisely with Curtis' description; that labelled 'Type' by Nixon bears no<tei:lb/>data whereas the other specimen has a label with the data published by Curtis. I have therefore<tei:lb/>designated the latter specimen as lectotype of esenbeckii, and it comes well within the limits of<tei:lb/>variation of armata. Marshall (1885: 142) synonymised esenbeckii with instabilis, giving no<tei:lb/>reason for his action but probably basing it on Curtis' description. I have no doubt that this<tei:lb/>placement is incorrect.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>It is quite clear from the descriptions of luteicornis and annularis that Herrich-Schaffer's<tei:lb/>figures of these two species were transposed. Thus figure 154.7 depicts luteicornis and 154.8<tei:lb/>annularis. Reinhard (1867: 263) synonymised luteicornis and armata based on an examination of<tei:lb/>specimens sent to him as luteicornis by Herrich-Schaffer. It is clear from Reinhard's description<tei:lb/>that he had correctly identified armata and I therefore accept his synonymy.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$. Antenna long, 36-39 segmented. Flagellum dilated medially, medial segments distinctly broader than<tei:lb/>long, apical five or six segments nearly moniliform; densely covered in short, thick adpressed bristles. Head<tei:lb/>subcubic, not strongly contracted behind eyes. Temple 1-5-2-0 times length of eye in dorsal view. Occiput<tei:lb/>strongly concave. Ocelli small, OO = 4 OD; ocellar triangle obtuse, ocelli almost on line. Frons behind<tei:lb/>antennae deeply excavate, generally smooth, shining and delimited laterally by a weak carina. A medial<tei:lb/>carina extends from upper part of face between antennae to anterior ocellus; grossly expanded between<tei:lb/>antennae into an erect triangular lamina. Eyes small. Malar space about half height of eye. Face<tei:lb/>protuberant, about twice as broad as high, strongly rugose, generally striate-rugose but sometimes<tei:lb/>reticulate medially with a weak tubercle medially at which point arises the interantennal carina. Clypeus<tei:lb/>protuberant though not strongly so, deeply divided from face; apical border convex, not protruding<tei:lb/>medially and without distinct tooth or tubercle; largely reticulate-punctate. Mandible stout, not twisted,<tei:lb/>densely punctate with long hairs. Pronotum projecting slightly in front of mesonotum; with a medial<tei:lb/>transverse groove dorsally, reticulate-rugose laterally; propleuron reticulate-rugose. Notaulices present<tei:lb/>but indistinct because mesonotum strongly rugose, posteriorly reticulate; medial lobe of mesoscutum often<tei:lb/>with a reticulate-punctate area anteriorly. Precoxal suture indistinct; mesopleuron completely reticulate-<tei:lb/>rugose except sometimes reticulate-punctate ventrally, but mesolcus rugose or reticulate. Propodeum<tei:lb/>strongly reticulate-rugose, divided into dorsal and posterior surfaces by a weak transverse carina which is<tei:lb/>produced posterolaterally into stout blunt teeth. Carapace long, rather narrow; finely reticulate-rugose,<tei:lb/>posteriorly rugulose-punctate. Ovipositor short, straight, abruptly tapered just before apex; ovipositor<tei:lb/>sheaths with apical brush of long hairs. Hind coxa transversely striate on dorsal and outer surface; hind<tei:lb/>tibia densely reticulate-punctate. Wings rather short, infumate.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE PALAEARCTIC SPECIES OF ASCOGASTER 373</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour black, basal segments of antenna light in colour; fore tibia completely, mid and hind tibia at least<tei:lb/>partly and gaster proximally yellow.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf . Same as $ except that flagellum not expanded medially, medial segments about as long as broad,<tei:lb/>gaster almost always completely black.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>

         <tei:p>HOSTS. Coleophora hornigiToll [= paripennella auctt.] (Lepidoptera: Coleophoridae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The massive head of this species together with its strongly excavate frons distinguish it<tei:lb/>from all other species of Ascogaster. The strong, dentate flange between the scapes is also a<tei:lb/>distinctive characteristic shared only by dentifer which is otherwise quite a different insect. A.<tei:lb/>armata has no medial tooth on the clypeus, a characteristic found otherwise only in reticulata and<tei:lb/>scabricula in the quadridentata-group.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster brevicornis Wesmael<tei:lb/>(Fig. 67)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster brevicornis Wesmael, 1835: 239. Syntypes, BELGIUM: Wesmael colln (IRSNB) [examined].<tei:lb/>Chelonus monilicornis Herrich-Schaffer, 1838: 154. Syntypes, GERMANY (lost). [Synonymised by<tei:lb/>Reinhard, 1867: 367.]</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Wesmael (1835: 240) stated that he had three males and one female of this species. Two males<tei:lb/>and two females in Wesmael's collection are labelled 'Ascogaster brevicornis mini' in Wesmael's<tei:lb/>handwriting; they are conspecific and agree with the original description. Clearly, however,<tei:lb/>there is a discrepancy between the sex of his specimens as given by Wesmael and that of the<tei:lb/>specimens which now stand above brevicornis in his collection. Thus there is doubt about the<tei:lb/>syntype status of the females and, as the characteristics which differentiate brevicornis are best<tei:lb/>exhibited by that sex, I have not designated a lectotype.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Reinhard placed monilicornis and brevicornis together in synonymy with similis. It is clear<tei:lb/>from Reinhard's description that he had correctly identified brevicornis and Herrich-Schaffer's<tei:lb/>description and figure of monilicornis support Reinhard's placement of these species. I do not,<tei:lb/>however, believe that similis and brevicornis are conspecific because the thorax and scutellum of<tei:lb/>brevicornis are always coarsely rugose whereas those of similis were described as finely and<tei:lb/>closely punctulate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$. Antenna short, 22-23 segmented. Flagellum slightly dilated medially, all segments considerably<tei:lb/>broader than long, preapical segments slightly broader than long, apical segment longer than broad,<tei:lb/>pointed, all segments in distal half of flagellum distinctly separated. Head roundly contracted behind eyes.<tei:lb/>Temple about equal in length to eye in dorsal view. Vertex strongly rugose, in part reticulate. Ocelli small,<tei:lb/>OO = 4 OD; ocellar triangle obtuse, the ocelli almost on line. Eyes fairly large but not protuberant. Face<tei:lb/>not strongly protuberant, about twice as broad as high, strongly rugose, generally reticulate-rugose<tei:lb/>medially with a small tubercle from which a weak carina extends back between antennae and ends at<tei:lb/>anterior ocellus. Clypeus not protuberant polished, punctate; apical border projecting slightly forwards,<tei:lb/>produced into a blunt tooth medially. Mandible not twisted, punctate at base. Pronotum dorsally with a<tei:lb/>deeply impressed foveolate transverse groove; laterally strongly rugose-reticulate. Propleuron reticulate-<tei:lb/>rugose. Notaulices deep, foveolate. Mesoscutum strongly rugose. Mesopleuron almost completely reticu-<tei:lb/>late-rugose, precoxal suture therefore indistinct. Propodeum completely reticulate-rugose, divided by a</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>374 T. HUDDLESTON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>weak, transverse carina produced into medial and postero-lateral pairs of stout dentate crests. Carapace<tei:lb/>viewed dorsally widest at about mid-point, tapering evenly to apex; laterally angulate posteroventrally, the<tei:lb/>ventral rim reaching almost to apex; completely strongly reticulate-rugose. Ovipositor short. Ovipositor<tei:lb/>sheaths wide, polished, with a brush of long hairs apically. Hind coxa rugose on outer surface.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour black: antenna at base, fore tibia completely, mid and hind tibia at base yellow.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf . Same as 9 except that antennal segments longer, less distinctly separated; ventral rim of carapace not<tei:lb/>reaching apex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>15 Cf , 29 9 Belgium, Czechoslovakia, France, Germany, Great Britain, Hungary, Ireland, Netherlands,<tei:lb/>Switzerland.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOSTS. No reared material examined.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. This species closely resembles quadridentata; the female of brevicornis is easily<tei:lb/>distinguished from quadridentata by its short, thick apically moniliform antenna. Further, the<tei:lb/>number of antennal segments (cf, 9) is different in the two species; 21-23 segments in<tei:lb/>brevicornis and more than 30 in quadridentata. The carapace also differs; in brevicornis the<tei:lb/>ventral rim reaches almost to the apex, in quadridentata it is always distinctly before the apex.<tei:lb/>The shape of the carapace viewed dorsally is also generally rather different, that of brevicornis<tei:lb/>being much more distinctly tapered and less rounded than that of quadridentata. The shape of<tei:lb/>the carapace in the latter species, however, is rather variable.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster canifrons Wesmael<tei:lb/>(Figs 58, 59)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster canifrons Wesmael, 1835: 236. LECTOTYPE 9, BELGIUM: Liege (Robert) (IRSNB), here<tei:lb/>designated [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster graniger Thomson, 1892: 1791. LECTOTYPE 9, SWEDEN: Skane, Palsjo (ZI), here desig-<tei:lb/>nated [examined]. Syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Wesmael (1835: 237) stated that he possessed one female and one male of canifrons', two such<tei:lb/>specimens are in his collection above the name canifrons, both labelled 'Ascogaster canifrons<tei:lb/>mini'. They are conspecific and agree precisely with Wesmael's description; I consider them<tei:lb/>syntypes and designate the female as lectotype.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>There are five specimens (2 cf , 3 9) in Thomson's collection above the name graniger. The<tei:lb/>three females and one of the males are conspecific and agree with the original description; the<tei:lb/>second male mounted on the same pin below the first belongs to the bidentula-gioup. The<tei:lb/>lectotype is from Palsjo (type-locality) and was selected and labelled as 'type' by Graham; it is<tei:lb/>well within the limits of variation of canifrons. One of the female specimens bears the labels 'L-d'<tei:lb/>(Lappland) and 'lapponicus' in Thomson's handwriting. At first sight, therefore, this specimen<tei:lb/>appears to be the holotype of lapponica but it disagrees with Thomson's description of that<tei:lb/>species in several respects. It has been pointed out by Huddleston (1980: 3) and Fitton (1982: 4)<tei:lb/>that species labels in Thomson's handwriting were not placed on the specimens by him and that<tei:lb/>the presence of such a label on a pin is not reliable evidence of the identity of the specimen.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>9- Antenna long, 39-40 segmented. Flagellum not dilated medially, strongly contracted distally, proximal<tei:lb/>and distal segments distinctly longer than broad, medial segments broader than long. Head large, strongly<tei:lb/>contracted behind eyes. Temple not rounded, slightly longer than eye in dorsal view. Occiput deeply<tei:lb/>concave. Ocelli small, OO = 3-0-3-5 OD, almost on line. Frons depressed behind antennae, strongly<tei:lb/>transversely rugose. Eyes not strongly protuberant. Face about 1-5 times as broad as high, moderately<tei:lb/>protuberant, completely rugose with a strong medial tubercle from which a weak carina extends back<tei:lb/>between the antennae to the anterior ocellus. Clypeus narrow, about half breadth of face; moderately<tei:lb/>protuberant, shallowly reticulate-punctate, apical border weakly convex with a distinct sharp tubercle<tei:lb/>medially. Mandible stout, not strongly twisted. Pronotum projecting slightly in front of mesonotum;<tei:lb/>rugose. Mesonotum completely densely rugose; notaulices not distinct. Mesopleuron completely coarsely<tei:lb/>reticulate-rugose; precoxal suture not distinct. Propodeum completely coarsely reticulate-rugose, not<tei:lb/>distinctly carinate but for a medial transverse carina which is expanded medially into two small blunt teeth<tei:lb/>and laterally into two larger ones. Carapace long, oval, densely and irregularly reticulate-rugose,</tei:p>

         <tei:p>posteroventral rim slightly in front of apex. Hypopygium short. Ovipositor short, straight, abruptly<tei:lb/>narrowed shortly before apex; ovipositor sheaths short, broad, clavate with a copious tuft of hairs distally.<tei:lb/>Hind coxa distinctly rugose.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Ascogaster dispar Fahringer<tei:lb/>(Figs 70, 71, 73)</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Ascogaster spinifer Tobias, 1964: 185. Holotype cf , U.S.S.R. : 9.vi. 1958 (Tobias) (AS) [examined]. Syn. n.<tei:lb/>Ascogaster koslo vi Tobias, 1972: 601. Holotype $&gt;, MONGOLIA: 3-4. vii. 1968 (Koslov) (AS) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>There are four specimens (1 cf , 3 9) above the name dispar in the NM collection bearing labels<tei:lb/>with dates from 13. v. 1912 to 25. vi. 1912 and the number 7-144; one also has a label bearing the<tei:lb/>host data cited by Fahringer and another a label 'Ascogaster dipsaris m.' in Fahringer's<tei:lb/>handwriting. All these specimens are conspecific and agree precisely with Fahringer's descrip-<tei:lb/>tion of dispar and I have no doubt that they are syntypes of that species. Fahringer obviously<tei:lb/>changed the specific epithet before publication.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The holotype of spinifer and that of koslovi are rather smaller than typical specimens of dispar<tei:lb/>but they are within the limits of variation of that species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$. Antenna 33-35 segmented.
