         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>25 cf, 21 9- Austria, Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, France, Great Britain, Greece, Hungary, Iran,<tei:lb/>Mongolia, Switzerland, Turkey, U.S.S.R., Yugoslavia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOSTS. Endothenia gentianaeana (Hiibner) (Lepidoptera: Tortricidae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The shape of the head is rather variable in this species; whereas in most specimens it is<tei:lb/>rather massive, expanded behind the eyes and strongly rounded, in smaller specimens it is not<tei:lb/>expanded behind the eyes, less strongly rounded, even weakly contracted. Thus some of the<tei:lb/>smaller specimens of dispar rather resemble quadridentata; in dispar, however, the mandible is<tei:lb/>always ventrally expanded at the base and never has a flange beneath, and in quadridentata the<tei:lb/>mandible is not expanded at the base and always has a small flange ventrally. Further, in dispar<tei:lb/>the clypeus is not distinctly differentiated from the face except by a change in sculpture; in<tei:lb/>quadridentata the clypeus is distinguishable from the face by a fold. The medial apical tooth of<tei:lb/>the clypeus is always long and pointed in dispar, less so in quadridentata.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster quadridentata Wesmael<tei:lb/>(Figs 60, 62, 63, 64)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster quadridentata Wesmael, 1835: 237. Lectotype $, BELGIUM: Brussels, colln Wesmael (IRSNB),</tei:p>
         <tei:p>designated by Shaw, (1984) [examined].<tei:lb/>Chelonus impressus Herrich-Schaffer, 1838: 153. Syntypes, GERMANY (lost). [Synonymised by Reinhard,</tei:p>
         <tei:p>1867: 367.]<tei:lb/>Ascogaster nigricornis Thomson, 1892: 1719. LECTOTYPE $, SWEDEN: Thomson colln (ZI), here</tei:p>
         <tei:p>designated [examined]. Syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster cynipum Thomson, 1892: 1720. Holotype cf , SWEDEN: Thomson colln (ZI) [examined]. Syn.n.<tei:lb/>Ascogaster egregius Kokujev, 1895: 83. Holotype cf , U.S.S.R. (AS) [examined]. Syn. n.<tei:lb/>Chelonus nigrator Szepligeti, 1896: 303. Holotype $, YUGOSLAVIA: Buccari, 16.viii.1889 (Biro) (HNHM)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>[examined]. Syn. n.<tei:lb/>Ascogaster epinotiae Watanabe, 1937: 76. Holotype $, JAPAN: Hokkaido, Sapporo, 14.vii.1927 (Uchida)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(UEI) [examined]. Syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Wesmael (1835: 239) described quadridentata from five males and two females. Seven specimens<tei:lb/>in his collection bear the label 'Ascogaster quadridentata mini', agree with the original<tei:lb/>description and are conspecific.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Reinhard examined Herrich-Schaffer's original material of Chelonus impressus and his<tei:lb/>placement of this species in synonymy with quadridentata is therefore accepted.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Three specimens (1 cT, 2 9) are in Thomson's collection above the name nigricornis', they are<tei:lb/>probably conspecific but the male and one of the females are in poor condition and are not<tei:lb/>readily identifiable. I designate as lectotype the better-preserved female, labelled 'type' by<tei:lb/>Graham. It agrees precisely with Thomson's description and is within the limits of variation of<tei:lb/>quadridentata.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The holotype of Chelonus nigrator Szepligeti bears a label with the data cited in the<tei:lb/>description and is within the limits of variation of quadridentata. The holotype of epinotiae<tei:lb/>Watanabe is smaller than average for quadridentata but is within the limits of variation of that<tei:lb/>species.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>One male in the collection of the AS, Leningrad agrees precisely with what Kokujev wrote<tei:lb/>about egregius, is labelled 'Asc. egregius m.' in Kokujev's handwriting and is here accepted as<tei:lb/>the holotype. It comes within the limits of variation of quadridentata.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$. Antenna long, 29-33 segmented. Flagellum slightly dilated medially, weakly tapered to apex, medial<tei:lb/>flagellar segments at most slightly longer than broad, generally slightly broader than long. Head rounded</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE PALAEARCTIC SPECIES OF ASCOGASTER 377</tei:p>
         <tei:p>behind eyes. Temple contracted (more strongly so in smaller specimens); about equal in length to eye in<tei:lb/>dorsal view. Occiput moderately concave. Frons slightly excavate behind eyes, generally strongly rugose.<tei:lb/>Vertex rugose, sometimes reticulate-rugose. Ocelli on line, OO = 3-0-3-5 OD. Eyes fairly large, not<tei:lb/>protuberant. Malar space about half height of eye. Face protuberant, about twice as broad as high; finely<tei:lb/>irregularly rugose, occasionally almost reticulate, with a small medial tubercle on the upper part of face, a<tei:lb/>fine carina extending from this to the anterior ocellus. Clypeus about half breadth of face, not strongly<tei:lb/>protuberant; polished, punctate except sometimes rugose laterally, apical border produced medially to a<tei:lb/>point and often with a small but distinct dentate tubercle. Mandibles moderately twisted, always with a<tei:lb/>small dentate flange formed at the junction of hypostomal and genal carinae, projecting beneath the base<tei:lb/>of the mandible. Pronotum projecting slightly in front of mesonotum; strongly rugose-reticulate laterally.<tei:lb/>Notaulices rather indistinct, obscured by the strong reticulate-rugose sculpture of mesonotum though deep<tei:lb/>and easily seen under oblique illumination. Precoxal suture likewise obscured; mesopleuron completely<tei:lb/>coarsely reticulate-rugose except random small areas smooth, punctate. Propodeum coarsely regularly<tei:lb/>reticulate-rugose with a medial transverse carina raised into a medial pair and a lateral pair of prominent<tei:lb/>dentate flanges. Carapace oval, generally laterally compressed posteriorly so that it appears sharply<tei:lb/>pointed in dorsal view, sometimes the point is produced into a tubercle, particularly in specimens of smaller<tei:lb/>than average size, in larger specimens the apex is often rounded, not pointed in dorsal view; posteroventral<tei:lb/>rim distinctly in front of apex. In some specimens, particularly those of smaller than average size, the<tei:lb/>carapace narrower in dorsal view and flatter. Hind coxa always strongly transversely striate-rugose.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour black, antenna at base brown or testaceous, mandibles brown, base of femur and tibia of foreleg,<tei:lb/>base of tibia of midleg and base of tibia of hind leg testaceous. Sometimes legs more extensively testaceous,<tei:lb/>in the lightest specimens only hind coxa black and mid and hind legs only lightly infuscate in the areas which<tei:lb/>are normally dark. Occasional specimens have a small pale mark at base of carapace on its lateral border<tei:lb/>but it is always diffuse.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf . Same as $ except antenna longer, flagellum not dilated medially, all flagellar segments longer than<tei:lb/>broad.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>130 Cf, 121 $. Belgium, Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, France, Germany, Great Britain, Greece, Hungary,<tei:lb/>Italy, Japan, Netherlands, Sweden, Turkey, U.S.S.R., Yugoslavia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOSTS. Cydia pomonella (L.), Cydia funebrana (Treitschke), Cydia pallifrontana (Lienig &amp;<tei:lb/>Zeller), Epiblema uddmanniana (L.), Spilonota ocellana (Denis &amp; Schiffermiiller) (Lepidop-<tei:lb/>tera: Tortricidae). Yponomeuta padella (L.) (Lepidoptera: Yponomeutidae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. It has been common practice for any specimen of Ascogaster with prominent flanges<tei:lb/>on the propodeum to be identified as quadridentata; this characteristic, however, is possessed by<tei:lb/>many species in the quadridentata- and bidentula- groups so it is not a reliable means of<tei:lb/>discriminating quadridentata. A. quadridentata is a common and widespread Holarctic species,<tei:lb/>rather variable in colour, size and certain other characteristics, probably because of its many<tei:lb/>host species. The smaller specimens tend to be darker in colour, more slender-bodied, with a<tei:lb/>prominent apical tubercle on the carapace, more coarsely sculptured and with shorter temples;<tei:lb/>Watanabe (1937) described the small form of quadridentata as epinotiae. I am convinced that<tei:lb/>these differences are infraspecific, resulting from the small size. The characteristics cited above<tei:lb/>occur sporadically in otherwise typical quadridentata and in small specimens, one or more of the<tei:lb/>differentiating characteristics is often of the normal quadridentata form. There is therefore no<tei:lb/>combination of characteristics by which the small form can be maintained as a distinct species.<tei:lb/>Larger specimens are stouter in build, the carapace generally more rounded apically and the<tei:lb/>head relatively more massive; they bear a close resemblance to scabricula. A. quadridentata also<tei:lb/>has a superficial resemblance to brevicornis (q.v.).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster reticulata Watanabe<tei:lb/>(Figs 61, 65, 66)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster reticulatus Watanabe, 1967: 41. Holotype cf [cited as $], JAPAN: Hokkaido, Asahigawa,<tei:lb/>15.vi.1966 (Kamijo) (UEI), [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Watanabe (1967: 42) confused the sexes of this species, describing the male as female and vice<tei:lb/>versa. The carapace of reticulata is very deep and the ventral opening short and it is therefore</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>378 T. HUDDLESTON</tei:p>
         <tei:p>difficult to examine the genitalia. Watanabe reasonably concluded that the specimens with the<tei:lb/>longer antennae were male, as is usual in Braconidae. In reticulata, however, as in several other<tei:lb/>species of Ascogaster, the converse is true.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$. Antenna long, 35-38 segmented. Flagellum weakly dilated medially, tapered to apex, two or three of<tei:lb/>medial segments about as long as broad, rest distinctly longer than broad. Head strongly contracted behind<tei:lb/>eyes. Temple about as long as eye in dorsal view or slightly shorter. Occiput moderately concave. Ocelli<tei:lb/>large, OO = 2-5 OD; on line. Eyes moderately large. Malar space about half height of eye. Face about 1-5<tei:lb/>times as broad as high, protuberant, coarsely irregularly rugose; a strong carina running from upper part of<tei:lb/>face between antennae to fore ocellus; ventral border of antennal scrobes produced, forming a flange<tei:lb/>which projects forwards and upwards from face. Clypeus not strongly protuberant, narrower than face;<tei:lb/>transversely depressed in apical half, strongly punctate, matt, apical border almost flat without any trace of<tei:lb/>tooth or tubercle. Mandible fairly stout, slightly twisted. Pronotum projecting slightly in front of<tei:lb/>mesonotum, coarsely irregularly rugose laterally. Notaulices indistinct, foveolate. Rest of mesonotum<tei:lb/>reticulate-rugose posteriorly and laterally; transversely rugose and foveolate anteromedially. Precoxal<tei:lb/>suture indistinct among strong reticulate-rugose sculpture of mesopleuron, ventrally mesopleuron general-<tei:lb/>ly punctate. Propodeum completely coarsely reticulate-rugose, divided by a medial transverse carina<tei:lb/>which is raised medially and laterally into prominent dentate flanges. Carapace short, deep; postero ventral<tei:lb/>rim conspicuously in front of apex so that ventral opening is only slightly more than two-thirds total length<tei:lb/>of carapace. Hind coxa smooth punctate; basitarsus of hindleg with a ventral longitudinal keel bearing a<tei:lb/>row of short, stout bristles on its edge and with a row of long, erect bristles on either side.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour black; antenna at base, mandible, palps testaceous; foreleg testaceous except tarsus infuscate,<tei:lb/>midleg testaceous except tibia at apex and tarsus infuscate, hindleg testaceous except base of coxa, apex of<tei:lb/>femur, tibia and tarsus more or less heavily infuscate but tibia with an ivory or pale yellow medial band.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf . Same as $ except antenna shorter, 32-34 segmented, flagellum barely dilated medially and weakly<tei:lb/>tapered to apex.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>7 cf , 6 . Czechoslovakia: 4 cf, 4 $ , Banska Stiavnica (Capek) (CC; BMNH); 1 cT, Klak, 1959 (Capek)<tei:lb/>(CC); 1 $, Kajlovka, 1962 (Capek) (CC). Japan: holotype cf; 1 Of, 1 $ (paratypes), same data as<tei:lb/>holotype.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOSTS. Adoxophyes orana (Fischer von Roslerstamm), Archips issikii Kodama, Archips<tei:lb/>oporana (L.), Archips pulchra (Butler) (Lepidoptera: Tortricidae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. The exceptionally short, deep carapace of this species is most distinctive and is only<tei:lb/>likely to be confused with that of varipes from which reticulata is easily distinguished by its<tei:lb/>strongly, irregularly rugose face and smooth, punctate hind coxae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I have examined one specimen from Korea (Yeson (Paik) (RNH)), reared from an apple<tei:lb/>leafroller (probably Adoxophes orana), that is probably conspecific with reticulata although it<tei:lb/>has a coarsely reticulate-rugose face, the carapace yellow at the base and the legs lighter in<tei:lb/>colour.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster rufipes (Latreille)<tei:lb/>(Figs 69, 77-79)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Sigalphus rufipes Latreille, 1809: 14. Syntypes, FRANCE (lost).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Sigalphus elegans Nees von Esenbeck, 1816: 264. Type-material, GERMANY (lost). [Synonymised by</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Thomson, 1892: 1716.]<tei:lb/>Chelonus fasciatus Dahlbom, 1833: 163. LECTOTYPE $, SWEDEN (ZI), here designated [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>[Synonymised by Thomson, 1874: 583.]<tei:lb/>Ascogaster ratzeburgii Marshall, 1885: 146. Holotype cf, GREAT BRITAIN: Norfolk, Brundall, 3.vii.l881</tei:p>
         <tei:p>(Bridgman) (NCM) [examined]. Syn. n.<tei:lb/>Ascogaster soror Telenga, 1941: 324. Lectotype cf, U.S.S.R.: 'Sinelnikovo', vi.1930 (AS) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>[Lectotype selected by Tobias.] Syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>I have not been able to locate Latreille's specimens of rufipes and the description of the species is<tei:lb/>insufficient for it to be identified with certainty. Several interpretations of the name have been<tei:lb/>used and this has led to some confusion. Thomson's (1892: 1716) remarks upon rufipes cleared<tei:lb/>away some of the confusion, showing that Nees von Esenbeck's intrepretation of rufipes was</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>THE PALAEARCTIC SPECIES OF ASCOGASTER 379</tei:p>
         <tei:p>incorrect. Thomson put forward his own interpretation of rufipes and so tactitly rejected that of<tei:lb/>Reinhard (1867: 365) who regarded rufipes and bidentula as conspecific. It is clear from his<tei:lb/>description that he had identified Wesmael's species correctly, but I cannot accept that bidentula<tei:lb/>fits Latreille's description of rufipes and so reject Reinhard's interpretation and follow Thom-<tei:lb/>son's. Nees von Esenbeck's description of elegans fits perfectly well with Thomson's interpreta-<tei:lb/>tion of rufipes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Four specimens are named fasciatus in the Fallen collection. Two are conspecific and one<tei:lb/>bears a label 'C. fasciatus Dbm var a' in Dahlbom's handwriting; I designate this specimen as<tei:lb/>lectotype. The third specimen bearing a small label 'var b' in Dahlbom's handwriting belongs to<tei:lb/>varipes and the fourth bearing the label 'var c' in Dahlbom's handwriting is a male abdominator.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>TTie holotype of ratzeburgii comes well within the limits of variation of rufipes. The lectotype<tei:lb/>of soror has three labels, one bearing the data published by Telenga, a second in Telenga's<tei:lb/>handwriting, 'Ascogaster soror sp.n. cf' and a third bearing Tobias' lectotype designation<tei:lb/>(though I have not been able to find where, or whether this was published); soror comes well<tei:lb/>within the limits of variation of rufipes.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>9 . Antenna 34-37 segmented. Flagellum generally slightly broader medially than at base, then tapering to<tei:lb/>apex, most segments longer than broad, a few medial segments about as long as broad. Head slightly<tei:lb/>expanded behind eyes, then roundly contracted. Temple about 1-5 times length of eye in dorsal view.<tei:lb/>Occiput strongly concave. Frons behind antennae excavate. Ocelli small, OO = 3-5 OD; ocellar triangle<tei:lb/>obtuse, ocelli almost on line. Weak carina extends from upper part of face to fore ocellus. Eyes not<tei:lb/>protuberant. Genae in face view rounded. Face protuberant, about twice as broad as high, reticulate-<tei:lb/>rugose. Clypeus weakly protuberant; smooth, punctate; apical border produced medially into a large<tei:lb/>dentate tubercle. Mandibles short, stout, moderately twisted. Pronotum projecting distinctly in front of<tei:lb/>mesonotum, laterally completely rugose except for a polished medial area. Mesonotum almost completely<tei:lb/>strongly reticulate-rugose except sometimes a small punctate area laterally. Notaulices indistinguishable.<tei:lb/>Precoxal suture indistinguishable, almost all mesopleuron strongly reticulate-foveolate. Propodeum<tei:lb/>completely regularly reticulate- rugose, divided by a medial transverse carina which is raised into strong<tei:lb/>flanges laterally and weak ones medially; dorsal surface rather long. Carapace rather long and narrow,<tei:lb/>coarsely reticulate-rugose, the longitudinal element predominant, expecially anteriorly; posteroventral<tei:lb/>rim not reaching apex of carapace. Hypopygium short. Ovipositor short, straight, abruptly narrowed<tei:lb/>shortly before apex. Ovipositor sheaths thick. Hind coxa polished, punctate, with fine transverse rugae<tei:lb/>dorsally.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour black, apical border of clypeus often rufous, mandibles at base testaceous; carapace at base<tei:lb/>yellow for slightly more than a third of its length; legs yellow or testaceous except all tarsi generally<tei:lb/>infuscate, at least in part, hind coxa at base and mid and hind tibiae often also infuscate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>C?. Same as 9 except antenna 32-35 segmented; carapace longer, narrower, always completely dark;<tei:lb/>legs generally darker.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>MATERIAL EXAMINED</tei:p>
         <tei:p>91 cf, 39 9- Czechoslovakia, France, Great Britain, Hungary, Ireland, Netherlands, Spain, Sweden,<tei:lb/>U.S.S.R., Yugoslavia.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>HOSTS. No reared material examined.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>REMARKS. Smaller and more delicate than most other species in the quadridentata-group; only<tei:lb/>brevicornis and the smaller specimens of quadridentata are of comparable size. A. rufipes also<tei:lb/>exhibits more sexual dimorphism than others in the quadridentata-group; it was Marshall's<tei:lb/>failure to appreciate this which led him to describe the male of rufipes as a distinct species even<tei:lb/>though he collected it with the female (for which he used the name elegans).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster scabricula (Dahlbom)<tei:lb/>(Figs 68, 71, 74-76)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Chelonus scabriculus Dahlbom, 1833: 166. LECTOTYPE $ , SWEDEN: Fallen colln (ZI), here designated</tei:p>
         <tei:p>[examined].<tei:lb/>Ascogaster limitatus Wesmael, 1838: 163. LECTOTYPE $, BELGIUM: Wesmael colln (IRSNB), here</tei:p>
         <tei:p>designated [examined]. Syn. n.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Ascogaster clypealis Thomson, 1892: 1719. LECTOTYPE $, SWEDEN: Oland, Thomson colln (ZI), here<tei:lb/>designated [examined]. Syn. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Four specimens in Fallen's collection are named scabriculus; I designate as lectotype the<tei:lb/>specimen labelled 'C. scabriculus Dbm. var. a' in Dahlbom's handwriting. It agrees with<tei:lb/>Dahlbom's description of 'scabriculus var. a' and is labelled 'cf' although I believe it to be 9-<tei:lb/>The other three specimens belong each to a different species; the only one which bears a label in<tei:lb/>Dahlbom's handwriting 'var. c' belongs to rufidens. Fahringer (1934: 544) synonymised scabri-<tei:lb/>cula with similis which, from his description he obviously interpreted as being conspecific with<tei:lb/>brevicornis', I reject this placement of scabricula. Wesmael (1838: 164) stated that he had<tei:lb/>examined two specimens of limitatus. In Wesmael's collection there is one specimen labelled<tei:lb/>'Ascogaster limitatus mini'; it agrees precisely with Wesmael's description and I accept it as a<tei:lb/>syntype. Wesmael gave the number of antennal segments as 33; in the material I have examined<tei:lb/>the number ranges from 30-32.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Three females (one without a head) are above the name clypealis in Thomson's collection;<tei:lb/>they are conspecific and agree with the original description. I designate as lectotype the<tei:lb/>best-preserved female, which Graham labelled as type despite the presence on the pin of a label<tei:lb/>'4-dentatus' in Thomson's handwriting; the significance of such labels is discussed under<tei:lb/>canifrons.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>$. Antenna 30-32 segmented. Flagellum dilated medially, tapered to end, most segments in distal half<tei:lb/>quadrate, in proximal half longer than broad (only three or four at base as much as twice as long as broad).<tei:lb/>Head rounded, more or less expanded behind eyes. Temple about 1-5 times length of eye in dorsal view.<tei:lb/>Occiput strongly concave. Ocelli small, OO = 3-5 OD; almost on line. Frons behind antennae slightly<tei:lb/>excavate, strongly rugose. Eyes small, not protuberant. Face protuberant, about twice as broad as high,<tei:lb/>completely regularly reticulate-rugose, divided from clypeus by a deep furrow. Anterior tentorial pits<tei:lb/>deep. Clypeus protuberant, polished, densely punctate, but with some rugae laterally; apical border<tei:lb/>produced medially with no distinct tubercle. Mandible moderately twisted, densely punctate at base.<tei:lb/>Genal carina joining hypostomal carina at base of mandible, forming a small flange which projects beneath<tei:lb/>base of mandible. Pronotum projecting but little in front of mesonotum, completely coarsely rugose.<tei:lb/>Mesonotum broad, almost completely rugose, the notaulices more or less indistinguishable. Mesopleuron<tei:lb/>completely coarsely reticulate-rugose, precoxal suture indistinguishable. Propodeum divided into dorsal<tei:lb/>and posterior surfaces by a weak medial transverse carina which is raised into two low broad humps<tei:lb/>medially and into two strong flanges laterally; completely, regularly reticulate-rugose with no distinct<tei:lb/>carinae. Carapace rounded, about 1-5 times as long as broad, deep; posteroventral rim not significantly in<tei:lb/>front of apex. Hypopygium short. Ovipositor short, straight, thick at base, abruptly narrowed shortly<tei:lb/>before apex. Hind coxa punctate except dorsally transversely striate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Colour black, fore tibia pale, at least in part.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Cf. Same as $ except posteroventral rim of carapace distinctly before apex; head more strongly<tei:lb/>contracted.</tei:p>

         <tei:p>Ascogaster contractus (Ratzeburg)<tei:lb/>Chelonus contractus Ratzeburg, 1848: 24. Syntypes, GERMANY (lost).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster dentiventris Telenga<tei:lb/>Ascogaster dentiventrisTelenga, 1941: 311. Syntypes, U.S.S.R. (lost).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster erythrothorax Marshall<tei:lb/>Chelonus erythrothorax Marshall, 1898: 171. Syntypes, FRANCE (lost).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster kabystanicus Tobias</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster kabystanicus Tobias, 1976: 235. Holotype cf, U.S.S.R.: Azerbaidzhan, 19. v. 1972 (Kasparyari)<tei:lb/>(AS) [examined] .</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This species belongs to the caucasica-group in which the males are extremely difficult to<tei:lb/>differentiate.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster lapponicus Thomson<tei:lb/>Ascogaster lapponicus Thomson, 1874: 588. Syntypes, SWEDEN (lost).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster pallidicornis Curtis<tei:lb/>Ascogaster pallidicornis Curtis, 1837: folio 672. Syntypes, GREAT BRITAIN (lost).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>One specimen named pallidicornis in Curtis's collection disagrees in most particulars with the<tei:lb/>original description and cannot therefore be a syntype.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster quadridens (Herrich-Schaffer)<tei:lb/>Chelonus quadridens Herrich-Schaffer, 1838: 154. Syntypes, GERMANY (lost).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>This species has been placed in synonymy with quadridentata but the latter never has pale marks<tei:lb/>at the base of the carapace as described for quadridens.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster rubripes (Lucas)<tei:lb/>Chelonus rubripes Lucas, 1849: 339. Syntypes, ALGERIA (lost).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster similis (Nees von Esenbeck)<tei:lb/>Chelonus similis Nees von Esenbeck, 1816: 262. Syntypes, GERMANY (lost).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster tersus Reinhard<tei:lb/>Ascogaster tersus Reinhard, 1865: 366. Syntypes, GERMANY (lost).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>One specimen named tersus in Reinhard's collection disagrees with the original description and<tei:lb/>cannot therefore be a syntype.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Excluded species</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Phanerotoma maculata (Wollaston ) comb. n.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Ascogaster maculata Wollaston, 1858: 24. Holotype $, MADEIRA (BMNH) [examined].</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Acknowledgements</tei:p>

         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>British Museum (Natural History)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Milkweed butterflies: their cladistics and biology</tei:p>
         <tei:p>P. R. Ackery &amp; R. I. Vane- Wright</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Danainae, a subfamily of the Nymphalidae, contains only some 150 species, yet aspects of<tei:lb/>their biology have stimulated far more attention than can be justified by species numbers<tei:lb/>alone. In recent years, an expansive literature has grown, considering aspects of their<tei:lb/>courtship and pre-courtship behaviour, migration, larval hostplant associations, mimicry and<tei:lb/>genetics. The popularity of danaines among biologists can certainly be attributed to this<tei:lb/>combination, within one small group, of so many of the factors that make butterflies such an<tei:lb/>interesting group to study. The obvious need to place this wealth of biological data within an<tei:lb/>acceptable systematic framework provided the impetus for this volume.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>Started eight years ago within the conventions of evolution by natural selection and<tei:lb/>Hennig's phylogenetic systematics, the book is now largely about natural history (what the<tei:lb/>animals have and do, where they live and how they develop) and natural groups - as revealed<tei:lb/>by a form of analysis approaching that practised by the new school of 'transformed cladistics'.<tei:lb/>The authors have prepared a handbook that will appeal to a wide range of biologists, from<tei:lb/>museum taxonomists to field ecologists.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>424 pp (approx.), 12 pp colour, 73 b/w plates, line and graphic illustrations, maps, extensive bibliography.<tei:lb/>ISBN 565 00893 5. Publication September 1984. Price 50.</tei:p>
         <tei:pb/>
      </tei:div>
      <tei:div>
         <tei:p>Titles to be published in Volume 49</tei:p>

         <tei:p>By D. Ragge &amp; W. J. Reynolds</tei:p>
         <tei:p>An historical review of the higher classification of the Noctuidae.</tei:p>
         <tei:p>By Ian Kitching</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Pimplinae, Xoridinae, Acaenitinae and Lycorininae (Hymenoptera: Ichneumonidae).</tei:p>
         <tei:p>By I. D.Gauld</tei:p>
         <tei:p>The Palaearctic species of Ascogaster (Hymenoptera: Braconidae)</tei:p>
         <tei:p>By T. Huddleston</tei:p>
